title: Review/Fashion; By Valentino, a Buoyant Look And 'Peace' in Silver Sequins
description: Valentino 's models sprinted down the runway at the Musee des Arts Decoratifs on Wednesday night as if they were race horses. They carried their meticulously beaded and appliqued clothes insouciantly, with the casual ease of sports clothes.

title: U.S.-British Talks End With No Aviation Pact
description: The latest round of talks aimed at fashioning a new civil aviation treaty between the United States and Britain ended angrily today after neither side would budge over five final demands by the British.

title: Extreme Cold Deepens Muscovites' Forebodings
description: The citizenry's sense of deja vu deepened today as a winter cold of the kind that has not been felt here for years throttled this hope-worn nation on the eve of tough new army policing powers and widely feared price rises.

title: Dodgers Get Valenzuela
description: Fernando Valenzuela got a raise to more than $2.5 million and Jim Gott and John Smiley became millionaires yesterday as the number of remaining salary arbitration cases dropped to 98.

title: Restrictions on War Photos
description: Out of concern for next of kin, the Pentagon has issued guidelines prohibiting photographers covering the war in the Persian Gulf from taking or transmitting pictures in which the faces of the wounded or dead might be recognizable. As a result, few if any photos of American casualties have been taken.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview SAUDIS RECAPTURE GHOST TOWN; ALLIES BOMB NEW IRAQI COLUMN; A 36-HOUR STRUGGLE
description: As Saudi troops backed by American marines drove Iraqi invaders from the deserted coastal town of Khafji near the Kuwaiti border today after a 36-hour struggle, allied bombers pounded a 10-mile Iraqi armored column apparently headed for Saudi Arabia.

title: Black History Month
description: Here is a sampling of events in the New York metropolitan area this weekend in celebration of Black History Month: TODAY "THE TRIALS OF MARCUS GARVEY -- MARCUS GARVEY THE MAN," a play by Titus Walker, presented by the Ujamaa Black Theater, Lincoln Square Theater, 250 West 65th Street, Manhattan, 8 P.M. Tickets, $25. Also tomorrow at 4 P.M., next Friday at 8 P.M. and Feb. 9 at 4 P.M. Information: (212) 642-8159.

title: Hogan Tour Graduate Leads at Pebble Beach
description: The Ben Hogan Tour gained a major dose of credibility today in the first round of the A.T.& T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am as three graduates from the PGA Tour's minor league proving ground took their places among the leaders.

title: Officer Cleared in Killing of Auto Thief
description: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday voted not to indict an off-duty rookie police officer who shot a 23-year-old man three times in the back while the man was stealing the officer's car, the authorities said.

title: Lotus Posts Its First Loss For a Quarter
description: The Lotus Development Corporation reported the first quarterly loss in its nine-year history today, dropping $31.6 million in contrast to a profit of $29.4 million, or 69 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Judge Clears Publication of Book On Iran-Contra by Ex-Prosecutor
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Penguin USA was free to publish a book by a former prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, over objections by the chief prosecutor that it would disclose secret grand jury materials and other information that could hinder continuing investigations.

title: 2D HOSTAGE KILLED BY COLOMBIAN RING
description: Officials said today that cocaine traffickers had killed the kidnapped sister of a former presidential aide who helped plan a large-scale anti-drug crackdown.

title: NCR Deadline For Meeting Set
description: The NCR Corporation took a step that forces it to hold a special shareholder meeting by May 29 to consider the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $6.1 billion hostile takeover offer. The computer maker announced it had set March 1 as the date of record for both the special meeting and its regular annual meeting. That means only those investors who own NCR shares on March 1 will be allowed to vote at the meetings.

title: Plan Signals a Shift by Nuclear Industry
description: In the most explicit signs yet that the nation's nuclear weapons industry is shifting its mission from producing nuclear warheads to restoring the environment, the Department of Energy has decided to close a reactor in South Carolina, to curtail plans for new weapons plants and to add money to its environmental programs.

title: Philip Morris to Enlarge Plant
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes and the world's largest packaged-goods company, expects to announce as early as today that it plans to spend $400 million to expand by nearly 50 percent the capacity of its cigarette factory in North Carolina.

title: Andersen & Lembke Says Billings Doubled
description: Andersen & Lembke, a small New York agency that is a unit of Chiat/ Day/Mojo, estimates that it doubled its billings this week by pulling in two multimillion-dollar accounts.

title: Household Finance 150 Million Issue
description: The Household Finance Corporation, a unit of Household International, yesterday priced through competitive bidding a $150 million issue of notes due in 1995.

title: Good Numbers for Nets (Except for Final Score)
description: Bill Fitch looked at the columns of numbers on the post-game statistics sheet tonight and seemed pleased. But it was still another loss in a week that was full of them.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Unfortunately, the best the wives can do now is just kind of wait for that telephone not to ring or for that military car not to appear in front of their homes." -- Linda Seymour, whose husband is a Marine sergeant. [ A9:1. ]

title: WAR IN THE GULF: China; Beijing Backs Away From Full Support of the War
description: While China was a partner of Western countries in the early stages of the Persian Gulf crisis, it has stepped back from the coalition since the fighting began and some diplomats worry that the split with the West could deepen.

title: Garden Revolt: King Cheered, Bianchi Jeered
description: Soon after Al Bianchi joined the Knicks as general manager in the summer of 1987, he let Bernard King get away. Last night, King helped make a bad Knick season even worse and the crowd at Madison Square Garden was chanting, "Al must go."

title: Lakers, Without Worthy, Extend Streak to 13 Games
description: A. C. Green, playing in place of James Worthy, had 20 points and 14 rebounds tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers won their 13th consecutive game, a 116-103 decision over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Brazil Freezes All Wages and Prices
description: The Brazilian Government indefinitely froze all wages and prices today in an effort to stop inflation, now running at 20 percent a month.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; U.S. Says Israel Is Signaling A Limit to Restraint on Iraq
description: While Israeli leaders are still inclined not to respond to Iraq's missile attacks, they have been signaling Washington that they cannot indefinitely absorb such strikes, particularly if Iraq uses a chemical warhead, American officials said today.

title: Some Super Bowl Heroes Might Be Cut Loose by the Giants
description: What do Ottis Anderson, Matt Bahr, Mark Bavaro, Perry Williams and Dave Duerson have in common? Two things:

title: Restaurants
description: When Petaluma opened to considerable fanfare in 1985, it was in the vanguard of what by now has become as commonplace as Madonna magazine covers: lofty, post-modern trattorias with open kitchens, brick pizza ovens and sizzling social scenes. New Yorkers were smitten by this diverting form of Italian dining, which was so different from the ceremonious Old World places they had been weaned on.

title: Robert W. Ponte, 46, Urban Planner, Dies
description: Robert W. Ponte, an urban planner who helped design major developments in New York City and Tehran, Iran, died on Jan. 17 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dinkins Yields to Council and Surrenders Bridge Data
description: The Dinkins administration avoided a confrontation with the City Council yesterday by turning over several boxes of documents sought by a Council committee that is investigating the safety of the city's bridges and by promising to provide any other information the committee wanted, Council officials said.

title: Death Toll From Smoking Is Worsening
description: More Americans are dying from smoking now more than 400,000 a year -- as the habits of the 1950's and 1960's take an increasing toll, Federal health officials said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Mesa Grill

title: Revitalized Millrose Games Seek to Rescue Sport's Image
description: A candy bar, of all things, is now the title sponsor of North America's most prestigious indoor track and field meet.

title: Xerox's Earnings Rise 11% On Strong Sales for Copiers
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that stronger-than-expected copier sales lifted fourth-quarter earnings 11 percent, overcoming a sharp decline in earnings from financial services.

title: Market Place; Investors Bid Up Retailing Stocks
description: IN an odd offshoot of the Persian Gulf conflict, investors have been bidding up the stocks of retail companies, even though consumers seem so caught up in the war news that they are not doing much shopping.

title: NBC Decides to Allow L.A. Gear Commercial
description: NBC, which said Monday that it would not broadcast a 30-second spot for L.A. Gear's new Catapult sneaker, reversed its decision yesterday and agreed to carry the commercial.

title: Tonka Accepts Offer From Hasbro
description: Last year's disastrous Christmas sales season claimed its first big victim yesterday. The Tonka Corporation, the nation's third-largest toy company, agreed to be acquired by Hasbro Inc. for about $516 million.

title: Union Oil Notes
description: Union Oil of California, a unit of the Unocal Corporation, is offering $250 million in senior notes due in 2003 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. The notes, with a 9 1/4 percent coupon, are priced at 99.214 to yield 9.36 percent, or about 133 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Noncallable for life, the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.

title: Cuomo: Tough Talk for Hard Times
description: As the opening move in Albany's annual budget tournament, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget proposal gave him a quick tactical advantage. It makes him look like a tough leader in times that seem to demand hard decisions. And it boxes state lawmakers in, forcing them to choose openly between two politically unpalatable options: raising more taxes or slicing programs sacred to their constituents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIE NELSON has a new satellite television venture that he announced yesterday, the same day the Internal Revenue Service auctioned his Colorado ranch for $650,000. Mr. Nelson owes the I.R.S. $16.7 million in back taxes.

title: Wheaties Makes a Small Giant Error
description: Wheaties may be "the Breakfast of Champions," but when it came to designing a box honoring the National Football League champion Giants, the folks at General Mills didn't pay too much attention to which Giants actually played in the Super Bowl championship.

title: December Farm Prices Up
description: Prices farmers get for raw products increased by seven-tenths of a percent from December to January, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques Surprise Sabres, 4-1 Jacques Cloutier, starting his first game for Quebec, made 35 saves last night as the Nordiques beat the Sabres in Buffalo. Cloutier, a former Sabre who was traded to the Nordiques earlier this week by the Chicago Blackhawks for Tony McKegney, came up big time after time. The victory ended a streak without a victory at five games for the Nordiques, who are tied with Toronto at the bottom of the overall league standing. In that span, Quebec had just one tie. The Sabres have lost four in a row. (AP) Bruins 5, Canadiens 2: Ray Bourque broke a tie with a power-play goal early in the second period, and Cam Neely and Dave Poulin added third-period goals for Boston in the Bruins' fourth consecutive victory. Boston increased its Adams Division lead over Montreal to 5 points with its second victory over the Canadiens in a week. Andy Moog, the goalie, earned his 21st victory of the season, fourth in a row and eighth in the last nine starts with relief help from Matt DelGuidice midway through the third period. DelGuidice made his National Hockey League debut at the same time as Montreal's Frederic Chabot, who replaced Andre Racicot after Boston went ahead, 5-2. (AP) Flyers 4, Penguins 2: Ron Sutter scored twice as Philadelphia ended Pittsburgh's winning streak at four games. The Flyers, who have won five consecutive home games, have won four of five over Pittsburgh. The victory lifted the Flyers into second place in the Patrick Division, a point ahead of Pittsburgh. (AP) Blues 4, Whalers 3: Rod Brind'Amour circled the net and scored his second goal of the game from the slot with 4:05 left in overtime for St. Louis at home. It was the Blues' second overtime victory in three games and gave Coach Brian Sutter his 100th victory in his third season with St. Louis. The Blues, who have won four in a row, also beat Detroit, 5-4, in overtime on Saturday. On the game-winner, Steve Tuttle fed the puck to Brind'Amour, who skated around the net and beat Daryl Reaugh with a quick shot. Tuttle had a goal and three assists for his first points of the season. (AP) SKIING Combined Event to Swiss Woman Chantal Bournissen of Switzerland won the women's combined event at the world Alpine championships in Saalbach-Hinterglemm, Austria, yesterday as Sabine Ginther fell near the bottom of the second slalom run. Ingrid Stoeckl of Austria won the silver medal and Vreni Schneider of Switzerland captured the bronze by posting the fastest time in the slalom yesterday. (AP) TENNIS Seles Withdraws in Tokyo A recurring shoulder injury forced Monica Seles out of the Toray Pan Pacific Open yesterday in Tokyo. A doctor at a hospital where she went for treatment diagnosed the injury as a rotator cuff strain and recommended a two-week break from tennis for the Australian Open champion. Kathy Rinaldi, Seles's scheduled opponent, beat a last-minute substitute, Yukie Koizumi of Japan, 7-5, 6-2. Martina Navratilova, playing her first tournament since knee surgery in October, defeated Jo Durie of Britain, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2, in a 1-hour-32-minute match on the artificial surface of Tokyo Metropolitan Gym. (AP) GOLF Mochrie Takes First Round Dottie Mochrie, who won the event in 1989, made four consecutive birdies on the front nine for a seven-under-par 65 yesterday and a one-stroke lead after the first round of the fog-hampered Ladies Professional Golf Association's Oldsmobile Classic in Lake Worth, Fla. Placing second with 66's over the par-72, 6,324-yard course at Wycliffe Golf and Country Club were Meg Mallon, Susan Sanders and Judy Dickinson. (AP)

title: 3 Auto Makers In Battery Plan
description: The Big Three United States auto makers said they had formed a joint effort to share the costs of developing batteries for electric vehicles.

title: Review/Film; Big Decisions And Small Horizons In Queens
description: "Queens Logic" is one of those films that suppose important life decisions are best made in the company of old pals, preferably pals who have lived and loved together over a long period of time. In this and other descendants of "The Big Chill," contrivance demands that the friends reconvene on a ceremonial occasion. That event, in "Queens Logic," is the scheduled wedding of Ray (Ken Olin) and Patricia (Chloe Webb), who are acutely mismatched. These two bicker a lot, but the film's central love-hate relationship is the one between the borough of Queens and the rest of the world.

title: Campbell-Mithun-Esty
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Chicago, has been picked to handle the $2 million AmeriFlora '92 account. AmeriFlora will be a six-month event next year in Columbus, Ohio, celebrating the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas. The agency bested 13 others in a review. Stephen C. Zonars, AmeriFlora's marketing director, said, "Campbell-Mithun got the nod because of the extensiveness of their media plan."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Shock Waves; 70 TERRORIST ACTS OUTSIDE U.S. LISTED
description: A State Department official said today that about 70 acts of terrorism had been committed against American and allied interests outside the United States since the Persian Gulf war began, including 11 in the last day.

title: For Children
description: Children's Library Center

title: Auctions
description: The Wrists Have It

title: W. C. Matthews, 70, Advertising Executive
description: William Cary Matthews, an advertising executive and a former vice president of Foote, Cone and Belding in San Francisco, died Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 70 years old.

title: Moody's Lowers Allied-Signal Debt
description: Citing a weakening economic environment, Moody's Investors Service Inc. yesterday downgraded about $2 billion in debt issued by Allied-Signal Inc., a diversified company that manufacturers products for the aerospace and automotive industries.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. ROBERT RUNCIE, retired yesterday after 11 years as the spiritual head of the world's 70 million Anglicans. In his speech of resignation at a meeting of the Church of England's General Synod, Mr. Runcie, who is 69 years old, touched on his heartache over TERRY WAITE , his envoy, who was kidnapped in Lebanon in 1987 while trying to free Western hostages.

title: Better Results On Super Bowl
description: Many people who watched the Super Bowl on Sunday said they remembered the commercials, a telephone study conducted for a Milwaukee ad agency found.

title: Review/Theater; A Dead Jewish Mother And Layers of Guilt
description: Scratch nearly any ordinary male American playwright, and he'll bleed out an angry play about a hateful mother. But David Greenspan apparently aspires to be the Richard Wagner of the genre. Mr. Greenspan not only wrote and directed "Dead Mother," the matricidal comedy at the Public Theater, but he is also the evening's star, playing both a terribly sensitive son and the castrating Jewish mother who, metaphysically at least, returns from the dead to humiliate and torture him.

title: Illegal Procedure? He's Heard of That
description: No doubt thousands of lawyers fantasize about being a professional football coach. But how many coaches imagine, with longing, the lawyer's life?

title: Judge Approves Plan Blocking Deportation
description: A Federal district judge gave final approval today to a settlement that blocks deportation of up to 500,000 immigrants from El Salvador and Guatemala and allows them to reopen their cases seeking political asylum.

title: New York City School Panel Goes Public With Its Discord
description: A brief meeting of the New York City Board of Education to hire a lawyer turned into a bitter public dispute this week, exposing long-simmering political and personal differences.

title: At the Bar; A guide (in lawyers' words) to the Palookas and the Cardozos on the Federal bench.
description: One Federal judge in Manhattan is "unstable." Another is "unduly concerned with publicity." A third is "a kind of stumbler on the bench" and a fourth "talks as if he just come off the Bowery." As for a fifth, "You get the feeling that he's getting a little old, it's boring and he'd rather be out on the golf course."

title: Ohio State Is Handed First Loss by Mich. St.
description: Ohio State suffered its first loss of the season tonight as Steve Smith scored 26 points and Mark Montgomery added a career-high 17 to lead Michigan State to a 75-61 victory.

title: At the Movies
description: Hallstrom in America

title: Bundesbank Lifts 2 Key Interest Rates
description: Germany's central bank raised two leading interest rates today in a surprise move that is likely to slow global economic growth and further strain the country's relations with its main European trading partners.

title: Pan Am Is Sued Over Its Policy Barring Iraqis From Flights
description: An Iraqi who was granted political asylum in the United States filed suit yesterday against Pan American World Airways Inc. over the airline's new policy of barring Iraqi passengers from all flights, regardless of whether they pose a security threat.

title: Cab Passenger Pays, Then Sets Driver Afire
description: A medallion taxi driver suffered serious burns on his head and chest yesterday when a passenger getting out of the cab poured a flammable liquid on him and started a fire, the police said.

title: Combat, and Combative Reporters
description: Americans thirst for news about the Persian Gulf war. In recent days they have sat for hours in front of television screens and scoured newspapers for detail and analysis. Why, then, are so many people so ready to concede to the military the power to limit what they know?

title: If Times Are Tough, It's A Job For The Funnies!
description: IF you missed the "High and Low" show at the Museum of Modern Art, there is still time to catch Hi and Lois at the World Financial Center. These well-known comic marrieds are just 2 of more than 100 characters appearing in almost 50 original drawings and vintage printed pages representing some of America's greatest newspaper comic strips from 1896 to the present. They are on loan through Feb. 15 from the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, N.Y.

title: E.P.A. Is Said to Plan a Curb On Dirty Air at Grand Canyon
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to propose strict and expensive pollution controls on an Arizona electric power plant to curb dirty air over the Grand Canyon, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Gianettino & Merridith
description: Gianettino & Merridith, a small agency in Short Hills, N.J., has picked up several new accounts. Yesterday, the agency won the $8 million account for the Tri-State Chevrolet and Geo dealerships. Earlier in the week, it got the $1 million Hotel Bar butter business, owned by Borden Inc., and a $1 million account for Foster Wheeler, an engineering and construction company. The agency now has billings of about $83 million.

title: Some Who Help the Neediest Are Grateful for No Junk Mail
description: Besides wishing to help the poor, contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are often moved by a more mundane concern: a desire to be free of junk mail.

title: Peat Marwick Partner Cuts
description: KPMG Peat Marwick told its 1,876 partners in a memorandum yesterday that the accounting firm had come up with a list of 265 partners who would be terminated.

title: Steinberg Is Secretive on His Plans for Plan B
description: Dick Steinberg thought Super Bowl XXV was a very exciting game except for one thing: the Jets were not in it.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Israel Gets $670 Million in German Aid
description: German military-transport aircraft began landing at Ben-Gurion Airport tonight, delivering $670 million in German military aid.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Infiltration; Saudis Are Reported to Execute 6 As Terrorists Infiltrate From Iraq
description: Terrorists have begun infiltrating Saudi Arabia with orders from Baghdad to carry out assassinations and sabotage, officials with access to sensitive information say.

title: New U.S. Plan on Heart Surgery
description: In an attempt to staunch the escalating costs of health care, the Federal Government announced yesterday that it was about to test a new and less expensive way to pay for heart surgery.

title: America's Purpose in Gulf Is to Fight Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Kline May Sign On as Papp Aide

title: Following A Sweater To Springfield
description: After all the buses that failed to start, all the gym lights that suddenly went dark and all the whistles that broke his heart, Lou Carnesecca knew a bogus clock when he saw one.

title: John W. Holahan, 60, A Former Union Chief
description: John W. Holahan, who resigned two weeks ago as head of the union that represents custodians and custodian engineers in the New York City public school system, died on Tuesday in Bonita Springs, Fla., where he was visiting. He was 60 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Sears Seeking to Offer The Visa Credit Card
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which offers the Discover card besides its own Sears credit card, said it intends to market the Visa card as well if it wins a suit against Visa U.S.A.

title: 'Junk' Index Posts a Gain
description: The First Boston Corporation's index of high-yield "junk bonds" posted a 2.7 percent positive return in January, its best showing since July.

title: Review/Film; Oh, Those Silly Teen-Age Boys!
description: Robert Shaye's "Book of Love," which tells a story it says is "written in the heart of every horny teen-ager," is best appreciated by those with immense fondness for the embarrassments of the past. William Kotzwinkle, who has somehow fashioned a straightforward screenplay from his seemingly unfilmable novel "Jack in the Box," reveres every kitschy pop-cultural artifact in the life of his hero, Jack Twiller, and delights in every wishful presexual fiasco. Under Mr. Shaye's direction, this translates as ripe middle-aged nostalgia for the kinds of pranks that barely adolescent boys play on one another at sleepaway camp.

title: John Graham, Architect, 82, Dies; Designed Space Needle for Seattle
description: John Graham, an architect whose designs included the Space Needle for the 1962 World's Fair in Seattle, died Tuesday at Swedish Medical Center in Seattle. He was 82 years old and lived in Seattle and on Bainbridge Island in Puget Sound.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, maker of health-care and consumer products, signed a collaborative research and development agreement with the National Cancer Institute for the development of Taxol, a compound that has shown promising antitumor activity in several clinical trials. * Chrysler Corp. will lay off 101 workers at its New Process Gear plant in East Syracuse, N.Y., and shut the plant for a week beginning Feb. 18. * Du Pont Medical Products, a unit of E. I. Du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., sold three medical diagnostic businesses. * GE Plastics, a division of General Electric Co., Pittsburgh, and Kumho Petrochemical Co., South Korea, formed a 50-50 joint venture company, Kumho GE Chemicals Inc., in South Korea. The company will build and operate a 7,500-ton resin facility. * Kelso & Co., New York, a merchant banking firm, signed a deal with Magtek Partners and Champlain Associates, two of the original investors in Magnetek Inc., Los Angeles, a maker of electrical equipment, to buy up to 7.9 million common shares of Magnetek for $10 a share. * Loral Corp., New York, a maker of electronic systems, computers and microwave products, said it would complete the sale of 49 percent of Space Systems/Loral for $182 million to three international partners by the end of it its fiscal year, March 31.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Dade County Health Facilities Authority, in Florida, is offering $38.8 million in tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds for a Baptist Hospital of Miami project, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Interest rates range from 5.60 percent to 6.75 percent. Because the bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. they are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P. * Limited Inc. is offering $150 million in 9 1/8 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.29, to yield 9.235 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P. * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $250 million in senior unsecured debt securities. COMMON STOCK * Microwave Laboratories Inc., Raleigh, N.C., has filed for a rights offering to buy 2.5 million common shares at 30 cents each. RATINGS * Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co.'s long-term debt and commercial paper ratings are being reviewed for possible downgrading by S.& P. The tire marker is based in Akron, Ohio. * Horn & Hardart Co.'s senior subordinated debenture, convertible subordinated debenture and subordinated note rating has been lowered to B-3, from B-2, by Moody's. * Scandinavian Airlines System's debt is under review for possible downgrading by Moody's. S.A.S., a consortium owned by private and government companies from Denmark, Norway and Sweden, is based in Stockholm.

title: USX to Issue Stock Linked to Steel Unit
description: The USX Corporation may be preparing an exit from its traditional role as a steel producer. In a move viewed as a step in that direction, it said yesterday that its board had approved a plan to separate the company's vast energy business from its steel operations by issuing new common stock linked to its steel business.

title: Witt Switches Routine And Lands Smoothly
description: The Caribbean sun had done its job; Katarina Witt's face looked radiant, red and relaxed, as if she had just walked off the beach.

title: Violinist and Pianist
description: The violinist Joshua Bell and the pianist Stephen Hough are to perform Brahms's Sonata No. 2 in A (Op. 100), Schubert's Fantasy in C (D. 934), Arvo Part's "Fratres II" and Grieg's Sonata No. 3 (Op. 45) at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: While Connick's Away

title: WPIX Retains Yankee Games
description: WPIX-TV, an outlet for Yankee games for the last 40 years, has reached an agreement with Madison Square Garden Network to televise 50 to 55 Yankee games a year for the next three seasons. No terms were disclosed in the joint announcement yesterday.

title: Hard Times, Faced Squarely
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo always says his budgets are lean, but this year he's done more than say it. Faced with a deficit that could reach $6 billion, and an economy that has yet to hit bottom, he has put together a tough-minded spending plan. However painful, it could help New York through its worst economic trauma in decades, and in the process give Mr. Cuomo's national image a harder edge.

title: Moscow Studio Theater To Perform at Triplex
description: The Moscow Studio Theater, a repertory ensemble led by Oleg Tabakov, is to appear March 5 to 10 at the Triplex Theater in Manhattan in its six-week tour of the United States. The ensemble, which last appeared in New York in 1989 at the Public Theater, is to present two works in repertory: Aleksandr Galich's "My Big Land" and Aleksandr Buravsky's "Teacher in Russian." Both works will be performed in Russian; audience members may rent earphones for $2 each for simultaneous translations.

title: Lawyer's Charge of Courtroom Ban Is False
description: To the Editor:

title: Philadelphia Journal; Frank Rizzo Is Back, Making Waves (Again)
description: In the opening round of this year's cam paign for mayor, the Chamber of Commerce held a forum on Wednesday for the 10 candidates who have announced their desire to pilot this city out of its fiscal crisis. But the best-known of the 10, former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, was not there.

title: UAL Posts Big Deficit In Quarter
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $123.5 million and a record quarterly operating loss of $296.6 million.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; Clashes Increase Between Israelis And the P.L.O.
description: Rocket and artillery clashes between Israel and guerrillas grew today in southern Lebanon after the Palestine Liberation Organization fired dozens of missiles toward northern Israel and sent infiltrators toward Israel.

title: Westhead Brings Defamation Suit
description: Coach Paul Westhead of the Denver Nuggets, head coach at Loyola Marymount last season, filed a defamation suit in Philadelphia Common Pleas Court yesterday accusing an attorney for Hank Gathers's family of unfairly blaming him for the college player's death last March.

title: Apartheid Foes to Rally At Parliament Opening
description: The African National Congress and its allies have called on supporters to stay away from work and join large demonstrations on Friday to protest the opening of Parliament, from which South Africa's black majority remains excluded.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: War Summary
description: IRAQI BUILDUP Allied pilots said they were attacking a line of 800 to 1,000 Iraqi military vehicles moving toward Saudi Arabia. Front-line United States Marine commanders reported that five or six Iraqi divisions, a force of some 60,000 troops, had gathered near Wafra in southern Kuwait, but senior allied officers discounted the possibility of an Iraqi attack on that scale. BATTLE FOR KHAFJI After 30 hours of artillery, tank and small arms fire, the allies claimed that they had driven four Iraqi battalions out of the Saudi coastal town of Khafji. Saudi and Qatari troops backed by American marines reportedly inflicted heavy casualties, taking 161 prisoners and destroying 42 tanks and 35 other vehicles. The allied commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, played down the significance of the battle, calling it "about as significant as a mosquito on an elephant." WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon listed 11 marines - one less than reported by the United States command on Wednesday - killed in ground combat; 10 other Americans were listed an non-combat deaths. Seven other American, eight Britons and one Italian were listed as missing in action. Eight Americans, two Britons, one Italian and one Kuwaiti were listed as prisoners of war. Iraq gave no estimate of allied casualties, but said it held more than 20 prisoners. Aircraft: The allies listed 18 planes - 11 American, five British, one Kuwaiti and one Italian - as lost in combat; 5 other planes and 3 American helicopters were reported lost to noncombat causes. Iraq said more than 180 allied aircraft had been downed. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq has reported 90 soldiers and 320 civilians killed and 400 wounded. The allied command, which has not given estimates of Iraqi casualties, said it has taken about 290 Iraqi prisoners. Aircraft: The American command reported 55 Iraqi planes destroyed in the air and on the ground. Iraq gave no estimate of its air losses. Navy: Sixty Iraqi ships have been sunk or badly damaged. Iraq gave no estimate of its naval losses.

title: Economic Scene; Barriers to Ending The Credit Crunch
description: IN his State of the Union Message, President Bush jawboned the banks and the Federal Reserve. "Sound banks should be making more sound loans," he said. "And interest rates should be lower, now."

title: Calendar Tricks Won't Fix N.Y. Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCO in Japan Minimarket Plan
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the Los Angeles-based oil company known as ARCO, said it would buy a 25 percent stake in AM-PM Japan, an operator of 26 minimarkets in Japan owned by the Kyodo Oil Company. It said the venture plans to have 100 minimarkets, which sell food and gasoline, by the end of the year.

title: Big Profit Gains at Lilly and Johnson & Johnson
description: Helped by the dollar's weakness overseas, Eli Lilly and Johnson & Johnson yesterday reported strong growth in quarterly earnings and sales. But Lilly, which had led the drug industry in earnings gains earlier in 1990, disappointed some analysts in the final quarter.

title: Review/Film; Insects With an Ecological Mission
description: By the time it finally ends, "Meet the Applegates" has the limp manner of a five-minute "Saturday Night Live" sketch that has been stretched to the length of a feature film, which is well beyond the snap-back point.

title: Founder Plans to Retire At Spaghetti Warehouse
description: Robert R. Hawk entered the restaurant business in 1972 with a venture that started out as a side investment. "It was the case of a blind hog stumbling into the sour mash," he said yesterday, proud of the 17-restaurant chain he has built into Spaghetti Warehouse Inc.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Budget Numbers Are Cut and People Bleed
description: Easily obscured by the New York State budget's antiseptic ledger of numbers -- the $6 billion gap, the $4.5 billion in cuts -- were flesh-and-blood New Yorkers who felt real anguish today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iran; A Top Iraqi Envoy Visits Teheran, and Is Told Planes Will Be Held
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran criticized a high Iraqi official visiting Teheran yesterday for allowing nearly 100 aircraft to fly into his country without permission and said the planes would be detained until the Persian Gulf war is over, the Iranian press agency reported.

title: U.N. Council Declines To Debate Cease-Fire
description: The United Nations Security Council today resisted an attempt to force a public debate on a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Denys Sutton, 73, an Art Critic, Editor and Curator of Exhibitions
description: Denys Sutton, an art critic, historian and editor who was a brisk and contentious figure on the international art scene for more than 40 years, died Wednesday at his home in London. He was 73 years old.

title: Company's Chairman Says Expertise Alone Won Contracts
description: The chairman of the Kentucky company being investigated in connection with its extensive water-meter installation work for New York City portrayed the company today as a highly efficient and knowledgeable competitor that was willing to endure financial hardships to win New York's business.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Staff Sergeant's 'General Store': A Scrounger's Heaven
description: Scrounging -- the acquisition of necessities and niceties the system forgot to provide -- is a time-honored practice in all armies, but at a forward logistics base, National Guardsmen, weekend warriors abruptly summoned to these sands, have raised it to an art form.

title: Brandeis Broke Ground on Privacy Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Bailout Money Is Threatened
description: Members of New England's Congressional delegation threatened today to block new spending for the savings and loan bailout until the Bush Administration comes forward with a plan to ease the credit crunch.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Formosa Cafe in West Hollywood, Calif., incorrectly summarized the ownership history of Warner Hollywood Studios, which is seeking to have the restaurant demolished. The studio was built in 1919 as the Jesse D. Hampton Studios. It was taken over by United Artists in 1928 and acquired by the Samuel Goldwyn Studios in 1938. Warner bought it in 1980.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; MORE AIR ATTACKS ON ROAD TO JORDAN
description: Travelers arriving across the cold and windswept desert from Iraq today reported an increase in allied attacks on the highway leading west to Jordan and said they had seen bodies on the roadside after warplanes bombed and strafed trucks, buses and civilian cars.

title: Bush Proposes More Anti-Drug Spending
description: President Bush declared today that while the nation was making unmistakeable progress against illegal drugs, much more remained to be done, and he called for an 11 percent increase in Federal spending to expand the drug war.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Offbeat Benefit for a Place That Benefits the Offbeat
description: The annual benefit for Performance Space 122, which runs for two shows a night through tomorrow, works on a series of levels. For starters, it functions as a sort of travelogue through what's left of bohemian New York. The 36 or so acts over the next two days range from a ukulele ensemble to Allen Ginsberg to the young guitarist Marc Ribot to the performance artist Paul Zaloom to the dancers Yvonne Meier and Jennifer Monson.

title: Too Clever by Half
description: The United States says that the decision to postpone the Moscow summit meeting had nothing to do with Mikhail Gorbachev's use of force to throttle the Baltic nations.

title: Dubious Justice in Israel
description: Under cover of a genuine war scare in Israel, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing coalition is promoting a spy scare that smells. Sari Nusseibeh, a prominent West Bank Palestinian, was arrested Tuesday for allegedly informing Iraqi targeters where Scud missiles had landed -- a grave charge if true. Mr. Nusseibeh, who denies doing any such thing, was given a six-month sentence without any trial or formal charges. That looks less like justice than a vendetta.

title: U.S. Securities Up; Trading Slow
description: As it had promised on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve yesterday added huge reserves to the banking system as a way of offsetting its rising cash balances. But that did little to excite participants in the credit market, who were more interested in the employment numbers for January that the Labor Department will release this morning.

title: Richter Misses 3 Shots, But Oh Those 59 Saves!
description: When the first-place Rangers visited the lowly Canucks at Pacific Coliseum tonight, they were matched against a weary, last-place team on a losing streak.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARK LEE and DR. JAN DAVIS may become the first married couple in space. The astronauts, who were assigned a year and a half ago to a -Spacelab scientific research mission scheduled for September 1992, were married about a month ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A8-11

title: A.T.&T. in Pact On Cable Ships
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its two new cable-laying ships would fly the United States flag. The nation's largest long-distance company also said it had reached a five-year agreement with the two unions that represent its maritime employees. The agreement covers manning, wages and working conditions on A.T.&T.'s cable ships.

title: Accounts
description: * Reuters Information Services, a division of Reuters Holding P.L.C., to Goldsmith/Jeffrey, New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Roche Brothers Supermarkets, Needham, Mass., a chain of grocery stores, to Mariani, Hurley & Chandler Advertising Inc., Providence, R.I. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Haitian Rhythms

title: Pool: It's on a Run
description: IT should not be said that pool playing is back in vogue, for a game more than a century old clearly exists outside of trends and fashion. One visit to Julian's, the oldest pool hall in Manhattan, will testify that the game's seamy grandeur has survived into the video age and shows no signs of waning. Even the newer, more luxurious halls like Corner Billiards or Amsterdam retain a tinge of outlaw glamour. Pool is a sport for those who prefer mental to physical exertion; for a recreational afternoon, it is a friendly competition that requires an abundance of enthusiasm more than skill.

title: Two New Governors Offer Plans to Trim Deficits
description: The new Governors of Massachusetts and Rhode Island presented their first budgets to the states' lawmakers today, taking painful steps that they said would eliminate projected deficits that are among the worst in the country.

title: Bertolucci's Uncut Epic Of Class and Clash
description: THE raggedy boy who catches frogs and turns them into a live, wriggling wreath on the brim of his hat is called Olmo. He will grow up to be a Communist hero played by Gerard Depardieu, dubbed into English but still a volatile presence. The boy in the elegant white suit who roughhouses with Olmo is Alfredo, the landowner's grandson. Forced to eat those frogs for dinner, to his immense credit he cannot keep them down. As an adult, Alfredo is Robert De Niro, whose American accent adds an unsettling whiff of modernism to his role as the last padrone that their northern Italian village will know.

title: Review/Dance; Feld Opens With Sequel to a Success
description: Eliot Feld has so many ideas that his ballets, if placed end to end, would make for an unusually wide diapason of choreography. But within this range, he also tends to create works in compartmentalized phases.

title: John McIntire, 83; Was Wagonmaster On 'Wagon Train'
description: John McIntire, the character actor who portrayed the stolid, laconic wagonmaster in the hit television series "Wagon Train" in the early 1960's, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 83 years old and had a home in Laguna Beach, Calif., and a cattle ranch in northern Montana.

title: Judge Backs Gulf Use Of Unapproved Drugs
description: The military may require troops serving in the Persian Gulf to take unapproved drugs to protect against biological and germ warfare, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Review/Art; One Work Embodies a Place, an Artist and an Era
description: "Eastman Johnson: 'The Cranberry Harvest, Island of Nantucket' " is another of the strong arguments American museums are making for the value of the small exhibition devoted to a single work. The single work, "The Cranberry Harvest, Island of Nantucket," as well as 14 related studies and paintings documenting Eastman Johnson's struggle with narrative, composition, atmosphere and light, fit into one large room of the National Academy of Design. By zeroing in on this one harmonious and ambitious work, the exhibition brings to life an important artist and an entire artistic moment.

title: People
description: * Dan Ballard was named chairman of Earle Palmer Brown of Bethesda, Md. Mr. Ballard had been chief executive of Lawler Ballard until Earle Palmer Brown acquired the firm this week. Earle P. Brown will continue in the position of chairman/founder of the firm.

title: Groupe FCA Buys Bloom In Latest French-U.S. Deal
description: THE Bloom Agency, known for its ads for Scott Paper and Pentax cameras, was acquired yesterday by Groupe FCA, a French agency that creates advertising in Europe for clients like Nestle, L'Oreal and Bayer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRESIDENT BUSH said Wednesday that he intended to nominate ROBERT B. ZOELLICK as Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs, expanding the powers of an official who already is one of the most influential figures in the State Department.

title: Eagles Add a Coach
description: Jim Vechiarella, defensive coordinator last season for the Cleveland Browns, has been signed as linebacker coach by the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Critic's Choice
description: Skillful and persuasive young cellists seem to be coming along in great numbers. One is Yosif Feigelson, who emigrated from Latvia in 1981, led a quiet seven years in this country and then made successul recital and orchestra-soloist debuts at the 92d Street Y three years ago. In the second instance, he stepped in at short notice for the violinist Nathan Milstein, who had canceled because of illness.

title: Review/Film; On the Lam, The Lessons Harvard Law Didn't Teach
description: "Run," about a Harvard law student who falls afoul of a powerful gangster and is forced to go on the lam, is something Kafka might have thought of if Kafka had been interested in knocking off mindless television-movie scripts as a sideline.

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures in New York City this weekend. GALLERY TALKS, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. "Looking at Modern Art: Architecture" by Christopher Miele, today at noon; "Abstraction" by Wendy Belser, today at 1 P.M.; "Modern Metal: Furniture" by Mr. Miele, today at 3 P.M.; "Architecture Since 1945" by Mr. Miele, tomorrow at 1 P.M.; "The Art of Architectural Drawings" by Mr. Miele, tomorrow at 3 P.M.; "American Art After World War II" by Julie Reiss, Sunday at 1 P.M.; "American Drawings: 1898-1945" by Ms. Reiss, Sunday at 3 P.M. Free with museum admission: $7 ($4 for students and the elderly; under 16, free). Information: (212) 708-9480. GALLERY TALKS AND LECTURES, Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Jan Vermeer" by Peter L. Donhauser, today at 11 A.M.; "Religion in Ancient Mesopotamia" by Kim Benzel, 11:30 A.M.; "Sacred Peaks in Chinese Literature" by Richard Pegg, today at 3 P.M.; "Painting and Photography of the 1940's and 1950's" by Ellen Handy, today at 3:30 P.M.; "European Masters: Nicolas Poussin" by Pauline Thayer McGuire, today at 6 P.M.; "Rubens and Italy" by Walter Liedtke, associate curator of the department of European Paintings, today at 6 P.M. (admission by ticket; two tickets per person, available at 5 P.M. at Uris Center Information Desk); "Understanding Musical Instruments: Their Place in the Art Museum" by J. Kenneth Moore, today at 7 P.M.; "French Decorative Arts Before and After the Revolution" by Christopher Miele, tomorrow at 11 A.M.; "Recognizing a Masterpiece: Urningirsu: A Sumerian Royal Portrait" by Zainab Bahrani, tomorrow at 7 P.M.; "Jan Vermeer" by Peter L. Donhauser, Sunday at 11 A.M.; "Dutch Arcadia: Garden Art in the Netherlands 1550-1750" by Vanessa Bezemer-Sellers, Sunday at 1 P.M.; "Dutch Houses and Castles" by Jorge Guillermo, Sunday at 2 P.M.; "At Home in the Golden Age: The 17th-Century Dutch Interior" by Danielle Kisluk-Grosheide, assistant curator of the department of European sculpture and decorative arts, Sunday at 3 P.M. Reservations: (212) 935-3960. LITERARY TALKS AND DISCUSSIONS, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. "Biographers and Brunch: Elizabeth Frank on Louise Bogan. Sunday at 11 A.M. Tickets, $15; "Novels Into Film" with the writers Ira Levin, Molly Haskell, Susan Isaacs and Dan Greenburg and the producer David Brown, Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $14. Information: (212) 996-1100. MUSEUM TALKS, Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street in Manhattan. "Works in Progress," with black and Hispanic photographers who will discuss their work and careers, tomorrow at 10:30 A.M.; "Shaping the Image," a panel discussion on the responsibility of photographers, tomorrow at 1 P.M.; "Something Glorious: Greenwich Village and the Theater," with Dr. Brooks McNamara of New York University, Sunday at 2 P.M. All the talks are free with museum admission: $4 ($2 for the elderly, students and children or $6 for families). Information: (212) 534-1034.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 532 money market mutual funds decreased by $892.9 million, to $448.73 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds decreased by $692.6 million, to $121.84 billion. The 268 general-purpose funds were down by $494.5 million, to $154.98 billion. The 103 broker-dealer funds increased by $294.2 million, to $171.9 billion, the institute said.

title: Hunter Lifts Capitals in Overtime
description: It wasn't precisely the same scenario from last Sunday at the Capital Centre, but the ending of the game tonight brought the same sadness for the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actress CATHY LEE CROSBY has sued JOE THEISMANN , the former Washington Redskins quarterback and her former fiance, for $4.5 million, contending that he broke his promise to support her. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in Los Angeles Superior Court, said that the couple agreed six years ago to combine their financial resources and to support each other financially.

title: CUOMO PROPOSING STEEP BUDGET CUTS AND TAX INCREASES
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed the largest package of spending cuts in New York State's history and a third consecutive year of sharp increases in taxes and fees.

title: Corrections
description: The Outdoors column in Sports Pages yesterday about the skier Stein Ericksen misidentified his accent. It is Norwegian; Norway is his native country.

title: Mets Sporting New Attitude to Go With a New Lineup
description: There is a popular belief that with Darryl Strawberry gone from New York, with vast improvements sighted in Chicago with the Cubs, with the defending champion Pittsburgh Pirates brimming with confidence, the Mets are no longer the favorites in the National League East.

title: TV Weekend; An Independent Spirit on the Prairie
description: The February sweeps are upon us, and that means the networks will be beefing up their schedules with special dramas and movies, most of them either shamelessly heartwarming or potentially scary. The heartwarming contingent gets off to solid start on CBS this Sunday at 9 P.M. with a " Hallmark Hall of Fame" presentation called "Sarah, Plain and Tall."

title: The First Lesson
description: Human rights and arms control are often dismissed by national security hawks as unimportant concerns. But the first lesson of the Persian Gulf war is that earlier and more acute attention to those concerns might have saved us much grief.

title: Phone Numbers For Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf. Army (800) 626-1440 Air Force (800) 253-9276 Marines (800) 523-2694 Coast Guard (800) 367-8724 Navy (800) 255-3808* Navy (800) 732-1206+ *Immediate family members. +Other relatives and friends.

title: 16 Injured in Crash Landing Of Aircraft in West Virginia
description: A twin-engine commuter airplane skidded about 4,000 feet in a crash landing Wednesday night, starting a fire in the plane's cabin. No one was killed, but at least 16 of the 19 people on board were injured, officials said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Bombers SAUDIS RECAPTURE GHOST TOWN; ALLIES BOMB NEW IRAQI COLUMN; NEW BASES FOR U.S.
description: To increase the number of B-52 bombing raids against Iraqi ground forces, the United States has been secretly basing some of the bombers in Spain and has obtained permission to use a British airfield as well, Western officials said today.

title: Couple Slain In New Jersey; Son Is Suspect
description: A prominent medical researcher and his wife, who had been warned that a son was deeply disturbed and a threat to them were found shot to death Wednesday in their home here.

title: Dow Climbs 23.27 Points; Nasdaq Up
description: Stocks advanced for the third day yesterday as money managers jumped on the bandwagon before it got out of sight. Trading continued extremely heavy.

title: Pool: It's Upwardly Mobile and It's on a Run
description: Here is a look at 11 pool halls in Manhattan. In the cost category, "for first player" means the basic rate for one player; some halls charge per table. Most places charge an additional $1 to $3 an hour for each additional person. Since hands need to be clean and dry for optimum playing conditions, some places offer washing facilities in the main room. Amsterdam Billiard Club

title: Our Towns; Fighting Static On the Railroad With a Computer
description: "GRAWK! Attention Scrabyson . . . shun Hairyshun . . . Gwarfnahgle 7:25 to . . . York is run . . . ty minutes late. Gwarfnahgle 7:25 to New . . . skriffing . . . late. We apologize for this delay and thank you for riding Metro-North."

title: Leonard N. Backer; Textile Engineer, 65
description: Leonard Norman Backer, a textile engineer for almost 40 years, died yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 65 years old and died of cancer, his wife, Sylvia, said.

title: Conservation Doubles Elephants in Uganda
description: Uganda's elephant population has more than doubled in a decade as a result of an intensified war against poachers.

title: Review/Music; The Boston In a Piece Of History
description: Murderers are never more horrifying than when they hide behind the mask of culture. Early in World War II, the Nazis set up a prison at Terezin in Czechoslavakia as a holding area for Jewish prisoners, many of them musicians, on their way to the death camps in Poland. For propaganda purposes, the Germans made Terezin into a Potemkin Village, going so far as to depict it in a pseudodocumentary film as an artistic preserve where interned musicians had their own orchestra and regular concerts to keep them happy. It is chilling now to remember how successful the Nazis were in anesthetizing the world to the barbaric realities of such camps, not only early in the war, but almost to its end.

title: Report Calls for Washington To Overhaul Export Policies
description: A National Academy of Science panel yesterday called for drastically simpler export controls but said the United States must not halt its efforts to keep high-technology equipment from the Soviet military.

title: Unleash the Israelis
description: Much as I hate to pour cold water into the luxurious bath of approbation in which Israel's "restraint" has plunged it, the truth is that the Israelis have very little choice.

title: Investigations Of Meter Work Are Expanded
description: Investigations into New York City's $290 million water-meter program intensified yesterday as the Manhattan District Attorney's office subpoenaed the financial records of the company that dominates the program.

title: Albanians Urge Official's Ouster
description: In a rare public protest, more than 1,000 Albanians demonstrated in the capital today, demanding the resignation of the Foreign Minister.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Invading Force Is Destroyed As Saudi Town Is Won Back
description: This deserted border town between Saudi Arabia and Iraqi forces in Kuwait was back in Saudi hands tonight, but showing the scars of intense fighting.

title: Richer, and Poorer
description: To the Editor:

title: Missile Fired at Israel
description: Another Scud missile was fired at Israel tonight but fell short of its apparent target, Tel Aviv, and landed in the West Bank, the Israeli Army said.

title: Company News; Reebok Net Rises 13%
description: Reebok International Ltd. reported today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 13 percent from a year earlier.

title: Ellis Haizlip Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to Ellis B. Haizlip, a producer of black cultural events, is to be held at 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Mr. Haizlip died last Friday in Washington at age 61.

title: The 22% Rise in Postal Costs Upsets Magazine Publishers
description: Already suffering from a pervasive advertising recession, magazine publishers are now facing the more formidable problem of a 22 percent increase in second-class mail, which will go into effect Sunday.

title: Bleak Forecasts For the F.D.I.C. Are Challenged
description: L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, today flatly contradicted forecasts that the bank insurance fund he manages would be insolvent within two years.

title: Cleared of Assault, Korean Grocer Finds Tension and Support
description: Pong Ok Jang stocked the front of his small grocery the usual way yesterday: a little before 8 A.M. he and other workers cranked up the store's metal gate and hauled crates of fresh apples, tomatoes and plantains to the sidewalk.

title: Bush Schedules A Day of Prayer
description: President Bush asked all Americans today to join on Sunday in prayer for peace and for United States troops pressing the war against Iraq.

title: America's Purpose in Gulf Is to Fight Evil; What About Our Kids?
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Journal; Why So Many Chinese Are Teary: The Soap Opera Epoch Has Dawned
description: It is just an ordinary house, a drab clay building at the end of a narrow lane, but this is where millions of Chinese have been spending their recent evenings, laughing, sniffing and reliving some of the worst years of their lives, as they watch the first major soap opera made in China.

title: Concern for Iraqi Antiquities
description: An international group of nine prominent specialists in ancient Near Eastern history and culture has petitioned the United States Government to "take every possible measure to protect" the museums and archeological monuments of Iraq.

title: Presiding as ideas Clash In Capital Appeals Court
description: Judge Abner J. Mikva, who presides over what may be the second most important court in the nation, is eager to dispute a popular notion among lawyers that it may rank No. 1 in ideological rancor.

title: Mario Valentino, Designer, 64; Known for His Leather Fashions
description: Mario Valentino, a fashion designer and manufacturer widely known for fine workmanship in leather, died yesterday at his home in Naples. He was 64 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Mood; Now, the Grief: 11 Families Get the Word They Dreaded for Months
description: For military families around the nation, the worst fears of months of waiting came true today with the first reports of casualties in the ground war in the Persian Gulf.

title: America's Purpose in Gulf Is to Fight Evil; TV as Security Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Hires a Specialist In African-American Studies
description: One of the nation's best-known scholars in African-American studies has been hired by Harvard, the university announced yesterday.

title: Chartwell Seeking Avon Board Seats
description: Chartwell Associates, a limited partnership that includes the family trust of the oil heir Gordon P. Getty, said it would seek the proxy votes of shareholders of Avon Products Inc. in support of its slate of candidates to the cosmetic maker's board. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chartwell said it would propose candidates for four board openings.

title: Review/Photography; A Glimpse of the 40's and 50's at the Met Museum
description: By most accounts, the art of photography in the years following World War II was something of a black hole. Two of the greatest impresarios of modern photography, Alfred Stieglitz and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, died in 1946, leaving their legacies uncertain. The social-documentary vein tapped by Dorothea Lange, Walker Evans and other Farm Security Administration photographers in the 1930's no longer appeared as fresh as it once had.

title: Keep in Mind
description: AFRICAN DANCE, a workshop taught by Sara Wendt with traditional drum rhythms of Africa, for children 8 and up, $10 a person. At Elisabeth Irwin High School, 40 Charlton Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street, Manhattan. Sunday at 1:30 P.M. Reservations: (212) 477-5316.

title: Joseph H. Johnson, 68, Executive Who Headed Retail Concern, Dies
description: Joseph H. Johnson, the former chief executive officer of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation and former vice chairman of one of its subsidiaries, Lord & Taylor, died on Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich and Longboat Key, Fla.

title: INSIDE
description: One Town's Fallen Sons The fears of a California town that is home to a Marine division came true with the first reports of deaths in the Persian Gulf ground war. Page A9. WCBS Dismisses Koch Edward I. Koch's mouth may have cost him the mayoralty. Now he says he has lost a job as a news show host for the same reason. Page B1.

title: Fordham Wins 9th in Row, Sinking Manhattan, 75-68
description: It's not necessary for Fordham and Manhattan to be in the same conference to draw a crowd. Being in the same borough has always been enough, and it was no different last night as a standing-room-only crowd of 3,034 gathered in the Jaspers' Draddy Gymnasium to see the Rams beat Manhattan, 75-68.

title: TV Station Is Taking Koch Off the Air
description: Sixteen months after voters weary of his candor kicked him out of office, WCBS-TV kicked former Mayor Edward I. Koch off the air yesterday, saying it had agreed to buy out his contract as a co-host of its year-old Sunday morning news program.

title: In Pakistan, War Stirs Emotions and Politics
description: Reactions to the American-led war against Iraq have created political havoc in Pakistan, where the Government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has been trying to stabilize the country and restart the economy after a year of domestic turmoil.

title: Man Is Guilty in Stealing Thousands of Rare Books
description: A Federal court jury convicted a man today of stealing millions of dollars worth of rare books from libraries and museums around the country.

title: Rhode Island Governor Is Accused of Violating Depositors' Privacy
description: Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun has made public a list of depositors with more than $100,000 in the state's closed banks and credit unions, prompting charges from those on the list that their privacy rights had been violated.

title: Eleanor Brown Is Dead at 100; Interior Designer Pioneered Field
description: Eleanor Stockstrom McMillen Brown, a leading interior designer and founder of McMillen Inc. one of this country's best-known design concerns, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100 years old.

title: Barred Colombian Settles for Visa in U.S. Suit
description: Patricia Lara, a Colombian journalist who was barred from entering the United States when her name came up on the Immigration and Naturalization Service's "lookout" list four years ago, has settled a suit against the Federal Government by accepting a visa.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Medics; Trek Across the Desert May Hinder Lifesaving
description: The front-line American medical system in the Persian Gulf is set up to handle 15,000 wounded soldiers a day, even if 3,000 of them need emergency surgery, officials say.

title: The Apocalypse -- Stay Tuned
description: The role of television in this war has already launched a thousand cliches, their glibness and truth not necessarily contradictions of each other. I'm dubious that television has really made the war a video game or mini-series for people, but it seems indisputable that TV instantly translated it into familiar terms the public could be comfortable with.

title: Atlanta Papers To Cut 255 Jobs
description: The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, the state's largest newspapers, said on Wednesday that they were laying off 133 people and leaving 122 other jobs unfilled, primarily because of a decline in advertising revenues.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about oil trading on Monday carried an erroneous news agency credit line. The article was by Reuters, not by The Associated Press.

title: Accounting Proposals For Banks
description: One of the nation's top banking regulators described several proposed accounting changes yesterday aimed at making the financial condition of banks appear less bleak.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 24 about an Iraqi missile attack on Israel on Jan. 22 misstated results of previous attacks. Other missiles had caused casualties but no deaths.

title: Kollmorgen Seeking New Chief Executive
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation is looking for a new chief executive. John L. Youngblood, who led the company successfully through several difficulties last year, has announced that he plans to resign July 1.

title: An Auction Is Planned For Eastern
description: Unexpectedly keen competition to buy the airport gates and takeoff and landing slots of Eastern Airlines has led the bankruptcy judge handling Eastern's case to schedule an auction.

title: U.N. Aide Assailed in Salvadoran Talks
description: With a new round of peace talks between El Salvador's guerrillas and Government scheduled to begin in Mexico City on Friday, Administration officials have criticized the United Nations mediator for failing to press the rebels to compromise.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amer Group Ltd., Helsinki, Finland, named Erkki E. Railo chairman of its Wilson Sporting Goods Co. and MacGregor Golf Co. * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, named Edwin J. Roland vice president for operations, planning and transportation. * Boston Whaler Inc., Rockland, Mass., a manufacturer of power boats that is a subsidiary of Reebok International Ltd., appointed Sharon Cohen vice president of marketing. * Cadbury Beverages International, Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., promoted John F. Brock to president. * Landes Organization, New York, appointed Matthew R. Kahn managing director of the Lexington Group, its financial services firm, and executive vice president of RKO Warner Video Inc., one of its retail affiliates. * Mattel Inc., the Hawthorne, Calif., toy maker, promoted Norman Vaughan to vice president for properties and administrative services. * USF&G Corp., Baltimore, named Edwin G. Pickett executive vice president and chief financial officer. The company also named Richard J. Potter senior vice president for strategic planning and Jack Hart senior vice president for human resources. James N. Stanard was named executive vice president of United States Fidelity and Guaranty Co., a subsidiary of USF&G. * Viacom Broadcasting, New York, a subsidiary of Viacom Inc., promoted Michael Kelso to executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Soap Sellers' New Credo: Less Powder, More Power
description: Say goodbye to "jumbo," "super" and "giant" boxes of laundry detergent. Say hello to, well, little. Or, as the detergent companies put it, "ultra."

title: Writers Honor Icahn
description: Carl Icahn, owner of Meadow Star, an undefeated 2-year-old filly, was named the winner yesterday of the New York Turf Writers Association's John A. Morris Award as the person who did the most for racing during the year.

title: Earnings Dip At Gannett
description: The Gannett Company said today that sluggish advertising demand contributed to earnings declines of 8 percent for the fourth quarter and 5 percent for the year. It was the company's first decline in annual profits since going public in 1967.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS - 10A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Books of The Times; Paying the Price for Dreams Followed to the Limit
description: Evenings at Mongini's And Other Stories By Russell Lucas 262 pages. Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: A disturbance rotating around a pool of cold air over Turkey will produce snow in the montains of Iraq and showers in Syria and Israel. Winds off the Persian Gulf will promote low clouds over Kuwait and northeast Saudi Arabia. High clouds will cover south Iraq. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 64, low 38; Riyadh, high 73, low 50; Dhahran, high 72, low 58.

title: Paine Webber Has Big Loss
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. reported a large fourth-quarter loss yesterday because of write-offs for failed merchant banking activities and for measures to reduce the size of the firm.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Respect for Hussein
description: Each day that Saddam Hussein survives is beginning to be considered by many Arabs, and even by some here in the Saudi capital, as a victory of sorts for him.

title:
Suburban Rental Market;
Stamford Apartments Near Completion
description: Trammell Crow Residential, the nation's largest builder of rental housing, is making its first entry into the Stamford, Conn., market with a 197-unit project that is to open for leasing this month and for occupancy in April.

title: Trials -- and Error -- in China
description: Nei jin, wai song, says China's Communist leadership, meaning that its policy of fierce domestic political repression can coexist with harmonious relations with the outside world. Not so is the outside world's only decent response.

title: Review/Film; A Real Horror Show That Spoofs Its Genre
description: "Buy a bag . . . go home in a box," reads the ad line for "Popcorn," a horror film that is less mindless than most in that it is both funny and gross.

title: Medal to Be Given To Justice Brennan
description: The Municipal Art Society, a private organization devoted to landmarks preservation and city planning in New York, plans to award its president's medal to Justice William J. Brennan Jr.

title: Yankees Sign Cary
description: Chuck Cary, who had a 6-12 record with a 4.19 earned run average last season, reached agreement with the Yankees on a one-year contract yesterday, thus avoiding arbitration.

title: Freed Rapist Seized in 5 Rapes
description: A man who was paroled four months ago after serving 10 years for rape and robbery has been arrested and charged with raping a 12-year-old girl and four women in a Bronx housing project, the housing police said yesterday.

title: Poison Gas Canister Forces an Evacuation
description: A leaking canister of poison gas forced the evacuation of a Lower East Side apartment building early yesterday morning and 7 tenants, 7 police officers and 11 firefighters were treated for nausea and dizziness, the police said.

title: Growth of AIDS Virus Is Slowed in Study
description: Growth of the AIDS virus in laboratory experiments was significantly suppressed by the addition of an amino acid that plays an essential role in the body's system for fighting infection, researchers say.

title: Key Rates
Oiler Is Suspended
description: The Edmonton Oilers center Craig Simpson was suspended yesterday for three games for a hit that injured Steve Bozek of the Vancouver Canucks in a game on Jan. 23.

title: Purchasers' Index Is at 9-Year Low
description: The economic decline in American manufacturing deepened in January, as another drop in new orders pushed an indicator to its lowest level in nine years, according to a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers.

title: ALLIED AIR FORCES POUND IRAQI UNITS AT KUWAIT BORDER
description: Allied air power continued to pound Iraqi troop positions today while artillery and tank fire echoed across the Kuwaiti border, but there was no sign of further Iraqi movements into Saudi Arabia.

title: Coach's Two Wrongs Make a $1,000 Fine
description: He was in the wrong place at the wrong time last Tuesday -- on the court when he should have been on the bench -- and so Coach Del Harris of the Milwaukee Bucks paid the price thrice.

title: South Africa Moves to Scrap Apartheid
description: President F. W. de Klerk moved today to smash the legal bedrock of apartheid by announcing that he would scrap the remaining laws on which South Africa's ideology of racial discrimination has long rested.

title: Femme Fatale
description: Women, though not necessarily the gentler sex, are far less inclined to pick up a .38 than men are. They're seldom quick to reach for a knife. And they're much more apt to wring their hands than other people's necks. For as long as anyone's been keeping tabs on such matters, women have accounted for no more than 10 to 15 percent of all murders.

title: Azinger Leads by 2 Shots at Helpless Pebble Beach
description: Near-perfect scoring conditions continued for the second round of the A.T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am today, and no one took better advantage of them than Paul Azinger.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the first use of gene therapy on cancer patients misstated the number of cases of maligant melanoma in the United States. It is expected to be 32,000 this year, not 8,000 to 10,000. The smaller figures referred to the number in which the cancer has begun to spread throughout the body.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Bush Tours 3 Bases, Thanking Troops and Families
description: With American flags and olive-drab war machines as his backdrops, President Bush sped through a made-for- television tour of three military bases today and thanked American troops and their families for "doing the hard work of freedom."

title: Review/Opera; A Tour for 'Figaro' And a Gain for Intimacy
description: Like many companies, the New York City Opera has a junior adjunct that tours with mostly youthful casts performing works from the standard repertory. Normally, whatever the merits of such enterprises, they serve primarily to advertise the parent company and to provide training for its apprentice artists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about proposals to restrict water use in California misidentified a state assemblyman. He is Chris Chandler.

title: Soviet Troops Join the Police on Patrol
description: Three dozen soldiers joined the Moscow police in pounding the capital's more populous beats today on the first day of the joint patrols decreed by the Government.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: A Serial Killer Gets a Sentence Of 250 Years
description: Arthur Shawcross, convicted of killing 10 Rochester-area women from 1988 to 1990, was sentenced today to a minimum of 250 years in prison.

title: 9 Avoid Arbitration
description: The number of players still eligible for arbitration in the final week before hearings continued to dwindle yesterday, dropping to 88, from the original 138.

title: Review/Music; Korean Violinist's Romantic Roots
description: Chin Kim is an experienced violinist from South Korea who has had the great part of his training in the United States. Such influences as Ivan Galamian, Dorothy Delay and Josef Gingold -- add also, of course, his own inclinations -- have turned him into an honorable practitioner of the strongly Romantic Eastern European style of violin-playing so prevalent in the first half of this century. The technique is strong, the pressure on the strings firm and heavy. Weight and dark color predominate.

title: Construction Spending Slid 0.5% in December
description: Construction spending slid for a ninth straight month in December, falling five-tenths of a percent and helping to trim building growth for the year to just six-tenths of a percent, the Government said today.

title: The Bad News Boys, Mr. Florio Cuts Back
description: Among the 30-odd states grappling with prospective deficits, New Jersey is in relatively good shape, thanks to big tax increases last year. But any deficit is difficult. Gov. Jim Florio's budget combines toughness, gimmickry and hope for only a mild recession.

title: Is the Start Treaty Slipping Away?
description: Postponement of the Moscow summit meeting is a major setback for U.S. security interests. Besides providing a timely opportunity for discussing the Persian Gulf war and the Baltic crisis, the meeting would above all have forced a deadline for signing the essentially complete Strategic Arms Reductions Treaty, or Start. Now, Start could become a tragic casualty of the delay.

title: Basketball; Knicks' Fans Turn Up The Heat on Bianchi
description: Frustration. It's mounting. The players and coaching staff have felt it all season. Now it's the fans' turn. The boos once targeted for Mark Jackson, for poor play and for squandered leads have spilled over to Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager.
