title: Jose F. Mora, 78, Dies; Professor of Philosophy
description: Jose Ferrater Mora, a professor emeritus of philosophy at Bryn Mawr College, died Wednesday at a hospital in Barcelona, Spain. He was 78 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa.

title: Grand Canyon Haze Plan Is Disputed
description: One owner of a giant coal-burning power plant in northern Arizona accused the Environmental Protection Agency today of basing a pivotal decision aimed at reducing haze in the Grand Canyon on flawed scientific research.

title: Naivasha Journal; Dutch Flowers? In Name Only. Ask the Kenyans.
description: In a cavernous hall set in a 4,500-acre flower farm here, an almost militarily precise work force grades, ties in bunches, packs in boxes and refrigerates a million carnations a day.

title: Edythe W. Donovan, Lawyer, 45
description: Edythe W. Donovan, a senior lawyer with the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed in Manhattan, died on Thursday at New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. She was 45 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Tactics; Iraqis, in the Open, Suit U.S. Strategy
description: Pentagon officials say that Iraqi ground forces have been playing into American hands by coming out of their entrenched positions and confronting allied air and ground power.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL A. VOLCKER and JAMES EARL JONES are among the six winners of Common Wealth Awards, which are given annually. The others are SEBASTIAO SALGADO, a photojournalist; ADRIENNE RICH, the poet; ROGER N. BEACHY, a research biologist who produced the first disease-resistant, genetically engineered crop, and Prof. NATHAN KEYFITZ , professor emeritus of sociology and demography at Harvard University. Each winner receives $120,000.

title: Patents; Heimlich Develops New Breathing Tube
description: The thoracic surgeon who pioneered the Heimlich maneuver, the technique for helping choking victims to breathe again, is still preoccupied with respiration.

title: Robert Havighurst, 90, Educator And Expert on Youth and Old Age
description: Dr. Robert J. Havighurst, an educator and researcher who wrote about the sociological aspects of youth and old age, died Thursday in Richmond, Ind. He was 90 years old.

title: Mr. Weicker Gets Ready
description: With customary candor, Gov. Lowell Weicker says "let's not tiptoe around this" -- Connecticut is in for $1 billion more taxes. The state's budget deficit is proportionately one of the nation's largest, and growing. The new Governor has little choice but to move boldly.

title: Unit of Williams In Centel Deal
description: The Williams Telecommunication Group, which has an 11,000-mile fiber-optic telephone network but has been in search of customers, agreed to acquire the business telephone unit of the Centel Corporation. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Stock Scandal in Japan Runs Deep
description: When the takeover artist Mitsuhiro Kotani was indicted last year for stock manipulation, many passed it off merely as an instance of a speculator going too far and being used to warn others that despite the almost total absence here of such prosecutions, there are limits. Six months later, few are dismissing this still-smoldering scandal so lightly.

title: Charles F. McElwain, Executive, 87
description: Charles F. McElwain, an executive who retired in 1965 after 42 years with the International Business Machines Corporation, died on Wednesday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 87 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y., for many years.

title: Charles Salesky, 71, Fashion Innovator In the Hat Industry
description: Charles H. Salesky, the former president of the Hat Corporation of America and an innovator in the industry in the 1960's, died on Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: Dow Drops 5.70, to 2,730.69, But Smaller Stocks Surge
description: Propelled by momentum in technology issues, smaller stocks continued to score big gains yesterday, while the blue chips fell. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,730.69, down 5.70 points.

title: Unisys Executive Is Set to Resign
description: The Unisys Corporation, based in Blue Bell, Pa., said yesterday that its vice chairman, Curtis A. Hessler, would leave the company on Feb. 15. He is returning to California for family reasons, Unisys said, and will join a company that does not compete with Unisys.

title: Murdoch Obtains Accord On Most of News Corp. Debt
description: The News Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with its scores of lenders to reschedule about $7.6 billion of its $8.2 billion in debts.

title: Job Losses Up Sharply Last Month
description: In a sharp setback to hopes that the sliding economy had begun to stabilize, the Government today reported a heavy new wave of job losses in January and an unusually large contraction in the length of the average workweek.

title: Judge to Reconsider Order on Child Support
description: A judge who ordered more than 40 children to use their absent fathers' last names has temporarily lifted the order after child-support officials protested.

title: Why the Gulf War Is Not Vietnam
description: "It won't be another Vietnam," President Bush keeps saying about the Persian Gulf war. That's a sure applause line. Americans now agree that the long U.S. military involvement in Southeast Asia was a disaster for America. But the President's oratory, and the applause, are confusing, because Americans still differ sharply about the nature of the disaster.

title: American and Pilots Brace for Strike
description: Pilots at American Airlines started passing the hat a year ago to build a strike fund. The dollar count has swelled into the millions and, with contract talks bogged down, cockpit crews at the nation's largest airline are bracing for a walkout as early as March.

title: War Summary
description: DAY 16 ON LAND AND IN AIR

title: Abrams to Run For U.S. Senate In 1992 Contest
description: Robert Abrams, who was sworn in a few weeks ago to a fourth term as New York State's Attorney General, said today that he is running for a new office: United States Senator.

title: Stamping Out Magazines
description: The recent clamor over whether a first-class postage stamp should cost 29 or 30 cents has obscured the fact that monumental rate increases for other mail classes are pushing the magazine industry closer to disaster.

title: Peril of Rock Concerts' Festival Seating
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Human Rights; Syria and Iraq Faulted by U.S. on Human Rights
description: The State Department said today in its annual report on human rights that Iraq's "abysmal record" of repressing virtually every category of human rights worsened last year, but the report also criticized the records of America's Persian Gulf war allies -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Syria and Turkey.

title: 2 Banks Seized By F.D.I.C.
description: Bank regulators declared two New England banks insolvent today and allowed healthier banks in Connecticut and Maine to acquire them.

title: Dr. John G. Kidd, 82; Research Pathologist
description: Dr. John Graydon Kidd, a former pathologist-in-chief at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died on Monday at the Nacogdoches Medical Center in Texas. He was 82 years old and lived in Center, Tex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf: 4-6

title: Basketball; Carnesecca Aims at 500th
description: Lou Carnesecca was 40 years old in the fall of 1965 when he replaced Joe Lapchick and became the 11th St. John's head basketball coach. When Carnesecca was asked this week if he believed back then that almost 26 years later he would be just one victory shy of 500, the 66-year-old coach arched his eyebrows in mock surprise.

title: Phil Watson, 78, A Former Player And Coach of the Rangers, Dies
description: Phil Watson, who played on the last Rangers team to win the National Hockey League Stanley Cup, in 1940, and who later took the Rangers to the playoffs in three of his four seasons as a coach in the 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 78 years old.

title: Basketball; Barkley Returns and Sparks Sixers
description: Charles Barkley, a surprise starter after missing seven games with a foot injury, had 24 points, 12 rebounds and 8 assists tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 96-89 victory over the Phoenix Suns. The Sixers outscored the Suns, 19-5, in the final 7 minutes 10 seconds.

title: Hollywood Abuzz Over Cost Memo
description: An internal memorandum written by the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Hollywood's most successful film studio, has quickly gained a wider readership here than any movie script, and set off a debate about the movie industry's inability to keep expenses under control.

title: A Pretty Flabby Defense
description: Thousands of followers of Professor Irwin Corey, world's foremost authority, are accusing me of plagiarism for referring in a recent column to Dr. Harold Liverworth as "world's foremost authority."

title: Lines of Jobless Grow as Benefits Staff Shrinks
description: At 7 A.M. a full moon was shining down on Tim Peck as he stood outside an unemployment office trying to ward off the bitter cold and his rising anger.

title: Benefit Performances To Aid Student Dancers
description: Benefit performances for the Emergency Fund for Student Dancers, a general assistance service formed by six major New York dance training institutions, will be presented at 8 o'clock tonight and 3 P.M. tomorrow at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. Tickets are $10. Information: 689-0740.

title: Critic's Notebook; Not Letting TV Do Its Best Job in the War
description: "Television is inherently a medium of simplicity," observed David Gergen, the White House aide turned journalist, at a forum put on this week by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Much of the day was given to criticism of television coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf from such other journalists and sometime journalists as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Hodding Carter 3d. There was a lot of politics in the air, but Mr. Gergen's simple observation about simplicity seemed to strike most directly at the network news departments' current problems.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Europe; France Says U.S. Bombers Can Now Use Airspace
description: France announced tonight that American B-52's based in Britain would be allowed to fly over its territory on bombing raids against Iraq and refuel at a French military base en route from Britain to the Persian Gulf war zone.

title: INSIDE
description: Severe Afghan Quake Said to Kill 109 in Pakistan

title: Right-Wing Party Joining Israeli Coalition
description: The Israeli Government signed an agreement today allowing the country's most extreme right-wing political party, which advocates expelling all Palestinians from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, to join the ruling coalition.

title: Key Rates
Ban on Some European Wines May End
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that a chemical that kills fungus on European grapevines was safe when consumed in trace amounts, a finding that should end the Government's barrier to imports of some high-quality wines.

title: Glen N. Cox, Professor, 87
description: Glen N. Cox, a retired professor and assistant dean at the New York University College of Engineering, died on Tuesday in Claremont, Calif. He was 87 years old and had lived for many years in Irvington and Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., before moving to Claremont two years ago.

title: New Haitian Leader Asserts Interim Rulers Drain Coffers
description: The President-elect charged today that the country's interim government is trying to "empty the treasury" before he takes office.

title: Yasushi Inoue, Novelist, 83
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31

title: Despite Making 59 Saves, Richter Shares the Spotlight
description: Under normal circumstances, the post-game focus of attention Thursday night at Pacific Coliseum would have been Mike Richter. The goalie of the Rangers faced 62 shots and stopped 59 of them as New York ended a four-game trip with a 3-3 tie against the Vancouver Canucks.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: BOMBER SITTING IT OUT: While the aging B-52 is playing a big role in the war, the nation's newest active bomber, the B-1, seems destined to sit it out. Page 9.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday about events in celebration of black history month misidentified the choir that will perform at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Covenant House, 346 West 17th Street, in Manhattan. It is the New York Boys Choir of Manhattan.

title: Yields Plunge As Fed Cuts Discount Rate
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday after the Federal Reserve, responding to a surge in unemployment and other negative economic data, cut its discount rate by a half-point, to 6 percent. The Fed also moved to lower the key interbank lending rate.

title: Bridge
description: Shooting is almost as common at the card tables of New York City as it is on the streets, but it is never noisy and always one-sided. When a team knows that it is trailing in a match, it "shoots" by looking for unusual results.

title: Sylvia Wilson, Editor, 28
description: Sylvia Wilson, a copy editor at The New York Times, died yesterday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. She was 28 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: Miriam Holman, 64, Soprano and Actress
description: Miriam Burton Holman, a soprano and actress who appeared on Broadway and in opera, died last Sunday at High Ridge House, a Christian Science nursing facility in the Bronx. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday about four of the United States marines killed in the Persian Gulf war reversed their identities. They were Lance Cpl. Dion James Stephenson, top left; Cpl. Stephen Bentzlin, top right; Lance Cpl. Daniel Byron Walker, bottom left; and Lance Cpl. David T. Snyder, bottom right.

title: Are We Now Due for a Stinging Lesson in Scorpion Logic?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bertram A. Levine, Lawyer, 84
description: Bertram A. Levine, a retired partner in the Manhattan law firm of Kramer & Kaprow, died on Wednesday at his home in White Plains. He was 84 years old.

title: A Steinbrenner Hearing
description: The court reporter being sued by George Steinbrenner, who accuses the stenographer of changing transcripts made during baseball's investigation of the Yankees owner, presented the case for dismissal before a Federal judge yesterday. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the United States Court, Southern District, listened to arguments from both sides for approximately 40 minutes, then reserved opinion and is considering his decision.

title: Crossland Has Wider Loss
description: Crossland Savings, the largest savings institution in New York State, reported yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter of 1990 exceeded the loss in the 1989 period and that it had filed a revised plan with Federal regulators to achieve compliance with capital requirements.

title: Troubled B-1 Bomber Spends War at Home
description: While the Air Force's aging B-52 bomber is playing a big role in the air attack in the Persian Gulf, the United States' newest active bomber, the B-1, appears destined to sit out the war on the sidelines.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At its annual commemoration marking the Jan. 22, 1973, Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, Roe v. Wade, the New York State National Abortion Rights Action League gave an award to KAREN FINLEY Tuesday night in Manhattan. The award was "in recognition of her contribution to reproductive rights through her performance art and her poetry," said ELLEN CARTON , the executive director of the 22,000-member group. A poem by Ms. Finley, "Aunt Mandy," was inspired by a relative who died after an illegal abortion.

title: 100% Deposit Insurance Is Wrongheaded
description: To the Editor:

title: Misdemeanors Charged in Happy Land Fire
description: The Dinkins administration said yesterday that it had filed five misdemeanor charges stemming from building code violations against the owner and landlord of the Happy Land Social Club building, where 87 people died last March in an arson fire.

title: Center for Auto Safety's Point Man
description: For Clarence M. Ditlow, the seeds of activism were sown on field trips to Pennsylvania factories when he was studying chemical engineering at Lehigh University.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Rutgers Routs Temple Keith Hughes and Earl Duncan scored 5 points each in a 20-2 first-half run last night as Rutgers won its season-high sixth consecutive game, 82-63, over Temple in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Invective Roils Genteel Gramercy Park
description: Gramercy Park, an elegant square where patricians and artists share quiet brownstones and keys to a private park, has long been known as the Bloomsbury of New York. Residents consider it an oasis, the last vestige of a gentler era that Edith Wharton, who grew up in the neighborhood, once described as "the safe daylight world of nice people and reputable doings."

title: Craig and Bavaro Among Those Up for Grabs
description: Some of the National Football League's most honored players, including Mark Bavaro and Ottis Anderson of the Giants and Roger Craig and Ronnie Lott of the San Francisco 49ers, were left unprotected yesterday as the league's teams filed their annual Plan B free-agency lists.

title: Excerpts From Remarks To Parliament by de Klerk
description: Following are excerpts from an address by President F. W. de Klerk at the opening of Parliament in South Africa today, as provided by the South African Government: In the short span of a single year, substantial progress was made. The Government is determined to build on the foundations laid purposefully, efficiently and with due speed.

title: Postage Due: 29 Cents
description: Pay those bills. Send those Valentine's cards early. Today is the last day of the 25-cent first-class letter; the rate rises to 29 cents at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Editors' Note
description: A report in the "On Stage, and Off" column of Weekend yesterday about personnel changes at the Public Theater quoted a staff member at the theater "who spoke on condition of anonymity" about JoAnne Akalaitis, a director who has been considered a possible successor to Joseph Papp ashead of the theater. The staff member was critical and indicated that Mr. Papp was also.

title: Palestinians and Israel Renew Lebanon Clash
description: Palestinian guerrillas and Israeli forces battled with howitzers and rockets in southern Lebanon today in the fourth day of what one television station called "the new front in the gulf war."

title: Tank Plant Layoffs Set By General Dynamics
description: Last month the company laid off about 4,000 aerospace workers at its plant in Fort Worth after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled the development of the Navy's A-12 jet because of cost overruns and delays.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At a meeting of the National Council for the Arts on Friday in Washington, it was announced that PRESIDENT BUSH planned to nominate to the council DONALD HALL, a New Hampshire poet, and WILLIAM E. STRICKLAND JR., the chairman of the Craftsman's Guild in Pittsburgh. The group serves as an advisory body to the National Endowment for the Arts. The two new members would replace PHYLLIS BERNEY and JACOB NEUSNER, whose six-year term expired last year.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Iraq Threatens P.O.W.'s
description: Countering Red Cross appeals for the humane treatment of downed American and allied pilots, Iraq urged today that the airmen be treated as killers and war criminals because of purported attacks on defenseless women and children.

title: Your Money; Profit Sharing Based on Age
description: Corporations in ever-growing numbers are cutting back or eliminating pension plans, leaving older employees who had counted on comfortable retirement benefits to fear that they will be short-changed.

title: Broadening the Focus on the Sanctity of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: After Giving to the Neediest, Finding Reason to Give Again
description: "And now just for luck, here is another buck.'

title: Daily News and Unions Begin Final Phase of Talks
description: Amid signs of movement and rising urgency, The Daily News and its striking unions have begun what both sides regard as a crucial final phase of negotiations that would either end the three-month walkout or force the closing of the 70-year-old newspaper.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan; Japan's Premier Backs a Compromise on Aid for the Gulf War
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, struggling to gain legislative approval of $9 billion in aid for the war against Iraq, has agreed in principle to a compromise that would prevent the money from being spent on arms, ammunition or anything else intended for lethal purposes, Japanese officials said today.

title: Trump Deal Is Seen With Bondholders
description: A settlement is imminent in claims made by some bondholders of Resorts International Inc. against Donald J. Trump, several people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Writers-in-Residence
description: A $1.8 million grant from the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund will enable more than 50 small colleges throughout the United States to have such writers as Russell Banks, Alice Adams, Tim O'Brien and Bharati Mukherjee on campus during the next four years. During residencies of up to eight weeks, the authors -- writers of fiction, poetry or literary nonfiction -- will conduct readings, classes, workshops and informal events.

title: An Opposition Leader?
description: The Persian Gulf war obviously has wide public support, enough to intimidate dissident politicians from standing up to oppose it. Someone, probably but not necessarily a Democrat, nevertheless may be missing an opportunity by holding his or her tongue.

title: Los Angeles Crash On Runway Leaves 5 Dead and 30 Hurt
description: A USAir jetliner landing here with about 90 people aboard collided this evening with a smaller commuter plane preparing to take off from Los Angeles International Airport, Federal aviation officials and the airline said.

title: Was St. Paul Gay? Claim Stirs Fury
description: Throughout his ministry as an Episcopal priest and bishop, John S. Spong has been surrounded by controversy as he has labored on the leading edge of movements to bring blacks, women and homosexuals into the full life of his church.

title: 100% Deposit Insurance Is Wrongheaded; Too Safe to Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellis Haizlip Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to Ellis B. Haizlip, a producer of black cultural events, is to be held at 2 P.M. today at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Mr. Haizlip died last Friday in Washington at age 61.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: M.I.A.'s; 2 Missing Soldiers Identified by U.S.
description: The Pentagon yesterday identified the two Army soldiers who were listed on Thursday as missing from their jeep near the Saudi border with Kuwait as Specialist 4 Melissa A. Rathbun-Nealy, 20 years old, of western Michigan, and Specialist 4 David Lockett, 23.

title: Books of The Times; Two Views of Rights and Repression in the U.S.
description: Protectors of Privilege Red Squads and Police Repression in Urban America By Frank Donner 503 pages. University of California Press. $34.95. Nobody's Business Paradoxes of Privacy By Alida Brill 197 pages. Addison-Wesley. $17.95.

title: At 32, Foster Outruns Years and Millrose Competition
description: He was training by himself the other day, on the University of Southern California track, when one of the school's hurdlers wandered over and watched for a while.

title: Trade Offer By Europe
description: The European Community today proposed a significant overhaul of its costly farm subsidy program in a move that could help restart stalled world trade talks.

title: Patents; Energizing Engines
description: A Pittsburgh inventor has patented a device to give internal combustion engines an extra kick of energy from water vapor heated beyond the boiling point. Invented by Fred G. Mahoney, the device is based on the idea that superheated water vapor can help an engine burn more smoothly and efficiently, by allowing the fuel mixture to disperse more evenly through the combustion chamber.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Should Parliament adopt the Government's proposals, the South African statute book will be devoid, within months, of the remnants of racially discriminatory legislation which have become known as the cornerstones of apartheid." -- President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa. [ 1:1. ]

title: Arts Officials Voice Shock at Cuomo Cuts
description: "We are reeling and on the ropes," Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday. Mr. Goodman, a Republican State Senator from Manhattan and chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Arts and Cultural Affairs, was referring to Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposal for a cut of 56 percent in the budget for the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Patents; Future Look At Cruise Control
description: A Researcher at the General Motors Corporation has patented a futuristic automobile cruise-control system that automatically adjusts the car's speed to keep a safe distance from vehicles in front.

title: Cuomo Budget Called Burden At Local Level
description: Local government officials predicted today that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, by relying heavily on spending cuts, would force them to increase taxes and cut services substantially at the local level.

title: Belichick Talks to Bucs
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers continued their search for a head coach, interviewing the Giants' defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, for nearly three hours yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest Inc., an airline based in Wichita, Kan., has completed the sale of aircraft and assets associated with its St. Louis-based Trans World Express operations to Trans States Airlines Inc., another Trans World Express operator. The sale price was about $12 million, down from the originally reported $16 million. * Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, said Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services, the leasing wing of Ansett Australia, had converted to firm orders two of its six options to purchase A300-600R twin-engine planes. * Ameritech, Chicago, a telecommunications company, said it had accepted tenders for more than 24 million shares, or 91 percent, of the common shares of Knowledge Data Systems Inc., Salt Lake City, a computer systems company, for a total cost of about $26 million. * International Business Machines, Armonk, N.Y., said its Federal Sector division in Manassas, Va., was leading a team of companies that had been awarded a five-year, $25 million contract to provide a data communications network for Federal courts in the United States. The two companies working with I.B.M. will be Computer Science Corp.'s Network Systems division in Herndon, Va., and Arix Inc., San Jose, Calif. * Polly Peck International P.L.C., London, said its three United States food businesses other than Del Monte were being offered for sale. The companies are Prevor Marketing in New York and Sweden, Mendelson-Zeller in Fresno, Calif., and Standard Fruit Vegetable in Dallas. * Wal-Mart Stores Inc., Bentonville, Ark., and Wholesale Club Inc., Indianapolis, an operator of wholesale warehouses, said Wholesale Club shareholders had approved its acquisition by Wal-Mart.

title: F.D.I.C. Is Dealt a Setback In Judge's Ruling on Mcorp
description: The top agency regulating the nation's banks was dealt a potentially costly blow today when a Federal judge in Dallas ruled that the agency violated banking laws two years ago by seizing a dozen banks owned by Mcorp.

title: Pierce Asks for Trade
description: As if the week wasn't bad enough for Harris, his All-Star guard, Ricky Pierce, said yesterday he was so unhappy with attempts to renegotiate his contract that he wants to be traded.

title: Coping; With Frail Fabrics
description: Antique linens, gloves, embroidered fans, lace, christening gowns and bridal dresses are often among a family's most cherished possessions. Yet if they are not handled carefully, these heirlooms can deteriorate or become damaged beyond repair.

title: Gorbachev, Easing Baltic Stand, Appoints Panels for Discussions
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev eased his hard-line pressure on the independence drives in the Baltic region today, appointing delegations to begin a "discussion of issues" with the three embattled republics.

title: Navistar to Cut 525 Staff Jobs
description: The Navistar International Corporation is eliminating 525 administrative, professional and management jobs as part of a cost-cutting program. The cuts include 263 jobs in the Chicago area, where the truck maker is based; 70 to 80 positions at Navistar's Springfield, Ohio, manufacturing plant, and additional reductions at the company's engineering center in Fort Wayne, Ind., a spokesman, Bill Greenhill, said. Navistar employs about 14,000 people nationwide.

title: Christina Robert, Producer, Is Wed
description: Christina Robert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yves Henry Robert of New York, was married last evening to Barnaby Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thompson of London. The Rev. Samuel B. Matarazzo performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Union's Role In Meter Work Is Investigated
description: State and Federal investigators are trying to determine whether a Staten Island plumbers' union local helped a small Kentucky company gain a competitive edge in New York City's $290 million water-meter program by allowing the company to underpay its workers, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article on Tuesday about poverty and the national political agenda referred imprecisely to a remedy proposed by Mickey Kaus, an expert on welfare policy. Under his plan to replace the welfare system with a program of guaranteed Government jobs, people who refuse to work would not receive Government payments but could be aided by Government programs that provide services.

title: Grand Met Seeks Big Board Listing
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British parent of the Pillsbury Company and the Burger King Corporation, said it was seeking a stock listing on the New York Stock Exchange. The company filed a preliminary registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its shares to be listed as American depository receipts. Each A.D.R. will represent the equivalent of two ordinary Grand Met shares, which are listed on London's Stock Exchange, the company said.

title: Flood of Corporate Issues Follows Credit Market Rally
description: American corporations responded to yesterday's big rally in the credit markets by flooding the market with new debt issues.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; U.S. Investigates Whether Marines Were Killed by American Jets
description: The Pentagon said today that it was investigating whether some of the marines who died during clashes with Iraqi troops this week were killed by fire from American jets, but officials warned that the investigation might prove inconclusive.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Town Regained, Morale Of Arab Allies Is Lifted
description: Saudi troops atop French-built light tanks raced out of the border town of Khafji to a resupply depot to the south.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS LOAN RATES TO PROD ECONOMY
description: In the face of stark new evidence of the nation's economic weakness, the Federal Reserve moved today with unusual force to stimulate the economy by sharply reducing the interest rates it controls.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For Luck, and Memories, a Little Bit of Lace
description: Tucked inside the Kevlar helmets of the many soldiers are the most sentimental mementos of loved ones far away: photographs, letters, lacy pink panties.

title: Chrysler Raising Some Rebates
description: The Chrysler Corporation increased rebates on some of its cars and mini-vans, as it continues to be haunted by slow sales. Among the changes announced, the company doubled the rebates to $1,000 on the Chrysler Imperial, New Yorker Fifth Avenue, Lebaron sedan, Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit. It also increased rebates on 1989 and 1990 models of its standard and extended-length Dodge and Plymouth minivans.

title: Guidepost; Winter Care for Shoes
description: In winter, sales of shoe-care and related products skyrocket as buyers look for ways to protect their shoes -- and themselves -- from ice, snow, water and salt. A range of products is available, although there is no consensus among manufacturers and leather experts about which are best. The choice often depends on the type and quality of the leather and the degree of protection desired. As always, read and follow label directions. Problem: Traction in snow or slush Solution: Rubber soles with a rib or tread. Avoid leather soles and high heels. Problem: Traction on ice Solution: Metal "claws" or "grippers" that clip or strap onto the sole. Problem: Protecting shoes from snow, water or salt Solution: For heavy-duty boots or work shoes, many experts recommmend a beeswax paste; for dress shoes, silicone, although it darkens some leathers, or fluoropolymer sprays, usually sold as water and stain protectors. Mink oil is a natural leather conditioner that can also darken some leathers. Problem: Removing salt stains Solution: Liquid salt-stain removers or desalting products, salt neutralizers or desalters. After applying these products, experts recommend that shoes be cleaned with saddle soap, then polished. Sources: Amity Finding Company, D.& L. Leather Company, Joseph H. Deacon Company, Fiebing Company, Kiwi Brands Corporation and Original Mink Oil Inc.

title: Making Sure a Health Club Is on Strong Financial Ground
description: This is the time of the year when health-club memberships surge, as the best of intentions overcome inertia, holiday overeating and the winter blahs. If you are about to join a health club, don't let the euphoria of the moment overcome the basic warning that should apply to any purchase: let the buyer beware.

title: Students, Athletes And Politics
description: Shortly after war erupted in the Persian Gulf, college presidents began huddling with their athletic directors to determine a course of action. They decided that the games should go on, primarily because they were a source of entertainment and provided a much-needed diversion from the dreary reality of war.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Khafji Clash: Whose Loss?; U.S., Saudis and Iraq Can Claim Benefits
description: It all depends on which lens you look through. The battle of Khafji, which produced the first protracted ground fighting of the Persian Gulf war, was an insignificant Iraqi incursion easily thrown back, or a demonstration of Arab prowess in battle, or evidence that the initiative now lies with Baghdad, or a warning that grim combat and heavy casualties lie ahead for American ground troops here.

title: Review/Music; Met's First 'Fidelio' Of Season
description: The "Fidelio" that occupied the Metropolitan Opera's stage on Thursday evening carried the distinction of being the first of the season. That proved to be one of its few distinctions. This was another of those substandard, barely routine performances that always seem to turn up in the drear midseason weeks.

title: Peter J. Camiel, 81, Philadelphia Chief Of '70's Democrats
description: Peter J. Camiel, who headed Philadelphia's Democratic Party in the 1970's, died Thursday at Fatlands, his estate in Valley Forge, Pa. He celebrated his 81st birthday on Tuesday.

title: New York State Unemployment Up to 6.5%
description: Unemployment in New York State rose a full percentage point in January, to 6.5 percent. And the jobless rate in New Jersey also jumped, to 6.4 percent from 5.7 percent.

title: U.S. and British Dispute On Air Routes Heats Up
description: A dispute between the United States and Britain over transferring the landing and takeoff rights at Heathrow Airport near London from Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways to American Airlines and United Airlines has escalated into a major diplomatic row during the last two months.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 23 about the use of tranquilizing drugs and restraints in nursing homes misstated an affiliation of Dr. Robert L. Kane. He is at the University of Minnesota, not the University of Pennsylvania. The article also rendered a remark by Dr. Kane incorrectly. He said doctors -- not regulators -- might change their prescribing habits if Federal rules were onerous.

title: U.S. Study Finds a Reduced Cancer Danger From Radon in Homes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would probably reduce its estimates of the amount of lung cancer caused by radon gas in homes.

title: New England Bank
description: Moving quickly to find potential buyers for the failed Bank of New England, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation set a March 15 deadline for interested bidders. The F.D.I.C. chairman, L. William Seidman, said bids would be accepted for three subsidiary banks in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine or for the entire franchise. The F.D.I.C. seized the Bank of New England on Jan. 6.

title: Payments Are Missed By T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it had defaulted on $75.5 million in payments on various notes. The airline said it wanted to conserve cash in the face of a severe drop in bookings that could last into the summer.

title: Dinkins's Trip to Israel Upsets Some Blacks
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, who is scheduled to leave for Israel today to show support for Israelis and American troops, is leaving behind a swirl of controversy over what the visit means for black-Jewish relations at home.

title: The Wrong Cause at the Worst Time
description: The strategic disaster of our time is unfolding.

title: Florio Vetoes Measure For 'Smokers' Rights'
description: Gov. Jim Florio, saying smoking is not a civil right, has vetoed a "smokers' rights" bill that would have prohibited employers from discriminating against workers because of their smoking habits away from the job.

title: Earthquake Kills 109 in Pakistan
description: A severe earthquake jolted the country before dawn today, sending panic-stricken residents fleeing into the streets. Officials quoted by the official press agency said that at least 109 people in Pakistan had been killed and 350 injured.

title: Gulf War Proving Bountiful For Some Prophets of Doom
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has flooded bookstores with works by veteran reporters, military planners and first-hand witnesses of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship. But most of these books are being outsold by "Armageddon, Oil and the Middle East Crisis," which promises on its cover to tell "what the Bible says about the future of the Middle East and the end of Western civilization."

title: Patents; An Industrial Pump To Move Solid Materials
description: A British scientist obtained an American patent this week on an industrial pump that he believes will simplify the job of moving anything from coal powder in an electric utility to beans and peas in a food processing plant.

title: Big California Utility Deal Is Set Back
description: The proposed merger of two large California utilities was dealt another setback today when two officials of the California Public Utilities Commission recommended against the deal.

title: About New York; He's in Arabia; She, in the Bronx, In Her Own Fight
description: Carmen Valentin hasn't heard from her husband, Andy, since the war began. He is an Army private somewhere in Saudi Arabia.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.56 percent this week, down from 9.61 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate matched the 9.56 percent level reached Jan. 4, which had been the lowest since a 9.43 percent rate in mid-April 1987. Rates peaked in 1990 at 10.67 percent in early May. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.75 percent, up from 7.69 percent last week.

title: Bush to Propose 'Star Wars' Rise In Arms Budget
description: President Bush is proposing a Pentagon budget of $295 billion for the fiscal year 1992 that includes $4.6 billion for "Star Wars" and money for four new Stealth bombers, Congressional officials said today.

title: Withdraw Gulf War Press Restrictions
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: After 28 years with WNBC-TV in New York City, BOB TEAGUE, the reporter and anchor, retired yesterday. The station said his tenure was the longest unbroken run for any television journalist in the city.

title: Opera's Revision Defines a Composer
description: After its premiere engagement at the New York City Opera in 1962, "The Passion of Jonathan Wade" was never performed again. Audiences applauded, but the critics were less than enthusiastic. As a result, the opera was never published and was all but forgotten, even by its composer and librettist, Carlisle Floyd.

title: Newsstand Plan For 5th Avenue Suffers Setback
description: Plans to build the first newsstand on the midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue -- right in front of Cartier jewelers -- have been upset by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Vote on Teacher Wage Plan
description: Teachers union officials said yesterday that they were worried that the rank and file might have defeated a plan to defer wages to save 3,000 jobs. Ballots cast by the United Federation of Teachers' 85,000 members were collected yesterday and are to be tallied this afternoon.

title: Choosing Sides; In the Mideast, A Fear That War Is Only The Beginning
description: EIGHTEEN days after the fighting began, it is obvious that the progress of the Persian Gulf war has deepened Arab wounds and widened the confusion throughout the Middle East over who is right and who is wrong, what the fighting is all about, and even how to define victory.

title: Postings: East Side Town House; Thailand's New Offices
description: The New York representatives of the Government of Thailand are settling into a new mission on the East Side. The six-story town house at 351 East 52d Street -- which was blessed by nine Buddhist monks in an elaborate ceremony in December -- had been a gutted eyesore. But now renovations are almost complete for Thailand's United Nations delegation, as well as for the Royal Thai Consulate General.

title: From Riches to Rags
description: SQUANDERED FORTUNE The Life and Times of Huntington Hartford. By Lisa Rebecca Gubernick. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

title: Style Makers; Claire Carlevaro, Art Dealer
description: Claire Carlevaro was wondering where to hang a painting she was about to buy at an auction when the idea occurred to her: an unpretentious consignment shop devoted exclusively to selling secondhand contemporary art. So in 1984, Mrs. Carlevaro, an art collector who had studied medieval art at Barnard College, opened the Art Exchange in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Are Women Serious About Finding a Mate?
description: I have been a widower for 21 months and started dating seriously about nine months ago.

title: Metro Dateline; Bail Plea for Woman In Child-Abuse Case
description: A psychiatrist testified on Friday that Margaret Kelly Michaels is not a danger to society and that she should be released on bail while her conviction on charges of sexually abusing 19 pre-school children is appealed.

title: The Murky World of Newspaper Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op and Condo Delinquencies Rising
description: IN a pattern showing up with increasing frequency at condominiums and cooperatives across the country, nine of the 31 shareholders at 210 West 103d Street -- a 50-year-old brick building in New York City's Manhattan Valley neighborhood -- have fallen more than 60 days behind in their monthly maintenance payments of about $725.

title:
ART;
The Possibilities of Abstractions, as Explored by Five Artists
description: THE word abstract has many definitions, but in art it refers most often to imagery that epitomizes the essence of a subject.

title: Mary K. Vergara To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Vergara of Westtown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Kathryn Vergara to Thomas Nelson Cook Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cook of Houston. An April wedding is planned.

title: Despite War, Pentagon Plans Big Cuts
description: Faced with severe budget pressures, the Pentagon is proceeding with its plan to reduce the armed forces by a quarter by 1995 despite the war in the Persian Gulf and renewed strains in American-Soviet relations.

title: Bush Blurs Home Goals
description: Republican aides and analysts responded to the domestic side of President Bush's State of the Union Message this week as though it were a Rorschach test, with each projecting different hopes and fears onto what seemed to be its indeterminate content.

title: Style Makers; Jane Brook Barba, Horticulturist
description: In winter, gardeners live with thoughts of spring, and Jane Brook Barba is a gardener with a mission. "I want to bring back the eco-systems that were here when I was a kid so that the bluebirds and the wildflowers that were everywhere will also return," the 45-year-old horticulturist said.

title: A Dying Man's Fierce Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Notre Dame; Minority Students Present Demands To Administration
description: In a reprise of minority student activism during the 1960's, a coalition of black, Hispanic and Indian students at Notre Dame last week presented the administration with a list of demands that include establishing a racial harassment policy, increasing the number of minority faculty members, improving ethnic studies programs and establishing a multicultural center.

title: Steinberg Defends Moves
description: Just before the Friday deadline for declaring what players he planned to protect from the Plan B free-agent market, General Manager Dick Steinberg went out and made a couple of deals that brought 600 pounds of heft to the Jets' offensive line.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Fourth-quarter productivity figures. * Meeting of European Community foreign and agriculture ministers. * President Bush sends 1992 budget request to Congress. * G.M. board meeting. * Eastern Airlines auction. TUESDAY: December factory orders. * January auto sales. WEDNESDAY: Chicago Auto Show preview begins. THURSDAY: Major retailers announce January sales figures and 1990 results.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
A Convention Hotel Proposed for Yonkers
description: OVER the last couple of years, there have been three proposals for new hotels in Yonkers. All face problems. One hinges in part on a will now being probated, bankruptcy proceedings impede a second and the third is awaiting a better economic climate. Moreover, many in the hotel industry say Westchester County already has a surfeit of rooms.

title:
Your Own Account;
When in Recession, Think Cycles
description: If you are worried about the recession and what is happening -- or is likely to happen -- to your job, income and life style, you should remember that the economy moves in cycles. Take heart from the experience of Houston, a city that suffered through its own recession in the 1980's while the rest of the country was booming. Houston is now on the upswing as other regions falter.

title: Carter Lynch to Marry Robert Adrian
description: Mr. and Mrs. George P. Lynch Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carter Tomlin Lynch to Robert Steward Adrian, a son of Irene S. Adrian of Boca Raton, Fla., and Richard A. Adrian of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Pilots Dead, Many Missing In Fiery Los Angeles Crash
description: Rescue workers at Los Angeles International Airport searched today for bodies in the charred wreckage of a USAir passenger jet and a small commuter plane as Federal investigators began their effort to determine why a seemingly normal landing by the jet turned into a fiery runway crash with the smaller craft Friday night.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of cruise lines on page 34 of the Travel section today omits three companies. They are Egon Oldendorff Line, Laeisz Line and Leonhardt & Blumberg Banana Boats, all represented in the United States by Freighter World Cruises, 180 South Lake Avenue, Suite 335, Pasadena, Calif. 91101; (818) 449-3106.

title: Personal Images From a Weaver and a Potter
description: A COMPATIBLE pairing of woven wall hangings and ceramic vessels offers an oasis of serenity at the Westchester Art Workshop here. Both Alice Ladziak's pots and Betty Vera's weavings, on view through Feb. 28 in the school's gallery, add a personal dimension to the visual language peculiar to a medium.

title: Business Diary/January 27 - February 1
description: THE ECONOMY Greenspan Points a Finger at the Persian Gulf War Jittery consumers and rising unemployment have made Alan Greenspan change his optimistic tone. On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Board chairman said that if the war drags on for more than three months, consumers will turn gloomy and the recession will become severe. On Friday, with a dismal unemployment report, he led the board in a unanimous vote to lower the discount rate a half-point to 6 percent, the second cut in six weeks. Banks responded by reducing their prime lending rate a half-point also, to 9 percent. Mr. Greenspan might be doing some pre-emptive rate-cutting and explaining. Politicians say he shares the blame for the recession, President Bush used his State of the Union address to press for lower interest rates, and Mr. Greenspan comes up for reappointment in August. If the economy does crash, Mr. Greenspan is in effect saying blame the war, not me. The Falling Payroll So much for the notion of a stabilizing economy. The Government said Friday that the nation's payrolls fell by 232,000 jobs and that the average workweek was a half-hour shorter in January. The unemployment rate climbed only one-tenth of a point, to 6.2 percent for the month, the highest rate since 1987, but analysts agreed that the figure understated the deterioration of the economy.

title: Stefanie Doak and Scott Frank to Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Hunt Doak of Ruxton, Md., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Stefanie Hamilton Doak, and Warren Scott Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren John Frank of West Newbury, Mass.

title: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DIRTY TRICKSBy Jack Matthews.Johns Hopkins University,Cloth, $26; Paper, $10.95.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Of all Western countries involved in the war against Iraq, Canada may have the least reason to fear terrorism. Unlike Britain, France and Italy, Canada has suffered no major terrorism attack in recent years from Palestinian groups or associates in Libya and Iraq.

title: Another Victory for Big Brother?
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Sue Dickstein Weds James L. Frank
description: Karen Sue Dickstein and James Lewis Frank were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi Saul Teplitz. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dickstein of Muttontown, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Frank of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I.

title: Sundance Plumbs Urban Darkness
description: Urban corruption and urban despair seem out of place in this picture postcard village with the snow cone mountain at the top of Main Street. But the two movies that resonated -- for very different reasons -- at the 1991 Sundance Film Festival come from the dark heart of city life.

title: The World; In the Long Run, the Oil Spill May Be Less Than Disastrous
description: THOUGH the huge oil slick in the Persian Gulf still threatens Saudi desalting plants, scientists who study the effects of oil at sea say that the spill might not produce the environmental damage once feared. Because the oil has been at sea for more than a week, they say, sunlight, waves and wind have already caused its most toxic chemicals to evaporate. The rest has probably become a far less sticky and poisonous mass of floating tar.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BLACK-HISTORY MONTH

title: The Persistence of Poison Gas
description: Since August, the woman has been gazing at pictures of gas-masked soldiers in the Persian Gulf with a special fascination and sorrow. Her grandfather, whom she never knew, died from exposure to mustard gas during World War I.

title: Lisa Ruth Becker Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John T. Becker of Greenwich, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Ruth Becker and Thomas Dunham Edmundson, a son of Robert T. Edmundson of Greenwich and Jane Norman Edmundson of New York.

title: When Patients Can't or Don't Pay
description: As a physician in practice in New Jersey, I read with interest the article "Hospitals Worried About Fund for Poor" (Dec. 23.). I understand the concern, but would like to raise several related issues.

title: Headliners; In Detention
description: Israel's arrest of a West Bank political leader as a spy last Tuesday amid the increasingly tense atmosphere of Iraqi missile attacks was startling for the prominence of the suspect. Sari Nusseibeh, a leading West Bank intellectual and a member of one of Jerusalem's most prominent Palestinian clans, has been a contact for American Congressional delegations and Israeli antiwar groups alike. The 41-year-old philosopher was sentenced to six months of administrative detention on charges of, among other things, collecting intelligence for Iraq. Officials asserted that he had passed data about missile strikes to the Iraqis that could be used to improve their aim. Calls came from the right for his expulsion and from the left for a trial. Amnesty International demanded that Israel support the charges or release him. The prisoner denied the allegations, saying, "It seems that the authorities want to benefit from the present atmosphere of dehumanizing Iraq to justify my arrest."

title: Germany and Japan -- Dragging Their Boots
description: In 1945, Germany and Japan, as defeated Axis powers, were driven from international politics by the victorious Allies. Now, the United States and Britain are insisting they return. Last week Chancellor Kohl acknowledged that Germany can no longer duck its global responsibilities. But can Washington have what it really wants -- a globally active yet obedient Germany and Japan?

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SPORTS ON AND UNDER ICE

title: Four Gorbachev Years: Hope to Disillusion/A special report.; In Soviet Life, Thaw Becomes Chill
description: The trajectory of hope inspired by Mikhail S. Gorbachev began and ended, in the minds of many of his citizens, with two telephone calls, four tumultuous years apart.

title: Upgrading Is Promised For Rural Phone Lines
description: BARBARA BARRY said her telephone has often been dead during the 19 years she has lived in Morris. She said she especially recalls the day she fell on the ice outside her home and fractured her leg. When she crawled inside and picked up the telephone, she recalled, she heard no dial tone. She was home alone with her infant daughter, Mrs. Barry said, and as she waited 15 minutes for the tone, she feared she would go into shock.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bellmore $115,000 142 Barbara Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old bungalow; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage, 500 feet of waterfront; taxes $1,500. Brentwood 125,000 7 Quarles Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; entry foyer, den, central air-conditioning, 80- by 140-foot lot, 1-car garage; taxes $4,200. East Meadow 172,000 2791 Cypress Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $5,500. Hicksville 115,000 15 Bond Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $,900. Kings Park $152,500 118 Aspen Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, skylights, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Massapequa $205,000 126 Rumson Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,600. OTHER AREAS Chester, N.J. 168,000 616 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; brick fireplace, 1-car garage, h/w floors, full basement; taxes $2,600. Rye, N.Y. 375,000 8 Martin Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old contemporary; family room, 2 fireplaces, screened porch, 1.3 acres; taxes $9,558. Bridgeport, Conn. 148,000 30 Holland Hill Circle 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old cape cod; fireplace, 1-car garage, 50- by 160-foot lot; taxes $3,456.

title: Crash Renews Concerns About Safety at Los Angeles Airport
description: The runway collision here Friday night is raising renewed concern about safety at Los Angeles International Airport, where both the skies and the runways are among the most congested in the world.

title: Speaking In Tongues
description: To the Editor:

title: Corinne Gillick Marries
description: Corinne A. Gillick and Edwin Richard Fivekiller were married yesterday at the Richardson (Tex.) Woman's Club. Judge Cameron D. Gray of Precinct 6 in Dallas County officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Gillick of Richardson. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Fivekiller of Fort Smith, Ark. Mrs. Fivekiller, a creative supervisor at Grey Advertising in New York, graduated from the University of Oklahoma. The bridegroom, an associate manager for capital planning and construction at the New York Public Library, received a bachelor's degree and a master's in public administration from the University of Arkansas.

title: Postings: Manhattan Valley; Mixed-Income Rehabs
description: Over the last few years, Manhattan Valley, on the Upper West Side, has been emerging from the sort of vacuum that sucks the life out of communities overtaken by drugs and abandonent.

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY ON THE GULF CRISIS -- ROME;
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: The number of passengers and the air traffic at Fiumicino Airport have dropped by as much as 40 percent as the airport, like others throughout Italy, swarms with police officers, dogs, soldiers, paramilitary Carabinieri, armed customs officers and plainclothes agents.

title: Campus Life: Stanford; A New Magazine Is a Joint Venture With Moscow U.
description: Despite the clouded out look for continued political and economic reform in the Soviet Union, student editors are celebrating the release of the first issue of a new Soviet-American college magazine published at Stanford University.

title: For New Art, a Building Drenched in Art History
description: In the collective memory of today's French artists, as well as their public, the Jeu de Paume represents that initial, often emotional, encounter with one of France's foremost moments in art. The building at the northwest end of the Tuilerie Gardens became synonymous with Impressionism when masterpieces of late-19th-century French painting were transferred there from the Louvre in 1947. In deference to their tenants, the rooms bore proper names, so that visitors moved from the Salle Degas to the Salle Cezanne to the Salle Monet.

title: Nader Group Asks Data on State's Nuclear Plants
description: A NATIONAL consumer group has written to the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to demand the release of safety information on the state's nuclear power plants.

title: Data Bank/February 3, 1991
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Hartsfield International Airport here has not experienced major delays or disruptions for security reasons; rather the closing of Eastern Airlines on Jan. 18 accounts for a major drop in airport passengers.

title: Portrait Miniatures: The Bigger Picture
description: Exquisitely painted images of children with ancient faces, women in sausage curls and lace-edged gowns and stern-eyed men wearing steel-rimmed glasses and high stiff collars -- the snapshots of yesteryear -- dominate "Tokens of Affection: The Portrait Miniature in America." The exhibition remains through next Sunday in the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Huggies and Isaac Newton
description: SCIENCE MATTERS Achieving Scientific Literacy. By Robert M. Hazen and James Trefil. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Headliners; Off the Air
description: Throughout his stint as Mayor of New York, Edward I. Koch appeared in the media so many times that he decided he might as well get paid for it. Since he was voted out of office in 1989, he has made much more money than he did in public service, not only as a partner in a law firm but also as a New York Post columnist, a lecturer, a commentator on WNEW-AM, and, until last week, a co-host for WCBS-TV's Sunday morning news program. "They found me too controversial," Mr. Koch said. "I was giving them too much agita with my provocative and candid comments, and at age 66, even though they thought I should tone myself down, there's no way in the world that I can change my personality." The decision to buy out Mr. Koch's contract came after Representative Charles B. Rangel complained that the former mayor implied that he was anti-Semitic. Mr. Koch insists that he merely criticized Mr. Rangel for supporting Representative Gus Savage of Illinois, whom Mr. Koch does consider an anti-Semite.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 14-17

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A Mt. Laurel Ruling Backs Impact Fees
description: AS a result of a recent New Jersey Supreme Court ruling, the Council on Affordable Housing will draft regulations under which communities may impose fees on developers to help pay for low- and moderate-income housing required by the state's Mount Laurel decisions.

title: Postal Service Is Sued Over Pollution Fears
description: New York City is suing the United States Postal Service to halt construction of a proposed $100-million mail center in Westchester County that the city said would pollute a major drinking-water reservoir.

title: Unexplored Territory, A Recession in Services
description: The unusual wave of white collar layoffs in the early stages of this recession is a sign that the United States service sector, once heralded as a powerful engine for new jobs, is undergoing a broad retrenchment, much as the manufacturing sector did in the past decade.

title: President to Seek $23 Billion Saving in Medicare Costs
description: Just three months after signing legislation to cut Medicare payments to hospitals and doctors by $32 billion over five years, President Bush will ask Congress on Monday to cut at least $23 billion more in a similar period from the fast-growing program.

title:
A Special Guide to Cruises Worldwide;
Ships Set Course for Calmer Waters
description: RESPONDING to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, with its threat of terrorism, cruise lines are moving ships out of the eastern Mediterranean and into less-volatile regions.

title: Rebecca A. Lang to Wed
description: October wedding plans for Rebecca Ann Lang and James Allen Russell 2d, a son of Jeanne Russell of Westfield, N.J., and James D. Russell of Garwood, N.J., have been announced by her parents, Joan Lang of Westfield and Allan Lang of Princeton Junction, N.J. Miss Lang, 22 years old, graduated from Smith College. She is an assistant editor at Joshua Morris Publishing, children's book publishers in Wilton, Conn. Her fiance, 23, is studying architecture at the Rhode Island School of Design, where he received a bachelor's degree.

title:
MUSIC;
English Trio's Concert Offers 17th-Century Works
description: AUDIENCES listening to the Consort of Musicke, an English ensemble specializing in early music, sometimes have to adjust their expectations about the volume and type of sound they are accustomed to hearing in vocal and instrumental performances.

title: Hidden Messages in Indian Artifacts
description: POWERFUL and sacred qualities of nature are embodied in two exhibitions of crafts by American Indians. In the shadowy stillness of the Rand Gallery of the Montclair Art Museum, ravens, whales, frogs and rattlesnakes echo tales that have been repeated by generations of the first Americans. Although the words remain unspoken, their images tell of legendary gods, of hunts and prayers for a good harvest.

title: As Economy Changes, the Port Authority Must Overcome Its Own Image
description: Tapestries adorn the walls and helicopters carry officials to meetings, but these days the once-prosperous Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is in the unaccustomed position of paring costs and pleading for money.

title: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .; Blacks in the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of the Times; Fragrance-Free Reading
description: They're back -- the magazines that smell. January is one of the few months when they don't. No jasmine in post-holiday January. No musk. No floral bouquet. But sensitive noses can no longer breathe easy. "Scent strips" have returned with the February issues.

title: IF I'D STOOD UP EARLIER
description: Goodson showed welcome candor in reassessing the role he played during the blacklisting period. One of his own stars, John Henry Faulk, did stand up to the blacklist -- and won. Faulk was targeted in 1955 by Aware Incorporated. CBS, under pressure from advertisers, dropped his program. But Faulk refused to play the role of victim, suing Aware for defamation. His case took six years to come to trial, but the jury, inspired in part by Goodson's effective testimony on Faulk's behalf, awarded him $3.5 million in damages. But Aware was by then out of money and Faulk couldn't collect. GARA LA MARCHE New York, N.Y.

title: The Dollars and Sense Of a $2 Million Comedy
description: Forget the conventional Broadway wisdom. Even common sense suggests that one would have to be loony to spend $2 million to produce the first play of a novice writer -- a faux-Moliere comedy about art written in rhyming couplets, no less -- and, as it turned out, with no stars. But that is exactly what the co-producers Stuart Ostrow ("1776," "Pippin" and "M. Butterfly") and Andrew Lloyd Webber are doing.

title: Mutual Funds; Global Bond Funds' Gulf Strategy
description: Managers of global bond funds were among the top performers last year. But now they're at the center of wildly volatile international markets. Their worst nightmare, they say, is this: Iraq bombs the oil fields of Saudi Arabia, disrupting world oil supplies, sending up inflation and depressing bond prices. A major breakdown in the flow of oil is the wild card in all of their strategies, the worst-case scenario.

title:
The Executive Life;
An Auction Pandering To Well-Bred Ambition
description: "Mikey, Pikey, Wikey!" The little girl's taunting challenge to her younger brother suddenly rang out in the huge room in Greenwich Village's Puck Building where Guernsey's Auction House was holding its much-ballyhooed Gentleman's Auction. With a ferocious scowl, the children's father spun around to hiss at the two: "I said stop it! I mean it! I'm trying to hear the bidding on the trains."

title: Ideas & Trends; The Push to Consider A Once Taboo Subject: National School Tests
description: IS there something un-American about testing all elementary and high school students and providing the results to colleges and potential employers?

title: White House Proposes Curbs on Insured Deposits
description: As part of its plan to overhaul the banking system, the Bush Administration has decided to seek a limit on the number of personal and corporate bank accounts insured by the Government, but the restrictions are less severe than had been anticipated, senior Administration officials in Washington said yesterday.

title: Deciding on Rose
description: The directors of the Baseball Hall of Fame will vote tomorrow on whether to bar Pete Rose and anyone else on baseball's ineligible list from selection to the Cooperstown shrine.

title: Topics of the Times; Sunlight in the Capitol
description: Would the five Senators now under scrutiny in the Keating Five case have intervened so aggressively on behalf of a big campaign contributor if they had known their tactics would have to withstand public scrutiny? The question answers itself, confirming the wisdom of a simple ethics rule proposed by Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader.

title: Subway Arson Foiled by Chemical System
description: A man who tried to set fire to a subway token booth in Manhattan yesterday was foiled by a chemical suppression system that automatically kicked in when the flames started, the transit police said.

title: Businesses Try to Trim Health-Care Costs
description: SPENDING $11.2 million to build a luxury hotel may not seem like a way to cut down health-care costs. But saving money is the idea behind the New Haven Medical Hotel. The hotel, designed to serve patients recovering from surgery who do not need a more costly hospital room, is one of several new approaches being used by Connecticut businesses to try to control spiraling medical-care costs.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Marines; War Is Vivid In Gun Sights Of the Sniper
description: In an age of lasers and computers, of guided missiles and smart bombs, the intimate tragedy of war perhaps seems most apparent when seen through the sights of a sniper's rifle.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: In the giant Frankfurt airport, police and security agents, many with automatic rifles, seem to outnumber passengers. The cavernous waiting rooms, normally jammed, were strangely quiet 10 days into the gulf war. "I've never seen this place so empty," said one traveler before a flight to Berlin. "The only people around here are soldiers and people who booked in advance and have to fly."

title: Three Opera Releases Kick Off a Mozart Year
description: With the onset of the Mozart year, Polygram Classics has favored us with not one but three new Mozart operas. Each has its merits; none displaces beloved past recordings.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in an apartment on the first floor of a six-story building. At times, the kitchen sink accumulates soapy suds or cloudy water that backs up from the drain. Thesuperintendent installed what he called a "check valve," which helped for a while, but now the condition has returned. Can this be corrected?

title: Delinquencies of Condo and Co-op Owners Rising
description: In a pattern showing up with increasing frequency at condominiums and cooperatives across the country, nine of the 31 shareholders at 210 West 103d Street -- a 50-year-old brick building in New York City's Manhattan Valley neighborhood -- have fallen more than 60 days behind in their monthly maintenance payments of about $725.

title: Wall Street; Supermarkets That Win Favor, Even With 'Junk'
description: Given the incessant grousing by reluctant "junk bond" holders -- from insurance companies to Uncle Sam -- it is notable to hear of investors who won't part with their junk for love or money. The owners of the Kroger Company's junior subordinated notes, for example.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iran; Iran Said to Reject Warplanes' Exit
description: In a renewed affirmation of neutrality, Iran was reported today to have rejected appeals by a senior envoy from Baghdad for the return of Iraqi warplanes that flew to Iran in quest of sanctuary from allied air-strikes.

title: Campus Life: Purdue; Fraternities Adopt A Ban on Kegs At Their Parties
description: Beer kegs will soon be a thing of the past at fraternity and sorority parties at Purdue University. Come March 10, it's strictly B.Y.O.B.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: O'Hare, the nation's busiest airport, has traditionally been among the more lenient. While other airports have long prohibited nonpassengers in the gate area, the gates at O'Hare have often been the scene of reunion bottlenecks. And, while some airports routinely ticket or tow waiting cars, Chicago motorists lingered with impunity.

title: Postings: After 200 Years; Scarsdale Town Houses
description: While the rest of the country got dotted with condominium developments like a kid getting freckles, Scarsdale -- the real Scarsdale -- remained untouched. Now, after 200 years as a village, it is getting its own little town-house project.

title: A Hole in the Stained-Glass Window
description: FALLING By Colin Thubron. 152 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: IF I'D STOOD UP EARLIER
description: There is a subtle yet dangerous message in Mark Goodson's article, namely, that the television blacklisting of the 1950's was wrong only because it hurt "innocent" victims. Thus, for example, Goodson tells us how he lost his temper over the attempted blacklisting of the actress Anna Lee because she was being confused with a writer of the same name.

title: Little Bit of Luck Benefited Giants
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Security at London's airports is at unprecedented levels, officials say. At Heathrow, armed soldiers in camouflage gear and armored vehicles stand guard outside. At both Gatwick and Heathrow Airports, heavily armed police officers in armored vests are on patrol, and additional security people frisk more passengers than usual and hand-search more carry-on bags.

title: Joanne Fox to Marry
description: Elaine Fox of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced September wedding plans for her daughter Joanne Fox and Jonathan Samuel Shapse, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Shapse of Chester, N.J. Miss Fox, 24 years old, is also the daughter of the late Dr. Leonard J. Fox. She graduated from the State University at Oneonta, N.Y., and is a sales manager for Evian Waters of France in Philadelphia. Her fiance, 27, is a vice president and the treasurer of Design Concepts Plus, a designer of kitchens and bathrooms in Havertown, Pa. He is a graduate of Skidmore College.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ERNEST PRINCE;
Pressing Country Clubs to Accept Blacks
description: THE county, with its 41 private and semiprivate golf clubs, some of them nationally known, is a dream place for those who like to tee up -- especially if they are affluent white men.

title: THE BIG FIVE OH
description: As the 48-year-old wife of a man who recently turned 50, I was charmed by Tom Brokaw's essay. Our family's approach to the event was to throw a giant rock 'n' roll party, a whole-hearted celebration of all things 50. It's rumored that even Elvis put in an appearance. SARA JASPER COOK Peekskill, N.Y.

title: A Stirring Giant
description: CHINA'S FATE A People's Turbulent Struggle With Reform and Repression, 1980-1990. By Edward A. Gargan. 340 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; Copter Pilot, After Battle, No Longer Sees Quick War
description: For the Marine pilot, Michael Steele, what he'd read in books and heard in lectures about the prowess of Iraqi soldiers was finally tested this week, and Major Steele left the confrontation all the more anxious about the fight to come.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Return 8 Missiles to Nicaragua
description: Leftist Salvadoran rebels today returned 8 of 28 Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles illegally transferred to them by officers of the Nicaraguan Army.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in an apartment on the first floor of a six-story building. At times, the kitchen sink accumulates soapy suds or cloudy water that backs up from the drain. Thesuperintendent installed what he called a "check valve," which helped for a while, but now the condition has returned. Can this be corrected?

title: Weicker Recruits His Team
description: LOUIS S. GOLDBERG is hardly a party hack. The 53-year-old business executive from Weston had never before sought public office and never toiled for a political party before his nomination last month by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to be the state's Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Miss Halikias Is Married To Dr. D. H. Montgomery
description: Katherine T. Halikias, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Demitrios Halikias of Garden City, L.I., was married at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday to Dr. David Harrop Montgomery, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lancaster Montgomery of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. William Pindar performed the ceremony.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Cambridge, Mass.;
A Hotel Rises On the Square
description: A 114-ROOM, $10 million hotel now rising on the outer edge of Harvard Square will be the first new hotel in the area in six years.

title: Said a Speaker To a Living Room: 'Speak to Me'
description: You may live in spacious splendor or a cramped studio apartment; your taste may run to thick rugs, overstuffed sofas or minimalist furniture and hard surfaces. Whatever the case, the loudspeaker designer has no clue to the acoustic quirks of your home.

title: BONN WILL RETURN PROPERTY IN EAST
description: Heinz Stern was 26 when his father was dragged off to the Buchenwald concentration camp and forced to sign a contract surrendering a family-owned flour mill to a German owner. The mill's new owner, in turn, lost it after World War II, as Soviet occupation officials nationalized key industries in east Germany.

title: How One Work Colors an Entire Museum
description: When the J. Paul Getty Museum acquired James Ensor's "Christ's Entry Into Brussels in 1889" three years ago, my response was sadness. I felt that this familiar but still little-known late-19th-century landmark belonged in Europe. Yet I wanted to see how it looked in the Getty, and if sadness was appropriate.

title: For a Weekend Treat, Dim Sum
description: AT North Sea Village, a bright new Cantonese restaurant in Livingston, several large round tables were filled with Chinese families on a recent Saturday morning, some of them three generations together. At one, a man playfully clapped his hands to entertain his infant grandson.

title: Headliners; The Rainy Season That Never Came
description: CALIFORNIANS fight over water the way other people fight over religion, land and oil. The north, where the Sierras provide a vast watershed, fights with the desert south, which needs a continuous stream of water to support its thirsty life style. The city dwellers fight with the farmers, whose industry is addicted to cheap, government-subsidized water and dependent on the state's mammoth irrigation projects.
