And the environmentalists fight with the dam builders whenever another large water project threatens a land whose main selling points have always included its beauty.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Britain; In Cotswold Town, Chance to Relive Finest Hour as B-52's Return
description: The Royal Air Force flew British Stirling bombers against targets in Germany from here in World War II, and gliders that landed 250 troops behind the beaches of Normandy on June 6, 1944.

title: Composition As Compost? Rotten Idea
description: Merciless historians remind us that 99.44 percent of all the music composed in any age is mediocre or worse. As if we needed reminding. But they also ask us to look at the bright side: though a new work may prove to have the shelf life of warm sushi, it serves an indispensable role in the creation of great musical art. Over time, these mountains of discarded scores act as the compost in which a few masterpieces can grow.

title: The World; If It's Good News For the Oil Industry, The World Beware
description: THERE is war in the Persian Gulf, recession nationwide and stubbornly high gasoline prices on every street corner, but over the last few days the major oil companies have nervously weighed in with news of a different tone: their profits are up sharply.

title: Ms. Bell Marries John E. Avery 3d
description: Elisabeth Claire Bell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Bell of Tulsa, Okla., was married in New York yesterday to John Edwin Avery 3d, a son of Mr. Avery 2d of Princeton, N.J., and Antonietta Avery of New York. Judy Wank, a minister of the Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Americas Society.

title: Doormat No More?
description: As the New York City Council flexes its newfound muscles against an embattled Mayor David N. Dinkins, it has borrowed a page from the book of the Tammany Hall philosopher George Washington Plunkitt: It seen its opportunities and it took 'em.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan/The Talk of Amman; Understanding Hussein: An Orphan Who Fights to Be Remembered
description: In the health clubs and barber shops, the talk across Amman is of the war, and a theme that recurs is that Saddam Hussein is an enigma only to the infidels who cannot grasp the Islamic and more personal history that has molded his current persona.

title: Chasing Few Buyers With Too Many Tires
description: Tom H. Barrett has had a gruelling two-year tenure as chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Since he took over, Goodyear, once known by its rivals as The Gorilla because of its dominance of the world tire business, has lost the lead to France's Groupe Michelin. And the tire business has taken a turn for the worst.

title: Jill Rubin Plans August Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Rubin of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Allison Rubin to Louis Lowell Plotkin, a son of Judge and Mrs. Steven Plotkin of New Orleans. An August wedding is planned.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Casualties; Pentagon Seems Vague on the Iraqis' Death Toll
description: After more than two weeks of war in the Persian Gulf involving the heaviest sustained bombing in history, the Pentagon is avoiding any estimate of Iraqi deaths so far.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Battling Nature in the Sculpture Garden
description: IN her waterproof boots and layers of goose down, wool and fleece, Pamela A. Popeson is an unorthodox sight to those expecting art conservators to wear white gloves and lab coats.

title: Maureen Cleary To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Thomas J. Cleary of Bronxville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Maureen Mary Cleary, to Paul Joseph Colligan, a son of Marcia W. Colligan of Hanover, N.H., and the late George A. Colligan. A June wedding is planned.

title: Margaret Schellbach, Accountant, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Schellbach of Manhasset, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Margaret Jane Schellbach and Ronald J. Fraser, a son of Karen Jensen of Mount Vernon, Wash., and the late Douglas H. Fraser of Alsgarde, Denmark, and Freeport, the Bahamas.

title: Traffic Fatalities Show Drop
description: DESPITE the fact that there are more people driving more cars on more crowded highways in New Jersey, and more people driving in excess of the speed limit than ever before, the state's traffic fatalities have dipped to their lowest number since 1961, according to figures released by the New Jersey Division of Highway Traffic Safety.

title: Hot Blues Too Much for Devils
description: Brett Hull scored his 53d goal of the season and Adam Oates had a goal and two assists to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 5-4 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: The Game of Life: Preparing for It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sara Nase to Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul K. Nase of Reading, Pa., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Sara Beth Nase, and Knute Andrew Leidal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Knute H. Leidal of Warren, N.J. Miss Nase, 28 years old, graduated from Bucknell University. Mr. Leidal, 31, graduated from the United States Military Academy. Both are engineers for General Electric in Springfield, Va.

title: Amber Lea Bohmfalk Marries Patrick Turner
description: Amber Lea Bohmfalk and Patrick Noel Waddington Turner were married yesterday at the Park Avenue Christian Church in New York. The Rev. Allen V. Harris performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN SILENCE Growing Up Hearing in a Deaf World. By Ruth Sidransky. St. Martin's, $18.95.

title: New Mattingly Awaits a New Season
description: The mustache is gone and so are perhaps a few pounds. So is the grueling work schedule that had long served as a personal trademark. For Don Mattingly, that's the way things have got to be from now on.

title: The Next Surprise?
description: Could it be that Saddam Hussein is now maneuvering toward proposing a cease-fire and announcing the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait?

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Streetscapes column about the Chapel of the Sisters on Jan. 27 misidentified the Queens Borough Historian. He is Henry Ludder.

title: Sunday Dinner; For the Love of Lamb, In Many Ethnic Styles
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some places to enjoy lamb. Alison on Dominick Street

title: Misconceptions On 'Tennis Teens'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The World; For the Economy, the Gulf War Has Little Impact -- So Far
description: WAR has a way of putting lesser matters in a different perspective, but as a number of politicians and economists noted last week, it does not make them disappear. Washington must still cope with the age-old issues of guns vs. butter. And mercifully, economists say, if there is ever such a thing as the right time to fight a war, this is it. Unless Iraq manages to wreak havoc in the Saudi oilfields or shocks American consumers into a prolonged and unaccustomed bout of self-denial, it will barely cause a ripple in the economy.

title: Chopin Meets the Slam Dunk
description: If, for whatever cockeyed reason, you wanted to cast a classical musician alongside a professional athlete in a sneaker commercial, you might find a likely candidate or two. But you would find a host of unlikely ones, and among the very least plausible would be the pianist Rudolf Firkusny.

title: Winning Their Hearts and Minds
description: FACING THE PHOENIX By Zalin Grant. Illustrated. 395 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: Laura Billington Is Engaged to Timothy Helmig
description: Elizabeth S. Bell of Wilton, Conn., and Robert L. Billington of Charlotte, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Louise Billington to Timothy Quinn Helmig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary Helmig of Wilton. An August wedding is planned.

title: Paying a Merger's Dues: More Tough Times at Unisys
description: The Unisys Corporation is being held up these days as an example -- but hardly in a flattering way.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Perth
description: To many people Perth means sailing, and specifically the America's Cup, following the successful United States challenge in neighboring Fremantle in 1987, but the city, isolated at the southwest corner of Australia, is also a frontier town of the 21st century. Four hours' flying time from Sydney, Perth is the state capital of an area stretching one million square miles north to the Kimberley Range and east to the Nullarbor Plain and the Simpson Desert.

title: Unknown Designers Parade Dreams Before Fashion Arbiters at 'Open-See'
description: Teresa Tymoski, a vice president of Henri Bendel, looked at a mohair chartreuse sweater the other day and nearly squealed in delight. "Fabulous," she said, holding the sweater over her black jacket.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Navratilova to Face Sabatini: Martina Navratilova defeated Laura Gildemeister of Peru, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday in Tokyo and moved into the final of the Pan Pacific Open against Gabriela Sabatini, who beat Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Sweden Eliminated in Davis Cup: Sweden, which reached the Davis Cup final for seven consecutive years in the 1980's, was eliminated in the first round yesterday. Yugoslavia clinched a victory over Sweden when Goran Ivanisevic and Goran Prpic beat Stefan Edberg and Peter Lundgren, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4, in doubles in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. The victories gave Yugoslavia an unbeatable 3-0 lead in the three-of-five-match competition. In another opening-round series, Italy took a 2-1 lead over Germany when Diego Nargiso and Omar Camporese beat Boris Becker and Eric Jelen, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6, 4-6, 6-3, in Dortmund. In other first-round matches, Czechoslovakia eliminated Austria, Australia downed Belgium, Spain beat Canada and Argentina defeated New Zealand. (AP) Skiing Title for Swedish Woman: Pernilla Wiberg became Sweden's first female world skiing champion when she won the giant slalom yesterday at the world championships in Saalbach-Hinterglemm, Austria. On the final run, Wiberg made up more than a second on Ulrike Maier of Austria, who captured the super-giant slalom on Tuesday. (AP) Golf Player Takes Two-Stroke Lead: Gary Player birdied three consecutive holes on the back nine and shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday for a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the Senior Tour's Royal Caribbean Classic in Key Biscayne, Fla. Player was at 10-under 132. Chi Chi Rodriguez, who shared the first-round lead with Bruce Crampton, shot a 68 and was in second. (AP) Mallon Leads by Two Strokes: Meg Mallon, seeking her first victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, started with a 60-foot birdie on the way to a three-under-par 69 yesterday and a two-stroke lead entering the final round of the $400,000 L.P.G.A. Classic in Lake Worth, Fla. Mallon started the third round tied for the lead with Dottie Mochrie and Colleen Walker. Mallon finished the round 11 under at 205. Betsy King was in second place after shooting 69. (AP) Track and Field Manhattan in Front: David Frazier, a Manhattan College sophomore, set a meet record of 24 feet 11 inches in the long jump and also won the triple jump at 50-11 1/2 yesterday as Manhattan took the lead in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor championships at Seton Hall in South Orange, N.J. Frazier's teammate Tom VanDemark won the shot-put at 58-3 1/4 as Manhattan scored 50 points to 39 for St. John's. Lou Chisari of New York Tech set a meet record of 68-3 3/4 in the 35-pound weight throw. Sonja Fitts of St. John's won two events, breaking her meet record with an effort of 47-1 in the shot-put and throwing the 20-pound weight 54-9 1/4. St. John's and Rutgers shared first place in the women's competition with 36 points, and Seton Hall had 34. Shana Williams of Seton Hall also won twice, going 20-1 3/4 for a meet record in the long jump and clearing 5-7 3/4 in the high jump. Leonie Codrington of St. John's set a meet record of 39-4 in the triple jump. The meet ends today. (AP)

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Where the Massachussetts State Police could once be seen scattered throughout the terminals at Logan International Airport here, they now circle the airport in their dark blue cars and stand at the terminal entrances, questioning passengers.

title: Corrections
description: Two illustrators' credit lines last Sunday were reversed in some copies. The illustration on page 3 was by Richard McGuire; the one on page 9 was by Janie Geiser.

title: My Search for Coke Stevenson
description: After "Means of Ascent" was published in March 1990, a number of the articles about it that appeared in magazines and newspapers made statements about Coke Stevenson, Lyndon Johnson's opponent in the 1948 United States Senate campaign, for which I believe there is no factual basis. Some of these articles, no doubt inadvertently, repeated allegations and rumors circulated in 1948 by Johnson and his followers in their effort to undermine Stevenson's reputation -- allegations and rumors I also believe to be without factual basis. This note is intended to expand and clarify the record in these areas and to explain the process by which I learned about Coke Stevenson.

title: Emancipation for What?
description: FREEDOM A Documentary History of Emancipation, 1861-1867. Selected From the Holdings of the National Archives of the United States. Series One, Volume Three. The Wartime Genesis of Free Labor: The Lower South. Edited by Ira Berlin, Thavolia Glymph, Steven F. Miller, Joseph P. Reidy, Leslie S. Rowland and Julie Saville. 937 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $54.50.

title: Court Victory for Homeless: 57 for Breakfast
description: A decision by state welfare officials to withhold a 57-cent-a-day breakfast allowance from a homeless man because he was eligible for a free breakfast at a New York City shelter has been rejected as "irrational and unreasonable" by a state appeals court.

title: Marilyn Resh to Marry Peter Buchin
description: The engagement of Dr. Marilyn D. Resh and Dr. Peter J. Buchin, a son of Dr. Jean Buchin of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Dr. Irving D. Buchin, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Ruth Resh of Baldwin, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Restoration Directory; From Angels to Windows
description: Looking for someone who can carve an angel in English Gothic style? Or replace wood shingles, copper gutters and slate roof tiles? Or dismantle and then move an entire 17th-century saltbox house? Or replicate a bronze storefront?

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Midseason Report; After a Half, Knicks Faltering on All Fronts
description: Anyone who can solve the Knicks' problems should report to Madison Square Garden immediately. The team needs help. No one expected New York to be well under .500 this late in the season; not the players, not the coaches, not the front office, not the fans, not even the team's opponents. But the Knicks, with a record of 20-25 after their victory over Sacramento last night, have earned every defeat.

title: Q and A
description: Garbage Truck Noise Question: Our apartment is across from a restaurant serviced by a private carting company that collects garbage between 3 and 4 A.M. The noise is impossible to sleep through. The Sanitation Department tells us they have nothing to do with regulating private carters. The restaurant has not responded to our request to see if it can change collection hours. Can we force them to have their garbage collected at a more reasonable hour? . . . Suzanne Arden, Manhattan Answer: No. The restaurant may not have much control over the schedule of its private carting company and there are no city regulations restricting the time that garbage may be collected. Not all collections are made in the middle of the night. But city sanitation trucks and private carters need to make pickups at times when there is little traffic congestion.

title: Images of Hearts for a Day of Schmaltz
description: Gifts from the heart, and especially gifts shaped like hearts, are plentiful for Valentine's Day.

title: Exchange Specialists Performed Duty in '87 Market Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Bush's Holy War: The Crusader's Cloak Can Grow Heavy on the Shoulders
description: AS President Bush gambles for greatness in the Persian Gulf, he finds himself in a rare predicament.

title: 13 Are Killed in 2 Shootings In Colombia, Police Report
description: Gunmen shot and killed 13 people in two separate shootings in Colombia, the police said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Real Estate section today carries an incorrect number. It is section 10; Sports is section 8.

title: Choosing Fertilizer for Indoor Plants
description: ONE of the least understood phases of indoor plant care is the use of fertilizers. People often equate any plant fertilizer with vitamins, pep pills or even food sources. Beware!

title: On Language; Balloon Goes Up on War Words
description: SECRETARY OF STATE James A. Baker 3d called Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador, into his office and informed him: "The balloon is going up. This is your notification." And so a piece of military slang from World War I was used to carry out a formal agreement of notification before an attack was launched on Iraq from United States bases in Saudi Arabia.

title: Finding a Stage Setting for Mozart
description: WITH the music world going all out to commemorate the bicentennial of the death of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, by the end of the year the composer's works will become familiar to anyone with even a casual interest in the classics.

title: Turnkey Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Even on Stage, Love Can Find Its Way
description: "IT HAD TO BE YOU," now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale through Feb. 17, is such a goofy love story that it took two playwrights, Renee Taylor and her husband, Joseph Bologna, to dream it up and write it down.

title: Boxing; Leonard Still Ticking as Clock Winds Down
description: It has come to this: He is 34 years old and the opponent this time around wears an earring. Need we further reminders that the clock is ticking down on the career of Ray Charles Leonard?

title: A Special Guide to Cruises Worldwide; A Cruise, but Not Smooth Sailing
description: CRUISE the Danube. Board your vessel a stone's throw from the Black Sea, view the plains of Romania from a poolside deck chair, follow the sun through the green-and-silver gorge of the Iron Gate, glide beneath the illuminated bridges of Budapest by night, peer at the picturesque villages of the Wachau Valley, enter Vienna by water as invading warriors once did. Sail through troubled Eastern Europe trouble-free, like a snail with its house on its back.

title: Your Own Account; For Growth, Look to the Little Guys
description: Large companies are expected to continue to slim down in coming years, resulting in fewer job opportunities at the country's largest firms, according to recruiters and outplacement specialists. Job growth, they say, will come from the very smallest businesses, and these companies will be looking for experienced people who can wear many different hats.

title: Anne Walsh Poggi, 78, Ex-Financial Executive
description: Anne Walsh Poggi, a former vice president of Dun & Bradstreet, died on Wednesday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reverberations From a Forgotten Recession
description: When the word "recession" is mentioned on Wall Street, it is the downturns of 1974-75 and 1981-82 that are recalled. But there was another recession sandwiched between those two, one that has been almost forgotten.

title: Princess Hope L. Namgyal Is Engaged To Thomas Reich Jr., a U.S. Diplomat
description: Hope Cooke of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Princess Hope Leezum Namgyal, to Thomas Gwyn Reich Jr., a Foreign Service officer. He is a son of Jayne Ericourt of Greensboro, N.C., and Mr. Reich of Wilmington, N.C. A July wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music; Pianist Returns to New York
description: The Dubravka Tomsic known to New Yorkers with long memories existed in the 1950's, when she came here to study the piano and subsequently flourished under the protectorship of Artur Rubinstein. Miss Tomsic went home to Yugoslavia at the end of that decade, brought up a family and for the last 30 years has conducted her playing career on a quieter scale.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Vertical Myth Robert Hughes, writing about American design between the world wars, reminds us that the imagination of an age can be read in its artifacts. This is from "Nothing if Not Critical: Selected Essays on Art and Artists" (Knopf).

title: Heart Problem
description: The Denver Nuggets' rookie guard Chris Jackson, the No. 3 selection in last year's National Basketball Association draft, has been sidelined after a test discovered a heart irregularity. Team officials said, however, that the problem did not seem to be serious.

title: Dollar Is Down On Interest Moves
Besieged, Stores Run Out of Flags
description: FOR several weeks Henry Nagle's telephone in Elmsford has been ringing off the hook. John A. Grillo in Mount Vernon and Carl Calo in Yonkers have been having the same experience.

title: Headliners; Off the Hook
description: For more than a year Pong Ok Jang, the manager of the Family Red Apple, a Korean-run grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, has endured the demonstrators who flock outside the business urging people not to go inside. The problem began last January when a Haitian woman, Gieslaine Felissaint, said Mr. Pong had slapped her as she shopped in the store. He denied striking her -- she had thrown pepper in a cashier's face, he contended -- but he was charged with assault. Last week when a jury acquitted him, Mr. Pong held his head in his hands and wept. "I'm glad it is over," he said. "I've tried very hard to understand." But his troubles may not be done. Protesters have vowed to continue the boycott and Ms. Felissaint has filed a $6 million lawsuit against the store. After the trial, Mr. Pong sounded perplexed when asked if he thought his fortunes would improve. "I don't know," he said, as he closed up the store for the night. "I was not guilty, and outside there are protesters."

title: Miss O'Donnell Weds J. N. Perry Jr.
description: Elizabeth Anne O'Donnell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah J. O'Donnell Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to James Nelson Perry Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Robert J. Sweeney performed the ceremony.

title: All About/Denim; The Appeal of Blue -- Now Red or Green -- Jeans
description: High-fashion denim, these days, means much more than designer jeans. Franco Moschino covers a denim jacket with transparent sequins. Donna Karan shapes a strapless denim minidress. As sales of blue jeans flag, designers are devising new uses for a familiar fabric.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption with the Technology column last Sunday misstated the capacity of an Applied Materials machine. It works on one wafer at a time and can accomplish several -- but not all -- of the steps in the making of computer chips.

title: Caroline Netchvolodoff Wed in Capital
description: Caroline Alexandra Netchvolodoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander V. Netchvolodoff of Washington, and William Dudley McCall, a son of David B. McCall of New York and Mrs. C. Paul Cox 2d of Easton, Md., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, who is the bride's godfather and an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Francis H. Wade at St. Alban's Parish in Washington.

title: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .; More Than '3 Squares'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Because the area has three of the busiest and most visible airports in the country, security officials are taking especially strong measures to counter any terrorist threat in New York.

title: THE BIG FIVE OH
description: Was the About Men column "Senior-Circuited" (Jan. 6) really written by the same Tom Brokaw of "Today" show fame, who not so many years ago was training to run in the New York City Marathon? (If I recall, he was done in by tendinitis.) My advice, Tom, is to put those golf clubs back in the closet until you are 80-something and get out the old running shoes while you are still 50-something. IRVING J. RAKSIN Baltimore

title:
FILM;
From a Dream Marriage Emerges a Nightmare
description: There are bad marriages, and then there are

title: 1-Year-Old Dies in Car Fire
description: An child who was left in an idling car by his baby sitter died Friday when the car caught fire and burned, the police said. Police said a baby sitter left 1-year-old Dean Ackerman in a child safety seat in the back of a two-door car while she visited friends. The woman, said to be in her mid-30s, was not identified. Police said the fire appeared to have started inside the Oldsmobile Delta at 9 A.M. Twenty minutes later, the fire had been extinguished, but the child was dead. The child appeared to have died of smoke inhalation, officials said. Police were investigating whether the fire was caused by a cigarette, though it was not known if the baby sitter was a smoker.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Passengers arriving at Benito Juarez International Airport here will find few of the stringent security measures invoked in other international cities. But the lack of bomb squads is matched by another striking scarcity -- a lack of Mexican passengers, who have canceled overseas flight reservations by the thousands, leaving the often-crowded airport eerily deserted.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;
Office Complex Near Hospitals
description: STERLING PLAZA, an $8 million office complex now rising here, is expected to help meet growing demands for space from the medical and academic community.

title: Mary Beth Cooleen to Marry Christopher J. Tully
description: Mrs. John J. Cooleen of Jackson, N.J., has announced September wedding plans for her daughter, Mary Beth Cooleen, and Christopher John Tully, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Tully of Bayside, Queens.

title: The 'Black Table' Is Still There
description: During a recent visit to my old junior high school in Westchester County, I came upon something that I never expected to see again, something that was a source of fear and dread for three hours each school morning of my early adolescence: the all-black lunch table in the cafeteria of my predominantly white suburban junior high school.

title: L.P.G.A. Seeks Stability With Mechem
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association's 41st season opened in Jamaica the same week war broke out in the Persian Gulf, and the sense of incongruency was emphasized by the lack of televisions at the cloistered Tryall Club.

title: Mutual Funds; Time for Science and Technology?
description: Analysts say that the successful use of United States military technology in the Persian Gulf war bodes well for future government and private spending in high-tech companies. The likely beneficiaries: funds that invest in science and technology stocks.

title: Insuring Against Changed Plans
description: IN the best of times, travel plans do not always work out and, with the outbreak of war in the Middle East, there is reason to be cautious about committing oneself in advance to expensive travel arrangements, such as a cruise. Before reserving a cruise, passengers should become familiar with the line's cancellation policy and consider buying trip cancellation insurance to avoid paying a penalty if plans change. Insurance is available to cover a variety of contingencies, including terrorism that leads to a change in itinerary.

title: IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA, HUNT FOR VILLAINS
description: Czechoslovakia has begun screening more than 1,000 top officials -- Parliament members, Government ministers and their aides -- to discover which ones were informers for the secret police under the former Communist leadership.

title: Alcohol Ban Stays At Texas Stadium
description: The sale of beer and wine just will not mix with Texas Stadium, Irving City Council members say.

title: In 'David's Mother,' A Flaunting of Guilt
description: DAVID'S mother, Sally Goodman, watches "The Wizard of Oz" and roots for the wicked witch. To a visitor who arrives at an inopportune time, she calls out matter-of-factly: "Just a minute. We're having an anti-spasmodic attack."

title: Gigi de Pourtales, Producer, to Wed Timothy Davis, Film-Story Analyst
description: Countess Alexander William Guy de Pourtales of Newport, R.I., and Scottsdale, Ariz., has announced the engagement of her daughter Marguerite Lois de Pourtales to Timothy Frank Davis, a son of Peter Davis of Castine, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: IF I'D STOOD UP EARLIER
description: Philip Loeb was not "forced off 'The Goldbergs.' " Rather, "The Goldbergs" was forced off the air because my mother, Gertrude Berg, writer, producer and star of the sit-com, would not fire him. The show finally reappeared after a long interval and only for a short time, on the small, independent Dumont network. Gertrude Berg was able to go on to great Broadway success, but, sadly, it is true that Philip Loeb became unemployable and after a few years committed suicide. HARRIET BERG SCHWARTZ West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Marion Salmon Has Wedding
description: Marion Elizabeth Broome Salmon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alec George Broome Salmon of New York, was married at the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday to Michael Wallace Hedges Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Hedges of New York. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: World Markets; The Bundesbank as Bogyman?
description: Both the Federal Reserve Board and the German Bundesbank moved key interest rates last week. On Friday, the Fed lowered its discount rate half a percentage point and was apparently trying to cut the Federal funds rate by the same amount. The day before, the Bundesbank pushed its key short-term Lombard and discount rates up half a percentage point.

title: Kerry Anne Celentano to Wed Brian J. Frawley
description: Kerry Anne Celentano, who is studying for a master's degree in social work at Fordham University, and Brian Johannes Frawley, who expects to graduate from Fordham in May, plan to marry in June.

title: A Season for Wearing Your Art on Your Sleeve
description: Fashion may not be art, but art is certainly in fashion this spring. Dresses, shirts, ties and tights are flaunting patterns inspired by Pop Art, Op Art and Abstract Expressionism. There are even hints of Matisse.

title: Major Wine Producer Files for Bankruptcy
description: LONG ISLAND'S showiest winery, La Reve in Water Mill, has run into financial difficulties, forcing the scheduling of a foreclosure procedure.

title: Sculpture-Paintings Borrow From the Past
description: WITH its current show of works by George Segal, the Whitney Museum branch in Stamford has changed character. Part of the no-nonsense corporate interior of the Champion Building has been transformed into a mausoleum with figures and, in the form of still lifes, the food and furnishings they need for eternity.

title: Men's Style; SHOULDER SHIFTS
description: SOMETHING WAS AMISS, AND BILL ROBINSON knew it. Reviewing his collection of men's fashions for spring several months ago, the designer quickly put his finger on the problem. The shoulders of his sport coats were a little too, well, muscular.

title: New Interest in Scotland's Painted Pottery
description: SCOTTISH painted enamel pottery of the early 20th century, with its organic designs and broad palette, brought color and life into the dark homes of the dour north. Until six or eight years ago, Scottish painted pottery could still be found in cheaper antique shops, in junk stores and in the Barras, Glasgow's flea market. But now dealers are snapping up anything of quality to come onto the market.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: New Managers on L.I.R.R.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Panthers Pounded By Bruins, 112-85
description: Don McLean atoned for his worst game of the season with 39 points and Tracy Murray scored 29 as U.C.L.A. took a 20-2 lead and then romped to a 112-85 victory over Pittsburgh this afternoon.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Should a Writing Class Teach Social Diversity?
description: Responding to criticism over their decision to include issues of racial and social diversity in freshman writing classes, English professors at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst say they are teaching students how to write, not how to be "politically correct."

title: The Region; Two Governors Face the Facts Of Life in a Lean Time
description: IT was a big week for bad news.

title: Wall Street; Disguising the Risks of Research
description: How profitable is your favorite biotechnology company? How much is it spending on research and development, the staff of life in any science-driven industry? What do you stand to lose if its hot new idea is a dud?

title: The Executive Computer; What Laptop Users Can Expect to Find at Airports
description: Airports have tightened their security since the start of war in the Persian Gulf as a precaution against potential terrorist attacks. All those laptop computers carried by business executives, along with portable stereos and other electronic equipment, are coming under particular scrutiny.

title: Laura Kirschstein Engaged to Marry Marc David Fink, a Fellow Prosecutor
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Kirschstein of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Beth Kirschstein to Marc David Fink, a son of former New York State Assembly Speaker and Mrs. Stanley Fink of Brooklyn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Veith to Wed John S. Reed Jr.
description: Dr. Charles J. Veith and Karen McDonald Veith of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Elizabeth Veith to John Shedd Reed Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reed of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Data Update
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: With the passengers seated for a near on-time takeoff for Haiti and the Dominican Republic, Capt. Kevin Kelly of Pan American emerged from his cockpit to announce the flight wouldn't be taking off so soon after all.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Families; Grief for the Lucky Ones Who Escaped the Bronx
description: Along the rough-and-tumble streets of the Melrose section of the Bronx, fluttering yellow ribbons dangle from windows, trees and car antennas in testimony to the uneasy vigil many families are keeping.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Security has always been tight at Narita International Airport, because of fear of left-wing radicals who view airport expansion as a military plot. But since the beginning of the gulf war, security patrols in the terminals have been increased and the number of guards has been doubled.

title: Technology; Using Biological 'Fire' To Turn Waste Into Fertilizer
description: With landfills closing and high-technology incinerators unpopular in many areas, some communities are turning to nature's way of getting rid of solid waste: composting.

title: Anxious Times for Residents With Family or Friends in Israel
description: DURING the first week that Iraqi-fired Scud missiles smashed into cities in Israel, Adele Konecky of Irvington found a reassuring message on her answering machine. "Don't worry, Mom, we're O.K.," she heard a muffled voice say.

title: Falling Back on Chocolate on Valentine's Day
description: WHEN I was in boarding school I had better taste in food than in boys. Valentine's Day was something I planned for weeks in advance; it was an excuse to buy a large box of chocolates. When the day arrived, I was the envy of my schoolmates. I received more cards than any of the other girls in my class: I sent them to myself. The cards were filled with romantic messages and love poems on padded silk hearts, the sort of thing 13- and 14-year-olds yearn for but seldom receive. The box of chocolates I bought also came in the mail; its anonymous sender had remembered that my great love was Cadbury's Milk Tray.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Home Front; War's Ribbons Are Yellow With Meaning of Many Hues
description: Sybil Roberts, whose nephew is in the Persian Gulf, was so angered by antiwar protesters at her door carrying petitions that she wrapped the columns on the porch of her Houston rowhouse with yellow satin, buried the facade under 14 giant yellow bows, and planted a sign in her lawn that read, "We support our troops" on side and "Down with protesting" on the other.

title: All Wrapped Up in His Work
description: MUMMIES OF THE PHARAOHS Modern Medical Investigations. By Maurice Bucaille. Translated by Alastair D. Pannell and the author. Illustrated. 236 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

title: All Language Was Foreign
description: A MAN WITHOUT WORDS By Susan Schaller. Foreword by Oliver Sacks. 203 pp. New York: Summit Books.

title: Meg Kelly to Wed in June
description: Robert J. Kelly of Newfane, Vt., and Mrs. Margaret Mickel of Mendon, Vt., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Margaret Hogan Kelly and Michael Robert Curry, the son of Robert L. Curry of Mahway, N.J., and Mrs. Linda J. Volkhardt of Hilton Head, S.C. Miss Kelly, 26 years old and known as Meg, graduated from Emmanuel College. She is an account executive at Harrison, Star, Wiener and Beitler, a New York advertising agency. Mr. Curry, 30, graduated from Denison University and received an M.B.A. from Duke University. He is a product manager for the Roerig Division of Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in New York.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: At Los Angeles International Airport, the nation's third busiest after O'Hare in Chicago and Dallas-Fort Worth, tensions and security measures have been high because of terrorism fears. Travel agents also said that a significant number of passengers were asking to be booked on flights from smaller suburban airports such as Burbank, Ontario and Long Beach, on the theory that LAX, as Los Angeles International is designated in airline code, was more of a potential target.

title: Redmen Give Carnesecca 500th Victory
description: Throughout his college coaching career, Lou Carnesecca has preached a cooperative philosophy of competition: namely, when I win, you win; when you win, I win. Yesterday at Madison Square Garden, Carnesecca's 23d St. John's team helped the coach win one of the most significant games of his career.

title: Minnesota: Training Indians To Become Business Leaders
description: Hoping to succeed where Yale University failed, the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota has established a business leadership program for American Indians.

title: Balancing The Budget With an Idea Borrowed From Past
description: GOV. JIM FLORIO'S plans to stanch the flow of red ink and balance his $14.3 billion budget for next year include finding some novel revenue sources, including the funds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, which previous governors have tried to capture without success.

title: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .; Dissent Is Patriotic
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Improvements Make a Visit Worthwhile
description: THE former bank building next to the A. & P. shopping center on Elm Street in Westfield, Union County, is a far cry from the tiny storefront just a few blocks away that was the first home of Ken Marcotte, the well-rated restaurant named for the chef-owner.

title: Women Warriors
description: The morning shows, the late-night shows, the radio call-in shows -- all of them were out rounding up women, as though they were casting one of those distaff buddy movies Hollywood was fond of for a moment. Women officials. Women professors. Women soldiers. A woman had reportedly been taken prisoner in the Persian Gulf. Biology, if not destiny, was at least newsworthy.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Security has been heightened considerably at Bangkok's Don Muang Airport, hotels and Western embassies since the United States State Department issued a warning Jan. 19 of "possible terrorist action" here.

title:
Ocean Grove Journal;
Seeking Rooming House Limits
description: THIS tiny, tranquil seaside town is perhaps the last place where one would expect to find the kind of social problems that have become routine in urban areas.

title: Ewing Out But Knicks Flourish
description: Against most teams, the Knicks would be in deep trouble playing without Patrick Ewing. Against the Sacramento Kings last night, Ewing's absence was no problem.

title:
DINING OUT;
Old-Fashioned Italian Menu in Armonk
description: SITUATED in the spot last occupied by Raphael's, Onda Blu has changed little of the established decor. Cool Art Deco colors and greenery set an attractive, if somewhat bare contemporary backdrop for an old-fashioned menu of Italian dishes most diners will find familiar.

title: Cotton Candy and Electric Dreams
description: Welcome to the City of Fire: Coney Island, birthplace of the hot dog and the roller coaster, a place made of electricity and dreams, a place where, as the film maker Ric Burns says, "energies were liberated." "Coney Island," Mr. Burns's history of America's greatest seaside resort, will be presented tomorrow night at 9 as part of the PBS series "The American Experience." Mr. Burns was most recently co-writer and collaborator with his brother Ken Burns on the PBS "Civil War" series.

title: In Horses, We Glimpse Our Lost Nobility
description: Fifteen years ago this week, the thoroughbred industry presented its annual award for the best 3-year-old filly to Ruffian, a horse who had captured the attention of the entire country. The ceremony, however, was a bittersweet event; seven months earlier, the undefeated filly had broken down during a nationally televised match race against Foolish Pleasure and had had to be destroyed.

title: A New Opera Company Begins With a Tribute
description: "IT'S not the best economic climate to launch an opera company," said Margaret Cicogna, one of the founders of Hudson Opera Theater. "But we've been encouraged by many Westchester residents who are looking for quality performances in an accessible location. Since we'll be based at SUNY Purchase, we think we're off to a good start."

title: Faction in U.N. Panel Blocks a Rights Group
description: Asserting interference in their internal affairs, Arab nations and Cuba have denied an application from America's largest human-rights monitoring organization, Human Rights Watch, for consultative status at the United Nations.

title: The Bridge To Ellis Island
description: Re: "Ellis Island Journal: Celebrating Gateway to Nation, Debating Link to Jersey City," Dec. 23:

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Civil airports turned into instant barometers of national anxieties about terrorism when war began in the Persian Gulf Jan. 16. The bustle of passengers faded and some air terminals became uneasily still as travel overseas dropped off precipitately and domestic travel thinned. Uniformed guards multiplied. Close-in parking areas were blockaded to limit damage from any car bombs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: O. HENRYA Biography of William Sydney Porter.By David Stuart.Scarborough House, $19.95.

title: Fashion; WINDS OF CHANGE
description: EVERYTHING AFFECTS FASHION -- INCLUDING, undoubtedly, the fighting in the Persian Gulf. Paris designers just finishing up their spring couture showings, and those elsewhere who are deep into plans for next fall's collections, are as concerned, distracted and apprehensive about the conflict as everyone else. How all this will come together in cloth and thread is still to be determined. The only sure thing is that it will. History has shown that style inevitably absorbs the atmosphere of the moment and distills it into adornment.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RED CABBAGE CAFEBy Jonathan Treitel.Pantheon, $19.95.

title:
THEATER;
He's Back Home, but Is It the Real Robert Wilson?
description: A tall, courteous, soft-spoken individual who dresses conservatively and often wears his tortoise-shell glasses on his forehead, Robert Wilson hardly looks like a wild man of the theater. In fact, the director has seemed increasingly a part of the Establishment, devoting more of his time in Europe lately to directing plays by others, rather than his own sprawling, often ineffable compositions, and to producing classical operas.

title: Hutchinson No Longer Holds Its Nose
description: Paul Ackland, Mayor of this prosperous little river city, noticed that his visitor was troubled.

title: 'A Parade Of Pianists' In Concert And Recital
description: "I TRY to make the piano sound like it's not a piano," said Vladimir Horowitz. "It can be a violin, a piccolo, a string ensemble, a woodwind quartet -- anything but a piano." True enough, there's variety to spare in the many recitals and other concerts with keyboards all around the state this week.

title: About Men; Mum's the Word
description: IT WAS SO LONG AGO, I don't remember the last time my wife and I really quarreled -- and I have told her, only half kidding, that credit for this phenomenon belongs not to us, nor to the Deity, but to our home-grown, unorthodox formula for tranquillity.

title: Locating Hard-to-Find Wall Studs
description: ATTACHING items like pictures, mirrors, shelves and cabinets to walls is usually rather easy in itself. But for sturdiness, fasteners for such items must enter parts of the building's framework called studs. These are inside the walls, and finding them can be difficult.

title: Commissioner Whom Cuomo Asked to Resign Is Still Serving
description: In December 1989, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo demanded that a New York State Labor Relations Board Commissioner, Theresa E. Hammer, resign after investigators rebuked her for official misconduct.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: RAYNA GILLMAN;
Helping the Laid-Off Executive Recover
description: WHEN some top executives are laid off, perhaps because of downsizing or takeovers, their former employers pay for the services of professional outplacement companies to help them search for new jobs. These offices often become homes away from home for the unemployed executives.

title: The World; 15 Years After Zhou's Death, His Image Is Larger Than Life
description: WHEN Zhou Enlai died 15 years ago, his body was allowed to lie in state for only two days, and Chairman Mao Zedong did not even bother to show up for the memorial service. But if he was snubbed at the time of his death, Prime Minister Zhou has been winning honor and encomiums ever since, and his reputation has never been greater.

title: Piggery's Denizens Thrive on Fresh Air And Home Cooking
description: THOMAS J. MILLARAS was tending to his cooking. "You have to simmer it," he said, as he piped steam into a 55-gallon drum.

title: Review/Theater; An Editor, His Wife and Her Lover
description: Harold Pinter's "Betrayal" is a malicious comedy of manners about mutual deceit. In this 1978 play, the web is taut and the words are weighted with portent and humor. The playwright tells his story in nine pithy scenes, all he needs to capture the hermetic world of his three conspirators. The essence of this devious work is delineated with precision in John Tillinger's revival at the Long Wharf Theater. Having previously mastered the farcical art of Joe Orton, Mr. Tillinger proves to be equally secure with the understated intrigue of Mr. Pinter.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Columbus, Ohio;
Subcontracts For Minorities
description: THE LIMITED is nearing completion of a $110 million subsidiary headquarters and distribution center near here in a project notable for its use of minority subcontractors.

title: This Troupe Transcends Family
description: The Matsuyama Ballet from Tokyo, which made its United States debut in New York and an engagement scheduled to end today at the Kennedy Center in Washington, is the first major Japanese ballet troupe to visit this country.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is the art of killing. We have to be perfect." -- Staff Sgt. Douglas A. Luebke, head of a Marine sniper platoon in Saudi Arabia. [ 1:5. ]

title: Romance and Murder Make Warmus Trial Its Own Theater
description: AT the Westchester County Courthouse here, the usual ebb and flow of justice -- prosecuting grand larcenies, drug sales and assaults -- has been overwhelmed by the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus, the 27-year-old Westchester teacher accused of killing her lover's wife.

title: Style Makers; Barbara Bosha Nelson, Jewelry Maker
description: Barbara Bosha Nelson never made a mark in fashion until the case of "the bloody typewriter keys." Ms. Nelson, an American who lives in London, specializes in turning found objects into something wearable. One day she was playing around with a typewriter -- she wouldn't go as far to say "writing" -- and was struck by the beauty of the black-and-white keys. Also, they were the perfect size for -- who would have thought -- cuff links.

title: Volunteers Take On Creative Campaigns
description: ONE of the goals of the Communications Network of Westchester is to be able to take on all the assignments coming its way. That's why it is actively seeking additional copywriters, graphic artists and public relations practitioners.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: "WELL, it will be a warm day in February before you see

title: Mary T. Ryder, Physician, Is Engaged
description: Capt. Mary Theresa Ryder and Capt. Barry Decaney Walters, both of the Air Force, plan to marry in August.

title: Coins
description: Back in 1913 an article was published describing three strange Middle Eastern coins. Like most Islamic coins, these showed no pictures, only writing. Two of the three were made of copper and the third was a gilt-covered copper coin with much of the gilt rubbed off.

title: Bereaved Find Solace in Gifts to the Neediest
description: The gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund could not bring back the friend who had just died of AIDS, but there was little else that Terese Kreuzer could do.

title: For 40 Years, the Retarded Find Work and Help in Bridgeport
description: IN 1951, Evelyn Kennedy was faced with limited choices in providing for her 7-year-old mentally retarded son: keeping him at home or putting him in an institution. To help create additional alternatives, she organized a small group that called itself Parents and Friends of Retarded Children, which evolved into the Kennedy Center in Bridgeport, a place where mentally disabled people are encouraged to stretch to their fullest potential.

title: Doctor Arrested Over Fraudulent Credential
description: A doctor who had failed a licensing test in anesthesiology four times used forged credentials to work in that field in a Manhattan hospital for seven months before being found out, law-enforcement officials said on Friday.

title: Arbour Gets a Laugh and a Tie
description: Al Arbour laughed as he leaned against the wall in a corridor underneath the stands at Nassau Coliseum after the Islanders' 3-3 deadlock tonight with the Canadiens.

title: After 6 Addicts Die, Police in Northeast Warn of Toxic Drug
description: Bags of drugs sold in the South Bronx on Friday left at least six heroin users in four Northeastern cities dead and more than 100 seriously ill yesterday, setting in motion a frantic effort to warn addicts away from the batch, sold under the name "Tango and Cash," the authorities said.

title: Odd Couples Need to Be Truly Odd
description: Movie characters often influence each other in amazingly tidy ways. Behavioral symmetry can be a formula-loving screenwriter's best friend. Should the writer elect to take this easy way out, then the safecracker who is accidentally handcuffed to a Scout leader will have become more honest and generous before the story is over, whereas the Scout leader will have loosened up and learned to have fun. Or a prostitute (vide "Pretty Woman") will have grown more ladylike, while her businessman friend learns to be better attuned to his human side.

title: Corrections
description: An interview last Sunday with the novelist John L'Heureux misidentified his wife. She is Joan Polston L'Heureux.

title: A Ski Jump Brings Pride And Experts To Salisbury
description: THE directors of the Salisbury Winter Sports Association gathered on Tuesday to make a crucial decision. In their headquarters at the Salisbury Pharmacy, they sipped coffee, consulted weather experts in Hartford and Albany by phone, weighed all the factors carefully and declared that preparations would begin immediately at the Satre Ski Hill for this weekend's ski jumping competition for children and adults, sanctioned by the United States Ski Association.

title: Sunday Outing; A Special Place to Celebrate Black History Month
description: The African-American Museum at 110 North Franklin Street in Hempstead focuses on the history of black Americans on Long Island, many of whom have made significant contributions to the region and the nation.

title: A Mother, and Proud of It
description: A new mother is complaining that South County Hospital left the recent birth of her son off its announcement list because she is not married. The 23-year-old mother, Traci Hendricks, said she checked the newspaper for the announcement of her son's birth and learned of the hospital's policy of sending announcements only for married mothers. Ralph L. Misto, the hospital president, said Friday the rule may be outdated. "The world has changed out there, and we may want to revise this," he said.

title: Miss Richardson Planning to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Heather Christine Richardson and Sean Paul Bonner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick D. Bonner of Deer Park, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Richardson 2d of Lyme, Conn.

title: Chess
description: The old saying that lightning does not strike twice in the same place still recruits believers although it is not sound meteorology. Moreover, its metaphorical extension to other matters, such as chess, is equally dubious. That's what Jan Timman, the leading Dutch grandmaster for 20 years, learned in his Katholieke Radio Omroep exhibition match in Hilversum, the Netherlands, with Yasser Seirawan, a Seattle grandmaster.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Housing Partnership Makes Progress
description: THE Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit organization based in Stony Brook whose stated mission is "to create homeownership for people who otherwise would not be able to own a home," has announced plans to build and sponsor 106 dwellings this year.

title: Informer: The Life and Death of an I.R.A. Man
description: It was a local woman out for a walk who found him lying by the side of the road in I.R.A. "bandit country" in South Armagh, Northern Ireland. Patrick Flood's hands were tied behind his back with tape, and a black garbage bag was pulled over his head. He had been shot once from behind. There was a large exit wound in his face, and the bag was smeared with blood. It was a still July evening, a quiet night for the quiet death of an I.R.A. informer.

title: The Curse of the Caucasians
description: WHITE PEOPLE By Allan Gurganus. 252 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title: Campus Life: Texas; Single-Sex Groups Told to Include Members of Other
description: Twenty-nine all-men or all-women organizations at the University of Texas are being forced to modify their sex-based membership requirements or risk penalties under Federal law.

title: Miss Carroll Wed To J. W. Parmele
description: Christ's Church in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Holladay Carroll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Brown Mabon Carroll of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and James White Parmele, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roome Parmele 3d of Skillman, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Johnston, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Ellen B. McKinley, also an Episcopalian, and the Rev. Robert Cushman, a minister of the Christian Alliance Church.

title: A Chinese Menu With Meaningful Stars
description: JUDGING by externals, little distinguishes Fortune Village in Branford from dozens of other Chinese restaurants in Connecticut.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Forum page last Sunday about effects of the Persian Gulf war on other nations referred incompletely to the area where people from third world nations were working before the war. In addition to Kuwait, they were in Iraq. The article also misstated the number of Filipino workers in those countries; it was 90,000, not 500,000.

title: Campus Life: South Carolina; 2 Win Fight To Display American Flags
description: After two undergraduates displayed the American flag in support of the nation's war effort in the Persian Gulf, the University of South Carolina has backed away from its policy against hanging objects outside residence halls.

title: On Buying Into Snobbery
description: To the Editor:

title: Afterward, Make Africa a Priority
description: When the war in the Persian Gulf is over, the United States will turn to the other pressing international concerns that need its attention. But there is a growing fear among United Nations, African and other development officials that one vital concern -- the deepening, decade-long economic crisis in Africa -- is unlikely to feature prominently in the post-gulf agenda of the United States and the other major aid-giving powers. Such neglect would deal a severe blow to the profound but largely unreported political and economic reforms being undertaken on the continent -- reforms that are Africa's only hope for reversing what is nothing less than an economic and social nightmare for its peoples.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Cedar Knolls 207,500 67 Summit Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; eat-in- kitchen, h/w floors, 2-zone heating; taxes $2,080. Chester 168,000 616 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; brick fireplace, 1-car garage, h/w floors, full basement; taxes $2,600. Mahwah 390,000 41 Heather Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; in-ground pool, fireplace, skylights, patio; taxes $4,320. Mendham 472,500 34 Lowery Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; new kitchen, 2 fireplaces, pool; taxes $5,717. Rockaway 173,000 35 McKeel Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath 27-year-old contemporary; vaulted ceilings, eat-in-kitchen, h/w floors; taxes $3,516. Saddle Brook 142,000 2 Hutter Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; full finished basement, C/A, h/w floors; taxes $4,052. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $375,000 8 Martin Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old contemporary; family room, 2 fireplaces, screened porch, 1.3 acres; taxes $9,558. Bridgeport, Conn. $148,000 30 Holland Hill Circle 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old cape cod; fireplace, 1-car garage, 50- by 160-foot lot; taxes $3,456. Bellmore, L.I. $115,000 142 Barbara Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old bungalow; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage, 500 feet of waterfront; taxes $1,500.

title: Susan Pomerantz Weds Kevin Davis
description: Susan Meredith Pomerantz, a daughter of John J. Pomerantz of New York and Mrs. Sanford Furman of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening in New York to Kevin Roger Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Davis of London. Rabbi Thomas Weiner performed the ceremony at Cen tral Synagogue.

title: Women and the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man Who Stayed in Bed
description: SERIOUS PLEASURES The Life of Stephen Tennant. By Philip Hoare. Illustrated. 463 pp. New York: Hamish Hamilton/Viking. $29.95.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: On Jan. 2, the first phase of a special security plan known as Vigipirate went into effect all over France, with 200,000 police officers and gendarmes placed on the alert. Phase two, declared on Jan. 17, represents the tightest security France has known since the 1954-62 Algerian war, with 3,000 "sensitive points" given extra protection. These include the Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports outside Paris.

title: 1991 Is Already Year of the Kicker
description: In the beginning, Alex Karras, then a devilish defensive tackle for the Detroit Lions, joked how soccer-style place-kickers from foreign countries would say, "I keek a touchdown." Nobody jokes anymore. Although a few foreign booters still exist in the National Football League, most soccer-style kickers are American born and bred. And accurate.

title: White House Reassures Hard-Pressed Governors
description: The nation's governors, their states battered by recession, came to Washington today to seek more Federal aid and greater flexibility in administering Federal programs.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE: Creating the Modern Middle East 1914-1922, by David Fromkin. (Avon, $14.95.) A historian tells how today's Middle East jigsaw was carved from the Ottoman Empire with the help of the British, who wanted to insure that they had a land bridge to India. " 'A Peace to End All Peace' is one of the first books to take an effective panoramic view of what was happening," Wm. Roger Louis said here in 1989. "Among the reasons for Mr. Fromkin's success is the breadth of his vision, which takes the reader deep into areas normally not associated with the Middle East."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: M.I.A.'s; Her Strength Is Theirs, Family of Casualty Says
description: A few days before she was listed as missing in action in the Saudi desert, Specialist 4 Melissa A. Rathbun-Nealy telephoned her parents in this rural community of wooded snow-covered hills and frozen lakes.

title: Managing; Welcoming Those With Disabilities
description: FOUR years ago, Honeywell Inc. formed the Council of Honeywell Employees With Disabilities. The committee spent much of 1989 cataloguing what sort of physical accommodations such employees need, and much of 1990 helping Honeywell management put them in place.

title: A Dancer, a Choreographer And Their Creative Alchemy
description: When the curtain rises for the first time this Wednesday on Eliot Feld's "Savage Glance," the choreographer's latest ballet, the audience will watch a haunting and seamless 18-minute dance unfold. What the public won't see, nor is it intended to ponder, are the painstaking hours that Mr. Feld and his dancers have spent in conceptual ferment -- exploring, distilling, refining and remembering movement.

title:
ART;
'Dick Tracy' at Cartoon Museum: Horror Balanced by Humor
description: "THE DICK TRACY EXHIBIT" at the Museum of Cartoon Art here acknowledges last summer's film: lifesize models of the movie's major villains stop you in your tracks as you enter each room of the exhibition, and in one segment Chester Gould's pen-and-ink creations are matched with color photographs of their Hollywood counterparts.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: While the police presence throughout Vienna has tightened, particularly at international conferences, embassies and foreign government installations, operations at the Vienna International Airport and Salzburg Airport are almost normal except for occasional delays for longer security checks, officials say.

title: Medical Technology And Its Costs
description: The excellent article on laparoscopic cholecystectomy in Long Island hospitals [ "Laparoscope-Tube Surgery Is Expanded," Jan. 6 ] is further evidence of the advancement of medicine and surgery to alleviate pain and suffering of those diseases that mankind is subject to. This is true in many other areas of surgery and medicine due to the development of technological equipment and expertise.

title: Maria Schubert, Promotions Chief, To Wed John Saltonstall 2d, Executive
description: Mrs. Walter B. Schubert of Maplewood, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Maria Louise Schubert to John Lee Saltonstall 2d, a son of David Saltonstall of New York and Mrs. Paul C. Cabot Jr. of Westwood, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY ON THE GULF CRISIS -- HONOLULU;
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Isolated though Hawaii is in the Pacific, the impact of war hits home quickly and hard. The state's top two industries, after all, are tourism and the military. The economy is dependent on the well-being of the vast numbers of visitors and armed forces personnel who move in and out.

title: Adrienne Wallace to Marry
description: June wedding plans for Adrienne Wallace and David Carmack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Carmack of Pasadena, Calif., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Wallace of Malverne, L.I. Miss Wallace, 27 years old, and her fiance, 25, are third-year medical students at Columbia University. She is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Office Complex Near Hospitals
description: STERLING PLAZA, an $8 million office complex now rising here, is expected to help meet growing demands for space from the medical and academic community.

title: Kathryn Lewis to Wed in September
description: Geraldine Lewis of Madrid has announced September wedding plans for her daughter, Kathryn Lewis, and James J. Hebert Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hebert of Norwalk, Conn.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 3, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 3 2 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 2 1 4 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) AND BEAR IN MIND

title: A Few Firms Shine in Face Of Downturn
description: DESPITE the pessimism that often envelops meetings of business groups on Long Island these days, some executives on hand remain silent. Their businesses are booming.

title: Strickland Hurt
description: The San Antonio Spurs' guard Rod Strickland suffered a fracture at the base of his right hand during an altercation Thursday night at a San Antonio nightclub and will be sidelined indefinitely, a club spokesman said yesterday.

title: Commercial Property: Showroom Buildings; Specialty Dealers Remain Together To Draw the Buyers
description: A VACANCY RATE of 9 percent would look good almost anywhere, certainly in an 84-year-old building. But that is not all that distinguishes 225 Fifth Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: On the Home Front The State of the Union Message last week was short on domestic policy, but that may have been a plus for President Bush and the Republican Party. News Analysis, page 28. A Question of Justice The arrest of a man who was once a prime suspect in five murders points up the vulnerability of the mentally ill in criminal cases. Page 18. Trouble in New York Port The Port Authority is in the unaccustomed position of paring costs and pleading for money. Page 34. News Summary, Page 2 Obituaries, Page 36 Weather, Page 37 Radio, Late TV, Page 55 Arts and Leisure/Section 2 No musical in the last decade has dared as much as Stephen Sondheim's darkly brilliant "Assassins." Book Review/Section 7 Three strange lives: an American journalist who became a Japanese; an heir who lost a fortune; an Englishman who was purely decorative. Business/Section 3 Across the Middle East, a fear that war is only the beginning. Real Estate/Section 10* Lenders are seeking workout deals instead of foreclosures when homeowners fall behind on mortgage payments. Regional Weeklies/Section 12+ Travel/Section 5 Cruise issue: Heading for calmer waters amid concern over security, plus a guide to worldwide sailings. Also: Reports on tighter airport security. Magazine/Section 6 It was a local woman out for a walk who found him lying by the side of the road in I.R.A. "bandit country" in South Armagh, Northern Ireland. Patrick Flood's hands were tied behind his back with tape, and a black gar bage bag was pulled over his head. He had been shot once from behind. It was a still July evening, a quiet night for the quiet death of an I.R.A. informer. He killed, and was killed, for the re publican cause. Sports/Section 8 Television Section 11* The Week in Review Section 4 With editorials, letters and Op-Ed Employment Advertising Section 9*

title: Teaching Children to Manage Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths in Pakistan-Afghan Quake Are Put at 300
description: Rescue workers trudged through knee-deep snow today to reach mountain villages in Pakistan and Afghanistan where at least 300 people were killed by an earthquake on Friday, according to official estimates.

title: Reflections on What the World Has Come To
description: WAR, plague, famine and pestilence may be closing in on the world, but artists keep plugging away at the issues as if they could be resolved. The six at Aljira, here, address the realities of daily existence in "Living Space -- Exterior/Interior."

title: Social Events
description: Actors Play at Bowls

title: IF I'D STOOD UP EARLIER
description: Cheers to Mark Goodson for reminding us, even belatedly, of the injustice of television blacklisting in the 1950's ("If I'd Stood Up Earlier. . ." Jan. 13). I was a young television writer and worked for a time as assistant story editor for Unit Four, a production company made up of bright, creative young men.

title: In Pursuit of Careers, Dancers Struggle to Survive
description: ON a typical day during the New Jersey ballet season, dancers do their first plies in classes that start about 10 A.M. and end at noon. They will rehearse for five hours more and, if there is an evening performance, continue dancing until 10 or 10:30 P.M., when the audience gathers up coats and leaves the theater.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Sarah Schulte is more or less accustomed to her daughter's and son's questioning what she is going to wear when she goes out or appears with them. She figures that maybe it's because she's an artist and likes offbeat clothes. "I don't know whether they think I'm going to underdress or overdress," she said.

title: Embracing Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Someone Was Silly
description: INSIDE CHRISTIE'S By John Herbert. Illustrated. 407 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.

title: Perspectives: The Assessment Roll; Changing a System of Unequal Burdens
description: BELATEDLY, assessments in New York City rose in the mid-80's to reflect the growth in market values. And now, again belatedly, they have begun to drop to reflect the decline.

title: Northeast Notebook: Bethany Beach, Del.; Old-Fashioned Bungalows
description: WITH Delaware's resort real estate selling at the slowest pace since the mid-70's, a developer here is trying to find a market niche with a waterfront project based on an old-fashioned concept .

title: Tennis World Loses Riordan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jennifer Gooch Is to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Herrick Gooch of Brookline, Mass., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Jennifer Duffield Gooch and Craig Hummer, the son of Harry Hummer of Houston and Jane Hummer of Worthington, Ohio. The couple, both 25 years old, are graduates of Kenyon College. She is a lyric soprano and an actress. He is a professional athlete competing in the triathlon.

title: Stamford Business Infuses a Drama
description: SO what if Thursday's opening of "The Warehouse," which is about Stamford, is more an apt coincidence than a planned celebration of the city's 350th anniversary? Timing is all, and Steve Karp's is perfect.

title: U.S. Offers Rules on Wine Drinks
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms announced a proposed change in regulations on Friday that would prevent companies from packaging potent wines to look like lower-alcohol wine coolers.

title: The Sloop of Araby
description: THE LAST VOYAGE OF SOMEBODY THE SAILOR By John Barth. 573 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: 'Opening Night on Broadway'
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Off the List
description: Four years ago, when Patricia Lara, a reporter for Colombia's leading newspaper, El Tiempo, came to New York to attend an awards ceremony at Columbia University, she was held in maximum-security detention and barred from the country. Ms. Lara's name was on the Immigration and Naturalization Service's "lookout" list because of suspicions that she was linked with a Colombian terrorist organization called M-19. Last week, Ms. Lara, who insists that her only contact with the group was as a journalist, settled a $10 million lawsuit against the Federal Government by accepting a visa. "You know, I love New York and I thought it was better to be able to go there whenever I want than to have $10 million," said Ms. Lara, who is now married to Colombia's new Ambassador to Austria, Alfonso Gomez Mendez. She and her husband expect to come to New York in two weeks on their way to Vienna, where she will be El Tiempo's correspondent.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TRIGGER DANCEBy Diane Glancy.Fiction Collective Two/University of Colorado, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.

title: The Region; New York City Tallies The Human Costs Of Its 1970's Cutbacks
description: FORCED to pare spending, some New York City officials are expressing concern that false economies will return to haunt them. Since the city's 1975 fiscal crisis, the enduring impact of thousands of layoffs, of other wholesale budget cuts, and of deferred maintenance of bridges, school buildings, roads and mass-transit equipment is difficult to quantify. But, as the city again considers economies of that magnitude for the first time since the mid-1970's, and New York State does, too, some officials are quietly asking -- and advocates outside government are questioning more vocally -- what price today's cutbacks will exact.

title: Review/Dance; The Young Eliot Feld Is Reflected in New Bill
description: "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man" might serve as a subtitle for the second program in the current season given by Feld Ballets/NY at the Joyce Theater.

title: Review/Music; Schutz-Purcell Program By Sine Nomine Singers
description: The Sine Nomine Singers devoted their program last Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall to music by Heinrich Schutz and Henry Purcell, composers whose lives overlapped but whose styles were a world apart.

title: In Defense of His Father
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
George Steinbrenner in Exile
description: For George Steinbrenner, the heat was getting to be a little too much.

title: Patriots Work. Star Wars Won't.
description: Night after night, television viewers have been stirred by scenes of Patriot missiles rising into the sky to knock down Iraq's Scud missiles aimed at Israel and Saudi Arabia. But now President Bush and Congressional hawks wrongly cite this achievement to justify reviving Star Wars, the ailing program to develop a space-based missile defense.

title: Residential Resales
