title: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .; Return to Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Key to 'Luisa' Is -- Luisa
description: On Thursday evening, Verdi's most unappreciated opera returns to the Met. (The superlative is important. In today's frantic-paced world of culture consumption, how much attention can we spare for artistic goods that aren't the most something or other?) Although "Luisa Miller" has over the last quarter-century edged into the semistandard repertory, it still doesn't get much respect. In fact, its performers often seem to be among the many opera folk who aren't quite sure why it should be bothered with.

title: The Limelight Shines Brightly on the East Coast
description: TOM VOLPE of Huntington is in the movie business. "I had Paul Newman over to dinner one night," he said. "I know him well."

title: St. John's Sexual-Assault Trial Delayed
description: The trials of six St. John's University students charged with sexually assaulting another student have been delayed for more than a month by an argument over whether a judge's decision in the case will worsen the victim's ordeal.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Check stored bulbs to be sure they are not drying out; spray gently with water if they seem to be on the dry side. Mail in seed and plant orders to be sure of getting first choices. Look over mulches made from cut-up evergreen branches and spread over flower borders to be sure they have not been tossed about by recent wind storms. Worms

title: Stricter Rules On Airport Noise May Be Blocked
description: Despite the unanimous vote of the Board of Legislators last year calling for a more restrictive noise policy at the County Airport, Westchester officials said last week that the request might have come too late.

title: Anne R. Chapin Plans to Marry
description: Neil Chapin Jr. of Siesta Key, Fla., and Mrs. Lincoln Stevenson of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Roberts Chapin to Dr. William Stanley Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Dean Martin of Rochester, Vt. A May wedding is planned.

title: Lisa Blauhut to Wed William Demarest
description: October wedding plans for Lisa Amy Blauhut and William Edward Demarest, a son of Carole Demarest of Woodside, Queens, and the late Gerard Demarest, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Blauhut of Piermont, N.Y.

title: Bugged
description: To the Editor:

title: Vilnius Tense as Rivals Patrol Streets
description: The independence government of Lithuania reported no noticeable easing of tensions in the streets of Vilnius today as rival night patrols were carried out by pro-Moscow Soviet army soldiers and militiamen loyal to the republic.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in an apartment on the first floor of a six-story building. At times, the kitchen sink accumulates soapy suds or cloudy water that backs up from the drain. Thesuperintendent installed what he called a "check valve," which helped for a while, but now the condition has returned. Can this be corrected?

title: Victory for Fly So Free
description: Racing for the first time in more than three months, Fly So Free solidified his position as the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby by passing previously undefeated To Freedom in the last 60 yards today to win the $92,455 Hutcheson Stakes by a length at Gulfstream Park.

title: Cari M. Shane Engaged to Wed Scott D. Parven
description: Nathan Shane and Corinne Shane of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cari Meredith Shane, to Scott David Parven, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Parven of West Hartford, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Schrempf Leads Pistons And Then is Ejected
description: Detlef Schrempf came off the bench, tied a career-high with 29 points, pulled down 13 rebounds and was ejected for fighting with Gary Payton in the Indiana Pacers' 106-100 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight.

title: Ms. Wasserman, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wasserman of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rochelle Beth Wasserman to Jeffrey Lee Dashevsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Dashevsky of Cheltenham, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Lab Official Guilty in Medical-Waste Case
description: An executive of a Brooklyn medical laboratory has been found guilty by a Federal jury in Brooklyn of illegally dumping vials of blood, some contaminated with hepatitis B virus, in waters off Staten Island and New Jersey in 1988.

title: And the Food Was Swill (I Mean Swell)
description: Tomorrow, the U.S.O. celebrates the 50th anniversary of serving our servicemen and servicewomen at home and overseas, in war and peace. This May, I'll be celebrating my 50-year relationship with the U.S.O. Few marriages last that long and, what's more, we've never said a harsh word to one another.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; This Time, 'Good to Go' Is American Battle Cry
description: "Sorry about that" was repeated by American soldiers so often in Vietnam that it became a disillusioned catch phrase for that war. Thus far in the Persian Gulf war, the comparable phrase is the far more bouyant "good to go."

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in an apartment on the first floor of a six-story building. At times, the kitchen sink accumulates soapy suds or cloudy water that backs up from the drain. Thesuperintendent installed what he called a "check valve," which helped for a while, but now the condition has returned. Can this be corrected?

title: Janet Leinwand to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. David Leinwand of White Plains have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Janet Leslie Leinwand and Andrew Paul Bein, the son of Joan Leibowitz of Yonkers and the late Walter Bein. Miss Leinwand, 23 years old, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. She teaches pupils with learning disabilities at the Churchill School in New York. Mr. Bein, 25, graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is studying for an M.B.A. from Stanford University.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Exhibit Displays University Photos By Ansel Adams
description: Photo graphs of the University of California, taken by Ansel Adams in the 1960's but largely ignored amid the campus upheavals of that era, have re-emerged from the university archives for a special exhibit that will tour six campuses over the next year.

title: All Aboard for the New Europe
description: REMEMBER WHEN EUROPE was just Europe? When it meant a trans-Atlantic crossing, a weekend in London to see the changing of the guard and the Harrods food halls, then to Paris for the clothes and the perfumes, Vienna for the opera and the Sacher torte, Rome for the Pope, and then back with a load of booty and a vague feeling of having seen the land of your (or probably someone else's) ancestors? Simple days, long gone. If you want to know Europe --

title: A Potent 'Designer' Drug
description: Fentanyl, scientists say, is a powerful tranquilizer used in surgery that has been redesigned many times by underground chemists seeking to create synthetic forms of heroin that can be made cheaply in the laboratory.

title: L.I. Sends China Moving AIDS Message
description: THE memory of a 9-year-old Long Islander who died of AIDS last year lives on, in China. It is in the panel of an AIDS quilt delivered in November to China by John Quinlan, a Cornell Cooperative Extension agent and an AIDS education specialist in Riverhead.

title: Custer, Call Your Spin Doctor
description: The occasion: the broadcast of the Super Bowl last Sunday on ABC. The sequence of images: Peter Jennings with a half-time update on the war in the Persian Gulf; a commercial for a four-hour ABC movie called "Son of the Morning Star"; a recap of missed entertainment highlights of the football game, the centerpiece of which was a gigantic patriotic pageant, a rally-round-the-flag extravaganza replete with a taped appearance by President and Mrs. Bush. The Republican National Committee could hardly have asked for more.

title: State Readies Plan to Treat Casualties Of Gulf War
description: WITH elaborate plans they hope not to need, military and civilian doctors, hospital administrators and emergency response personnel in New Jersey are preparing for a major influx of casualties from the conflict in the Persian Gulf. By all accounts, the state could play a significant role if a full-scale ground war begins and large numbers of wounded troops are sent home for treatment and rehabilitation.

title: Contrast Seen In 2 Crashes Of USAir Jets
description: Friday night's collision at Los Angeles International Airport was the second fatal runway accident involving a USAir Boeing 737 in 17 months, but safety experts said yesterday that the crashes appeared very different and that there was no indication so far that USAir or its employees were at fault Friday.

title: Father's Complaint
description: To hear his father, Phillip Harrison, tell it, Shaquille O'Neal of Louisiana State has been the victim of incessant vicious and potentially dangerous assaults that are all too often ignored by referees.

title: Why the World Is After Vanilla Ice
description: Everyone seems to hate Vanilla Ice -- except the seven million or so fans who ignited his rocket ride to the top of the pop charts. With much verve and a bit of glee, the press has combed his past, uncovering inconsistencies in his official biography. To many potential fans he's too teeny-bopper to be cool. Even macho auto buffs laughed when Vanilla Ice was near the first in line to plunk down more than $100,000 for a shiny Acura NSX sports car.

title: Hall of Famer Palmer Says He Pitched Wrong
description: Jim Palmer's attempted comeback, as improbable as it might seem, has to be particularly galling to Pete Rose. Not only can't Rose make a comeback, but he also will learn tomorrow that he's not eligible for the Hall of Fame. Palmer is already in the Hall of Fame.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQ NAVY THREAT ENDED, ALLIES SAY; 2 U.S. JETS DOWNED
description: Six months to the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the American command in the Persian Gulf announced tonight that the allies had put out of action the Iraqi Navy, a slight but dangerous fleet of mostly small patrol boats capable of launching anti-ship missiles from a range of more than 40 miles.

title: HEATING THE GLOBAL WARMING DEBATE
description: LAST MONTH SCIENTISTS reported that 1990 was the warmest year on the meteorological record: the average global temperature, measured over land and sea, exceeded that of any year in the past century or so. Citing this, a group of 16 senators, including Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, wrote a letter to President Bush calling for immediate policy action to counter global warming. The 1990 information, said the senators, "illustrates clearly that global climate change is real."

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN THE COMPANY OF WRITERS A Life in Publishing. By Charles Scribner Jr. Based on the oral history by Joel R. Gardner. Scribners, $22.50.

title: A Special Guide to Cruises Worldwide; To Nassau And Back On a Weekend
description: "SPECTACULAR" seems an understatement for the lobby atrium of the Nordic Empress. A panorama of white, beige, brass and glass, like much of the ship's public areas, it is punctuated with flowering plants and a multilevel waterfall and sparkles with the reflection of hundreds of tiny lights. It is said to soar nine stories -- my count wasn't as high but no matter -- however many stories it is, it's eye-catching. What with the circular glass elevators, and the white piano on a small raised stage, the only thing missing is Noel Coward with a cigarette and Carole Lombard in a figure-hugging white satin gown.

title: Women's Club Still Thriving in Massachusetts
description: Back in a time shortly before World War II when the country's preoccupations dealt with sports and recreation rather than the serious military involvement that ensued, there was just one small hitch in American outdoor life: while men would do almost anything for their women, they doggedly refused to take them hunting and fishing.

title: Mary E. O'Hara Marries in Roslyn
description: Mary Ellen O'Hara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. O'Hara of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn to Andrew Thomas Coyne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Coyne of Drexel Hill, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rt. Rev. Matthew Leavy, who is the abbott of St. Anselm Abbey and the chancellor of St. Anselm College, both in Manchester, N.H. He is a cousin of the bride.

title: Jacqueline Reses To Wed This Year
description: September wedding plans for Jacqueline Dawn Reses and Matthew Benjamin Apfel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. Apfel of Gladwyne, Pa., have been announced by her parents, Ronnie Reses and Stephen Reses, both of Margate, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends; Electricity And Cancer? The Mystery Increases
description: JUST north of Lenox, in the Berkshires of western Massachusetts, the nation's electric utility industry recently finished building a peaceable subdivision with a narrow road, an overhead electric power line, 19 lots, and one lonely two-story Cape Cod style house with nothing inside but naked studs and joists.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;
Freeway Site Project Starts
description: ON a long-derelict swath just north of downtown, construction has begun on the first phase of East Pointe Commons, which, with 700 units, will be the city's largest residential complex. The whole project will cost $85 million and cover nine blocks.

title: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
description: Security measures and police patrols at Brussels International Airport have been reinforced since the war began but so far inconvenience to travelers has been minimal. There have been no more departure delays than usual, and no bomb alerts requiring clearing of the terminals.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 3, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians. 2 2 THE CONQUEST, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $5.50.) Romance bonds two long-feuding feudal families in 15th-century England. 3 1 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures fraught with love, intrigue, revenge and murder. 4 2 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) (Times Books/Random House, $5.95.) A report on the Iraqi President and his invasion of Kuwait. 4 * 63 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 1 DEEP COVER, by Michael Levine. (Dell, $5.95.) The failure of the Government's war on drugs, as seen by a former Federal agent. 8 19 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 7 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 2 27 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 10 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 4 118 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Science Fiction
description: The word for Arthur C. Clarke's latest novel is sunny. On the evidence of THE GHOST FROM THE GRAND BANKS (Bantam Spectra, $19.95) Mr. Clarke, now in his early 70's, is a happy man. He sees the universe as a marvelous toy, coquettishly begging to be understood yet always mocking our success with some deeper mystery. Death, too, has a place in this universe; its ever-present shadow makes our brief moment in the sun all the more precious.

title: CORRECTIONS

A Museum's Replica Inspires New Ideas For a Landscape

He said he had been suffering from homesickness and was taken to the Astor Court Chinese Garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. "I walked through the moon gate and suddenly I was back in China," he said. "It was magic."

description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Still Life With Skyscrapers
description: Between dawn and dusk, the mood of New York City shifts constantly. The architectural photographer Nathaniel Lieberman tries to capture these changes in MANHATTAN LIGHTSCAPE (Abbeville, $55). Choosing panoramas over details, he anchors his photographs with familiar landmarks: the Empire State Building soars out of the hazy gold of the midtown skyline; a lavender twilight becomes a backdrop for the luminous clock on the Metropolitan Life Tower. There are no people in his pictures, no traffic jams. Time-lapse shots turn cars into ribbons of light. The absence of everyday elements makes the images appear weightless. This works well with photographs like one of the Manhattan Bridge at nightfall that reveals its delicate beauty, but just as often the effect is remote and impersonal. Bird's-eye views of New York Harbor and St. Patrick's Cathedral turn the city into an abstract collection of shapes rather than a human habitation. There is more to New York light than the angle of the sun on the side of the Citicorp building.

title: Mediate Leads by 1, Finding the Touch With Long Putter
description: Rocco Mediate stood up to strong Pacific gusts and leaned on his long putter to handle Spyglass Hill's treacherous greens today for a one-shot lead going into the final round of the A.T.& T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

description: Portuguese Vineyards

title: Volatile Seas and Icebergs Await BOC Sailors

The rough waters off Cape Horn in South America impose a physical challenge for competitors, but the self-imposed pressure to win presents a mental obstacle that may be greater.

title: On the Street; Oh, to Stroll in a Scarf That Struts

As winter dress coats were unbuttoned during last week's mild weather, the scarfs were a counterpoint to the tone on tone coloring of calf-length coats and well-tailored suits. Double-breasted and high-button single-breasted styles were popular. The personal choice of scarf and necktie added dash. Other style points were cuffed trousers and suede shoes in shades of brown. Who says winter is bleak?

description: IT was notable in its own right -- an early office tower built under the setback zoning provisions of 1916, elegantly styled after the French Renaissance and first home to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: IF I'D STOOD UP EARLIER
description: Mark Goodson's article would seem to indicate that blacklisting died in 1955. That is far from the case. It was alive and still causing all sorts of problems in the early 1960's when I arrived at B.B.D.O. in New York. One person was assigned to maintain the list, and the euphemism used to request a search through the list was "check availability." To illustrate the absurdity of the times, I recall seeing a teletype message from a regional office that read: "Please check the availability of Joseph Conrad." WILLIAM O'DONNELL MILLER Detroit

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Hamilton
description: THE Fort Hamilton enclave of Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section hasn't changed much since 1930, the last year of a housing boom that had been started by the 1915 extension of the New York City subway system to Brooklyn. Many of the stucco or brick private homes built in those years have remained in the same families.

title: Talking: Water Bills; Curbing Alarming Increases
description: MANY condominums and cooperatives that depend on municipal water supplies have been suffering from sharply rising rates and bills.

title: Bridge
description: Very strong balanced hands have long been a theoretical weak point in standard bidding methods. In the traditional style a three no-trump opening indicated a hand with about 26 points, and higher bids showed even stronger values. This left little room for effective exploration of game and slam possibilities and poor contracts were often the result. In effect, the players were floating in the stratosphere with only a small chance of a safe landing.

title: Tech Notes; Coming Soon: Fiber-Optic Gyroscopes
description: At the heart of most guidance systems are three gyroscopes, devices that measure changes in rotation along each axis. Most of them are mechanical, with a rotating flywheel, or electronic. Now, fiber-optic gyroscopes, with no moving parts, are about to be introduced. Currently in prototype stage, they are being developed by the Guidance and Control Systems Division of Litton Industries Inc. in Woodland Hills, Calif. They are small, from 1 to 3 inches in diameter, depending upon their sensitivity. Gyroscopes work on the principle of the Sagnac interferometer, which measures the interference of light waves. A single beam of near-infrared light is optically split into two beams of identical wavelength. Each beam is sent the opposite way through a tightly wound spool of fiber-optic wire. Changes in the rotation of the spool mean one beam must travel farther than the other, which causes them to interfere with each other. This can be measured by the interferometer; the larger the interference, the greater the rotational change.

title: Mr. Bush Avoids the Q Word
description: "I will once again press the Congress," President Bush said in his State of the Union address last week, "to strengthen the laws against employment discrimination without resorting to the use of unfair preferences." His audience needed no such pressure. Only a few months ago, by nearly two-thirds in each house, Congress passed an excellent civil rights bill -- only to have Mr. Bush veto it.

title: A New Swing for the Once-Forgotten Clarinet
description: The clarinet, which has been modified little over the last century, is one of the most exasperatingly difficult instruments to play. So it is no surprise that it flourished in America mainly in the early decades of this century, when a disciplined, Victorian approach to musical training prevailed. But the clarinet may also be the most rewarding instrument, with its broad range of voices. It can growl with the bite of muted brass or soar with the soulfulness of strings, and its funky subtones can undulate erotically.

title: Food; The Square Meal
description: Know a man whose mother made a "chateaubriand meat loaf," -- with a sauce of undiluted cream of mushroom soup -- about which he waxes poetic. Ruth Adams Bronz, chef and owner of Miss Ruby's Cafe in Manhattan, still makes her mother's recipes: a "basic Texas" variety, and a dish which, for reasons still not entirely clear to Bronz, her mother called Middle Eastern Meat Loaf.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PRISONERS OF WAR

title: Foreclosures Yielding To a Helping Hand
description: WHEN Timothy Protzman left his job at a Hartford radio station three years ago, he saw no financial danger in the month-long break before the start of his next position, at a local televison station. But that unpaid furlough was the beginning of his financial freefall.

title: Deposit Insurance Plan
description: The Administration has decided on a limit, less severe than expected, to the number of bank accounts insured by the Government. Page 28.

title: Design; SNUGGLE UP
description: This winter, oil prices are cause for piling on the blankets and bringing in an extra stash of logs for the wood-burning stove. Those searching for inventive ways to avoid turning up the thermostat can look to homes in England, where an inordinate amount of energy goes into staying warm. In large country houses, for example, heavy velvet curtains -- or portieres, as they are called -- are hung from brass rods and form puddles on the floor. Strategically placed over doorways, they have been a classic solution to keeping out drafts.

title: Ski Poles Of Many Facets
description: Scott USA, the ski-equipment manufacturer from Sun Valley, Idaho, has developed a new method for producing ski poles. The company said the new method would make its poles for next season about 25 percent lighter than this year's.

title: Plan to Limit Deposit Insurance Is Defended
description: The Treasury Department's plan to curtail deposit insurance at the nation's banks was described yesterday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady as an attempt "to make the system safe for savers, but yet to make sure the taxpayer does not have to pay enormous bills when banks fail."

title: Toxic Heroin Has Killed 12, Officials Say
description: The death toll from a batch of poisonous heroin rose to 12 yesterday, the authorities in four Northeastern cities said.

title: Craving for Better High Is Synthetics' Fatal Lure
description: The appearance of a potent synthetic heroin that killed 12 addicts over the weekend is dramatic evidence, drug experts say, that there is a constant quest in the murky world of narcotics for better, more intense highs -- even at the risk of death -- and perhaps an attempt by drug dealers to introduce new products as cocaine and crack wane in popularity.

title: Iceland Puts the West to Shame on Baltics
description: To the Editor:

title: Developers Shrug Off Rate Cut
description: The latest steps to reduce interest rates -- the Federal Reserve's half-point cut in the discount rate on Friday and a similar cut in the prime rate used by banks -- are no more likely to provide relief to developers and investors in the beleaguered commercial real estate market than other interest rate cuts in the last six months, developers and financiers say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If you're going to ride the elevators alone at night, you better go with Jesus." -- Crystal Gover, a resident of the Martin Luther King Jr. Towers, a public housing project in Harlem. [ B4:2. ]

title: Outdoors: Hunters Prepare for Chase
description: UPLAND bird, waterfowling and deer seasons have ended in the Northeast, save for February ruffed grouse hunting in most of New York State and one more day of Canada goose hunting in Massachusetts and Connecticut, but many hunters are abroad in pursuit of cottontail rabbits and varying hares.

title: Cuts After Decade of Cuts: Governors Grim at Meeting
description: People who have been attending the midwinter meetings of the nation's governors for years cannot remember a bleaker assessment of the states' financial condition than the one they heard this weekend.

title: Chronicle
description: Reading poems by T. S. ELIOT that have never been published, ALAN BENNETT will play the poet at an English festival commemorating the 50th anniversary of VIRGINIA WOOLF' s death.

title: Review/Television; A Potpourri Of Cher's Mood Swings
description: Whatever you may think of Cher, born some 44 years ago and named Cherilyn Sarkisian, it's just about impossible to ignore her as she keeps popping up in movies, on magazine covers and -- as can be seen tonight at 10 on CBS -- as the indisputable centerpiece of her own television specials. "Cher at the Mirage" was taped last summer at the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. The star was on her "Heart of Stone" tour, in a stage show directed and choreographed by Kenny Ortega.

description: A crowd of 3,500 people marched around the White House today to show support for President Bush and the Persian Gulf war. The marchers waved flags, jeered at peace demonstrators and burned an Iraqi flag.

title: Review/Jazz; Far From the Conservatory
description: Lynne Arriale is a pianist who seems intent on doing things the hard way. Nine years ago, having earned a master's degree in classical music at the Wisconsin Conservatory of Music, she turned her back on a classical career and started studying jazz, to which she had previously paid little attention.

title: Carnesecca Talks Memories
description: Someone asked Lou Carnesecca on Saturday which of his 500 victories had been the most satisfying. Obviously the victory over Seton Hall on Saturday ranked right up there because it was his 500th.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Library Is Given a New Name
description: The New York Public Library at Lincoln Center has been renamed the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Arab-Expulsion Party in Israel's Cabinet
description: After a long and angry debate, the Israeli Cabinet today voted to accept as a new member of the Government a small right-wing party that advocates expelling all the Palestinians from the occupied territories.

Gleason has been appointed a creative director of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. * McCann-Erickson Worldwide promoted Rob Brown to senior vice president, Steve Cunetta to vice president and Ed Tajon to vice president. * Michael V. title: The Welfare Hotel That Isn't
description: The Regent was a notorious welfare hotel just a few years ago, as bad for its residents as for the surrounding Upper West Side community. Violence, drug use and prostitution flourished in its shabby corridors and spilled out onto the street. Two years ago, as a threatened loss of Federal funds led the Koch administration to phase out the use of welfare hotels, the Regent went out of the homeless business. Now it's back.

title: Science Would Receive One of Sharpest Rises in Spending in Bush Plan
description: Science and technology would receive one of the highest rates of increased spending under the budget that President Bush will send to Congress on Monday, Administration officials say.

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: Clearing skies are expected in the Persian Gulf. Sunny and mild weather will prevail in Iraq and northern Saudi Arabia. After morning clouds, sun will increase in Syria and Lebanon. Clouds will linger from northern Egypt to southern Israel as onshore winds blow. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 57, low 34; Riyadh, high 70, low 43; Dhahran, high 69, low 49.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Factory Orders . . . Dec. Wednesday None Thursday Consumer Credit . . . Dec. Friday None

title: South Asia Earthquake Toll May Exceed 700 Fatalities
description: As many as 400 people may have been killed in Afghanistan during the earthquake that struck South Asia on Friday, aid workers said today. That could bring to more than 700 the number of people killed in the quake, felt from Soviet Central Asia to India.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; In Super Bowl Race, The Loser May Win Big
description: WHEN the National Football League agreed to its latest television contract a year ago, it held one prize out of the package: the 1994 Super Bowl. The race to claim that prize began last week, with at least some of the competitors convinced that the biggest loser may be the ultimate winner.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; Beirut Reports Arrest Of Terrorist's Aide; Army to Go to South
description: The Lebanese Government says it has arrested four senior Palestinian guerrillas, including a senior aide to the terrorist leader Abu Nidal, and is sending hundreds of troops to the south of the country in a bid to check the Palestine Liberation Organization's power there.

title: Congress to the Rescue
description: The New York Times is now frequently using the words "the Gorbachev Government" to refer to the clique purporting to lead the disintegrating Soviet Union.

title: As Realty Taxes Go Up, Up, Dreams Die in New Jersey
description: Much of the often angry politics in Trenton these days boils down to the kind of numbers that torment Angelo Verduci, a 74-year-old retiree in this fast-growing suburb.

title: Raiders Chic: A Style, And Sinister Overtones
description: Nearly 3,000 miles from Southern California, 19-year-old Andy Sennon could be found the other day in Brooklyn, draped over a parked car, wearing the black and silver of the Los Angeles Raiders football team.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Sensuous Ode, With Action, to Open Sexuality
description: Doug Elkins helpfully provides the key to his work with the title of his new program, "The Incessant Recycling of Images," which runs through Sunday at Dance Theater Workshop (219 West 19th Street). Mr. Elkins is an assembler. And in his new "A Cerca de la Escuelita," set to popular music ranging from Queen Latifah to Cole Porter with a heavy dose of salsa thrown in, the pieces add up to an invigorating, often witty outpouring of dance.

title: Credibility Gap in Gulf War
description: Signs of a credibility gap in the gulf war have appeared, but top officers seem eager to head off a worsening antagonism between the military and the press. News analysis, page A9.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Troop Carrier; Armored Vehicle Is Checked For Defective Transmissions
description: The Army said yesterday that it was checking its most advanced armored personnel carrier for defective transmissions, but added that the problem was not widespread and would not erode the effectiveness of American forces in the Persian Gulf.

title: College Sports: Losing Millions?
description: Bribery, altered transcripts and players who never graduate have given college sports a horrendous public image. The emerging facts about the shaky financial condition of college athletic departments darken it further. Even glamorous, "successful" athletic departments can spend millions more than they take in, running deficits that siphon off precious educational resources.

title: Soldier Is Discharged for Not Telling of AIDS
description: A soldier who was ordered to tell his sex partners that he was infected with the AIDS virus was dishonorably discharged when he failed to do so, Army officials have said.

title: It's Settled! Knicks Commit to a Starting 5
description: After two months as the Knicks' coach, John MacLeod thinks he has finally settled on a starting lineup for his team.

title: Life-Death Struggle Tests Doctors Sorely
description: To the Editor:

title: New Delhi Ousts Government of a Big State
description: In a move that critics say was as much an assault on the Indian Constitution as on a leader of the political opposition, Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar has dismissed the elected government of a big southern state, Tamil Nadu.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; War Cries and Whistling in the Dark
description: Capt. Mike Sanders of the Army's Second Armored Division used the tip of his bayonet to draw sharp, forceful lines in the dirt floor of his tent, mapping out what he said would be a land war of extraordinary violence.

title: Environmental Coalition Is Split
description: An unlikely coalition of state officials, industry representatives and environmentalists that had pledged to reduce the amount of solid waste going into landfills in the Northeast has become divided over rules intended to cut down the amount of packaging used in consumer products.

title: Pete Axthelm, 47, Sports Author, Columnist and TV Commentator
description: Pete Axthelm, a columnist, television sports commentator and author, died on Saturday at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 47 years old and lived in New York City and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Janet Hobhouse, 42, A Novelist and Editor
description: Janet Hobhouse, a writer and editor who earned acclaim and adherents for three stylish novels on marriage and alternative styles of living, died on Friday night at her home in Manhattan. She was 42 years old.

title: Despite Ad Slump, U.S. Magazines Move to Britain
description: Steven Goodman, a London media analyst, contends that the current British market for new magazines is "downright diabolical."

title: 'Indecent' Cartoon Prank
description: Federal authorities are investigating the broadcast of seven seconds of sexually explicit videotape during a morning children's program on a television station here. The broadcast, on WNOL-TV, a Fox affiliate, was described as "indecent" by Madelyn Bonnot, the station's general manager. It appeared Thursday in the cartoon series "Wake, Rattle and Roll." "We are outraged and are conducting a thorough investigation," Ms. Bonnot said.

title: Time to Thaw U.S. Policy in Korea
description: While cold-war frost still chills U.S. diplomacy in Korea, Japan and North Korea have begun breaking the ice. Their first round of talks on normalizing relations ended inconclusively last week. But North Korea's new flexibility offers promise when talks resume next month.

title: For Ad Agencies, a Costly Hard Sell
description: When the Volvo North America Corporation concludes the three-way competition for its automobile advertising account this week, one ad agency will walk away with business worth $40 million in annual billings.

title: New York Teachers Defer Wages
description: By a closer vote than one taken by their leadership, New York City's teachers ratified an agreement that will defer a portion of this year's salary for four years and avoid thousands of layoffs, union officials announced early yesterday.

title: MNC Posts Loss for 1990
description: MNC Financial Inc. reported last week that it lost $198 million in the last quarter of 1990 and $440 million for the full year.

title: Doris Roslyn Robin Is Wed
description: Doris Roslyn Robin and Arthur Irwin Witz were married last evening by Rabbi Charles J. Davidson at the Metropolitan in Glen Cove, L.I. Mrs. Robin-Witz is the executive legislative coordinator and secretary to Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker and majority leader of the New York City Council. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of her husband, a manufacturers' representative to the electrical industry.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Armstrong World Industries Inc., Lancaster, Pa., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $250 million in debt securities. Common Stock * Cygnus Therapeutic Systems, Redwood City, Calif., is offering three million common shares at $9 a share through Robertson, Stephens & Co. Ratings * Summit Bancorporation's senior debt rating has been lowered to Baa-3, from Baa-2, by Moody's. The company is based in Summit, N.J.

title: Hard Lesson for Army Reserve: How to Write a Will
description: Like reserve soldiers all over the United States, the men and women of the aviation-repair unit of the Connecticut Army National Guard here are watching events in the Persian Gulf with a mixture of fear, anticipation and resignation. The war is lasting longer than many originally thought, and rumors are rife that the unit will be shipping out soon to Saudi Arabia.

title: Changing View of Cancer: Something to Live With
description: Margaretta Young was a Charlotte, N.C., teacher when she felt a tiny lump in her breast on Easter weekend in 1963. Since then, doctors have found tumors in her bones, liver, brain, parathyroid and stomach.

title: SOVIET VENTURES ARE LOSING APPEAL FOR U.S. BUSINESS
description: One casualty of the political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union has been American enthusiasm for investment there.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sabatini Wins Pan Pacific Open: Gabriela Sabatini won the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo yesterday with a three-set victory over Martina Navratilova. Sabatini, who beat top-ranked Steffi Graf in the quarterfinals and fifth-ranked Mary Joe Fernandez in the semifinals, defeated Navratilova, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4, to earn a $70,000 first prize. Sabatini is ranked No. 4 in the world and won the United States Open last September. Navratilova, returning to action after missing three months of competition because of surgery on both knees, breezed through the first five games as Sabatini struggled to adjust her serve on the artificial surface. Sabatini, who had seven double-faults, began the second set with an ace and went on to win the next three games with strong passing shots and well-placed serve returns. Though Navratilova broke Sabatini's serve in the third set's first game, her own service was broken in the sixth and again in the eighth after she led 40-0. (AP) Germany Defeats Italy: Boris Becker rallied and Michael Stich recovered, rescuing Germany for a 3-2 victory yesterday over Italy in first-round Davis Cup competition in Dortmund, Germany. Becker beat Omar Camporese, 3-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, giving Germany a tie at two matches to two in the three-of-five-match competition. Stich then defeated Paolo Cane, 7-6, 6-7, 7-5, 6-1, for the victory. Germany, playing for the first time since reunification, faces Argentina in the next round. Second-seeded Australia completed a 5-0 sweep of Belgium. Richard Fromberg, the top-seeded Australian, beat Eduardo Masso, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, and Wally Masur beat Filip Dewulf, 6-1, 6-2. Australia will face either Israel or France in the next round. (AP) N.F.L. A.F.C. 23, N.F.C. 21: Jim Kelly, the Buffalo Bills' quarterback, threw two touchdown passes, the second a 13-yarder to Ernest Givins of the Houston Oilers with 1 minute 49 seconds remaining, to give the American Football Conference a victory in the Pro Bowl last night in Honolulu. Unlike last week's Super Bowl, Kelly was on the other side as a team failed to kick a game-winning field goal in the final seconds. Last week, Scott Norwood of the Bills failed on a 47-yarder as Buffalo lost to the Giants, 20-19. Last night, Morten Andersen of New Orleans who failed to come through for the National Football Conference, when his 46-yarder was blocked with seven seconds to play by Miami's Jeff Cross. (AP) Skiing Nierlich Keeps Giant Slalom Title: Rudolf Nierlich successfully defended his world title in the men's giant slalom yesterday in the world Alpine championships at Saalbach-Hinterglemm, Austria. Nierlich, who also won the giant slalom at the 1989 world championships, held on to his title when the first-run leader, Alberto Tomba, fell near the top of the course. He finished with a winning aggregate time of 2 minutes 29.94 seconds. Urs Kaelin of Switzerland won the silver medal with a time of 2:30.29 and Johan Wallner of Sweden took the bronze in 2:30.73. (AP) Auto Racing Haywood Team Wins 24-Hour Race: Hurley Haywood and four Europeans completed an almost faultless drive yesterday in winning the Daytona 24 Hours in Daytona Beach, Fla., in a Porsche 962C prototype. The victory was a record fifth in the event for Haywood, from nearby Jacksonville, as well as the fourth for his teammate Bob Wollek of France. Also taking turns in the car fielded by Reinhold Jost of Germany were John Winter and Frank Jelinski of Germany and Henri Pescarolo of France. The victory for Porsche gave the German manufacturer its 18th victory in this race in 23 attempts, although Jaguars had won two of the last three. The winning car averaged 106.663 miles an hour, completing 719 laps around the 3.56-mile Daytona International Speedway circuit, a total of 2,559.64 miles. (AP) Soccer Bayern Munich 4, United States 0: Roland Wohlfarth scored two goals in the first half yesterday as the German champion, Bayern Munich, beat the United States, 4-0, in the Miami Cup tournament. (AP)

title: Liquor Ad Rule Is Reconsidered
description: The Washington State Liquor Control Board adopted rules last week to limit alcohol advertising but later decided that it had acted illegally and that it would have to start over again this week.

title: Helping Hostile Cultures Touch
description: Richard Sennett is a man who likes to ramble, both intellectually and on foot. In his new book, "The Conscience of the Eye: The Design and Social Life of Cities," the widely published and much-debated New York University sociologist takes the reader on several walks through New York City, commenting along the way on the lack of community, the separation of misery and wealth, and the absence of "a telling moment of talking or touching or connection."

title: Shutdowns Set By Car Makers
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers plan to shut 24 car and truck assembly plants this week, temporarily idling more than 62,000 workers because of a shortage of dealer orders, the companies said last week.

title: China Takes Hard Line, Waging War on Words
description: As part of the broad struggle for the soul of China, a tug-of-war has emerged over the future direction of the Chinese language, and therein is a tale of comrades, poisonous weeds, Misses and kisses.

title: Rangers See Progress, But Lose to Jets, 4-3
description: Certainly there were positive aspects for the Rangers in their 4-3 loss to the Winnipeg Jets last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Frank Rose, U. of Alabama Chief During Racial Turmoil, Dies at 70
description: Frank Anthony Rose, the president of the University of Alabama from 1958 to 1969, the era when it was peacefully desegregated, died Friday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 70 years old and had homes in Washington and Lexington, Ky.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Logistics; From Bombs to Burgers, Gulf War Involves Biggest Supply Effort Ever
description: The two-lane highways snaking through the desert north and east of here look like American expressways at rush hour these days.

title: Hometown Hero With an Arm of Clay
description: "NICE September." The voice, loud and laced with sarcasm, pierced the gathering quiet of the Bensonhurst movie theater as John Franco and his wife took their seats last Christmas night.

title: Oakland Journal; Schools Resist Call of the Military
description: Oakland Technical High School is a campus of nearly 1,600 students, 93 percent of them black, Hispanic or Asian. Unlike some other inner-city high schools, it appears to be winning the war against drugs and gangs and is keeping its old buildings well-maintained and nearly graffiti-free.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Rogues' Gallery of Sociopaths
description: Sociopaths sell.

title: Bridge
description: Ignorance of or disregard for one fundamental law of duplicate tends to promote ignorance of all the others. Whenever an irregularity occurs, the director must be summoned; the players are not permitted to settle matters among themselves, even if they are sure that they understand the appropriate law. Dummy may not call the director, but if the other players fail to do so he may remind them of that duty.

title: Review/Music; Wind Quintet With Piano
description: The literature for piano and woodwind quintet is sorely limited, but opportunities multiply quickly if one or another player is willing to sit out at times. So woodwind groups occasionally form lasting alliances with pianists.

title: List of Deaths On One Plane
description: Following is a list, released by SkyWest Airlines, of crew members and passengers who were killed. USAir has not provided a list of casualties on its plane, but it has said that the pilot, Capt. Colin Shaw, 48, of Washington, died in the crash. The list was provided by The Associated Press. Crew LUCAS, Capt. Andrew, Pismo Beach, Calif., pilot. PRENTICE, Frank Charles 3d, San Luis Obispo, Calif., co-pilot. Passengers FULLER, Michael, Palmdale, Calif., SkyWest Palmdale station manager. GILLIAM, Scott, Palmdale. JANISSE, Judy, California City, Calif. MARTIN, Bryan, Palmdale. REID, Ed, Palmdale. RIDDLE, Ed, Lancaster, Calif. ROBERTS, Debbie, Azores Islands, Portugal. SRIJAERAJAH, Krishani, Palmdale. STEEN, Jeff, Palmdale; WILBURN, Randy, Palmdale.

title: With New Law, Budget Makers Face New Limits
description: Some items in President Bush's 1992 budget, which will be made public on Monday, will be worth careful scrutiny. Others can be safely ignored.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Latin America; War's Ripples Lap at Latin America
description: One recent morning, a group of young men hurled paint bombs at the United States Consulate here, protesting American participation in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Pressures Are Building For Lower Bond Yields
description: Many credit market analysts say bond yields, which have not fallen nearly as far as short-term interest rates have declined during the last seven months, may be about to make up for lost time.

title: A New Place for Getting In Some Cuts
description: ABOUT a year and a half ago, Gary Rosenberg of Manhattan got upset when he first realized that if he wanted to take his son to a batting cage, he would have to travel to Brooklyn. "I thought it wasn't fair that because I choose to live in Manhattan, my son Erich would be deprived of the pleasure of taking his swings at a neighborhood batting cage," Rosenberg recalled.

title: INSIDE
description: Radar Lapse in Plane Crash The radar that air traffic controllers use to watch aircraft on runways was out of service when two planes crashed in Los Angeles. Page A13. No Elixir for Real Estate Friday's announcements of lower interest rates are likely to provide no more relief to developers and investors than previous rate cuts. Page D1. New Budget, New Process Partly because of the new budget law, only part of what President Bush proposes today will warrant great scrutiny. News analysis, page A14. Exit for Italy's Communists Italy's Communist Party faded into history, transformed into an uncertain creation called the Democratic Party of the Left. Page A3. War of Words in China As part of the struggle for the soul of China, a tug-of-war has emerged over the future direction of the Chinese language. Page A6.

title: Anne Walsh Poggi, 78, Ex-Financial Executive
description: Anne Walsh Poggi, a former vice president of Dun & Bradstreet, died on Wednesday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Thumb in Baseball's Hall of Fame
description: THUMBS will surely go down today in the meeting room of the board of directors of the Baseball Hall of Fame, and bury the hopes of Pete Rose. The board has gathered to act on the recommendation by a special committee that anyone (read that "Rose") who is on baseball's permanently ineligible list be ineligible for the Hall of Fame.

title: 2 Verdicts Voided in Du Pont Secrets Case
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned the convictions of two Argentines accused of trying to extort $10 million form the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in return for stolen documents that included trade secrets.

title: As Villagers Return Unfazed, Chernobyl Aims for Tourists
description: Here in the forbidden zone so close to the entombed remains of the deadly Chernobyl nuclear accident, less and less seems to be forbidden.

title: Miss Weil Weds L. R. Glassman
description: Jessica Clare Weil, a daughter of Lynn McNeil and Bruce R. Weil, both of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Richard Glassman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ephraim Glassman of Brookville, L.I. Rabbi John Schechter performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Chronicle
description: LANCE LIEBMAN, a 49-year-old Harvard University law professor whose career has centered on social issues in Asia and the United States, has been chosen as the new dean of the Columbia University School of Law.

title: Poland Asks West to Cancel Most of Its Big Foreign Debt
description: Asserting that Poland deserves favorable treatment because it is a pioneer in moving toward a market economy, Poland's new Prime Minister called on Western creditors today to forgive 80 percent of his nation's $46 billion in foreign debt.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Draft; Despite Pentagon Denial of Plans, Many Are Looking Over Shoulder
description: Although Selective Service offices around the country report a surge in registrations by 18-year-olds and a barrage of telephone inquiries about the possibility of a resumption of the draft, Defense Department officials insist there is ample active and reserve manpower to see the war in the Persian Gulf to its conclusion.

title: Review/Film; Photojournalist Copes With Tragedy but Not Heartbreak
description: Rarely has a city been filmed with such an exquisite sensitivity to the relationship among architecture, climate and the emotions as Montreal the way it is pictured in Lea Pool's visually compelling drama, "Straight for the Heart."

title: Blooming Outside The Garden
description: RICK PITINO settled into one of the visitors' seats in his office at Memorial Coliseum and listened intently as a reporter from New York recounted woeful tales from Madison Square Garden.

title: Debate Properly Shifts on Animal Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Yellow Ribbons
description: In Rome, Ga., they stream from car antennas, and in Jacksonville, Fla., they decorate the lampposts. A florist in Pound Ridge, N.Y., is giving them away, and a few days ago, on the Massachusetts Turnpike, a long line of tractor-trailers flourished them on their hoods. All across the United States the streamers flutter in the winter air. Yellow ribbons, miles of yellow ribbons, for every American man and woman in the Persian Gulf.

title: U.N.L.V. Overruns Rutgers
description: Stacey Augmon had the second triple-double of his career and Anderson Hunt scored a season-high 29 points today as Nevada-Las Vegas routed Rutgers, 115-73, to remain the nation's only undefeated major college team. Augmon scored 27 points and had 11 rebounds and 11 assists. U.N.L.V. (18-0) blew the game open with a 20-2 run to start the second half. The loss snapped a six-game winning streak for Rutgers (13-7). Daryl Smith led Rutgers wih 17 points. DePaul 72; Georgetown 63

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: FILLING THE GAP Oil-producing nations in East Asia are stepping up efforts to drill, and several governments are scrambling to profit from the current demand for crude oil. Business Day, page D1.

title: Cambodia Peace Accord Adjustments Sought
description: In an effort to break an impasse on a United Nations peace plan for Cambodia, the country's four warring factions will be asked to meet again in the next few weeks, Western and Asian diplomats said today.

title: Review/Music; Popular Tunes That Aged Into Classics
description: James Richman, the director of Concert Royal, found an interesting premise for his ensemble's program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening. The focus was on music that was popular in London in the 17th and 18th centuries, with examples of what Mr. Richman described in his program notes as both high and low art.

title: The Old Order
description: Shortly before midnight last Tuesday, Israeli police took Sari Nusseibeh, a prominent Palestinian moderate, from his home in a Jerusalem suburb. He was told that he was being put in "administrative detention" -- prison -- for six months.

title: Frederick J. Handler, Yacht Builder, Marries Jennifer Lynne Eley, Pianist
description: Jennifer Lynne Eley, a concert pianist, and Frederick John Handler, a writer and yacht builder, were married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. Ernest E. Ryden, a Lutheran minister who is an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Scandal Yields Windfall for an Impoverished City
description: Frustrated by the roller coaster of high hopes and dashed dreams that this nearly bankrupt city has been riding for years, a Federal district judge has found a way to turn a financial scandal into a windfall for its residents.

title: Chandris Picks Korey, Kay
description: Korey, Kay & Partners has been awarded the account for Chandris Celebrity Cruises, worth an estimated $10 million in billings.

title: Few Bidders Are Expected In Bank Sale
description: Like skeptics coming to kick the tires at a used-car lot, bankers have been flying to Boston to examine the books at the failed Bank of New England. Within three months, the bank is scheduled to be sold by the Federal Government, most likely to another bank. But those close to the process say it will not be an easy sell.

title: Head of Federation To Resign at Year-End
description: After 23 years as president and chief executive of the American Advertising Federation, Howard H. Bell has announced plans to resign at the end of the year.

title: Azinger Fires a 67 For a Big Victory
description: Paul Azinger used an eagle on the second hole as a catapult to run away from a group of struggling contenders today and easily win the A.T.& T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Ereng Is Back In Run
description: Paul Ereng was just days past his 20th birthday in 1988 when he won the 800-meter final at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. A little-known Kenyan runner at the time, and a sophomore-to-be at the University of Virginia, he upset a powerful field that included Said Aouita of Morocco, Joachim Cruz of Brazil and Peter Elliott of Britain.

title: Reviews/Dance; An Abridged 'Swan Lake' With a Regal Odette
description: Valentina Kozlova dances so lucidly as the Swan Queen that she deserves an unmuddied "Swan Lake." The one-act version of the familiar Tchaikovsky classic that the New York City Ballet has in its repertory is more peculiar than persuasive. Nevertheless, Miss Kozlova invested it with both drama and lyricism when she appeared on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater as Odette, the Queen of the Swans who has fallen under a sorcerer's spell.

title: Limited War, Maximum Advantage
description: The U.S., the recent victor in the 45-year-long cold war, has just become involved in a regional war. The outcome of that war might well determine whether the U.S. will enjoy the fruits of its global victory. Indeed, the outcome may decide whether the U.S. will be able to shape "the new world order," of which President Bush has spoken so often.

title: Radar Screen Was Broken At Time of Plane Collision
description: The ground radar that allows air traffic controllers at Los Angeles International Airport to watch the position of aircraft on runways was broken when a collision killed 33 people on Friday, a Federal investigator said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Overview; U.S. BOMBERS HIT IRAQIS' AIR BASES AND SUPPLY LINES
description: Continuing their heavy bombardment of Iraqi military positions, allied warplanes today concentrated on supply lines and the reinforced concrete bunkers hiding many Iraqi aircraft, American officers said.

title: Miss Friedman Weds Robert Wander
description: Jessica Ruth Friedman, a lawyer, and Robert Mark Wander, a banker, were married yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York by Rabbis David Silverman and Morton M. Leifman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Friedman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The bridegroom is a son of Arlene Wander of New York and Philip Wander of New York and Remsenburg, L.I.

title: 2-State, 100-Officer Chase Follows 'Minor' Violation
description: Hector Castaneda knows a good driver when he sees one. Or at least when he is caught by one after a two-state, 12-mile, 90-mile-an-hour chase in which, the police say, he roared through barricades and red lights and raced the wrong way down one-way streets while shooting wildly at pursuing officers.

title: Record High Temperatures Bring High Spirits and Fears
description: Scientists have theorized that the greenhouse effect will warm the earth's climate most dramatically in the latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere above the tropics. Yesterday, some non-scientists in those latitudes theorized that this would not be an entirely bad thing.

title: Dinkins Stresses Solidarity on Israel Visit
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins arrived here today from New York City for a lightning visit to show solidarity with Israel.

title: A Chess Lesson for Ruthless Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sudden Revival for East Asian Oil
description: In the months before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, East Asia was beginning to despair of its role as a producer and refiner of oil and feared that its huge dependence on the Middle East for crude oil would only rise as this region's continuing economic boom sent fuel consumption soaring.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Covering the War; Press and the Military: Old Suspicions
description: The first fissures of a new credibility gap have opened before the Persian Gulf war is a month old.

title: Filling Deep Gaps for Neediest
description: Eight-year-old Guy Jones had been silent for weeks, doing nothing besides sitting around the apartment and watching television.

title: More Old Universities
description: To the Editor:

title: Rio Journal; City of 'Zillion Vanities' Is Set to Flaunt a Few
description: In a hall as cavernous as an airplane hangar, Portela's legions prepared for battle. Seamstresses glued huge plastic cucumber slices onto cardboard shields. Carpenters worked on a tank-sized parade float, readying a battery of four-foot-high red lipsticks.

title: Heavy Schedule of Auctions
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, and the quarterly refunding that begins on Tuesday with an auction of 3-year notes, followed on Wednesday by a 10-year note auction and on Thursday by an auction of 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Metro Matters; Beyond Theories To What Works For the Homeless
description: A century ago, Jacob Riis explored "How the Other Half Lives" in urban tenements and concluded: People in nice houses don't throw stones.

title: Huge Morocco March Supports Iraq in War
description: At least 300,000 people demonstrated in the streets of the Moroccan capital today in an orderly show of support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Washington Talk; A Hard Swim Upstream For Political Lobbyists
description: The toughest chore of political salesman ship anyone is attempting in Washington these days is the argument that political action committees are getting blame they don't deserve.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 3: MONDAY Gen Mtrs Corp Source Cap Inc Xerox Corp TUESDAY Airborne Fght Corp Gen Housewares Corp IE Inds Inc Kansas City Pwr & Lt Co Learonal Inc Liberty Corp S C Monarch Mach Tool Co Sotheby's Hldgs Inc WEDNESDAY Bemis Inc Carlisle Cos Inc Corning Inc Hanna M A Co Ingersoll Rand Co Nrthwstrn Pub Svc Co Peoples Energy Corp Pilgrims Pride Corp Prec Castparts Corp Thomas & Betts Corp Utilicorp Utd Inc Wynns Intl Inc THURSDAY Apache Corp Chemed Corp Delta Wdsde Inds Inc New Guardsman Prods Inc Marriott Corp Maytag Corp Oryx Energy Co Pac Amer Income Shs Inc FRIDAY Alco Std Corp Boise Cascade Corp Deluxe Corp Dover Corp Union Elec Co SATURDAY Raymond James Finl Inc Vulcan Matls Co

title: New Campaigns
description: * A new spot introduced this month by Radisson Hotels International tries to link the chain's competitors with the image of a jail. The spot, entitled "Alcatraz," is one of several television and print ads that will convey the theme line, "Why get a room when you can get a Radisson?" The multimillion-dollar campaign was prepared by CHC Advertising, Newark. Radisson is a subsidiary of the Carlson Companies. * Beginning Feb. 7, television viewers will see the actors David Haselhoff, Alan Thicke and Don Diamont cavorting in various stages of undress for a series of commercials promoting Fruit of the Loom underwear. As a saxophone blares, the actors answer the tagline, "Whose underwear is under there?" with the response, "Fruit of the Loom, 'cause it fits." The campaign was prepared by Grey Advertising, New York.

title: Paperbacks Seem to Be Making a Comeback
description: In the economically lean 1990's, people have been returning to sensible things like home-cooked dinners and family cars. Now, publishers are beginning to detect a swing back to another sensible product, the paperback book.

title: Fiscal Reality: Bumpy Streets, Library Cuts and Tuition Rise
description: The sleek stone facade of the central branch of the Brooklyn Public Library is to be draped in black today, in mourning as much as protest, over a New York City fiscal crunch that is only now beginning to impinge on the lives of New Yorkers.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'Fancy Free' Ages Graciously Into the 90's
description: It was 46 years ago that two youngsters by the names of Jerome Robbins and Leonard Bernstein got together and produced a ballet called "Fancy Free." The ballet received 44 curtain calls at its first performance, danced by the recently founded Ballet Theater (now American Ballet Theater). It was an easygoing portrait of wartime America, with three sailors on leave who soon after became the heroes of the Broadway musical "On the Town." Mr. Robbins and Mr. Bernstein had taken on a home-grown subject and turned it into art that has remained fresh nearly five decades later, as a performance by the New York City Ballet proved on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Rockwell Fine Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court upheld a $5.5 million fine against the Rockwell International Corporation last week, saying its admission that it double-billed the Air Force on a satellite contract came too late.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Luge Runs Aren't Just for Olympians
description: SNOW shovels in hand and knee pads firmly affixed, track workers grasp side railings and methodically move outside a luge course.

title: Review/Television; The Coney Island of New York's Age of Innocence
description: Tonight's edition of "The American Experience" is a loving evocation of Coney Island in its grandest, giddiest years between the 1870's and World War I. The producer and director Ric Burns uses to good effect some of the techniques he helped apply to "The Civil War": remarkable old photographs brought to life by the television camera and played off against quotations from the likes of Maxim Gorky and Henry Miller, read by voices you may recognize. (George Plimpton is back.)

title: 'What Does It Mean To Seal a Room?'
description: These past few weeks have been a bit like the end of a pregnancy: You know something is going to happen soon; you just don't know when. After we've sealed our rooms, we fill the time with house cleaning, laundry, cooking.

title: Bonnie Messing Weds Frank Sui
description: Bonnie Lynn Messing, a daughter of Norma J. Messing of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Robert H. Messing, was married yesterday to Frank Sui, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chin-Tang Sui of Bridgewater, N.J. Judge John J. Grossi Jr. of New Jersey Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Armory, a restaurant in Perth Amboy, N.J.

title: Question Box
description: Solid Baseball Marks

title: Transit Police Enforce Subway Rules While Helping Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A8-A10

title: Janet DePalma Marries Marc Britton in New Jersey
description: Janet DePalma, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George DePalma of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Marc Britton, a son of Dorothy Britton of Syosset, L.I., and the late William Britton. The ceremony was performed by Mayor Richard Schooler of Demarest, N.J. at the Alpine (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Reviews/Dance; Getting Around, Sometimes Upside Down
description: Whatever else dancers must do onstage, they must somehow go from place to place. No wonder choreographers like works about journeys.

title: War Summary
description: AIR RAIDS AND ANOTHER LOSS As attacks on the lifelines of 545,000 front-line Iraqi troop went on unabated, an American B-52 bomber plunged into the Indian Ocean while returning to base on Diego Garcia. Three crewmen were rescued, and the search continued for three others missing in the crash, possibly caused by mechanical failure. MOVING THE BEANS AND THE BULLETS As the number of allied troops passed 500,000 with the arrival of reinforcements from Germany, desert highways took on the look of an American expressway at rush-hour; bumper-to-bumper. The largest quick-order military deployment in history in in its last stages. CREDIBILITY GAP REVISITED The atmosphere at military briefings has turned noticeably testy as correspondents disparage the information as short on facts and at times misleading. Some veterans complain that their briefers seem even less informative than those of "five o'clock follies" memory in Saigon. WAR LOSSES ALLIES FORCES Troops: Two airmen were killed in a crash in Kuwait and three were missing in the crash of the B-52. This would bring the daily tally of American losses to 14 killed in action, 26 airmen missing in action and 8 confirmed as prisoners of war. The U.S. Central Command in Riyadh did not provide an overall count. A Saudi spokesman said 18 Saudi soldiers were killed in the fighting at Khafji last week, 29 were wounded and 4 were missing. A Qatari spokesman said he had no casualties to report. Aircraft: In addition to the B-52 bomber lost on its way back to base, an AH-1 Cobra with two aboard and a UH-1 helicopter carrying four crashed over Saudi Arabia. But the U.S. Central Command's briefer in Riyadh did not add them to the daily cumulative count of aircraft losses because, he said, they were believed to be "non-combat-related." The command said combat losses as such stood at 15 American and 7 other coalition aircraft, for a total of 22. IRAQI FORCES Troops: The number of Iraqi prisoners grew to "some 800," according to the United States command. No reliable data on other or military or civilian losses were available. Aircraft: The Riyadh command's count of aircraft destroyed while parked or bunkered rose sharply to at least 99 and as many as 140, since some bunkers sheltered more than one. The number of aircraft shot down stood at 27, and 89 aircraft and crews remained sequestered in Iran.

title: Johnson Helps Suns End Pistons' Streak
description: Kevin Johnson scored 28 points today as the Phoenix Suns defeated Detroit, 112-97, snapping the Pistons' winning streak at five games.

title: Correction
description: A brief report with the Business People column on Wednesday about the appointment of a chairman and chief executive at Apple Bancorp Inc. referred incorrectly to the company's takeover last October. Apple was taken over by Stanley Stahl, a New York real estate developer, through a cash tender offer, not in a leveraged buyout.

title: Steel Company Agrees to Pact With Workers
description: After two days of extended bargaining, the USX Corporation and the steelworkers' union announced a tentative three-year contract today, averting a strike by 20,000 workers in the Great Lakes region and Alabama.

title: Project Tenants See Island Of Safety Washing Away
description: Herman Everett bounded down the stairs, his grandmother's voice filling the graffiti-smeared hallway behind him. "Be safe," she called. "Be safe."

title: Market Place; Chairman's Role In Rexene Feuds
description: WILLIAM J. GILLIAM, a brash young deal maker in the 1980's, split from his three partners in a messy Wall Street-style divorce in 1988. At the time, Mr. Gilliam argued that he had been the brains behind the partners' best-known deal -- a buyout and, later, a public stock offering of the Rexene Corporation, a petrochemical company based in Dallas. Sure enough, he wound up in effective control of the company when two of his former partners, who had been on the Rexene board, resigned in early 1990.

title: Coca-Cola's Earnings Drop 61.1%
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said yesterday that because of large one-time gains a year earlier, its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 61.1 percent. But operating earnings rose 27.1 percent.

title: Citicorp Makes a Deal To Sell Data Businesses
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it had agreed to sell several businesses that provide data processing services to banks and other financial institutions. The buyer is Fiserve Inc., a small but growing Milwaukee company.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the wake of protests by actors, a canceled show and the capitulation by Actors' Equity, JONATHAN PRYCE , the star of "Miss Saigon," has finally arrived in New York, where rehearsals began last week.

title: Chess
description: The narrow victory by the Hungarian team over the Soviet Union's in the Women's Olympiad in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia, hinged on matches with the Czechoslovakians. And at the center of the action was one player, the 14-year-old Hungarian superstar, Judit Polgar.

title: General Motors Cuts Dividend
description: Citing the war and a weak economy, the nation's largest car maker slashed its dividend nearly in half and announced it was reducing its salaried work force and its capital spending plans. Page D1.

title: Review/Television; A Play by Arthur Miller And a Talk With Him
description: With sponsorship extended for at least a second season, "General Motors Playwrights Theater" is returning at 9 tonight to the Arts & Entertainment Network. The four-part series of one-act plays, produced by Nederlander Television and Film Productions, begins with "Clara," written by Arthur Miller. Coming up in the next few months will be works by Israel Horowitz, Robert Anderson and Jonathan C. Levine.

title: Jumbo Was a Humbug
description: Here's a big development in soap, and big developments in soap must be important for America because if somebody asked, "What does America mean to you?" you wouldn't list very many other items ahead of soap, would you?

title: Reviews/Music; Early and Late Mozart
description: Zubin Mehta is back from Israel, where he had flown spontaneously when war broke out, and he and the New York Philharmonic have leaped into Lincoln Center's Mozart maelstrom feet first. The orchestra's subscription program last week at Avery Fisher Hall, heard Friday afternoon, consisted of Mozart's first and last symphonies and the cantata "Davidde Penitente" (K. 469).

title: Argentina's Markets Back Economic Plan
description: The Government of Carlos Saul Menem announced a plan late Sunday night aimed at reducing Argentina's huge internal deficit, and today the financial markets gave the plan a vote of confidence, as interest rates plunged and the local currency rose against the dollar.

title: P.L.O. Pledges to Stop Rocket Raids on Israel
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it would stop rocket attacks against Israel from southern Lebanon and would use other means to assist Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.

title: LeMond Honored
description: The cyclist Greg LeMond, who won his third Tour de France last year, was selected yesterday as winner of the 1991 Jesse Owens International Trophy Award.

title: Review/Dance; An Evening of Good Will
description: Students from six prominent New York City dance schools gathered on Saturday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The occasion was a concert to benefit the Emergency Fund for Student Dancers, which is intended to help dance students in crises. In recognition of the occasion's importance, Marymount made the theater available to the fund without charge. It was an evening of good will and good cheer.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; Cheney Cautious on Declaring Early War Success
description: As progress continued to defy measurement in the air war against dug-in Iraqi forces, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cautioned today against pronouncing early military successes because "there is a great deal of uncertainty" ahead.

title: Man Seized in New Jersey Killing of Parents
description: A Jamaican constable who recognized a picture of a man accused of killing his parents last week in their Bernards Township home, arrested the man today in Jamaica, the Somerset County Prosecutor, Nicholas Bissell, said.

title: Board Says Rose Is Ineligible for Hall of Fame
description: As long as Pete Rose is ineligible to work in baseball, he will be ineligible for the Hall of Fame, the Hall's board of directors ruled unanimously yesterday.

title: Business and Health; Companies Add Long-Term Care
description: A GROWING number of large companies are helping employees buy their own insurance coverage for long-term care. One impetus is that because of Federal budget concerns, taxpayer subsidies are unlikely. Insurers say that after a slow start, sales to large employer groups are beginning to take off.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Mallon Scores First Pro Victory Meg Mallon won the rain-delayed $400,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Classic in Lake Worth, Fla., yesterday for her first pro-career victory. Mallon carded a 71 for a two-stroke victory over a rookie, Dana Lofland. Mallon finished at 12-under 276. (AP) TENNIS Krickstein and Hlasek Advance Sixth-seeded Aaron Krickstein of the United States made short work of Amos Mansdorf of Israel, and fifth-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland defeated the American Todd Witsken in straight sets yesterday as the Milan indoor Association of Tennis Professionals tournament began. Krickstein beat Mansdorf, 6-0, 6-1, in 49 minutes. Hlasek beat Witsken, 7-6, 6-2. (AP) N.B.A. Pierce Leads Bucks to Victory Ricky Pierce scored 20 points in the second half and Jeff Grayer had 11 in the fourth quarter as the Milwaukee Bucks beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 103-96, last night in Richfield, Ohio, for their first road victory in more than a month. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Pittsburgh Defeats Seton Hall Brian Shorter scored 22 points and made three free throws in the final 34 seconds to seal No. 24 Pittsburgh's first victory in four games, an 86-80 decision over Seton Hall last night in Pittsburgh. Jason Matthews, benched for the first time this season, made three 3-pointers and scored 11 points -- all in the second half -- for Pittsburgh (16-7, 5-4). Seton Hall is 13-7, 5-6. (AP) Southern Mississippi 98, Appalachian State 74: Russell Johnson scored 22 points to lead five Southern Mississippi players in double figures as the 12th-ranked Golden Eagles (15-2) rolled over Appalachian State (11-10) at Boone, N.C. (AP) COLLEGE HOCKEY Boston College Overcomes Goalie Tom Cole, the Northeastern goalie, stopped 51 shots by Boston College last night, but that was not enough as the Eagles rallied to defeat the Huskies, 5-3, in the opening game of the 39th annual Beanpot Tournament at Boston Garden. Northeastern (4-22-2) led by 2-0 and by 3-1 in the second period before Boston College, the East's top-ranked team, began to dominate. The Ea N.H.L. Kings Move Fast and Furious Luc Robitaille's tie-breaking goal with 4:05 remaining in regulation time spoiled the Red Wings' comeback and led the Los Angeles Kings to a 6-4 victory at Detroit last night. (AP)

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Minefields a Nightmare? Allies Sleep Better After Test
description: Frowning generals, stars marching across their Kevlar helmets, descended by helicopter on a dusty desert firing range to see if one of their newest weapons really works.

title: Man in the Window
