description: "How long?" I asked this man a few minutes after we met. He knew exactly what I meant.

title: Profits Spurt at Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Corporation reported sharply higher earnings today for the fourth quarter, showing a profit of $99 million, or $1.57 a share. In the corresponding period a year ago, Lockheed lost $109 million.

title: Dow Soars in Heavy Trading to Gain 41.59
description: Stocks rose strongly yesterday in hectic trading, with the Dow Jones industrials and other leading averages scoring new highs for the year. One of the nation's most influential Wall Street investment houses said the six-month bear market had ended.

title: Cuomo and Florio Paths Converging on Budgets
description: A year ago, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York seemed to be the two faces of Democratic politics.

title: Staff and Services Cut Back At U.S. Embassy in Amman
description: The State Department today announced a reduction of staff at the American Embassy in Amman, Jordan, and the cutback of consular services offered there.

title: Review/Jazz; An Organist Who Reveres The Past
description: In the 1980's, jazz feasted on its own history. Young musicians, looking for direction, took up idols old enough to be parents, grandparents and great-grandparents. But none of the odd juxtapositions of age and class beat Barbara Dennerlein's. Miss Dennerlein, a 24-year-old German organist from Munich, plays deep in the organ tradition, funk included. Until someone tries to revive the crooning of Al Bowlly, the South African singer from the 30's, she has won the arcane influence sweepstakes.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iran; Iran's President Offers to Broker Gulf Settlement
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran today offered to serve as a mediator between the United States and Iraq to seek a peaceful end to the Persian Gulf war. Iraq had no immediate public reaction, and the overture was received coolly by the Bush Administration.

title: Fall of Rose
description: Sept. 11, 1985: Pete Rose, in his 23d season, gets 4,192d career hit, against Eric Show, to break Ty Cobb's 57-year-old major league record.

title: Charles G. Adsit, Doctor, 75
description: Charles G. Adsit, a doctor who practiced in Manhattan for more than four decades, died on Jan. 25 in South Orleans, Mass., where he lived in retirement. He was 75 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Plot Turns Continue Past End Of Thriller
description: Douglas Post's "Earth and Sky" is a case of film noir on stage. Hard-bitten but with a tinge of sentiment, the play (at Second Stage) follows the mysterious travails of a Chicago poet and librarian (Jennifer Van Dyck) whose lover has suddenly and inexplicably been murdered.

title: Eaton Unit Offers 10-Year, 10% Issue
description: Eaton Offshore Ltd., a unit of the Eaton Corporation, priced $100 million in 10-year notes yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Casper R. Callen, Executive, 95
description: Casper R. Callen, a Manhattan real-estate executive for more than half a century, died on Sunday in Winter Haven, Fla. He was 95 years old and lived in Winter Haven.

title: Sitka Journal; Life, Liberty, and Maybe Marijuana
description: As everything from license plates to burger billboards boast, this is the Last Frontier. And with that slogan go some eccentricities: free moose meat from the railroad, no state taxes, homesteading -- and the right to smoke marijuana in the privacy of your home.

title: A Proposal To Limit F.D.I.C.
description: In an apparent slap at the nation's senior banking regulator, L. William Seidman, the Bush Administration will recommend that his agency lose its authority to supervise banks, senior Government officials said today.

title: Review/Ice Skating; Sliding Around With Mickey and Friends
description: Mickey Mouse's diamond jubilee is the theme of the newest edition of "Walt Disney's World on Ice," the family extravaganza that brought 60 performers with 3.5 million sequins between them to Radio City Music Hall on Friday afternoon.

title: Suddenly, Italy's Communists Find Themselves Leaderless
description: A day after Italy's Communists dropped their old party name and symbol, they today inexplicably upended the leader who had made their changes possible.

title: Inventors' Hopes on Display, From Mousetraps to Engines
description: As a 200th-birthday tribute to its founder, the inventor Peter Cooper, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art is documenting the proverbial quest for a better mousetrap.

title: Sylvia Weiner Leiferman, Philanthropist, 77
description: Sylvia Weiner Leiferman, an artist, philanthropist and president of the Leiferman Investment Company, died on Thursday at the Heartland of Miami Lakes, a nursing home in North Miami, Fla. She was 77 years old and lived in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Employers Favor Student 'Warranty'
description: To the Editor:

title: For CBS, A Coup In Ratings
description: The first Sunday showdown of what is expected to be the most intensely competitive month in recent television history produced a lopsided victory for CBS , thanks largely to Glenn Close.

title: Judge Drops Charges Of Delivering Drugs To an Unborn Baby
description: A judge dismissed a drug charge today against a woman accused of passing cocaine to her newborn baby by using the drug while pregnant, saying lawmakers did not intend the law to be applied that way.

title: Rossini's 'Petite Messe'
description: Rossini's "Petite Messe Solennelle," the composer's final work, will be performed by the Collegiate Chorale on Thursday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The original instrumentation for two pianos and a harmonium will be used, but the chorus will be augmented to 150 singers from the 12 originally called for. Guest soloists will be the soprano Leona Mitchell, the mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar, the tenor Vinson Cole, and Jeffrey Wells, a baritone; Robert Bass will conduct. Tickets are $11 to $45. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: News Analysis Tactics and Numbers; A Budget Intended to Counter an Image Of a White House That Courts the Rich
description: In the budget they sent to Congress today, President Bush and his advisers tried to neutralize the strongest political point the Democrats have developed in the Bush Presidency: the argument that this Administration favors the rich at the expense of the poor and the middle class.

title: Anheuser-Busch Profits Up
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest beer brewer, said yesterday that profits in the fourth quarter of 1990 rose 10.6 percent, to $141.7 million, or 50 cents a share, from $128.1 milion, or 45 cents a share, in the quarter in 1989. Sales rose to $2.9 billion from $2.5 billion.

title: William T. Cowin, 89, Ex-Judge in New York
description: William T. Cowin, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Friday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 89 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: PATTERNS
description: The Beauty Business

title: War Summary
description: "BIG MO" GOES TO WAR, AGAIN For the first time since the Korean War, the battleship Missouri fired its 16-inch guns in combat. Shells weighing a ton each hurtled toward what American commanders described as Iraqi command bunkers near the Kuwaiti coast. The command also reported thatsince the war started aerial bombing sorties averaged one a minute. A report from Baghdad said the capital and environs suffered five hours of predawn raids yesterday. Among other targets were tank formations and the lifelines of Iraqi frontline forces. THE VIEW FROM THE TOP Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of the American forces, said Saddam Hussein's will to keep fighting is not likely to be broken since he takes a "very rudimentary tactical approach to warfare." The Iraqi military is another story, in his view. It probably is beginning to crack, the general said, and is not "holding up very well." In Washington, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cautioned that uncertainties still abounded and that no quick victory was in sight. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The U.S. Central Command gave no new figures at yesterday's briefing and said the reported deaths of four marines in the a helicopter crash in Saudi Arabia remained unconfirmed. One of three airmen listed as missing after the crash of a B-52 over the weekend was found dead. This brought the number of American losses recorded to date to 15 killed in action, 25 airmen missing and 8 more confirmed as prisoners. Aircraft: A Marine Huey UH-1N helicopter with four men aboard crashed in Saudi Arabia in the 24 hours preceding today's briefing, the second helicopter loss in 24 hours. Termed "non-battle damage," the crash did not add to the previous count of 22 aircraft shot down, 15 of them American. Iraq claimed its forces downed nine more aircraft. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq issued no report, and aside from some anecdotal evidence, no meaningful figures on military or civilian casualties were otherwise available. Aircraft: The American command added 10 more to its count of Iraqi aircraft impounded in Iran, bringing the total to 99.

title: Chairman Is Replaced At Hollywood Park
description: The fight to control the company that owns the Hollywood Park race track ended on Sunday with an agreement that removes the company's chairman and replaces her with R. D. Hubbard, a dissident shareholder.

title: Robert Phillips, 57, Part of Piano Duo
description: Robert Phillips, a pianist and composer, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Fashion; Split Personalities In Evening Skirts
description: Mention the hemline wars of the early 1970's, when midi replaced mini as the vogue length, and anyone who was paying attention at the time will get the shakes. The drop in hemlines led to demonstrations, boycotts and the disappearance of long-lived fashion companies from the business.

title: Yankees Draft New Ad Team
description: The New York Yankees ball club is expecting some serious pitching from the newest talent on its roster: Le Donne, Wilner & Weiner Advertising.

title: By Design; Brooches Big or Clustered
description: It's not that brooches are new. This winter though, pins have become a punctuation point.

title: 'New World Order,' Old Self-Interest; Postwar Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking on Form 1040 With 2 Mac Programs
description: TAX software for personal computers continues to get better. Many of the new 1990 tax-year programs, which are just now appearing in final form, have added streamlined controls and features that help the taxpayer understand the tax code and fill out the appropriate forms as painlessly as possible.

title: Moceli Eyes Mile Record
description: Noureddine Morceli's winning time of 3 minutes 53.50 seconds in the Wanamaker Mile of the Millrose Games last Friday has given rise to the notion he might break the world indoor record this Friday night in the Meadowlands/Vitalis Invitational.

title: British Dancer Wins Swiss Competition
description: The 19th annual Prix de Lausanne Ballet competition, whose past winners have gone on to major companies after being awarded scholarships at prestigious ballet academies, presented its gold medal this year to Christopher Wheeldon, a 17-year-old contestant from Britain.

title: Europeans Move to Lift Pretoria Curbs
description: European Community nations promised today to lift remaining economic sanctions against South Africa as soon as the Pretoria Government formally asks Parliament to repeal laws that have long sustained apartheid.

title: The Turkish Press Is Anything but Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Aid Society Confronts Its Own Eviction
description: The Legal Aid Society, which is expert in irritating landlords on behalf of tenants, has irritated its own landlord and is now in the spot usually reserved for its clients: Legal Aid is the target of an eviction suit.

title: Trial of Winnie Mandela Is Opened
description: The trial of Winnie Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, got under way today, opening a potentially lengthy criminal process fraught with political consequences for the projected discussions on constitutional change between Mr. Mandela and the white minority Government.

title: Rostock Journal; Left Out in Cold, German Port Fights to Survive
description: It is only 350 miles across the choppy waters of the Baltic Sea to Klaipeda, in Lithuania, and for the big rail ferries that link the cities the trip is an overnight run. So it did not sit well with some people here when they found out the other day that the latest ships to leave were hauling tanks, armored vehicles, trucks and other equipment belonging to the 350,000 Soviet troops still huddled in what was East Germany.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Jan. 23, about a technique for lowering the fat content of meat, miscalculated the percentage of calories from fat in ground beef from which fat had been removed. The technique produces ground beef with 37 percent of its calories from fat, comparable to a skinless chicken leg.

title: Key Rates
7 Are Killed in Wisconsin Plane Collision
description: Two small airplanes apparently "just crumpled together and fell" here on Sunday, killing seven people, including five members of a sky diving club who were in one plane. The five were in a Cessna 182 and the two other victims were in a Piper aircraft, officials said.

title: Arthur Leidesdorf, 72, Accounting Executive
description: Arthur D. Leidesdorf, a former managing partner in the accounting firm of S. D. Leidesdorf & Company, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: N.F.L. Has 29 Players Listed for Early Draft
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, Notre Dame's game-breaking running back and wide receiver, led the list of underclassmen approved yesterday by the National Football League for its annual college draft.

title: After Review, Hardee's Stays With Ogilvy
description: OGILVY & MATHER has managed to hang onto the $80 million Hardee's account, winning a creative shootout yesterday against J. Walter Thompson, Chiat/Day/ Mojo and Ayer.

title: Nancy Kulp, 69, Dies; Film and TV Actress
description: Nancy Kulp, an actress best known for her role as the secretary Jane Hathaway on the television series "The Beverly Hillbillies," died of cancer on Sunday at a friend's home. She was 69 years old.

title: Collision Warning System Is Being Updated
description: An advanced airport radar system intended to avert accidents like the runway collision in Los Angeles on Friday is being developed for the Federal Aviation Administration and could be ready for operation within three years.

title: Business Groups Fight Laws In California on Wage Scales
description: Several communities in the San Francisco Bay area have enacted what labor lawyers say are the nation's first local laws that specify the wages to be paid to employees of private businesses.

title: For Joe D, 1941 Glows Golden Now
description: Only a few baseball players are identified forever with a year: Babe Ruth with 1927, Bobby Thomson with 1951, Roger Maris with 1961. Even fewer endure long enough to celebrate the golden anniversary of their year. But for Joe DiMaggio now, it's as if it were 1941 when he batted safely in 56 consecutive games -- a record that has never really been approached, a record that probably will never be broken.

title: Setback for Cranes
description: The last wild flock of whooping cranes, which has rebounded from the brink of extinction, has suffered a setback with the mysterious disappearance of six cranes from their wintering grounds.

title: Dynamics of Bats' Sonar Are Revealed in Study
description: SCIENTISTS are closer to deciphering the sophisticated sonar system of bats. These winged mammals emit ultrasonic pulses and use the returning echoes to navigate and to locate prey by determining the distance and velocity of a target.

title: Lineman Preparing Big Leap to N.F.L.
description: Eric Swann has never played a down of college football. But the 20-year-old defensive lineman has successfully petitioned the National Football League to be eligible for its draft under a special exemption, and there are scouts who believe that he could be a first- or second-round selection in April.

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: Government Risk; To Insure S.& L. and Bank Deposits, $88 Billion
description: A leading element in the $281 billion deficit that the Bush Administration projected today in the budget for the 1992 fiscal year is the $88 billion that planners say may be needed for the insurance that protects depositors in banks and savings and loan associations.

title: Fuhr Reinstated by N.H.L.
description: The Edmonton goaltender Grant Fuhr, suspended for one year by the National Hockey League last September for drug use, was reinstated today by the league president, John Ziegler.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Spirited Hildegarde Who Never Grows Tired
description: "Wrinkle, wrinkle, you'd be a tonic, if you'd go visit Harry Connick," joked Hildegarde, the indomitably buoyant nightclub legend, who opened a once-a-week cabaret series upstairs at the Russian Tea Room on Sunday evening, two days after she turned 85. She held up a mirror that revealed a happy, smiling face with few wrinkles.

title: Q&A
description: Survival of the Fattest?

title: Chip Estimate Cut By NEC Officials
description: The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's top makers of computers and semiconductors, lowered its estimate for production of its most sophisticated computer chips because of weak demand. NEC officials said the company had expected production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips to reach about four million a month by this summer. But they said output was now expected to hover around three million a month.

title: Filly-Colt Showdown Likely in Triple Crown
description: Is another legendary battle of the sexes taking shape in racing's Triple Crown classics?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. Battleship Shells Iraqis In Bunkers on Kuwait Coast
description: The United States stepped up its naval assault on Iraqi targets today by unleashing the fury of the 16-inch guns aboard an American battleship for the first time in the Persian Gulf war, while the outskirts of Baghdad were pounded this morning by allied aircraft.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A11-A14

title: Reviews/Music; Pianist's Diverse Recital
description: Anton Nel, who played a wildly varied sequence of piano pieces at the Frick Collection on Thursday afternoon, is South African in origin but was largely educated in this country. He teaches at the Eastman School and has done the requisite tour of competitions, winning four years ago what is perhaps in its quiet way the most prestigious of them all, the Naumburg.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: G.M. Cuts Dividend Almost 50%
description: The General Motors Corporation, citing war and a weak economy, slashed its dividend nearly in half today and announced cost-cutting measures, including reductions in its salaried work force and its capital spending plans.

title: U.S., Allies Join in Buying The Dollar
description: The Federal Reserve and the central banks of the United States' major economic allies bought dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an apparent effort to support the weakening currency and to signal that economic cooperation among the allies was still in force.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Sentenced For Giving Secrets to Soviets
description: The only man convicted of espionage while serving as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was sentenced today to 20 years in Federal prison.

title: Global Thermostat
description: Scientists say they have confirmed one step in a chain of events by which microscopic ocean plants may influence the earth's temperature.

title: Reviews/Dance; In Masked Art of Indonesia, A Portrait Gallery in Motion
description: Two dancers and a clown created a theatrical portrait gallery in "Topeng Cirebon: Masked Dance of West Java" on Sunday night at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University. The event was an attraction of Festival of Indonesia, a series of performances to acquaint American audiences with Indonesian culture.

title: Some Use Creative Formulas In Donating to the Neediest
description: This is how Alfred Jaffe of Somers, N.Y., decided that his gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund would be for $ 102: he took the number of years he and his wife have been married (51) and then multiplied it by the cost of their marriage license ($2).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If anyone thinks this is an enjoyable experience, they're dead wrong, dead wrong. I've known a lot of generals who were war lovers. They scare the living hell out of me, and they're also not very good generals, not by my measure. Custer loved war, and look at what he accomplished." -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. [ A13:3. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Chang a Winner
description: Michael Chang cruised to a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Marcelo Filippini of Italy today to advance in the $1 million Newsweek Champions Cup.

title: 8 1/2% Notes Priced By Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company priced a $100 million issue of two-year notes through its own underwriting operations yesterday.

title: The 1990 Census, State by State
description: Through April 1, the Census Bureau is gradually reporting state population figures by race and Hispanic origin, as people described themselves. People of Hispanic origin can be of any race.

title: Careers; Monitoring The Trauma Of Job Loss
description: AS chairman of Drake Beam Morin Inc., a large outplacement firm, William J. Morin worries about the level of emotional depression among managers who have lost jobs, especially those out more than a year.

title: Gorbachev Is Promoting Hard-Line Police Chief
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, maintaining his emphasis on tightening the Kremlin's control over the nation, rewarded the new hard-line Soviet police chief today with a promotion and authorized further investigative powers in the name of fighting corruption and crime.

title: Review/Blues; The Women: Bad. The Man: Weak.
description: During the blues boom of the 1960's, too many albums brought seasoned performers together with enthusiastic but incompatible younger musicians. Record producers have become smarter since then, but touring blues musicians still have to contend with the vagaries of local backup bands.

title: Budget Deceit, Punctured; And This Deficit Is No Demon
description: The Federal deficit for fiscal 1991 will exceed $300 billion, and next year's won't be much lower. These are chilling facts, enough to make critics belittle last year's budget accord and fear for the health of the economy.

title: Neilson Sees Danger in Injury Reports
description: Two weeks ago, before the Rangers played the Edmonton Oilers, the New York newspapers reported in detail that Brian Leetch had a sore right ankle, but would play anyway. The story was picked up by the Edmonton papers and Leetch took what Ranger officials thought was more than accidental punishment from the Oilers.

title: U.S. Accepts Greenhouse Target
description: The Bush Administration today opened an international conference on global warming with the declaration that the United States will stabilize its overall production of the gases that have been linked to rising world temperatures.

title: Spanish Town Is Largely Unmoved by B-52's
description: The dark, bristling tails of 15 giant B-52's look strangely out of place against a backdrop of olive groves, green wheat fields and scattered cows. And except when the long-range bombers roar down the runway, the entire area is wrapped in silence.

title: Making It Safe for Endangered Animals to Go Home Again
description: ZOOS have been remarkably successful in breeding many animals that are at or near extinction in their natural habitats. But the success has raised a curious new problem -- that of teaching the surplus zoo-born animals how to live and survive in the wild.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the U.S.A.-U.S.S.R. Screenwriters Festival opened in New York last night, the 10-member Soviet delegation had been reduced to 9. During the West Coast segment of the festival in Los Angeles, IRAKLY KVIRIKADZE underwent emergency quadruple-bypass surgery.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business pages yesterday misidentified the job taken by Gary Billings at Lintas Worldwide. He becomes director of human resources, not public relations.

title: As Antimissile Era Dawns, Planners Eye Panoply of Weapons
description: THE antimissile era has dawned in thunder and flame as wave after wave of Patriots has knocked Iraqi Scuds out of the sky. But the Patriot is just the beginning. A new generation of ground-based missile interceptors -- all of greater range, power and precision than the Patriot -- is fast being perfected.

title: Our Towns; How a Parkway Became a Ribbon Of Living Beauty
description: Imagine a time when Americans went for Sunday spins in the country with no destination in mind or golden arches in sight.

title: AMERICAN REVIVAL IN MANUFACTURING SEEN IN U.S. REPORT
description: In the last recession, America's aging industrial heartland was widely considered to be incapable of saving itself. But a Government report issued yesterday suggests that the Rust Belt has staged a renaissance on the factory floor.

title: China Posts Criminal Trials For 2 Tiananmen Dissidents
description: A court notice posted today says that China will try two more Tiananmen democracy advocates on charges of "organizing and leading a counterrevolutionary clique."

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: Proposals; Winners and Losers: How Bush's Plan Would Affect Domestic Spending
description: Here are President Bush's budget proposals for major domestic programs in the 1992 fiscal year: Health

title: In a Warming World, Who Comes Out Ahead?
description: IN a finding fraught with sensitive political implications, some scientists say that if global warming takes its expected course, some parts of the world could come out winners, even while many others reap disaster.

title: 'Africa Centered' School Plan Is Rooted in 60's Struggles
description: For all its currency, the conflict over the proposal to start a small "Africa centered" high school mainly for black boys in New York City has a past that is as old as the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school wars of the late 1960's and the move prompted by that upheaval toward community control of the schools.

title: Bush Applauds de Klerk
description: President Bush called President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa today to applaud his latest moves to dismantle apartheid, the White House said. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Mr. Bush commended Mr. de Klerk and "noted that these are historic measures."

title: ARIZONA EXPANDS POLITICAL INQUIRY
description: The police have seized checks at state Democratic Party headquarters, a Republican legislator's automobile and records on dozens of people as part of an investigation of possible political corruption.

title: 2 Bridges Over Tracks Are to Be Closed
description: Two small but heavily used bridges in Brooklyn and the Bronx are to be closed, and other neighborhoods could face similar disruption as dozens of other small bridges fall victim to deferred maintenance and shrinking budgets, Transportation Department engineers say.

title: State Makes Videotape Public in Right-to-Die Case
description: The Missouri Department of Health today presented its case against a father's effort to determine medical treatment for his severely brain-damaged daughter to two courts, the Missouri Court of Appeals and the court of public opinion.

title: Productivity Flat Over All In 4th Quarter
description: The productivity of America's non-farm workers was practically unchanged for the fourth quarter, growing at an annual rate of one-tenth of 1 percent, but for the year it fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, the worst decline since 1982, the Government said today. Coupled with the 1989 drop of seven-tenths of 1 percent, it was the first back-to-back reversal in a decade. These figures are not seasonally adjusted.

title: Review/Dance; Aloft On a Magic Oriental Carpet
description: Whether the world needs still another ballet by Eliot Feld to Steve Reich's music becomes irrelevant when Mr. Feld thinks he does: "Ion," a solo for Buffy Miller in his company, the Feld Ballets/NY, is his eighth piece of choreography to a Reich score.

title: Trip Wire Of Armageddon
description: The U.S. commander in the Persian Gulf has been authorized to use "nonlethal riot-control gases" against Iraqi forces in certain circumstances. This Pentagon authorization and an earlier decision to attempt to immunize our troops against biological weapons significantly increases the danger that weapons of mass destruction will be used.

title: Bond Rating For New York Holds Steady
description: In a sign of confidence in New York City's plans for confronting its fiscal problems, the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday removed its "credit watch" on the city's bonds and reaffirmed the city's A- bond rating, which had been in jeopardy since last fall.

title: A Champion Who's Fighting Obscurity
description: The road here is long and sometimes desolate, and a wrong turn can lead to nowhere. But eventually, the highway from San Diego bends toward a paved offramp, which leads suddenly to a lonely dirt path, which winds its way past a house and toward a broad yellow barn on a small hill.

title: Weekly Edition of Life Will Focus on the War
description: For the first time since 1972, Life magazine will appear on newstands in a weekly format.

title: Susan K. Ginsberg, 59, Social-Agency Lawyer
description: Susan Karelitz Ginsberg, a lawyer who devoted her career to working with social agencies dealing with the problems of women and children, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Elizabeth Silverstein, New Jersey Lawyer, 98
description: Elizabeth Blume Silverstein, one of the first women to practice law in New Jersey, died on Sunday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. She was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Adding School Districts Would Be Power Grab
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Barred From Sealing Most Records
description: Expanding the public's access to information about environmental and consumer hazards, New York State's judiciary adopted rules today that prohibit court records from being sealed in most cases.

title: Growth and Death of Hair Yield Clues to Cell's Cycles
description: IT grows where it is not welcome, forsakes the spots where it is desperately wanted, turns coarse when it should be lustrous, tufts up when it should curl under, lies limp, springs into gray and otherwise behaves with the imperious anarchy that only hair can muster.

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: High clouds will thicken across northern Saudi Arabia, southern Iraq and Kuwait. A few showers will develop near the Red Sea. The Mediterranean Coast will be clear with offshore winds. Winds form the north will strengthen over the Persian Gulf with gusty winds in Iraq. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 55, low 36; Riyadh, high 68, low 45; Dhahran, high 66, low 47.

title: Women's Club Hiring Is Ruled Discriminatory
description: A women-only health club's policy of not hiring men is discriminatory, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Giants' Taylor Is Arrested
description: The Giant linebacker Lawrence Taylor was arrested Sunday night for allegedly hitting a car with a metal pipe after a traffic accident, police officers here said.

title: Hills Department Stores Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: Hills Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest discount retailer, filed for protection from its creditors yesterday after failing to gain approval from banks and bondholders for a refinancing plan.

title: Bridge
description: It was not a surprise when Paul Chemla and Michel Perron of France, both former world champions, won the prestigious Sunday Times Pairs in London nine days ago. But it was a surprise that second place went to Boris Schapiro, 81 years old, who has been connected with the sponsors since the tournament was first held nearly three decades ago, and Irving Gordon. Other rankings were: 3d, Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; 4th, Tony Forrester and Andy Robson of England; 5th, Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., and Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Miscellany
description: * Partners & Shevack, New York, said it had resigned the creative assignment for Meineke Discount Mufflers because of an "inability to reach an acceptable compensation agreement." A Meineke spokesman declined to comment. * Oglivy & Mather Direct, a subsidiary of th Oglivy Group, has formed a new division, the Production Group, to meet all direct advertising production needs. The group, to be run by Norman T. Paley, senior vice president of production services at Oglivy & Mather Direct, will be based in New York.

title: Drought Forces Cutoff of Water To Vast Farmlands in California
description: The huge water project built a generation ago to protect the fast-growing state against drought cut off all water to farmers today as a result of the worst drought in California history.

title: RURAL UNION CHIEF IS SLAIN IN BRAZIL
description: Underlining the volatility of Brazil's Amazon frontier, a rural workers' union buried its slain president today, a day after an American human rights group issued a report calling for his protection.

title: Advertising Star Opens New Show
description: From the inception of mass marketing in the late 19th century, scholars and practitioners have debated whether advertising is an art or a science. Had the experts visited the headquarters of McCabe & Company last Thursday, in a space so bare that heating ducts doubled as desks, they would have learned that advertising is really a romance.

title: Norway Approval For Conoco Plan
description: The Norwegian Government announced it would approve development of an offshore oil and natural gas field operated by Conoco Inc. The development of the Heidrun field off western Norway will cost about $3.2 billion and be completed in the third quarter of 1995, according to a statement issued by the oil and energy ministry.

title: Morris Talks to Twins
description: Jack Morris, who has played his entire 13-year career with the Detroit Tigers, may be close to moving to the Minnesota Twins. Morris's agent, Richard Moss, has been talking with the Twins, and he said yesterday, "It is possible that the Twins will have an announcement to make in the morning."

title: Reported Slayings in Liberia Anger Nigerians
description: The reported killing of two Nigerian journalists by rebel forces in Liberia has provoked a fierce debate about Nigeria's role in that country's civil war and whether it should seek retribution against a rebel leader, Charles Taylor.

title: Teheran's Game Plan
description: The fact that about 90 Iraqi planes have flown to Iran and its President is offering to mediate between the U.S. and Iraq is not as mystifying as it appears. To sort out these events, it helps to recall America's attitude toward the Iran-Iraq war.

title: CHRONICLE
description: By starting a regional theater, the actor JEFF DANIELS intends to give Michigan playwrights and actors a voice. A spokesman for the company said yesterday that Mr. Daniels had invested more than $300,000 in the Purple Rose Theater Company, a nonprofit group in his hometown of Chelsea, 60 miles west of Detroit. The first production, "Blush at Nothing," is an original comedy by LISA A. WING of Ann Arbor; previews are to begin Thursday in the company's newly renovated theater.

title: For a Babel of Programs, Translation
description: YOU have a problem. Assigned to prepare a major report, you must gather information from the accounting department's spreadsheets, the sales department's databases and memos from branch offices, some of which were prepared with a word-processing program different from the one you use.

title: Magic Johnson Gets Clearance After Tests
description: An anxious wait is over for the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: But Are There Enough Jobs for the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: To Restore New York City - First, Reclaim the Streets; Collapsing the Mental Health Featherbed
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo's new budget is a gloomy exercise in shared pain for New Yorkers. But in one area, mental health, Mr. Cuomo would allocate the pain in a promising way. If successful, he might at last loosen the hold of forces that have long skewed the delivery of mental health services.

title: Editor of Journal Envisions New Directions and Lighter Tone
description: ON July 1, Dr. Jerome P. Kassirer, a 58-year-old expert in kidney disorders, will become editor of The New England Journal of Medicine and one of the world's most powerful doctors.

title: Trenton Postpones School Voting
description: Both houses of the Legislature voted today to postpone local and regional school board elections this spring for four weeks because New Jersey's 610 school districts have not been told how much state aid they can expect in the next fiscal year, beginning July 1.

title: Europe Has Its Share Of Airline Problems
description: Airlines in the United States are not the only ones reeling from the Persian Gulf war. Uncertainty and a fear of terrorism generated by the conflict have also severely depressed the business of European airlines, which like American carriers had already been hit hard when fuel prices soared last year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Egyptians Now Replace Other Arabs in Saudi Jobs
description: Egyptians have become the fastest-growing foreign population in the Saudi kingdom, with more than a million now living and working here. Many of them have replaced Yemenis, Jordanians and Palestinians who were in effect forced to leave after their political leaders criticized Saudi Arabia's role in the coalition opposing Iraq.

title: Withdrawing for Safety Allowed
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals Tour, monitor of the men's tennis circuit, has responded to the Persian Gulf war with some rule-bending. The tour, recognizing that certain players may have recently become wary about international travel, last week decided to make it permissible to withdraw from an event without incurring a penalty if a player believes his safety could be jeopardized by the traveling.

title: The Crumbling of Apartheid
description: South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, has proved even bolder than his word. As expected, his speech to Parliament last Friday called for the repeal of the Group Areas Act, the law imposing residential segregation. But he went much further than anybody expected by urging the revocation of the Population Registration Act of 1950.

title: Accounts
description: * Gund Inc., Edison, N.J., a toy manufacturer, to Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster, New York, with a budget of $3 million. * Thompson Medical Co., West Palm Beach Fla., to Beber Silverstein & Partners, Miami, for Arthritis Hot, an external analgesic. Billings were not disclosed.

title: 'New World Order,' Old Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounting Board Staff Cut
description: The Financial Accounting Foundation said yesterday that it would shut its two-member Washington office and dismiss four employees at its Norwalk, Conn., headquarters because of cost pressures.

title: Federated Posts Profit
description: The Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc., which have been operating under Federal bankruptcy protection for 13 months, said today that they had their second consecutive profitable month in December.

title: Execution Urged in Drug Case
description: For the first time in New York State, Federal prosecutors will seek the death penalty for a defendant if he is convicted under a drug law that Congress amended in 1988

title: Former Interim Chief To Head Kinder-Care
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., the child-care company that got into financial difficulties with investments in "junk bonds," said yesterday that its president and chief executive had resigned and that Tull Gearreald, an investment banker, was returning to head the company.

title: Lilly Research Pact
description: Eli Lilly & Company has signed a four-year research agreement with the Neurogenetic Corporation, a biotechnology company in Paramus, N.J. The agreement is intended to enhance Lilly's development of drugs for the central nervous system. Lilly also said it would join a group of investors in buying partial ownership of Neurogenetic in a financing deal scheduled for the first quarter of 1991.

title: EEI Pleads Guilty In Kickback Case
description: A Southern California military subcontractor and one of its executives today pleaded guilty to a felony charge of making a kickback payment to a Hughes Aircraft Company employee, the Government said.

title: INSIDE
description: A Plan to Limit F.D.I.C. Role In an apparent slap at L. William Seidman, the Treasury will propose that his agency lose its power to oversee banks, officials said. Page D1. Crash Uncovers Problems Unreliable equipment and a shortage of air traffic controllers at the Los Angeles airport have emerged in the crash investigation there. Page A20. Antimissile Era Dawns A new generation of missile interceptors is being perfected, with greater range and power than the celebrated Patriot. Science Times, page C1. Iran-Contra Bribe Reported A new book by a former Iran-contra prosecutor accuses the C.I.A. of bribery in its efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels. Page A16. Can Long Be Far Behind? Convinced that long skirts are inevitable, couturiers like Gianfranco Ferre are trying an interim step: short in front, long in back. Page B8.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Egypt; Egypt Appears More Likely To Join in Ground Combat
description: Indications are growing that the estimated 45,000 Egyptian troops and support staff members stationed in Saudi Arabia will go into action against Iraqi forces, should a ground offensive be mounted to recapture Kuwait.

title: Books of The Times; Looking to Grow Rich, And Be Happy, in Texas
description: Small Fortunes Two Guys in Pursuit Of the American Dream By Edward Zuckerman 296 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Shamir Tells West to Beware Of Pressing New Peace Plans
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned the Western world this evening that it had better take into account the lessons learned from the Persian Gulf war before pressing Israel to accept any new Middle East peace plans.

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: The Governors; BUSH ASKS STATES TO PRESS CONGRESS
description: President Bush told the nation's governors today that "we're going to have to fight together" to enact the Administration's budget proposal to give the states control of $15 billion worth of Federal programs, and warned that it could face serious Congressional opposition.

title: Holding On to Dreams Amid Harlem's Reality
description: A nasty two-inch scar snakes down Schwanna Youngblood's left cheek, the work of a teen-age girl wielding a razor blade in anger.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Logistics; Some 'Larceny in Your Heart' Helps in Getting War Supplies
description: Vast military supply dumps have been built in the northern Saudi desert, spawning a subculture of military operatives who barter, pilfer and cajole to get needed items for their units.

title: 2 Longtime Executives Are Promoted at Cargill
description: Cargill Inc., the huge world grain trading company based in Minneapolis, has named Heinz F. Hutter president and chief operating officer, the company's No. 2 post. Mr. Hutter began with the company in 1955 in Germany.

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: The Overview; PRESIDENT SUBMITS SPENDING PACKAGE TIED TO OPTIMISM
description: President Bush today sent Congress a 1992 budget request of $1.45 trillion that admittedly understates the cost of the Persian Gulf war, offers no measures to combat the recession and seeks to redistribute some Federal subsidies that now go to the most affluent.

title: Bombs Found at Huge Chemical Tanks
description: Pipe bombs were discovered today at the base of two storage tanks filled with several million gallons of highly combustible and toxic commercial chemicals, but demolition experts disarmed them before they could explode and possibly endanger nearby Navy shipyards.

title: V..A. Lowering Loan Rates
description: The Veterans Affairs Department said today that it was lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, effective Tuesday.

title: Thornburgh May Be Witness at Drug Trial of Former Aide
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh may be called to testify in the cocaine-conspiracy trial of a former top aide, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: Bucs Sign Williamson To Two-Year Contract
description: Richard Williamson, who guided the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to one victory and two losses as interim head coach after Ray Perkins was dismissed last December, has signed a two-year contract to be the Buccaneers' new head coach, the team announced yesterday in Tampa, Fla.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Telecommunications Corp., Baton Rouge, La., named Norman Klugman president and chief operating officer. * Borden Inc., Columbus, Ohio, named James T. McCrory senior vice president for public affairs. * Fairchild Space and Defense Corp., Germantown, Md., a subsidiary of the Matra Group, named Larry M. Calvert corporate vice president. * Melville Corp., Harrison, N.Y., named Judy Vredenburgh president of its Chess King division, a retailer of apparel for young men. * Neutrogena Corp., Los Angeles, named Martha R. Pease senior vice president of marketing. * Nikko Securities Co. International, New York, a subsidiary of Nikko Securities Co. of Japan, named Stephen A. Maher executive vice president and general manager of its fixed-income division. * Pratt & Whitney Co., East Hartford, Conn., named John P. Balaguer president of its government engines and space propulsion business. He succeeds William C. Missimer, Jr. who will retire on April 1. Robert A. Wolfe was named executive vice president of the government engines and space propulsion business. He succeeds Mr. Balaguer. * Sony Corporation of America, Park Ridge, N.J., a subsidiary of Sony Corp. of Japan, named Paul Foschino vice president of the mobile electronics division, Sony Audio Component Systems Co. Sony also named Jay Sato vice president of its consumer video products company.

title: Encounters in Israel Make Dinkins Feel at Home
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins set out this morning to show solidarity with the Israeli people in their time of trouble -- and ran into New Yorkers and a Soviet immigrant hoping for help getting an apartment.

title: Staffing and Radar Problems Are Linked to Crash
description: A fatal airplane collision that at first glance seemed solely due to a momentary mistake by a harried air traffic controller also involved longstanding problems, including the use of unreliable radar equipment and a chronic shortage of air traffic controllers, Federal investigators said today.

title: Book Accuses C.I.A. in Contra Aid Plot
description: A book by a former Iran-contra prosecutor accuses the Central Intelligence Agency of bribing officials in Costa Rica to allow the construction of an airstrip to resupply the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Hughes Unit Plans Layoffs
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a military contracting subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it would lay off about 300 people at one of its units by the end of March.

title: Blazers Improve at Nets' Expense
description: Portland's reserves scored 53 points, led by Cliff Robinson's 20, as the Trail Blazers improved their league-best record with a 117-102 rout of the Nets tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest Inc., an airline based in Wichita, Kan., said it had accepted an offer of $8 a share made by Mesa Airlines Inc., Farmington., N.M. * Baroid Corp., Houston, a drilling services and equipment company, said it had agreed to acquire Diamond Boart Stratabit S.A. from Diamond Boart S.A. of Belgium and Sanvik A.B., Sanviken, Sweden, for $70 million in cash and five-year warrants to buy two million Baroid shares at $7.875 each. * CIT Group Holdings Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Corp., announced that the Federal Reserve had approved its planned acquisition of Fidelcor Business Credit Corp., the commercial finance unit of First Fidelity Bancorp., Lawrenceville, N.J. * Delphax Systems, Randolph, Mass., a printing technology concern, said it had acquired the Imaging Systems division, in Hopkinton, Mass., of Avery Dennison, Pasadena, Calif. * Hamilton Standard, Windsor Locks, Conn., a unit of United Technologies Corp., plans to reduce its work force by 550 people. The reductions -- about 5 percent of its 13,000-member work force -- will be through layoffs, voluntary resignations and retirements. * RTZ Corp., London, said its Capper Pass & Son Ltd. tin smelter unit is to close in the next six months, with the loss of 489 jobs at the plant.

title: Market Place; Still More Woes For Real Estate
description: AS the problems in the commercial real estate markets drag on, some of the nation's biggest real estate investment funds have been hard hit by the fall in property values. In the last few months there was a wave of markdowns of the appraised values of properties held by nearly all the major property funds. Not surprisingly, many pension funds are trying to get their money out.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working rotary oil and gas rigs dropped last week by 55, to a total of 996, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count was higher than a year ago, when there were 931 working rigs. Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes, attributed last week's decline to a high number of drilling completions in West Texas and Bakersfield, Calif., as well as traditional seasonal declines.

title: George I. Bloom, Politician, 92
description: George I. Bloom, a longtime Republican leader in Pennsylvania, died Sunday at Holy Spirit Hospital in Camp Hill, Pa., after a short illness. He was 92 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The U.S. Commander; COMMANDER CLAIMS GAINS IN BREAKING IRAQI ARMY'S WILL
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander in the Persian Gulf, said today that he doubted the allies could ever undermine the determination of President Saddam Hussein to keep fighting. But he said that he thought the will of the Iraqi Army could be broken and that his forces were "making great progress in that direction."

title: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: The Military; Despite Detailed Pentagon Blueprint, Questions on Spending Remain
description: The military budget announced today represents the Pentagon's most comprehensive effort to reshape the American military in the face of political changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and the fast-growing deficit at home. But for all its details, it leaves some main issues unanswered.

title: Budget Deceit, Punctured; But Defense Still Stands Alone
description: On the surface, Budget Day in Washington yesterday seemed bland, even boring. In truth it was a remarkable occasion, because for once, the Government avoided its annual plunge into the solemnly ridiculous.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Weapons; A Warhorse That Fires The Heftiest of Shells
description: The United States Navy called on a former floating museum yesterday to join the battering of Iraqi troops in Kuwait.

title: Accord for Daniels
description: Kal Daniels, who two years ago had his $325,000 salary determined by a coin flip with Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, reached agreement with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday on a 1991 salary of $2,025,000.

title: Brooklyn Grand Jury Finds School Patronage Pervasive
description: A grand jury investigating charges of corruption in a Brooklyn school district has indicted one person and concluded that patronage was widespread in the district.

title: Study Says Ad Revenue For Radio Rose 5.2%
description: Amid a sluggish market for print and television advertising, radio advertising revenue grew 5.2 percent in 1990, according to a survey released yesterday by the Radio Advertising Bureau.

title: People
description: * Valentine Zammit has been named chief financial officer of Bozell Inc., New York. * TBWA Advertising Inc. has named three executive vice presidents: Grant Castle, Patricia Cameron and Geoff Hayes.

title: Spill Backfires on Iraq
description: Pentagon analysts reported today that Iraq had shut down the southernmost of four seawater-desalting plants in occupied Kuwait, apparently after it became fouled by oil from the vast Persian Gulf spill unleashed last month.

title: Tests of Nasal Insulin Spray Show Promise for Diabetics
description: DANISH scientists have developed insulin that can be taken as a nasal spray, raising hopes that some diabetics now dependent on the drug may soon be able to treat their disease without injections. Insulin currently must be given by needle, and many diabetics take one to four shots each day.

title: Rally Continues in Treasury Issues
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates dipped again yesterday, continuing the big rally on Friday. Interest rates on the three-month and six-month securities auctioned yesterday fell to their lowest levels in nearly three years.

title: Carl Carlson, 78, Dies; Cigar Industry Leader
description: Carl J. Carlson, a retired cigar manufacturer, died on Saturday at his home in Plainfield, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: Saturn Disq reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian funds.

title: Office Club Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: War Summary
description: BUSH LOOKS AT THE WAR SO FAR President Bush asked his two principal war counsels to make a quick trip to the Persian Gulf for a first-hand look and to get the advice of their top commander there. Mr. Bush sounded doubtful that air power alone could achieve his war objectives and the visit might take him nearer to a decision on when, or whether, to order an American ground offensive. IRAQ'S ELITE FORCE REMAINS JUST THAT Pentagon analysts believe that three weeks of the most powerful bombardments ever have barely dented the potency of the crack Republican Guard and tank divisions lying in wait along the Iraqi-Kuwait border. A "strategic reserve," they are sheltered in well-protected shelters, sustained by underground supply lines and widely dispersed depots that could last them for up to six months. MISERY FOR THE IRAQIS The people of Iraq, suffering a cold winter of bombs and scarce food, water or electricity, were hit even harder when Baghdad said it was halting the supply of fuel until further notice. The sudden decree gave the people no chance to stock up on heating oil or gasoline. Most of Iraq's refineries are reportedly bombed-out wrecks. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon said the toll among American forces stood at 12 killed in action, 11 wounded, 24 missing and 8 confirmed prisoners of war. Aircraft: According to the Pentagon, 15 American and 7 allied aircraft were shot down by the Iraqis. That does not count aircraft otherwise lost on war-related missions, like the B-52 and two helicopters that crashed over the weekend with at least some of their crew members killed. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Twenty-five Iraqi soldiers surrendered, having hidden in the battered Saudi town of Khafji since last week's fighting. With them, American commanders counted 842 prisoners in all, including 49 officers. Baghdad said 428 civilians had been killed so far. Aircraft:At least 10 more aircraft reportedly fled to Iran, bringing the number of warplanes and crews sequestered there to about 110. In addition, the Pentagon tallied 28 aircraft lost in combat and 31 on the ground.

title: Court Backs Options System
description: A Federal appeals court in Chicago has ruled that a computerized system for trading options on Government securities could be approved for operation by the Securities and Exchange Commission without classifying the system as a securities exchange.

title: U.S. Proposing Steps to Curb Ground Collisions of Aircraft
description: Moving swiftly after a fatal crash in Los Angeles, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said today that his agency was proposing systemwide changes in the measures airports, airlines and air traffic controllers take to avoid runway collisions.

title: Watkins-Johnson Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $ 514,000, or 6 cents a share, from settlement of a pricing dispute with U.S. Government, settled in the fourth quarter.c-After losses from various settlements and claims of $ 1,780,000.d-After gains from various settlements and claims of $ 651,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Palmer Tube Mills Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the impact of the Persian Gulf war on European airlines misstated the number of United States cities served by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and the number of flights from those cities that it has canceled. The line serves 8 cities in the United States and has canceled 5 of its 49 flights from them.

title: Weis Markets Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
John G. Von der Heide; Executive, 88
description: John G. Von der Heide, a former official of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Sunday at the Sprain Brook Manor convalescent home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 88 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Pier 1 Will Curtail Expansion Plans
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc. said it would slow its expansion program and lay off 29 of its headquarters staff because of the sluggish retailing climate. Pier 1, the nation's fastest-growing home furnishings retailer, has grown to 570 stores from 265 since 1985, and had hoped to have 1,000 stores by 2000. It opened 85 stores in 1989 and 74 last year.

title: Iraq Suspending Fuel Sales, As Raids Widen Shortages
description: Iraq announced the suspension of all fuel sales today, bringing further deprivation to a wintry land suffering from shortages of food, water, electricity and gasoline after allied bombers have hammered its refineries and distribution networks.

title: U.S. Acts to End Monopolies In New York Trash Hauling
description: The United States Justice Department is negotiating to sell commercial garbage-collection routes in New York City to some of the nation's biggest waste-disposal companies, a move that could open the way to more competition in a business widely viewed as controlled by organized crime.

title: Best Iraqi Troops Not Badly Hurt By Bombs, Pentagon Officials Say
description: After nearly three weeks of heavy bombing, the United States and allied military forces in the Persian Gulf have not substantially weakened the combat effectiveness of Iraq's elite ground forces in a well-entrenched "strategic reserve" in northern Kuwait and southern Iraq, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Jail Is Planned For Brooklyn, And Foes Rise
description: A Federal detention center that will hold 1,000 inmates is scheduled to open in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn later this year despite opposition from neighbors and elected officials.

title: New York's School Spending Is Questioned
description: The New York City Board of Education spends $68 million a year on dropout prevention, even paying neighborhood groups to dispatch their workers to the homes of truants and coax the children back to school.

title: Knights Hire a Wide-Open Coach
description: The first coach of the New York Knights of the World League of American Football will be Darrel (Mouse) Davis, known throughout his 16-year college and professional coaching career as an avid proponent of the run-and-shoot offense. He will be introduced today at a news conference in Giants Stadium, where the Knights will play their games.

title: Former S.& L. Officer Indicted
description: A former senior officer of a failed New Jersey savings and loan institution was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that he took more than $2.5 million in illegal kickbacks from developers for substantial loans and that he failed to report the payments on his income tax.

title: Review/Recital; A Violinist Who Shares, Not Merely Dazzles
description: The designation "virtuoso" has come to imply a singularity. Virtuoso performers exist by virtue of their brilliance of sound, their unusual agility and an aggressiveness of personality, attributes that separate them from the merely competent and professional.

title: Manville's Profit Plunges; Costs of Asbestos Fund Cited
description: The Manville Corporation said today that its earnings had plunged in the fourth quarter and in all of 1990, partly because of expenses associated with changes at the trust set up to compensate asbestos victims.

title: One of Our Goalies Is Missing
description: In the latest news from hockey, Roger Neilson has decided that loose lips sink ships. The coach of the New York Rangers is concerned that published reports of injuries to his players might prompt opponents to pound on the injured areas.

title: On Holiday, Trying the Exotic (and Trying to Like It)
description: ONCE, as a teen-ager, I was having lunch at a resort in the Catskills when a man with a particularly loud voice made a remark I remember thinking was absurd.

title: Rose Going to Shows
description: Pete Rose may have been barred from the Hall of Fame until the commissioner removes him from the ineligible list, but he still expects to make a living from baseball.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Bowe's Latest Success Has Offers Pouring In
description: Rock Newman, the fight manager, has been in Las Vegas, Nev., this past week, mulling offers for Riddick Bowe, his undefeated (21-0 with 19 knockouts) heavyweight.

title: Real Estate; Swedes Join Foreign Rush To Build Hotels in Atlanta
description: A SWEDISH developer has begun construction of a luxury hotel here, its first project in the United States and one that will add to the city's growing inventory of foreign-owned hotels.

title: Zenith Considers Sale Television Business
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, which is battling a proxy challenge from a small New Jersey company, confirmed yesterday that it was considering selling its television manufacturing business.

title: Thornburgh Testifies That a Former Aide Denied Using Drugs
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh testified for the prosecution today in the trial of a former top aide accused of using cocaine and making false statements to the Federal Government about drug use.

title: Evidence of Cash Problems Mounting at Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest department store operator on the West Coast, said this evening that efforts to improve its financial future had fallen through, including a plan to sell its credit-card receivables.

title: Washington Post Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fannie Mae Issues Total $1.5 Billion
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced a total of $1.5 billion in five-year and 10-year debentures through various securities dealers.

title: New Jersey to Open Agency on Women and AIDS
description: The New Jersey Department of Health is establishing an Office on Women and AIDS as part of a strategy announced today for combating the disease in the state for the rest of the decade.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York yesterday priced $138 million in bonds to refund other debt sold when interest rates were higher.

title: The Next Soviet Challenge
description: Abel Aganbegyan, an economic adviser to whom Mikhail Gorbachev doesn't listen anymore, put it mildly to participants at the World Economic Forum here. "The choice is establishing the market in the Soviet Union or chaos, nothing else," he said

title: Kroger Returns To Profitability
description: The Kroger Company, which took large losses in 1989 to reduce its long-term debt, posted earnings for the fourth quarter and 1990, the grocery company said today.

title: McDonnell Douglas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects pretax charge of $ 350 million for termination of A-12 program and an after-tax gain of $ 142 million, or $ 3.71 a share from the settlement of certain pension fund obligations through the purchase of an annuity contract in the quarter and the year included income from discontinued operations of $ 31,000,000, or 81 cents a share.c-Net incomed-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 77,000,000, or $ 2.01 a share, and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 179,000,000, or $ 4.68 a share.The company said net income for the fourth quarter of 1990 included a loss from continuing operations of $ 11 million, compared to a loss of $ 17 million, in the year-earlier period.The company also said fourth quarter of 1990 included net from discontinued operations of $ 10 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to $ 77 million, or $ 2.01 a share, a year-ago.

title: Social Links Are Seen in Black Stress
description: A study offers new evidence that environmental factors like poverty, diet and the stress of racial discrimination could outweigh genetic factors in explaining the excessive rate of high blood pressure among black Americans.

title: Smithfield Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
From Passaic to Riyadh . . .
description: I've never been a war correspondent, never covered the Pentagon and I've never been to the Middle East. But lately I've been thinking that I recognize the generals and the colonels who are briefing us on the Persian Gulf. They remind me of New Jersey's local police officers.

title: Polaroid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Preston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 17.8 million after-tax loss reserve ($ 3.08 a share) recorded in the third quarter in connection with the closing of Reeves Transportation Co. and Pioneer Transportation Systems.

title: The Drums of Protest
description: Since before the Persian Gulf war began, President Bush has been waging a running battle with a small but vigilant band of antiwar protesters beating their drums across the street from the White House.

title: Indonesian Oil Outlook
description: Indonesia expects its oil exports to rise by 6.7 percent in the fiscal year starting in April, the head of the state-owned oil company, Pertamina, said on Monday. Faisal Abdau said the next fiscal year's exports would average 849,000 barrels a day, up from 796,000 a day this year.

title: Orders to Factories Showed No Change in December
description: Despite huge purchases of military goods and commercial aircraft, the overall level of orders to factories was unchanged in December, helping depress the increase for all of 1990 to a meager 1.4 percent, the Government reported today.

title: What Went Wrong at the Rock in Rio Festival
description: Rock in Rio II, an attempt to create the biggest rock festival in history, failed to reach that goal and has left a troubled aftermath since it ended last week. One person died at the festival in a fall after climbing a wall of the Maracana Stadium in Rio de Janeiro, where the concerts were held, and newspapers there reported that one concertgoer was raped by four military policemen.

title: Harry Ackerman, 78, TV Producer, Is Dead
description: Harry S. Ackerman, a television producer who made or helped to create such hits as "Gunsmoke," "I Love Lucy" and "Leave It to Beaver," died on Sunday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: Hewlett to Buy Informix Stake
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would acquire up to 10 percent of the common stock of the Informix Corporation, a producer of data base-management software based in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Paris Schools Add a Course, A la Carte
description: Ever nervous about the foreign (read American) influences besieging French culture, the Government is now reaching into the classroom to make sure future generations are properly trained in the proudly French arts of cooking and eating.

title: Review/Music; Riley, Minimal No Longer, Turns to a Polyglot Swirl
description: From a purely statistical point of view, the programs Leonard Slatkin and the St. Louis Symphony played at Carnegie Hall on Sunday and Monday evenings were masterpieces of balance and symmetry. Three of the six works Mr. Slatkin conducted were American scores, two by living composers. One, a Terry Riley work, was a world premiere. Another, Joseph Schwantner's 1978 "Aftertones of Infinity," was a deserved revival. And the third, Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto, has been inching its way into the standard repertory.

title: Who's Entitled?
description: Entitlements. Few Washington words are more misused or abused -- which is why the Bush Administration deserves respect and support for a brave initiative in its new budget.

title: Suspect Is Killed in Struggle With 5 Officers in Queens
description: A man suspected of stealing a car suffocated in a struggle with five police officers early yesterday in Queens, and the Chief Medical Examiner's office ruled the death a homicide.

title: Deals
description: BASKETBALL INDIANA (NBA) -- Activated Rik Smits, center, from the injured list. Released Jawann Oldham, center.

title: China Legal Scholar Faces Death Penalty In Democracy Trial
description: A legal scholar went on trial today for "conspiracy to overthrow the Government," the most serious criminal charge known to be leveled so far in the latest round of trials of Tiananmen democracy advocates. Conviction could bring the death penalty.

title: National Healthcorp L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Knicks' Rally Falls Short as Magic Sweeps Season Series
description: Even last-minute heroics were not enough for the Knicks tonight. They fell behind by too much. They ran out of time. And they are quickly running out of excuses for a disappointing season.

title: Pacific Telecom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $ 1.9 million and $ 5.2 million in the quarter and year, respectively.c-Included a gain of $ 1.5 million in the quarter and a loss of $ 1.6 million in the year, both from discontinued operations.The company said the increase in operating income was primarily due to the acquisition of North-West Telecommunications Inc. and the sale of capacity on the North Pacific cable. This increase was partially offset by intrastate rate reductions by the company's long lines subsidiaries.

title: 'Ponzi Scheme' Is Cited As Assets Are Frozen
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams has obtained an injunction freezing the assets of Stockbridge Funding, a mortgage banking corporation that is being investigated for possibly bilking investors, mostly Polish-Americans in the New York metropolitan area, of as much as $100 million.

title: Despite Terrorist Fear, Overseas Studies Go On
description: Because of the war in the Persian Gulf, some American colleges and universities have canceled international exchange programs or switched from domestic air carriers to overseas lines to keep from becoming terrorist targets. Most of the 3,200 overseas study programs for American students, however, are running without interruption.

title: Review/Jazz; More Than One Way To Improvise
description: Because the saxophonist Craig Handy had been delayed by a recording session, his show at Bradley's last Thursday night started out with a series of duets by the pianist John Hicks and the bassist Don Pate. The performance moved from insecurity to aggressive confidence as the two figured out a mutual approach to a tune's harmony. The pieces at first had a groping quality, as if the musicians were answering questions with more questions; once they figured out their route through various compositions, things changed.

title: Cuomo Begins Budget Fight; He Still Opposes a Tax Rise
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today began an impassioned and defiant defense of his plan to make severe cuts in the state budget, telling anxious legislators and angry labor leaders that his stand against higher taxes would remain firm.

title: Penn State Foils Rutgers
description: Susan Robinson scored 20 points and Tanya Garner added 19 as Penn State, ranked No. 2 in the country, defeated ninth-ranked Rutgers, 78-72, last night in an Atlantic 10 game.

title: Dinkins and Other Officials Assail Bush's Budget Over Spending Cuts
description: New York City and state officials and a Brooklyn Congressman reacted today with varying degrees of scorn and disappointment over President Bush's budget.

title: The Pop Life
description: Quite a Guy

title: Trilling Medical Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bears Rehire Ditka For Three More Years
description: Mike Ditka will be prowling the Chicago Bears' sidelines for the next three years after agreeing to a new contract yesterday.

title: Pedro Arrupe, Jesuit Chief for 18 Years, Dies at 83
description: The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, head of the Jesuit order from 1965 to 1983, died yesterday at the Jesuit headquarters in Rome. He was 83 years old.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a third quarter after-tax charge of $ 218 million for costs related to plant Vogtle nuclear facility.

title: Miscellany
description: * Oglivy & Mather Direct, a unit of the Oglivy Group, has formed a new division, the Production Group, to meet all direct advertising production needs. The group, to be run by Norman T. Paley, senior vice president of production services at Oglivy & Mather Direct, will be based in New York.

title: McDonnell Has Loss and Cuts Payout
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation lost $1 million in the fourth quarter and slashed its stock dividend for the first time in recent memory, company officials said today.

title: People
description: * Terry Bonaccolta has left her position as executive vice president-management director of new business at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver Advertising. Jim Dragoumis, executive vice president-management director of account services at the agency, will now oversee the Subaru account, which had been Ms. Bonaccolta's responsibility. * Grey Advertising promoted Jack Aaker and Paul Jones to vice president-associative creative directors. Don Lowy was named vice president-group management supervisor. * Campbell-Mithun-Esty announced several promotions in its New York office: Michael F. Aldrich, to senior vice president-management supervisor; Elizabeth I. Barrack, to account supervisor; Diane Connolly, to senior vice president-management supervisor; Mario R. Gigante, to senior vice president-director of print production, and Richard J. Karnbach, to senior vice president-art director. * Cliff Freeman & Partners named David D. Woodruff vice president-management supervisor and Lori Podsiadlik vice president-account supervisor in its Detroit office. * Carolyn Clare has joined Judy Wald Agency, New York, a division of J. W. Adventures International, as senior vice president and creative placement manager.

title: Sage Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Everyone but Oil Companies Is for Cleaner Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Appointment At Times
description: The New York Times has appointed Susan Greendale Russo group director of planning, operations and The New York Times Magazine, Erich G. Linker Jr., senior vice president for advertising, said yesterday.

title: Dow Up 16.09, to 2,788.37 in Heavy Trading
description: Stock prices kept rising yesterday in exceptionally heavy trading as money managers and individuals alike jumped into the market.

title: United Television reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unican Security reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Book Notes
description: Cash Still Influential

title: Campeau Closing 4 Florida Stores
description: The Campeau Corporation, the struggling Canadian retailer, said it would close four stores in Florida. It said three Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh department stores, in Tampa, Sarasota and Hollywood, would close by March 31, along with an unprofitable Burdine's store in Miami's Mayfair mall.

title: Bush Offers Proposals to Encourage Saving
description: Citing a need for a higher American savings rate to finance long-term economic growth, the President's budget proposes to restore the tax preference for capital gains, to authorize special new tax-exempt savings accounts and to allow first-time home buyers to withdraw money prematurely from individual retirement accounts without penalty.

title: Chicago Test Of Trading
description: Several brokers and traders are learning this week to use electronic trading cards in an unusual joint effort by the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Reader's Digest Association Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect the incorrect recording of sales in the 1989 second quarter. The restatement had the effect of reducing revenue by $ 8.9 million and net income by $ 4.6 million, or 4 cents a share, for that quarter.

title: Salomon Says It Lost $15 Million in Period
description: Reflecting the turmoil on Wall Street in recent months, Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it lost $15 million in the fourth quarter of last year, compared with earnings of $68 million, or 42 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989.

title: Pope Sees Walesa; Urges Aid
description: Warmly welcoming Lech Walesa to the Vatican as both the new President of Poland and a Roman Catholic pilgrim, Pope John Paul II appealed to wealthy nations today to help his fellow Poles through the financial hardships afflicting their young democracy.

title: War Spurs Navigation by Satellite
