description: American soldiers trying to find their way in the featureless deserts of Saudi Arabia are being aided by a Pentagon satellite system that allows them to determine their location precisely. That system is becoming the basis of a small but rapidly growing industry that is supplying navigation tools for nonmilitary uses.

title: Dr. John P. Clay, 80, Ex-Chemistry Professor
description: Dr. John Paul Clay, a retired chairman of the chemistry department at Lehman College, part of the City University of New York, died last Wednesday in Ormond Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 80 years old and had lived for many years in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Tembec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Bridge
description: For many years, Hugh Kelsey, the Scottish player-writer, has acted as general editor of an important bridge publishing effort in Britain. His "Master Bridge Series," published by Victor Gollancz, recently introduced a fine new writer, Danny Roth. His "Clues to Winning Play," on detective work at the card table, was followed by "Signal Success in Bridge," which dealt with the use of signaling methods old and new.

title: Proposal Has Supporters, But Many Raise Objections
description: The Treasury's proposal to overhaul the banking system was applauded yesterday by executives of some of the nation's largest banks, but it provoked objections from competing financial companies and from smaller banks.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: SHRIMP cook extremely well in a microwave oven without toughening or getting stringy. There is no water to bring to a boil, and the shrimp can be cooked either on their own or in traditional dishes.

title: Wing Device Saves Fuel on 727's
description: Plastic composite wingtips installed on older Boeing 727 airliners could raise fuel economy as much as 5 percent, said Valsan Partners, developer of the device. This could help airlines struggling to cope with high fuel costs and make the aircraft more attractive to buyers as the American airline industry restructures.

title: Netcor reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Redmen's Title Aspirations Are Throttled by Bryson
description: Following an emotional victory over Seton Hall on Saturday, Lou Carnesecca cautioned his St. John's team against a letdown, especially in the midst of a suffocating Big East race, especially against Villanova.

title: Books of The Times; Short Stories Spanning Graham Greene's Career
description: The Last Word And Other Stories By Graham Greene 150 pages. Reinhardt Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: School Bus Offers a Bonus With the Ride: Videos
description: Eric Heard, a fifth grader at the Patrick Henry School in St. Louis, is a lot more excited about taking the bus to school these days. That's because he rides on the nation's first "video school bus" -- with five television monitors, eight built-in speakers and a videocassette recorder.

title: New York State Publications Should Sell Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: McClatchy Newspapers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lawmaker Has Brain Surgery
description: Silvio O. Conte, Republican of Massachusetts, underwent emergency brain surgery Friday for removal of a blood clot, and has been in intensive care ever since, his office said today. The 69-year-old lawmaker has suffered no permanent damage and is expected to recover fully, a spokesman said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The state income-tax fraud case against HARRY HELMSLEY ended quietly yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan when the 81-year-old real-estate magnate was ruled incompetent to stand trial.

title: Weldotron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,660,000, or 91 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossThe company said that in May 1990 it sold certain assets of Metropac Inc., an 80 percent owned unit. In September, the company received $ 11.9 million from Hobart division of Premark International as settlement. Also, the company incurred certain non-recurring expenses during the third quarter.

title: INSIDE
description: California's Water Fight Drought and relentless population growth in California are forcing a political struggle between farm and urban interests that could change the face of the state. Page A12. Cuomo's Cuts Stun Suburbs Suburban officials say they are beginning to realize how many basic services would be hurt by cuts proposed in Governor Cuomo's budget. Page B1.

title: Everyone but Oil Companies Is for Cleaner Gas; Tax the Truckers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rodman & Renshaw Names a New President
description: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a financial services concern in Chicago that has been expanding for two and a half years, yesterday named Norman E. Mains president and chief operating officer.

title: Lord, Dentsu Loses Dannon
description: Lord, Dentsu & Partners, which until recently was known as HDM Worldwide, has lost the $10 million Dannon account.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH DOLE , who resigned as Labor Secretary last November to head the American Red Cross, said Monday that she would give up her first year's salary to highlight the work of Red Cross volunteers. Mrs. Dole's salary is $200,000 a year.

title: Editor Sues Magazine For Publishing Letter
description: Gordon Lish, the author and editor at Alfred A. Knopf Inc., has filed a libel suit against Harper's Magazine Foundation because the magazine published a letter to students enrolled in his writers' workshop in Manhattan. The complaint, filed Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, also alleges copyright infringement.

title: Backers of Policy Seize Initiative in the Streets
description: As happened in the Vietnam era, a war overseas is bringing with it a struggle for the allegiance of Americans at home.

title: Frank A. Cardman, 75, Ex-Pan Am Executive
description: Frank A. Cardman, former director of security for Pan American World Airways, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Glen Head, L.I.

title: TCI International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Panel Approves Funds for Bailout
description: The Senate Banking Committee today authorized an additional $30 billion in taxpayer money to continue closing failed savings and loan institutions.

title: Tales of Attack on Town Dear to Baghdad
description: Since the allied bombing of Iraq began, the Baghdad radio has maintained that the American-led coalition has attacked Saddam Hussein's hometown of Tikrit.

title: Key Rates
Monroe Arnold, Actor, 64
description: Monroe Arnold, an actor, died Saturday at his home in Queens. He was 64 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Carl-Uwe Steeb Beats Chang Michael Chang's first appearance in Milan was short-lived. Chang lost, 6-1, 7-5, to Carl-Uwe Steeb in 83 minutes last night a first-round match of the Milan Indoor tournament and admittedly started the year badly. Chang, who lost in the first round of the Italian Open last year, was overwhelmed by the unseeded German player in the first set, spoiled chances of a rally in the second. Steeb, 23 years old, has recovered from a foot surgery that sidelined him for several weeks late last year. He broke Chang's serve three times in the first set, then overcame 2-4 and 4-5 deficits to win the second, capitalizing on unforced errors by Chang to win the last three games. In other first-round action, Anders Jarryd of Sweden breezed past Roberto Raffa of Italy, 6-0, 6-1. The Soviet players, Aleksandr Volkov and Andrei Chesnokov, also earned second-round berths, defeating Cedric Pioline of France and Sebastian Soresini of Italy, respectively.(AP) Gomez Holds Off Devening: Second-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador fought off a first-round upset bid in the Volvo-San Francisco tennis tournament yesterday and beat 371st-ranked Brian Devening of Bradenton, Fla., 4-6, 6-4, 6-4. "I can't remember how long it has been since I won a first-round match," said Gomez, the world's No. 6 ranked player. Gomez said the near upset was part of the price he is paying for having taken two and a half months off after a disappointing second half this season. Earlier in the season, he won the French Open, his first Grand Slam title. Also advancing to the second round were Kevin Curren, David Pate, Mark Kratzmann of Australia and Guillaume Raoux of France.(AP) N.H.L. Robitaille Lifts Kings Over Flyers Luc Robitaille's 30th goal of the season snapped a third-period tie and lifted the Los Angeles Kings past the Flyers, 3-2, last night in Philadelphia. Robitaille took a pass from the defenseman Bob Halkidis and beat Ron Hextall to the far side with a slap shot from the right circle at 7:53. It was Robitaille's 21st goal in his last 30 games. Wayne Gretzky, playing in his 900th league game, was held pointless for only the fifth time in 53 games this season. (AP) Bruins 6, Oilers 5: Ken Hodge completed the first hat trick of his N.H.L. career by scoring with eight seconds remaining in overtime to lift Boston at home. Petr Klima scored three goals for the second time in four games for the Oilers and Craig Simpson had the other two goals for Edmonton, which led by 4-1 early in the second period before Hodge led Boston's comeback. (AP) Capitals 5, Canucks 3: Dino Ciccarelli scored his 400th career goal early in the third period to ignite a four-goal rally that lifted Washington past Vancouver at home. The loss extended the Canucks' streak without a victory to seven games. Ciccarelli, Al Iafrate and Dale Hunter scored in an 8:27 span as Washington overcame a 3-1 deficit. (AP)

title: NO TERRORIST LINK TO BOMBS IS FOUND
description: Federal investigators said today that they had no evidence that terrorists had planted two pipe bombs that were disarmed here early Monday before they could blow up some chemical tanks.

title: 40 COLOMBIANS DIE IN REBEL VIOLENCE
description: More than 40 rebels, civilians and police officers died in 14 guerrilla attacks on Monday and today, the authorities said.

title: Tultex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
It's Official: Big East to Play Football
description: After decades of futile discussions in which independent Eastern colleges were unable to form a football alliance, eight universities came together this morning to compete under a banner that changed the college sports marketplace in the 1980's.

title: Hero to the Hopeless
description: In nearly 12 years as Iraq's dictator, Saddam Hussein has done nothing for the Arab world, for Islam or the third world. Quite the contrary. He squandered oil revenues on arms, terrorized Muslim clerics and waged aggressive war against Islamic Iran. Then he attacked Arab Kuwait.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A8-11

title: Plan to Shift $15 Billion Faces an Uncertain Fate
description: President Bush's proposal to take about $15 billion worth of Federal programs, abolish them and give the states the money to use for the old purposes or new ones has been greeted with interest by the governors, with cheers by some Republicans and with skepticism and scorn by the Democrats who run Congress.

title: Senior Service Chief Oversees Acquisition
description: Kenneth B. Hamlet, a former executive of the Holiday Corporation, is now concentrating on the expansion of a business that serves the elderly, the Senior Service Corporation.

title: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Drop 31.5%
description: Sales of American-made vehicles dropped 31.5 percent in late January, closing a month of drastic sales declines for auto makers buffeted by war and a weak economy.

title: Cleanup of Nuclear Waste At Arms Plant Is Postponed
description: The Department of Energy has announced a delay of at least one to two years in stabilizing the most dangerous radioactive waste problem in the nuclear weapons complex, and the State of Washington and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are accusing the department of violating a cleanup agreement reached two years ago.

title: Prospering Amid Recession: The Avrett, Free Approach
description: EVEN with the industry in a slump, some agencies are still able to grow rapidly, like Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, which has picked up a number of sizable accounts recently.

title: 4,000 Jobs To Be Cut At Pan Am
description: The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that it would cut about 4,000 jobs and reduce service to Europe as a result of the falloff in international air travel since the Persian Gulf war began.

title: Arthur H. Konvitz; Fund-Raiser, 78
description: Arthur H. Konvitz, a fund-raiser who was an early developer of the charity telethon, died on Jan. 26 at his home in Inverrary, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: Food Notes
description: Many Foods, One Shape

title: As Many Fall, Project's Survivors Struggle On
description: On a crisp winter afternoon, a half-dozen middle-aged black men huddled around a chess table in the shadow of the Martin Luther King Jr. Towers in Harlem.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Pinball's Back And Wizards Tilt With Joy
description: "THIS is like when a batter steps up to the plate," said Aaron Bateman, flexing and flailing his wrists, loosening those muscles, relaxing those joints.

title: Eastern Germany Part of Coke Plan
description: The Coca-Cola Company plans to buy bottling and distribution plants in eastern Germany. The agreement in principle with Treuhandanstalt, the state agency charged with privatizing industry in the formerly Communist country, and new capital investments will bring Coca-Cola's investment to more than $450 million, the company said at a beverage conference here.

title: William Benedict Johnson; Engineer, 76
description: William Benedict Johnson, a chemical engineer who helped develop processes for converting coal to oil, died on Sunday at his home in Sudmouth, England. He was 76 years old.

title: Leonard W. Arentsen; Executive, 53
description: Leonard W. Arentsen, president of Batus, Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British conglomerate B.A.T. Industries, died on Friday at the Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Arizona. He was 53 years old and lived in Anchorage, Ky.

title: Israel Bombs Palestinian Targets Near Major Port in South Lebanon
description: Israeli fighter-bombers mounted broad attacks today against Palestinian guerrilla strongholds near the southern Lebanese port of Sidon. The police said that 12 people were killed and 25 wounded, and that buildings in several villages were destroyed.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 111.3 million, and a loss of $ 6.3 million from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for investment tax credits.c-Net incomeThe latest year's income before items included a non-recurring restructuring charge of $ 40 million. The extraordinary charge of $ 111.3 million resulted from a writedown in the third quarter for an unrealized loss on investments in common stock.Revenues were restated to reflect the previously reported reclassification of certain engineering and construction revenues and costs, which had no effect on income.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday misidentified State Senator John Lynch of New Jersey. He is the Senate President.

title: U.S. to Close Nuclear Sub Base in Scotland in '92
description: The United States nuclear submarine base at Holy Loch, Scotland, which opened despite strong antiwar protests and British Government misgivings in the early 1960's, will close sometime next year, Defense Secretary Tom King told the House of Commons today.

title: LuEsther Mertz, 85, Arts Patron And Partner in Magazine Business
description: LuEsther T. Mertz, a general partner in Publishers Clearing House who was known for her extensive philanthropy on behalf of the arts and other causes, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 85 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bombardier Inc., Montreal, said its Belgian subsidiary, BN S.A., had won a $60 million order from Belgian National Railways for 72 intermediate coaches for existing self-propelled trains. * Constellation Holdings Inc., Baltimore, a subsidiary of Baltimore Gas and Electric Co.; 3i Ventures Corp., Boston, a technology investment concern, and Whiting-Turner Corp., Baltimore, have joined with Johns Hopkins University and the Johns Hopkins Health System to form Triad Investors Corp., a $5.25 million venture capital fund to help develop the inventions of members of the univerisity's faculty. * Dakota Capital Corp. said members of the Hatch family had agreed to tender their 54.3 percent stake in T. G. Bright & Co., Niagara Falls, Ontario, a wine maker, under Dakota's takeover bid of $20 a share. * Duty Free International Inc., Ridgefield, Conn., an operator of duty-free shops, completed the acquisition of a chain of 16 duty-free and three retail convenience stores for about $45 million. * Elite Industries, a chocolate and coffee company in Israel, will acquire Israel Edible Products Ltd., a producer of margarine and mayonnaise, for about $40 million. * Geodyne Resources Inc., Tulsa, Okla., an oil and gas exploration company, said its Geodyne Production Co. subsidiary would purchase about $52 million in oil and natural gas producing properties from BHP Petroleum (Americas) Inc. * Healthco International Inc., Boston, a dental equipment supply company, said its shareholders had approved the company's proposed acquisition by an affiliate of Hicks, Muse & Co. and Ray C. Davis for $19.25 a share, or about $250 million.

title: About New York; Barks and Coos From a Master Of Tin Pan Alley
description: Writing the words of a song is the highest of callings, perhaps even higher than writing newspaper columns. At least, the words of a very good song. (There are many, many bad songs.)

title: Michigan Court Bars Doctor From Using His Suicide Machine
description: A judge today barred a doctor who invented a suicide device from using the machine.

title: Sensormatic Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an unspecified extraordinary gain on sale of the business and assets of retail market electronic article surveillance operations.Year-ago period was restated.Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Television; 'Anything but Love,' but Much Else
description: Finally pouncing on romance this season, "Anything but Love" has misplaced its charm. In the beginning, about a season and a half ago, the ABC series offered the promising concept of the actress Jamie Lee Curtis and the comic Richard Lewis playing magazine writers Hannah Miller and Marty Gold in Chicago. The inevitable question: Would they or wouldn't they? Tired, granted, but in this case, offbeat personalities and clever scripts created at least the illusion of freshness. Alas, gone, all gone.

title: For the Confident U.S. Pilots, a Cautionary Word
description: Allied air supremacy has been declared over the skies of Iraq and Kuwait, but American fighter pilots are battling a new enemy: overconfidence.

title: Ex-Governor Brown Will Run for Senate In '92 in California
description: Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. announced Monday that he would resign as chairman of the California Democratic Party to run next year for the Senate seat being vacated by Alan Cranston.

title: Salomon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeResults for 1990 included a pre-tax charge of $ 155 million for the downsizing of the Philipp Brothers commodities unit.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: CAUTION FOR STUDENTS ABROAD: Most overseas study programs for American students are continuing, despite the gulf war, although the students are being advised to take certain precautions. Education, Page B5. FINDING THEIR WAY: A Pentagon satellite system that allows American soldiers to determine their location in the featureless Saudi deserts is becoming the basis of a growing industry supplying navigational tools for nonmilitary uses. Business Day, page D1.

title: Gorbachev to Disregard Lithuanian Vote
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev decreed today that a plebiscite on Lithuanian independence scheduled for Saturday is "without legal foundation," once again challenging the Baltic republic's efforts to break free of the Soviet Union.

title: Boston College Buys Beckett Collection
description: Boston College has purchased a collection of about 300 books, manuscripts and articles by Samuel Beckett.

title: Vigilance Is Urged in the Treatment of Asthmatics
description: Doctors must be more vigilant in recognizing and treating asthma, an increasingly fatal disease in the United States, Federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Prize-Winning Violinist
description: Michelle Makarski has the distinction of being the first and perhaps the last prize winner of the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition for Violinists. She took first place in 1989. The event was subsequently suspended.

title: Ohio Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for the quarter and year were down because of an adverse decision in August by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which substantially cut Ohio Edison's requested $ 218 million rate increase. The company had requested the increase to cover costs associated with its share of the Beaver Valley 2 generating unit.

title: U.S. Backs Researcher In Suing Ex-Colleague Over Accuracy of Data
description: In an unusual move, the Justice Department has joined a researcher in a lawsuit that accuses his former university colleague of falsifying results of a study to obtain a public grant.

title: Oil Reserve Deliveries Begin
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that deliveries of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve had begun under the sale announced when allied forces first bombed Iraq.

title: Bird to Return Soon
description: Larry Bird's return is imminent. After a month of mediocrity while Bird recuperated from a serious back problem, the Celtics could have him in the lineup for tonight's game against Charlotte.

title: Pepsico Up in Quarter 31.6%, to $265.9 Million
description: Pepsico, the soft drink company that also makes Frito-Lay snacks and operates Taco Bell restaurants, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 31.6 percent, to $265.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $202.1 million a year earlier, or 25 cents a share.

title: Pepsico reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included after-tax charges of $ 22.5 million from its Pizza Hut operations, consisting of the reduction of carrying charges for a foreign joint-venture investment, and of domestic and international restructuring charges.c-Included charges of $ 13.2 million after-taxes for reorganization costs in its international soft drinks operation and in Taco Bell.d-Included an after-tax charge of $ 4.2 million. The charge, which represents a pre-tax gain of $ 35.2 million, included a pre-tax gain of $ 118.2 million from its KFC-Japan initial public offering; the charges noted in the quarter results of $ 22.5 million; and charges for restaurant closures, domestic retail accounts receivable exposures in soft drinks and snack foods, and accelerated contributions to Pepsico foundation, and also included is a loss of $ 13,700,000, which represents a charge for pending lawsuits and claims relating to a business sold in 1989.e-Included an after-tax credit of $ 1.8 million comprising a $ 32.5 million pretax credit in international soft drinks, a domestic restructuring charge for Kentucky Fried Chicken, a charge in domestic snack foods and the charges noted in the quarter of $ 13.2 million.

title: Review/Fashion; Honest, Earthy Clothes for Men
description: WHEN designers make more clothes for the woods than for the nightclub, something is up. Burliness, honesty, naturalness and integrity -- these are the qualities American men's wear designers celebrated in their fall showings last week.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: HOMEY is the buzzword in cooking today. Everywhere I go, restaurant menus are replete with the kind of food I have always considered simple home fare: stewed chicken, daube, fish casseroles, mashed potatoes, tripe, calf's liver and more.

title: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts turned sharply down in the week ended yesterday, a result of the cut in the Fed discount rate on Friday to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent, and the cut in many big banks' prime rate to 9 percent, from 9 1/2 percent.

title: Schlumberger Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 13 million, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of the defense systems businesses of Schlumberger Industries, and a gain of $ 21.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from an award by the Iran-U.S. claims tribunal.

title: Economic Scene; Keeping Chicken In Every Pot
description: WILL the baby boomers be the first generation to give the lie to the American dream? Frank Levy and Richard Michel, economists at the University of Maryland and the Urban Institute, think the thirtysomething set still has a chance to live better than their parents. But the researchers' study, "The Economic Future of American Families," published this month by the Urban Institute, is hardly fodder for optimism.

title: Wine Talk
description: Think you're pretty knowledgeable about wine, do you? No trouble impressing friends, family and headwaiters? O.K., then, try this:

title: Today's Gulf Weather
description: Shifting winds over the Persian Gulf will blow from the southeast, bringing low clouds to southern Iraq and Kuwait. A disturbance in Turkey will cause clouds in Syria and northern Iraq. Isolated showers will occur in easthern Saudi Arabia Temperatures: Baghdad, high 52, low 30; Riyadh, high 73, low 50; Dhahran, high 72, low 55.

title: Polaroid Earnings Rise
description: The Polaroid Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, but the company warned that its profits will be squeezed this year by the recession and investments in new products. Polaroid's net income for the quarter was $55 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $46.5 million, or 72 cents a share in the 1989 period. Sales rose 11 percent, to $596.2 million, from $538.1 million. The company said its results were bolstered by strong overseas sales of instant cameras and conventional film.

title: Gulf Military Questions
description: President Bush is to be commended for not micromanaging the Persian Gulf war. But his passion against interference hints that he may be overreacting to President Johnson's management of the Vietnam War -- and giving his generals too much running room.

title: High-Tech Takes On Truffles
description: DARIUS, an unusually well-mannered Labrador, has had a productive life here in the Quercy region of south-central France. At this time of year, he scratched around the earth, picked up the scent of truffles and found them for his master, in exchange for cookies.

title: Under the Rug: Minority Scholarships
description: The Bush Administration has tried to sweep a new policy limiting race-exclusive college scholarships under the rug, but it still hasn't done justice to the question. The President says he wants to increase the enrollment of minority students. But his Administration no longer wants to use special scholarship money to encourage that. Mr. Bush can't have it both ways. He needs a sound policy, not just one that sounds good.

title: WAR PUTS STRAIN ON NORTH AFRICA
description: The Persian Gulf war is causing great strains on the Governments of Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco, which face intense public pressure to back Iraq but also fear angering Western nations, which provide aid and trade.

title: Canada to Join U.S. and Mexico in Talks on Free Trade
description: The United States, Canada and Mexico announced today that they would open talks, probably starting this summer, to create a North American free trade zone that would be one of the world's largest open markets,with 360 million consumers and annual output of $6 trillion.

title: Bank Plan's Gains Are All Long Term
description: The broad changes in the banking system proposed today by the Bush Administration would not solve the nation's current economic woes, but they could have important long-term benefits for the economy.

title: 3-Year Note Yield Lowest Since 1987
description: Good demand for a $12.5 billion offering of new three-year notes yesterday in the first part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions produced the lowest yield on such a security since early 1987.

title: LeMond Ready for U.S. Tour
description: Cycling's premier stage race outside of Europe will have a new sponsor this year and a healthy Greg LeMond.

title: Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 770,000 in the quarter and $ 4,031,000 in the 6 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This is the worst in 40 years we've been farming. To just come up all of a sudden and say you are not going to get any water -- I never thought we'd end up like this." -- Fred Starrh, a California farmer. [ A12:1. ]

title: Why Democrats Lose
description: The main reason the Democrats have lost the Presidency in five of the last six elections is a "convoluted and haphazard" nominating process. If it isn't changed, the party will lose again in 1992, Terry Sanford of North Carolina has properly warned Democratic colleagues in the Senate.

title: Ex-Officer Reclimbs The Whitestone Bridge
description: A former New York City policewoman who had recently settled a sexual-harassment suit against the city climbed to the top of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge yesterday for the second time in five years, the police said.

title: Drought May Alter Face Of California as It Spurs Showdown Over Water
description: Once it seemed that there would always be plenty of water for Fred Starrh to irrigate the rich soil in Kern County on the western slopes of California's Central Valley. Come February, he would normally plow and irrigate for the cotton crop and water the alfalfa.

title: Terrorists Get Early Release
description: Two Palestinians convicted of helping the hijackers of the Achille Lauro cruise ship have been released from prison early and expelled from Italy, their lawyer said today.

title: Oil Slick Kills Gulf Shrimping
description: The world's worst oil slick has killed the Persian Gulf's shrimp industry, the head of a major gulf fishing company said today.

title: Soviets Increase Patrols by Army, Extending Crackdown to 86 Cities
description: The Gorbachev Government stepped up its high-visibility police crackdown today, announcing a 50 percent increase in army patrols in the cities and pursuing criminal charges against a prominent millionaire proponent of free enterprise.

title: U.S. Hits Hussein's Town, As War Hits Home in Iraq
description: Allied planes ranged deep into Iraq today, dropping heavy payloads on Baghdad, Basra and Tikrit, President Saddam Hussein's hometown, amid new indications that the air campaign is deeply disrupting Iraqi civilian life and military activity.

title: 43-Ton Soviet Space Station Will Plunge to Earth
description: An abandoned orbiting outpost that was the centerpiece of the Soviet space program as it came of age, complete with astronauts' feats of daring, will plunge to earth in a rain of fiery debris today or early tomorrow, Soviet and American officials said yesterday.

title: Goodrich's Earnings Off By 48 Percent
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company, a producer of plastic resins, specialty chemicals and aerospace components, said yesterday that its net income fell nearly 48 percent in the fourth quarter, as sales from some specialty chemical products were hurt by higher costs for petrochemical-based raw materials.

title: Everyone but Oil Companies Is for Cleaner Gas; What Is Spilled
description: To the Editor:

title: Rubbermaid Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represented net sales.All figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Eldon Industries.

title: L.S.U. Routs Kentucky As O'Neal Dominates
description: Shaquille O'Neal scored 33 points and Louisiana State got 35 points from its bench tonight to beat Kentucky, 107-88, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Administration Presents Its Plan For Broad Overhaul of Banking
description: The Bush Administration today formally presented its plan for the most sweeping overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Great Depression.

title: Temple U. Reaches an Accord With Professors Who Struck
description: Temple University reached a tentative contract agreement on Monday with the union representing professors who went on strike for 29 days last fall.

title: What a Neighborhood In Philadelphia Did
description: To the Editor:

title: RJR Nabisco's Losses Are Slashed
description: Two years after it emerged from history's largest leveraged buyout, RJR Nabisco has made significant progress toward becoming, as one analyst put it, "just another operating company."

title: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from continuing operations of $ 62 million and an extraordinary loss of $ 75 million.c-Included a loss from continuing operations of $ 462 million and an extraordinary gain of $ 33 million. The extraordinary gain reflected a pre-tax gain of $ 220 million on the repurchase of certain debt on the open market, the writeoff of deferred financing fees aggregating $ 79 million and potential income taxes of $ 108 million on the entire recapitalization program.d-Included a loss from continuing operations of $ 138 million and a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6 million.e-Included a loss from continuing operations of $ 1,172,000,000 and income from discontinued operations of $ 23 million.The 1989 year included the results of RJR Nabisco Inc. from Jan. 1, 1989 through Feb. 8, 1989, when the company had a loss from continuing operations of $ 197 million, with a net loss of $ 173 million, after income from discontinued operations of $ 24 million, on sales of $ 650 million.

title: Lakers' streak Reaches 16
description: Magic Johnson returned to the lineup with 22 points and 13 assists in slightly more than a half as the Los Angeles Lakers ran their winning streak to 16 games with a 116-102 victory over the Clippers tonight.

title: ISRAELIS SLACKEN CURFEW ON ARABS
description: The army today began loosening the harshest and longest curfew ever imposed in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, but warned Palestinians that they would be sent back into their homes if they continued demonstrating support for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Marketing Campaigns Receive Top Honors
description: The 13th John Caples International Awards were presented in New York last night, recognizing the best direct-marketing campaigns of 1990.

title: BASEBALL  Morris Finally Receives His Chance With Twins
description: Jack Morris, whose 162 victories were the most by any major league baseball pitcher in the 1980's, finally overcame an obstacle-strewn road out of Detroit yesterday and moved to Minnesota four years after he first tried to join the Twins.

title: Life's Small Problems Inspire Donations to Neediest Cases
description: A few months ago, Linda D. Boatti's 5-year-old son contracted bronchitis. She gave him a liquid antibiotic, but the boy could not tolerate it. A few hours later, she bought chewable tablets, and the problem was brought under control.

title: In the Table-Flat Land, Sand, Wind and Flies
description: Across the northern desert of Saudi Arabia, tons of war materiel and men are pouring into the front lines along the border with Kuwait and Iraq.

title: Fearing Loss of U.S. Money, Capital Council Kills Gun Law
description: The District of Columbia Council repealed the nation's toughest ordinance against anti-assault weapons today after Congressional critics said the measure threatened a special $100 million payment the city is seeking from Congress.

title: Browns Hire Belichick For Head Coaching Job
description: Bill Belichick left the security of the Super Bowl champion Giants yesterday to become the National Football League's youngest head coach, taking over the moribund Cleveland Browns.

title: Waxman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $ 320,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the early repayment of debt.

title: Daily News Operating Loss
description: The strikebound Daily News had operating losses of $69.3 million in the fourth quarter and $114.5 million for all of 1990, its parent, the Tribune Company, said today.

title: Winnie Mandela Is Rebuffed As Judge Upholds a Charge
description: A judge refused today to dismiss kidnapping charges against Winnie Mandela, overruling defense claims that prosecutors failed to provide enough evidence to proceed with the trial.

title: OUTLOOK IS CLOUDY FOR AN ARMS DEAL BY U.S. AND SOVIETS
description: The once-bright outlook for completing and effecting new arms control agreements between the United States and the Soviet Union has faded as the Soviet military has reasserted its influence in Moscow, Administration officials say.

title: Wisconsin Pharmacal Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included legal expenses of $ 75,000 from pending patent litigation.

title: Edward S. Taylor, 88, a Pioneer In Aircraft Engine Development
description: Edward S. Taylor, an international authority on aircraft engines and professor emeritus of flight propulsion at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Saturday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 88 years old.

title: BUSH DOUBTS AIR WAR ALONE WILL DEFEAT IRAQI MILITARY; TOP UNITS STILL JUDGED ABLE
description: President Bush said today that he was skeptical that air power alone would drive Iraq from Kuwait and ordered his top two military advisers to visit the Persian Gulf later this week to assess whether a ground offensive against President Saddam Hussein's army would be necessary.

title: Remains of 14 Eagles Found in Oklahoma
description: The remains of 14 bald eagles have been found on the prairie north of here.

title: Review/Rock; Neil Young, Wailing and Murky
description: As smoke billowed onto the stage at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, the sounds of gunfire and explosions filled the hall. Neil Young began playing a stately guitar melody bristling with distortion, which turned into "Blowin' in the Wind"; then he sang the song, backed by his own tolling chords and Billy Talbot's bass. Red, white and blue lights played over the smoke, and a spotlight focused on a yellow ribbon that was blowing in the wind from a fan in the wings.

title: Rifle Association Backs Tough Crime Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well
description: SUGGESTING that cooks substitute canned beans for home-cooked is the kind of culinary heresy that ranks right up there with substituting frozen orange juice for fresh. Some would say it is even worse.

title: Medicare Plan: Who Would Pay More?
description: Under a proposal in President Bush's budget, more than half a million affluent elderly people would have to pay much higher monthly premiums for health insurance coverage they receive through Medicare.

title: Big Airlines Gain in Eastern Sales
description: The nation's biggest airlines appear to have strengthened their already powerful holds on various airports by scavenging the assets of the bankrupt Eastern Airlines.

title: SPS Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 5.9 million related to the consolidation and reorganization of certain manufacturing activities.c-After a loss of $ 1.5 million from discontinued operations.d-Net incomeThe latest year's loss from continuing operations included that charge in the fourth quarter of $ 5.9 million.

title: In India, Muslims Find Fair Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; 'Battered Woman's' Defense For Victims Who Fight Back
description: Each year several hundred American women kill husbands or boyfriends who they say have beaten them. Until recently most have been convicted of murder, but lately a defense has been provided in the form of the "battered woman's syndrome." This diagnosis, as described on tonight's interesting edition of "48 Hours" (CBS, 8 P.M.) by the psychologist who discovered or devised it, applies to "somebody who reasonably perceives that her life is in danger." The program's reporters visit with several women, mostly in Ohio, who are pleading the syndrome in an attempt to have their jail sentences reduced or commuted.

title: Market Place; Surprising Profits Of Futures Funds
description: SPECULATORS in commodity futures are a curious lot. They make contracts either to buy goods they do not want or to sell goods they have no intention of delivering.

title: Seven Lawmakers in Arizona Indicted in Corruption Inquiry
description: Seven prominent Arizona legislators were indicted today along with seven lobbyists and political figures on charges of money laundering, conspiracy to bribe and filing false election statements.

title: Carbide Insurance
description: The state supreme court ruled that the Union Carbide Corporation can collect insurance money for the Bhopal, India, gas disaster from the Connecticut Insurance Guaranty Association, a state body that pays claims for failed insurance companies. Three insovent out-of-state insurers were unable to pay $32.5 million in claims.

title: Darman Greeted Politely in Cautious Foray to Hill
description: Chastened by his brawl with Congress last year, President Bush's budget director appeared on Capitol Hill today for the first time since then, gave a low-key, polite defense of the President's 1992 budget, confessed earlier errors and charmed at least a few senators who had been put off by his cocky self-assurance in the past.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Behrman Capital L.P., New York, an investment partnership, has been formed by Darryl G. Behrman, who resigned as a partner of Wertheim Schroder & Co. and Grant G. Behrman, his brother, who resigned as a principal of Morgan Stanley & Co. * Barneys New York named Constance Darrow senior vice president, general merchandise manager for women's ready-to-wear. The retail chain also named Bonnie Pressman senior vice president, general merchandise manager for women's accessories and cosmetics. * Burson-Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, named Peter Vanderwicken managing director of its financial and business services sector in its New York office. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, named Marvin H. Koslow president of the company's Consumer Products Group. Stephen E. Bear was appointed senior vice president-strategic planning for that group. Richard F. Gaccione succeeds Mr. Bear as president of Bristol-Myers's products division. * Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., New York, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan Corp., named Joel L. Epstein senior vice president in charge of its Manhattan branch network. * Eddie Bauer Inc., Redmond, Wash., a subsidiary of Spiegel Inc., named Carolyn Swearengin vice president-general merchandise manager for women's wear.

title: Educators Disappointed With Bush's New Budget
description: Calling it inadequate and a replica of last year's proposals, many education groups said today that they were disappointed with President Bush's budget. The budget is likely to be a prominent topic in the questioning of Lamar Alexander on Wednesday, when the Senate begins confirmation hearings on his nomination as Secretary of Education.

title: Patancheru Journal; 300 Factories Add Up to India's Very Sick Town
description: For the last six years, Dr. Krishna Rao has watched a catastrophe unfold around him as he cares for the sick in the town where he was born 50 years ago.

title: Tracking Bierstadts: The Making of a Show
description: The phone call, when it came last May, was more than surprising. "It was remarkable," said Dr. Linda S. Ferber, the chief curator of the Brooklyn Museum. A Providence, R.I., television news reporter was calling from a car phone, trying to identify a very large 19th-century painting offered at an estate sale.

title: United Telecommunications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
To Avoid Skimming Soup
description: To The Living Section:

title: Spur Has Surgery
description: The San Antonio Spurs guard Rod Strickland underwent surgery yesterday to have a pin inserted in his right hand, which he broke in a fight outside a nightclub. Strickland, the Spurs' starting point guard, will be out indefinitely because of the injury and has been placed on the injured list.

title: Dean Jagger, Actor, 87, Is Dead; Versatile Figure in Films and TV
description: Dean Jagger, a robust and sympathetic character actor who appeared in more than 120 films over half a century, died yesterday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Woman Confesses to Killing 2 Men Along Florida Roads
description: A female drifter who investigators say killed seven male motorists has admitted killing two of the men, court records show.

title: Blast at Apartment Complex Kills 3 in Milwaukee Suburb
description: A construction accident set off a natural gas explosion today, damaging an apartment building for elderly people where three residents were killed and six injured, the authorities said.

title: HOCKEY: College Notebook; B.C.-B.U. Showdown in Beanpot
description: Jack Parker amended a coaching mistake; David Emma reached new heights; Tom Cole became the surprise hero while Harvard just sagged. Those were the key components of another hockey night in Boston, the opening of the 39th Beanpot Tournament at the Garden Monday night.

title: Contract Study Faults Awards Without Bids
description: Nearly half of New York City's $5 billion in major government contracts, from heavy equipment to social services, are awarded without competitive bidding, according to a computerized study of government contracting made public by the City Comptroller yesterday.

title: Suburbs Staggered by Cuomo Budget Cuts
description: In suburban communities around New York State, mayors, managers and town supervisors are studying Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget and using words like "stunned" and "dazed" to describe their response.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: FEB SO it's Feb again. Feb is the best time to give a party for the friends you really wanted to see over the holidays.

title: William C. Clyne; Internist, 81
description: Dr. William C. Clyne, a former staff president of St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers, died on Sunday at the center. He was 81 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Universal Security Instruments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from insurance proceeds on fire settlement of $ 1,002,078, or 29 cents a share.c-After a benefit from real estate sale of $ 615,719, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Terreri Stops 37 Shots
description: The Devils may be on their way to recovery from last month's atrocious stretch of 11 games without a victory.

title: GTE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insurance Giants No Longer Ask To Be All Things to All People
description: Some of the oldest and best-known American insurance companies have decided to abandon their all-things-to-all-people approach in favor of a narrower focus. The change could substantially affect rates for many kinds of insurance, the prices of insurance stocks and the economy in the Northeast, where the largest insurance companies are based.

title: Germans Support War Against Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Baltics and Ukraine to Get U.S. Medical Aid
description: President Bush today authorized the shipment of emergency medical supplies directly to the three Baltic republics and the Ukraine in what Administration officials called an attempt to register American concerns about Moscow's policy toward its restive republics.

title: Penguins Lose Mullen
description: Joey Mullen, a Pittsburgh Penguins right wing, is expected to miss the rest of the season after undergoing surgery yesterday to remove a herniated disk.

title: Ex-Thornburgh Aide Was Cocaine User, 3 Witnesses Testify
description: Federal prosecutors rested their cocaine-conspiracy case against a former aide to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today after jurors heard three more witnesses say they used cocaine with the defendant.

title: Davis Meets the Press
description: Darrel (Mouse) Davis was introduced as the first coach of the New York/New Jersey Knights of the World League of American Football yesterday at Giants Stadium and promised that his run-and-shoot offense would keep the excitement level high during the 10-week season, which opens on March 24 and ends with the championship World Bowl game on June 9.

title: LTV Reports Net Loss
description: The LTV Corporation said today that it lost $19.5 million in the fourth quarter because of a decline in steel earnings and a charge for a research division the company is trying to sell. The company, which has been reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since July 1986, also reported a 1990 profit of $70.9 million, down 73.2 percent, from $264.9 million in 1989. LTV's loss in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 compared with a profit of $72.3 million, or 50 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenues rose to $1.61 billion, against $1.58 billion a year earlier.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD REAGAN celebrated his 80th birthday yesterday at a black-tie party that attracted dignitaries and dollars for his Presidential library. Former Prime Minister MARGARET THATCHER of Britain was among the speakers, and MERV GRIFFIN was the host at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: One Exit Clear on Smoky Jet, Many Died in Rush to Escape
description: As smoke and flames filled the cabin of their jetliner after it crashed into a smaller plane last week, those aboard rushed to the six exits only to find one jammed shut, another blocked by flames and movement through a third impeded by two scuffling passengers, Federal investigators said today.

title: Bird Comes Back to Lead Celtics to 133-117 Victory
description: After a month on the sidelines, Larry Bird played as though he never missed a day. He showed no signs tonight of the back injury that kept him out of 14 games and reduced the Boston Celtics from mastery to mediocrity. He had 18 points, 13 assists and 9 rebounds as they beat the Charlotte Hornets, 133-117.

title: The Many Lives of a Very Common Chair
description: THE chair costs $45 at the Door Store, $59 at the Workbench, $312 at Palazzetti or $813 from the Knoll Group, and yet, to the average person, all the chairs look the same.

title: Job Security Is an Issue At Hearings on Trade
description: At the first Congressional airing yesterday of the Bush Administration's plan to break down trade barriers between the United States and Mexico, lawmakers were generally sympathetic but wary that American jobs might be lost because of lower Mexican wage and environmental standards.

title: A Sturdier Footing for the Tilt-Top Table
description: This familiar table is known by several names: tilt-top, tip-top, tripod, snap and pedestal. It came into being during the reign of Queen Anne in the first decade of the 18th century and probably reached its height of popularity in tea-swigging colonial times; hence, the additional name of tea table.

title: NOMINEE CRITICIZES SCHOLARSHIP MOVE
description: Lamar Alexander, President Bush's nominee to be Secretary of Education, said today that his first act on taking office would be to suspend and reassess the rulings the Department of Education recently made on minority scholarships.

title: After Killing Woman, Man Is Slain by Police
description: A man was shot to death by two police officers last night after he stabbed his companion to death in their Bronx apartment, the police said.

description: b-After a tax credit of $ 30.8 million, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and year.c-Net incomeFourth quarter 1990 results included tax benefits of $ 23 million from ''fresh start'' provisions and restructuring charges of $ 21 million.Year-ago fourth quarter results reflected tax benefits of $ 8 million from ''fresh start'' provisions, an after-tax gain of $ 56 million from divestitures and the after-tax restructuring charge of $ 77 million.Travelers said its results for the year 1990 included an after-tax charge of $ 21 million related principally to restructuring programs in the property-casualty businesses. ''Fresh start'' tax benefits were $ 45 million. The after-tax impact from losses due to natural catastrophes in 1990 was $ 25 million.The year 1989 reflected an after-tax restructuring provision of $ 77 million associated primarily with plans to streamline certain insurance activities and strenghen managed care operations, and after-tax gains of $ 65 million from divestitures.''Fresh start'' tax benefits for 1989 were $ 30 million. The after-tax impact from losses due to natural catastrophes was $ 86 million in 1989.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Jan. 7, about the selection of Paul Auster's novel "Moon Palace" as best book of 1990 by the French literary journal Lire, misstated the number of Americans whose works have received similar designations in past years. Mr. Auster was the third American, not the second. "Sophie's Choice" by William Styron was the second, and "The Executioner's Song" by Norman Mailer was the first.

title: S.&P. Cuts Ratings of Detroit's Big 3
description: Standard & Poor's downgraded the credit ratings of all three top domestic auto makers today, underscoring the rapidly unraveling conditions in the industry and raising the prospect of higher borrowing costs.

title: United Investors Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $ 574,000 for the quarter and $ 669,000 for the year.c-After realized investment losses of $ 475,000 for the quarter and $ 599,000 for the year.

title: Editor at Woman's Day
description: Hachette Magazines Inc. has appointed Jane Chesnutt editor in chief of Woman's Day, Daniel Filipacchi, chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday. Ms. Chesnutt, 40 years old, has been the beauty, fashion and health editor of Woman's Day. She replaces Ellen Levine, who last month was named editor in chief of Redbook, a Hearst Magazines publication.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir IAN McKELLEN, the British actor and director, went on national television Monday night to speak about gay rights and to defend his decision to accept a knighthood from the Thatcher Government. Last month, he was criticized in The Guardian by DEREK JARMAN, a film director, for accepting the knighthood from a government that he said was repressive to homosexuals. Subsequently, a letter from 18 gay theater professionals supporting his action was also published.

title: U.S. Almost Triples Estimate Of Hard-Core Cocaine Users
description: Accused of underestimating the number of hard-core cocaine abusers in the United States, the Bush Administration nearly tripled its estimate today, to 1.7 million people.

title: Violets and Voltaire
description: To The Home Section:

title: War in the Gulf; War Summary
description: ALLIES CONTINUE TO HIT GUARDS Senior allied officers argued that weeks of day-and-night bombing raids had significantly weakened Iraq's elite Republican Guards, but most said that more must be accomplished in the softening-up process before a ground offensive could begin. Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, the Pentagon operations chief, said in Washington that "there has been damage done" to the Guards, but declined to say how much. "We would like to see more damage," he added, "which is why we're continuing with the bombing campaign." IRAQ DESCRIBES CIVILIAN CASUALTIES Iraq said about 150 people, including 35 children, were killed by an allied air raid on the southern city of Nasiriya. The Government also asserted that its artillery killed 40 allied soldiers. The report of the deaths in Nasiriya overnight was by the far the highest casualty toll asserted by Iraq in a single attack since the Persian Gulf war began on Jan. 17. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon said there were no American fatalities yesterday, leaving the toll among American forces at 12 killed in action, 11 wounded, 24 missing and 8 confirmed prisoners of war. Aircraft: There were no further allied losses yesterday, the Pentagon said. Fifteen American and 7 allied aircraft have been shot down by the Iraqis so far. Those figures do not include aircraft otherwise lost on war-related missions. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Seventeen Iraqi soldiers surrendered to American units, 6 to the Marines and 11 to the Army, raising the total of prisoners of war to more than 850. Aircraft: At least 4 Iraqi fighters tried to flee to Iran, and at least 2 were shot down by American fighters in pursuit. The other 2 planes may also have been destroyed; those losses would bring the overall count in air-to-air fighting to 33 enemy planes lost, against zero for the allies. An Iraqi helicopter was also destroyed over Kuwait. A military spokesman revised the numbers of Iraqi planes taking refuge in Iran, saying 20 fled on Tuesday, not 10, and that the total now stands at 120, not 110, comprised of 95 fighters and 25 transports.

title: Chemical Waste Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for 1990 reflect consolidation of Brand Cos. following Chemical Waste's exercise of an option to acquire majority ownership of the company, which is now 55.9 percent own by the company. Fourth quarter results accordingly include a $ 108 million addition to consolidated revenues.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Espionage; 2 or 3 Agents Are Believed Killed After Rare U.S.-Syrian Contacts
description: Two or three undercover agents believed to be working for Israel in a Syrian-based terrorist group were unmasked and killed last fall, not long after the United States gave the Damascus Government information about terrorist activities in the country, several Bush Administration officials say.

title: For Troubled Girls, A Caring Refuge
description: IT sounded like a stampede, and the entire building began to shake. That is what happens in a restored farmhouse, built well over a century ago, when seven teen-age girls bound out of their rooms and gallop down the stairs to dinner.

title: South Africans Headed for Multiparty Talks
description: A conference of political parties representing blacks, whites and other racial categories to be drawn from both inside and outside Parliament is rapidly shaping up as the next step leading to negotiations that President F. W. de Klerk has proposed on the nation's future.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; ELITE IRAQI FORCES HURT BY BOMBINGS, ALLIED AIDES INSIST
description: Senior allied officers argued today that weeks of day-and-night bombing raids had significantly weakened Iraq's elite Republican Guards, but most said that more aerial attacks on the troops' positions would be needed before a ground offensive could begin.

title: Micronetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Friends, More Than Interests
description: "We have no eternal allies and we have no perpetual enemies," said Viscount Palmerston, England's Foreign Secretary, in 1848. "Our interests are eternal and perpetual, and these interests it is our duty to follow."

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "This proposal is an act of desperation to cover up the collapse of morality in this city. By allowing this proposal, our children will become nothing more than objects of illicit sex that degrades and kills their body and soul." -- Helen O'Neill of Brooklyn, arguing against condoms in the schools. [ B2:5. ]

description: Robert Morris College, encouraged by the recent successful plea by top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas, announced today that it had appealed its ban from the 1991 Northeast Conference and National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournaments.

title: Salvador E. Luria Is Dead at 78; Shared a Nobel Prize in Medicine
description: Salvador E. Luria, a biologist and physician who shared a 1969 Nobel Prize for his pioneering work in medicine and physiology, died yesterday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 78 years old.

Pilots at Northwest To Weigh Concessions
description: The pilots for Northwest Airlines have agreed to negotiate contract concessions because of the carrier's worsening financial condition.

description: Was it poor defense by the Nets tonight or Miami's incredible shooting? Was it that the Nets were weary and the Heat were rested? Or maybe the Nets just aren't much better than Miami.

description: Summers do not pass at this chic, bustling resort city on the southern coast of Uruguay without talk of beautiful women, tiny bathing suits, deep tans, visiting royalty and a night life that regularly ends at 4 or 5 in the morning.

description: Doctors have reported two more cases of suicidal behavior and suicidal fantasies that they believe can only be explained by the effects of the widely publicized antidepressant drug Prozac.

A Magazine Interested In Image
description: "AMERICAN magazines have lost their graphic inspiration," said Lloyd Lecash. "Even fashion magazines are looking very catalogue-y."

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Blistex Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., manufacturer of medicated lip-care products, named Richard K. Green president and chief operating officer. * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, named Deborah L. Talbot to head its United States private banking division. * Ford Motor Co. (Japan), a subsidiary of Ford Motor Co., named Konen Suzuki president. * Nielsen Marketing Research and Nielsen Media Research, subsidiaries of Dun & Bradstreet Corp., said John H. Costello, president of Nielsen Marketing Research USA, would assume the additional title of chief operating officer, Nielsen Marketing Research USA. * Polo Ralph Lauren Corp., New York, said that Peter Strom, who has been president and chief operating officer, would become vice chairman. In addition, Michael J. Newman will become president and chief operating officer of Polo Ralph Lauren Men's Co. and Cheryl L. Sterling will be president and chief operating officer of Polo Ralph Retail and Licensing Co. * U S Sprint, Kansas City, Mo., a unit of United Telecommunications Inc., named Chris Rooney president of its government systems division. * Walt Disney Co., Burbank, Calif., named Joe Shapiro senior vice president for administration.

title: An Elegant Facility
description: To The Home Section:

title: Key Rates
Review/Theater; Dark Time in Black Military History
description: In June 1917 the United States entered the Great War, and the American Expeditionary Forces, commanded by Gen. John J. Pershing, fought its first action. At about the same time, units of the 24th Infantry Regiment, one of only four black regiments in the United States Army, arrived in Houston and began to build a new camp on the outskirts of town.

title: Kodak Posts Improved Earnings
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, best known as a producer of photographic film, yesterday reported strong earnings for the fourth quarter and year, despite a $564 million after-tax charge to settle its patent-infringement case with the Polaroid Corporation. Most of the quarterly growth came from overseas operations.

title: Business and the Law; The Insurer's Role In Waste Cleanup
description: NO wonder insurance companies and their policyholders are waging a coast-to-coast conflict over who has to pay to clean up hazardous waste sites. By some estimates, more than $500 billion is at stake.

title: Bush Plan to Fight Infant Deaths Would Use Money Going to Poor
description: Administration officials told Congress today that they intended to finance a proposal by President Bush to combat infant mortality in 10 cities by taking money from other health programs that serve pregnant women, poor children and the homeless.

title: A Compromise For Lockheed
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, who failed to unseat the Lockheed Corporation's board last year, offered to forgo another challenge this year if he is given control of three board seats.

title: Trying to Open Up the Barnes, And Pay Some of Its Bills, Too
description: Its famous collection of paintings must be worth hundreds of millions of dollars, but the budget from the Barnes Foundation's $10 million endowment barely covers the cost of keeping open its deteriorating galleries for a few days each week. Responsibility for the institution's governance belongs to a small predominantly black university whose own $6 million endowment is smaller than the value of many of the roughly 170 Renoirs and 55 Cezannes in the collection.

GTE reported earnings of $413 million, or 61 cents a share, on revenues of $4.74 billion, compared with after-tax profit of $392 million, or 58 cents a share, on revenues of $4.63 billion a year earlier. Contel reported fourth-quarter earnings of $59 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenues of $898 million, compared with earnings of $84 million, or 53 cents a share, on revenues of $831 million a year earlier.

title: Politely Evicting a Worrisome Guest
description: ANYONE who speaks of "my garden" is guilty of an act of hubris, for much more lives in gardens than gardeners and the plants that grow there. From viruses and nematodes on up, the plot I tend teems with life, some of it welcome, some not.

title: EX-NAVAJO LEADER DRAWS A JAIL TERM
description: Peter MacDonald, the former tribal chairman of the Navajo Nation, was sentenced today to 450 days in jail for bribery, fraud, conspiracy and ethics violations in the tribe's purchase of a ranch.

title: After Many Hours and Miles, L.I. Boy Is Rescued From Kidnappers
description: A 14-year-old boy from the North Shore of Long Island was rescued at dawn yesterday from a Queens apartment, 55 hours after two masked men wielding a gun barged into his family's house on Sunday night and kidnapped him.

title: Hess's Stores Names Chief
description: Robert O'Connell has been named chairman and chief executive of Hess's Department Stores, the 73-store chain owned by the Crown American Corporation, effective Monday, Frank J. Pasquerilla, Crown American's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Tricks, Miracles and Consequences
description: The Miracle Game By Josef Skvorecky Translated by Paul Wilson. 436 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: School Board Reappoints Dismissed Counsel
description: In a mildly contentious prelude to a tumultuous day at the New York City Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, the board voted yesterday to reappoint as its counsel a lawyer whom the board's president had dismissed.

title: Earnings Fall At Travelers
description: After taking a beating in the real estate market, the Travelers Corporation today reported a 14.4 percent drop in net income in the fourth quarter and posted the first yearly loss in its 127-year history.

title: Personal Health
description: The skin, a person's most extensive and obvious organ, is often a window to health problems hidden within the body and mind. By reading the skin's signals correctly, physicians can sometimes obtain early clues to serious physical ailments or help patients avoid futile treatment for emotionally triggered skin problems.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Labor Board Mess
description: Light work and high pay may help explain why Theresa Hammer clings to her job as a New York State Labor Relations Board Commissioner more than a year after Gov. Mario Cuomo demanded her resignation for official misconduct. Harder to understand is Mr. Cuomo's refusal to initiate a removal proceeding.

title: Haiti Buoyant on Eve of Inauguration
description: With hundreds of people cordoning off neighborhoods to clean littered streets, whitewash walls and paint curbstones in bright yellow, Haitians prepared today for the inauguration on Thursday of the country's first democratically elected president.

title: Not Using Fossil Fuels Could Add to Warming
description: Efforts to head off a predicted global warming by reducing the burning of fossil fuels, as is widely being urged, could actually worsen the warming in the short run, scientists say.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Is Reported On Loans to Accountants

The bank later failed, and became one of the nation's most costly bailouts.

title: Behind Ivy, Architects' U.S. Mecca
description: MAJOR American cities may compete for architectural superiority, but the town of Princeton, N.J., is arguably in the running. Its buildings represent a microcosm of American architecture, dating from the founding of Princeton University in 1746 through the present.

title: Valmont Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Eruption at Mount St. Helens
description: Mount St. Helens shot a plume of steam and volcanic ash 18,000 feet into the air on Tuesday, but it was not expected to be a hazard, scientists said. Rick Benson, research scientist at the University of Washington's Geophysics Laboratory in Seattle, said the plume above the 8,366-foot volcano quickly began dissipating. The mountain in southwestern Washington erupted on May 18, 1980, reducing its elevation by 1,300 feet, leveling 230 square miles of trees and leaving 57 people dead or missing.

description: The Energy Department has completed a three-year environmental review of the superconducting supercollider and determined that its 54-mile underground tunnel will have a minimal effect the environment.

title: Leonard Risks Filling A 'Void'
description: As a teen-ager, he watched televised fights that emanated from Madison Square Garden, notably Ali-Frazier I nearly 20 years ago. He later sat at ringside there as a Home Box Office analyst. But he has never hopped up the steps into the ring there, never took off his robe there, never heard the ring announcer there intone, ". . . and the winner is, Suuugaaar Raaay Leonard."

title: Offer of Free Voyage in Space Sends 2 on Trip to Texas Jail
description: Two founders of a company that is offering Americans a free ride on the Soviet space station were arrested here today and charged with operating an illegal lottery.

description: The Administration's proposed limits on Federal deposit insurance coverage indicate that the learning curve in Washington remains disturbingly flat. Those in the Administration arguing that deposit insurance caused the mess in the nation's financial system must also believe that health insurance causes cancer.

description: A large-scale search by air and sea today failed to locate a Greek Air Force C-130 military transport plane a day after it went down in stormy weather in a rugged eastern mountainous region. Sixty-six members of the military were aboard.

title: Reviews/Music; Sawallisch Conducts
description: Wolfgang Sawallisch's guest-conducting connection with the Philadelphia Orchestra goes back nearly a quarter of a century, but his appearance at the head of the orchestra on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall aroused unusual interest. The tall, graying German musician is scheduled to become the Philadelphia's next music director, succeeding Riccardo Muti in 1993. Judging by the alert and energetic playing that this tradition-rich ensemble delivered, Mr. Sawallisch must be a popular choice in the ranks.

title: Perfume Bottles for Eyes, Not Noses
description: GEOFF ISLES, a Manhattan glass artist, held a graceful perfume flask with a big round stopper, designed just in time for Valentine's Day. The bottle was more than 12 inches tall, embellished with bubbles that appear to float in the clear glass and provide a shallow hollow for the scent. "It doesn't hold much," Mr. Isles admitted. But very few of his scent bottles are ever filled with perfume. "They're mainly visual," said Mr. Isles, a glassmaker for 11 years.

description: IS it the beginning of the end of the bear market? Or is it a fool's rally that will fizzle with the next grim headline from the Persian Gulf or the next disappointing statistics from Washington?

title: Son of Co-Founder Named President of Sturm Ruger
description: William B. Ruger Jr., whose father co-founded Sturm Ruger & Company in 1949, yesterday was named president of the company.

Sir Lawrence Gowing, a Painter, Writer, Curator and Teacher, 72
description: Sir Lawrence Gowing, a painter, writer, curator and teacher who was a key figure in British art circles for many years, died early Tuesday at Charing Cross Hospital in London. He was 72 years old.

title: Yugoslavia Returns 368 Escapees to Albania
description: Faced with rising numbers of Albanian asylum-seekers and the increasing reluctance of Western countries to provide ultimate sanctuary for such people, Yugoslav authorities last week began forcibly handing over escapees from Albania to that country's Communist Government, which has reportedly imprisoned returned escapees for up to three years.

title: HDR Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Texas Town Rejects Tradition With Vote to Spurn Football
description: Residents of this rural community just west of Fort Worth have done the unthinkable in a state where even cotton, cattle, chili and crude oil take a back seat to high school football -- they have voted not to play the game.

description: A Hong Kong official says that efforts by the United Nations to persuade Vietnamese to stay home are having some effect in limiting the flow of boat people, especially from northern Vietnam.

title: Miscellany
description: * Time Inc. Magazine Co. has formed a new division to market its global facsimile network. The network enables the transmission of pages via satellite and fiber-optic circuits to 19 printing sites throughout the world. * Two Northern California advertising agencies, Hayes, Davidson Inc. and Orlie, Hill & Cundall, both of Sausalito, merged to form Hayes Orlie Cundall Inc. with annual billings of $4.5 million. * Career Projections Inc., New York, a recruitment specialist for the advertising and public relations industries, changed its name to O'Hare & Associates. * Publicis-FCB, the European network of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., signed exclusive agreements with two Eastern European advertising agencies, Mertis in Prague and Estra in Warsaw.

title: Ashton-Tate Posts Deficit
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation today reported a loss for the fourth quarter and year that ended on Dec. 31. The company, which is based in Torrance, Calif., said its fourth quarter was profitable before a special provision for pending shareholder lawsuits.

title: Editorial Notebook; Washington D.C. Caves on Guns
description: As one of his final acts in office, Mayor Marion Barry of Washington D.C. signed a law designed to curb military assault weapons in an indirect way. Now his successor, Sharon Pratt Dixon, has ditched the law in a cynical sellout that challenges legislatures in New York and other urban states.

title: Fay's Is Acquiring Rival Drug Chain
description: Fay's Inc., a regional drugstore chain, said it was acquiring the Carls Drug Company for an undisclosed amount of cash. Carls, based in Rome, N.Y., was founded in 1939 by Carl A. Panasci. Fay's was founded in 1958 by Mr. Panasci's brother and nephew.

title: Strange Hones Talent As Gamez Takes Lead
description: Curtis Strange has reached the point in his career where his real goals are major championships. But to get to the point where he thinks he can be a threat in those events, Strange is on a crusade to play well every time out.

description: Regarding the latest year's per share earnings, United Federal completed a conversion/merger with Founders Federal Bank of Williamsport in November 1990. description: New Government efforts to refocus the space program are rippling through the aerospace industry. While they are brightening the prospects for makers of unmanned rockets, the evolving changes are clouding the future for building space shuttles and forcing a scaling back of other programs like a space station.
