description: * Alan Chalfin and Mark Silveira joined BBDO New York, a division of BBDO Worldwide Inc., as creative directors and senior vice presidents, and Philippe Krakowsky joined BBDO Worldwide as director of corporate communications. The agency also named five new vice presidents: Vicki Halliday, Gretchen Hofmann, Linda Kligman, Guy McCarter and Douglas Russell. * Daniel J. Albert and Robert N. Georgalas have been named vice presidents of Leo Burnett Co., Chicago. * Colleen O'Sullivan Boselli has been named a vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide Inc.She is an account supervisor in the Chicago office. * Bob Murphy has been named senior vice president-creative at Waring & LaRosa Inc., New York. * Robert Roark has been named vice president and director of marketing and advertising services for the Kamber Group, Washington. * Kelly Lane and Noreen Gannon were named associate producers at Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago. * Peter Winter has been promoted to senior vice president of product and market development at the Newspaper Advertising Bureau Inc., New York. * George Santiago has been named a New York advertising sales representative for Better Homes and Gardens magazine.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) -- Agreed to terms with Billy Hatcher, outfielder, on a two-year contract, and Chris Sabo, third baseman, on a one-year contract.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: KNOWING when and how to help your children with their school projects and homework is as much an art as a science. The things they learn from your involvement often have more to do with their self-image and your relationship than with the topic of the assignment. Ideally, by working together, you can help improve their skills and reinforce the value you put on academics. But trying to help can backfire. Some approaches may do more harm than good.

title: Colonial Investment Grade Municipal Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income represented net investment income.As of Dec. 31, net assets in the latest period was $ 124,871,000, or $ 10.85 a share, compared with $ 126,856,000, or $ 11.02 a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: Regrets Only
description: It's often used as a sour quip, the sentence "Hindsight is always 20-20," a dismissive remark, a coda. But then you see hindsight with tears in its eyes, and realize that perhaps this is one of our greatest tragedies, that our mistakes become clear to us only when we see them over our shoulders, trailing us like an ugly dog.

title: Wolfpack's 3-Pointers Turn Back Tar Heels
description: Rodney Monroe scored 23 of his 37 points in the second half as North Carolina State unleashed its 3-point shots on North Carolina and held on for a 97-91 Atlantic Coast Conference victory tonight.

title: Male Chauvinism on the Wing
description: A passenger got off a plane and took a later flight from Phoenix to Seattle rather than fly with a female pilot, an Alaska Airlines official said. Lou Cancelmi, assistant vice president for corporate communications, said Alaska Airlines Flight 603 had taxied a few feet from the gate on Sunday when a male passenger learned that the pilot was a woman and asked to be let off. "They dropped the stairs, let him out on the tarmac and unloaded his baggage," Mr. Cancelmi said. He did not identify the passenger or the pilot.

title: U.S. Gives Trade Rights
description: President Bush on Monday restored duty-free trade privileges to Chile, Paraguay and the Central African Republic as a result of improved human rights practices.

title: Don't Take Hussein's Bait
description: It is virtually certain now that allied ground forces will be called upon to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The only question is when, which is what Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are going to Saudi Arabia to figure out.

title: Harsco Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; Israelis Continue Raids in Southern Lebanon
description: For the second day in a row, the Israeli Air Force struck guerrilla targets in southern Lebanon today, and the Lebanese Army moved into the area for the first time in 13 years to extend the authority of the central Government.

title: U.S. in Top Form for World Freestyle Ski Races
description: The world Alpine ski championships ended last Sunday in Saalbach-Hinterglemm, Austria, but another world championship competition is about to begin. The world freestyle championships will be held at Whiteface Mountain, near Lake Placid, N.Y., from Sunday until Feb. 17.

title: Lawmaker's Condition Critical
description: Representative Silvio O. Conte, the only Republican member of Massachusetts' Congressional delegation, was listed in critical condition today after a second round of surgery to remove blood accumulating in the right side of his brain. The 69-year-old lawmaker, a member of Congress since 1959, had an operation over the weekend to remove a blood clot, and took a turn for the worse on Tuesday. He was first hospitalized Friday after he lost feeling in his left hand.

title: GWC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in earnings primarily to a $ 3.9 million decline in other income from the sales of utility and non-utility assets. Although operating income during the fourth quarter increased $ 1.8 million, primarily due to increased utility revenues, other income decreased $ 4.4 million.

title: Ranger Rookie's Joy Erased by Death of Father
description: After the Rangers beat the Islanders by 5-2 at Madison Square Garden last night, several reporters waited outside the locker room to interview Tie Domi.

title: China Tries Another Student for Protests
description: A court put a physics graduate student on trial today on charges of "conspiracy to overthrow the Government." It was the second day in a row that a Tiananmen democracy advocate has faced charges that could ultimately lead to a death penalty.

title: Big Fight on the Ropes
description: Is the April 19 heavyweight title fight between Evander Holyfield and George Foreman in danger of being postponed?

title: Kiam Apologizes After Joking About the Olson Incident
description: Victor Kiam, the owner of the New England Patriots, the team that was fined $50,000 by the National Football League on Nov. 27 after players sexually harassed a female reporter, apologized yesterday for joking about the incident at a sports dinner Monday night.

Dow Rises By 42.57, To 2,830.94
description: Stocks rallied briskly yesterday for the third day in a row as investors scrambled to pour more money into what many on Wall Street see as the start of a new bull market.

title: Fairmont Hotel Goes Outside Family for Chief
description: For the first time in its 45-year history, the Fairmont Hotel Company has gone outside the founding Swig family for a president and chief executive. Yesterday, Fairmont named Robert Small, executive vice president of the Walt Disney World Resort division, to the post, effective March 1.

title: First-Night Echoes: Torment of Moving
description: THE elevated-train trestle outside the window might have been a hint. Nancy Hume remembers noticing the track, a scant 100 yards away, and even watching the train go by on the day she and her fiance, Peter Morse, decided to rent a sunny loft in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. On the first night there, however, as the F train rattled past her pillow, she recalls thinking, "This is a terrible mistake."

title: Review/Cabaret; Marilyn Sokol's Way With Guilt
description: Marilyn Sokol has a dangerous conspiratorial grin and a fondness for Tin Pan Alley esoterica that are very much in the modern vaudeville tradition of Bette Midler.

title: Review/Piano; Chance Is a Star at a Debut
description: Looking back at the hundreds -- perhaps thousands -- of independently produced debuts at Weill Recital Hall over the years, one surveys a smooth plain of competence interrupted by scattered indentations of mediocrity and, very rarely, a promontory offering something beyond the ordinary.

title: Wagner Butler Shoots Wife and Kills Himself
description: A butler shot his wife in the head and then committed suicide on the top floor of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner's Upper East Side brownstone home, the police said yesterday.

description: Evoking Islamic faith and Arab honor, King Hussein of Jordan abandoned his professed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war tonight to align himself with Iraq.

N.L.R.B. Finding Accuses News
description: The Daily News engaged in unfair labor practices that caused the union representing its deliverers to strike, the acting regional director of the National Labor Relations Board charged yesterday in a complaint.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For the Saudi Fallen, Martyrdom; To Their Families, Hefty Benefits
description: In the United States, those killed in the war against Iraq have been considered patriots who sacrificed for country. In this ancient desert land, they are instead revered martyrs for Islam.

title: Salyut 7, Soviet Station in Space, Falls to Earth After 9-Year Orbit
description: After nine years in orbit, the abandoned Soviet Salyut 7 space station re-entered the earth's atomosphere in a fiery show over Argentina last night, American officials said.

title: Nuclear Support Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said these figures do not reflect two new lines of businesses that were purchased from Westinghouse Electric Corp. and any income statement impact resulting from the transaction, completed Jan. 7. The fiscal second quarter will be the first and likely preliminary indication of the effect of the transaction.

title: Skinner Backs Sales by Pan Am
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner conditionally approved the sale of several trans-Atlantic routes held by Pan American World Airways to United Airlines.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included pretax charge of $ 8.2 million due to provisions for the settlement of litigation and the write-off of an amount due related to the sale of a division.The company said results for 1990 include pretax gain of $ 1.8 million, compared with a gain of $ 5.7 million in fiscal 1989, from the sale of four operations.

title: Planners' Vision of Newark Arts Center
description: A comprehensive master plan for a $200 million arts complex near Newark's troubled central business district was made public today by the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.

title: Nynex Ties Commercial to Gulf War
description: As many marketers try to avoid the appearance of exploiting the Persian Gulf war, the Nynex Corporation is swimming against the tide. The telecommunications company is scheduled to start an advertising campaign today that was created specifically to run alongside war-related television news.

title: Trying to Carry the Winning Torch
description: Bill Belichick has left the security that comes with being an assistant coach on a Super Bowl champion to join a troubled team as a head coach. In doing so, he became part of a surprisingly small number of assistants who have tried -- and failed -- to take success with them from a title team to a loser.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; IRAQIS SEVER TIES WITH SIX NATIONS
description: The Baghdad radio reported today that Iraq was severing diplomatic relations with six allied countries, and Iraq reported that about 150 people, including 35 children, were killed by allied bombing in a southern city.

title: State Labor Official Faces Investigation
description: A New York State Labor Relations Board Commissioner who has defied a demand by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that she resign is being investigated for possible misconduct in office, a spokesman for District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said Tuesday.

title: The Rich Get Richer In Recruiting Derby
description: Notre Dame thinks it has a replacement for Rocket Ismail, who opted for the professional ranks. Despite losing Coach Dick MacPherson to the pros, Syracuse was able to sign all 21 of its top recruits for Paul Pasqualoni, the new coach. Tony Dorsett's son, Anthony, signed to play as a wide receiver or defensive back with Pitt, and Florida State laid claim to taking both the top-rated offensive and defensive players.

title: Gorbachev Sees Threat to Soviet Status
description: Warning that the Soviet Union's reputation as a superpower was at stake, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tonight appealed to the nation to doom the separatist republics to failure by strongly supporting him in his March 17 referendum on the necessity of preserving the country.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. Inc., New York, will acquire Revere Travel Inc., Lawrenceville, N.J., for undisclosed terms. * Asarco Inc., New York, a metals company, and M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an Australian metals company, said they were exploring a possible joint venture in the lead-acid battery recycling business in the U.S. * Aspen Imaging International Inc., Lafayette, Colo., a maker of computer printer cartridges, will buy all the assets of Ikselah Corp., a maker of toner for laser printers and copiers, for undisclosed terms. * Broken Hill Proprietary Co., Melbourne, Australia, owner of about 50.1 percent of Hamilton Oil Corp., Denver, said it had presented a proposal to acquire 100 percent ownership of Hamilton for $40 a share. * Diamond Shamrock Inc., San Antonio, a petroleum refiner and retailer of gasoline and automotive products, said it would re-enter the ammonia marketing business by reopening an ammonia plant later this month. * Ford Motor Co. of Australia, Sydney, said it would temporarily halt production because of slow sales. * W. R. Grace & Co., New York, a specialty chemicals company, said its Grace Specialty Chemicals Co. unit had acquired A. A. Consultancy and Cleaning Co., a British supplier of specialized water treatment services. Terms were not disclosed. * Haagen-Dazs Co., Woodbridge, N.J., a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, introduced a low-fat, low-calorie frozen yogurt. * Northern Telecom Ltd., Mississuaga, Ontario, a telecommunications company, is laying off 122 employees from its transmission hardware assembly plant in Winnipeg, Manitoba, effective May 17. * Systemhouse Inc., Arlington, Va., a systems intergration firm, has been awarded a $270 million, 11-year contract from the Postal Service to provide and operate a comprehensive tracking, tracing and inquiry service for mail.

title: Tough Questions for Darman on Aid
description: Richard G. Darman invited the House Budget Committee today to work with him to develop income standards that would limit Federal aid to some well-off recipients.

As the column said, one Macintax program is for the Apple Macintosh and the other is for computers using the Windows operating system.

title: U.S. Experts Try to Estimate AIDS Infections by Doctors
description: Federal health experts estimated yesterday that as few as 13 or as many as 128 Americans have been infected with the AIDS virus either by their dentists or surgeons.

title: For Dinosaur Extinction Theory, A 'Smoking Gun'
description: After more than a decade of global searching and spirited debate, geologists say they have found the clearest evidence yet that a massive object from outer space smashed into Earth 65 million years ago, at the time of the mass extinction of the dinosaurs and many other forms of life.

title: A Gang of Six at the U.N.
description: No finer compliment has been paid Human Rights Watch than for its application for consultative status at the United Nations to be rejected. It was blocked by a minority of a 19-member committee that has to decide unanimously which private groups should be allowed to address U.N. committees and circulate staff papers. America's largest, most wide-ranging human rights organization was found wanting by six flagrant rights abusers: Cuba, Iraq, Syria, Libya, Algeria and the Sudan.

title:
CURRENTS;
In Honor of Architects Standing the Test of Time
description: ARCHITECTURE has never been considered a young man's profession. Nor a young woman's. Most architects are not fully established until they are well into their 40's.

description: The Household Finance Corporation, a unit of Household International Inc., a financial services company, is offering $150 million in five-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

description: b-Net incomeThe 1990 results included a pre-tax special charge of $ 25 million which represents a provision for the planned disposition of the missiles and electronics group's defense electronics business.The 1989 results included a pre-tax special charge of $ 30 million to reflect the writedown of costs related to the flexible composites center of the aircraft products group.The company said the loss for the fourth quarter primarily resulted from a $ 69.5 milliion decline in steel earnings and a $ 25 million special charge for the planned disposition of the company's defense electronics unit. In addition, minor earnings declines were experienced by the aircraft products and the energy products operations.

title: Chrysler May End Grand Wagoneers
description: The Chrysler Corporation may stop producing luxury Jeep Grand Wagoneers next year because declining sales have made it unprofitable to continue building the $29,000 vehicle. Chrysler sold 334 Grand Wagoneers in December, less than half the 776 sold in December 1989.

title: Danny Thomas, 79, the TV Star Of 'Make Room for Daddy,' Dies

He said the allied war effort was "against all Arabs and all Muslims and not against Iraq alone" and was aimed at asserting "foreign hegemony." But he did not back up his fervor with any concrete offer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl Gains in Milan Top-seeded Ivan Lendl needed more than two hours to win a service battle with Magnus Larsson yesterday and earn a second-round berth in the Milan Indoor tournament in Italy. Lendl broke Larsson's serve in the final game of each set for a 7-5, 7-5 victory over the 20-year-old Swede. Lendl, ranked third in the world, takes on Cristiano Caratti of Italy, a surprise quarterfinalist at the Australian Open, in the second round. Aaron Krickstein and Jakob Hlasek, both one round ahead of Lendl, advanced to the quarterfinals. Krickstein, seeded sixth, got an easy trip to the final eight when his French opponent, Thierry Champion, defaulted because of a sudden illness after losing the first four games. Hlasek, seeded fifth, survived a third-set scare before downing Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-3, 0-6, 6-4. In other first-round action, Eric Jelen of Germany defeated Christo van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-4, 6-2, while Jan Gunnarson of Sweden downed Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Curren in Quarterfinals: Kevin Curren advanced to the quarterfinals of the Volvo-San Francisco tournament yesterday with a victory over Luis Herrera of Mexico, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2. In other first-round play, Darren Cahill and Wally Masur, both of Australia, and Ramesh Krishnan of India all advanced. Cahill, seeded No. 6, brushed aside Thomas Hogstedt of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2. Seventh-seeded Masur stopped Brad Pearce, 6-1, 6-4. Krishnan needed two tie breakers to eliminate Finland's Aki Rahunen, 7-6, 7-6. (AP) Appelmans and Reggi Win: Top-seeded Sabine Appelmans of Belgium and Raffaella Reggi of Italy, who is seeded second, won their opening-round matches yesterday in the Oslo Open women's tournament. Appelmans defeated Andrea Mueller of Germany, 6-1, 6-3. Reggi defeated Sandrine Testud of France, 6-1, 2-6, 6-4. Cecilia Dahlman of Sweden, seeded eighth, eliminated Sabine Lohmann of Germany, 6-1, 7-6. (AP) N.H.L. Whalers Rout Oilers Ron Francis's power-play goal led a four-goal third period as Hartford defeated Edmonton, 5-1. Francis's goal, his 800th career point, broke a 1-1 tie 6 minutes 53 seconds into the third period. The Whalers had scored only 8 goals in the previous 14 periods. The Oilers, who lost, 6-5, in overtime in Boston on Tuesday, got their only goal by Kevin Lowe at 10:10 of the second period. (AP)

description: In a region whose political bazaar rarely fixes absolute prices and where reality is filtered through emotional perceptions, King Hussein has taken two gambles by aligning himself with Iraq.

The program, called Barbie for Girls, includes new lines of furniture, girls' apparel and other products linked to Barbie.

description: Defense Minister Michel el-Murr said today that Lebanese Army troops deployed in the south would seek to prevent the launching of rockets against Israel and oust gunmen from the region.

title: Aryness Wickens, 90, Economist Who Developed Major Cost Index
description: Aryness Joy Wickens, an economist and statistician who played the crucial role in developing the Government's cost-of-living index, now the Consumer Price Index, died last Saturday at the Lakeland Health Care Center in Jackson, Miss. She was 90 years old and lived in Jackson.

title: CHRONICLE

His father is an investment adviser, a New York State Republican Party leader and the President's younger brother.

title: Thermedics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
In East Africa, U.S. Cuts Diplomatic Presence
description: Across East Africa, the United States has moved to ward off terrorist attacks as a result of the Persian Gulf war. After incidents of violence and threats by Muslims sympathetic to Iraq, Washington has closed its embassy in the Sudan, evacuated officials in Tanzania and increased precautions in Uganda and Kenya.

title: CHENEY FORESEES NEW SOVIET UNREST
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress today that he foresaw "continued economic decline" and "increased unrest" in the Soviet Union. As a result, he said in his exceedingly bleak assessment, the Administration may reconsider its request for reductions in military spending over the next six years.

title: New Federalism, Not So New
description: President Bush's new budget proposes to take about $15 billion worth of Federal programs, abolish them and turn the money over to the states. It's an old and seductive idea, and the nation's governors, hard pressed for cash, are understandably enthusiastic.

description: Whether inside the palace, as Shakespeare observed correctly, or in tennis, there's often little relaxation for the head that wears the crown. Just ask Boris Becker.

description: Two of the last three defendants in the Bensonhurst murder case were acquitted yesterday in another blow to the prosecution in the racially charged case.

description: Several days before their church wedding, MADELEINE GURDON and ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER were married secretly in London. A church ceremony is to be held tomorrow in Suffolk, south of London.

description: THE battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. President Bush's aim is to restore confidence in the banking system and make America's banks world leaders again.

title: TBC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At 37, Parish Doesn't Miss a Beat
description: Basketball history has shown that the game can be controlled by a big man in the middle, especially one who understands that a center, among other things, must be a defensive coordinator.

title: January Sales Data Reflect Continued Retail Weakness
description: Leading retailers reported generally disappointing results for January, creating concern over profits in the final quarter and the year as a whole.

title: Saddam Hussein, Editor
description: Saddam Hussein will lose the war and may turn out to be the world's most overrated commander. Meantime, he is doing a pretty good job as an editor of American television.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Freedom Gives Germans More Room to Run
description: It seems almost unimaginable that their lives were once so structured and controlled. With their Western-style clothes, the freedom to travel, the creature comforts those in so many other countries had always taken for granted, athletes from the former East Germany are finding their lives have changed in the four months since German unification in ways they never knew possible.

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures this weekend in New York City:

title: DINKINS CRIME PLAN WINS THE BACKING OF TOP LAWMAKERS
description: State legislative leaders and Mayor David N. Dinkins reached a tentative agreement today on an ambitious and expensive anti-crime package for New York City, ending four months of arduous negotiations that have left a bitter political aftertaste.

title: Great Western Reports a Profit
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, which operates a large California savings and loan association, reported fourth-quarter net earnings today of $3.7 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with a loss of $77.3 million share in the period a year earlier.

title: A Moment of Rapture as a Saint Is Marched Home
description: Scores of priests in golden robes and thousands of believers accompanied the relics of one of Russia's most hallowed saints today on a journey back to the church from which he was hidden for more than 70 years.

title: Big Stake Holder's Chief To Be Fuqua President
description: Charles R. Scott, who has spent his career buying and developing midsize companies, was named president and chief executive of Fuqua Industries yesterday in a move to shore up his concern's investment in the company.

Muslims in Paris Keep Their Counsel
description: A girl who looked about 10 years old asked timidly for a tape "to learn how to pray." A young man wearing an embroidered fez searched for a bilingual edition of the Koran, while an older man in a well-cut, European-style overcoat came to buy a prayer rug.

title: Critic's Choice
description: No doubt many fans of violin music are disappointed that illness has forced Shlomo Mintz to cancel his recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. But the Y's concert department has found an extremely promising substitute. Pamela Frank, a 22-year-old violinist who has made a strong impression in recent seasons, is to perform instead of Mr. Mintz.

title: Peddling Iran-Contra Secrets
description: The promotional material for "Opening Arguments," a book by a former member of the Iran-contra prosecution staff, promises to reveal secrets from the criminal investigation of the Reagan Administration's biggest scandal. To some extent the book delivers. But there's a serious question whether the author, Jeffrey Toobin, has any business peddling these secrets now.

title: INSIDE
description: Senators Seek Overhaul Of Intelligence Agencies Concerned that United States intelligence agencies produce timid assessments of world events and remain focused on cold war issues, leaders of a Senate panel proposed changes in espionage operations. Page A18. Standoff on Atomic Waste Bowing to a threat from Idaho's Governor, a Colorado utility says it will postpone nuclear waste shipments to a Federal storage site. Page A17. Bensonhurst Acquittals In another blow to prosecutors, jurors took only about three hours to find two more defendants not guilty in the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins. Page B1. Revolving Doors of Justice? A habitual sex offender in Washington State who finishes his prison sentence is likely to face trial for what he might do in the future. Law, page B16.

title: Jobless Drop in Europe
description: The European Community's unemployment rate was 8.3 percent in 1990, down from 8.9 percent in 1989, the community's statistics agency, Eurostat, reported today. The 1990 jobless rate was down 23 percent from a high of 10.8 percent in the 1984-86 period. Spain's 1990 rate of 16.1 percent was the highest of the 12 European Community nations. Luxembourg and Germany had the lowest rates.

title: I.R.A. Attacks 10 Downing Street With Mortar Fire as Cabinet Meets
description: Three mortar rounds were fired from an abandoned van this morning toward the offices of Prime Minister John Major in 10 Downing Street, and one exploded in the backyard as he presided over his war Cabinet. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the attack, in which three people were slightly wounded.

Ruling on Pinups as Sexual Harassment: What Does It Mean?
description: Women's rights advocates have hailed a recent Federal court ruling in Florida that the displaying of nude and pornographic pictures in the workplace can be a form of sexual harassment, and they say they hope it will prompt other employers to rid factories and construction sites of such pictures.

description: With the purchase of a new home, people often become preoccupied with interest rates and mortgage payments, buying furniture and coordinating colors in the living room. But for some, the change in residence also inspires a desire to help others and to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: I.R.A. in London: Decade of Violence
description: The Irish Republican Army has carried out many attacks in its campaign to have the British leave Northern Ireland. The last assassination attempt of a British Prime Minister was a 1984 bombing at a Brighton hotel where Margaret Thatcher was staying during a Conservative Party conference. Below are some of the I.R.A. attacks in London. 1990 Sept 27: Four pounds of Semtex, a plastic explosive, is discovered at the Royal Over-Seas League on Park Place. July 20: Bomb damages the Stock Exchange; no one is hurt. June 26: The Carlton Club, a Conservative Party club on St. James's Street, is bombed, wounding one man seriously and at least six others. June 10: Honorable Artillery Company, an army unit on City Road, is bombed. May 17: Soldier is killed and another is seriously wounded when a bomb destroys a minibus outside an army recruiting office in Wembley. May 15: Bomb buried in a flowerbed damages an army educational office in Eltham, southeast London, wounding seven. 1988 December: 106 pounds of Semtex explosive is discovered in I.R.A. "bomb factory" in Clapham. Aug 1: Inglis Barracks at Mill Hill in North London is bombed; one killed, nine wounded. 1983 Dec. 17: Car bomb outside Harrods kills 5 and wounds 91. 1982 July 20: Two members of the Queen's Household Cavalry are killed by a car bomb in Hyde Park and six army musicians are killed when a bomb explodes under a bandstand at Regent's Park. 51 people are wounded in the two attacks. 1981 Seven bomb attacks throughout the year, , including a nail bomb at Chelsea barracks that kills two people and a bomb that kills a disposal officer on Oxford Street. 1979 March 30: A car bomb kills Airey Neave, the Conservative spokesman on Northern Ireland, as he leaves the House of Commons.

title: Lancaster Colony reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Consumer credit fell at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in December, the steepest decline in nearly four years, the Federal Reserve said today. The report surprised analysts, because December is usually a busy shopping month.

title: Review/Film; Entertaining the Troops, No Matter Which Side
description: In Spain in 1938, Carmela (Carmen Maura) and Paulino (Andres Pajares) perform their music-hall act for groups of weary Republican Army soldiers. These entertainers, purveying what they optimistically call "Tip-Top Variety," are motivated by patriotism and a desire for self-preservation, though not in that order. When Carmela appears in a white toga as a symbol of the Republic, she is taking no more fervent or personal a stand than her husband does in prompting the troops to laughter by making comically rude noises. Carmela and Paulino are partisans in principle, but in fact they live mostly to entertain.

title: War Summary
description: Bombing and Waiting Continue Bombing of Baghdad continued almost nonstop as did air attacks on bridges and other links supplying Kuwait. The British commander, Lieut. Gen. Sir Peter de la Billiere, said the bombing was "minor, compared to what they've got coming." The timing of a ground assault by the allies on President Saddam Hussein's forces will be a main topic of discussion for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as they arrive in Saudi Arabia today to meet with the allied commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon reports 12 Americans killed in combat, 26 noncombat deaths, 11 wounded, 26 missing and 8 confirmed P.O.W.'s. Aircraft: A Navy FA-18 Hornet returning to its carrier crashed into the gulf. Its pilot was missing. An Army Huey helicopter crashed, killing one soldier and hurting four. Eighteen American and seven allied planes have been downed, none in aerial combat, in the war. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Neither Iraq nor the allied command has given figures on Iraqi military deaths. Almost 900 Iraqis are prisoners, including 4 who turned themselves in to a group of correspondents who directed them to an Egyptian unit. Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, visiting the port of Basra, site of Iraqi headquarters for Kuwait, said coalition bombs had blasted hospitals, houses, restaurants and other civilian sites. Aircraft: Iranian television reported that six Iraqi aircraft flew into Iran, five of them crashing with one pilot killed and another hospitalized after being ejected, and one plane landing safely. United States Air Force F-15's shot down two Iraqi SU-22 attack jets and probably another as they tried to flee the war zone. Allied sources say 134 Iraqi planes have found sanctuary in Iran, 37 others have been shot down and about 100 have been destroyed on the ground, putting more than half of the 700 combat aircraft estimated to make up Iraq's air force out of action.

title: War Brings Eerie Peace To Busiest Airline Hub
description: These days, you can find a parking space at O'Hare International Airport right by the elevators. You can walk the terminals without your bag bumping into somebody else's. You can find a seat at the gate. You can have the souvenir shops, taverns, rental car vans and just about anything else you want all to yourself.

title: Coastal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 8,200,000.

title: Lockheed Rejects Simmons Proposal
description: The stage has been set for another proxy fight for control of the Lockheed Corporation when the company rejected a proposal from the investor Harold C. Simmons to reconfigure its board. On Wednesday, he offered to stop seeking control of Lockheed if the company granted him three seats. But in a letter today directed at Mr. Simmons, Lockheed's chairman, Daniel M. Tellep, declined the offer.

title: ALLIES TO STEP UP ATTACKS ON IRAQIS IN COMING WEEKS
description: Declaring that a ground war with Iraq is now inevitable, the British commander in the Persian Gulf said Thursday that the allies planned to greatly intensify their fierce air assault on President Saddam Hussein's forces in the coming weeks.

title: New York Faces Loss of Insurers For Bond Issue
description: Next week, for the first time in many years, New York City bonds are likely to be issued without insurance backing because the Wall Street house underwriting the issue could not find an agency interested in providing it.

title: TIC International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flames End Bruins' Streak Brian MacLellan and Sergei Makarov scored less than two minutes apart late in the first period and the Calgary Flames ended Boston's home winning streak at seven games last night with a 4-1 victory over the Bruins. In their third victory in the last four starts, the Flames dominated Boston, the Adams Division leader, outshooting the Bruins by 24-9 in the first two periods and by 31-18 in the game. Tim Hunter gave Calgary a 3-0 lead late in the second period before Graeme Townshend spoiled the shutout bid by the goalie, Mike Vernon, with his second goal of the season in the third period. (AP) Canucks 2, Flyers 1: Troy Gamble turned away 36 shots as Vancouver beat Philadelphia, giving the Canucks only their third victory in 20 games. The loss was the Flyers' third in a row. The Canucks are 3-15-2 in their last 20 games. Vancouver scored first when Trevor Linden's wrist shot from the right face-off circle eluded the Philadelphia goaltender, Ron Hextall, at 6:51 of the opening period at Philadelphia. Linden leads the Canucks in points (44) and goals (24). Dan Quinn made the score 2-0 when he scored his 10th goal of the season on the power play in the final period. Quinn slipped a rebound past Hextall at 9:55. The Flyers scored at 14:33 of the third period. Norm Lacombe took a pass alone in the slot and beat Gamble for his eighth goal of the season. (AP) Canadiens 5, Nordiques 1: Guy Carbonneau set up second-period goals by Mike McPhee and Russ Courtnall as Montreal broke a tie and went on to beat the Nordiques at Quebec. Andrew Cassels, Shayne Corson and Denis Savard had the other goals for the Canadiens. The only Nordique to beat the Canadiens' goaltender, Jean-Claude Bergeron, was the Soviet defenseman, Aleksei Gusarov, Quebec's eighth pick in the 1988 draft. Gusarov got his first National Hockey League goal, tying the score 1-1 in the first period. (AP) North Stars 4, Maple Leafs 2: In Bloomington, Minn., Brian Bellows had his fourth two-goal game in the last three and a half weeks, putting him within 1 of 300 career goals, as Minnesota took a major step toward making the N.H.L. playoffs by beating Toronto. The North Stars, 5-2-1 in their last eight games, moved 11 points ahead of last-place Toronto in the Norris Division. Minnesota, 16-5-8 when allowing 3 or fewer goals, has a four-game home winning streak for the first time since winning eight in a row in November 1989. Toronto remained 3 points ahead of Quebec, the N.H.L.'s worst team. (AP)

title: Senators Proposing Overhaul Of U.S. Intelligence Agencies
description: Concerned that United States intelligence agencies often produce homogenized, timid assessments of world events and remain focused on cold war issues, the leaders of an important Senate committee today proposed a reorganization of the Government's espionage operations.

title: Ashton-Tate reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included exceptional provision of $ 8,500,000 for estimated future litigation costs and expenses related to pending stockholder class-action lawsuits for both the quarter and year.

title: TLC Beatrice International Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a loss of $ 1,572,000 for the quarter and income of $ 86,275,000, or $ 8.86 a share, for the year, from discontinued operations, primarily on sales of non-core assets. The periods also were after extraordinary charges of $ 10,489,000 for the quarter and $ 13,994,000 for the year, from writeoffs of deferred debt issuance costs on the early retirement of debt.

title: F.D.I.C. Role Questioned In Case of Failed S.& L.
description: Former regulators at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told a Congressional hearing today that their superiors thwarted for more than a year their efforts to recover large losses from the billionaire owner of a Phoenix savings and loan that failed.

title: Nine Are Killed in Collision Of Two Vessels in Argentina
description: A power boat crashed head-on into a ferry packed with vacationing retirees today, drowning at least 9 people and injuring 19, according to news reports.

title: Keating Gets Warning
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission formally warned Charles H. Keating Jr. today that it might charge him with violating securities laws in the sale of $250 million in "junk bonds" at the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which was owned by Mr. Keating's family.

title: A Giant Killer in Silicon Valley
description: A small Silicon Valley company with an unusual giant-killing strategy has emerged as one of two leaders in the race to sell computers based on the simplified chip design called RISC.

title: Review/Film; Sure, She's Pretty. Pretty Scared, Too.
description: Martin Burney (Patrick Bergin) has a successful career, an imposing glass-walled beach house and a gorgeous wife, who, at a party, wears the backless black dress that Martin recommended and smiles invitingly at him from across a crowded room. Despite this, and for reasons a film as skin-deep as "Sleeping With the Enemy" would never begin to explain, Martin is a bitterly unhappy man.

title: MIPS Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomec-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,065,000.

title: A Surprise Profit at Chrysler
description: Chrysler Corporation surprised Wall Street yesterday by posting a $31 million fourth-quarter profit in the face of plunging car and truck sales. The auto maker said it stayed in the black with a bookkeeping adjustment and by cutting costs faster than revenue fell; still, its profit was too narrow to quiet growing concerns that the No. 3 auto maker may soon face severe financial difficulties.

title: U.S. Concern: Captives' Fate In Gas Attack
description: American officials are preparing to hand out gas masks to captured Iraqi soldiers, and given the state of their Soviet gas masks this may be good news for Iraqi prisoners.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., is offering $100 million in 9.2 percent notes due in 2003 at 99.85 to yield 9.221 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Noncallable, they are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $110 million shelf offering of debt securities and warrants. * Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in floating-rate notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 to float at 55 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the three-month Treasury bill. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The issue is being sold through underwiters led by First Boston Corp. * United Telecommunications Inc., Kansas City, Mo., is offering $573 million in zero-coupon exchangeable subordinated debentures through Kidder, Peabody & Company. If held to maturity, the securities will yield 8 percent. They are priced at $308.32 per $1,000 of bonds. They are exchangeable for common shares of the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, owned by United Telecommunications, at an initial price of $36.8875 a share. Noncallable for two years and rated Ba-1 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P., the securities can be sold back to the company in the fifth and 10th years. * Xerox Credit Corp., Stamford, Conn, a unit of the Xerox Corp., is offering $100 million in 8 3/4 percent notes in due 1995 at 99.84 to yield 8.80 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P. Preferred Stock * Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, has filed for 2.85 million preferred shares. Common Stock * Health Management Associates Inc., is making an initial public offering of 2.55 million common shares at a price of $16 a share through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * National Medical Waste Inc., Nashville, is making an initial public offering of a million common shares at $6 a share through Reich & Co.

title: NO PROOF IS FOUND IN STANFORD CASE
description: The first of several Federal investigations into billing practices at Stanford University has found no proof that the university overbilled Government research agencies by as much as $200 million over the last decade.

title: Reviews/Art; He Painted the West That America Wanted
description: Albert Bierstadt is one of the more fascinating and dismaying figures in American art. His "great pictures" and "wondrous inventions," as some of his Technicolor extravaganzas of the 1860's and 70's were called, gave Easterners exactly the image they wanted of the grand and bountiful West. He may be the prototype of the American artist as hustler, social climber, market manipulator and entrepreneur. Alongside him, the huckstering and self-promoting artists of American art in the 1980's look positively benign.

title: Iowa-Illinois G&E reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: During the cold war, analysts rehearsed worst case scenarios of a Soviet attack. The debate on the gulf war lacks such a discussion. We hope any ground war replays the invasion of France in World War II, when imagination and daring overcame hazards, and casualties were held down. But this time there may be a military tragedy. Consider a scenario that argues against a ground war.

title: Jan Minkowski, 74, Engineering Professor
description: Jan M. Minkowski, professor emeritus of electrical engineering at Johns Hopkins University, died on Tuedsay at his home in Baltimore. He was 74 years old.

title: Review/Film; Steve Martin's Paean to Los Angeles
description: "L.A. Story," written by and starring Steve Martin, is the sort of film to which, in good conscience, you could send your aunt if she were the proverbial little old lady from Dubuque.

title: Long Island Lighting Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 11,680,000, or 10 cents a share.c-Net lossThe company said its 1989 loss resulted from charges to income in the second quarter. The charges were associated with the 1989 settlement with New York State concerning the controversy surrounding the Shoreham nuclear power station and with a class settlement concerning litigation.Earnings for the year ended Dec. 31, 1990 reflect the positive effect of the Shoreham settlement for the entire year while the comparable period in 1989 reflected only 6 months of the settlement.

title: Scope Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; What Constitutes An 'Exchange'?
description: MORE than 50 years after Congress adopted the Securities Exchange Act, putting the regulatory framework in place for the modern marketplace, a debate is raging among industry professionals and Government officials: Just what is a securities exchange?

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Boston, Boston, has been building a case to show that a combination with the Bank of New England, Boston, would benefit the region, The Boston Globe reported. * Davy Corp. P.L.C., London, the petroleum and chemical company, said it had sold its Davy McKee A.G. unit to Metallgesellschaft A.G., Frankfurt, for 227.5 million German marks. * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, and Polaroid Corp., Cambridge, Mass., said each would appeal a damages award in a patent-infringement case. * Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., La Jolla, Calif., said it had cut its stake in Cummins Engine Co., Columbus, Ind., to 8.1 percent, from 14.9 percent. * Lufthansa A.G., the German airline, said it would cut 23 of its 109 weekly North Atlantic round-trip flights. * Maytag Corp., Newton, Iowa, cut its quarterly common stock dividend to 12.5 cents a share from 22.5 cents. Its year-end bonus dividend was also eliminated. * Prudential Insurance Co. of America, Newark, said about 500 jobs would be eliminated at several units.

Doctor to Test Ruling on Suicide
description: A doctor who helped a woman to commit suicide last year has pledged to test the limits of a court injunction that bars him from again using the suicide machine he developed.

Results for 1989 were restated to present the aircraft leasing business as a discontinued operation.c-Net incomed-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 700,000 for the quarter and $ 249,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $ 6,203,000 for the quarter and year relting to the company's early retirement of debt and is reflected net of income tax benefits.The latest periods' income from continuing operations included charges relating to writeoffs of airline customer receivables, which decreased earnings from continuing operations before taxes by $ 7.5 million, or $ 5 million after tax.Year-ago quarter's income from continuing operations included a gain from the sale of Insurance Management Services, which increased earnings from continuing operations before taxes by $ 20 million, or $ 9 million after tax, or 11 cents a common share.The 1989 year's income from continuing operations included that fourth quarter gain and several unusual charges that reduced pre-tax earnings from continuing operations by $ 90 million ($ 57 million after tax). These charges related primarily to changes in estimated prior years workers' compensation loss reserves and anticipated losses on the disposal of surplus vehicles.As a result of these charges, pre-tax earnings for Vehicle Leasing and Services, Automotive Carriers and Aviation Services were reduced by $ 68 million, $ 14 million and $ 8 million, respectively.

title: Knight, Cowens Among Six In Basketball Hall of Fame
description: Bob Knight, the temperamental Indiana University basketball coach who asked that his name be dropped from the nomination list in 1988, was among the six nominees named yesterday to the Basketball Hall of Fame. Knight was joined by Dave Cowens, Nate (Tiny) Archibald, Harry (the Horse) Gallatin, and the late Larry O'Brien and Larry Fleisher.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Franco-American Fiddling

title: Yankees Decide LaPoint Doesn't Fit Into Their Plans
description: Two years ago, when Dallas Green was trying to rebuild the Yankees' pitching staff, he recommended the signing of Andy Hawkins and Dave LaPoint as free agents. Hawkins, Green said, would be the anchor of the staff. LaPoint would be there right behind him. LaPoint, however, is in his last 10 days with the Yankees, and Hawkins may not last much longer.

title: Senate Confirms Martin as Labor Secretary
description: The Senate unanimously confirmed Lynn Martin as the Bush Administration's new Secretary of Labor today, praising her as a Cabinet member who would work well with Congress.

title: Malone's 25 Help Hawks To 16th in Row at Home
description: Moses Malone came off the bench and scored a season-high 25 points tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to their 16th consecutive home-court victory, a 127-114 triumph over the Charlotte Hornets.

title: Wildcats Are Upset By Southern Cal, 87-83
description: Harold Miner scored a season-high 36 points and Southern Cal defeated Arizona for the first time in 12 games, 87-83, tonight in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: Pentagon Eyes Syrian Airspace but Bush Is Wary
description: The Pentagon wants access to Syrian airspace to help wage the air war against Iraq, but the White House has declined to push Syria for permission, Administration officials said today.

title: Food Lion Inc. reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 29
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Terminal Data Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Casimir A. Rogus, 85, Sanitation Dept. Aide
description: Casimir A. Rogus, an engineer who helped build New York City's garbage incinerators and landfills, died yesterday at the Carillon House Nursing Home in Huntington, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived in Huntington and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Truckers' School Penalized
description: New York's largest tractor-trailer school was ordered closed for five days today by a state judge who found the company had allowed an uncertified instructor to train students on the road. The school, the National Tractor Trailer School in Liverpool, also was fined $200 by Administrative Law Judge Harris Gavenda, said George Filieau, a spokesman for the State Department of Motor Vehicles, which filed the charges in the case.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,371,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,518,000, or 27 cents a share, in the year.

description: In the Palaces of Memory How We Build the Worlds Inside Our Heads By George Johnson 255 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Carolina Wins Wolfpack Rematch
description: Near midnight, Chris Corchiani surveyed a raw spot on his right hip, and a deep gash below his left knee that dribbled blood down his shin and stained a white sock. He regarded the wounds proudly, as badges illustrative of his hustle and leadership in directing North Carolina State to a 97-91 victory Wednesday over North Carolina.

title: Critic's Notebook; Black Films: Imitation Of Life?
description: NAOMI is a pretty little black child living in a comfortable all-black middle-class world, untouched by the poverty of the 1930's. But she is cursed.

title: Michael Guerriero, Professor, 72
description: Michael Guerriero, professor emeritus in the department of school services at the City College of New York, died last Friday in Plantation, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Postmaster Obsessed With Mail Sacks in Flux
description: Maj. Michael H. Whitaker may have the toughest job in the military these days.

title: Affiliated Publications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30

title: For Children
description: Potato People Dalton School 108 East 89th Street Manhattan (212) 744-1649 Recommended ages: 3 to 12 Tomorrow

title: Electric Currents and Leukemia Show Puzzling Links in New Study
description: Preliminary results of a new scientific study show that childhood leukemia is not associated with normal household exposure to electromagnetic fields. But, in a finding that scientists say is baffling, the cancer is associated with proximity to power lines and the use of certain appliances like hair dryers.

title: At the Fast-Turning Hub of the Heroin Trade
description: In the stark shadows and the glare of headlights at the corner of Hunts Point and Seneca Avenues in the South Bronx last Friday night, a brand of heroin called "Tango and Cash" was selling faster than big-jackpot Lotto tickets.

title: L.A. Gear's $7.1 Million Loss
description: L.A. Gear Inc., which had warned that it would lose $4 million to $6 million in its fourth quarter, said today that the loss totaled nearly $7.1 million. In the comparable period a year ago, the company reported a profit of $11.6 million, or 58 cents a share.

title: Algerian Aiming for Mile Record
description: Of all the athletes who will compete tonight in the Vitalis/Meadowlands Invitational, none will run with higher expectations than Noureddine Morceli, the 20-year-old Algerian who was the top-ranked 1,500-meter runner in the world last year.

title: Woman in Sex-Assault Case Must Testify in Three Trials
description: A woman whom several St. John's University students are accused of sexually assaulting will have to testify in three trials as a result of a ruling yesterday by a state appeals court.

title: DIALOGUE: GROUND WAR IN KUWAIT Will Iraq Fight or Fold Its Tent?; Liberation in Less Than a Week
description: It is widely believed that the ground war in Kuwait will last months and cost thousands of American lives. This view is unduly pessimistic. The U.S. military can liberate Kuwait in less than a week and suffer relatively few casualties -- probably less than 1,000 fatalities.

title: Amax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unocal Settles Suit on Pricing
description: The Unocal Corporation has agreed to a $78 million settlement with the State of California and City of Long Beach in a price-fixing lawsuit that goes back 16 years and involves five other oil companies.

title: Adele L. Auchincloss, An Artist, 59, Is Dead
description: Adele Lawrence Auchincloss, an artist, environmentalist and former deputy administrator of the New York City Parks and Recreation Department, died on Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dinkins Seeks To Control School Board
description: Frustrated by months of conflict with educational policymakers, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would seek greater control over the Board of Education by gaining the power to appoint a majority of its members.

title: Girl, 17, Strangled at Home
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn girl was found strangled with an electric cord around her neck in the bathroom of her family's apartment last night, the police said. The body of Callandre Felder of 1351 Eastern Parkway in the Crown Heights section was found by her mother at 7 P.M., shortly after she returned home from work and discovered the door to the aparment unlocked, the police said. The victim was fully clothed and the apartment had not been ransacked. The police said no motive was apparent for the slaying.

title: Victim's Husband Testifies In Westchester Murder Trial
description: The husband of Betty Jeanne Solomon testified today in the trial of the Westchester teacher accused of killing his wife, describing his affair with the defendant and her resistance to his efforts to end it.

title: Constitutionality of a Choice for Puerto Rico's Future Is Challenged
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today challenged the constitutionality of enhanced commonwealth status for Puerto Rico, one of three choices proposed for a referendum that would also allow voters to choose statehood or independence.

title: Sony Now Has Its Eye on Orion
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan, which already owns one major Hollywood studio, Columbia, is talking to Orion Pictures about buying that financially troubled film and television company, according to people close to the discussions.

title: Review/Dance; Eliot Feld Joins the Club Of the Unpleasant Ballet
description: Jerome Robbins proved there was room for the distinctly unpleasant ballet when he created "The Cage" in 1951. Now Eliot Feld has joined the club. "Savage Glance," which had its premiere with Feld Ballets/NY on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) is a sort of "Revenge of 'TheCage.' "

title: Office Depot Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 532,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column in The Home Section yesterday about a new magazine called Push misstated the first name of the publisher and editor. He is Leon Lecash.

title: Bassett Maguire, 86, a Botanist And Expedition Leader, Is Dead
description: Bassett Maguire, a botanist who led many expeditions into nearly inaccessible reaches of Venezuela and Brazil, died on Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: KLM, After Loss, To Cut 2,000 Jobs
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it would cut 2,000 jobs in the wake of a large third-quarter loss attributed to increases in the costs of fuel and materials and losses on investments. The Dutch flag carrier said it lost 213.9 million guilders, or $130.4 million, in its third quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, compared with a profit of 58.6 million guilders, or $35.7 million, a year earlier.

title: Manhattan Doesn't Have to Suffer From Newsstand Blight
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Of Rap, Race, Decibels And a Precision Hairdo
description: Vanilla Ice is a third-rate rapper, a diligently ungraceful dancer and one of the smarmiest new pop figures in a decade of video poseurs, but he certainly has well-engineered hair. During his 90-minute set on Wednesday night at the Beacon Theater, as he self-importantly moonwalked and swiveled his hips and tried to make pushups lascivious, not a hair budged in his blond-tipped semi-pompadour. When the teen-age girls who made up at least three-quarters of the audience outgrow Vanilla Ice, perhaps he can become a mousse-company model.

title: Investigators Tell of Mix-Up in Runway Crash
description: An air traffic controller told Federal investigators today she thought the runway was clear moments before two airplanes collided on it last week, and that her first reaction was to think that a bomb had exploded.

title: Leonard Has Norris at Hand, but Hearns on the Mind
description: The man Sugar Ray Leonard will fight tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden is Terry Norris, the World Boxing Council superwelterweight champion. But if Leonard had had his druthers, it would be Thomas Hearns, not Norris, answering the opening bell.

It said 1990 results included about $ 2.8 million of profit from sales of excess warehouse and manufacturing facilities, while 1989 results include shutdown and restructuring charges aggregating $ 4.8 million, representing the estimated costs to realign several operations.

title: Health Risk Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: Representative TED WEISS was elected chairman of the -Congressional Arts Caucus yesterday. The New York Democrat, who represents the West Side of Manhattan and part of the Bronx, has been a member of the caucus since its founding in 1981. The bipartisan group, which has more than 250 members in the House and Senate, was formed on Capitol Hill to support the arts. Mr. Weiss, the group's fourth chairman, succeeds Representative BOB CARR, Democrat of Michigan.

title: Hertz Notes Priced
description: The Hertz Corporation yesterday priced a $100 million offering of notes due on Feb. 1, 1998, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers. Underwriters priced the 9 3/4 percent notes at 99.383 to yield 9.873 percent, or about 221 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable by the car rental company, based in Park Ridge, N.J., the 10-year notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

title: Renewed Fight on Futures
description: In the opening round of this year's battle over overhauling regulation of nation's futures exchanges, the top officials of two rival regulatory agencies resisted a compromise proposal.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed its nominees yesterday for election to the board of the NCR Corporation as part of its attempt to acquire the computer concern.

title: U.S. Says It Is Reviewing Aid to Jordan
description: The Bush Administration announced today that it was reviewing all of its economic aid to Jordan after a speech by King Hussein in which he seemed to abandon his professed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war and threw his support behind Iraq.

description: On an evening when Bernard King looked like he was destined to score 50 points and the Nets looked like certain losers before the first half was complete, something odd happened on the way to the apparent rout.

Inquiry Ordered Into Sewage Plants
description: New York State's top environmental official has ordered an inquiry into whether New York City must upgrade its sewage-treatment plants to reduce discharges that have polluted Long Island Sound, an undertaking that could cost the city several billions of dollars to carry out.

description: A DOZEN roses is now $40. By next Thursday, they'll be twice that!

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about changes in the insurance industry referred incorrectly to the reinsurance business of the Lincoln National Corporation, based in Fort Wayne, Ind. While Lincoln recently sold a reinsurance company, it remains in the reinsurance business.

title: Review/Art; The Surreal Extravagance of Malcolm Morley
description: Malcolm Morley still paints at top volume. His latest works, on view at the Pace Gallery on 57th Street, continue to combine something of the lush extravagance of the High Baroque with the strangeness of Surrealism.

title: TJ International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Is Slain in Turkey
description: A gunman assassinated a retired American serviceman today who was employed at an air base used for bombing raids on Iraq. A terrorist group said he was killed because of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Voice of the Pentagon Delivers Press Curbs With a Deftness Honed on TV
description: During his 10 years as a reporter-cameraman for KTWO-TV in Casper, Wyo., Louis A. (Pete) Williams once sneaked onto a restricted MX missile site to film a stand-up. Now, as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, he stands at the lectern and earnestly defends restrictions on journalists.

description: b-Net income

title: Avon to Raise Dividend Payments
description: The Avon lady may stay independent after all. In a surprise move that analysts say could help it win a coming proxy fight, Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it would increase its annual dividend 40 percent, to $1.40, and pay a special dividend of $3 a share, or more than a year's profits.

description: b-Included gain of $ 599,000, or 25 cents a share, from one of two real estate transactions completed in 1990.c-Included gain of $ 759,000, or 32 cents a share, from both real estate transactions completed in 1990.d-Included gain of $ 126,000, or 5 cents a share, from real estate transactions for the quarter and year.

title: People
description: * Janet B. Keeler and Susan C. Read were named executive vice presidents at Ayer Inc., New York. The agency also named Robert Sanchez director of new-business development at Ayer Direct, its direct response division. * John H. Griffin Jr. and Nancy Weber have been named vice presidents at McCall's, part of the women's publishing division of The New York Times Company Magazine Group. The magazine group also promoted Mary Anne Sommers, John Loughlin and Sonda Miller to vice presidents in the women's publishing division.

title: MacMillan Bloedel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: ISRAELIS STRIKING P.L.O. IN LEBANON
description: For the first time since the Persian Gulf war began, Israeli commandos ventured beyond their self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon today to raid Palestinian guerrilla bases. The Government here warned that such strikes would continue unless the Lebanese Army ejected "terrorist organizations" from the region.

title: Test for Japan's Leader; Kaifu Faces Growing Difficulty in Building A Consensus on Tokyo's Role in Gulf War
description: An extraordinary national debate over Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's pledge of aid for the war against Iraq is suddenly proving to be the biggest test of Japanese friendship for the United States in many years -- and the biggest test so far of Mr. Kaifu's ability to remain in office.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Rumpelmayer's

title: Affiliated's Profit Slips
description: Affiliated Publications Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings plunged 54 percent, largely because of declining advertising volume at its flagship newspaper, The Boston Globe. Affiliated had net income of $6.3 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $13.5 million, or 19 cents a share, in the 1989 period. Revenues totaled $139.8 million, a 6 percent drop.

title: Technical Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Robert Strunsky, 84, Former CBS Executive
description: Robert Strunsky, a former director of corporate affairs for CBS Inc., died on Wednesday at his home in Kingston, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Vital Signs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NAC Re Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the ''fresh start'' loss reserve discount boosted 1990 income by $ 400,000 and 1989 income by $ 200,000.

title: Miscellany
description: * Four senior executives at J. Walter Thompson Co., New York, will fill the new office of the chief executive, which will have operational and financial responsibility for the agency. They are: Peter Schweitzer, vice chairman for agency operations; Bill Thompson, vice chairman for client operations; Lew Trencher, executive vice president and chief financial officer, and Don Sullivan, executive vice president for worldwide planning and development. The office will report to Burt Manning, chairman and chief executive of Thompson.

title: James N. Lanzetti, Apparel Buyer, 45
description: James N. Lanzetti, a haberdashery buyer and a vice president of merchandising and design at Bidermann Industries in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: Gas Concern Prices $100 Million Issue
description: A $100 million debt issue by the Southern Natural Gas Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included results of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Arkansas acquired in June 1990, and $ 2.7 million in previously reported environmental remediation charges.c-Included $ 12 million in environmental remediation charges, a restructuring charge of $ 9.3 million related primarily to the planned standardization of the company's information systems, the establishment of incremental reserves of $ 10 million, or 5 cents a share, for potentially uncollectible trade receivable, and a one-time gain of $ 59.3 million, or 27 cents a share, from the sale of Portsmouth Coco-Cola Bottling Co. Inc., the food service vending operations in Memphis and majority interest in Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio.

title: Restaurants
description: On the capacious ethnic buffet that is New York City, Korean cuisine is only a small, inconspicuous platter. That may be because there are relatively few Korean restaurants in town or because the food remains mysterious and intimidating to the average diner. A fine introduction to this colorful and salubrious cooking can be found at Woo Chon in midtown's Little Korea along West 36th Street.

title: Worker Team Plots Purchase Of Daily News
description: As the countdown continued at The Daily News, a team that is trying to arrange an employee stake in the purchase of the paper met yesterday to lay out its strategy.

title: Stocks Fall; Volume Is Still Strong
description: Stocks fell yesterday for the first time in almost a week, but trading remained exceptionally heavy.

title: U.S.-Israeli Strains Appearing Over Delayed Housing Aid
description: Israeli officials reacted with irritated astonishment today to remarks made by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday about why Washington had not yet provided $400 million in loan guarantees for Soviet Jewish housing.

title: Roto-Rooter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carter Hawley Payment Query
description: The New York Stock Exchange said today that Carter Hawley Hale Inc., one of the nation's largest and most indebted retailers, would miss $22 million in interest payments on its high-yield bonds next week.

title: Bringing the Bill of Rights Home: A Legal Trek Across The Land By a President's Daughter
description: A generation ago, John F. Kennedy somehow managed to make people care about Lucius Quintus Cincinnatus Lamar and other, less obscure figures in "Profiles in Courage." Now, the late President's daughter, Caroline, a lawyer in New York, is helping people (and, in this week's issue, People) to care about the Constitution.

title: When Beauty Was a Duty
description: "THERE is only one hairdresser in all of Paris who can dry your hair: Gervais," reported the renowned Vogue war correspondent Lee Miller after rolling into Paris with United States liberation troops in August 1944. "He has rigged his dryer to stove pipes which pass through a furnace heated by rubble. The air is sent by fans turned by relay teams of boys riding a stationary tandem bicycle in the basement. They cover 320 kilometers a day to dry 160 heads."

title: 3 Children Die In House Fire in Brooklyn
description: Three small children were killed yesterday in an electrical fire that swept through a row house in Brooklyn. Consolidated Edison Company officials said that electricity was being illegally siphoned through a tangle of extension cords from a power box under the sidewalk.

title: Mayors Attack Bush Plan to Shift Control Over $15 Billion to States
description: The nation's mayors today denounced President Bush's proposal to give states control over $15 billion worth of Federal programs, saying it would permit governors to skim money that now flows directly from Washington to hundreds of cities around the country.

Food Lion Inc. reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 29

title: Maginot Line Wasn't Originally Defensive
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, the telecommunications company, said it would develop and operate a communications system in Moscow with Belle Mead International Telephone Inc. USA. * Child World Inc., Avon, Mass., a toy retailer, said negotiations to sell the company would continue through the weekend and into next week. * Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a data systems and services company, will sell all of its 10.7 million common shares in Seagate Technology Inc., Scotts Valley, Calif., a maker of hard-disk drives for small computers, to Salomon Brothers for $143 million. * EG&G Inc., Wellesley, Mass., a scientific and technical products and services company, will acquire a majority interest in Heimann G.m.b.H., a unit of Siemens A.G., a German electrical and electronics concern. Terms are still to be negotiated. * Johnson & Firth Brown P.L.C. has bought the Monroe Forgings business from United Dominion Industries Ltd., Charlotte, N.C., an engineering and construction services company, for $21 million. * Mercedes-Benz A.G., the German car and truck maker, has started production of its medium-range trucks at a plant in what had been East Germany. * News Corp Ltd., the Australian publishing company, led a group that sold its stake in Presstek Inc., Hudson, N.H., a printing press research and development company, at prices ranging from $13.125 a share to $13.875 a share. * Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd., Crewe, England, said it would cut an additional 230 jobs. The company had announced 340 layoffs in December. * Toyota Motor Corp., Tokyo, said it would build two new domestic production plants in Kyushu and Hokkaido, Japan.

title: CHAOS IN TOWER AT LOS ANGELES
description: An air traffic controller told Federal investigators on Thursday she thought the runway was clear moments before two airplanes collided last week, and that her first reaction was to think that a bomb had exploded.

title: Business Records Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said 1990 results include $ 1,359,000 in litigation adn contractual settlement. Also, the increased number of elections held in 1990, compared to 1989 aided in the company's improved performance.

title: Baldwin Technology Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Critic's Notebook; Tragedy Is Rewriting Avant-Garde's Agenda
description: The opening event of the annual benefit series presented by Performance Space 122 last week was like a crash course in the performance art of the 1980's. But the very forces that have rendered much of those 80's antics almost offensively irrelevant may also be toughening the avant-garde for the 90's, lending it a resonance and a seriousness it has so grievously lacked. In short, tragedy may make for better art than rampant greed and trivial hedonism.

title: Where Now? Conservatives Wonder
description: Conservatives met here this week to plot their future in a world where Communism is collapsing, Ronald Reagan is consigned to history and the current Republican President has broken with conservative dogma and raised taxes.

title: Police Question Londoners On Attack at Major's Office
description: The police scoured snow-covered streets today near Whitehall, the seat of Britain's Government, interviewing passers-by and looking for clues to the terrorist team that fired mortar shells on Thursday at the residence and office of Prime Minister John Major.

title: Editorial Notebook; Reading History on Harbor Waves
description: Much of New York City's economic history was inscribed on the salt waters that separate all but one of the modern city's boroughs from the rest of North America.

title: AIDS From A Healer, Scorn From Others
description: The disbelief, the disbelief that lingers among strangers even yet, stings Kimberly Bergalis almost as much as the disease. Two weeks after her 23d birthday, she repeats the story of how she got AIDS. She speaks in a just-the-facts monotone, until she begins to talk about the doctors, the friends, the strangers who would not believe her.

title: Mortgage Rates Decline
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.36 percent this week, down from 9.56 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The average was the lowest since April 3, 1987, when it was 9.27 percent. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.68 percent, down from 7.75 percent last week and the lowest since 7.66 percent on May 13, 1988.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Americans bought $953 million in United States savings bonds in January, the Treasury Department said today. January sales were up 15 percent from the same month in 1990, when they totaled $826 million. Last month's total was the highest for any January since 1944, when sales were $1.09 billion. Savings bond sales have increased steadily since July 1990, the Treasury said, and totaled $8.09 billion last year, 6 percent higher than in 1989. The bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 7.19 percent when held five years or longer.

description: One day within the past two weeks everybody in Washington started to say "defining." For instance, "The gulf war will be the defining event of the Bush Administration."

description: The Vancouver Canucks have always had trouble with the Rangers -- they have won only twice in the last 22 games between the teams -- but their ineptitude reached the point of ridiculousness last night at Madison Square Garden.

description: For the most part, American consumers will probably not see drastic price increases, reduced supplies or inferior quality in California fruits and vegetables in spite of the drought and state and Federal water cutbacks to agriculture, farming experts and growers' representatives say.

title:
The Sky Above, the Slick Below;
The Gulf Isn't Dead
description: With the massive release of oil in the Persian Gulf, environmentalists are shrieking that the gulf will turn into a dead sea. After all, at as much as 460 million gallons, this is the largest known oil spill in history. It is 40 times larger than the

title: Clemens Signs for More Than $5 Million a Year
description: Roger Clemens, considered by most people to be the No. 1 pitcher in baseball, became the highest-paid player in the sport yesterday. Clemens and the Boston Red Sox agreed on a contract extension that guarantees the pitcher $21,521,000 for four years, making him the first player to have a contract averaging $5 million or more a year.

description: b-Net loss and the year is after an extraordinary credit of $ 1,042,000, or 43 cents a share.
