title: Angry Panel May Seek Limit On Jail Inmates
description: A majority of New York City correction board members are threatening to take the drastic step of barring the department from exceeding the limit on the jail population, interviews with board members indicate.

title: Algerian Wins Mile With Third-Fastest Indoor Time
description: For all the peripheral annoyances, like bagpipe bands playing during high-jump attempts and announcements that football players were signing autographs in the corridors, the Vitalis/Meadowlands Invitational tonight wasn't a half-bad track and field meet.

title: Recession Is Forcing Many To Lessen Hopes for College
description: The deepening recession is forcing growing numbers of parents to reconsider plans to send their children to colleges whose tuitions they may no longer be able to afford.

title: Ewing Offers to Defer Salary to Help Knicks
description: Patrick Ewing, frustrated about the Knicks' disappointing season, made some strong statements today about his team and his future.

title: Ailing Conductor Replaced
description: Because of illness, Dennis Russell Davies will not conduct the American Composers Orchestra at its Carnegie Hall concert at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Replacing him will be Paul Lustig Dunkel, the orchestra's resident conductor and co-founder. Mr. Davies is the orchestra's principal conductor and music adviser. On the program, which remains unchanged, are the violinist Itzhak Perlman as the soloist in Earl Kim's Violin Concerto; "Wisconsin Suite" and the New York premiere of "Symphonic Fantasia No. 5," by Otto Luening; the premiere of Wayne Peterson's "Widening Gyre," and the New York premiere of Peter Lieberson's "Drala."

title: Haiti's New Leader Takes on the Army
description: Within hours of being sworn in on Thursday as President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide said that all but two of the army's eight generals would be given a "well-earned retirement."

title: Aaron Siskind, a Photographer Of Abstract Images, Dies at 85
description: Aaron Siskind, a photographer best known for his nearly abstract black-and-white pictures and a major influence on the development of postwar art photography, died yesterday at Miriam Hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Discount Rate Cut Was Urged at Meeting
description: Most Federal Reserve banks, noting "appreciable weakening in economic activity," urged a half-point reduction in the discount rate at the December meeting of the Fed's policy makers, according to minutes released today.

title: Simpson, O'Meara In a Sizzling Duel
description: Ideal scoring conditions continued to send scores plummeting here as Tim Simpson and Mark O'Meara today set a scintillating pace after three rounds of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Parallel Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Corrections
description: The At the Bar column on the Law page yesterday misidentified a Columbia University official, Jack Greenberg. He is dean of Columbia College, not the university's dean of students.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's bleak assessment of the Soviet Union's future omitted part of the third paragraph. It should have read, "Mr. Cheney's comments, in testimony before the House Armed Services Committee, were the clearest statement to date of his concern that the Soviet Union might implode and that the Administration might have to rethink Pentagon spending plans."

title: Attacks on Iraq Worry and Divide Archeologists
description: The allied bombing of Iraq, widely regarded as the richest country in archeological remains, has caused anguish and division among specialists in Middle Eastern culture, many of whom have devoted their professional lives to studying the cradle of civilization.

Quotation of the Day
description: "There will be casualties in any campaign. But the assumption that the ground campaign is Mr. Hussein's campaign and that we'll fight it his way is not necessarily an accurate one." -- Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ 6:3. ]

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Ground War; The 'Move It or Lose It' Ultimatum
description: In a rousing exhortation to airmen and airwomen, the Pentagon's top leaders today promised an early end to the Persian Gulf war saying that an American-led ground assault could draw Iraqi troops out in the open where they would be eeasier targets for American and allied combat planes.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Relief; Allies Asked to Guarantee Safe Transit on Medical Aid
description: Unicef and the World Health Organization are asking the allies in the Persian Gulf war to guarantee safe passage through eastern Iraq for a convoy carrying medicine from Iran to women and and children in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday summarizing the Bush Administration's domestic spending proposals for the 1992 fiscal year misstated the amount of an increase in spending for the Federal Aviation Administration. Spending would rise 14 percent, to $9.3 billion,not 10 percent, to $4.5 billion. The article also referred incorrectly to a spending proposal for Amtrak. That Administration request, for $485 million, is the first request in seven years for any funds for the passenger rail service, not the first in seven years for an increase.

title: Your Money; Taxes on Homes Rented Out Briefly
description: Despite the depressed real estate market, some homeowners have little choice but to put their homes up for sale. Job relocations as a result of layoffs or transfers force some to move, while for others personal or family situations necessitate a move.

William Hess, 75, Tenor and Teacher
description: William Hess, a tenor and voice teacher, died on Jan. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

description: Trying to salvage the mammoth Trump City development he has proposed for the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Donald J. Trump is negotiating with civic groups about significantly reducing the project's size.

description: "Bunch o' clowns," groused Sgt. Charles Castro, gravely shaking his head over the latest crop of rookies that division had consigned him to turn into police officers. "Wimps," he taunted them. "Don't even like to give summonses."

title: Review/Opera; At the Met, Winter Calls The Tune

This is the time of year when opera managers dread to hear the telephone ring because it is likely to mean that the traditional midseason jinx has claimed yet another singer or conductor. Sure enough, in a week that brought cancellations by two leading sopranos, Mirella Freni and Teresa Stratas, the Metropolitan Opera had also to find a substitute for Susan Dunn on Thursday evening in the first "Luisa Miller" of the season.

title: Review/Film; In Fantasia, the End May Be in Sight

It was possible to see this film in near-perfect solitude at the Gemini Twin, one of the many theaters at which it opened yesterday. That suggests the saga, again adapted from Michael Ende's 1979 novel, will not be never-ending after all.

title: The Police Plan's Ambitious Promise
description: The night of his primary victory over former Mayor Edward Koch, David Dinkins vowed to be "the toughest mayor on crime this city has ever seen." With Albany now all but certain to approve his sound program to reinforce the New York City Police Department, he makes clear that it was no idle promise. A daunting challenge remains: motivating a rock-ribbed police bureaucracy to embrace the principles of community patrol.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;
description: Benito Santiago, who more than tripled his salary by winning in salary arbitration a year ago, emerged a loser yesterday in his second effort, becoming the third player to fail to break the arbitration record Don Mattingly established four years ago. title: Guidepost; A Day of Wine and Roses
description: To the romantic -- and who isn't -- St. Valentine's Day evokes thoughts of candlelight, flowers and, of course, wine. Ah, but what wine? But of course: some romantically named wines, at $10 to $75 or more, to pour once the candles -- and you -- are glowing. Wine Description Saint-Amour One of the 10 Beaujolais permitted to bear the name of the towns from which they come. Les Amoureuses A famous vineyard in Chambolle-Musigny, in Burgundy. The wine is superb, and the name is perfect: the Lovers. Wedding Cuvee Iron Horse Vineyards in Sebastopol, Calif., in Sonoma County, originally made this elegant sparkling wine for a family marriage. Now everyone can enjoy it. Chateau Calon- Segur, St.-Estephe, Bordeaux This chateau's trademark is a heart. In the 18th century, its owner also owned Chateaux Lafite and Mouton. "I make wine at Lafite and Mouton," he said, "but my heart is at Calon." Chateau Mouton-Baronne-Philippe, Pauillac, Bordeaux Baron Philippe de Rothschild, who bought Chateau Mouton d'Armailhacq in 1933, named it Mouton-Baron-Philippe in 1956. After his wife, Pauline, died in 1976, he changed Baron to Baronne -- baroness -- in her memory. Hidden Cellars, Mendocino County, Calif. Nothing romantic about this winery's late-harvest riesling, but the grapes come from a grower named Bailey J. Lovin.

title: American Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: About New York; In Black History, Reconstruction Is Also a Struggle
description: Joan Maynard was her father's only child, born on Aug. 29, 1928, when he was 55 years old. Her father, John W. Cooper, told her stories about growing up in Brooklyn, about its churches, about the history of what became the nation's largest black community. She had a sense of where she came from.

title: Centex Telemanagement reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manufacturers Urge Big U.S. Export Push
description: Arguing that exports are the bright spot in an otherwise bleak economy, the National Association of Manufacturers is urging the Bush Administration to play a much more aggressive role in promoting the sale of American products abroad.

title: The Death Of a Prep Legend
description: Several weeks ago in Chicago, a postal worker named Paxton Lumpkin died, at age 54. The name, with its crunchy, alliterative juxtaposition of vowels and consonants, often brought a smile to a listener, just as Paxton Lumpkin, when he was a basketball player -- so clever, so deft, so joyous, dribbling low the way Groucho Marx walked but dribbling the ball as if it were simply a yo-yo in his hands -- brought a smile to the spectator.

title: Death Row Inmate Rebuffed On Plea of Forced Confession
description: A Federal district judge has rejected accusations that law-enforcement officers, including one who went on to serve in Congress, forced a man now on death-row here to confess to a 1983 murder.

title: Jones Spacelink Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 4,037,000, or 5 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,996,000.

title: Dinkins Budget Stand
description: By musing on the merits of stretching out New York City's current budget problems over several years, Mayor David N. Dinkins spoke words this week that no New York mayor had dared utter since a city humbled by its brush with bankruptcy was forced to submit to the credo of pay-as-you-go.

title: Glendale Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Brand Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 6.5 million for both the quarter and year. The charge reflects the anticipated costs of closing certain satellite offices, relocating or reassigning personnel and providing severance benefits in connection with certain management changes undertaken to realize greater integration with Chemical Waste Management Inc.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; President Increases Pressure On Jordan to Stay Neutral
description: With the Administration concerned that any change in Jordan's neutral status in inter-Arab politics would have a profound effect on the entire Middle East, President Bush stepped up pressure on King Hussein today not to join forces with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Air War; Clouds Reported to Delay Bombings
description: Bad weather has forced allied pilots to cancel more than half of their daily bombing raids on top-priority targets in Iraq and Kuwait, a senior Air Force officer said today.

title: Gundle Environmental Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Regional Primaries for President Proposed
description: Senator Alan J. Dixon introduced a bill Thursday to create eight regional Presidential primaries and diminish the influence of early voting in Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: The 51st State?
description: "I want Puerto Rico to become the 51st state," President Bush has said. Does he realize that would mean fewer Puerto Ricans in private-sector jobs, more on welfare, and a probable additional cost of $17 billion to the U.S. Treasury?

title: Southern Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $ 248,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 500,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Eagle Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
London Journal; Sipping in a Snowdrift: Numb Britons Carry On
description: For two days now, this city has been surrendered to winter, besieged by the kind of cold, snowy weather more common to Chicago than England.

title: War Summary
description: HOME FOR EASTER?

title: Bank Lending Still Tight Despite Easing by the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board's latest readings on whether banks are lending show that despite aggressive easing by the central bank recently, they continued to tighten lending standards this winter.

title: TIC International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
L.I. Hauler Sued for Dumping on State Land
description: For more than a decade a garbage hauler has illegally dumped ton after ton of construction debris on the edge of a mental hospital here, state officials say. The company, they say, even moved in heavy equipment, dug an enormous pit and started mining for sand.

title: Alfredo Machado; Leading Publisher Of Brazil Was 68
description: Alfredo C. Machado, a Brazilian book publisher who was well known in the United States and Europe, died yesterday in Sao Vicente de Paulo hospital in Rio de Janeiro. He was 68 years old.

title: Terex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Religion Notes
description: Banned in Philadelphia

title: More Cost Cutting Expected at Ford
description: A senior executive of the Ford Motor Company said the automobile maker would intensify cost cutting in response to the industry's recession but would not lower capital spending as the General Motors Corporation has decided to do. Alexander J. Trotman, executive vice president of the No. 2 car maker and head of its North American operations, declined to elaborate on how Ford would further reduce costs but said, "It's not business as usual."

title: Universal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 3.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, from receivable due from Iraqi State Tobacco Monopoly deemed non-collectible.c-After income of $ 7,984,000, or 47 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change relating to the adoption of FASB 96 ''Accounting for income taxes.''

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on Tuesday depicting the human hair mislabeled one element. A part extending to the right of the hair shaft was the sebaceous gland, not the hair bulge.

title: KRU International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Home Nutritional Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Delrina Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bayou Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,572,000.

title: Eastern Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,807,872.c-After loss from discontinued operations of $ 757,436 and $ 1,004,237 in the quarter and year, respectively.Year-ago results are restated.

title: Jane Ann Picardi Has a Wedding
description: Jane Ann Picardi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand L. Picardi of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Marcel Gerard DeWinter, the son of Dr. Urbain J. DeWinter of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. J. Robert Yeazel performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: From Pearls to Condoms
description: Once when I was working as a long distance operator at A.T. T., I leaned over and asked a fellow worker if she had a tampon I could have. She strained way over her console and whispered back, "No, sorry." Then she strained even farther to the woman across from her and really quietly whispered to ask if she might have one for me.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; Many Cooks for the Middle East Pot
description: The Bush Administration unfurled its tentative blueprint for a postwar Middle East this week and was immediately reminded that Washington is not the only party that intends to play architect for the troubled region.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a cruise of the Black Sea, I am writing to alert other travelers of the perils of Yalta and Odessa.

title: Kremlin Role Questioned in Georgian Ethnic Strife
description: Refugees and wounded children are easier to find than the truth in this mountain region, the latest flashpoint in the conflict between the Kremlin and assertive Soviet republics.

title: Mutual Funds; Still Fighting Shy of Stocks
description: The Lipper Growth Fund Index, which charts stock funds much the way Standard & Poor's 500 charts stocks, increased nearly three-fold, from 163.5 to 461.6, in the last decade. You might think, then, that money would be pouring into stock funds. Not so. The portion of mutual fund assets stashed in stock funds has remained virtually unchanged since recovering from the recession lows of 1981-82, according to a recent study by Lipper Analytical Services Inc., in Summit, N.J.

title: Canadiens Blitz Rangers' 4-0 Lead
description: In a collapse of unusual magnitude, the Rangers squandered a 4-0 lead tonight and lost by 6-4 in spectacular fashion to the Canadiens before a screaming crowd of 17,629 at the Forum.

title: Shaky Provenance
description: To the Editor:

title: Criminal Type Named Horse of the Year in Upset
description: Criminal Type, whose rousing career was shortened by injury last year, scored one more upset victory today when he defeated Unbridled and Go for Wand at the ballot box and won the Eclipse Award as 1990's Horse of the Year.

title: Personal Interpretations of the Past
description: A VISIT to "Ancient Origins," an exhibition of contemporary crafts, provides an interval of harmonious silence, away from the cacophony of breaking news events. The artists chosen for the show found their inspiration in icons, artifacts and architectural remains of ancient cultures.

title: The Murderer in Her Dreams
description: MALINA By Ingeborg Bachmann. Translated by Philip Boehm. Afterword by Mark Anderson. 244 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $24.95.

title: Vietnam Veterans Say They Hope Lessons Were Learned
description: AFTER several weeks of relentless war coverage from the Persian Gulf, Roger Paulmeno said he expected some stepped-up activity at the Vietnam Veterans Outreach Center in White Plains, where he is the acting director. "We're surprised ourselves that no one is calling us," Mr. Paulmeno said. "Vietnam vets like to stay underground."

title: Beauty; The Sweet Smell of Excess
description: THE LAST FEW YEARS HAVE been weird ones for perfume debuts. There were such oddities as Canteen (not a scent you want to think too much about), Adidas (old sneakers?) Soho (the cappucino at Dean & DeLuca?) and on and on into the realm of the ridiculous. Similarly, it seemed that celebrities signed more perfume bottles than they did autograph pads, what with Julio and Liz and Elvis (in one of his many posthumous appearances) and even Priscilla all horning in on a piece of market share.

title: On the Street; Wool, Fanciful and Light
description: The practical wool coat of winter has taken on a fanciful, romantic border: a lacy cutout edging that resembles nothing so much as a paper doily. On some coats, it's a foot wide.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. COMMANDERS REPORTED TO CALL FOR A 3--WEEK DELAY BEFORE A GROUND OFFENSIVE
description: Senior officers said today that American field commanders had recommended continuing the allied air campaign against President Saddam Hussein's forces for at least three more weeks before a ground offensive is undertaken.

title: Reaching the End of the Road
description: While Volvo has replaced last year's top-of-the-line 760 models with the 940 series, the real star of the company's road show is the limited-production two-door Bertone, formerly known as the 780.

title: QUICK! WHAT'S A QUARK?
description: I learned most of the facts in the scientific-literacy quiz in high school ("Quick! What's a Quark?" by Robert M. Hazen and James Trefil, Jan. 13). The authors are correct in identifying the need to change the reward structures in colleges and universities to encourage researchers to spend time and energy teaching undergraduates; however, they should not have to teach them high-school material. Colleges have a right to expect their entering students to have basic literacy, including scientific literacy. LYNNE THOMSON Chicago

title: High Levels of Radioactivity Shut Nuclear Plant in Japan
description: An emergency cooling system shut down a reactor after abnormal levels of radioactivity were detected at a nuclear plant in Japan today, officials said.

title: Calling Bank Supervision Archaic, Greenspan Seeks Major Change
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, called today for major changes in the way Federal bank examiners supervise lending practices at commercial banks. He said that by often failing to recognize banking's true nature, the examiners had played a significant role in making banks reluctant to lend.

title: On Triptychs, Corsets and Other Imponderables
description: Cluttered dances can be as unsightly as littered streets. Mark Taylor and Stephen Petronio are talented choreographers, and they both presented fine works last month during the "Altogether Different" series of modern-dance performances at the Joyce Theater. But they also presented some dances cluttered with theatrical excess.

title: Legacy on the East End: Fewer Fire Volunteers
description: THE summer houses built on the East End in the real-estate boom of the 1980's have at least one factor in common. They pushed out young moderate-income residents who might have volunteered for the Fire Department.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We wallpapered our bathroom with a solid vinyl, and the edges are now peeling. The walls are plaster, which we covered with wallpaper lining and then primed. We overlapped the vinyl wallpaper strips by about one-eighth inch, and these edges are curling back. I tried several adhesives, but none held up for long. Some places will not stick down at all. Any suggestions?

title: Miss Zacks Weds Clifton S. Robbins
description: Deborah Lou Zacks, a daughter of Mrs. Irving May Shlesinger of Atlanta and the late Barry Bernard Zacks, was married last evening to Clifton Scott Robbins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of New York and Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Two Irish Treasuries of Books
description: JUST as it is no great trick to get the Irish to admit that Ireland has produced a disproportionate number of great writers, so it is as simple as finding the rain to get them to concede that their country has at least two great bookstores.

title: A Magical Moment In Prague
description: THE MIRACLE GAMEBy Josef Skvorecky.Translated by Paul Wilson.436 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We are looking out two windows. We love our people here, but we love our people there, too. We're existing in two worlds, but one of the things that hurts most is how little people in our world here really know about our world there." -- William Ali, an Arab-American. [ 1:2. ]

title: Montana Governor Signs King Holiday Bill
description: Montana has added to its calendar a holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Witch Hazel Signals Approach of Spring
description: LUCKY are those who have a witch hazel in their garden. This magnificent shrub is now in bloom or soon will be.

title: Ghana
description: To the Editor: Judith Graham's excellent article "The Slave Fortresses of Ghana" (Travel, Nov. 25) is a haunting reminder of the cruel history of the Guinea coast of West Africa, where I lived for a number of years.

title: Miss Hutchinson Plans May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Hutchinson of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Victoria Hutchinson to Richard Gruver Kline Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Kline of Annapolis, Md. A May wedding is planned.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; Official Syrian Paper Urges Iraqis to 'Liquidate' Hussein
description: A leading Syrian newspaper that reflects official thinking issued an extraordinary personal attack on President Saddam Hussein today, urging the Iraqi people and army to turn against him and "liquidate him in cold blood" to spare his country a "horrible massacre" in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Irish Fare With Continental Inspiration
description: BLACK ROCK CASTLE, an Irish restaurant in Bridgeport, is named for afortress on the River Lee built to protect the Cork City harbor in 1582. Bridgeport's Black Rock is not a real castle, but rather a gray-painted concrete block building with a tower made to look like a castle. In the same way, many dishes bear Irish names but have roots that are more discernibly Continental. Nevertheless, taped Irish tunes set the scene for a pleasant, low-key dining experience.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GRANNY WILL YOUR DOG BITEAnd Other Mountain Rhymes.By Gerald Milnes.Illustrated by Kimberly Bulcken Root.48 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. (All ages)

title: In Scarsdale, Teachers Attend Health Lectures
description: WHEN the Scarsdale Union Free School District began paying its own medical bills, administrators decided that it would make financial sense to try to keep the district's 750 employees as healthy as possible.

title: A New Coalition Seeks to Fill Vacant Apartments
description: THE depressed real-estate market and the sinking economy have prompted an unlikely alliance of housing advocates, developers, real-estate agents and landlords to create a plan that could free 3,000 empty Westchester apartments for rent or purchase at affordable prices.

title: Romantic Selections
description: SONG, oratorio, concerto, dance, renaissance music and jazz: all can be heard at concerts today in Westchester.

title: Baseball Notebook; Cubs Favored, and Frey Is Relieved
description: Some of the early -- foolhardy? -- prognostications are out, and the Chicago Cubs are among the teams touted for a division championship. Jim Frey, their no-nonsense general manager, is sort of relieved.

title: Arabs in U.S. Feel Separated by Other Gulfs
description: A University of Michigan cap on his head, a loaf of pungent Lebanese breakfast bread in his hand, William Ali stood by the counter at the Arabian Village Bakery here trying to explain the torment of three million Arab-Americans.

title: Sunday Outing; Breathtaking Scenery on a Hudson Bicycle Trip
description: Tales of hearty skiers and skaters notwithstanding, winter is probably the most sedentary season for New Yorkers. "It's God's way of saying 'read a book,' " said Richard Rosenthal of Manhattan, who, despite his skepticism, spends many of his winter weekends cycling in and around the city.

title: Connecticut's Favorite Traitor Can Still Inspire Fierce Debate
description: FOR decades, Benedict Arnold has been mostly cast as a greedy, dishonorable Revolutionary War officer who plotted to betray the fort at West Point to the British for $:20,000. But lately, a high-profile naysayer has been arguing that Arnold, the Connecticut Yankee whose name has long signified big-league baseness, was not that bad.

title:
Your Own Account;
Developing a Skills Portfolio 'To Go'
description: When Charles Handy's children left college a few years ago, he told them this: "I hope you won't look for a job in a corporation." Instead, he suggested they should develop skills, services and products that they could sell to corporations and to others in the marketplace. "Look for customers," he advised. "If you have a saleable skill, you can always work."

title: Seton Hall Upends Oklahoma
description: Terry Dehere scored 21 points and Anthony Avent had 17 points and 10 rebounds today, leading Seton Hall to a 92-85 victory over Oklahoma. The loss was the fifth in six games for the Sooners.

title: Small Presses Look to 'Niches' For Business
description: "One of the requirements of a small press is kids running in and out of the room," Peter Falk said with a patient smile. "You answer the phone and try to sound businesslike, and in the background suddenly someone cries, 'Daddy!"'

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi Beaten: Third-seeded Brad Gilbert beat top-seeded Andre Agassi, 6-1, 6-2, in a 59-minute match yesterday to advance to the final of the Volvo-San Francisco tournament. Gilbert had 12 service aces in beating the 20-year-old defending tournament champion. Agassi called it his worst loss since Pete Sampras beat him in the final of the United States Open. Gilbert will face the winner of last night's semifinal between sixth-seeded Darren Cahill and No. 7-seeded Wally Masur, both of Australia. Gilbert faced only two break points on his serve in the match and broke Agassi twice in each set. (AP) Volkov-Caratti Final: Starting slowly and heating up only when the match got tight, Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union reached the final of the $600,000 Muratti indoor tournament in Milan, Italy, with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland. In the final, Volkov, the tournament's eighth-seeded player, will face a wild-card entry, 20-year-old Cristiano Caratti of Italy, who reached the first Grand Prix final of his career with a 7-6, 6-7, 6-3 victory over Carl Uwe-Steeb of Germany. Skiing Merle Wins Super-G: Carole Merle of France blazed to her first World Cup victory of the season yesterday in winning a super-giant slalom in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, by more than half a second. Merle had a winning time of 1 minute 26.14 seconds on the icy Kandahar course for the 10th World Cup victory of her career and the seventh in a Super-G. Karin Dedler of Germany was second in 1:26.67 and Michaela Gerg of Germany was third in 1:26.80. The two-time world champion, Ulrike Maier of Austria, had to settle for a 12th-place tie yesterday with Chantal Bournissen of Switzerland, winner of the downhill Friday. Both were timed in 1:27.60 over the 2,070-meter-long course. (AP) Speed Skating World Record in 5,000-Meter: Johann Olav Koss of Norway set a world record as he defended his title in the 5,000-meter event yesterday and took a commanding lead halfway through the world championships in Heerenveen, the Netherlands. Koss won in 6 minutes 41.73 seconds, cutting 1.86 seconds off the 1987 record set by Geir Karlstadt of Norway. Koss leads with 78.633 points. Roberto Sighel of Italy, with surprisingly good showings at 500 and 5,000 meters, took second place in the overall standing with 79.174. Peter Adeberg of Germany won the 500 meters ahead of American Nathaniel Mills and Lee In-hoo of South Korea. Adeberg was timed in 37.52 seconds to beat Mills, who skated his best 500 ever in 37.87. The four-distance championships end today with the 1,500- and 10,000-meter races. Each distance has equal value. (AP) Golf Charles Leading Seniors: Bob Charles shot an even-par 72 yesterday to move into a one-stroke lead going into the final round of the Suncoast Senior Classic tournament at Tampa Palms Golf and Country Club. Lee Trevino shot a 71, one of only three rounds under par, and was second at 141. Bobby Nichols was third at 142 after shooting a 73. (AP)

title: Andrea Grossman to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin S. Grossman of Colonia, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Andrea Nancy Grossman and Gary Todd Abrams, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Abrams of New Milford, N.J. Miss Grossman, 26 years old, graduated from the University of Maryland and is studying for a master's degree in elementary education at Kean College. The prospective bridegroom, 25, is a graduate of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. He is a supervisor at Advertising Displays, a division of Kettering Industries, in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress; Legislators See Limited Value in Their Private War Briefings
description: They gather two or three times a week in guarded rooms to hear the latest Pentagon account of how the war against Iraq is going. But members of Congress generally think they do not know much more about the war than careful newspaper readers or television viewers do.

title: Campus Life: Dayton; Dispute Prompts Open Hearings By Election Panel
description: A disputed closed-door decision that upset the University of Dayton's spring 1990 student elections has led the student government to allow students access to election committee hearings.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There's a general impression that women are more sentimental and romantic than men, and it is probably both true and not true. Men are, in fact, capable of making wonderful grandiose gestures in the name of love, generally to a far greater degree than women, although there is not an iota of scientific backup for this theory.

title: Jennifer Briggs to Wed G. E. Braswell
description: Jennifer Backman Briggs and Geoffrey Emory Braswell, who are archeologists working on Mayan excavations in Copan, Honduras, plan to marry in May.

title: Building Bridges in the Jewish World
description: I would like to complement the article, "New Jersiy Seminary in Mt. Vernon" (Jan. 6).

title: FOUR GENERATIONS IN THE PROJECTS
description: There is no simple solution to poverty, but it seems to me that birth control could alleviate many of the problems. The one consistent theme in the article was illegitimate children. Without the physical and mental burden of these children, perhaps people would have more energy to improve their circumstances. ELIZABETH P. SCOTT Brookfield, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about Marine snipers in the Persian Gulf misidentified a book widely read by a sniper unit. It is "Marine Sniper: 93 Confirmed Kills," by Charles Henderson.

title: The Rent Tug of War In Commercial Space
description: JEAN KAHN, a Manhattan baker, is a survivor of the real estate boom gone sour. The owner of Patisserie les Friandises, a croissant and cake shop on the Upper West Side, she has gone through four years of tenacious bargaining with her landlord.

title: Jet Goes to Jail
description: A benevolent judge allowed him to fulfill his obligations to the Jets, but with the football season behind him, Joe Mott has finally faced up to his day of reckoning. On Friday, the New York Jet linebacker was sentenced to 60 days in jail for fondling an unconscious teen-age girl during a beer party in Endicott, N.Y., in January 1990.

title: Plantation Mansions on the Mississippi
description: ALONG the stretch of the Mississippi between Baton Rouge and New Orleans runs an old two-lane highway known as the River Road, until the ascendancy of the steamboat in the early 1800's an important route between the two cities and the plantations marshalled along the river. The highway, actually two roads on the two banks of the river, reflects the errant ways of the Mississippi, meandering to follow the levees, changing its name and its number as it winds past isolated villages, towering chemical plants and occasional stands of sugar cane.

title: Design; The Disappearing Dining Room
description: Of all the rooms in the house, the dining room is by far the most ritualistic. It is the setting that readily comes to mind when one thinks of holidays or family occasions. In this country, the dining room is also the room that has seen the most transformations. A victim of tastes, fashions and economic climates, it has gone from a commodious place of its own to just an "area," an L-shaped space in the far corner of a living room, and back to a formal room again. Now, it appears, the tides are turning once more: the conventional dining room is disappearing.

title: POSTINGS: Triumph for Norwalk; A Stylish Warehouse
description: Although Norwalk, Conn., may have little in common with Beverly Hills, Calif., one thing both cities share is an aversion to incompatible architecture. That fact has become abundantly clear to Public Storage Ltd. Partnership, a California company that runs more than 1,000 public-storage operations across the country and has been negotiating for three years to build one in Norwalk.

title: The Man Who Wouldn't Be King
description: KING EDWARD VIII A Biography. By Philip Ziegler. Illustrated. 552 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; U.S. Battle Plan Is Said to Stress Iraqis' Reserves
description: As allied forces arrayed against Iraq prepare to shift the war from the air to the ground, an American tactic called "AirLand Battle" is expected to undergo its first trial in real combat. If the tactic succeeds, victory may be swift and allied casualties minimal. If it fails, battlefield confusion could greatly complicate fighting and prolong the war.

title: Stephanie Thomases To Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Koch of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Stephanie Ellen Thomases, and William Martin Hutchison 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hutchison Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Deep Doubts About Ground War
description: The war spiral turns. Since at least Nov. 8, President Bush has been relentlessly pushing the pace of war in the Persian Gulf. First, he was sure that the international embargo could not force Iraq out of Kuwait. Now, he's convinced himself that the thunderous air war won't do it either. He has sent his top brass to Saudi Arabia this weekend almost certainly to ratify the judgment that a ground war is needed to achieve victory.

title: A Radical Bassist Who Fights For Every Note -- and Wins
description: In an era of musical conformity, Charlie Haden is a throwback, a veteran insurgent with a doggedly unconventional approach to the bass. Back in the late 1950's, Mr. Haden was in the midst of the jazz fray, helping his boss, Ornette Coleman, reshape the music's very language. Mr. Coleman was out to change the rules, and Mr. Haden's own free-ranging style mirrored the leader's preoccupation with open-ended improvisation.

title: New York to Promote Minority Sanitation Workers
description: The Dinkins administration will promote 120 black and Hispanic sanitation workers to settle a lawsuit charging that a 1985 Sanitation Department test for promotions was discriminatory.

title: Albanians' Effort to Flee Sets off Clash
description: Thousands of people seeking to leave Albania clashed with the police today in the Adriatic port of Durres, witnesses and Albanian television said. At least four youths and five police officers were injured, an opposition journalist said.

title: Mutual Funds; The Embattled Energy Funds
description: Fielding telephone calls from angry investors has become part of Ned Shadek's routine since he took over the Putnam Energy-Resources Trust in late December. What gives? That's what investors want to know. Oil prices soared as high as $40 a barrel late last year. Oil companies are reporting excellent earnings. But the fund's performance -- like its peers' -- is down.

title: The Region; Crimes of Passion, Deals of a Lifetime
description: IN true crime stories, the crime precedes the story -- but not by much anymore. Such is the appetite for shocking tales that book and movie deals are often far along before the jury has had time to decide who did what.

title: Syracuse Escapes An Upset
description: At a climax of one of the most volatile periods in Syracuse basketball history, in which the eligibility of four of the school's top five scorers was uncertain until 20 hours before a nationally televised game against Notre Dame, the athletic gifts of Billy Owens prevented a difficult situation from growing worse.

title: Paired by a Show and by Marriage
description: IN times gone by, married artists were loath to exhibit together. The reasons were never spelled out, but it is likely that professional jealousy was one.

title: Only Price Controls Cause Gas Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: U.C.L.A.; Upgraded Status Urged For Chicano Studies
description: The Mexican-American com munity of Southern California last week pressured the University of California at Los Angeles to recognize the region's close cultural ties with Mexico by establishing a full-fledged academic department devoted to Chicano studies.

title: The Silent Language Of Opera
description: A reader asks me to explain, if I can, why I am so hard on new productions at the Metropolitan Opera. The request is a little perplexing, coming on the heels of my appreciative review of David Hockney's staging of "Die Zauberflote," but I will not dodge it on that account. It is true that in this season's premieres so far the overinflated, the ugly and the simply incoherent have outweighed the good.

title: Lithuania Votes Overwhelmingly For Independence From Moscow
description: Lithuanian voters turned a republic-wide plebiscite into a festival of defiance of the Kremlin on Saturday, affirming their republic's harrowing state of independence 11 months after it was officially declared by their elected representatives.

title: Retailers Are Rallying Round the Flag
description: You might call it grass-roots fashion. The current trend for wearing the Stars and Stripes started with the man and the woman on the street. Oh, designers have been showing clothing and accessories emblazoned with the American flag for a couple of years, but when the gulf war started, civilians in droves took to wearing their patriotism on their backs.

title:
Gardening
Jump-Starting Spring To Ease Doldrums
description: As each day lengthens perceptibly, the gardener gets the familiar itch to do something to hasten the season. The new crop of seed catalogues are already dogeared. The nurseries hereabouts are not yet braced for the onslaught of your patronage.

title: Westminster: A Fancier's Delight
description: Westminster, known to fanciers as the blue-ribbon dog show, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow. One of the oldest continuous sporting events in the country, Westminster has been held every year since 1877. This 115th edition has drawn 2,500 dogs representing 142 breeds or varieties. They come from 49 states (only Hawaii is missing), Canada and Japan.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Travels With My Editor" by Sherry Marker (Travel, Nov. 25), I have visited numerous hamams (Turkish baths) in various parts of Turkey including the capital, Ankara, and have yet to see or hear about one where men and women are together in the same section. Therefore, I was surprised to see the reference to the author's seeing naked Japanese businessmen. This would be a highly unlikely if not impossible occurrence. MICHAEL KESEND New York, N.Y. Sherry Marker replies: The Turkish bath and sauna in the Buyuk Efes Hotel in Izmir, where I stayed, has hours for women only, Tuesday noon to 4 P.M., and for men only, Tuesday 4 to 9 P.M. Other days except Monday the bath is open to both men and women from noon to 9 P.M. In contrast to the situation in public baths in Turkey, mixed bathing is not uncommon in hotel baths, which cater to foreigners, most of whom wear bathing suits.

title: Headliners; Political Rehab
description: Italy's Communist Party is used to living on the political edge. But lately the relevance of Italian Communism has seemed even more suspect than usual, leaving the party's secretary, Achille Occhetto, with the problem of converting what many people see as a political relic to something more germane. Last week at a conference, the party changed its name to the Democratic Party of the Left, and it was assumed that Mr. Occhetto would be easily chosen to stay on as leader. When the vote for him fell short of the required majority, he felt decidedly unappreciated. "Well then," he said, renouncing his candidacy, "get yourselves another secretary." Though blame for the defeat was laid on a minority of hard-liners and on the fact that dozens of electors were absent, the Italian press taunted the party for its disarray. On Friday, the renamed Communists tried to undo the damage by re-electing Mr. Occhetto. This time, he decided to accept.

title: Computers Show Paths in Heart Arteries
description: EMERGING from the cardiac-catheterization laboratory where he had just finished an angioplasty to dilate clogged blood vessels in the heart, Dr. Jerome Koss brimmed with enthusiasm.

title: What Did Video Do in the War?
description: Like most activities, video has shown the effects of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. In a weekly survey called Videoflash, the consulting firm Alexander & Associates tracks the tape renting and buying preferences of 2,000 households across the country. At the outset of the war, with viewers locked into TV news reports, rentals fell, only to rebound several days later.

title: Jane D. Bernholz To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Michael Bernholz of New York and Lloyd Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Donnelly Bernholz to Christian Hartwell Maltby, a son of Ruth Maltby of Port Washington, L.I., and Thomas W. Maltby of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Colleen Costello To Wed S. J. Irish
description: Dr. and Mrs. John J. Costello of Oneida, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Colleen Anne Costello to Stephen John Irish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Irish of Basking Ridge, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: When Sam Clemens Roughed It
description: THE SAGEBRUSH BOHEMIAN Mark Twain in California. By Nigey Lennon. Illustrated. 203 pp. New York: Paragon House. $19.95.

title: Review/Theater; Linney Sets Chekhov In a Town in Appalachia
description: Anton Chekhov's short story "In the Ravine" is a sorrowful tale of small-town greed and cruelty partly offset by a figure of enduring innocence. Artfully transplanting the narrative from late-19th-century Russia to the foothills of Appalachia in the 1920's, Romulus Linney demonstrates his own creativity as a playwright and the universality of Chekhov. In this adaptation, Mr. Linney continues to be a poet of America's heartland.

title: Lindsey A. Whitaker To Wed K. D. Olsen
description: June wedding plans for Lindsey Anne Whitaker and Kenneth Dannevig Olsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olaf T. Olsen of Farmington, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lucius M. Whitaker Jr. of Farmington.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Great Barrington, Mass.;
New Stores For Old Farm
description: THE owners of the former site of Jenifer House are working to revive the Great Barrington property for new retail uses.

title: 'Just Lucky' Not to Be No. 1
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Your Own Account; Reinventing Yourself
description: It's not easy for many people to think of what what their skills and talents are beyond the title a corporation has given them. To free up your thinking about what you're good at, Charles Handy, a visiting professor at the London Business School and a writer on organizational change, suggests that you go to 20 people you know and ask each to tell you one thing you do very well.

title: Q and A
description: Escrow on a Tax Account

title: Hitsville, USA
description: In 1959 Berry Gordy was a moderately successful songwriter, with two Jackie Wilson hits, "Reet Petite" and "Lonely Teardrops," to his credit. He had recorded a group called the Matadors, but lacking his own record company Mr. Gordy was unable to promote their song "Got a Job" to his satisfaction. "Why work for the man?" asked Smokey Robinson, the Matadors' lead singer. "Why not be the man?" At the age of 30, with $800 borrowed from his parents, Mr. Gordy started Hitsville, USA. The company was soon renamed Motown; Mr. Robinson's group was renamed the Miracles -- and the rest, of course, is music history, a history well told by the journalist Ben Fong-Torres in THE MOTOWN ALBUM: The Sound of Young America (Sarah Lazin/St. Martin's, $50). Photographs recall Motown's astounding stable of smash acts, among them the Four Tops, the Supremes and Stevie Wonder, and also give faces to such crucial behind-the scenes workers as Cholly Atkins, the dance instructor who put the Temptations through their paces, and Maxine Powell, the martinet owner of a modeling school who taught etiquette to Motown's girl groups. That fabled Motown is no more, except in our memories -- and in this book.

title: Juliet Tammenoms Bakker Engaged To Wed Barrie Thrasher 3d in March
description: March wedding plans have been announced for Juliet Priscilla Tammenoms Bakker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Age Robert Tammenoms Bakker of Amsterdam, and Barrie Holt Thrasher 3d, a son of Dr. Thrasher Jr. and the late Matilda Parker Thrasher of Atlanta.

title: The Region; Dinkins Is Running a Deficit In His Credibility Account
description: IF Credibility Gap were a place, David N. Dinkins might be its mayor.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Ensnared by Freedom Solitude has long been a preoccupation of English writers; none wrote about it with more idiosyncratic style and zest than Rose Macaulay. This is from "Personal Pleasures" (Ecco, paper).

title: Streetscapes: The New Amsterdam Theater; A Landmark Mired In Bureaucracy
description: THE New Amsterdam Theater at 214 West 42d Street is one of New York City's greatest theaters, an interior and exterior city landmark. Why, then, is it in such bad shape?

title: Commune Chief Charged With Child Slavery
description: The founder of a disbanded communal group that preached strict discipline as the way to steer inner-city youths from crime and drugs has been indicted with seven of his followers on charges of enslaving children and denying them their civil rights.

title: 3 Arrested in Plot to Bomb 2 Chemical Tanks in Norfolk
description: The Federal authorities announced today that they had arrested three men and charged them with conspiring to bomb two storage tanks in Norfolk, Va., to collect the insurance on a chemical kept in one of the tanks.

title:
ART;
Putting the Blame On Adam and Eve
description: THE idea that all women should be punished for Eve's disobeying Yaweh is as farfetched as thinking that all men should have their livers torn out because Prometheus disobeyed Zeus.

title: When Movies Ought to Be in Pictures
description: Question: What's better than a movie?

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
A Long Road To Near Sellout
description: AFTER languishing vacant for almost two years after its completion in 1985, a 115-unit condominium with a spectacular view of downtown Pittsburgh and its three rivers has only now neared a sellout of its two- and three-bedroom units despite drastic price reductions.

title: New Comiskey Nears Completion
description: There aren't any baseballs, players or screaming fans in the new Comiskey Park yet.

title: Campaign Finance Rules May Take Two Routes
description: Congress could pass campaign finance legislation that would give the House and the Senate very different rules for paying for elections, the new head of the House Democrats' study group on the issue said this week.

title: Residential Resales

title: OUR TOYS ARE US
description: Thank you for putting all my suppressed "toy thoughts" into print (Hers: "Our Toys Are Us" by Peggy R. Ellsberg, Jan. 13).

title: Volleyball Event Put Off in Africa
description: The African Volleyball Federation on Friday postponed for the duration of the Persian Gulf war the African clubs' championship, which was to have been held this month in Morocco.

title: CRIME
description: The stark title of Ed McBain's new police procedural, WIDOWS (Morrow, $19), says it all. Men are murdered and women weep -- unless, of course, one of the widows did the dirty deed herself.

title: Campus Life: North Carolina; G.O.P. Attacks 'Peace Village' Protesting War
description: There is little peace at the University of North Carolina, where protesters supporting and opposing the war in the Persian Gulf are engaged in their own battle over events there.

title: RHODE ISLAND GETS BANK BAILOUT LAW
description: The new law creates a bailout agency, the Depositors Economic Protection Corporation, which will take over and then liquidate the assets of the 14 failed institutions and provide refunds to their depositors, whose money has been frozen for the last month.

title: Jim Jacoby, Bridge Champion, 58; Represented U.S. at World Level
description: Jim Jacoby, one of the world's greatest bridge players, died Friday night at Doctors' Hospital in Dallas. He was 58 years old and lived in Richardson, Tex.

title: Albanians in U.S. Share Homeland's Burdens
description: Albania's cautious move from Communist dictatorship toward multiparty democracy has kindled hope among Albanian-Americans that they can help speed the process.

title: About Cars; Volvo Makes Some Quiet Changes
description: "Longtime Volvo watchers will find it amazing, but for the third year in a row, Volvo has actually made changes you can see!"

title: St. Maarten
description: To the Editor: Your otherwise illuminating report on St. Maarten (Travel, Dec. 9) failed to describe the beautiful villas available.

title: Debra Jane Parmet Weds Clifford Brook Sondock
description: Debra Jane Parmet, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Parmet of Melville, L.I., was married in New York at the Lotos Club yesterday to Clifford Brook Sondock, a son of Eleanor Sondock of New York and the late Filmore Mayer Sondock. Rabbi David Posner officiated. Mrs. Parmet-Sondock, 29 years old, graduated from Cornell University. She is a buyer in New York for the retail division of the Polo/Ralph Lauren Corporation. Mr. Sondock, 33, graduated from Washington and Lee University and is the director of leasing for Spiegel Associates, a real estate development corporation in Jericho, L.I. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Newcomer Creates a Stir in Corridors of Power
description: REPRESENTATIVE Robert E. Andrews has been in Washington only 100 days, but he has already begun causing a stir.

title: Hartford Stage Offers Gurney's 'Snow Ball'
description: FIRST, the author wanted his story to be a play, he said, but it was so elaborate that he feared no one would stage it. So he wrote it as a novel instead. Then he tried to turn it into a musical, but that didn't work. Finally, he wrote the play.

title: Requiring Helmets for Young Skiers
description: All the people opposed to Dr. Norman San Agustin's ski helmet bill should be forced to watch a child die from a head injury. I doubt if they would then oppose any future move to improve safety on the ski slopes of New Jersey.

title: No Profit in a Ground War
description: To the Editor:

title: Shevardnadze Said to Form Policy Research Enterprise
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who resigned recently as Soviet Foreign Minister, has rejected offers to teach at American universities and is forming a foreign policy research group, the independent news agency Interfax reported rtoday.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; For Downtown Westport, a Minivillage
description: INSTEAD of a bridal suite and wishing well, a small hotel opening in downtown Westport in November will have 15 individually designed period suites, a restaurant and the Saugatuck River flowing by.

title: Eastern Issues Ticket Refunds
description: Eastern Airlines, which ceased operations on Jan. 18, is offering refunds to travelers holding Eastern tickets. To obtain a refund, ticketholders should send their tickets or unused portions of tickets to Eastern Airlines, Passenger Refunds, Miami International Airport, Miami, Fla. 33148. An Eastern official said that people requesting refunds should expect to wait four to six weeks. Travelers who purchased tickets through a travel agent will receive a refund through the agency. For further information about refunds, call Eastern at (305) 873-3400.

title: Ashburn Called Out
description: Anyone who thought that Pete Rose was the only former major leaguer barred from the Hall of Fame on Monday didn't read the fine print of the measure adopted by the hall's directors on a 12-0 vote.

title: After Abortion Protests, Complaints of Leniency
description: ADVOCATES of abortion rights complained last week that anti-abortion demonstrators had been treated too leniently by the police during a recent series of protests in the county.

title: Elisa Hirsch Weds Dr. H. D. Fischer
description: Elisabeth Stewart Hirsch, a daughter of John Arthur Hirsch of New York and Mariellen Evans Stewart of Westport, Conn., was married at Tavern on the Green in New York yesterday to Dr. Harry David Fischer, the son of Anne Rose Fisher of Brooklyn and the late Joseph J. Fischer. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Offbeat Settings Enhance Winter Show
description: When the 37th annual Winter Antiques Show ended last Sunday, most participants were relieved, and some were jubilant. Business, while down from a year ago, was better than many dealers had expected, considering the war and the recession. Although the East Side House Settlement, the sponsor of the 10-day bazaar at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, reported fewer tickets were sold than last year, the decline was less than had been projected. Even the new floor plan, with its wider aisles and shallower booths, was praised more than condemned.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HYPOXIA IN THE SOUND

title: Encouraging Both Stars and Novices in the Literary World
description: If you've been to a poetry or fiction reading or have taken a writing class in the last several years, chances are that a Manhattan-based organization called Poets & Writers has had something to do with it. Since 1970, the organization has provided matching grants for such projects to colleges, libraries, and community groups throughout the county.

title: Future Concerns Syracuse
description: Supporters of Syracuse University's nationally ranked basketball team breathed a sigh of relief yesterday after the National Collegiate Athletic Association's swift reinstatement of seven players who had been declared ineligible by the university, apparently for accepting cash from team boosters.

title: A Valentine's Menu With Some Twists
description: THE heart motif prevails for Valentine's Day. Heart-shaped brownies, cookies, cakes, tarts and so forth dominate the dessert menu.

title: Hindu Party in India Seeks a Governing Image
description: In a move that could strengthen its image as an alternative government for India, the conservative Bharatiya Janata Party has named a shadow cabinet in preparation for the opening of a crucial session of Parliament later this month.

title: Style Makers; James Johnston, Screen Designer
description: James Johnston's wooden screens are not meant to screen much. Their top ridges rise and fall precipitously, and holes often puncture their midsections. Even when they are made of traditional rectangular pieces, they do not look conventional: Embossed curlicues and gilded patches dance across their surfaces, and their backs are completely different from their fronts.

title: Leonard Falls Twice; Then Says Goodbye
description: Terry Norris beat a legend last night, driving him back into retirement.

title: Headliners; What's Being Done About Runway Deaths
description: ONE constant in aviation is that disaster spurs Government action. Such was the case last week when, four days after a landing USAir jet crushed a SkyWest commuter plane in Los Angeles, killing 34 people, James B. Busey, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, announced a sweeping plan to reduce the risk of such ground collisions.

title: Stamps
description: The political centrifuge in which the Soviet Union is spinning has thrown off increasingly strident nationalist movements in many of the lands that make up the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: 'Mineral Province' Divides Brazil and Venezuela
description: Brazil and Venezuela are enmeshed in a dispute over gold, Indians and 2,000 square miles of rain forest.

title: FOUR GENERATIONS IN THE PROJECTS
description: I can't work up much sympathy for the Haynes clan, profiled in Lemann's article on the Robert Taylor Homes in Chicago. In reading the article, I was struck by their overall irresponsibility, immorality and unwillingness to work for positive change in their lives. These are people who did drugs, had numerous children in and out of wedlock and, when they had money, squandered it. Sadly, these refrains are repeated again and again from one generation to the next. PAULA J. SCHAUKOWITCH McKees Rocks, Pa.

title: INSIDE
description: Hope for Black Townships South Africa's President is developing a plan of incentives to encourage white towns to merge with poorer black townships. Page 3. U.S. Holds 3 in Bomb Plot Three men were charged with plotting to bomb chemical tanks in Norfolk to collect insurance. Page 20. A Puzzle at Syracuse Suspensions and reinstatements have raised suspicions about the Syracuse basketball program. Sports, section 8. News Summary, Page 2 Obituaries, Page 42 Weather, Page 43 Radio, Late TV, Page 64

title: A Hideaway For Surfers And Birders
description: SAN BLAS, on Mexico's Pacific coast, is the kind of place that invites legends -- tall ships, pirates, Spanish missionaries, California surfers.

title: Kimberly A. Lutz Weds A. S. Gould
description: Kimberly Ann Lutz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Lutz Jr. of West Islip, L.I., was married last evening to Alan Steven Gould, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Gould of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Gluck, Momentarily Neglected, Awaits a New Tide of Fashion
description: At the end of an upperfloor back hall on the north side of the Metropolitan Opera, far from the ground-floor, south-side offices of James Levine and Joseph Volpe, the company's artistic and administrative leaders, one comes suddenly upon a painting of Christoph Willibald Ritter von Gluck. He sits calmly, even placidly, staring out at the few passers-by over a gulf of 200 years. Is he awaiting a return call to glory, or just moldering away into the dustbin of history.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 9 about Monserrat misstated the reason for the heat of the island's sand. It is black and traps the heat of the sun; its iron content is not the primary factor. A reader wrote to The Times in December about the error; the correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title: The Nation; Washington's Plan To Funnel City Aid Through the States Enrages the Mayors
description: IN the Depression year of 1933, when people were starving in the streets, three mayors came to Washington, met with President Franklin D. Roosevelt and asked for emergency assistance. Over the objections of governors, who argued that aid should be funneled exclusively through the states, Congress in 1933 earmarked 25 percent of each state's road funds for municipal projects.

title: The Last Stalinist
description: GUERRILLA PRINCE The Untold Story of Fidel Castro. By Georgie Anne Geyer. Illustrated. 445 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Celebrating the Humble and the Humdrum
description: The quartet of sculptures at the top of the main staircase in the Corcoran Gallery of Art here might easily be mistaken for the efforts of four artists, so diverse are they in material, touch and appearance. They neatly sum up the work of Tony Cragg.

title: Trash Recycling
description: To the Editor: Your "Q & A" column on Dec. 23 suggested, under the heading "Trash Recycling," that the Sanitation Department is entitled to inspect garbage on private property. It cited Anne Canty of the Santitation Department as the authority. Both are mistaken for several reasons.

title: Nothing New About a Hotel for Recovery
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR GENERATIONS IN THE PROJECTS
description: To end the article with the suggestion that the problem is a failure of liberalism, architecture or big government trivializes the herculean sacrifices of those few like Ruby Haynes's former daughter-in-law, Connie Henry. Give her the help in moving out that she seeks. RUTH MOYERMAN Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: BROWN U. RECEIVES GIFT OF $25 MILLION
description: Thomas J. Watson Jr., the 77-year-old chairman emeritus of the International Business Machines Corporation and former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, gave $25 million yesterday to Brown University, where a dean once told him, "It doesn't look promising for you in college."

title: Many High Schools Bar Basketball Game Fans
description: Miguel Montero, the star center of the George Washington High School basketball team in Washington Heights, longs to hear the roar of the crowd. But when Stuyvesant High School's team visited his school one afternoon recently, most of his 29 points were greeted by only polite applause.

title: Sununu vs. Scientists
description: The answer: John Sununu, White House chief of staff.

title: Out of the Mouths
description: The voice of the 2-year-old is heard in the land, a cross between the sound of fingernails on a blackboard and the Concorde taking off. "No news!" she keens as the modulated voice of some British broadcaster who has managed to remain in Baghdad provides a polite counterpoint. "No news!"

title: Is Victory Over Iraq Really a Sure Thing?; Tonnage Exaggerated
description: To the Editor:

title: Can the Ayckbourn Curse Be Broken?
description: When Alan Ayckbourn's "How the Other Half Loves" passed through Palm Beach, Fla., on its way to Broadway 20 years ago, everything that could go wrong on an opening night duly did so. A trolley rolled down the raked stage, plastering a couple in evening dress with sticky food. Worse, Phil Silvers was far from having mastered the leading role.

title: Sunday Dinner; For Francophiles, La Cuisine at Its Best
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some French restaurants in Manhattan. Cafe Un, Deux, Trois

title: Rep. Silvio O. Conte Is Dead at 69; Longtime Battler for the Underdog
description: Representative Silvio O. Conte, a combative Republican who battled, sometimes against his own party, for the poor, for students, for the environment and for medical research, died Friday night at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 69 years old.

title: Mother Chose the Wrong Life
description: SWALLOW HARD By Sarah Gaddis. 315 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.
