title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Art Show Dropped After Complaints Of Censorship
description: After criticism that the rules for a student art contest were vague and amounted to censorship, Wisconsin University officials here canceled the competition 24 hours after it began.

title: New League Says War Won't Have Much Impact
description: Some of the extravagance and exuberance that marks pro football in the United States will not be seen when the World League of American Football unveils itself in Europe next month.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CHOICES WE MADE 25 Women and Men Speak Out About Abortion. Edited by Angela Bonavoglia. Random House, $19.95.

title: Jury Rejects Stress Defense
description: A sailor was convicted of a double murder Friday despite the defense's contention that he had been driven insane by the May 1987 Iraqi attack that killed 37 of his shipmates on the U.S.S. Stark. The defendant, Walter Thomas Taylor, 24 years old, was a lookout when an Iraqi plane fired two missiles into the ship. The defense said he was suffering from post-traumatic stress syndrome when he fatally beat an acquaintance, 21-year-old Paula Smits, and her 3-year-old daughter, Amanda, with a hammer in August 1987. Prosecutors said the murders were a coverup of his rape of Ms. Smits.

title: Philadelphia Official Resigns
description: The city's finance director, Elizabeth C. Reveal, who has led efforts here to escape a deep financial crisis, announced her resignation Friday, effective March 8. "I just really feel personally that it is the right time for me to move on," Ms. Reveal said. Mayor W. Wilson Goode praised her record over the last three years, in which she spearheaded attempts to put the city budget on a five-year plan. He said he had not decided on her successor.

title: Mexico's Blossoming Coast
description: FOR years the whole of Mexico's Oaxacan coast could have been described as escondido, which means hidden or unknown. Cut off from the rest of the country by the rugged Sierra Madre del Sur, only fishermen, the occasional cruising sailor and tramp steamers knew about this coast.

title: Ike, Winston and the Russians
description: THE CHURCHILL-EISENHOWER CORRESPONDENCE, 1953-1955 Edited by Peter G. Boyle. Illustrated. 230 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $24.95.

title: Social Events
description: For Learning the Ballet

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Other Enemies: Fine, Pervasive Sand and Cutting Rocks
description: The sand of the northern Arabian desert, as fine as talcum powder, is becoming a new enemy to allied troops, already plagued by grit-clogged equipment, as they move into their most forward positions in preparation for a ground war. The northern desert is very rocky, too, taking its toll on self-propelled weapons and vehicles.

title: Enshrining the Old South
description: PRESERVATION of the past is big business in America, but nowhere is it bigger business than in Natchez. I was brought up in England on the notion of the house as museum, but I was quite unprepared for the astonishingly determined re-creation of a bygone age that I saw in the many houses of Natchez during Pilgrimage Month.

title: Sports of The Times; Syracuse May Be Added to an Untidy Laundry List
description: Two years ago, well before the current Syracuse basketball problems erupted, it was learned on very good authority that there was almost nothing wrong with college sports. "The state of college sports," announced Richard Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, "is as good as it's been in a long, long time. Ninety-nine percent of everything is positive."

title: Police to Restrict Filming of Political Rallies
description: New York City Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown has issued new rules limiting police surveillance of political activities after an oversight panel found that officers had improperly photographed and videotaped participants at street rallies concerning Cuba.

title: A Search for Lincoln's DNA
description: A Government museum is considering an effort to clone tissue samples from Abraham Lincoln in an attempt to answer persistent questions about his health and how it might have affected his performance as President.

title: Murdock Too Hot for Redmen
description: Cheered on by a record Civic Center crowd of 13,307 fans, Eric Murdock, the leading scorer in the Big East Conference pumped in 23 of his game-high 28 points in the second half tonight to lead Providence to a 75-64 victory over St. John's.

title: Who Needs Reminders?
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Memphis;
A New Village On an Island
description: A 132-ACRE development called Harbor Town is taking shape on an island in the Mississippi River linked to the downtown area by a four-lane bridge.

title: Formula One Tryout for an Andretti
description: Few practice sessions in recent racing history have been as intriguing to American fans as one that took place last Tuesday through Thursday in Estoril, Portugal. That's because for the first time since 1981, a driver named Andretti was sitting in a Formula One car.

title: Picasso and Gertrude Stein: Mano a Mano, Tete-a-Tete
description: One of the significant women in the life of Pablo Picasso was Gertrude Stein, who loomed large as collector, muse and phenomenon. Shortly after they met in 1905, when he was 24 and she 31, Picasso began to paint her portrait. In the first volume of "A Life of Picasso," to be published by Random House later this month, John Richardson tells the story of that encounter.

title: Comfort After Fatal Error
description: Co-workers at Los Angeles International Airport rushed a distraught air traffic controller into seclusion shortly after a runway collision that killed 34 people last week, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Bronx Woman Abandons 2 Foster Children on L.I.
description: A mentally disturbed Bronx woman abandoned her two foster children on a Long Island doorstep and returned home without them Friday night, setting off a police search that ended 12 hours later when the children were found in good condition, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Michigan Plan for Budget Cutting Jolts a Town Bolstered by Prisons
description: This town once welcomed prisons that other cities shunned. But now officials fear that state budget cuts will leave Ionia's five state prisons with too few guards to control the 4,900 inmates.

title: Campus Life: Cincinnati; Students Get A Taste of Life In a Wheelchair
description: Physical therapy majors at the University of Cincinnati put themselves in the wheelchairs of their future patients last week.

title: Discovering Patrick O'Brian
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; ISRAEL IS WARNED ON COMPLACENCY
description: As the 31st Iraqi missile hurtled toward a quiet neighborhood in the Tel Aviv area early this morning, the most persistent civil defense warnings being broadcast to Israel's people were admonitions against complacency.

title: Giving to Neediest Because of Vulnerability
description: "There, but for the grace of God, go I."

title: Carol A. Melone Becomes Bride Of T. J. Zuckert
description: Carol Ann Melone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Melone of Short Hills, N.J., and Boynton Beach, Fla., was married yesterday in Short Hills to Timothy Joseph Zuckert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Zuckert of Old Greenwich, Conn., and New Castle, N.H. Msgr. William P. DeVine performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Adding It All Up; Battle Plans Are Deadly Simple; The Strategic Weapon Is Politics
description: FROM the chain of command, all the way up to George Bush, the word to the public last week was that the war in the Persian Gulf was going according to plan -- as if the Bush Administration had subverted the military maxim first uttered by Count Helmuth von Moltke the Elder, the Prussian Chief of Staff who said no battle plan survives contact with the enemy.

title: Lesson From Vietnam: Escaping the B-52's
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Shelburne, Vt.; A Complex For the Elderly
description: A LOCAL investors group, a Baltimore developer and an Albany investment banking firm are working to win final legal approvals for construction of the state's first continuous-care retirement community.

title: Businesses' Enthusiasm For the State Said to Drop
description: AFTER a decadelong boom in the state's economy, New Jersey's business associations say they are detecting a new streak of pessimism in the private sector. Although the economic picture is generally bleak throughout the nation, some businesses say that conditions in New Jersey are worse than in other states, prompting them to reassess their commitment to remaining here.

title: Hartford Seminary Fosters Understanding of Islam
description: DR. DAVID KERR says that anti-American street demonstrations in Muslim countries, "from Morocco in the West to Malaysia in the East" underline the "lessons to be learned" from the history of European colonialism in the Middle East.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: American International Toy Fair, through Feb. 20 in New York. TUESDAY: President's Council of Economic Advisers presents its 1991 report to Congress. * Housing completions for December. * Treasury auctions 52-week bills. WEDNESDAY: January retail sales. * Auto sales for early February. * Criminal negligence trial of McNeil Consumer Products, makers of Tylenol, in Chicago. THURSDAY: December business inventories and shipments. * Jobless claims for week ended Feb.2. * Possible release of Ford and G.M. earnings. * Valentine's Day. FRIDAY: Deadline for NCR shareholders to offer their stock to A.T.& T. in its takeover attempt. * Producer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization for January. * Merchandise trade balance for December.

title: John G. Loftus Wed in Bronxville To Miss Williams
description: Margaret Crawford Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Williams of Hilton Head, S.C., was married at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday to John Geoffrey Loftus, a son of William V. Loftus Jr. of New York and Mrs. Edward P. Brandeau of Flemington, N.J. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Splendid Isolation
description: WINTER Notes From Montana. By Rick Bass. Illustrated. 162 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/ Houghton Mifflin. $18.95.

title: Miss Diamond to Wed T. C. Harrison
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Diamond of Todt Hill, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Blach Diamond to Timothy Colton Harrison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Harrison of Norfolk, Va. A July wedding is planned.

title: AIRLINE NEAR PACT WITH PILOTS' UNION
description: American Airlines and the union representing its 8,900 pilots said today that they had tentatively resolved a 16-month contract dispute in which many pilots were prepared to strike if demands for higher pay and other terms were not met.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WALKING ON ICEBy Susan Hubbard.University of Missouri,

title: Assault Charge Sends Pickets to Queens Grocery
description: A group of black Queens residents called for a boycott of a Korean-owned grocery store in Elmhurst yesterday after a Korean employee was arrested and charged with assaulting an 11-year-old black boy. The police said the store worker said he thought the boy was shoplifting.

title: New Owners Rescue Bantam Cinema
description: MOVIEGOERS will sip free champagne next weekend at the Bantam Cinema, as they celebrate the news that this tiny theater will remain open. The theater, which is believed to be the oldest continuously operating movie house in Connecticut, was to close in December if a new owner had not been found. But a new owner was found. She is Lisa Abelow Hedley of Litchfield, and she has been busily planning for the reopening on Friday.

title: Hers; The Caretakers
description: "CARETAKING'S HELL." So said Eve, my local florist. She, too, lived with illness. We spoke a moment when I picked up another yellow rose for my invalid husband. Each day the flower I brought opened while I was at school, teaching; it gave him something to watch. In the language of flowers, yellow roses mean courage, as much for me as for him. Eve understood -- later she would make a blanket of yellow roses for his grave -- so she gave me a hug. Because she is still her husband's caretaker, now I hug her whenever I go into the shop.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VALENTINE EVENTS

title: Managing; Mastering the Language of Disability
description: There are plenty of jobs at the Bank of Montreal that people who are deaf, blind or learning impaired, could do. And since Canadian companies, like their American counterparts, face legal and demographic pressures to hire more people with disabilities, the bank wishes more of them would apply. But for years, applicants with disabilities have been few and far between.

title: Danny Aiello Journeys Along The Blue-Collar Road to Stardom
description: Danny Aiello is threefourths of his way through roasted chicken and mashed potatoes -- real mashed potatoes -- and the phone rings. Again. Usually it's guys with names like Tony and Paulie. This time it's Paulie. He says Danny is on TV.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 10 of the Travel section today about Taos includes an outdated visiting schedule for the Taos Pueblo. It was closed to visitors on Thursday and will remain closed through March 10.

title: Alimony Lives -- but Call It Maintenance
description: To the Editor:

title: State Says Rabies Is Spreading Rapidly
description: RABIES in terrestrial animals, primarily raccoons, is spreading rapidly throughout New Jersey, the State Health Department says.

title: POSTINGS: 6 Stories on West 43d; Rosoff's Redone
description: With rooms going for as little as $65 a night, the newly renovated Rosoff's Hotel, at 147 West 43d Street, will be more on par with European midrange hotels than with other newcomers to the Times Square area, like the Hotel Macklowe around the corner and Embassy Times Square four blocks away, where rates are over $150.

title: Pretoria Seeking Nonracial Local Government
description: In what could become the most significant move toward true racial integration in South Africa this year, the Government of President F. W. de Klerk is putting the finishing touches on a major program that would encourage white towns to merge administratively and financially with poorer black townships, with legal backing and financial incentives from Pretoria.

title: Catherine R. Warren, Law Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Warren 3d of Roslyn Heights, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Ruth Warren to Anthony Robin Koumis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacovos Koumis of London. A July wedding is planned.

title: Dance by the Light of the Tube
description: There was a time when choreographers worked exclusively with human bodies and music. It was Merce Cunningham who changed that, doing away with music as an integral element of dance and making choreographic choices through random procedures, like tossing coins to determine movement sequences. At the age of 71, the modern-dance master is now exploring another frontier. Using innovative new software called Life Forms, Cunningham has become the first major choreographer to create dance by computer. This new work, called "Trackers," will be performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company during a two-week season beginning March 12 at City Center in New York.

title: O'Meara Leads by 1 in Hope Classic
description: One of the most birdie-filled shootouts in recent times is anticipated Sunday as a tightly bunched group of players will try to speed past Mark O'Meara at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Miss Keefe Weds J. F. Anderson Jr.
description: Jennifer Douglas Keefe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Keefe of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel to Joseph Frederick Anderson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Clinton, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Sweaters for the Transitional Season
description: When the season is changing from lion to lamb, a cotton sweater lends just the right insulation, especially when the choices introduce color to a drab winter wardrobe.

title: A Bomb Threat Puts An End to a Benefit
description: A ball at the Museum of the City of New York Thursday was interrupted at midnight by a bomb threat that sent 900 guests scurrying into the chilly night, many of them without coats.

title: Commercial Paper Has Troubles, Too
description: Banks are not the only lenders tightening credit in these hard times. Some borrowers are having trouble tapping another source of short-term cash -- the commercial paper market, which some analysts had hoped would give a few companies refuge from the credit crunch.

title: Special Education P.T.A. Is Revived
description: SOME parents here have recently revived the Special Education Parent-Teacher Association, which had been dormant for about 10 years.

title: U.S. BACKS DRILLING FOR OIL AND GAS IN NEW OCEAN SITES
description: The Department of the Interior is proposing to open thousands of miles of the outer continental shelf to offshore oil and gas exploration, calling for new lease sales off the East Coast, the Florida Panhandle, parts of Southern California and vast areas of Alaska.

title: The State of the Governor
description: It is the last day of the year, and Albany, living up to its cheerless reputation, is gray and frigid. Nevertheless, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has decided to walk to his swearing-in ceremony. He marches down the hill from the State Capitol, a powerful figure in a shapeless fedora, his aides trailing behind him, hugging themselves against the cold.

title: Headliners; A Victory of Sorts
description: Perhaps it was a moment for one of Leona Helmsley's trademark Cheshire-cat smiles. On Thursday, a New York State appeals court dismissed the remaining charges in what was left of the state's income-tax fraud case against Mrs. Helmsley, the 70-year-old wife of Harry Helmsley, the ailing real-estate magnate, and the self-styled queen of their hotel empire. Earlier, Mr. Helmsley was ruled unfit to stand trial, as the Federal court had said earlier. Mrs. Helmsley's lawyer, Alan Dershowitz, hailed the ruling, which held that the case was nearly identical to the tax fraud charges on which she was convicted in Federal court in 1989 and thus constituted double jeopardy. "It struck down a political jackpot in which Federal and state prosecutors all wanted a piece of the action," Mr. Dershowitz said. "It was a classic and blatant case of governmental over-reaching." Mrs. Helmsley has appealed the Federal conviction, which said she evaded taxes by claiming expensive personal items as business deductions.

title: Philippines Gains Little In Marcos Building Sale
description: The Crown Building, a Fifth Avenue landmark once owned by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, was sold at auction on Friday after years of court battles, international intrigue and deal-making.

title: The U.N. Never Said 'Saddam Must Go'
description: A central element in President Bush's "new world order," as he stressed in his State of the Union address, is "the rule of law." And, in contrast to other recent U.S. military actions, thus far the gulf war has been played by the book, legally speaking.

title: The Best of Rhymes
description: THE POETS OF TIN PAN ALLEY A History of America's Great Lyricists. By Philip Furia. 322 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: Topics of the Times; More Than a Token of Love
description: If, despite the recession and the war, anyone is still throwing money around the way they did in the 1980's, the American Greetings Corporation has the perfect valentine. Before the economy slid and before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, the company commissioned 2,000 oil paintings of roses by artists in the Far East, which it is offering to moonstruck Americans for $100 apiece.

title: Fewer Tourists in Mexico as War Cuts Travel
description: Reflecting the deep new reluctance of many Americans to travel abroad, tourism officials here say that reservations for air travel to Mexico, the most popular foreign destination for American travelers, have fallen by as much as 25 percent since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August.

title: Eclipse Tours In Hawaii
description: Travelers planning to be on the island of Hawaii for the total solar eclipse on July 11 -- it will last about six minutes from 7:28 A.M. -- had better act fast before the sun sets completely on accommodations. Upward of 20,000 visitors are expected on the Big Island for the phenomenon, which will not be visible from the same location for another 360 years. Many more people will settle for the astronomical cheap seats on other Hawaiian islands, which will experience up to a 99 percent eclipse.

title: Blast Hits Austria Line That Ships U.S. Tanks
description: A bomb blast early today damaged part of a rail line in western Austria that is to be used to transport American tanks to the Persian Gulf, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry said.

title: Review/Jazz; Shearing Plus Three
description: Like most veteran performers, the jazz pianist George Shearing has a vast repertory of familiar tunes that are associated with him and that can provide his fans with an evening of nostalgia. But Mr. Shearing, who opened an engagement at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) on Tuesday night that will run through Feb. 23, is not simply pressing the nostalgia button this time.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; Ballplayer's Death Prompts a Call For CPR Training
description: The death of a Dartmouth College baseball player who suffered a heart attack during an unsupervised practice has prompted college officials to encourage coaches and all members of the athletic department to learn cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

title: Central Banks Fail To Bolster Dollar
'Is Any Sex Safe?'
description: BOYS LIKE USBy Peter McGehee.166 pp. New York:St. Martin's Press.

title: Songbirds Dwindling Along With Woodlands
description: BETTY HAYDEN never leaves for her job as a teacher at the North Shore Hebrew Academy without feeding her "children." Although her two grown sons have left the house, she considers the birds that visit the four feeders at her house in Sands Point "her feathered offspring."

title: The Enemy of Our Enemy Was Our Enemy
description: THE LONGEST WARThe Iran-Iraq Military Conflict.By Dilip Hiro.Illustrated. 323 pp.New York: Routledge.Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: Style Makers; Robert Mannino, Swimsuit Designer
description: When a fashion magazine wants to photograph a glamorous swimsuit, a call goes out to Robert Mannino and he packs up a bunch of sequined and lame numbers with high-cut legs and low-cut necks and perhaps a long panel floating like a train down the back. When a store like Bergdorf Goodman or Charivari calls, he packs up black and white checked suits or cotton jacquards. His swimwear collection for women is extensive enough to include suits for sunning and suits for swimming, but most of them are cut daringly brief enough to require a perfect body.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE MUSEUM OF CARTOON ART;
Dennis the Menace Prepares To Leave Ward's Castle
description: DENNIS THE MENACE still clings to the mahogany banister, and a gallery of Dick Tracy villains still glowers at visitors. Hundreds of original comic strips, comic book pages, magazine and newspaper cartoons line the walls, as always. What is more, exhibitions are scheduled through next fall, including a major show of art from the Walt Disney animated film "Fantasia."

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MORE AND MORE MOZART

title: Miss Hambrecht Weds Robert Eu
description: Elizabeth Boyer Hambrecht, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Hambrecht of San Francisco, was married there yesterday to Robert James Eu, a son of Mrs. Andrew Keng Wai Eu of New York and Hong Kong and the late Mr. Eu. The Rev. Richard P. Fowler performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

title: Miss Stahl to Wed Drake D. Stimson
description: June wedding plans for Sarah Elizabeth Stahl and Drake David Stimson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Stimson 2d of San Marino, Calif., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Stahl of Rochester.

title: A Fantasy Land of Toys Where No Child May Play
description: Toy makers and toy vendors have turned a section of this Renaissance city into a paradise for children, but no child is allowed to see it.

title: Other People's Cars
description: KILLER DILLER By Clyde Edgerton. 247 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Qualifications For a Director
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Emotional Themes Emphasized Anew
description: PAINTERS whose work attempts worldly analysis are enjoying a renaissance, undoubtedly because of our involvement in historically heady times.

title: Another Opening, at a New Address
description: WHEN times are hard, have a theater built. That appears to be the credo of William B. Stutler and Robert J. Funking, the producers of An Evening Dinner Theater, which opened here in 1974, the beleaguered year of an energy shortage, a bear market and multiple monetary crises.

title: Somebody Always Knows Best
description: THE IDEA BROKERS Think Tanks and the Rise of the New Policy Elite. By James Allen Smith. 313 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: Design for a Post-Cold War Company
description: Japan's leading microelectronics companies are opening state-of-the-art research and development laboratories in the United States and are trying to steal away America's best scientists. Is the American computer industry -- the last bastion of American technological superiority -- about to succumb to the Japanese threat? A number of analysts think so. But it is not the Japanese we should be afraid of. We are our own worst enemy.

title: Houston Journal; Now That a City Has Grown, the Planning Begins
description: This sprawling city is taking its first steps toward eliminating a traditional Houston point of pride: the right of developers and businessmen to build almost anything almost anyplace.

title: Sofa a Hero as Car Invades Queens Home
description: Cleo Cooley won't get any argument from her husband, James, the next time she insists on buying the best.

title:
The View From: The Beardsley Zoo;
Bridgeport's Fiscal Watchdogs Want the Tigers Off the Payroll
description: THE Beardsley Zoo in Bridgeport has suddenly become an endangered species. The city's state-imposed Financial Review Board has ordered the transfer of the zoo's operations by April 1 from the municipal government to the Connecticut Zoological Society, as part of the effort to close Bridgeport's $7.6 million budget gap. The board said the transfer would save $100,000 a year, but the Zoological Society's executive director, Lisa Tyson, said, "It would mean closing the zoo."

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ERNESTO L. BUTCHER;
Moving Traffic on Bridges and Tunnels
description: ERNESTO L. BUTCHER is a man on the move. He is on his way up at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He leaves his home in East Orange about 6 A.M. every day to run three to seven miles, "no matter what the weather." He has run in four New York City Marathons.

title: Supersensitive Machines Help The Disabled Communicate
description: JOHN C., a multiply handicapped teen-ager who up to several years ago had no means of communication except grunting and raising his eyes to indicate yes, can now, through a communication device, converse and make his needs known.

title: All About/Oil Services; A Lean, High-Tech Industry Poised for Postwar Growth
description: During the oil boom of the early 1980's, most companies spent more than $10, some more than $20, to find and produce a barrel of oil in the United States. Since then, the service companies that provide equipment and crews to drill for oil, and for the natural gas often found with it, have improved the process vastly. They have introduced supercomputers to spot drilling sites and sophisticated equipment that can even drill sideways (box).

title: Dr. Jill Appel Engaged To Dr. Louis Felder
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Appel of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Jill Appel and Dr. Louis Felder, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Felder of Pittsburgh.

title: Technology; Keeping Track of a Hermetic Universe
description: Next month, one of the most complex software packages ever designed will get a chance to prove itself in the middle of the Sonoran Desert near Tucson, Ariz. There, in Biosphere II, a structure that looks like a combination greenhouse and futuristic shopping mall, eight scientists will seal themselves inside for two years. Their environment will be controlled by G2, the most advanced of a new batch of computer programs, known as expert systems, that are designed to mimic human decision-making.

title: Farewell Message To Cypress Point
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The World; Apartheid's Laws Are Dismantled, But Not Its Cages
description: WHEN President F. W. de Klerk announced on Feb. 1 that he would scrap the basic laws underpinning South Africa's system of racial discrimination, he drew fresh acclaim from around the world. Yet apartheid was so intricately constructed over four decades and has created such economic disparity between blacks and whites that many South Africans might find their separate lives little changed by the reforms.

title: Perdue Farms to Ease a Production Practice
description: Ending a dispute that had lasted more than a year, the nation's fourth-largest poultry producer has agreed to create a program to reduce repetitive motion injuries among employees who dress chickens on its production lines at four North Carolina plants.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BLUE BEDROOM AND OTHER STORIES By Rosamunde Pilcher. Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's,

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Louis Parley;
Taking a Legal Approach to Marriage
description: VALENTINE'S DAY and true love notwithstanding, some couples on the threshold of marriage sign a covenant that would make Cupid blanche. Louis Parley, a lawyer and a co-author of "Lindey on Separation Agreements and Anti-Nuptual Contracts," says that everyone contemplating marriage should consider drawing up a prenuptual agreement.

title: Sports of The Times; The Biggest Baseball Dealer
description: Along Main Street here, baseball memorabilia fills the window of the National Pastime gallery not far from the Short Stop restaurant. In the Pro Image Photo store, you can wear a real major league uniform while your picture is taken. And at T.J's restaurant with its Home Plate memorabilia counters, above a few items related to baseball's notorious exile, a Pete Rose autographed Cincinnati Reds jersey hangs high. Like Pete Rose himself.

title: Rutgers Women Are Upset, 77-68
description: George Washington shot 62 percent from the field in the first half and went on to stun Rutgers, 77-68, this afternoon, handing the Lady Knights their second successive loss.

title: No Headline
description: Nearly four months after the director of the city's Office of Latino Affairs resigned, saying he lacked access to Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Mayor has appointed a Citibank executive and former Congressional aide to the post.

title: A Coffin for Mihailovic
description: THE RAPE OF SERBIA The British Role in Tito's Grab for Power, 1943-1944. By Michael Lees. 384 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Dr. Lee Schlesinger;
The Bible as a Literary Anthology
description: LEE SCHLESINGER has never taken a Bible course, yet for the last nine years his course on the Bible at the State University of New York at Purchase has drawn increasing numbers of students, from 16 to 85 years old.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AND THE SEA WILL TELL By Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. Norton, $22.95.

title: Jolie's Halo Takes Donn Handicap
description: The big horse, Unbridled, was back in the barn healing his bruised front foot this afternoon. But, in his absence, a new star soared across the racing scene when Jolie's Halo won the Donn Handicap by eight lengths at Gulfstream Park in a wire-to-wire performance that opened the new American Championship Racing Series for older horses.

title: Mozart by the Yard For the Bicentennial
description: This is The Mozart year -- the bicentennial of his death -- and Lincoln Center, with great fanfare, has already begun its live play-everything-he-ever-wrote festival. Not surprisingly, record companies, with somewhat less fanfare, have noticed the anniversary too. Mozart releases are never in short supply, but there has been an exceptionally active schedule for the occasion, in the usual way: one disk at a time.

title: Campus Life: Kenyon; Housing Policy Changes the Rules For Fraternities
description: A new housing policy that di minishes the longstanding control of the best places to live by fraternities and similar groups was announced last month by Kenyon College.

title: Deborah Lynch To Wed T. J. Cook
description: The engagement of Deborah Ann Lynch to Timothy John Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Cook of Cassington, Oxfordshire, England, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Lynch of Scarsdale, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Bob Marley and the Wailers: 'Talkin' Blues' Tuff Gong/Island 422-848-243; all three formats.

title: Talking: Tax Strategy; Turning A Loss to Advantage
description: IN the past, most tax strategies for the sale of a personal residence assumed that there would be a profit on the transaction. This is no longer true; in today's weaker market, many homes are being sold at a loss.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: YANKEES IN THE LAND OF THE GODS Commodore Perry and the Opening of Japan. By Peter Booth Wiley with Korogi Ichiro. Viking, $24.95.

title: Violence Against Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer D. Stein, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Stein of Williamsville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Diane Stein to Charles Todd Kumble, a son of Barbara K. Kumble of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Steven J. Kumble of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Reprising a Tempestuous Pianist's Life
description: VICTOR BORGE and Dudley Moore have done it, but they weren't playing a part. Julie Harris, as Emily Dickinson, and Hal Holbrook, as Mark Twain, have done it, but they weren't playing the piano.

title: Leafs Top Islanders
description: Bob Rouse had a goal and an assist tonight, and Peter Zezel assisted on two of three second-period power-play goals to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: Lasting Truths of 'White America'
description: A FAINT but recognizable American flag is outlined in black and white across the entire back wall of the stage, from side to side and floor to flies.

title: Style Makers; Zully Alvarado, Orthopedic Shoe Designer
description: Orthopedic shoes often inspire nicknames like "space shoes" and "bricks," such is their clunky appearance.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Old Saybrook, Conn. 100,000 12 Second Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old Cape Cod; views of marsh and river, dining room, 1-car garage, 670 square feet; taxes $667. Westport, Conn. 379,000 38 Red Coat Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; picturesque site, possible 3d bedroom, 1 acre; taxes $3,351. Weston, Conn. 345,000 14 Beaver Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; 4 levels, exceptional views, oversized rooms, 2 acres; taxes $5,109. Bedford, N.Y. 370,000 182 Cedar Hill 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, new kitchen, family room, 2.9 acres; taxes $5,695. Bronxville, N.Y. 540,000 321 Pondfield Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, country eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $12,948. Pound Ridge, N.Y. 325,000 Rolling Meadow Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-level family room, decks; taxes $4,495. OTHER AREAS Jackson, N.J. 157,000 25 Chelsea Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old contemporary; deck, family room, patio, fireplace; taxes $4,015. Manalapan, N.J. 171,000 11 Locust Grove Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split level; 1-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, patio, h/w floors; taxes $2,932. West Hempstead, L.I. 151,000 36 Norton Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement; taxes $3,900.

title: NEW YORK LAYOFFS START, IN REVERSE
description: The first of more than 1,200 New York City employees due to be laid off by the end of the month were let go on Friday -- but within a few hours their bosses were scrambling to get some of them back.

title: A Misfit in Korea
description: FESTIVAL FOR THREE THOUSAND MAIDENS By Richard Wiley. 226 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: QUICK! WHAT'S A QUARK?
description: If our kids are too lazy, or too misguided, to learn how the world in which they live hangs together, they will pay throughout their lives with a lower standard of living. What really frightens me is that our lawmakers have no idea whether, say, their environmental laws make sense. They must rely on overspecialized experts who, for a fee, will prove that the earth is getting warmer, Or, with equal profundity, colder. MAX J. SCHINDLER Boonton, N.J.

title: Miss Kauff and Eric Feiner Are Wed
description: Nancy Lynn Kauff, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip L. Kauff of Yardley, Pa., and Eric Jay Feiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin H. Feiner of Edison, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi David E. Straus and Cantor David S. Wisnia officiated at Har Sinai Temple in Trenton.

title: Sarah Wood to Wed Ronald Siracusa
description: The engagement of Sarah Jane Wood to Ronald J. Siracusa has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Wood of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Joseph Siracusa of San Diego and the late Patricia Siracusa. A September wedding is planned.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 16-19

title: England
description: To the Editor: Thank you for your coverage (Travel Advisory, Jan. 13) of the Gatwick and Heathrow Sterling Hotels.

title: The Housatonic, the Little Railroad That Could, and Did
description: NINE years ago, John Hanlon Jr. heard about an overgrown, abandoned railroad line from New Milford to Canaan. With an entrepreneur's vision, he imagined the tracks cleared and trains again bringing passengers and freight from northwest Connecticut to Manhattan.

title: Wall Street's Steadfast Faith In the Airlines
description: Markets can be so inconvenient. No sooner did George Bush point to the stock market rally as evidence that the recession will be short and shallow than the rally began to sputter.

title: Shadow of War Over Paris
description: "WHAT'S wrong here?" asked an American child, arriving in his father's arms for nursery school at the American Church on the Quai d'Orsay, and encountering a security guard at the door. French children too peered anxiously over their heavy scarves.

title: World Markets; The Yin-Yang of Rates and Earnings
description: Stock markets around the world rallied last week and several analysts declared that the bear market was over. It will take some time for these bulls to be proved right. In the meantime, the markets are likely to move up and down in response to a tug of war between falling interest rates and falling company earnings.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Ossining, N.Y., on Jan. 27 referred incorrectly to the village's triplex cinema. It has closed.

title: As the Recession Deepens, Hunger Is Moving to the Suburbs
description: ON a recent chilly Saturday, 69 people -- a dozen or more of them children, many of them women with tired faces -- sat at long tables in a church basement eating spaghetti and meatballs. At the local soup kitchen, lunch is served every Saturday.

title: Ms. Allston-Wright, Speech Expert, Is Wed to Edward Lewis, Publisher
description: Carolyn Allston-Wright and Edward Lewis were married yesterday at the Equitable Tower in New York. The Rev. Calvin Butts, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, performed the ceremony.

title: Those Windsor Girls
description: ROYAL SISTERS: Queen Elizabeth II and Princess Margaret. By Anne Edwards. (Morrow, $22.95.) Elizabeth, the firstborn, was a serious child suited by temperament to the splendors and miseries of royalty; she liked dogs and horses. Margaret, four years younger, was a freer spirit;

title: POSTINGS: Reviewing the Review; Environmental Quality
description: When it comes to planning policy in New York, there are few things on which almost everyone agrees. One of them is that the City Environmental Quality Review process -- known by the acronym CEQR (pronounced SEEK-er) -- needs revision.

title: Advice Every Investor Should Ignore
description: I Have been advising people about how to invest their money for 38 years. What I have learned is simple: You have to forget about forecasting the markets and the professionals who say they can.

title: Television Without Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Speedy Johnson Races to the Top
description: He is nearly 25 years old, looks younger and has an altar boy demeanor. He is earning $1,750,000 this season and will reach $2,750,000 in 1995 as part of his seven-year, $15 million contract. Not bad for someone who grew up in the poor section of Sacramento, Calif., thinking baseball rather than basketball.

title: Rose Aside, Let's Talk Perry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Free Acres Journal; A Haven Where Residents Own the Houses but Not the Land
description: COMMUTERS cruising along Interstate 78 as it slices through the Watchung Mountains are likely to be unaware that they have just passed through one of the most unusual little communities in New Jersey.

title: Sludge: New Focus On Recycling
description: THE day is near, officials and environmentalists say, when the waste flushed down kitchen sinks, toilets and industrial drains will be filtered, processed, packaged and ultimately sold as fertilizer, ground cover and even decorative mulch to be spread around shrubs and flower beds.

title: Devils Can't Beat The N.H.L.'s Worst
description: The annual winter carnival in this city apparently didn't put the Devils in the right spirit this afternoon. Playing a listless game against the worst team in the league, the Devils suffered a 3-1 defeat at the hands of the Nordiques at the Colisee.

title: The Guardians of Pound Ridge's Attic
description: IN the 1740's, a family named Crawford sailed from Ireland to the Colonies. The mother, who had one toddler and a baby due, traveled with a blue wool shawl with a paisley border.

title: Modernism's Tragic Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Harper To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Marion Clay Harper Jr. of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Victoria Harper, to Richard Mestres Moeser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Moeser of Cincinnati. A June wedding is planned.

title: What Agency Will Supply Energy After Shoreham?
description: COMPETING plans for providing electricity to Long Island are making two state authorities compete with each other.

title: Being the Big Guy; Actor John Goodman: Funny and Formidable
description: It's 2 in the morning in the Hollywood Hills and Monte Kuklenski, Chuck Louis, Kenny Ralph Harper and John Goodman are at the bar in Goodman's den, nursing the last beers in the house and their memories of the true glory days when all were drama students at Southwest Missouri State University. And, although one is now making his living driving a limo, another is a part-time caterer and a third has a desk job with a television network, no one seems to miss their old college triumphs more than Goodman.

title: Mamet Views Cops Through a New Lens
description: Dressed in faded jeans and work boots, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and film maker David Mamet seems very much at home in the abandoned Public Waterworks building, where he is shooting his third film, "Homicide."

title: New Home for National Art Museum of Sport
description: The National Art Museum of Sport, founded in New York in 1959 before spending 10 years in Madison Square Garden and then moving to the University of New Haven in Connecticut, has a new home in Indianapolis. An inaugural exhibition through April 20, entitled "Sport in Art From American Museums," features 70 paintings and sculptures by artists like Thomas Eakins, George Bellows, Paul Cadmus, Marjorie Phillips, Andrew Wyeth, Elaine de Kooning and Andy Warhol. Among the paintings are William Ranney's "Duck Shooting" (1856) and Winslow Homer's "Trappers Resting" (1874).

title: Camera
description: Sometimes ad writers get under my skin. How's this headline sound: "Talent? Who Needs It?" The ad is for the Noritsu Autostudio, an all-in-one portrait outfit that's meant to appeal to the mini-lab market. (Noritsu, in case you don't know of it, also manufactures film-processing and printing machines that mini-labs use.)

title: It's Not Easy Being Friends
description: LOVE WITHOUT WINGS Some Friendships in Literature and Politics. By Louis Auchincloss. 187 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: The Executive Computer; A New Sidekick For a Modern World
description: Borland International Inc. has completely revamped Sidekick, turning its popular program into an executive organizing tool. Version 2.0, introduced last month, bears little resemblance to the original programmers' grab bag that sold more than a million copies and became synonymous with utilities and memory-resident software.

title: Cards to Help the Tongue-Tied
description: Greeting cards of all kinds fill the racks at the Thoughtfulness Gallery, a stationery store in the financial district of Manhattan. Right beside the Happy Birthday section is one for Congratulations, and one aisle over is Get Well. A few steps away, Be My Valentine is in season, here gushing sentimentality from a lace-trimmed heart, there snickering about a racy suggestion.

title:
ART;
One Man's Vision Combines Three Worlds
description: EARLY in the 1980's, a breath of fresh air entered the New York art world in the form of the Three C's. The Italian artists Sandro Chia, Enzo Cucchi and Francesco Clemente were all brilliantly bold yet temptingly recondite. All three have persisted as mainstays of the contemporary art world, but Mr. Clemente is the most redoubtable. A retrospective of his work, "Francesco Clemente: Three Worlds," is currently at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. The hefty show is culled from an even larger one at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where it originated.

title: Air Traffic Controllers Fight Stress and Savor It
description: What bothers Harold Whitehead is not a radar screen congested with blinking spots, each representing a tube of people dropping down from the sky toward a lane of asphalt.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare in a Sophisticated Setting
description: THE Eastern goldfinch may be the state bird and the violet the state flower, but if New Jersey has a cuisine to call its own, hands down it would be Italian.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: The Willistons
description: A SIMPLE wooden sign on the East Williston village green carries this homily by Abraham Lincoln: "I like to see a man proud of the place in which he lives."

title: U.S. COMMANDERS REPORTED TO CALL FOR A 3--WEEK DELAY BEFORE A GROUND OFFENSIVE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that the Persian Gulf war was threatening to go beyond the mandate set by the United Nations, and said he was sending a personal envoy to Baghdad to appeal to President Saddam Hussein to end the war.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Taos
description: For the traveler approaching Taos from the south, there is a sudden sense of light and space on emerging from the Rio Grande valley onto the high desert of northern New Mexico. From the dark blue mass of Taos Mountain on the east to distant horizons on the north and west, the gray-green expanse sparkles with remnants of winter blizzards. A deep slash several miles long marks the river's path about 300 feet below. The rest of the view is huge sky.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Robert M. Liebert;
How Children React to Graphic Violence on TV, Real and Fake
description: THE television coverage of the gulf war is re-igniting debates on the effects on children of graphic depictions of violence. Scenes showing missiles exploding over cities and people rushing to bomb shelters with gas masks deliver images of war into children's homes.

title: Dr. Prussin Wed To Ivan Barkhorn
description: Dr. Rebecca Ann Prussin, a psychiatrist, and Ivan Barkhorn, a management consultant, were married yesterday at their home in New York in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Marie de Young, a Unitarian minister. Dr. Barkhorn is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Simon Prussin of Los Angeles. Her husband is a son of Adelaide Eby and Richard Barkhorn, both of New York.

title: Shortwave Radios
description: To the Editor: A few clarifications are in order regarding shortwave radios (Practical Traveler, Dec. 2). Although the wavelengths associated with shortwave signals are shorter than those from commercial AM stations, they are actually much longer than those from commercial FM stations. While shortwave signals often reflect off the ionosphere, FM signals will generally penetrate the ionosphere and continue out into space.

title: Colleges Cut Travel By Students
description: THOMAS C. DUFFY, the director of Yale University's bands, said he was relieved at first when the United States State Department told him that simple precautions would reduce the risk of a terrorist attack during the concert band's upcoming tour of Eastern Europe. But when he discovered that the simple measures included hiring dogs to sniff concert halls for bombs, he balked, Mr. Duffy said. Deciding that a group of 70 American students with a publicized itinerary would make a tempting terrorist target, he canceled the trip on Jan. 21.

title: O.K., O.K., Call Me a Protectionist
description: There is no use hiding anymore. I'm tired of denying it, and turning my back every time I hear those dirty little whispers. Since some people are cruel enough to say it to my face, it's time to get the truth out.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Case of Missing Flags

title: Ideas & Trends; Learning to Live With Other Religions
description: OVER the centuries, Christians in scores of countries have launched more than 780 plans to convert the world to their faith. David Barrett and James Reapsome, the evangelical researchers who tallied these efforts, found that most such plans expired within a few years, but that more than 50 "multimillion-dollar megaplans" are still afoot, many of them setting the year 2000, the new millennium, as their deadline.

title: Review/Music; Collegiate Chorale in Rossini's 'Petite Messe Solennelle'
description: On the manuscript of his "Petite Messe Solennelle" (1863), Rossini wrote, "Twelve singers of three sexes -- men, women and castrati -- will be enough for its performance: that is, eight for the chorus, four for the solos, a total of twelve cherubim."

title: 'All His Jazz'
description: To the Editor:

title: Discouraging Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Bennington to Bronx: Canvases Span the Gap
description: FROM Bennington to Hunts Point: the journey is not as long as Gen. Colin Powell's from youth in this Bronx neighborhood to pre-eminence in the Pentagon. Still, the presence of five Bennington graduates at the Krasdale Foods Art Gallery here is an event not to be sneezed at. Moreover, theirs is the first show here confined to conference rooms and lobbies, as opposed to the previous spectacles that have spilled over into the corridor dividing the office space. The modification makes for much easier viewing.

title: Chess
description: Chess is a game in which to hearken back to the good old days is often to be right up with the latest trend in strategy. There are several reaons for this.

title: Advice Given on Getting Property Tax Rebates
description: LOW-INCOME and moderate-income homeowners and tenants and many of the elderly can receive up to $500 from the New Jersey homestead property tax rebate of 1990, the state said. To obtain the refund, applicants must file a New Jersey 1040 tax return even if they do not have sufficient income to pay state taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/February 3-8
description: THE ECONOMY Help From Washington for America's Humbled Banks Laws passed decades ago to restrict the big American banks might now be rewritten to help save them. What a change in the bankers' image: from heartless oppressors, vilified in American literature and film, to bumbling spendthrifts and lenders to hopeless causes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady presented a plan on Tuesday for the first overhaul of the banking system since the Depression. While the laws have remained fixed, the banking world has changed. Foreign banks, once cowed by their American rivals, now account for 29 of the 30 largest in the world. Markets as small as a city or state, once dependable, now are too limited and volatile for consistent profits. Restrictions on underwriting securities and a ban on bank ownership by other industries, once essential limits on banks' influence and risk, now are accelerating their decline. Congressional opposition to several features of the plan is inevitable. Many lawmakers come from states that have restricted the ability of banks to branch out even across county lines. But as Federal officials scramble to bail out the bank insurance fund and loosen bank credit, they recognize that the financing of the nation's businesses and consumers is at stake. Stripping the F.D.I.C. of Power If you can't hit the soldier, shoot at his horse: the Administration's proposed banking laws would strip L. William Seidman's Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation of its regulatory powers. The plan would split the F.D.I.C.'s authority over banks between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, leaving Mr. Seidman to meekly watch over his dwindling bank insurance fund. Fast as a House Budget Committee microphone could be switched on, he was ready to denounce the plan as "an invitation to regulatory civil war." In a skirmish last year, the Bush Administration tried to topple Mr. Seidman from his post; his term runs until October. An Optimistic Budget The din of war and the plaints of recession echo only faintly through the 1992 Bush budget. The $1.45 billion budget he submitted to Congress on Monday counts on an end to the recession by mid-year and allied aid so generous that the Persian Gulf war will cost the nation only $12.8 billion. Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the Administration will probably have to ask for more war money in a few months. The President, painted by the Democrats as the protector of the undeserving rich, hopes to maneuver them into defending some breaks for the wealthy. He wants to limit subsidies to the rich for agriculture, Medicare, school lunches and student aid -- programs dear to many Democratic politicians. Productivity Gains - at a Cost If American factories have truly become more efficient, why all the dismal, shuttered Youngstowns and Flints? The Commerce Department said last week that manufacturing productivity climbed at a record 3.6 percent annual rate in the 1980's, matching trading partners' gains. A service economy it may be, but as productivity among white-collar workers stagnates, manufacturing accounts for an increasing, 23.3 percent share of the nation's output. But the decade's improvements in plant efficiency have come with the loss of two million jobs. Industries like textiles have reversed their fortunes by automating, but far lower employment is the result. Nobody would comfort a small, failing farmer by saying that the success of the vast, mechanized spread next-door was all for the good. Manufacturing productivity likewise comes at a cost. California Runs Dry You farm where there's no rain from April through November, build cities hundreds of miles from the needed water supplies, and sooner or later you're going to run dry. After five years of drought, California's state water project has cut off supplies to Central Valley farmers. Rationing is already the rule in southern California. Several economists estimate that losses to the state's farmers, food processors and factories that depend on inexpensive water will reach $3 billion. This in the nation's most populous and agriculturally productive state. A Whole New Computer Game A powerful group of companies aims to redesign the personal computer from the chip up. Microsoft, Compaq and Digital are nearing an agreement to produce computers and software based on chips designed by MIPS Computer Systems. The group's main targets appear to be International Business Machines and Apple, which have their own personal computer standards, and Sun Microsystems, which makes competing chips.

title: Headliners; Laws of Science
description: Beginning in 1973, Dr. Eugene Dong, an associate professor of cardiovascular surgery at Stanford University, unsuccessfully pursued a case against a fellow professor he accused of falsifying data in order to obtain Federal research grants. In the process he earned a law degree and is now representing another scientist who has accused a former colleague of fraud. The plaintiff, J. Thomas Condie, has accused Dr. John L. Ninnemann of obtaining almost $1.3 million in grants from the National Institutes of Health by making false statements about his research. Also named in the suit are the two universities where Dr. Ninnemann worked when he obtained the grants, the University of Utah and the University of California at San Diego. And, in an unusual twist, Dr. Condie will be joined in his suit by the Justice Department, which is seeking triple damages. Under the Federal False Claims Act, a private citizen can sue those who commit fraud against the Government and collect 25 percent of any penalty assessed.

title: Harry L. Towe, 92, A Former Congressman
description: Harry Lancaster Towe, a former Congressman and deputy attorney general of New Jersey, died on Friday at his home in Lakewood, N.J. He was 92 years old.

title: The World; As Soviet Borders Open, the West Braces for an Economic Exodus
description: THE withering of the Soviet empire and the economic strains that accompany it may produce the largest migration since World War II, demographers say, and that will present Western governments that have long pressed Moscow to open its frontiers with the uncomfortable problem of what to do about a flood of would-be immigrants.

title: Crane Festival In Colorado
description: Tens of thousands of sandhill cranes stop in the San Luis Valley of southern Colorado every March on their annual trek from Texas to Canada. Bird watchers are also treated to glimpses of the endangered whooping cranes, which travel with the sandhill flock.

title: Me and the Mob and the Music
description: IVORY JOE By Martyn Burke. 303 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HOLLYWOOD: A Novel of America in the 1920s, by Gore Vidal. (Ballantine, $5.95.) By writing about Hollywood's Golden Age and what was going on in Washington, Gore Vidal has come up with a novel whose cast of characters includes Woodrow Wilson, Charlie Chaplin, Mary Pickford, Henry James, Warren G. Harding and Fatty Arbuckle. The result is "a wonderfully literate and consistently impressive work of fiction that clearly belongs on a shelf with the author's best earlier efforts," Joel Connarroe said here last year.

title: Using Borrowed Money to Defend Foreign Economies
description: To the Editor:

title: OUR TOYS ARE US
description: Yes, our children should be protected from greedy advertisers; yes, many toys glorify violence and wasteful consumerism; true, it's hard to say "no" to your child when every other kid in the sandbox has one. Nevertheless, I suspect we're secretly glad when our children turn out to be rather typical for their age, because that means they are like the other kids and will probably be liked by them, thank God. CAROLYN KOHLI Brooklyn

title: War Summary
description: A DAY OF ASSESSMENT

title: Life, Loss, Death And 'Thirtysomething'
description: Death, as Hollywood cynics are prone to snipe, can be a wise career move. Just look at the smarties over at "Thirty something." It's not for nothing that the show's producers have decorated the reception area of their offices with a Mad magazine spoof titled "Thirtysuffering." As in an Ingmar Bergman film, it's almost as if a black-hooded figure has become another character on the ABC series, lurking in the background and waiting for just the right moment to strike.

title: OUR TOYS ARE US
description: While it is true that there is too much violence in every aspect of popular culture, the play of children is not political. Many other developmental issues are being worked out here. Parents who refuse to buy toy guns for their children often find them running around the playground shooting with their fingers.

title: The Executive Life; Cancel That Meeting, It's Friday the 13th!
description: Several years ago, when George Wasserberger was chairman of the luxury-goods purveyor Mark Cross & Company, he made a crucial mistake: He arrived at an important meeting wearing one black shoe and one brown shoe.

title: POSTINGS: New Plant in Harlem; Expanding a Doll House
description: Beatrice Behrman began making rag dolls in 1923 and by 1930 they had developed molded heads and limbs, eyelashes, fingers and the grand name their creator had assumed: Madame Alexander Dolls.

title: Virtue All Around in Handel's 'Susanna'
description: It is often claimed that the current obsession with historical performance styles has produced little more than a new frisson in the experiencing of old, familiar works. But in certain areas, the adoption of playing techniques and performing styles based, however loosely, on the models of previous ages has opened up of huge tracts of repertory previously thought impenetrable and impractical.

title: Clemens Gives Mets Dilemma
description: Craig Fenech, agent for Frank Viola, considered the record contract signed by Roger Clemens on Friday and said, "I'm probably having a better weekend than Al."

title: Julia L. Blewer, Banker, Is Wed To Rev. R. J. Cox
description: Julia Livingston Blewer, a daughter of Sondra Gerdau Blewer of New York and Sugar Hill, N.H., and John M. Blewer of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to the Rev. Robert John Cox, a Southern Baptist minister who is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Theodore O. Cox of Evansville, Ind.

title: Requiring Helmets For Young Skiers
description: Re: "Ski Industry Wary of Move on Helmets for Children," Jan. 13:

title: The Nation: Nature Humbles a State of Mind; 5-Year Drought Is Only the Latest Trouble in Paradise
description: CALIFORNIANS yet again have cause to ponder the consequences of the profligacy, recklessness and greed that have long dulled the California dream of hope, renewal and optimism. In what the historian Kevin Starr has called "the intensified pursuit of human happiness" that marks the energetic history of California, insult after insult has been inflicted on this earthly paradise. The great Gold Rush left the mountains scarred like a battlefield. Lumbermen denuded the magnificent stands of redwood to the point that the few remaining trees are tourist curiosities. Automobiles have exhausted the air of Southern California. And now, it seems, the water is nearly all gone.

title: Campus Life: Stanford; Task Force Seeks Revised Handling Of Rape Charges
description: In a series of recommendations to cope with the problem of acquaintance rape, a Stanford University task force is proposing the creation of a coordinator to oversee the univerity's responses to complaints of sexual assault. It is also proposing fundamental changes in Stanford's judicial policy. University officials, however, said that Stanford lacked the money to hire a coordinator.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 20 about corporations' efforts to help municipalities cope with medical emergencies referred incorrectly to the program run by the Chubb Group of Insurance Companies in Warren Township. It already operates; it began last April.

title: Stephanie Fried to Wed R. O. Senzer; Deborah Savitz to Wed R. A. Senzer
description: March wedding plans for Stephanie Gayle Fried and Robert Owen Senzer, and June wedding plans for Deborah Renee Savitz and Richard Adam Senzer, have been announced by the prospective brides' parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Fried of Forest Hills, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Savitz of Philadelphia. The prospective bridegrooms, who are twins, are sons of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Senzer of Roslyn, L.I.

title: Liza Reed to Wed Thomas M. O'Reilly
description: Elizabeth Jane Reed, a sports marketing executive in New York, and Thomas Michael O'Reilly, a banker in Boston, plan to marry in July.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 10, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 9 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 2 2 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures. 3 3 THE CONQUEST, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $5.50.) Romance bonds two long-feuding feudal families in 15th-century England. 4 3 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) A physician struggles to clear his name. 5 2 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $6.95.) The history of the sea islands told in fictional form. 6 2 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Warner, $5.95.) Adam Dalgliesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 7 17 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 8 25 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 9 * 5 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Signet, $5.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. 10 7 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving ceremonial masks. 11 17 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $5.95.) Glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 12 2 MERCY, by David L. Lindsey. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Houston detective on the trail of a killer. 13 12 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 14 * 1 SECRET SONG, by Catherine Coulter. (Onyx, $4.95.) A handsome rogue sets out to rescue a young woman imprisoned in a stronghold in 13th-century Britain. 15 15 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 16 * 9 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 26 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 2 4 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) The ordeal of an American woman held captive in Iran by a hostile husband. 3 2 THE RAPE OF KUWAIT, by Jean P. Sasson. (Knightsbridge, $4.95.) The invasion of Kuwait as observed by people who witnessed it and escaped. 4 2 SADDAM HUSSEIN AND THE CRISIS IN THE GULF, by Judith Miller and Laurie Mylroie. (Times Books/Random House, $5.95.) A report on the Iraqi President and his invasion of Kuwait. 5 64 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 6 1 REPUBLIC OF FEAR, by Samir al-Khalil. (Pantheon, $12.95.) An expatriate Iraqi scholar's account of life in his homeland during the reign of Saddam Hussein. 7 * 22 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 8 * 1 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Avon, $5.95.) Prognostications about political, economic and social developments during the next decade. 9 * 381 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 10 11 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Cliff Stoll. (Pocket, $5.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 11 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 2 8 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 3 28 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 4 119 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 9 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Commercial Property: East Side Rehabilitation; Creating New Roles For Art Deco Buildings
description: IF not alpha, there was at least omega, and many others besides: lambda, rho, delta, gamma, theta, zeta and pi. Hidden almost three decades behind a "modern" travertine facade, these deeply carved Greek letters came surprisingly to light during the renovation of the Beekman Tower Hotel.

title: If Those Floors Squeak
description: A SQUEAKING floor is annoying, but seldom a sign of serious trouble. Most squeaks are caused by loosened floorboards, subflooring or the joists underneath, and repairs are usually easy to make.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We wallpapered our bathroom with a solid vinyl, and the edges are now peeling. The walls are plaster, which we covered with wallpaper lining and then primed. We overlapped the vinyl wallpaper strips by about one-eighth inch, and these edges are curling back. I tried several adhesives, but none held up for long. Some places will not stick down at all. Any suggestions?

title: Italy's Freeing of 2 in Ship Hijacking Splits Cabinet
description: An early release given to two Palestinians imprisoned in connection with the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985 has splintered Italy's governing coalition, with one party protesting that the action "borders on the grotesque."

title: Judge Restricts Exxon Liability In Valdez Spill
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the Exxon Corporation is liable to pay civil damages only to those who suffered direct economic losses from the nation's worst oil spill.

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: Given the bad press airlines have been receiving, I would like to recount a recent positive experience. My wife and I had purchased "nonrefundable" tickets to Turkey on Pan Am for our honeymoon in August. At the time of our wedding, the current Middle East tensions had just begun to develop; in fact, the Turkish Parliament had given the country's President authority to declare war against Iraq. Due to the potentially volatile situation and not a little parental pressure, we chose to go to more peaceful Bermuda.

title: An Aging Dancer Fights to Keep Up
description: Does Silicon Valley have a future?

title: Taking a Timeout To Savor Victory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Looking Beyond War
description: A diplomat says Saudi officials hope the war can end by June, when Muslims make their pilgrimage to Mecca. And as the Bush Administration maps postwar strategy, it finds others also want to play architect.

title: Is Victory Over Iraq Really a Sure Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Iran Positions Itself for Postwar Advantage
description: AYATOLLAH RUHOLLAH KHOMEINI, when he overthrew the Iranian monarchy in 1979, promised an interventionist foreign policy that would establish an Islamic republic in Iraq and toss the rich gulf sheikdoms into "the dustbin of history."

title: Defense in Love-Triangle Killing Attacks Inquiry
description: The victim's husband was allowed to wash her blood from his hands. Her former lover was never fingerprinted. The prosecution's key witness told the police four different stories, and they believed him each time.

title: 50 Percent Drop In Americans Visiting London
description: London hotels are cutting back on overtime for employees and not replacing people who leave because of the downturn in travel, particularly from the United States, British tourist officials say, adding that for the visitor things are less crowded at restaurants and tourist attractions and at theaters, where tickets are now easier to get.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Notebook; Metal Detectors and Bomb-Sniffing Dogs
description: From a security viewpoint, the National Basketball Association All-Star Game here Sunday will look similar to the Super Bowl last month in Tampa, Fla.

title: Henry James Among the Philosophers
description: LOVE'S KNOWLEDGE Essays on Philosophy and Literature. By Martha C. Nussbaum. 403 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: 'Trust Me, Babe, It's Gonna Be Our Year'
description: "Sure, babe, trust me."

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Witches 1990. Warner. $92.95. Laser disk, $24.98. 1 hour, 32 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Checking into an English resort, nine-year-old Luke (Jasen Fisher) and his grandmother stumble upon a witches' convention disguised as a meeting of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and chaired by the Grand Royal High Witch (Anjelica Huston). Caught observing the crones during a secret session, Luke is turned into a mouse but rallies to save his contemporaries from a similar fate. A "brilliantly told bedtime story," Nicolas Roeg's tale "makes a fanciful film for savvy children." (Caryn James) Days of Thunder 1990. Paramount. $91.95. LD, $34.95. 1:47. CC. PG-13. As the stock-car driver Cole Trickle, Tom Cruise leads the boys-will-be-boys horseplay in Tony Scott's film about Mr. Cruise and race cars. Robert Duvall and Randy Quaid are on hand for the pit stops, as are cheering fans, picturesque rural Americana and "enough upbeat soundtrack music to generate toe-tapping in the dead." (Janet Maslin) Darkman 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. LD, $34.98. 1:35. CC. R. A disfigured scientist named Westlake (Liam Neeson) sheathes himself in synthetic skin to battle evil in Sam Raimi's thriller, with a comic-book look reminiscent of "Batman." Plenty of action and spectacular effects try to lift a film that "sustains mild interest but never takes off, partly because a real estate scam, gangland shootouts and city corruption clutter up the sad story of Westlake's strange mutation." (James) Flatliners 1990. RCA/Columbia. $91.95. LD, $34.95. 1:51. CC. R. Kiefer Sutherland and Julia Roberts are medical students who place themselves in a deathlike state in order to experience the afterlife. A foggy atmosphere pervades as the director Joel Schumacher creates a "stylish, eerie psychological horror film that thrives on its characters' guilty secrets." (James)

title: Minniefield Sentenced
description: Dirk Minniefield, a former Kentucky basketball standout, has been ordered to serve a 12-month sentence for violating probation.

title: Island of Catastrophe
description: THE SCISSOR MANBy Jean Arnold.287 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Why Rich New York Is So Poor
description: In his latest budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York proposes sizable cuts in Medicaid, local aid and the state payroll, which fiscal conservatives have been urging for years. Yet even after these cuts are in place, New York will still be spending more per capita and relative to income than most other states. And the Governor's tax increases insure New York's standing as one of the highest taxed states in the nation. Mr. Cuomo has to do better.

title: Is Victory Over Iraq Really a Sure Thing?; Use Tear Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Tax Urged for Some Products
description: The Worldwatch Institute, a leading environmental research group, said today that governments should impose heavy taxes on "products and activities that pollute, deplete or otherwise degrade natural systems."

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Serving the Affluent With Upscale Malls
description: DESPITE falling retail sales and rising shop vacancies, Long Island continues to be one of the most attractive areas in the country to developers of retail space.

title: Anniversary for Emerson Quartet
description: THE Emerson String Quartet, in addition to its worldwide schedule of concert appearances, is celebrating its 10th anniversary as ensemble in residence at the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford in West Hartford.

title: Food; That Old Poisoned Arrow
description: It was in 1979 when, suffering from late-70's malaise, a writer friend I'll call Hemingway and I took off from college and headed south from Boston down I-95, the long cord connected to the toaster that is Florida. Hemingway, who'd been dipping into the writings of guess who, chattered the whole way down about going to Key West and eating conch chowder -- pronouncing conch with the final "ch" instead of "konk," as the locals do. He also smoked clove cigarettes.

title: Stately Homes and Gardens
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Rocketing
description: He got his nickname running track as a youngster, so it should come as no surprise that Raghib (the Rocket) Ismail should be getting a little exercise with the Notre Dame track team as he awaits the National Football League draft in April.

title: Rookie Wins Dunk Contest
description: At 6 feet 1 inch, Dee Brown was the shortest competitor in tonight's National Basketball Association slam-dunk contest. But he was also the best.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Residential Resales column on Feb. 3 misstated the status of the town house at 34 West 87th Street. It is a four-family, not a one-family, structure.
