title: Miss Carley Weds W. M. Brancucci
description: Eileen Ann Carley, a daughter of Janet C. Carley of Wayne, N.J., and the late James P. Carley, was married yesterday to William M. Brancucci, the son of Margaret F. Brancucci of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Philip A. Brancucci. The Rev. James Rugel performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church in Wayne.

title: Cozying Up to the Psychopath That Lurks Deep Within
description: The perversely twisted mind has always been a favorite subject of storytellers. From Iago to Norman Bates, Dr. Jekyll to Harry Lime, Vladimir Nabokov's Humbert Humbert to David Lynch's Leland Palmer/Bob, the logic of villainy has been fictionally explored, on the page, the stage and the screen, over and over. Even when failed by their powers of sheer imagining, writers and actors have drawn inspiration from grim reality: Jack the Ripper, Lizzie Borden, Dick and Perry, Gary Gilmore, Charles Manson, not to mention Adolf Hitler, Joseph Stalin and Richard III. By now, Saddam Hussein is undoubtedly a twinkle in some wordsmith's eye.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LAND WAS OURS A Novel of the Great Plains.By Charles W. Bailey.Cornelia and Michael Bessie/HarperCollins,

title: Tech Notes; Maser for Radar
description: Masers are to microwaves what lasers are to light. Both devices concentrate diffuse waves of energy into tightly focused beams of the same wavelength, intensifying their power. Now, Igor Alexeff, a professor of engineering at the University of Tennessee, has built a prototype maser for generating high-frequency microwaves for use in radar. The maser's narrow beam produces sharper radar images than are now possible. In Professor Alexoff's prototype, housed in a glass bell jar, a highly charged positive wire excites the electrons in a negatively charged metallic resonator. The negatively charged electrons migrate to the wire, where they emit coherent beams of microwave radiation for the radar signal.

title: Understandable Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan C. Sigda, Banker, Is Wed
description: Susan Catherine Sigda, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Robert Sigda of St. Augustine, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Alexander Lotocki de Veligost, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Borys Lotocki de Veligost of Muralto, Switzerland. The Very Rev. Wolodymyr Bazylevsky performed the ceremony at the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of St. Volodimir, after which the Rev. Dr. John Andrew performed an Episcopal ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: Soviet Military's High Death Rate Draws Scrutiny
description: Soviet Army officials told Yelizaveta Nekrasova that her son Mikhail died suddenly of "18 different sicknesses." They told Yuliya and Fyodor Gubersky that their son Igor became depressed and shot himself to death. They told Anatoly Zubaryev that his son dived into a shallow pool, fatally breaking his neck.

title:
DINING OUT;
Going South of the Border in Larchmont
description: A BIT of Tex added to a lot of Mex describes the style of food diners will find at Hacienda Don Emilio. In its seventh year, the restaurant is a well-ensconced neighborhood eatery with a cadre of regular customers who seem already to have discovered their favorite items and stuck to them.

title: Perspectives: Business Improvement Districts; Banding Together for Local Betterment
description: FIRST they were called special assessment districts. Then, after the adoption of legislation by the New York State Legislature in 1982, they came to be known as business improvement districts. Sometimes the term is special services district.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Kremlin; Excerpts From Statement by Gorbachev on the Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from a statement yesterday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on the war in the Persian Gulf, as provided by the English-language service of Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

title: New Competition in the Sky, And Just in Time for the War
description: Military contractors have not been the only companies to get a lift from the United States-led war against Iraq. The nearly insatiable demand for live television reports about the war has been a bonanza for companies providing satellite services.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charlotte, N.C.; Energizing Golf Projects
description: WHEN Duke Power Company was buying land along the Catawba River years ago to make way for the lakes its dams would create, it had electricity generation in mind. Now a subsidiary is hoping to generate profits by turning some of the utility's land along the Catawba Piedmont of North Carolina into golf-course communities.

title: 'Wrinkles' Depicts An Aged Motley Crew
description: IF memories of acne or the very mention of constipation, hemorrhoids and failing vision strike you as hilarious, there seems no reason to deny yourself the joys of "Wrinkles."

title: The World; The Baltics: More Bolts From the Blue Man In Moscow
description: HURLING decrees from the Kremlin like thunderbolts from Olympus, Mikhail S. Gorbachev presents the image of a busy man these days. Blam! He decrees that Lithuania's plebiscite has no legal standing. Blam! The newly tamed state television network is converted to a state-owned company. Blam! He decrees special honors for veterans of Soviet wars and respect for their monuments. Blam! Blam! Blam! Soldiers patrol the streets, large-denomination ruble bills are yanked, all on the solitary signature of the President.

title:
FOCUS: Boston;
Boston and Builders: The Shoe Is on the Other Foot
description: The downturn in the real estate market has turned the tables on this city's planning officials.

title: JERSEYANA
description: SOMETIME early in the morning of Feb. 26, 1959, Abner Zwillman committed suicide in his mansion at 50 Beverly Road in West Orange.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Some vegetables, including caulifower, lettuce, broccoli, pepper and eggplant can be started from seed indoors this week for early planting in coldframes. Check fruit trees for evidence of damage from mice and if there is any, attach wire mesh to the trunk bottoms. Prune overgrown birches, maples, dogwood, rhododendrons and grapevines. The unseasonably warm weather may have caused bulbs and buds to be especially vulnerable to a cold snap ahead. Only time will tell. Pinching

title:
Focus: Boston;
Weak Market Turns Tables on Planners
description: THE downturn in the real estate market has turned the tables on this city's planning officials.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Shelburne, Vt.; A Complex For the Elderly
description: A LOCAL investors group, a Baltimore developer and an Albany investment banking firm are working to win final legal approvals for construction of the state's first continuous-care retirement community.

title: Sunday Menu; Black-Bean Soup Freezes (and Ages) Well
description: The black-bean soup you are about to make freezes well, so you can make the whole recipe, even if there are only two of you. It also survives in the refrigerator for a week and gets better every time you reheat it.

title: How to Snare Elusive Bargains From Airlines
description: "WITH the current bad economic climate," one travel agent said in New York, "the airlines are not going to offer any specials on any tickets they can sell at a regular price. What they are saying is, 'If you want to travel and you are willing to meet our terms on days and places, you can travel for a cut rate.' "

title: From Chicago to Chelm, Three on the Aisle
description: Would you settle this morning for a TV movie, a resurrected theater and a vaguely philosophical question?

title: Data Update
Watching the War: Viewers on the Front Lines
description: On day four of the war in the Persian Gulf, we had the television on all day, with family members flicking from channel to channel. At one point, the picture was bouncing between the movie "Top Gun" and the coverage of the war. I realized with a start that I couldn't tell which was which. They both had martial music, splendid graphics, high-tech shots of planes soaring into the sky. It was only when Tom Cruise came on the screen that I knew which was the movie. Even then, he didn't look much different from the pilots whose faces I saw on CNN.

title: Data Bank/February 10, 1991
Miss Sadowski to Wed Gerald Patrick Lally
description: August wedding plans for Donna Marie Sadowski and Gerald Patrick Lally, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Lally of Verona, N.J., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sadowski of Suffern, N.Y.

title: The Patriot's Success: Because of 'Star Wars' Or In Spite of It?
description: THE success of the Patriot missile in the Persian Gulf has set off a bitter war of words over whether the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars, has helped or hurt the development of anti-missile defenses. Last week the Bush Administration cited the Patriot's feats when it called for a hefty rise in financing for S.D.I. Yet some experts say the Patriots' fiery destruction of Iraqi Scud missiles in the Middle East has occurred not because of the Star Wars effort but despite it.

title: Coup Attempt Fails in Ciskei
description: A group of army officers tried to seize power today in the nominally independent black homeland of Ciskei, officials said. A member of the military government said the attempt failed.

title: Bringing Haiti's Shattered Economy Back From the Brink
description: When Jacques Auguste returned here in 1960 armed with an engineering degree and visions of founding his own building materials company, he quickly discovered how little of what he had learned at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute prepared him for the rigors of doing business in his native Haiti.

title: Rebecca West: This Time, Let's Listen
description: In a hotel in Belgrade in 1937, Rebecca West watched businessmen at the bar lifting their glasses and slapping each other on the back. "That I might have seen in London or Paris or New York. But in none of those great cities have I seen hotel doors slowly swing open to admit, unhurried and at ease, a peasant holding a black lamb in his arms." There he stood, waiting, "still as a Byzantine king in a fresco, while the black lamb twisted and writhed in the firm cradle of his arms." Rebecca West recorded the image with reverence.

title: MAINLAND THREAT WORRYING TAIWAN
description: No one here seems to expect a military invasion from China soon, but some officials believe the threat of an attack from the mainland may again be increasing.

title: Toddler Is 4th Child To Die From Injuries In a Brooklyn Blaze
description: A 21-month-old girl died yesterday from injuries suffered in a fire that killed three of her cousins on Friday in Brooklyn.

title: In Times Square, Dignity by Day, Glitter by Night
description: In the shotgun marriage of office buildings and honky-tonk that is coming, slowly but steadily, to replace the tawdry Times Square of old, the newly finished skyscraper at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets, represents an achievement of sorts: it is a building that manages to come off more as sleek than showy, more as refined than glitzy. The special zoning laws that were adopted several years ago to preserve some of Times Square's old rakish flavor -- requiring that new office towers have huge advertising signs and special lighting -- have been followed so slyly here that there is no real way to tell that this building is any different from the towers that go up anywhere else in town.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's "Strange Sounds of the Highlands" (Travel, Dec. 16) was delightful; inevitably, there were some interesting things he had to leave out.

title: Johannah Conway To Wed in July
description: The engagement of Johannah Mary Conway to Mario Francis Dottori, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario R. Dottori of Hamden, Conn., has been announced by her parents, John T. Conway of New York and Arlington, Va., and Priscilla K. Conway of Washington. A July wedding is planned.

title: Headliners; Leap of Inspiration
description: His performance of the role of Dr. Coppelius, the mad old dollmaker in "Coppelia," has always been tinged with sadness, said Shaun O'Brien. Last Friday night, though, the sadness was on both sides of the footlights as one of the New York City Ballet's premier actor-dancers made his last appearance. The 65-year-old Mr. O'Brien recalled that George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova had created the City Ballet production of "Coppelia" in 1974, after Suzanne Farrell, a favorite of Balanchine, had left the company, and Mr. O'Brien used the sadness he saw in Balanchine in creating the role of Dr. Coppelius. Some of the inspiration for the other part for which Mr. O'Brien is best known, the kindly Herr Drosselmeyer in "The Nutcracker," came from a figure in another century: the bashful but loving storyteller Hans Christian Andersen. Mr. O'Brien said last week that he was leaving the ballet with a sense of "completeness," but conceded that he might feel "a little twinge around 'Nutcracker' time."

title: Bridge
description: The furore, still bubbling around the world, over the Germany-Canada semifinal at the World Championships in Geneva, Switzerland, in September, has obscured another dramatic episode on the previous day. The unknown German foursome was locked in a close match with a British team that was among the favorites for the title, and the diagramed deal has become a cause celebre in Europe.

title: CUSTOMERS RESIST CHEAPER CABLE TV
description: The two cable television companies in Manhattan are introducing something that might seem guaranteed to please even the most cynical customer: a less expensive form of service.

title: Judge Investigated on Payment to Help Son
description: A Queens judge whose son was arrested after a brawl in a diner is being investigated to determine if a $2,000 payment he made to the diner's owner was a bribe to have the charges reduced, law-enforcement authorities say.

title: Pop Turns the Tables -- With Beefcake
description: So what happened to all the fat guys and wimps in pop music? You used to see herds of them at concerts and on MTV, playing their guitars, surrounded by gorgeous women. Guzzling beer and wearing black T-shirts stretched to the limit, they gave the male audience just the right reinforcement.

title: Schools Making Room For Baby Boomlet
description: AFTER closing hundreds of schools during the past decade, local education officials throughout Connecticut are now considering reopening old buildings and putting up new ones to meet rising enrollments. Crowded classrooms, most prevalent at the elementary level, are the result of higher birthrates in the 1980's and migration into the state during cheerier economic times, says a study from the State Education Department.

title: Fashion; TAKE THE PLUNGE
description: AS A GIRL, ANN OGDEN WAS INFATUATED BY the sleekness and dash of Emma Peel in "The Avengers," the popular television series. Last summer, Ogden rediscovered that same athletic style in a sporting-goods store. Inspired by snug surfing and diving clothes, she created her own scuba-influenced line under the Basco label. Ogden is one of many designers, from Karl Lagerfeld of Chanel to Geoffrey Beene and Donna Karan, who are impressed by the vivid colors, expandable fabrics and functional elegance of clothes made to be worn under water. Lagerfeld has gone so far as to simulate the look of a surfer's suit in its natural element, designing close-fitting jackets covered in sequins for a sea-drenched appearance. The designer Pamela Dennis is fascinated by the hardware, accenting a scuba-style dress with crystal-outlined zippers that open to reveal tantalizing glimpses of bosom and hips. Made of Darlexx, the body-molding, water-repellent material used for scuba suits, her little black dress is more likely to be splashed by brandy than brine. No problem, Dennis promises: "The stains will slide right off."

title: All Paths Led to Las Vegas
description: Larry Johnson stood in a parking lot outside the Thomas and Mack Center where an hour before he scored 23 points to lead Nevada-Las Vegas to another lopsided victory. This time it was by 40 points over Fresno State.

title: On Language; My Aching Back-Formation
description: The verb to backform was backformed from the compound noun back-formation . To many of us in the language dodge, that observation of a new circularity is proof of the inexorable working of justice, the symmetry of feedback and the existence of God.

title: Q and A
description: The Single Supplement

title: Towns Crack Down on False Alarms
description: FALSE burglar alarms from homes and businesses are a growing nuisance to the police, and many Westchester municipalities are trying to address the problem by passing laws that impose fines and by other means.

title: Indoor Seedings
description: The top two seeded players in the United States Pro Indoor tennis tournament in Philadelphia this week are Ivan Lendl and Pete Sampras. . . . William B. Hunt, who joined the National Collegiate Athletic Association in 1972 and has headed its enforcement department since 1985, has resigned to pursue "other opportunities," according to an N.C.A.A. announcement. . . . George Foster, the last National League player to hit more than 50 home runs in a season, has accepted a position at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., as a volunteer hitting coach for the Division II school.

title: Topics of the Times; Facing the Music
description: "If they are going to throw money away, we might as well get some of it," remarked one North Dakota resident upon learning that Congress had appropriated $500,000 to restore the North Dakota birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the television bandleader.

title: Deciphering Victorian Underwear, And Other Seminars
description: On the third morning of the modern Language Association convention (known to members of the literary profession as the M.L.A.), a late-December fog veils Chicago's lakefront and visibility in the Loop falls to 0.0 miles. Near the entrance to the Hyatt Regency Hotel on East Wacker Drive, assistant professors in black leather pegged pants wade through icy slush. Andrew Ross watches them impassively. Under his mane of unruly hair he looks exhausted, but so do the hundreds of other literature scholars who eddy about in the hotel lobby, arguing.

title: A Bow to Old-Style Dining Ambiance
description: THESE are lean economic times. Even President Bush acknowledges the R word. Yet, four-year-old Buon Giorno in Lynbrook continues to maintain its pre-recession style. There are no downpricing, no midweek price breaks, no pasta nights and no inexpensive early bird menus.

title: Is Victory Over Iraq Really a Sure Thing?; High-Tech Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimberly Conklin To Wed in Spring
description: Spring wedding plans for Kimberly Burnett Conklin and Sean Thaddeus Connett, a son of Ellen T. Connett of New Providence, N.J., and Albert N. Connett 3d of Quogue, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Conklin of Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: The article about the Hungarian artist's colony Szentendre ("SoHo on the Danube: An Artist's Village," Travel, Nov. 18) recalled an unpleasant impression that this town made on my wife and me.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Factory-Built Affordables for Paterson
description: IN the Wrigley Park section of Paterson, time-worn buildings, littered streets and vacant lots testify to the suburban flight, economic hard times and neglect that marked this city's decline decades ago.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We wallpapered our bathroom with a solid vinyl, and the edges are now peeling. The walls are plaster, which we covered with wallpaper lining and then primed. We overlapped the vinyl wallpaper strips by about one-eighth inch, and these edges are curling back. I tried several adhesives, but none held up for long. Some places will not stick down at all. Any suggestions?

title: Rye Library Turns to Saving Turtles
description: "TURTLES are disappearing very quickly -- they are imperiled," said Dr. Michael Klemens, a Rye resident who is director of turtle conservation at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. "Locally, we've lost the mud and bog turtles. Now they may be found only in the northern part of the county. The box turtle is a lot scarcer than before and the spotted and wood turtles are becoming very scarce."

title: John Tower Strikes Back
description: CONSEQUENCES A Personal and Political Memoir. By John G. Tower. Illustrated. 388 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title:
MUSIC;
Berlin's Songsas a Social History
description: THE composer and pianist Earl Rose, who believes that there is no other popular composer in the 20th century whose contribution comes close to that of Irving Berlin, has set about to prove it to American audiences in a 12-week tour with a small orchestra, singers and dancers.

title: Kathleen Jensen To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Kathleen Vuono Jensen to Joseph Anthony Bellissimo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bellissimo of Weston, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Jensen Jr. of Riverside, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Wall Street; Industrial Pressures Hit the Metals Markets
description: Since at least mid-1989, the precious metals have tended to take their lumps in unison. But more recently, that has started to change, with gold meandering along a dull but steady course while platinum, palladium and silver sink like rocks.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Hong Kong's Lively Sizzling Dishes
description: IT stands to reason that the bustling, flamboyant little colony of Hong Kong, which loves to call attention to itself and its success, would invent an exuberant restaurant dish that also demands attention and admiration. That specialty is a sizzling dish, and whenever it is served here, even the most jaded diners turn to stare, because these noisy, lively dishes simply cannot be ignored.

title: Wall Street; When a Legend Goes Speculating
description: It would be hard to pick three companies with less in common than the Patten Corporation, Engex Inc. and Erly Industries.

title: Convoy of German Aid to Soviets Begins Journey Through Poland
description: Despite mounting criticism of hardening Soviet policy, Germany set in motion this weekend the largest emergency aid shipment yet to the Soviet Union, including nearly 200 tons of food, medicine and medical equipment from stockpiles of the old East German Army.

title: Minorities Aren't Fooled
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Fear War Could Disrupt Muslim Ritual
description: While Saudi officials are not pressing the United States to launch an immediate ground attack against Iraqi troops, they agree with American officials that it is important to end the conflict by the time Muslim pilgrims journey to Mecca in June, a senior Western diplomat said today.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: I spent several months last year planning an independent trip to the Soviet Union through Liberty Travel, Five Star Touring and Intourist. My itinerary changed continually as trouble erupted in different republics, and I ended up going to Moscow, Leningrad, Talinn, Tiblisi and Irkutsk.

title: FOUR GENERATIONS IN THE PROJECTS
description: As an elementary school teacher 20 years ago in the Robert Taylor Homes in Chicago, I was greatly saddened by Nicholas Lemann's article "Four Generations in the Projects" (Jan. 13). My classrooms were in the project -- sometimes in converted apartments -- and although I was an "outsider," I never encountered any form of threat from anyone there. In the years since I left Chicago, I thought that increasing opportunities for blacks would improve the lives of people in the projects. Tragically, I was wrong. For those who are there now, the picture seems very grim indeed.

title: Track and Field; Morceli Was Counting On a Little More Push
description: Noureddine Morceli of Algeria had two people to push him toward a world indoor mile record in Meadowlands/Vitalis Invitational on Friday night. Only one did, and that's why Eamonn Coghlan's eight-year-old record of 3 minutes 49.78 seconds still stands.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Elmwood Park 155,000 56 Washington Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,687. Fair Lawn 161,000 36-23 Gardenview Terrace 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, new furnace, h/w floors, full basement; taxes $3,024. Jackson 157,000 25 Chelsea Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old contemporary; deck, family room, patio, fireplace; taxes $4,015. Manalapan 171,000 11 Locust Grove Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split level; 1-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, patio, h/w floors; taxes $2,932. Ramsey 260,000 301 Myrtle Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath 33-year-old ranch; deck, new kitchen, enclosed patio; taxes $3,499. Waldwick 149,000 53 Moore Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, new windows, h/w floors; taxes $2,969. OTHER AREAS Westport, Conn. 379,000 38 Red Coat Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; picturesque site, possible 3d bedroom, 1 acre; taxes $3,351. Bedford, N.Y. 370,000 182 Cedar Hill 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, new kitchen, family room, 2.9 acres; taxes $5,695. Hauppauge, L.I. 177,000 84 Village Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26- year-old ranch; den, fireplace, basement, 1-car garage, 0.50 acres; taxes $3,000.

title: Why the 'Mule Bone' Debate Goes On
description: Controversy over the play "Mule Bone" has existed ever since it was written by Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston in 1930. Not only did an authors' quarrel prevent the play from being produced, but its exclusive use of black folk vernacular has also provoked debate. In 1984, when the play became part of the publishing project of Dr. Henry Louis Gates Jr., the editor of Hurston's complete works, he sent a copy of it to Gregory Mosher, then the artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago. When Mr. Mosher moved to the Lincoln Center Theater in New York, he brought the play with him, and eventually the theater decided to mount it. Dr. Gates and George Houston Bass, the literary executor of the Hughes estate, edited the play and served as consultants to the production. "Mule Bone" is being published this month to coincide with its world premiere Thursday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Broadway. Dr. Gates, the John Spencer Bassett Professor of English at Duke University, was elected to the board of Lincoln Center Theater last spring.

title: A la Carte: For Sweethearts
description: THE Island's restaurants will offer music, flowers, dancing and the foods of romance on St. Valentine's Day. Love songs will drift through seductive waterfront spots, captivating penthouses and cozy country inns warmed by stone fireplaces.

title: How to Teach Arithmetic So That It Stimulates Young Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We wallpapered our bathroom with a solid vinyl, and the edges are now peeling. The walls are plaster, which we covered with wallpaper lining and then primed. We overlapped the vinyl wallpaper strips by about one-eighth inch, and these edges are curling back. I tried several adhesives, but none held up for long. Some places will not stick down at all. Any suggestions?

title: Kids at Risk in Mr. Bush's Budget
description: In memory and in the occasional novel, the 1980's are seen as an Age of Affluence. But for America's children, they were the Age of Indifference. And if President Bush's budget message is any guide, more years of official neglect lie ahead.

title: Tough One to Call
description: A CONFLICT OF RIGHTS The Supreme Court and Affirmative Action. By Melvin I. Urofsky. 270 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: Don't Tamper With Saratoga
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At State Universities, Wounds From Budget Cuts Are Visible
description: At the State University Center at Binghamton, courses once limited to 25 students now have 45. Sophomores trying to fulfill lab requirements in physics must wait until senior year because of cutbacks in the equipment budget. The running track has so many potholes that sprinters practice in a parking lot.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; Baker and Dole Disagreeing On Warning by Gorbachev
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today brushed aside Soviet complaints that the United States was on the verge of exceeding United Nations resolutions by destroying Iraq and not just liberating Kuwait, but a top Republican Senator said the Soviet position might be correct.

title: Chip's Down; Pavin Is Winner
description: Corey Pavin won his first tournament in more than two years and went one-up in a longtime rivalry when he holed a 40-foot wedge shot on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to wrest the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic away from Mark O'Meara.

title: Review/Ballet; 'Coppelia': A Farewell And a Joyful Partnership
description: As a sendoff, the New York City Ballet could not have done better. Shaun O'Brien, who joined the company in 1949 and was thus virtually its last remaining charter member, gave his farewell performance on Friday night as Dr. Coppelius in "Coppelia."

title: Iraq Hit the Stark to Push U.S. Into War
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Air Posts Big Loss
description: Northwest Airlines lost $121 million in the fourth quarter and its parent company lost $302 million for the year, the private airline has reported.

title: BRAZIL SKEPTICAL OVER PRICE FREEZE
description: Last March, Brazilians thrilled to hear their dynamic new President announce that he had "one bullet to kill the inflationary tiger."

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Broward County, Florida, is offering $68.3 million in tax-exempt gas tax revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of about 6.69 percent for a bond due in 2010. Yields on serial bonds range from 4.50 percent in 1991 to 6.55 percent in 2004. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * CIT Group Holdings Inc., a unit of Manufacturers Hanover Corp., New York, is offering $250 million in 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1996, at a price of 100, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering $160 million in 7.19 percent consolidated system bonds due in 1994 at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley & Co. * MBIA Inc., Armonk, N.Y., is offering $100 million in 9 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.352 to yield 9.10 percent, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Inc. The noncallable notes are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P. * Republic New York Corp. is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 2001, at 99.25, to yield 8.99 percent, through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P. * Tenneco Corp., Houston, is offering $200 million in 9 7/8 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.65, to yield 9.93 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P. * Texaco Capital, a unit of Texaco Inc., White Plains, is offering $200 million in 8 1/2 percent notes due in 2003 at 99.15, to yield 8.615 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. COMMON STOCK * Uno Restaurant Corp., West Roxbury, Mass., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 1.2 million common shares through A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. * Zilog Inc., Campbell, Calif., has filed an initial public offering of two million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. RATINGS * Armstrong World Industries' senior debt rating has been lowered to A-2, from A-1 by Moody's. The company is based in Lancaster, Pa.

title: Books of The Times; Waking Up a Complacent America
description: The Next Century By David Halberstam 126 pages. William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Fighting Is Reported to Break Out Between Somalia's Rebel Groups
description: New fighting has broken out between rival rebel groups seeking power in Somalia after the ouster of President Mohamed Siad Barre, a Kenyan newspaper reported today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Girl, 16, Slain on Way Home From Friend's House on L.I.
description: A 16-year-old girl who seemed to have found a good fit with a foster family after years of casting about was found stabbed to death and nude Saturday morning along a wooded path minutes from her foster home in Central Islip, L.I., the police said.

title: Review/Television; Roaming Los Angeles With One Who Loves It
description: John Gregory Dunne confesses more than once in tonight's edition of "Travels" that he loves Los Angeles. It's not catching. "L.A. Is It," at 8 on Channel 13, is a partly familiar, partly eccentric visit that is not likely to change anyone's opinion for the better.

title: Motorola Plan For Modem
description: Motorola Inc. says it will provide technical details today of its high-speed wireless modem, which uses microwaves to carry data between computers.

title: U.N.L.V. Perks Up To Pass a Big Test
description: The national champion Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team came here this weekend undefeated in 19 consecutive games this season, with an average winning margin of 32 points.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Alka-Seltzer literally carves its new theme, "Laws of Indigestion," into stone in a campaign that begins Tuesday. The initial 30-second television spot opens with a chisel scratching out "Law VII," followed by the image of a young man looking woefully at a plate of food. "The one food you cannot tolerate," an announcer intones, "will always be served by your in-laws." The campaign was prepared by McCann-Erickson. * In a campaign that begins today, Showtime Networks employs a bank of 35 televisions to stress the theme line: "We entertain you like no one can." As 34 of the screens remain blank, a single screen flashes highlights from the cable network's offerings for the year. The television spot, part of a larger campaign that includes print and radio, was prepared by Ally & Gargano, New York.

title: Barbara Ann Cohen Is Wed
description: Barbara Ann Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Cohen of Seaford, L.I., was married yesterday at Tavern on the Green to Ronald Gary Zemel, a son of Ruth Zemel of Altamonte Springs, Fla., and Nathan Zemel of Orange City, Fla. Rabbi Moshe Herson officiated. Mrs. Zemel, 36, graduated from Hofstra University and was until recently the assistant to the president of LACO International Inc., an offshore risk arbitrage fund in New York. Mr. Zemel, 41, graduated from the University of South Carolina. He is a certified public accountant and the chief financial officer of Reid-Dolph Inc., a television production company in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Germany Stands Alone on Rates
description: The German central bank's surprising decision to increase interest rates last month has raised new questions about Germany's commitment to international cooperation in general and to Western Europe's goals of economic integration and monetary union in particular.

title: Japan Pressed to Buy More U.S. Awacs Jets
description: Heating up another front in the continuing trade disputes with Japan, 70 members of Congress complained last week that Tokyo has dragged its feet in assuming responsibility for the defense of its air space and sea lanes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KEN BURNS, the film producer who taught millions of Americans about the Civil War, is the winner of the first $50,000 Lincoln Prize for scholarship.

title: William L. Dunfey, 65, Hotelier and Democrat
description: William L. Dunfey, a hotelier who was long one of the leading figures in Democratic politics in New Hampshire, died this morning at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Hospital here. He was 65 years old and lived in Rye Beach, N.H., a coastal community near Portsmouth.

title: Economic Calender
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales...Jan. Thursday Business Inventories...Dec. Friday Producer Price Index...Jan. Merchandise Trade...Dec. Industrial Production...Jan. Capacity Utilization...Jan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NORMAN MAILER has joined Vanity Fair as writer at large and will contribute several articles a year to the magazine. His first, in the March issue, which will be on newsstands tomorrow, is yet another piece on "American Psycho," the novel by BRET EASTON ELLIS that was rejected by Simon & Schuster, which objected to its graphic violence. It will be published instead by Vintage Books. Already the book has been the subject of a number of articles and protests by feminists.

title: Monk Magazine Takes Founders on a Rewarding Journey
description: Jim Crotty and Michael Lane travel the country in a mobile home, writing about themselves and America on a solar-powered Macintosh.

title: Bridge
description: The only team event in the New York calendar, and perhaps anywhere in the United States, that tests adaptability is the Betty Kaplan Teams competition, in which players must rotate partnerships.

title: On Memorial To the Dead, 14 Who Live
description: Fourteen Americans can visit the Vietnam Veterans Memorial and find their names carved in black granite among the names of those killed in the war.

title: No Peace Talks After the Ground War Starts
description: After the ground war begins, the U.S.-led coalition will be tempted with many calls for negotiations, such as that just offered by Iran. Washington should ignore them.

title: People
description: * Barbara J. Fallon, Dominick Maiolo and Michael A. Rizzo have been named vice presidents at Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. * Jerry Acciaioli has been appointed vice president-corporate new business at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Minneapolis.

title: McLean Journal; The Gulf War, Between School Bells
description: War came to McLean High School the way it did all over the country. Students gossiped that a fire drill was really a bomb threat, they declared the videotapes of allied bombing missions awesome, and some spray-painted an American flag on a boulder they call the Rock.

title: Laettner Outduels O'Neal
description: Whenever Louisiana State plays, the storyline revolves around the play of a big man. Usually it's Shaquille O'Neal, the Tigers' 7-foot-1-inch sophomore center, generally regarded as the top professional prospect in college ball.

title: Dogs Warm Up for Big Show
description: It was specialty day in the metropolitan area yesterday, with breed clubs staging 19 specialties at six sites as a prelude to the 115th annual Westminster Kennel Club fixture in Madison Square Garden, which opens a two-day run this morning. Heading the program yesterday was a new circuit, held under the aegis of the Empire Specialty Associated Clubs, with 12 shows taking place on Pier 90 at the Hudson River, and drawing a total of 1,093 dogs.

title: And Mookie Plays On . . .
description: MOOKIE BLAYLOCK has a concert tonight in Los Angeles. Huh? Mookie Blaylock's sound is often compared to the rock band, U2. Double huh?

title: Metro Matters; Routine Murders In a Hurried City Numb to Pain
description: Every so often, a crime seems so shocking that it is viewed as symptomatic of a collective personality disorder.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD World Mark for Bubka: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his own world indoor pole-vault record yesterday, clearing 19 feet 11 1/2 inches at the Soviet winter track championships in Volgograd. Bubka, set the previous record of 19-10 1/4 on March 17, 1990. Franz K. Minchanin also set a world record on the first day of the winter championships, covering the 5,000-meter walk in 18 minutes 23.88 seconds. Minchainin's time broke the previous record of 18:27.10, set by Mikhail Shchennikov of the Soviet Union at Budapest on March 5, 1989. (AP) Woman's 5,000-Meter Mark: Uta Pippig of Germany set a world-indoor record in the 5,000-meter run in Stuttgart yesterday, covering the distance in 15:13.72. The previous record of 15:17.28 minutes was set by Sonia O'Sullivan of Ireland in Boston two weeks ago. (AP) TENNIS Volkov Tops Caratti: Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union defeated Cristiano Caratti with a 6-1, 7-5 victory in the final of the Muratti indoor tournament yesterday in Milan. The victory was the 23-year-old's first in the Grand Prix since turning professional in 1987. Lindqvist a Winner: Third-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden beat Raffaella Reggi of Italy, 6-3, 6-0, yesterday to win the Oslo Open. Reggi, seeded second, lost in both the singles and the doubles finals. Claudia Kohde-Kilsch and Silke Meier beat Reggi and Sabine Appelmans, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4. (AP) SKIING Wachter Takes Giant Slalom: Anita Wachter of Austria turned in a blistering second run to win a women's giant slalom event in Zwiesel, Germany, yesterday for her first World Cup victory of the season. Wachter trailed Eva Twardokens of the United States by 24-hundredths of a second after the first run, but was more than half a second faster than the rest of the field in the second heat and won the event by 86-hundredths of a second. She had a total time of 2 minutes 16.83 seconds for the two runs; Twardokens clocked 2:17.69. Vreni Schneider of Switzerland finished third in 2:17.78. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 5, Flyers 2: Washington and Philadelphia received a combined 294 penalty minutes yesterday, and, between fights, Kevin Hatcher had a goal and two assists to help the Capitals to their third consecutive victory. The penalty minutes were the most by two teams at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., easily surpassing the 240 minutes by the same teams in March 1982. (AP) Bruins 7, Nordiques 4: Craig Janney scored two goals, one during a three-goal blitz in a 2:14 span that broke a third-period tie as Boston overpowered Quebec at home. (AP) Sabres 2, Jets 0: Daren Puppa made 24 saves and Dave Snuggerud's short-handed goal in the third period broke a scoreless tie Buffalo beat the Jets at Winnipeg. Snuggerud broke the tie at 2:48 of the third period. (AP) Whalers 3, Blackhawks 1: Rob Brown scored twice within 12 seconds in the second period and Peter Sidorkiewicz stopped 20 shots as Hartford, playing at home, beat Chicago. Sidorkiewicz, 8-3-1 in his last 12 decisions, lost his shutout bid at 13:14 when Chicago's Jeremy Roenick scored a short-handed goal. Carey Wilson also scored and Ron Francis had a pair of assists for the Whalers. (AP) GOLF Daniel Still Winning: Beth Daniel began the 1991 season where she left off last season: winning tournaments. Daniel, the 1990 Ladies Professional Golf Association player of the year with seven victories, turned back challenges by Nancy Lopez and Laura Baugh with three birdies on the final eight holes yesterday to win the $500,000 Phar-Mor Classic in Lauderhill, Fla. Daniel had a closing round 69 at Inverrary Country Club for a seven-under-par 209 and a two-shot victory over Lopez. (AP) Charles a Winner: Bob Charles beat Lee Trevino and George Archer by four strokes yesterday to win the $450,000 Suncoast Classic tournament in Tampa, Fla. (AP)

title: New Challenge of Youth: Growing Up in Gay Home
description: For Will Dixon-Gray, being a parent means waking his 14-year-old son several times each morning before the boy finally rousts himself from bed. It means nagging him about wearing the rubber bands on his braces and reminding him to walk the dogs and not to just put them in the yard. It means nursing him through colds, reviewing his homework and watching "The Simpsons" on television with him on Thursday nights.

title: Review/Music; Colombian Pianist's 'Iberia'
description: Isaac Albeniz's "Iberia," like so many works of the early-20th-century Spanish nationalists, proves that under the right conditions, formal and vernacular styles can mingle, to the detriment of neither and the benefit of both. The work's movements are named for, and vividly describe, a dozen Spanish cities, districts, song and dance forms and even a religious procession, using melodies and rhythms derived from flamenco. In terms of harmonic complexity and density of texture, though, Albeniz's score bears a close kinship with the piano music of Liszt and Debussy.

title: John Sloan Dickey Is Dead at 83; Dartmouth President for 25 Years
description: John Sloan Dickey, a lawyer who was president of Dartmouth College from 1945 to 1970, died Saturday in the campus infirmary. He was 83 years old and lived in Hanover, N.H.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; HUSSEIN, IN SPEECH, URGES THE IRAQIS TO BE STEADFAST
description: Faced with the systematic destruction of his country's major public works and other installations, yet displaying little readiness for peace, Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, urged his compatriots tonight to practice "patience and steadfastness" and assured them that Iraq would win the Persian Gulf war.

title: Civics 101 on Tape in Arizona, Or, 'We All Have Our Prices'
description: "Are you sure there are no hidden cameras up there?" joked State Representative Don Kenney moments before accepting what the police say was a $55,000 bribe and zipping it into a gym bag.

title: Condoms Can Decrease Teen-Age Pregnancy and AIDS Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: The Keating Curve of Blame
description: Torn between the public's outrage and the Senate's clubbiness, the Senate Ethics Committee is having trouble reaching verdicts on the "Keating Five," their colleagues who did too many favors for Charles Keating, the disgraced savings and loan operator. If the committee honors the public's reasonable expectations, it will apportion blame fairly among all five and proclaim new, higher standards of political behavior.

title: Carole Bernstein Is Married on L.I.
description: Carole Rose Bernstein, a daughter of Irene Bernstein-Pechmeze of -- Whitestone, Queens, and the late Alan Bernstein, was married yesterday at Temple Israel, Lawrence, L.I., to Dr. Neil David Herbsman, a son of Dr. Horace Herbsman of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Brenda Herbsman. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated.

title: There He Is, Mr. N.F.L. Draft Hopeful
description: MIKE SULLIVAN was waiting his turn to stand on a medical table and allow the team doctors of the National Football League to conduct their search for pain.

title: Engineers Cite Design Flaw In Bridge Woes
description: Engineers in and out of New York City government point to years of deferred maintenance to explain the drastic deterioration of the 82-year-old Manhattan Bridge in the last few years.

title: Colombians Revising Charter Get Two Sharp Hints
description: Although they have neither voice nor vote in the National Assembly that is to rewrite the Colombian Constitution, drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas nevertheless managed to seize the rostrum last week and be heard.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Raids Said to Badly Delay Baghdad Messages to Front
description: The allies in the Persian Gulf believe that they have so severely disrupted Iraqi communications that it takes 24 hours for President Saddam Hussein to get a message to the front by reasonably secure means, American intelligence officers said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; G.I.'s Bristle but Pay Nonetheless as Saudi Stores Double Their Prices on a Desert Road
description: Saudi shopkeepers along the main northern highway have doubled and tripled prices as United States troops have poured into the northern desert and come to rely on local stores for the small amenities like snack food and kerosene heaters that the Army does not provide.

title: Ms. Levy Weds S. B. Greenberg
description: Andrea Rona Levy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Levy of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday at the Plaza to Dr. Sheldon Burt Greenberg, the son of Lillian Greenberg of New York and the late Dr. Morris Greenberg. Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz performed the ceremony.

title: CNN Sees Its Concept Paying Off
description: The enormous success enjoyed by the Cable News Network in the first weeks of the Persian Gulf war has been largely a triumph of a concept: providing news as it happens from all over the world virtually around the clock.

title: Review/Theater; High Art Battles Low in Rhymed Couplets
description: "La Bete," the new play by David Hirson at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, begins with a bang that can make even a jaded New York audience abruptly spring to attention. The lights come up on a chorus of babbling 17th-century French swells who are figuratively guillotined by a progression of elegant, falling front curtains, each more disfigured than the last by blotted, calligraphic graffiti. Not long after that, the same curtains rise on a new shock for the eye: a towering period anteroom in nearly unrelieved white, as seen from a skewed, fisheye-lens perspective. And then comes the piece de resistance: A corpulent buffoon -- the beast of the title, known as Valere and played by Tom McGowan -- delivers a marathon soliloquy that runs some 400 lines and, like the entire play, has been composed in rhymed verse!

title: Bond Rally's Continuation Is Questioned
description: With long-term interest rates at their lowest levels in more than a year, some credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether the bond market rally that began in mid-January has run its course.

title: Terreri and Devils Shut Out Canucks
description: Fear of dropping out of a playoff spot for the first time this season, and a search for redemption for losing to the worst team in the league a day earlier, provided enough incentive for the Devils this evening.

title: Rangers Succumb To Their Emotions
description: In losing by 6-4 to the Montreal Canadiens amid the emotion of the Forum on a Saturday night, the Rangers not only squandered a 4-0 lead but also showed how they react when tested under the kind of stress that teams face routinely in the playoffs.

title: Jerry Lewis With Slim-Fast
description: Thompson Medical Company, the maker of the Slim-Fast diet aid, has signed up Jerry Lewis, who has already started on the diet, said Grey Advertising, which represents Thompson.

title: Mr. Bush Hires a Writer
description: To a sailor, a telltale is a strip of cloth attached to the mast to indicate the wind's direction; to a railroader, a telltale is a ribbon hung over a track before a tunnel to warn trainmen off the roofs of cars; to a pundit, a telltale is some seemingly insignificant sign that is a portent of a change in political emphasis -- as when a President hires a new chief speechwriter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "My favorite line is, 'What's in it for me?' "

title: Campaign Hopes to Promote Bronx Zoo and Its Mission
description: HEEDING Darwin's lesson -- adapt to survive -- the Bronx Zoo will soon begin its first big image campaign. With safari-like commercials promoting the zoo's naturalistic settings, the zoo hopes to use the call of the wild to attract visitors and additional donations.

title: Reviews/Music; A Soprano's Insights
description: Roberta Alexander does not possess the most lustrous of sopranos, but she remains one of our most appealing artists, in opera but especially in song and double-especially in American song. On Friday night at Weill Recital Hall, an intimate space that boxed in her voice and turned it edgier than usual, she still managed to triumph in the Barber and Ives material after the intermission.

title: N.F.L. Negotiators Are Reorganized
description: JACK DONLAN, the executive director of the NFL Management Council for the past 10 years and the man who guided the National Football League's negotiating team through player strikes in 1982 and '87, has submitted his resignation, apparently unhappy about a move by owners to limit his organization's power.

title: Seeking a Place on Santa's List
description: Hide this newspaper, Mom and Dad, and blindfold the children. Here is what Santa Claus is bringing next Christmas, or at least that is what the toy industry hopes.

title: The Inside Story On Giants' Season
description: IF you want to find out what happened on the Giants' sidelines this season, check out their video yearbook from NFL Films. Bill Parcells was wired with a microphone for a bunch of games and he reeled off a few fabulous one-liners. After Ottis Anderson scored a touchdown one Sunday, the coach walked past the running back and muttered, "That hole was so big, I could have scored through it."

title: Car Dealers Struggling To Survive
description: Auto dealers have been going out of business in droves, and those who remain are adopting survival tactics. The intent is not only to lure customers, but to slash costs, motivate sales forces and bring more business to service departments.

title: Waiting and Waiting on Tables for Her Big Break
description: The face is familiar: she was Tom Hanks's mother in "Big," a furiously jealous Mafia wife in "Married to the Mob," and a smart, savvy and sexy Wall Street lawyer Off Broadway in "Other People's Money."

title: For Leonard, Time to Move On
description: He had introduced his younger brother to boxing some 20 years ago, and now toward midnight in a Madison Square Garden dressing room, Roger Leonard realized that the long and eventful career of Sugar Ray Leonard was really over.

title: Barkley Overcomes Pain to Win M.V.P.
description: Even when injured, Charles Barkley can do extraordinary things.

title: Gaelic Sports Season May Die In Dispute Over Bronx Park
description: Gaelic Park, the ramshackle Bronx stadium that has been a center of Irish life in New York since hurling and Gaelic football were first played there in the 1920's, may be empty when the season begins this spring, Irish sports officials said yesterday.

title: National Health Insurance Benefits Everyone; The Elderly Victimized
description: To the Editor:

title: Jan Ellen Michell Marries
description: Jan Ellen Michell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Michell of Glencoe, Ill., was married yesterday at the Stanhope in New York to Mitchell Harris Freeman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Freeman of West Hempstead, L.I. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony. The bride, who is keeping her name, is 39 years old. A graduate of Skidmore College, she is a freelance writer and an advertising consultant. The bridegroom, 40, is a managing director of Fuji-Wolfensohn International, investment bankers in New York. He graduated from George Washington University and has an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: New Industry for Outer Banks: Home to Retirees
description: Bill and Abelina Reid came here from Vermont for the sea and the solitude. Bill and Betty Logan came from New Jersey for the memories: the dunes and marshes of the Outer Banks were the landscape of their honeymoon. Francis Rogallo, an aeronautical engineer who developed the hang glider, came for the winds, just as the Wright Brothers did 80 years before.

title: Co-Workers Comforted Controller After Her Fatal Error, Paper Says
description: Co-workers at Los Angeles International Airport rushed a distraught air traffic controller into seclusion shortly after a runway collision that killed 34 people last week, The Los Angeles Times reported Friday.

title: Census Likely to Renew Strife in Indian State
description: A nationwide census this month is likely to worsen tensions in the remote state of Assam, where more than 5,000 people have been killed in ethnic, linguistic and religious clashes in recent years.

title: The End of the Road
description: BY fights's end, the relatively elderly gentleman, Sugar Ray Leonard, had suffered a lump to the side of his face, a reddened puffiness to both eyes, a bloodied mouth, and some hard, cruel facts to the psyche, all courtesy of the younger, quicker, stronger, though not necessarily tougher, opponent, "Terrible" Terry Norris. Norris, who is 23 years old, looked, as the bell ended the 12th and final round, like 23; not a hair on his black mustache appeared to be out of place. Leonard, meanwhile, who is 34, looked 54.

title: War Summary
description: RUIN IN BAGHDAD Twenty-five days of round-the-clock bombings have reportedly wrecked much of modern Iraq's pride: the roads and bridges, the power stations and refineries, communications and waterworks. With shortages acute, Iraqis heard President Saddam Hussein urge them last night to be patient and steadfast and victory would be theirs. KNOTS IN THE CHAIN OF COMMAND Its instant communications a shambles, Iraq's central command spends a full day to get word to the front lines via "pretty primitive" - but relatively safe - backup networks, American intelligence officers in Saudi Arabia said. They said quicker but less secure lines were monitored by eavesdropping planes and spy satellites. "Once the land battle starts," one officer commented, "that won't be nearly good enough." 'STILL A LOT OF POTENTIAL' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, en route from the gulf to report to President Bush, seems to agree with field commanders that three or four more weeks of air attacks are needed before Mr. Bush can order an "AirLand Battle" to begin. "I think," he said, referring to Iraq's ability to resist a ground assault, "there is still a lot of potential out there." WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The United States Central Command in Riyadh gave no new tallies. Aircraft: The briefer in Riyadh reported the loss of a Marine Harrier jump jet over Kuwait and said the pilot was missing. This increased the number of American aircraft shot down to 18. The coalition partners have lost 7, for a total of 25. The officially acknowledged losses do not include aircraft crashes on support missions, on training flights or in other "noncombat" incidents. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Forty-two more Iraqi soldiers were reported to have crossed lines, pushing the total of war prisoners toward 1,000. Aircraft: The command in Riyadh said Iraqi losses remained the same.

title: Linconln's Birthday Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state open. Local option. Post office: Regular service. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleanings. Schools: Closed Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, Long Island Rail Road and Metro North on regular schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal open, state closed. Local option. Post offices: Regular service. Banks: Option to close Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal open, state closed. Local option. Post offices: Regular service. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule.

title: Review/Television; A Bad Man Is Back to His Old Tricks
description: When it comes to the intricate craft of calculated obfuscation, "based on fact" television movies must rate just below Washington briefings. These are the movies that are usually based on a nonfiction book but that advise the viewer that some names have been changed, certain time sequences have been altered and a few characters are really composites. Keeping your eye on the bouncing ball of fact can be hazardous to your mental stability.

title: PRETORIA ASSAILED ON POLICE ROUNDUP
description: The African National Congress has criticized a police roundup over the weekend in which 11,000 people were arrested for crimes ranging from murder to cattle theft. It questioned the South African Government's motives and demanded a breakdown by race of those held.

title: Charge Is Dropped Against Store Clerk In Sale of Playboy
description: A convenience store clerk was arrested here for selling a Playboy magazine to two 16-year-old boys, then was strip-searched and forced to spend the night in jail.

title: The Rev. James Cleveland, 59; Pastor Hailed as 'King of Gospel'
description: The Rev. James Cleveland, who taught Aretha Franklin to sing gospel and was widely hailed as the "King of Gospel" died Saturday at the Brotman Medical Center here. He was 59 years old.

title: Lift Statement Limits For War Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Kills 26,000 Turkeys
description: A fire killed 26,000 young turkeys and destroyed a barn on Saturday. The blaze was apparently started by a stove used to keep the birds warm, an official said. More than 100 firefighters battled the blaze that caused an estimated $210,000 damage to the barn, said John Houck, a fire chief in York Township. The value of the 10,000 two-week-old turkeys and 16,000 12-week-old turkeys owned by Round Hill Foods was not determined.

title: Review/Ballet; New Faces in Old Roles In an Evening of Risks
description: The New York City Ballet offered several role debuts and first performances of the season on Tuesday and Wednesday nights at the New York State Theater. In the end, however, it was the familiar that triumphed, in the exalted and sumptuous dancing of Kyra Nichols and Adam Luders in George Balanchine's "Allegro Brillante."

title: The Talk of Teterboro; Tax Haven in New Jersey, In Bind, Plans to Drop Police
description: All was tranquil in this square-mile tax haven until Borough Manager Michael W. Tedesco proposed disbanding the eight-member police force.

title: Back Pain: Signal That Should Not Be Ignored
description: BACK pain is no fun for anybody, but for the athletically inclined it's a double whammy. It restricts you physically in the activity of your choice, and psychologically, too. Now you're no longer so sure the sport you love is as good for you as you always thought it was. Indeed, maybe it's bad for you. Gone is runner's high, replaced by runner's paranoia.

title: For 2 Huskies, It's Not Just Another Hike
description: THERE is nothing fancy about Mason and Bosco. They are stringy-looking dogs, not fluffy or pretty. They do not appear strong or excitable but they have been training their entire lives for this moment.

title: Dependence and Sovereignty Pull at Panama's Equilibrium
description: More than 13 months after the United States invaded Panama and arrested Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, most of the problems that have plagued the nation for years remain. Panama is still searching for its own identity and seems linked more than ever to Washington.

title: It's a Dog's Life on Show Circuit
description: ON a thousand rickety grooming tables crammed into Barnstable High School last week sat a thousand dogs, some resigned, some enthralled, some yelping at the sight of the toenail clippers, all of them primed and primped for their moment of glory in the eight-ring circus operating in the gymnasium just down the hall.

title: National Health Insurance Benefits Everyone; Teamwork Is Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan Now for Peace
description: Secretary of State Baker, Senator Albert Gore and others urge Americans to think about the peace to follow the Persian Gulf war. The peace? How can anyone think sensibly about that prospect when there's so much uncertain about the war?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Statement; Excerpts From Saddam Hussein's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from an address by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq broadcast tonight by the Baghdad radio. The excerpts were translated by The Associated Press from a transcript transmitted by the Iraqi News Agency. Iraqis, your enemy believed it was capable of achieving its goals and reversing the course of history, and when he failed, he resorted to direct armed aggression. Here we are in the fourth week of this aggression with the Iraqis becoming more firm in their faith, and shining out more in front of the whole world.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KATHARINE HAMNETT, the London designer who shows her collection in Paris, has pulled out of the ready-to-wear showings in March because she believes that American and Japanese buyers will not travel because of fear of terrorism. The show, which was scheduled for March 16, will be replaced by small presentations in Paris, London, New York and Tokyo, a spokesman for the designer said on Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A12-14

title: Accounts
description: * Pet Inc., St. Louis, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, for its Progresso Italian food products. Billings are $15 million. * America's Cup Challenge '92, San Diego, to Vic Olesen & Partners Advertising, Culver City, Calif. Billings have not been determined. * House of Louis Roederer, France, to Team One Advertising, El Segundo, Calif., for its Cristal, Brut Premier and Roederer Estate Champagnes. Billings are estimated at $1 million.

title: Seeking Stars, Hollywood Is Spending Freely on Books
description: Forget about book advances. After rising sharply in the 1980's, they are now stagnant or even slipping. But options are hot.

title: Rodale's Soviet Venture: Sausages and a Magazine
description: Within the magazine industry, it is jokingly known as "turning pigs into magazines." But a project that gets under way in the Soviet Union today with the publication of a Russian-language agricultural magazine is one of the most remarkable American-Soviet joint ventures to date.

title: A New U.S.-Japan Rift
description: Seventy members of Congress complained that Japan is dragging its feet in assuming responsibility for defense of its air space and sea lanes. One issue is whether Japan needs to buy more AWACS radar planes.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Question Box
description: 20-Victory Seasons

title: Queens Grocery Owner Plans For Meeting to End Boycott
description: The owner of a grocery store in Queens said yesterday that he wanted to work with community leaders to end a boycott of his store as the number of protesters dwindled to a handful and business appeared to be brisk.

title: You Want to Talk Real Streaks?
description: THE Los Angeles Lakers have a 16-game winning streak going, and they cannot lose at least until tomorrow mainly because they do not have another game scheduled until then.

title: Labor Unhappy With Weicker And New Cuts
description: With Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. scheduled to release his much-anticipated budget on Wednesday, union leaders representing state employees say they are angry and ready to try to steal the spotlight before then.

title: More Poor Children Eligible for Disability Benefits
description: The Government has approved regulations expanding by tens of thousands the number of poor children entitled to disability benefits each year, Administration officials said today.

title: Times Publisher To Be Honored
description: The Advertising Council has announced that Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, will receive its Public Service Award in November.

title: Lithuanian Voters Add To Relentless Prodding
description: There was at least one popping champagne cork, maybe two; accounts differ. There was a modest cry of "Hurrah!" from some aberrant individual, and thus went the celebration in the barricaded Parliament at 3 A.M. today at the news that the republic's citizens had just voted 9 to 1 in favor of independence.

title: Article 114091 -- No Title
description: The PNC Financial Corporation said last week that it had lost $168.3 million in the fourth quarter, mostly because of a $430.1 million provision for credit losses.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; To Saddam Hussein, With Ill Wishes
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney flashed a wicked smile, grabbed the big black marking pen and sent something less than his best wishes to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Two Die in Stunt Plane Crash
description: A biplane doing stunts over a rural area crashed and caught fire on Saturday, killing the two men aboard, the Sonoma County Sheriff's Department said. The Boeing Stearman was attempting a loop and was only a few feet from the ground when it crashed, witnesses said. The plane was flying out of Schellville, a small town near Petaluma, just north of San Francisco, said Art Morriston, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 10, 1990: MONDAY Cooper Tire & Rubr Co Jeff Pilot Corp FPL GroupInc Total Sys Svcs Inc TUESDAY Baker Fentress & Co Mattel Inc Cinci Milacron Inc Questar Corp Cummins Engine Co Reliance Grp Holdings Inc Inter Paper Co V F Corp Lafarge Corp WEDNESDAY Albany Intl Corp Inco Ltd Atmos Energy Corp Sysco Corp Gerber Prods Co THURSDAY Arvin Inds Inc McDermott Intl Inc Lawter Intl Inc Wisc Pub Svc Corp FRIDAY Barnes Group Inc Reynolds Metals Co Dominion Res Inc So Jersey Inds Inc Realty Refund Tr United Dom Inds Ltd SATURDAY United Telecomm Inc

title: Economic Watch; Does Government Have the Stuff to End a Recession?
description: Many analysts fear that a legacy of chronic budget deficits, insolvent banks and dependence on foreign capital has undermined Washington's ability to keep economic growth on track. "We're in a recession with no tools to get out," said Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.

title: Gunmen, Rebuffed at Party In Flatbush, Wound Eight
description: Three men who had been refused entry to a birthday party in Brooklyn yesterday opened fire with semiautomatic weapons on a crowd of about 100 partygoers, wounding eight, including a 12-year-old girl, the police said.

title: Easing War Stress in the Workplace
description: A growing number of companies are helping their employees to deal with fears and worries about the Persian Gulf war by organizing support groups, providing counseling and encouraging informal assistance.

title: Beijing Journal; The Winter of One Chinese Campus's Discontent
description: In the dead of winter, gray clouds hang ominously over the campus of Beijing University and bare trees rustle in the wind. But inside the dank, putrid dormitories, students complain that a spiritual bleakness chills the bones even more than the outdoor cold.

title: Is It Our Leaders, or Is It Us?
description: Hawaii is, and feels, remote from mainland America. But for all its exotic quality, the concerns on people's minds are not so different from those in Boston or New York or Los Angeles. People worry about the war, about the recession, about racial tension.

title: Big Numbers For Joyner
description: WALLY JOYNER, Angels' first baseman, yesterday broke the record held by Don Mattingly, the Yankees' first baseman when an arbritrator awarded Joyner a $2.1 million salary, the largest ever in arbitration.

title: Even in Banishment, Steinbrenner Won't Go Away
description: Last summer, after George Steinbrenner, by his own signature, relinquished his role as the Yankees' managing partner, one of his minority partners admitted that he was as puzzled as anyone about Steinbrenner's choice of penalties for his involvement with and $40,000 payment to an admitted gambler. Commissioner Fay Vincent wanted to suspend him for two years, but Steinbrenner opted for life.

title: Editorial Notebook; Pan Am's Glory Days
description: These are tough times for Pan Am. Its competitors are picking over its routes and equipment as if it were the carcass of a week-old turkey. Pan Am is still flying, but a month ago it slid into bankruptcy. And even though its logo still sits atop its Park Avenue headquarters, the building itself was long ago sold to an insurance company.

title: Sampson Field, 88, Businessman And Ex-Head of the Philharmonic
description: Sampson R. Field, a former president of the New York Philharmonic and chairman of the Marlboro School of Music and Marlboro Festival in Vermont, died last night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Wacky World Of N.C.A.A. Rules
description: On Saturday, Coach Jim Boeheim of Syracuse described his basketball players as 19- and 20-year-old "kids" who didn't really understand all the different N.C.A.A. rules and regulations.

title: INSIDE
description: Stolid Lithuanians As Lithuanians relentlessly plod toward independence, their weapon against the Kremlin is stolidness, not demonstrativeness. Page A2. A Scenic Rural Retirement A fast-growing county on the Outer Banks of North Carolina illustrates a new demographic trend: retirement to scenic rural America. Page A16. Auto Dealers Are Struggling As more and more dealerships fail, those that remain are cutting costs and adopting survival tactics like offering free oil changes. Page D1. Return of Subway Graffiti In spite of a largely successful campaign to rid New York's subway system of graffiti, the number of "hits" on trains doubled last year. Page B1.

title: Bobby Riggs in Love Rematch
description: BOBBY RIGGS, the 73-year-old tennis hustler who thrives on conversation and thirsts for challenges, is getting married in California on Valentine's Day. It is a sweet tale that grows sweeter because Riggs is marrying Priscilla Wheelan, a woman he divorced 20 years ago, and John, a minister and one of their three children, will preside.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: DOES OPEC HAVE A FUTURE? The gulf war may do long-lasting damage to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, by stimulating oil production while depressing global demand. Business Day, page D1.

title: Dropped by Nurse as Baby, Blind Boy Gets $1.2 Million
description: A hospital has been ordered to pay $1.2 million to a blind, retarded boy who was dropped on his head by a nurse when he was 3 days old.

title: Environment Versus Freer Trade
description: Efforts to protect health and the environment are clashing more and more frequently with the goal of freer world trade.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan; Truckers Risk Death on the Iraq Run
description: The war in the Persian Gulf has confronted Khamis Faris Ahmed with a quandary. With two wives, 17 children and himself to feed and clothe, he needs to work. But the only way he can make a living, he said, is by driving an oil tanker-truck down an Iraqi road prey to daily allied air strikes.

title: Review/Music; Jazz That's Free, but Not Too Free
description: For the Reggie Workman Ensemble, melodies and rhythms and vamps are always permeable but never ignored. In its first set at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night, the six-piece group played free jazz that prized a unified group sound over individual display, though there was plenty of improvisation.

title: After Suit, a Princeton Club Admits Its First 27 Women
description: Twenty-seven women have been admitted to the last all-male eating club at Princeton University, the Tiger Inn, its president said today.

title: Toyota Profit Falls 1%
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a 1 percent decline in net earnings on Friday despite increased sales for the six months that ended on Dec. 31. Japan's largest auto maker posted a profit of $1.16 billion, while its operating profit fell 15 percent, to $1.49 billion. Sales rose 16.6 percent, to $32.33 billion. The company cited higher labor costs and increased spending on research and development for the downturn in earnings.

title: Political Memo; Stars of War Room Are Auditioning For the Presidential Battles to Come
description: It just may be the most extraordinary collection of Presidential ambition ever gathered together in one room, with the possible exception of when Harold Stassen dined alone.

title: Japan Nuclear Accident May Impede Push for Plants
description: A nuclear accident over the weekend, described by experts as a close brush with disaster, appears likely to add impetus to a growing antinuclear movement here and to hamper the Government's efforts to lessen Japan's dependence on imported oil by building more reactors.

title: Marathoner Gets Cornea Transplant
description: HUNDREDS of inspirational stories emerge from the New York City Marathon each year, but none from 1990 could be more precious than that of Tuul Piambu. When the blind Mongolian runner returns home, he will tell friends he completed the marathon in five hours. Piambu may also be able to tell them that his vision has been partly restored. In January, Dr. John Seedor performed a free corneal transplant on Piambu making him the second person to benefit from the Achilles Track Club/New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Challenge Program. Seedor said Piambu is excited because he can see light and dark shapes and he should soon know for certain if some of his vision has been restored.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Cheney Returning to Washington With a Call for Further Bombing
description: After a weekend of listening to the strategic advice of American field commanders in Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney flew back to Washington today for meetings with President Bush on the next steps the United States and its allies should take in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Subway Graffiti Back and Bothersome
description: In spite of a vigorous and largely successful six-year campaign to rid the New York City subway system of graffiti, Transit Authority officials say the number of "hits" on trains doubled from 1989 to 1990.

title: Good Will Through Golf
description: FRESH from putting a dent in a Hawaiian cabdriver's taxi with a tire iron last week, the Giants' Lawrence Taylor finished the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by hitting a recovery shot off the rocks that dinged the golf cart of the tournament host.

title: Reviews/Music; Baritone's Recital Debut
description: Kevin McMillan is a young Canadian baritone who made a good impression singing the title role of Mendelssohn's oratorio "Elijah" with Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic in December. Last Tuesday night, he appeared at the 92d Street Y for his New York recital debut, offering Schubert's song cycle "Die Schone Mullerin."

title: Must Whistling Skyscraper Change Tune? Hearing to Decide
description: For 48 years, Frank Siegfried played the violin professionally, from the Artie Shaw and Radio City Music Hall orchestras to the pit band of "Jesus Christ Superstar." Mr. Siegfried loves music, but even he has had to draw the line at a building that whistles, generally an octave above middle C.

title: Stars Play Sloppily As East Edges West
description: Everyone wanted to be a showman here today at the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game. But some players tried too hard and some made too many mistakes.

title: How Will It Be in the New World Order?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * As part of the new partnership between Dentsu, the giant Japanese agency, and Young & Rubicam, HDM Worldwide Direct, Los Angeles, has reorganized and changed its name to Bowes Dentsu & Partners. The direct-response agency will focus on the United States, with offices in Los Angeles, Chicago and New York. * Ketchum International, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc., has acquired a majority of Frenz Advertising, Germany.

title: Orion Looks for Ways To Turn Its Recent Success Into a Trend
