description: After a long box-office drought that plunged it into the red, the Orion Pictures Corporation is savoring the success of "Dances With Wolves," a $100 million hit the rest of Hollywood was convinced would never work. But the company needs several more hit movies quickly if it is to assure its survival, studio executives and financial analysts say.

title: Mario Firmino Miguel, Portuguese Army Chief, 52
description: The commander in chief of the Portuguese Army, Gen. Mario Firmino Miguel, was killed in a car accident, the army said today. He was 52 years old.

title: The Hue and Cry of Love
description: Roses are red,Violets are blue,Sugar is sweetAnd so are you. Nursery rhyme, suitable for St. Valentine's Day

title: Report Criticizes Cleanup at Atomic Arms Plants
description: A Congressional study says the Government's effort to clean up atomic weapons plants is being hampered by a shortage of resources and a lack of public credibility, and it criticizes the Energy Department for understating the health threat posed by the plants.

title: Like Champion, Like Contender
description: FLOYD PATTERSON, the former heavyweight champion, enjoys telling a neat story about his adopted son that always forces him to smile. It happened about 10 years ago when a reporter asked him why he adopted Tracy Harris, a promising boxer he trained. Knowing that Tracy was nearby, Patterson said, "Because I fell in love with him."

title: National Health Insurance Benefits Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Sports Aren't a Pain in the Back
description: FOR the runner who can't get out on the road or the tennis player who can't serve because of an aching back, hearing from sports medicine experts that no sport is intrinsically bad for your back, or that sports don't cause injury, they just bring out an existing precondition, is not terribly comforting. All the weekend athlete really wants to know is which sports are pain free and which ones might be accompanied by some back pain.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and tomorrow's auction of one-year bills.

title: John Steinbeck 4th, Freelance Writer, 44
description: John Steinbeck 4th, a writer and son of the Nobel Prize-winning author John Steinbeck, died Thursday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in Encinitas, Calif., where he was undergoing surgery for a herniated disc. He was 44 years old and lived in Encinitas.

title: New Opposition Paper Appears in Albania
description: A second opposition paper appeared on the newsstands of Albania today and sold out almost immediately, residents in the capital, Tirana, said.

title: BRITISH AIR TAKES A THIRD OFF FARE TO CROSS ATLANTIC
description: A major fare war erupted over the North Atlantic yesterday when British Airways cut its main trans-Atlantic fare by a third and greatly reduced the penalties for cancellations. The moves sharply increase the financial pressure on Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways, its ailing rivals.

title: Salvador Editor Says Attack Won't Keep Paper Shuttered
description: The director of an independent newspaper whose presses were destroyed in a fire that officials described as arson said today that the paper would continue to publish.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Some Palestinians Are Permitted to Return to Jobs
description: The Israeli Army allowed some West Bank and Gaza Palestinians to return to their jobs in Israel today for the first time in three weeks.

title: Getting Into The Groove
description: A new practice device for golfers is designed to tell you electronically how far you have hit a ball. Sensors mounted to a cross arm measure the force of each swing to a tethered ball and relay the distance the ball might have traveled.

title: Chinese Dissident Begins a Fast to Delay His Trial
description: A leading democracy advocate charged with sedition has gone on a hunger strike in prison in hopes of delaying his trial, friends and family members said today.

title: Assessing the Damage to OPEC
description: OPEC, founded in 1960 in Baghdad, may now be withering there.

title: Market Place; Evaluating Rally Of Small Stocks
description: SMALL stocks are enjoying their best rally in almost a decade, as money pours into the group. While big stocks are rising, the small ones are soaring.

title: Sharp Quake on Guam
description: An earthquake measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale rocked Guam today. The quake, centered near Saipan, about 150 miles southwest of Guam, "was felt strongly by the people of Guam," said Pat Jorgensen, a spokeswoman for the United States Geological Survey here. There were no immediate reports of injuries or structural damage.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Financing; U.S. Has Received $50 Billion in Pledges for War
description: For the first time since the American Revolution, the United States is accepting financial contributions from other countries to pay for a war.

title: Syracuse Booster Is Told to Step Down
description: As a result of Syracuse University's investigation into improprieties in its basketball program, the president of the Hardwood Club, Syracuse's primary basketball fund-raising organization, has been told to resign.

title: A Lot of Big Names At a Collector's Event
description: Presidents' Day is a week away, and Brian Kathenes is ready. He has a tie clip engraved with Richard M. Nixon's signature. He has an envelope with Millard Fillmore's signature where the stamp should have been. He has a form that Woodrow Wilson signed when he was a college president, which he was before he was that other kind of President.

title: Dixon Serves as Inspiration
description: Many of the 231 athletes competing in yesterday's finals of the Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden have aspirations of winning an Olympic medal. After all, the competition was set up in 1975 to provide opportunities for young women, particularly from the inner city, to get exposure to top-flight competition.

title: Polish Debt: Don't Even Ask
description: Poland's overnight leap from centralized economic control to markets has been painful. By stripping away price controls and Government subsidies, prices soared, unemployment rose and living standards dropped at least 10 percent. But Polish endurance is paying off. Export earnings are rising, the currency and inflation have now stabilized, and Poland is about to launch a radical plan to privatize factories and farms.

title: Mencken, Dead, Has More to Say
description: In what are believed to be his final pronouncements from the grave, H. L. Mencken has turned his sharp eye and sharper tongue on many of the major literary figures of this century, proclaiming Sinclair Lewis a drunkard and James Joyce's "Ulysses" a hoax.

title: Vermont Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Evaluating Its Boosters
description: All it takes is $25 to become a Hardwood Club member and pledge your support for Syracuse basketball. Or you can receive more exclusive rights by contributing $600 and joining the Dave Bing Club.

title: USAir to Lay Off 3,585 and Cut 268 Flights
description: USAir Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 3,585 employees, including 660 pilots, as part of major new reduction in flights to try to survive through the current period of slumping traffic and high fuel costs.

title: Compaq Said To Discuss Silicon Link
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has approached Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading maker of computer work stations, to discuss a possible merger, sources close to the two companies said today. Such a merger would unite two of the fastest-growing companies in different sectors of desktop computing and give Compaq an instant entry in the hotly contested work station market.

title: Condoms Can Save Kids' Lives
description: Hundreds of parents, students, clergy, physicians and their patients crowded into a Board of Education meeting last week to talk about AIDS. All discussions of AIDS are painful; this one was especially so. New York already has more AIDS among adolescents than any other city, and the number is certain to increase, given that 80 percent of young New Yorkers have had sexual intercourse by the age of 19.

title: Sony Offers Free Ads High Above Times Sq.
description: The huge television screen that Sony hoisted above Times Square last Thanksgiving has piqued the curiosity of countless passers-by, but it has apparently turned few heads at the city's advertising agencies.

title: Feeling Cheerful? Thank Brain's Left Lobe
description: THE secret to a sunny disposition, or a doleful one for that matter, may lie in a specific pattern of brain activity, recent studies suggest.

title: Shasper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 137,000.Results are in Canadian funds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Banks will announce tomorrow the interest rates for a total of $1.2 billion in six-month and one-year bonds. * First Chicago Corp. is offering $100 million in 11 1/4 percent noncallable subordinated notes due 2001 at 99.55 to yield 11.326 percent through Salomon Brothers. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. * Wells Fargo & Co., San Francisco, is offering $100 million in 8 1/4 percent noncallable notes due 1993 at 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

title: CPAC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Genius's 'Game' Is Suspected in Woman's Death
description: Days after Peggy Carr sipped from a poisoned Coca-Cola, her hair began to fall out and she said her feet felt like they were on fire and she could not walk.

title: Charles W. Beck; Investment Banker, 79
description: Charles W. Beck, president of the investment banking concern of Charles W. Beck & Company, died on Feb. 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the earnings included a net gain from sale of investments of 14 cents a share for 1990 quarter, 6 cents a share for the 1989 quarter, 52 cents a share, or $ 18,675,000, for the year 1990, and 30 cents a share, or $ 11,427,000, for the year 1989.

title: Review/Television; An Hour's Journey Into a Night Of the Soul
description: Spread the word Have you heard? Hey, my brother, This is Lewisburg.

title: Soot Is the Danger In Oilfield Fires
description: To the Editor:

title: Sears, Roebuck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax charge of $ 264.4 million, or $ 155.2 million after taxes, for restructuring of merchandise group. Also included is a tax benefit of $ 139 million for insurance group.c-Included gain of $ 10.5 million, or 3 cents a share, on disposal of operations.d-After income of $ 62.7 million, or 18 cents a share, from discontinued operations, which included income of $ 2.8 million from discontinued operations and $ 59.9 million from gain on disposal of operations.

title: Corrections
description: A map caption on Saturday about Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's visit to Saudi Arabia misstated his itinerary. He visited Riyadh, Taif and two air bases in southwestern Saudi Arabia, but not Dhahran.

title: XL/Datacomp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $ 4.8 million, or 40 cents a share.

title: Trial Starts for Tiananmen Dissident
description: The Government put a leading democracy advocate on trial today for "conspiracy to overthrow the Government," an offense that can bring the death penalty, and barred his wife from attending the trial.

title: Southeastern Michigan Gas Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to give retroactive effect to 5 percent dividends in May 1990 and May 1989 and a 4-for-3 stock split in January 1989.

title: Shelter Components Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transtechnology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 1,697,000 from discontinueed operations.c-Net incomed-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 973,000 for the quarter and $ 3,549,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bankers Offer Their Plan To Bolster Insurance Fund
description: A proposal by bankers to refinance the shaky deposit insurance fund began circulating here today, and regulators and bank lobbyists cautioned that parts of it faced strong opposition.

title: In Jordan: Better the King We Know
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia, once among Jordan's closest allies, are understandably angry at King Hussein for his open expression of sympathy with Iraq. Yet the King is faithfully expressing the feelings of his people, native Jordanians and Palestinian refugees alike. In fact, by giving their sentiments a legitimate political outlet, he may be making it easier to preserve Jordan's military neutrality and its partial compliance with United Nations sanctions against Iraq.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL UConn Puts Clamps on Hoyas Chris Smith scored 17 of his game-high 27 points in the first half and John Gwynn scored 10 of his 15 after intermission to lead Connecticut to a 61-55 victory over Georgetown last night before a sellout crowd of 16,294 fans at the Hartford Civic Center. But it was the Huskies' defense that stole the victory. Employing a tenacious two-three zone defense, UConn shut down the Hoyas' inside game to such an extent that Alonzo Mourning was forced into foul trouble in the first four minutes of the game, held without a field goal and held to a career-low 5 points, all after intermission. While holding Georgetown (15-7 over all, 7-4 in the Big East) to 30 percent shooting for the game, the Huskies (15-7, 6-6) shot 51.4 percent for the game. "I told the guys before the game that when you play a team of high intensity like Georgetown you've got to match their intensity," said the Connecticut coach, Jim Calhoun. Dikembe Mutombo, the 7-2 Georgetown center, who was averaging 16.5 points and 12.2 rebounds, was held to 11 points. Furman 104, East Tennessee State 93: Hal Henderson scored a career-high 29 points to spark the Paladins in a Southern Conference game. Furman (17-6 over all, 9-2 in the Southern) has won 10 in its last 11 games and 13 in a row at home. East Tennessee (21-3, 9-2) saw its winning streak snapped at seven games. (AP) Ohio State 81, Michigan 65: Jim Jackson scored 21 points as the Buckeyes gained a share of first place in the Big Ten Conference with Indiana. Ohio State (20-1 over all, 10-1 in the Big Ten) won its 15th consecutive game at home. Michael Talley scored 21 points for Michigan (11-10, 4-7). (AP) TENNIS Rosset Upsets Svensson Unseeded Marc Rosset of Switzerland beat fifth-seeded Jonas Svensson, 6-0, 6-4, yesterday on the opening day of the Donnay indoor tournament in Brussels. In other matches, Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union beat Juan Aguilera of Spain, 6-2, 6-2, and sixth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union beat Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4. Pat Cash, a wild-card entry who has slipped badly in the world ranking, struggled to a 2-6, 7-6, 6-3 victory over Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia. (AP) Raoux Beats Goldie in Philadelphia: Guillaume Raoux of France beat Dan Goldie, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday in the opening round of the United States Pro Indoor tournament in Philadelphia. Alexander Mronz of Germany qualified to play fourth-seeded John McEnroe by defeating Horatio de la Pena, 6-2, 6-2. (AP) COLLEGE HOCKEY Boston University Wins Beanpot Boston University broke open a tense contest with three quick goals near the end of the second period last night and defeated Boston College, 8-4, to win the Beanpot Tournament at Boston Garden for the second year in a row. The Terriers' Tony Amonte, who scored three goals, was voted the tournament's most valuable player. This was Boston University's (20-9-2) 16th Beanpot championship, and the sixth won at the expense of Boston College (24-8-0) since 1970. Northeastern won the consolation game with a 5-0 victory over Harvard.

title: U.S. Filter Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary net operating loss carryforwards of $ 165,000 for the quarter and $ 283,000 for the 9 months.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 489,000.All share earnings are less than 1 cent a share.

title: OPEC Output Declines
description: OPEC's daily production of crude oil dropped by 760,000 barrels in January, primarily because of the Persian Gulf war, the Middle East Economic Survey reports. It said the total daily output of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was 23.1 million barrels, down from 23.86 million in December.

title: Apple Upgrades Portable, Cuts Cost
description: Apple Computer Inc. lowered the price of its Macintosh Portable by more than $1,000, added back lighting to make the screen easier to read and increased the internal memory by one megabyte. The changes represent an effort to improve the poor sales of the machine, but they are not expected to help much because the computer, which weighs more than 15 pounds, is still considered too heavy to compete with notebook computers that weigh five to seven pounds.

title: Times Co. Reports a Profit Of $12.2 Million in 4th Period
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported net income for the fourth quarter of $12.2 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with a loss of $19 million for the quarter a year earlier.

title: RAC Mortgage Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Top Poodle Leads Four Into Final
description: The top-winning poodle in the breed's history, Ch. Whisperwind on a Carousel, last night became the finalists in the 115th Westminster Kennel Club dog show, which opened a two-day run in Madison Square Garden.

title: Quality Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Intermark Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 46,000 in the quarter and $ 2,014,000, or 16 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net incomed-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,246,000 in the quarter and $ 1,619,000 in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included an extraordinary gain from a change in accounting practices related to subsidiary stock sales of $ 6,403,000, or 70 cents a share.

title: Reviews/Music; A Philharmonic Surprise
description: Concert programs often follow a standard pattern: something relatively inconsequential, then a concerto and finally a self-consciously serious Romantic symphony. On the surface, the current New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, which can be heard for the last time tonight, conforms to that formula. But the way things turned out late Friday morning, it was the beginning "throwaway" that gave the most pleasure, followed by the concerto and ending, at the bottom of the list, with the symphony after the intermission.

title: War Summary
description: THE "AIR-LAND BATTLE" PUT ON HOLD

title: Iberia Air Plans Up to 10% Staff Cut
description: Iberia, the state-owned airline, said it would begin talks with unions aimed at temporarily cutting staff by as much as 10 percent. The airline said the layoffs were needed because a reduction in passengers since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis in August had cost it about $1.1 million in lost revenue.

title: Market Place; Sickly Ambase: Now a Bargain?
description: THE Ambase Corporation, parent of the Home Group of insurance companies, rode every giddy, improbable wave of the 80's.

title: Holmes Settles Suit
description: Larry Holmes, the former heavyweight champion, has settled a four-year-old lawsuit with the widow of the New York sportswriter Dick Young, whom Holmes had ejected from one of his sparring sessions.

title: Key Rates
Board of Unisys to Suspend Preferred Stock Dividend
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that its board had voted to suspend its preferred stock dividends, saving the heavily indebted computer company $120 million a year. The company, based in Blue Bell, Pa., also repeated that it plans to sell assets, noting publicly for the first time that the assets for sale were valued at more than $1 billion.

title: Lucky Duck Comeback Pays Big Dividend
description: Same ring, different outcome.

title: Earning the Right to Borrow
description: Deficit financing -- jargon for going into debt -- is getting attention right now because the financier Felix Rohatyn has suggested that borrowing might save New York City from fiscal disaster. Mayor David Dinkins hasn't ruled out the idea. But it's a dangerous one.

title: Real Fans Know Who 'Must Go'
description: For those disappointed by the Knicks' dismal season, have no fear. Al Bianchi is as good as gone as general manager.

title: A Guilty Plea Ends Bronx Prosecution Of School Officials
description: Jerome A. Greene, the former president of Community School Board 9 in the Bronx, pleaded guilty to larceny charges yesterday, the Bronx District Attorney said.

title: War Renews Interest in Sea-Air-Space Museum
description: Since the hostilities in the Persian Gulf began on Jan. 16, attendance has more than doubled at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum in Manhattan, which has had more than its share of financial problems in recent years. During the last few weekends there have been 5,000 visitors, compared with less than half that number in the same period last year.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Federan and state open. City closed. Post offices: Regular service. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleanings. Schools: Open. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Busses, subways, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular schedule. New York Schools Are Open New York's public schools are open today. The Times erroneously reported yesterday that they would be closed for Lincoln's Birthday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal open, state closed. Local option. Post offices: Regular service. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal open, state closed. Local option. Post offices: Regular service. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule.

title: Review/Music; Parnas and Lipkin in Recital
description: Aspiring young performers work mostly on technique. Musicianship, for the gifted ones who acquire it at all, tends to come later -- often much later. But once acquired, musicianship, by way of compensation, proves durable, lingering even after technique begins to falter with age.

title: Airlines Ban Smoking And Air Piracy, Too
description: A man upset about being unable to smoke aboard a flight from Oakland to San Diego on Sunday wrote a note saying he was carrying explosives and demanding $13 million and a flight to Cuba, the authorities said. A few minutes later the man said it was just a joke.

title: Revere Fund reports earnings for As of Jan 31
description: Assets represented net asset value.

title: Davis Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net incomeLatest share earnings for the quarter is fully diluted.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 3 Girls Arrested as Arsonists
description: Three middle-school girls were arrested and charged with setting a fire that destroyed an abandoned factory today, authorities said. The three, an 11-year-old and two 13-year-olds, were charged with third-degree arson and released to the custody of their parents. The police did not release their names because of their ages.

title: CHRONICLE
description: While playing his final performance in a speaking role in "Die Fledermaus" on Friday night at the Metropolian Opera, DOM DE LUISE got a surprise. Just when he was making a wisecrack about LUCIANO PAVAROTTI , who is not in the opera, onto the stage burst Mr. Pavarotti, accompanied by two policemen.

title: Diagnostic-Retrieval Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Dance; Fresh Talent in Graham Ensemble
description: Performances by young dancers tend to have a distinctive freshness and spirit. That was true of a program by the Martha Graham Ensemble on Thursday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: DOW SURGES 71.54
description: The stock market caught fire yesterday, scoring strong new gains in heavy trading and rising to its highest level since just before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.

title: Transnet Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The increases in revenues for both the latest second quarter and 6 months were attributable primarily to the acquisition of Round Valley Computer Center Inc.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 22,982 for the quarter and $ 49,797 for the 6 months.

title: Alliant TechSystems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that net income for the latest fourth quarter reflects a one-time benefit of about $ 6.5 million from the recognition of tax benefits not recognizable at the spinoff date.Alliant TechSystems was spun off from Honeywell Inc. on Sept. 28, 1990.

title: Ribi Immunochem Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yes, Building Whistles, Judge Rules, but It May Be Legal
description: A judge yesterday took up the case of New York City's first whistling building and ruled, after weighing the evidence, that the building was in fact whistling. But before him lies a more complicated question: is the whistling illegal?

title: Gibson Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Japanese Symbol of Excess
description: It was bad when the banks sent their people to monitor his debt-laden operations and worse when they slammed the brakes on his hectic pace of property acquisitions. But now the bankers say the three private jets must go.

title: Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an aftertax charge of $ 10 million for the consolidation of operations in the company's marine segment in both the quarter and year.c-Included a net gain of $ 46.7 million from the disposition of the nondefense businesses of the company's technical segment.d-Net loss

title: Lotus to Add Electronic Mail Unit
description: The Lotus Development Corporation is attempting to build on its early success in providing valuable software programs for groups of workers connected by computer networks. The company said yesterday that it would acquire the largest publisher of electronic mail programs for personal computers, cc:Mail Inc., and announced an upgraded version of its own Notes computer conferencing program.

title: The New York Times Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After income of $ 198,448,000, or $ 2.52 a share, from discontinued operations, which included gain on the sale of The New York Times cable television and operations prior to the sale date.The latest periods included equity in operations of the forest products group of $ 38,000 for the fourth quarter and $ 3,965,000 for the 12 months.The year-ago quarter and 12 months' results included a charge of $ 27.2 million for a valuation reserve against the company's investment in its forest products group. Equity in operations of the forest products group before the charge totaled $ 2.1 million for the quarter and $ 11.3 million for the 12 months.The year-ago periods also included $ 30 million of costs related to anticipated voluntary union staff reductions.The Times said that the structuring of its McCall's and Golf World acquisitions lowered the latest periods earnings by 8 cents a share in the quarter and 29 cents a share in the year, compared with 9 cents a share and 18 cents a share, for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Gant Gets Giant Raise
description: Ron Gant, who became a major league star last season after plummeting to the minors, was rewarded yesterday with a raise of more than $1 million. Gant, who batted .303 with 32 home runs and 84 runs batted for the Braves, agreed to Atlanta's offer of $1,195,000 after having earned $150,000 last year. The outfielder had sought $1.34 million in salary arbitration, compared with the Braves' offer of $900,000.

title: Gasoline Prices Decline
description: Lower winter demand and increased oil supplies have pushed gasoline prices lower by more than 5 cents a gallon at stations nationwide in the last two weeks, a survey has found. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service stations, including taxes, was $1.2522 a gallon on Friday, down 5.13 cents from Jan. 25, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of more than 13,000 service stations.

title: Alexander & Alexander Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 1,100,000, or 3 cents a share.The company said net income for the 1990 fourth quarter included a gain of 21 cents a share, from the settlement of certain pension obligations in the U.K. and charges of 15 cents a share related primarily to the restructuring of the company's global operations.

title: Tax Help for DOS-Based Machines
description: THE Federal income tax begun 77 years ago did not require the use of a personal computer. Those fortunate enough to earn $3,000 to $500,000 a year were simply asked to pay 1 percent of the total to Uncle Sam. In contrast, the "simplified" 1990 tax laws almost demand a computer, as much to keep track of forms as to do the calculations. Luckily there are more than a dozen personal tax preparation programs available to make the ordeal easier.

title: Computer Data Service Is Shut Down by Nynex
description: The Nynex Corporation yesterday become the latest company to discontinue its electronic information service, which has lost money in its three years of operation.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Finance Shortage The Federal fund that helps finance Presidential campaigns with tax money is facing a shortage, and support for primary election candidates in 1992 may be in peril. Page A16. Expelled for Racial Epithets Brown University expelled a student for shouting racial epithets in perhaps the first such action under rules banning "hate speech." Page A17. Radiation Leak in Japan The Japanese company that operates the nuclear power plant involved in a weekend accident conceded that a "small amount" of radiation had been released. Page A3. Fighting Malaria's Scourge As drug-resistant malaria spreads, doctors say discoveries are laying the groundwork for new ways to fight the disease. Science Times, page C1.

title: Black Writers Gain Audiences And Visibility in Publishing
description: Books by black writers have suddenly become an important force in American publishing, as well as in the world of belles-lettres. Current and forthcoming catalogues abound with a vast range of books by blacks -- literary novels, westerns, memoirs, works of scholarship and blueprints for making money.

title: Allies Step Up Gulf Air Offensive; Strikes Focus on Iraqis in Kuwait
description: As the skies cleared and an American officer proclaimed it "a beautiful day for bombing," the allies said today that they were stepping up their already furious air assault on Iraq's Republican Guards and other ground forces in occupied Kuwait.

title: Who's Afraid of Nationhood Now? Few, It Seems
description: Like many Quebecers, Genevieve Roy remembers exactly where she was when she heard that Rene Levesque had died, on Nov. 1, 1987. She was in Pennsylvania, driving to design classes at the Art Institute of Pittsburgh, and the radio report of the death of the man who led the independence struggle in Quebec marked, she says, a watershed in her life.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day yesterday about campaign plans for the Bronx Zoo misstated the surname and title of an executive at the zoo's agency, Geer, Dubois. He is Rodney Underwood, not Underhill; he is the agency's vice chairman and creative director, not executive vice president.

title: Rewards Of War
description: There is something in America's value system that threatens the lives of G.I.'s in the gulf: It is more rewarding for a President to win a war than to avert one. This may not be obvious to Americans, but it is striking for a visitor from Germany like myself.

title: Pause for Peace
description: Before America hurries into an incalculably costly ground war, the Bush Administration should order a temporary halt in allied bombing that would give third parties such as Jordan and Iran a chance to mediate an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. No one can guarantee that Saddam Hussein would accept a peace proposal. But given the fearsome consequences of continued fighting, we must make the effort.

title: Sears to Cut More Jobs; Profit Falls
description: Continuing a cost-cutting drive to try to regain its competitive edge, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced today that it was eliminating 9,000 more full- and part-time jobs in its struggling merchandise group. The trims will bring to 33,000 the number of jobs cut by the end of the year.

title: Dana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1990 full year included a $ 25 million special charge due to increased loan loss reserves at its Diamond Savings & Loan unit. Its 1989 full year included $ 14 million of non-recurring gains.

description: Louis Shapiro, a retired associate justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court and a former majority leader in the State House of Representatives, died on Friday at Hartford Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Farmington.

title: Durable Landmark to Irish Glory Fading Out on the East Side
description: From under a bold green awning, the Mattie Haskins Shamrock Imports shop has for decades been a magnet for new neighbors, old regulars and nostalgic Irishmen, who took the time to stop for a chat over a cup of tea.

title: Farm Plantings Forecast
description: Corn farmers intend to increase plantings this spring to 77.5 million acres, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today. Soybean plantings are expected to rise 1 percent, to 58.5 million acres, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said. Total wheat plantings for the 1991 harvest, including winter wheat planted last fall and spring-planted varieties, were forecast at about 68.6 million acres, down 11 percent from last year. The 1991 planting figures were based on a special survey of nearly 19,000 farmers to help determine how much land may be used for the major crops this year.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: In the N.H.L. They're Specialists, Not Goons
description: On opening night, Troy Crowder, a New Jersey rookie, beat up Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings, the reigning heavyweight champion of the National Hockey League. Seconds after they took the ice together on Jan. 28, the much-talked about rematch began. Probert won. Later in the game, they fought again, to a draw.

title: Johnson Wins Race After 30-Minute Wait
description: When the Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson won at Osaka, Japan, in 1985, 1986 and 1987, the gap between him and his competition was measured in meters. Yesterday, in Johnson's fourth comeback race after a two-year suspension for using steroids, judges needed 30 minutes before officially declaring him the winner of the 60-meter dash.

title: K N Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 25,654,000, or $ 2.70 a share, from ETSI Coal Slurry pipeline litigation settlement.

title: Japan Now Tells of Radiation Release
description: The company that operates the nuclear power plant involved in a major accident over the weekend provided a new account of events today, saying for the first time that operators waited 50 minutes before moving to shut down the plant and that a "small amount" of radiation had been released into the atmosphere.

title: Accounts
description: * Steuben Glass, a division of Corning Inc., to Graf Bertel Dominique, a unit of TBWA Advertising, which previously held the account. Billings were not disclosed. * John Breuner Co., San Ramone, Calif., to Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, for a broadcast campaign for its Breuner's and Barker Brothers furniture stores. Billings are $2.5 million.

title: Toy Sales Mostly Flat; Hasbro Gains
description: Despite a dismal Christmas for the toy industry, Hasbro Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter performance was relatively strong. The toy maker said earnings rose 16.3 percent to $27.9 million, or 49 cents a share, from $24 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Medical Historians See Paul as Epileptic
description: To the Editor:

title: Trench Battle Routs Drugs In the Bronx
description: When the corner got so thick with drug dealers that ordinary people could not use the sidewalk, the neighbors had the pay telephone yanked out. Then they nagged the owner of a lot that was being used as a drug shooting gallery until he put up a chain-link fence. Next the merchants chipped in and hired private guards with attack dogs to patrol the main avenue.

title: Detroit Police Chief And Former Deputy Charged With Theft
description: Detroit's Police Chief and his former civilian deputy were indicted by a Federal grand jury today and charged with stealing $2.6 million from a police undercover operations fund.

title: 2 U.S. Agencies Differ On Food Label Rules
description: The Department of Agriculture has tentatively proposed new nutrition labeling rules for fresh meat and poultry that conflict with labeling regulations approved by Congress last year for other foods, Federal officials said today.

title: UNC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 128,000.c-Net lossd-After a loss of $ 406,000 for the quarter and income of $ 3,427,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Ingles Markets reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Worn Out, Some Step Back From Fight Against AIDS
description: Marie St. Cyr first encountered AIDS nine years ago when she headed a social-services program in Florida. A client in his 30's began losing weight and falling ill for no apparent reason; he soon died.

description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $ 17,000 for the quarter and $ 43,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months.c-Net loss

title: Beneficial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 13,400,000, or or 60 cents a share, and an extraordinary charge to fully write off company's entire investment as a limited partner in certain leveraged real estate partnerships for both the quarter and year.The company said included in 1990 fourth quarter net income were several special items, the effect of which offset one another. In December 1990, the company received a $ 34 million payment in full steelement of a contingent note and an equity option it held in the insurance subsidiaries which were sold in 1987 as part of the company's major corporate restructuring. The net aftertax gain from this payment of about $ 20 million is reflected in income from discontinued operations.Offsettng this credit in discontinued operations was a $ 7 million net aftertax charge to reflect a credit guarantee issued by the company to the purchaser of two Eastern Airlines 727-200 aircraft leveraged leases included in the leveraged lease portfolio sold during Beneficial's restructuring.The company also recorded a $ 13.4 million net aftertax extraordinary charge to fully write offs its entire investment as a limited partner in certain leveraged real estate partnerships. Accordingly, the net impact of these items on net income is nill.The company also said that in the latest fourth quarter net chargeoffs increased to $ 29.1 million from $ 20.6 million in the fourth quarter of 1989. For the full year, net chargeoffs increased to $ 100.1 million, compared to net chargeoffs of $ 78 million in 1989.

title: Kustom Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income

title: SWISS TO SPONSOR CUBA'S DIPLOMATS
description: Switzerland announced today that it would replace Czechoslovakia as formal sponsor of the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, assuring that the United States and Cuba will continue to have diplomatic representation in each other's capitals.

title: NSC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Katie Louchheim Is Dead at 87; Official for U.S. and Democrats
description: Katie Louchheim, a former State Department official and a former vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee who was a prominent figure in the social life of Washington for four decades, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87 years old.

title: Leslie Fay Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: The company said results for the fourth quarter of 1989 included a pretax reserve provision of $ 1.9 million for the accounts receivable owned to it by Allied/Federated Stores at the time of their bankruptcy. Also included in that quarter is a pretax writeoff of $ 665,000 for the closing of the Knitivo division.

title: Coca-Cola Prices $200 Million Issue
description: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday priced $200 million in notes due Feb. 15, 1996, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Jack Winter, 82, Dies; Clothing Manufacturer
description: Jack A. Winter, a Wisconsin clothing manufacturer, died Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old and maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Fox Point, Wis.

title: Take Our Poor, Angry Hartford Tells Suburbs
description: Raymond Eugene Shipman says Hartford cannot afford to play nice anymore. Since arriving last fall to become City Manager, he has bluntly, repeatedly described what he sees as the main source of this troubled capital city's problems: its isolation as an urban core, kept impoverished by state tax policies and suburban attitudes.

title: Up Close: The Natural World From an Ant's-Eye View
description: Scientists whose studies take them into the microscopic world sometimes come across natural forms of striking beauty.

title: BMTC Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,952,000, or 32 cents a share, and an extraordinary credit of $ 15,393,000, or $ 1.21 a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Redlaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian funds.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: NEW GLORY Flag waving is fashionable again, among both supporters and opponents of the war. Page B6. NETWORKS' ANGER DEEPENS News executives from two television networks accused CNN of making concessions to the Iraqis in exchange for special access to news from Baghdad in the first three weeks of the war. The Arts, page C11. MEXICO'S WINDFALL Mexico pocketed a reported windfall of more than $3 billion when oil prices surged after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, but it squirreled the money away in anticipation of weak demand and lower prices. Business Day, page D6.

title: Rocket Delayed
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail's private workout for National Football League scouts was postponed to Feb. 21 because of his hectic schedule, a Notre Dame spokesman said yesterday.

title: Russian in Iraq, Soviets Tell U.S.
description: Soviet officials informed the Bush Administration today that Moscow's senior Middle East envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, would enter Iraq today by land from Iran, but a Pentagon official said tonight that he was not aware of any special precautions taken to protect the diplomat from allied bombing.

title: Outwitted by Malaria, Desperate Doctors Seek New Remedies
description: MALARIA invulnerable to drugs is spreading across the world, leaving a widening trail of suffering and death.

title: Pact at American Airlines Makes Some Pilots Best-Paid in Industry
description: The conditional labor agreement that American Airlines and its pilots reached Saturday includes salary increases that will make some, but not all, of them the best-paid in the airline industry.

title: Q&A
description: Sore Throat Relief

title: Condom Plan To Be Debated By the Regents
description: The State Board of Regents will consider requiring the distribution of condoms in schools across the state, a measure that was recommended recently by the state's AIDS Advisory Council, several Regents said today.

title: Chess
description: The top female players are showing less and less respect for grandmaster adversaries all the time nowadays. They are not to be intimidated or flustered by the sex or rank of their opponents. Their attitude seems to be the practical and confident one of expecting the player who makes the best moves to in the game, and if it isn't the grandmaster opponent, that's his worry.

title: 30-Year Bonds Are Issued by ITT
description: The ITT Corporation yesterday priced $250 million in 30-year debentures due Feb. 15, 2021, through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: TII Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Mockery Is Made Of Disney Memo
description: First came the Memo, a 28-page analysis of the state of the motion picture industry prepared last month by Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of Disney Studios . An attack on "runaway costs and mindless competition," the memo quickly became required reading in Hollywood. Now there is the Sequel, a deft parody of Disney's and Mr. Katzenberg's corporate style that has studio executives here in stitches.

description: b-Included one-time, after-tax charges, including restructuring reserve, of $ 52 million.c-Net incomeThe company noted that 1990 results included one-time, after-tax charges, including a restructuring reserve to reposition the North American refrigeration manufacturing operation.The company said in the latest fourth quarter, interest in Brazilian affiliates resulted in an equity loss of $ 20 million, compared with earnings of $ 3 million, or 4 cents a share, in year-ago period.

description: Sales represented net sales.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE IS PUTTING OFF LAND-WAR DECISION
description: After meeting with his top two military advisers, President Bush said today that he would continue the bombing of Iraqi positions and put off making the politically difficult decision about whether to order American ground troops into combat.

title: Seel Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Citing South Africa Ties, Florio Barring Shell Oil From Turnpike
description: The Shell Oil Company will not be allowed to operate service stations along the New Jersey Turnpike beyond next year because of the operations of Shell's parent company in South Africa, Gov. Jim Florio said today.

title: TORY GROUP BACKS BLACK CANDIDATE
description: Hoping to put an end to an ugly political debate charged by allegations of racism, British Conservatives in western England have agreed to unite behind a black barrister as their candidate for the House of Commons.

title: Chip Indicator Up a Bit
description: The semiconductor industry's key indicator, the book-to-bill ratio, rose slightly in January, but both sales and orders in the American market declined from December's levels, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today. The book-to-bill ratio, which compares new orders, or bookings, with shipments, or billings, shows that for every $100 of chips sold in January in the United States, only $96 in new orders was received, a sign that business was not strong.

Review/Theater; Talking Dogs and Dastardly Deeds
description: Trapped in a stale marriage, a woman (Christine Toy) seeks help from a psychiatrist and is advised to get a dog for company. She names her new pet Carl. In Peter Tolan's "Stay Carl Stay," the title character is given a waggish performance by Daniel Hagen. This shaggy dog story is the riotously funny finale to four amusing plays in Evening A of the Manhattan Punch Line festival of one-act comedies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
description: There were more political advertisements on television in 1990 than in any other non-Presidential national election year, according to a survey by the Television Bureau of Advertising Inc.

title: Dinkins Reflects on Trip to Israel
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, reflecting yesterday on his trip to Israel last week, said that black criticism of his visit came from only a handful of people and that the relationship between blacks and Jews -- old allies in the civil rights struggle -- was still good.

title: Judge Orders Trial for Woman In Infants' Starvation Deaths
description: A 23-year-old woman was ordered Monday to stand trial in the starvation deaths of her 7-month-old twin daughters.

title: Northwest Air Raises Possibility of a Merger
description: In a letter to employees today, the co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, Alfred Checchi, broached the idea of merging with a stronger airline or selling the carrier's lucrative Pacific routes.

title: Support for Iraqis Grows in Nigeria's North
description: The manager of the Fahad supermarket here, Malam Isyaku Bature, recently received an ominous warning from his neighbors: either change the name of the store or "something very bad could happen."

title: Rising Number Of Blind Found To Be Illiterate
description: The head of a national parents group says there is a crisis of illiteracy among blind students because many of them are not learning Braille in public schools.,

title: New Cause Of Concern On Global Warming
description: A CHEMICAL that limits heat-trapping methane in the atmosphere has been significantly depleted in the Northern Hemisphere, according to a computerized simulation of atmospheric processes by scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

title: Patterns
description: Transatlantic Shuffle

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debentures of $ 211,000 and $ 644,000 in the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Lincoln: Was He America's Bismarck?
description: Can an analogy be drawn between our Civil War and Otto von Bismarck's achievement of German unification in 1871? It is true that the American Union had been brought into existence almost a century earlier. But was that Union a

title: CHRONICLE
description: President CORAZON C. AQUINO of the Philippines testified yesterday before a Manila court hearing her libel case against a popular newspaper columnist.

title: Cycare Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe 1990 year-end results included a pretax charge of $ 20.9 million taken in the second quarter related primarily to management's decision to refocus the company on its core business, physician-controlled-entities.

description: b-After realized investment losses of $ 4,254,000.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 11,585,000.d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,180,000 in the quarter and $ 7,165,000 in the year.Latest year's income from continuing operations of $ 61,240,000, or $ 4.90 a share, is after realized investment loss of $ 24,244,000 and included one-time gain of $ 13 million from the release of accrued income taxes no longer necessary after a second quarter settlement of the 1981-1985 tax years.Year-ago quarter and year's continuing operations of $ 16,789,000 and $ 60,649,000, respectively, are after realized investment losses of $ 3,129,000 in the quarter and $ 11,586,000 in the year.

title: TV Anchor Is Slain in Michigan
description: A television anchor who had received threatening calls and a letter from a rebuffed male admirer was shot to death in her driveway, but investigators today did not rule out other suspects.

title: Richard Simmons, A Bank Executive And a Lawyer, 62
description: Richard Sheridan Simmons, a lawyer, banker and an expert on banking law, died on Sunday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla., where he maintained a winter home. He was 62 years old and lived in Plandome Manor, L.I.

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Case Dropped Against Clerk in Playboy Sale
description: A convenience store clerk was arrested here for selling a Playboy magazine to two 16-year-old boys, then was strip-searched and forced to spend the night in jail.

title: Business Scene; Industry's Tactics To Deflect Slump
description: THE recession has severely damaged major industries, among them real estate, construction, auto making, banking and finance. But for the vast majority of manufacturers -- the heart of the American economy -- the recession is just beginning to undermine operations. And the great hope of the executives who run these companies is that by fall the recession will have ended, leaving them almost unscathed.

title: Olsten Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included restructuring charge after tax of $ 2.3 million relating to consolidation of existing operations with Upjohn Healthcare Services Inc. and Health Care Services Upjohn Ltd. for both the quarter and year.Latest quarter and year revenues included revenues of $ 16.3 million from Health Care operations of Upjohn Healthcare Services Inc. and Health Care Services Upjohn Ltd. since acquisition Dec. 1, 1990. The operations did not contribute to operating income during the period.

title: Too Many A's Seen at A. M. Best
description: A. M. Best, the 92-year-old company on which thousands of American corporations and consumers depend for evaluations of the financial health of insurance companies, is being accused of grade inflation. A new study concludes that it is significantly easier for insurance companies to win a top rating from Best than from two other major raters of insurance companies -- Standard & Poor's and Moody's.

title: 'The Last Day of Spring'
description: That's how a New Yorker overheard in an elevator this week described Sunday. "No more softball, no more beach," he added sadly. An unexceptional statement, really -- except that he was making it in early February.

title: Student at Brown Is Expelled Under a Rule Barring 'Hate Speech'
description: Brown University has expelled a student for shouting racial epithets, thereby violating an anti-harassment rule enacted in 1989 as part of an effort by the university to combat racism on campus. It is the first time a Brown student has been expelled for such a violation and is thought to be the first such expulsion in the country.

title: Cons HCI Holdings reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6,090,000. The company said stock portfolio operated by investment division was disposed of at a loss.c-Net incomeYear-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinued operation of the investment division.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: One Argument That Competition Has Its Beginnings in the Embryo
description: Animals of the same species compete for food, mates and shelter. Siblings in a litter vie for access to the mother's teats. From birth onward, competition is one of life's few guarantees.

title: Smear from the Whip
description: Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming let fly last week with words too snide even for Bart Simpson. At a Washington press luncheon, the Republican whip said that Peter Arnett, CNN's correspondent in Baghdad, is "what we used to call in my day a sympathizer. . . . He was active in the Vietnam War and he won a Pulitzer Prize largely because of his anti-Government material." Those sentiments awaken thoughts of Senator Joe McCarthy.

title: Europe Backs Brewery Deal
description: The European Commission today cleared a proposed asset swap between Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Courage, the brewing arm of Elders IXL Ltd., after the companies agreed to an adjustment in the deal.

title: Frontier Insurance Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Vincent Sounds Off On Return
description: Declaring, like Mark Twain, that "reports of my demise are extremely premature," Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, returned to his office yesterday after an 81-day absence and fired off one of his most pointed verbal shots ever at George Steinbrenner.

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday listing closing schedules for the Lincoln's Birthday holiday referred erroneously to the New York City public schools. They are open today. A corrected table appears today on page B1.

title: Review/Music; Exercises in Simplicity
description: Through his magazine Soundings, Peter Garland has been a broker for original ideas in American music. Composers, many of whom showed up for a concert of Mr. Garland's own music at the Greenwich House on Thursday night, owe their publisher and promoter much for making experimentation a less lonely occupation.

title: BASKETBALL: Notebook; Dunleavy Recalls Knicks' Glory Days
description: During the 1971-72 season, when the Los Angeles Lakers won a record 33 straight games, Mike Dunleavy was a heavily-recruited senior at Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, always looking for a game of HORSE, much the way be does now, as the Lakers' 36-year-old rookie coach.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an Iraqi missile attack on Israel referred incorrectly in some copies to the four deaths in previous attacks. Israeli officials said that three of the people died of heart attacks and that the fourth person was crushed to death when his home fell on him.

title: Par Pharmaceutical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 629,000, or 6 cents a share.Year-ago loss from continuing operations of $ 1,069,000 included a $ 637,000 charge for minority interest in earnings of subsidiary.The company said the current quarter's loss was substantially attributable to losses and write-offs incurred by Par's injectable manufacturing subsidiary, Quad Pharmaceuticals Inc., which voluntarily ceased shipment of its approved products in March 1990.

title: Who's No. 1 In Science? Footnotes Say U.S.
description: BY the seemingly mindless technique of tallying footnotes in journal articles, investigators are piecing together a revealing view of scientific enterprise.

title: O'Brien Energy Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net charge resulting from the settlement of litigation amounting to $ 355,000.c-Net incomeYear-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisitions of Mobile Power Rental Co. The acquisition was treated in a manner similar to a pooling of interests.

title: A Japanese Symbol of Excess
description: It was bad when the banks sent their people to monitor his debt-laden operations and worse when they slammed the brakes on his hectic pace of property acquisitions. But now the bankers say the three private jets must go.

title: Grossman's to Sell Or Close 15 Stores
description: Grossman's Inc., a retailer of lumber and building materials, said it would sell or close 15 of its building supply stores in the Northeast. The decision will force the company to absorb a $7.1 million charge for store-closing expenses, leading Grossman's to suffer a net loss of $3.9 million for the fiscal year that ended on Dec. 31. In 1989, Grossman's had a profit of $15.8 million.

title: Morceli Returns
description: Nourredine Morceli, the 20-year-old Algerian who has electrified track fans the last two Friday nights, will get another shot here at the world- indoor record for the mile. Yesterday, he entered the mile in the USA/Mobil national indoor championships, Feb. 22 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The air campaign has been very, very effective and will continue for a while. We are going to take whatever time is necessary to sort out when a next stage might begin." -- President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

title: ITT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company noted numerous charges and items in the latest fourth quarter which totaled $ 221 million, or $ 1.61 a share after-tax: an after-tax charge of $ 48 million for a provision for restructuring and withdrawal from some independent agent-produced personal automobile insurance markets; and an after-tax loss of $ 50 million for a charge to exit the coal business and write down the company's investment in Carbon Industries to its estimated realizable value.The fourth quarter also included an after-tax charge of $ 51 million for a provision for environmental matters principally related to the previously closed Southern Wood Piedmont operation. The charge for SWP and the aforementioned Carbon Industries charge will be reported as discontinued operations.Also included is a $ 71 million after-tax provision to strengthen the reserves of the consumer small loan and real estate portfolios and litigation exposures at ITT Financial Corp.; and a $ 16 million after-tax provision at Electronic Components to reorganize and consolidate Electromechanical components manufacturing facilities in the U.K.The fourth quarter also included a one-time ''fresh start'' tax benefit at ITT Hartford of $ 15 million, or 11 cents a share, associated with the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1990.The company also said its 1990 full-year results were impacted by a third quarter charge of $ 26 million after-tax for the write-off of ITT Sheraton mortgage loans to a hotel property.Income for 1990 benefited from a gain of $ 139 million after-tax, or 99 cents a share, on the company's sale of 7 percent of Alcatel in the second quarter and a gain of $ 47 million, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of ITT's investment in Alcatel Alsthom in the first quarter of 1990.

title: Raymond Paul Wallace; Engineer, 81
description: Raymond Paul Wallace, an engineer and registered patent agent, died on Thursday at Community Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Corrections
description: Two captions in the Long Island Weekly on Sunday about trout fishing misidentified the men pictured. Joe Gardini was shown (above) casting for trout and (below) releasing them, at Connetquot River State Park; the onlooker was Gil Bergen, the park superintendent.

title: Regenex Inc. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The increase in revenues in the latest year was primarily due to the inclusion of CJR Processing Inc., which was acquired in January 1990.

title: Kohl and Major Meet Amid Strains Over War
description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl here today, and afterward both leaders stressed their friendship and common policy goals.

title: Careers; Law Schools Put Stress on Specialization
description: BEYOND torts, property and other first-year basics, law schools are rethinking the second and third years of their programs.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Hudson General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 27,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 337,000, or 28 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Net lossThe company said pre-tax income from its Kohala joint venture with Oxford First Corp. improved to $ 957,000 in the latest quarter, and $ 1,256,000 in the latest 6 months, compared with $ 581,000 and $ 941,000 in the year-ago quarter and 6 months.

title: Some Tough Questions in Teacher's Murder Trial
description: The defense lawyer for Carolyn Warmus today attacked Ms. Warmus's former lover, Paul Solomon, making him acknowledge that he had led on the defendant in their affair, had had other affairs before, and had lied to his wife.

title: Consolidated American reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: GORBACHEV URGES ALLIANCE BE ENDED
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a letter to the chiefs of state of the Warsaw Pact countries today proposing that the alliance's military structures be disbanded by April 1.

title: Spread of Cholera From Peru Expected by Health Agency
description: A senior World Health Organization official said today that a cholera outbreak that had taken 51 lives in Peru since January was likely to spread to neighboring Latin American countries.

title: College in Virginia To Return Old Bell To Japanese Island
description: A 15th-century bronze bell seized by Marines on Okinawa in World War II will be returned to the Japanese island, said an official of the military college where it has been on display for 46 years.

title: Civic Forum, Prague's Leading Party, Splits in Two
description: The Civic Forum, the party born of the mass movement that overthrew Communist rule here 15 months ago and carried its leader, Vaclav Havel, to the presidency, has broken into two wings, it was announced today.

title: Political Pressure Dismantles East German Sports Machine
description: The big bronze statue of the javelin hurler identifies the building as a sports school, but half the javelin is snapped off and the marble base is crumbling. Inside the building that was once the premier academy of the powerful East German sports machine, glass trophy cases gape emptily, and a tax consultant, one of thousands of private businesses sprouting in eastern Germany's dash to the market, has taken up rooms on the ground floor.

title: Fab Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Strikers Agree With The News On a Mediator
description: The Daily News and leaders of its striking unions agreed yesterday to have William J. Usery, a former United States Secretary of Labor, try to mediate the strike, which is now in its fourth month.

title: 4 Workers Are Exposed to Radioactive Acid
description: A mechanism for dissolving unused nuclear fuel malfunctioned Saturday, spraying radioactive acid over three workers at a chemical plant, the Energy Department said.

title: Bridge
description: The mixture of events at the Greater New York Bridge Association's tournament over the weekend, played mainly at the Werner Erhard Center in Manhattan, was primarily for inexperienced players.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as dealers and investors began to acclimate themselves to interest rate levels they have not seen in a year or longer.

title: Skywest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
17 South Africans Die in Ambush
description: Seventeen people were killed on Sunday and 29 were wounded, 11 of them seriously, after gunmen ambushed a motorcade of members of the Inkatha Freedom Party outside the town of Pietermaritzburg, the police said today.

title: By Design; Star-Studded Luxury
description: If your taste -- and budget -- are on the luxurious side, Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche Boutique at 857 Madison Avenue (71st Street) has big, globby earrings made of rhinestone stars surrounding a heart for $140. The same earrings with some long dangles of stars and hearts added on are $340.

title: Duriron Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roger D. Hansen, 55, Professor and Author
description: Roger D. Hansen, a professor of international relations at Johns Hopkins University's Nitze School of Advanced International Studies in Washington, was found dead Friday at the home of a friend in Rehoboth Beach, Del. He was 55 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Grossman's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company said it decided to close or sell 15 stores, resulting in a 1990 fourth-quarter pre-tax charge of $ 7.1 million in both the quarter and year, and the year also included charges of $ 1.8 million incurred in connection ''with the unsuccessful consent solicitation by two dissident stockholders'' and a gain of $ 4.1 million on the sale of two divisions.c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 17,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary charge from debt retirement of $ 1,867,000.

title: Letters; Get Over That Terrorism Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolina Earthquakes
description: Examination of geologic evidence along the seaboard from New Jersey to Florida has shown that six large earthquakes occurred in South Carolina in the last 2,000 to 5,000 years, five of them near Charleston. But the risk of a big earthquake there in the next several decades is low, researchers said.

title: Wisconsin Welfare Plan: To Reward the Married
description: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who has made a national reputation with his aggressive proposals to overhaul Wisconsin's welfare system, offered another one this month. He wants to reward teen-age mothers who marry and penalize those who do not.

title: Moscow and Baghdad
description: The war in the Persian Gulf is still to be won, but the struggle for the shape and meaning of the peace already has been joined.

title: Sampson R. Field, Businessman, 88; Headed Orchestra
description: Sampson R. Field, a former president of the New York Philharmonic and chairman of the Marlboro School of Music and Marlboro Festival in Vermont, died Sunday night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline on Saturday about Aaron Siskind, photographer, misstated his age. He was 87.

description: b-Included an after-tax charge totaling $ 10,445,000.Results are in Canadian funds.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES has agreed to the publication of a book of his paintings, along with his own text, by Little, Brown & Company in the United States, Britain and Canada. The book, of about 70 of his watercolors, will be issued in the United States by Bulfinch Press, the company's illustrated-book division.

title: A Japanese Symbol of Excess
description: It was bad when the banks sent their people to monitor his debt-laden operations and worse when they slammed the brakes on his hectic pace of property acquisitions. But now the bankers say the three private jets must go.

title: Football and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: RACING: Notebook; Two Fillies Who Leave Impressions
description: Leroy Jolley strode toward the paddock at Gulfstream Park in blue blazer and red tie and admitted that he had one great filly in his barn and another great filly in his heart.

title: An Aerial View: Bomb More and Put Off Ground War
description: The top brass have been explaining in great detail how and why the pressure of aerial bombardment should be maintained to prepare for a ground offensive, and here is how the issue is viewed from the cockpit.

title: Books of The Times; Dark Side of the Human Condition
description: Hardware River By Alyson Hagy 190 pages. Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: ISRAELI TELLS BUSH OF MISSILE DAMAGE
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, in a hastily arranged one-day visit to Washington, told President Bush today that Israel was suffering heavy "destruction" from Iraqi missile attacks and that its willingness to refrain from retaliating was wearing thin, Administration officials said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines Inc., Dallas, a unit of AMR Corp., has exercised four options on MD-11 aircraft, increasing its firm order for MD-11's from McDonnell-Douglas Corp. to 19. * FMR Corp., Boston, a holding company, is part of a group that has cut its stake in House of Fabrics Inc., Sherman Oaks, Calif., a fabric retailer, to 10.35 percent from 11.57 percent of the common shares outstanding. * Firstbank of Illinois Co., Springfield, Ill., will acquire Central Banc System Inc. and its two subsidiaries, Central Bank of Fairview Heights and Farmers and Merchants Bank of Carlinville, Ill., for $27.5 million, subject to certain adjustments. *Nokia A.B., Helsinki, Finland, has agreed to buy the privately owned British mobile telephone maker Technophone Ltd. for $:34 million in cash. * Safeco Corp., Seattle, an insurance, real estate and investment company, said it would close its Canadian property and casualty insurance operations. * Universal Health Services Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., an operator of hospitals, has sold its three hospitals in the United Kingdom to Compass Group P.L.C. for about $51.1 million plus future considerations.

title: Blaze Destroys 5 Businesses
description: A fire that was visible from 15 miles away destroyed five businesses at a Putnam County shopping mall, fire officials said. The fire at the Seavy Plaza on Route 52 was reported at 7:30 P.M. on Sunday. Thirteen fire departments from Putnam, Westchester and Dutchess counties brought it under control at 2:09 A.M. today, said Fire Chief Wayne Resino of Lake Carmel. The damage estimate is $1 million, he said.

title: Ziploc Bags Makes Its Point With a Peripatetic Finger
description: DELLA FEMINA McNAMEE, the agency that created Joe Isuzu, the quintessential lying car salesman of American Isuzu Motors commercials, is hoping its latest oddball spokesman can duplicate that success.

title: Aetna Hires a Manager For Its Investment Unit
description: Daniel P. Kearney, who has held top government and Wall Street posts, has been hired by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company to manage its investments.

description: "Fauna," the final premiere that Eliot Feld has choreographed for his company's season, which runs through March 10, is a welcome change of pace from all the rigor that has colored his recent and more severe ballets.

title: Witness Against Winnie Mandela Disappears
description: The criminal trial of Winnie Mandela stopped abruptly today when the prosecution announced that one of its main witnesses against her was believed to have been kidnapped last night.

title: 2 Bone-Marrow Donor Programs Stop Sparring and Agree to Merge
description: Two bone-marrow donor programs have settled their differences and agreed to merge into a single organization dedicated to helping patients who need marrow transplants.

title: Sleek, Slick, Updated
description: THE first version of Sidekick that I used came with a portable computer a couple of years ago. It was a modest program that soon became indispensable. It allowed me to call up a calendar, calculator or little notepad on the screen while doing something else, without turning off that something else. It is still part of that portable.

title: Shaw Cablesystems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest first quarter included operations of Barrie, Ont., radio station CHAY-FM acquired during the third quarter of the 1990 fiscal year, and Cable Systems serving 26,500 customers in British Columbia.Results are in Canadian funds.

title: G.M.'s Timetable On Antilock Brakes
description: Antilock brakes will be standard or optional equipment by 1993 on virtually all of the General Motors Corporation's cars and light trucks, G.M.'s chairman, Robert C. Stempel, said. Auto makers already offer antilock brakes on about 35 percent of all new trucks and cars, mainly luxury and large models. But new technology has allowed G.M. to design inexpensive systems that could be offered as options on compact cars, Mr. Stempel told the National Automobile Dealers Association on Saturday.

title: Correspondents Protest Pool System
description: The imposition of a rigid press pool system in the Persian Gulf war, with fewer than 100 reporters authorized to talk to half a million American servicemen and women, has led to the detention of correspondents and angry protests to military authorities.

title: Somerset Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 29,000 for the quarter and income of $ 802,000, or 45 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $ 59,000 for the quarter and $ 833,000 for the year.

title: U.S. Long Distance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: An Absolut Puzzle: Jigsaw Ad for Vodka
description: The company that gave magazine readers ads that sprinkled snow, played music and conveyed spoken greetings will insert its newest promotion in the Feb. 25 issue of New York magazine: a cardboard jigsaw puzzle.

title: Compaq Is Adding Customer Services
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation plans to deal with troubles in the computer retailing industry by opening a customer service telephone line and designating a special class of high-end dealers. Compaq, which has always relied on dealers to provide all direct customer service, said it would offer technical support to customers over the phone starting on March 4. Customers using the service will be charged a fee. General questions about Compaq products will be answered free at a separate number.

title: Mexico's Windfall Exceeds $3 Billion From Oil Price Rise
description: After reeling for years because of low world oil prices, Mexico has pocketed a windfall of more than $3 billion thanks to the surge in oil prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to Mexican officials and a United Nations report.

title: Schultz Sav-O Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 344,000, or 13 cents a share.
