title: For North Dakota Shoppers, No More Minnesota Sundays
description: Cleone Jensen is among thousands in North Dakota who made history on Sunday just by going shopping.

title: Networks' Anger With CNN Deepens
description: Friction between the broadcast networks and the Cable News Network escalated yesterday when two network news executives accused CNN of making concessions to the Iraqis in exchange for CNN's special access to news from Baghdad in the first three weeks of the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: William D. Tyler, 82, A Retired Ad Executive
description: William D. Tyler, a retired advertising executive, died on Thursday in Tryon, N.C., where he was visiting. He was 82 years old and lived in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Sizeler Property Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 611,000 on the sale of two department store properties and a charge of $ 333,000 for unreimbursed costs incurred in connection with certain proposed investments.c-Included a charge of $ 854,000 for unreimbursed costs incurred in connection with certain proposed investments.

title: Chapter 11 For Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest department store chain on the West Coast, sought protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy law today in an effort to shore up its deteriorating finances.

title: Top Brass in Gulf: Profiles in Uniformed Authority
description: Until last August, the United States Central Command was something of an odd creature in military circles.

title: Brooklyn Clash Spurred Queens To End Boycott
description: When community leaders in Elmhurst, Queens, heard last week that an employee of a Korean-owned supermarket there had been charged with assaulting an 11-year-old black boy, and that anger was growing among black residents, they knew what they did not want to happen.

title: Malaysia Trading Plan Seeks a Unified Voice
description: East Asia may be the site of some of the world's fastest-growing economic powers, but historically it has always been so fractious and competitive that it could never be organized into anything resembling a trading bloc.

title: The Senator, the Press And Crossed Swords
description: The lan guage of modern politics has be come as bland and as standardized as fast food, the tiniest variations on a very limited set of themes. In that setting, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, stands out, railing against "boobs" and "bug-eyed zealots" and Democrats with "burning bosoms" for the Presidency.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Emery Worldwide, Palo Alto, Calif., a subsidiary of Consolidated Freightways Inc., named Thomas Reilly vice president finance. * Federal Home Loan Bank of New York named Keith Bigwood to the newly created position of vice president for financial services. * Grace Energy Corp., Dallas, a subsidiary of W. R. Grace & Co., named Barry L. Morris a corporate vice president for investor relations. * Hills Department Stores Inc., Canton, Mass., named John G. Reen chief financial officer and senior vice president. * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, named C. Michael Shaw executive vice president for school publishing. * Mastercard International Inc., New York, named Paul J. Novak Jr. vice president for its Businesscard product group. * Nielsen Media Research, a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet Corp., named William G. Jacobi president and chief operating officer. * Otis Elevator Co., Farmington, Conn., a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., named Robert A. Pentland vice president of new equipment operations for its North American operations. * Rite Aid Corp., Shiremanstown, Pa., named Timothy J. Noonan and Alex Schamroth executive vice presidents.

title: Sallie Mae Offering Totals $650 Million
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes due Aug. 8, 1991, through various securities dealers.

title: Iraqi Lifts Estimate of Civilian Loss to Thousands
description: An Iraqi Cabinet minister said today that thousands of Iraqi civilians had been killed or wounded by the allied bombardment and that new reports of casualities were arriving constantly.

title: Far From Gulf, British Royalty Is Under Fire
description: Amid the distant rumbles of war in the Persian Gulf, a second front has opened in Britain. London newspapers are exchanging shots with Buckingham Palace following reports that some younger members of the royal family are cavorting while the rest of Britain goes to war.

title: Personal Best For Komondor
description: Maybe it was the fresh batch of garlic-spiked liver his owner cooked up, or maybe it was the wide open spaces of Madison Square Garden, but Leo the champion komondor, a k a Ch. Snokote's Aliyah, achieved a personal best last night at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show. Leo, 5 years old, won best of breed for the 193d time in his career, but the shaggy dog stunned his owners, Alice and Steve Lawrence, by earning third place in the working group, his 87th group placement.

title: An Africa-Centered School Can Reverse Alienation and Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Official Moving To Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., the leading Canadian telecommunications company, yesterday appointed Edward E. Lucente a senior vice president for marketing and a member of the executive office.

title: Cutting Funds for '92 Candidates Is Proposed, but to Stiff Resistance
description: Facing a potential shortage financing the 1992 Presidential election, the Treasury Department has proposed reducing the Federal matching money available for the primaries. But the chairman of the Federal Election Commission urged today that the idea be dropped.

title: Workers Strike Maker of Gulf War Materiel
description: About 1,300 employees of a company that provides supplies for the war in the Persian Gulf have gone on strike, but the company said it does not foresee problems filling orders for the military.

title: Dinkins Efforts Set Back by Cut In Bond Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on New York City bonds one notch yesterday, a blow to efforts by Mayor David N. Dinkins to show that his administration was mastering the city's finances.

title: Ballistic Recovery Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Home Test Of Blood May Aid Pregnant
description: TEACHING pregnant women to monitor their blood pressure at home can produce accurate results and reduce unnecessary medication and visits to the doctor, a new study suggests.

title: Our Towns; As Bombs Fall And Flags Fly, Business Booms
description: Dan Connors thought he'd never see anything quite so bizarre at work. Squads of silent men in nice suits pulled open every drawer, every door, every closet, every box in the Annin Company factory here. They took nothing, these smile-free fellows, just poked through everything.

title: Extortion Charges Dismissed Against 2 Paper Distributors
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed charges that two employees of a wholesale newspaper distributor had extorted payoffs from a home delivery service.

title: Review/Fashion; Hemlines for Fall And All Moods
description: Less than a week after the dramatic introduction of his spring and summer haute couture collection in Paris, Yves Saint Laurent sent his pre-fall ready-to-wear clothes to New York. The show was workmanlike, not grand.

title: So You Want to Live in France, Do You?
description: To the Editor:

In-House Investigation
description: Texas-El Paso will conduct its own investigation of possible wrongdoing uncovered by the National Collegiate Athletic Association during an investigation of the Miners' program, university officials said yesterday.

title: National Heritage reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An obituary of Danny Thomas on Thursday misidentified his movie role in the 1953 version of "The Jazz Singer." He portrayed the son of a cantor, the role played by Al Jolson in the 1927 original.

title: Northwestern Public Service reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dinkins, in Albany, Attacks Cuomo Budget
description: Buoyed by the Legislature's passage of his anti-crime package today, Mayor David N. Dinkins began what could become an even more difficult struggle -- fighting state spending cuts -- by harshly criticizing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget proposal.

title: Dehere Shoots Seton Hall Past Pitt
description: Terry Dehere's long-range shooting saw him make 4 of 5 attempts from 3-point range tonight, score a game-high 25 points and lead Seton Hall to an 83-73 Big East victory over Pittsburgh at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: What if War Costs Came Out of Paychecks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Long-Repressed Tale of Repression
description: The junk heap to which the characters of "Larks on a String" are consigned is a kind of paradise. Here, in the early 1950's, former members of Czechoslovakia's banished bourgeoisie are nominally engaged in forced labor, but in fact are free to play cards, discuss philosophy, joke sardonically about their situation and languish as they choose.

title: Church Council Assembly Distracted by War
description: The world's largest ecumenical convocation, the World Council of Churches, is finding the war in the Persian Gulf both a convenient focus for its sprawling seventh assembly and an inevitable distraction from other concerns.

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about the fears for archeological remains in Iraq gave an incorrect date in some copies for the Arch of Ctesiphon. It dates from the third century A.D.

title: N.C.A.A. Inquiry on Syracuse Is Reported
description: Hundreds of basketball fans surrounded the court at the Carrier Dome before tonight's game between Syracuse and Providence, trying to get close to the players. As they always do. They proudly wore the school colors and offered warm cheers for their beloved Orangemen. As they always do.

title: CHRONICLE
description: H. AXEL SCHUPF, an investment adviser and a former chairman of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, has been elected chairman of the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. Mr. Schupf, 55, succeeds MORRIS W. OFFIT, who became the museum's president after serving four years as its chairman.

title: Gary, Not Nancy, Dies On 'Thirtysomething'
description: In the end, Nancy was spared, but death still made an appearance on tonight's episode of the ABC television series "Thirty something." In an unexpected plot development, Gary, the English professor turned househusband, was killed in an automobile accident just as Nancy Weston was celebrating the success of her treatment for ovarian cancer.

title: Thermo Electron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: Results have been restated to reflect the May 30, 1990, merger between Thermo Electron Corp. and E. & M. Lamort S.A.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., a natural gas company, will sell its Dyco Petroleum subsidiary to Continental Drilling Co., a subsidiary of Samson Investment Co., Tulsa, Okla. * Du Pont Co., Wilmington, Del., and DNA Plant Technology Corp., Cinnaminson, N.J., an agricultural biotechnology company, formed a joint venture, Intermountain Canola Co., to develop and market canola oil. * E-Systems Inc., Dallas, a producer of electronic surveillance systems, said its Serv-Air unit had won a contract worth more than $100 million from the Army to provide support services at Fort Monmouth, N.J. * Finevest Foods Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a food wholesaler, filed a Chapter 11 petition in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Jacksonville, Fla. * JWP Inc., Purchase, N.Y., a technical-services company, will acquire Comstock Canada, an electrical and mechanical services company. * LTV Steel Co., Cleveland, a unit of LTV Corp., will recall about 600 employees and resume steel-producing and direct-rolling operations. * Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., the chemical company, offered to buy the 5.2 million shares it does not already own of its Canadian unit, Union Carbide Canada Ltd., for $19 a share, or $99 million.

title: British Air Net Off 63%
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that its third-quarter profits sank 63 percent, largely because of sharply higher fuel costs resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis. It said its fuel bill rose 29.5 percent in the period.

description: GET with it, man! I mean, where have you been ? Ed Debevic's in town.

description: The Dallas investor Harold Simmons lost a bid today to push back the Lockheed Corporation's annual meeting until late May, forcing him to decide quickly whether to try again this year to unseat Lockheed's board.

Man, 19, Charged in Killing of L.I. Girl
description: A 19-year-old man was arrested Monday night and accused of stabbing a 16-year-old girl to death in Central Islip over the weekend after she resisted his attempt to rape her, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: CHINA SENTENCES 2 OF ITS DISSIDENTS TO 13-YEAR TERMS
description: A Chinese court sentenced two longtime democracy advocates today to 13 years in prison, the longest sentences announced so far in connection with the Tiananmen protests and a clear warning to the Chinese people not to take on the Government.

title: Rig Count Holds Steady
description: The number of working rotary oil and gas rigs in the nation edged up by one last week, to a total of 997, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. A year ago there were 899 working rigs. Ike Kerridge, a Baker Hughes vice president, said the count traditionally drops in the first quarter of the year and continues to decline through March and April. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for petroleum and natural gas.

title: INSIDE
description: 45-Year Prison Term For Bakker Is Voided

title: Aon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; Hard Times, Easy Subsidies
description: DOES one bad subsidy deserve another? Easy credit offered to the Soviet Union is likely to increase Western sales at the expense of cash-and-carry Eastern European exports. That is why Daniel L. Bond of the United States Export-Import Bank and Anthony M. Solomon, the former president of the New York Federal Reserve and now an adviser to the S. G. Warburg Group, want to help the Eastern Europeans build a subsidy system of their own.

title: Goodyear Off in Quarter
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today reported a 21 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings and a loss of $38.3 million for 1990 as a whole. Goodyear posted net income of $11.6 million, or 20 cents a share, for the period that ended on Dec. 31, compared with $14.7 million, or 25 cents a share, in the comparable 1989 period. Fourth-quarter revenues edged up 2.6 percent, to $2.81 billion, from $2.74 billion a year earlier. Goodyear's loss for all of 1990 was in contrast to net income of $206.8 million, or $3.58 a share, in 1989. Revenues for the year increased 3.7 percent, to $11.27 billion, from $10.87 billion a year earlier.

title: Sale of Most Ambase Assets Approved by Shareholders
description: After some nail-biting delays and last-minute lobbying, shareholders and note holders of the Ambase Corporation have approved the sale of most of the company's assets to a Scandinavian investment group. The assets include the Home Group of insurance companies and the Wall Street firm of Gruntal & Company.

title: James B. Hamilton, 80,Anatomy Expert, Dies
description: James Bruce Hamilton, former chairman of the anatomy department at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn and an authority on baldness, died on Jan. 21 at the Bon Secour Nursing Facility in Ellicott City, Md. He was 80 years old and lived in Ellicott City.

title: Ramey in Recital
description: Works by Handel, Mozart, Verdi, Rossini and Copland will be performed by Samuel Ramey, bass, in his only New York recital this season, on Feb. 24 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Tickets range from $12 to $27. Information: 247-7800.

title: Kremlin Accuses Banks in West of Plot
description: Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov contended today that the Kremlin's recent confiscation of currency was intended to foil a Western bankers' plot to topple the Soviet Government by cornering billions in rubles and destabilizing the economy.

title: Eastern Shore Journal; 'Us Against Them' Pride Lives On in Maryland
description: Here on the Eastern Shore, the rural 200-mile-long peninsula that is separated by the Chesapeake Bay from the rest of the East Coast, there is an old chauvinistic saying.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Exiles; The Refugees Envision A Transformed Kuwait
description: The sand-colored high-rise apartment complex is known to its neighbors as Kuwait City, and each afternoon knots of idle young men and women gather in the marble entryways to swap rumors about the progress of the war and to plot the future of the country they hope soon to reclaim.

title: Hired to Be Negotiator, But Treated Like Pariah
description: President Bush gave him the job of knocking on the doors of the nation's governors. But all are afraid to answer. Where he hoped for a yes, he would now consider himself lucky with a maybe.

Stiller vice president and director of its personnel division. He succeeds W. Perry Brown, who retired. * Bain & Co., Boston, named Jonathan I. Mark head of its consumer marketing practice. * Capital Cities/ABC Inc., New York, promoted Christine Hikawa to vice president-broadcast standards and practices. She succeeds Alfred R. Schneider, who is retiring. * Western Union Corp., Upper Saddle River, N.J., named Alan H. Friedman vice president and comptroller.

description: Because of the gulf war, Saudi Arabia is seeking to borrow billions of dollars from international banks, a Western diplomat said. Page A15.

title: For India Castle, Many Tourist Cancellations
description: It could be a bad year for Kesri Singh Mandawa, the 42-year-old grandson of the last Maharaja of this onetime little kingdom. Flat on his back with a slipped disc, Mr. Mandawa spends what's left of his working day in the family castle chalking up the tourist cancellations.

title: Oscar Nitzchke, Modern Architect Who Designed U.N., Is Dead at 90
description: Oscar Nitzchke, an architect who designed a number of internationally recognized buildings, including the United Nations headquarters in New York and the Los Angeles Opera House, died Monday at the Hopital Charles Foix in Ivry sur Seine, a suburb of Paris. He was 90 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Top Poodle Is Chosen As Best at Westminster
description: A white standard poodle, Ch. Whisperwind on a Carousel, better known as Peter, stood alone in the center of a green-matted ring in Madison Square Garden last night as the supreme winner of the 115th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

description: Few of journalism's inner sanctums are as sanctified as the editorial meetings at Time magazine, sessions so secret that bookies are said to take odds on the identity of Time's "Man of the Year."

title: Indictments of 2 Officials Darken Detroit's Mood
description: Twenty-four years ago, in devastating riots, this city burned with black rage over a predominantly white Police Ddpartment that seemed to blacks to be more like an occupying army. Then came Coleman A. Young, the city's first black mayor, and soon afterward, William L. Hart, the city's first black police chief, and an era of black pride and inclusion.

title: Monsanto Told to Halt Promotion Of Its Gene-Engineered Milk Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered the manufacturer of a genetically engineered hormone that increases milk production to stop promoting the drug while it is still under Government review.

description: The Reader's Digest Association said last week that it would begin publishing a Hungarian-language edition of Reader's Digest in October. The magazine will be published by a wholly owned subsidiary in Budapest.

title: The P.L.O. -- Back From the Brink
description: If there is to be a chance for a regional peace initiative after the gulf war, Washington must make a determined effort to resolve the Palestinian problem. Diplomacy will falter anew if Washington, to avoid controversy with Jerusalem, tries to sidestep this central issue and moves instead toward direct talks between Israel and Syria. These would only divert the peace process.

title: Doctors Press States to Curb Reviews of Procedures' Costs
description: The fierce battle between insurers trying to control medical costs and doctors angered by the intrusion is spilling into state legislatures around the country, and the doctors appear to be gaining.

description: At a time when schools are struggling to teach troubled youngsters the basics of reading and mathematics, a week of unusually public discord among the New York City Board of Education's seven members has prompted some soul-searching about whether their president, Dr. Gwendolyn C. Baker, can pull them together to take on the central issues of education.

title: War? Poverty? In Rio, Carnaval Goes On
description: Toasting the crowd from an exclusive box, Brazil's most famous transvestite blew kisses. A television actress in a red satin dress swayed dangerously over a brass rail clutching a champagne glass. Below, a mass of pirates and Polynesians, clowns and cancan dancers danced on, fueled by rivers of beer and a blasting samba band.

title: Political Memo; Amid Silence, Portents of Bush's 1992 Campaign
description: Official Washington almost considers it bad manners to talk about the 1992 election in the midst of a war, but beneath the silence are portents about the shape of the Republican political apparatus in the next campaign.

title: Bakker's 45-Year Prison Term Set Aside
description: Saying that the sentencing judge had improperly emphasized religion, a Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the 45-year prison term imposed on the evangelist Jim Bakker and ordered that he be resentenced.

title: Hickok Electrical Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hebrew Arts Center Is Changing Its Name
description: Beginning March 10, the Hebrew Arts Center at 129 West 67th Street will be known as the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center. Lydia Kontos, executive director of the center, has announced that the name is being changed to recognize a recent gift, to be used toward an endowment. The center includes the Merkin Concert Hall, the Ann Goodman Recital Hall, the Art Gallery and the Birnbaum Music Library. Mrs. Kaufman has been a trustee of the Hebrew Arts School, which is also part of the center, for six years and is a vice president of the board.

title: Fuller Industries Picks Executive From Avon
description: Stuart A. Ochiltree's new challenge is to turn around Fuller Industries, a once-dynamic maker and direct seller of brushes and cleaning products that used to be known as the Fuller Brush Company. Mr. Ochiltree, former president and chief executive of the direct sales group of Avon Products Inc., has been named Fuller's president and chief executive.

title: Suburban 911: Where, Exactly, Are You Calling From?
description: The emergency telephone number 911 is moving to the suburbs and beyond, but not easily. Residents who have long obscured their wooded retreats from everyone but friends, relatives and the mail carrier are bracing for the ultimate indignity: sequential street numbering.

title: McGwire Stands Tall Under Scouting Pressure
description: Throughout the past weekend, athletes had come through the hotel lobby in search of a ride to the airport and an airplane to take them far from the most elaborate, unique and economically significant inspection of their football lives.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about weather-related delays in the bombing of Iraq and Kuwait referred incorrectly in some editions to an assessment of the air war. Brig. Gen. Buster C. Glosson, architect of the bombing campaign, said it was not approaching a "point of diminishing returns" for the number of planes sent out.

title: Accounts
description: * The National, the sports daily, to Ayer, New York, with a budget of $8 to $10 million. * Health Innovations Inc., Reston, Va., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, for its Lifesign anti-smoking program and Dietmate weight-loss program. Billings are $1.7 million. * Labatt's USA Inc., Darien, Conn., to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., New York, for Clausthaler, a nonalcoholic beer. Billings were not disclosed. * Wilson Sporting Goods Co., River Grove, Ill., a subsidiary of Amer Group, to Martin/Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis, for its Staff line of golf balls and clubs. Billings have not been determined.

title: Lincoln and the Gulf
description: If the Persian Gulf war ultimately becomes long and bloody, two things can be predicted with certainty: There'll be more and louder dissent, and there'll be more and louder reaction against it. The latter will be described all too often as patriotic, leaving the impression that dissent is unpatriotic.

description: William Bentz Plagemann, whose writing often focused on his experiences in the Navy, died Friday at his home in Palisades, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

description: Nearly six years after a series of grisly slayings in Northern California, the case and the public outcry over it are posing a serious challenge to extradition procedures between Canada and the United States.

description: Sabena S.A., Belgium's national airline, announced a plan today to cut routes, eliminate 2,200 jobs and recapitalize the company to make the airline profitable for the first time.

description: The Phoenix Suns ended the Los Angeles Lakers' 16-game winning streak last night beating them, 99-95, as Kevin Johnson scored 10 of his 35 points in the final 8 minutes 13 seconds and Tom Chambers hit a decisive hook shot with 28 seconds left.

title: Review/Theater; Laughing While Crying With Ayckbourn
description: Alan Ayckbourn has written more plays than William Shakespeare and perhaps as many good plays, of all shapes and sizes, as any other English dramatist of his generation. But if you wanted to define the Ayckbourn sensibility with a single incident in a single play, you could do it by turning to a passage in Act II of "Absent Friends," the early comedy (1974) that is receiving its belated New York premiere in an exquisitely orchestrated production directed by Lynne Meadow at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Donald J. Wilcox, History Professor, 52
description: Donald J. Wilcox, a professor of history at the University of New Hampshire, died on Friday at his home in Boston. He was 52 years old.

description: THE California wine industry is an upbeat business. Like Florida real estate was in the 1920's, it is held together by optimism. The scenery is breathtaking, the wineries are architectural wonders, the wine makers are brilliant and the wine is terrific. What could go wrong?

description: When the opening lead is a high card, the third player usually has an opportunity to signal. Exactly how he should do that varies with circumstances and is a matter for debate in expert partnerships.

title: Mayor Wagner's Gift
description: Hard as it is to imagine now, there was a time when New York City was in an uproar over a plan to add fluoride to the water supply. Mayor Robert F. Wagner supported the proposal but kept refusing to bring it to a vote. "Trust me," he said for months to his frustrated Health Commissioner. Then he finally relented -- and the Board of Estimate duly approved fluoridization.

title: A Day's Quiet Wait For Early Winners
description: Like a motionless cloud formation, the standard poodle, who would become top dog at Westminster hours later, dozed away the afternoon. The boxer waited for her walk. The Kerry blue terrier kept one eye on the passers-by in the aisle, but the Old English sheepdog ignored them.

title: Prominent Psychiatrist Is Pleading Insanity
description: A prominent forensic psychiatrist who for three decades has been a court witness testifying about defendants' mental health now intends to try to prove that he himself is criminally insane.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Giving Homeless a Rescuing 'Push'
description: Alice T. does not like the Brooklyn housing project where she and her three daughters live. She does her best to ignore the hallways covered with grafitti, the broken windows, the gun shots at night and the puddles of urine in the elevators. But she is quick to admit that it is better than the alternative.

title: About New York; In the Autumn Of Life, Romance Still Blossoms
description: Tomorrow is Valentine's Day, a time to celebrate young love. But frankly, dear, young love is for youngsters. This column is about real love, meaning mature love.

RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sampras Tops Srejber in U.S. Pro Pete Sampras, seeded second, began the defense of his title last night with a 6-2, 7-5 victory over Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia in the second round of the United States Pro Indoor tournament at Philadelphia. Sampras dominated the first set, winning it from 4-2 on the fourth set point as Srejber served three double-faults in the eighth game. Earlier yesterday, Wayne Ferreira, from South Africa, eliminated No. 8-seeded Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-2, and Chuck Adams upset 10th-seeded Derrick Rostagno, 7-5, 6-3. (AP)

description: Almost alone among economic indicators, the stock market has been sending strong signals that the recession is nearly over. While other measures like housing starts continue to offer a dreary run of bad news, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 21.5 percent since it bottomed on Oct. 11, despite yesterday's decline of 27.48 points, to 2,874.75.

title: Some Women Could Coach Men's Hoops
description: The best college basketball game of this season, and a lot of other seasons, was played in Raleigh, N.C., on Jan. 12. The University of Virginia was down by 20 points to North Carolina State with 12 minutes to play and wound up winning, 123-120, in triple overtime on a steal and a layup by a player who was energized because she thought she had been told to give up.

description: Allied shells fired from land, sea and air rained down on a large concentration of Iraqi infantry, armor and artillery in southern Kuwait today in what military spokesmen called the largest combined operation of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Bucharest Journal; Uneasy Romania Asks: Where Are Spies Now?

After the Romanian revolution of December 1989, he was hired by the country's newly formed intelligence service, and immediately cast a keen eye on the rapidly coalescing opposition to the Government.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The P.L.O.; Arafat, the Survivor, Now Finds Support Vanishing
description: In more than two decades as leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat has survived crises, setbacks and challenges to his leadership. But senior policy makers in the Middle East say his support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war may have finally ended his effectiveness as the foremost Palestinian leader.

description: "Our Constitution, of course, does not require a person to surrender his or her religious beliefs upon the assumption of judicial office. Courts, however, cannot sanction sentencing procedures that create the perception of the bench as a pulpit from which judges announce their personal sense of religiosity and simultaneously punish defendants for offending it." -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. [ B6:1. ]

title: Blue Skies for Mr. Bush's Economists
description: An overview of the current and future economy could be a valuable source of analysis and a stirring call to action. But you won't find either in the latest Annual Report of the Council of Economic Advisers. Slavishly opposed to government intervention, including any new taxes, President Bush's economists address few pressing problems. Indeed, they devote more attention to Eastern Europe and South America than to matters at home.

RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Tocchet Helps Flyers Top Leafs Rick Tocchet returned from a five-game absence with two goals and Gord Murphy scored the game-winner early in the third period last night to lead the Philadelphia Flyers past the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-3, in Toronto. The Flyers ended a four-game losing streak. Tocchet had been out since pulling a groin muscle on Jan. 26 (AP) Whalers 6, Red Wings 2: Ron Francis had a hat trick, scoring two goals within 1 minute 33 seconds of the second period, and had two assists as Hartford won at home. (AP) Bruins 7, Canadiens 4: In Montreal, Craig Janney and John Carter scored unassisted goals 11 seconds apart to spark a four-goal third period for Boston. The Bruins have won 5 of their last 6 games and 9 of their last 11, including three victories over Montreal. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL North Carolina Routs Wake Forest Rick Fox scored 21 points last night as North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 85-70, in Chapel Hill, N.C. Wake Forest went into a shooting slump late in the first half and North Carolina gained control and improved its record to 18-4 over all and 7-3 in the Atlantic Coast Conference. Wake Forest is 14-8 and 5-5. (AP) Temple 69, Penn State 59: Donald Hodge scored consecutive jumpers to start a 15-2 run in the first half and Temple held off a late rally to beat Penn State in State College, Pa. The Owls (17-6 over all, 11-3 in the Atlantic 10) built a 33-21 halftime lead, holding the Lions to their lowest output in a half this season. Penn State (15-8, 8-6) was no closer than 3 points in the second half. (AP) Rutgers 95, St. Joseph's 87: In another Atlantic 10 game, Keith Hughes scored 17 of his 21 points in the second half to spark Rutgers (15-7, 11-3) in Piscataway, N.J. Rutgers has won 9 of its last 10 games and 8 straight in the conference. St. Joseph's fell to 8-15 and 5-10. (AP) TENNIS Lendl Advances in Philadelphia Top-seeded Ivan Lendl beat Guillaume Raoux of France, 6-1, 7-5, yesterday in the United States Pro Indoor tournament at Philadelphia. Earlier, MaliVai Washington upset Patrick McEnroe, seeded 16th, 6-0, 6-3, to advance to the third round. Washington will play the defending champion, Pete Sampras, today.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Burrell Proves He Is the Fastest The American sprinter Leroy Burrell, upset that his world-record indoor time in the 60 meters was nullified because he jumped the gun, ran the distance a second time yesterday and again turned in a record time at an indoor meet in Madrid. Burrell ran 6.40 seconds in the first race but the judges ruled that he had left the starting blocks too soon. When the judges announced their decision, Burrell shouted, "Let's run again now!" The judges decided to repeat the race after 10 minutes, and Burrell then clocked 6.48, a world-record indoor time. The listed record is held by Lee McRae with a time of 6.50 in Indianapolis on March 7, 1987. (AP)

title: Kirk Douglas Injured in Crash
description: The actor Kirk Douglas and a cartoon voice artist, Noel Blanc, were injured today when the helicopter they were in collided with a stunt plane, killing two people aboard the plane. The names of the dead were not immediately available. Mr. Douglas, 74 years old, suffered cuts and bruises and was in stable condition, said Rulon Barlow, president of Santa Paula Memorial Hospital. Mr. Blanc, 52, the helicopter pilot and son of the late Mel Blanc, had surgery for a broken leg, broken ribs and possible internal injuries and was in serious condition. Michael Carra, a Beverly Hills police officer, suffered bruises and was in stable condition.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: HAVING children is viewed as so integral a part of adulthood that couples who are childless by choice are sometimes viewed with suspicion or disdain. They may be accused of being self-centered and uncaring, as if not having children is a sign of a larger emotional problem. Yet research on childless couples shows little basis for those accusations.

title: I.B.M.'s New Fast Chip
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had built the world's fastest high-capacity memory chip, which should help the company build faster computers. The new chip, which I.B.M. described as experimental, can send or receive eight billion bits of information a second, the fastest data rate of any chip ever reported, the company said. A bit is the smallest unit of computer language.

title: Dancing in a Moving Set Designed by Architects
description: Even the scenery moves in "The World Upside Down," a new dance by Elisa Monte that is to be performed tomorrow and Sunday nights as part of the American Movement series at City Center. A gravity-defying excursion into light and shadow, it features giant panels that rise and fall and sweep about the stage, nearly gobbling up the dancers in their path. The dancers themselves are multiplied by those shadows, imprinted in glowing fluorescence or glimpsed as faint distant figures, as if behind a scrim.

But the department is arguing that it should not have to pay, in part because it has no budget for fines.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York City misstated Jacob K. Javits's role in the 1956 race for the United States Senate. Mr. Wagner was defeated by Mr. Javits, a Republican who was then the State Attorney General. They competed for the seat vacated by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, who chose not to run again. Mr. Javits was not the incumbent.

description: Debt * Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelphia, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent subordinated notes due 2001 at a price of 99.335 to yield 9.73 percent through Lehman Brothers. Noncallable through maturity, the issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. * General Motors Acceptance Corp., Detroit, plans to redeem $300 million of outstanding 9.25 percent notes due Feb. 15, 1993, on March 15 at a price of 100, including accrued interest. * Merrill Lynch & Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $1.5 billion in medium-term notes with fixed or variable rates through its own underwriting facilities. * Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., through its Health and Educational Facilities Board, is offering $23.5 million of tax-exempt bonds for Vanderbilt University. The underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Co., initially priced the issue to yield from 5 percent in 1992, 6.6 percent in 2006 and 6.75 percent for a bond due 2016. Brown & Sons Inc. * Gensia Pharmaceuticals Inc., San Diego, filed for 2 million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons. * Immunogen Inc., Cambridge, Mass., filed for 2 million common shares through Paine Webber Inc.
