description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. tonight proposed to overhaul Connecticut's tax system by imposing a personal income tax on wages beginning on July 1 while cutting the state's 8 percent sales tax almost in half.

title: Defying Kenya's One-Party State, Dissident Plans Opposition Group
description: In a challenge to the one-party state in Kenya, one of the country's best known, out-of-power politicians declared today that he was forming an opposition political party.

title: Husband Defends Immunity in Love-Triangle Case
description: Paul Solomon, who was the initial suspect in the murder of his wife, Betty Jeanne, two years ago, testified today that it was his lawyer's idea that he seek immunity from prosecution. The immunity was granted in exchange for his testimony before the grand jury that indicted his lover in the killing.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: EUROPE Bombing Puts Britain's Government on Defensive; Arab Nations Divided
description: Jordan reacted angrily today to the bombing of a reinforced concrete building in Baghdad where civilians had taken shelter, and said that incidents of this sort were exactly what it had hoped to prevent by opposing the American-led attacks on Iraq.

title: Review/Dance; Stretching the Limits of Movement
description: The definition of dance continues to be stretched, as it should be, within the precincts of modern dance and as American Movement, a new series, confirms this week at City Center (131 West 55th Street).

title: Confertech International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,000 in the quarter and $ 156,000 in the year.

title: Metro Matters; Wagner Legacy: The Redefining Of the Mayoralty
description: "We went down hill," Carmine G. De Sapio said the other day, "and we haven't come up since."

title: Bowmar Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,000.

title: Progress Gets Ham Radio Operators in Trouble
description: The sleepy world of ham radio operators, best known for electronic tinkering in the garage and relaying emergency messages in natural disasters, has become embroiled in a high-technology dispute over the broadcasting of a computerized chain letter that solicits support for an antiwar group.

title: Quality Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Aetna Life & Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a third quarter one-time, after-tax charge of $ 60 million related to severance benefits and other costs associated with a reorganization of the company's domestic insurance operations.c-Included tax benefits of $ 22 million and $ 37 million in the quarter and year, respectively.The company said that in the fourth quarter its net realized capital losses were $ 95 million, compared with net realized capital gains in the 1989 fourth quarter of $ 28 million, or 25 cents a share.For 1990, net realized capital losses were $ 82 million, compared with net realized capital gains of $ 109 million, or 97 cents a share in 1989.

title: I.R.S. Seeks $5 Billion From Drexel
description: The Internal Revenue Service filed a claim for more than $5 billion today against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for back taxes, interest and penalties.

title: Interest in Ski Dorms Goes Beyond Weekends
description: Ski dorms have been around since young people began sliding down snow-covered hills. The dorms were attractive because they provided warm beds, a menu of hearty food and they were cheap. They offered few frills, but the atmosphere was informal and friendly.

title: Soldiers and Barbie Aiming at Nintendo
description: THE noise of war was deafening, and a lone soldier dressed in beige desert camouflage stood ready for battle. But this soldier, a 6-foot-tall mannequin, held in his hand not a lethal weapon but a new board game, "A Line in the Sand," in which the allied forces fight the army of Iraq on a map of the Middle East.

title: Artistic Visions of Home Sweet Home
description: SOME shows that tackle the subject of home are not always meant as a vehicle to sell the art and objects on display. A new exhibition called "Home Sweet Home" simply offers a challenge to the eye. The show opens Monday and runs through April 12 at Columbia College on the South Side of Chicago. It includes 19 projects by 21 artists from Chicago who explore individuality in the home.

title: Key Rates
IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: A FALLEN SON: For two days, family, friends and strangers held funeral services in Minnesota for a young marine killed two weeks ago in the war's first ground combat. Page B18. SOMBER TOY FAIR: A somber and unsettled mood has settled over the 88th American International Toy Fair in New York this week because of the war, and there is controversy over toys that capitalize on the fighting. The Home Section, page C1.

title: Bombing Puts Britain's Government on Defensive
description: The reported deaths of hundreds of civilians in Baghdad in what Iraq said was a bomb shelter and the United States said was a military command bunker put the British Government on the defensive today for the first time since the war began.

title: Gorbachev's Envoy Sees 'Glimmers' of Hope After Talks With Iraqi Leader
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's special envoy to Iraq returned to Moscow today saying he had detected some "glimmers" of hope in his meetings with Saddam Hussein, but no substantive details of his mission were immediately made public.

title: Egghead Discount Software reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 5
description: b-Reflects a $ 1.4 million reimbursement from the company's insurance carrier for costs incurred in the defense of a class action shareholder lawsuit settled in October.c-Included net litigation expenses of $ 1.3 million.d-Net loss and included litigation expenses of $ 2.6 million.

title: The Tiny Bathroom Tiles Are Back
description: IN the 1920's, 30's and 40's, well-dressed bathroom floors were usually outfitted with tiny white hexagonal tiles. The look was hopelessly out of style by the 1950's. But in recent years demand for white ceramic "hexies" has revived.

title: Gerald J. Dunworth, A Lawyer, Dies at 79
description: Gerald J. Dunworth, a lawyer in Manhattan for 35 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Waldwick, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Lilco Offers Bonds With 8.81% Yield
description: The Long Island Lighting Company priced $250 million in general and refunding bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: Umpires Fear Lockout
description: Richie Phillips, executive director of the Major League Umpires Association, said yesterday he feared a spring training lockout of umpires by major league owners despite contract negotiations that he described as on schedule.

title: France Imposes a Tighter Political Refugee Policy
description: Convinced that tens of thousands of foreigners are claiming to be political refugees as a subterfuge for entering and working in this country, France has decided to clamp down on third-world and Eastern European nationals seeking asylum here.

title: Hertz Subsidiary Goes To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: The HCM Claim Management Corporation, a Hertz Corporation subsidiary that administers liability and employee-benefits claims, said yesterday that it awarded its business-to-business advertising campaign to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss Inc., New York.

title: Market Place; Gambling Curbs On Money Funds
description: MONEY market funds are not supposed to be gambling devices. Yesterday, the Securities and Exchange Commission took steps to restrict the ability of fund managers to gamble in two different ways -- making risky loans or taking interest-rate risks by investing for long periods. The result may be to reduce slightly the yields available on money market funds, which compete with bank accounts for investor money, and have cultivated an image of safety. So important is that image that the fund industry generally backed the changes with enthusiasm.

title: Alice Vansteenberghe, A Resistance Hero, 82
description: Alice Vansteenberghe, a World War II Resistance hero and physician who testified against the Nazi Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie, has died, officials said Tuesday. She was 82 years old.

title: Aspin Enters Hospital With a Heart Ailment
description: Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was admitted to University Hospital here Tuesday night after suffering from breathing difficulty.

title: Gerber Toy Line
description: The Gerber Products Company signed an agreement for Lewis Galoob Toys Inc. of South San Francisco to design and market a new Gerber toy line by March 1992. Galoob makes Micro Machines and Baby Face toys. Gerber used to sell a line of plush toys but sold it along with unprofitable furniture, trucking and child-care subsidiaries.

title: Bancroft Convertible Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Woman Killed With 4 in Fire After Saving 2
description: Five people, including three young children, perished early today when fire swept a three-story house being warmed by both electrical and illegal kerosene heaters because the furnace was not operating.

title: Pakistan Paper in English
description: The International News, the first new English-language newspaper in Pakistan since the end of martial law and press censorship three years ago, went on sale this week. The paper is being published in Rawalpindi, Lahore and Karachi in Pakistan, and in London and New York, which have large Pakistani communities. The newspaper is owned by the Karachi-based Jang Group, which also publishes the largest Urdu-language newspaper, Jang. Analysts estimate English-language newspapers here have a combined circulation of about 100,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: *American Telephone and Telegraph Co., reached an agreement to sell phone systems for small businesses to the Moscow Local Telephone Network. The deal's value was undetermined. * Barneys New York said it would open a 20,000-square-foot store in the Galleria Houston in August as part of its new national chain. * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, the insurance and financial-services corporation, acquired an interest in Seguros Progreso S.A., a Mexican insurance concern, for undisclosed terms. * Cummins Engine Co., Columbus, Ind., a producer of diesel engines, components and power systems, said Industrial Equity Ltd., La Jolla, Calif., an investment company, sold 1,176,800 shares of Cummins common stock through Shearson Lehman Brothers to more than 20 investors. * Dick Clark Productions Inc., Princeton, N.J., an entertainment company, has formed a new subsidiary, Dick Clark Corporate Productions Inc., to handle corporate events, meetings and trade shows. * Fund American Cos., Purchase, N.Y., said it was accepting for purchase almost 9.1 million common shares at $56 under its "Dutch auction" tender offer. It said that after the offer, it would have about 21.8 million shares outstanding. * Health and Rehabilitation Properties Trust, Cambridge, Mass., will acquire four rehabilitation centers for about $75 million from an affiliate of New Medico Group, Boston, an operator of health-care centers. * MMG Patricof Group, an institutional investor, said it had raised $400 million for investment in European companies. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, the military contractor, said Transwede, a Swedish carrier, had placed a firm order for two MD-83 twin jets and reconfirmed two additional options for MD-83's. The potential value of the orders is about $150 million. * Niugini Mining Ltd., an Australian concern that is 57 percent owned by Battle Mountain Gold Co., Houston, will buy the Red Dome Gold Mine in Queensland, Australia, from NZ Forest Products Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. * Woolworth Corp., New York, has acquired two athletic footware and apparel outlets, Freedom Sportsline Ltd. of England, and five stores operated by Sportsworld B.V., a Dutch company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New Jersey Symphony May Face a Strike
description: Musicians of the financially troubled New Jersey Symphony rejected management's latest contract offer late Tuesday and authorized its bargaining committee to call a strike. A five-concert subscription series by the orchestra was to begin tonight in Englewood, N.J. and end at Carnegie Hall on Monday.

title: Top Ogilvy Executive Resigns in Chicago
description: Bruce Beach has resigned as executive vice president and managing director of Ogilvy & Mather's Chicago office, a position he held for three years.

title: Ask Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest figures included results of Ingres Corp. since its acquisition Oct. 22, 1990.

title: 'Landscapes for the Interior'
description: THE New York-based architectural firm Shelton, Mindel & Associates has taken today's awareness of the environment metaphorically. Its new line of furniture is called the Arboretum Collection.

title: Club Med Buying A Tour Operation
description: Club Mediterranee S.A. said it planned to buy the French tour operator Club Aquarius. Club Med's chairman, Gilbert Trigano, said the cost of the transaction was not yet clear but would be known after an audit of Club Aquarius's assets, which is expected by June.

title: Gibraltar Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Music; Beaux Arts Trio's Premiere of Rorem Piece
description: Carnegie Hall, even before its major renovation, was hardly an ideal place to hear small-scale chamber music because of the auditorium's sheer size. In recent years there has been another problem: a slight reverberant haze that tends to dog individual instruments or voices placed forwardly onstage. For the concert of the Beaux Arts Trio on Friday evening, a large screen was placed behind the players, extending well to either side. Yet the sound remained slightly cloudy, particularly from the piano, whose light runs and quick arpeggios often dissolved in a blur.

title: Excerpts From the TV Reporter's Account
description: Following are excerpts from a Cable News Network broadcast featuring Peter Arnett as he was interviewed from Baghdad yesterday by Ralph Wenge from the CNN center in Atlanta, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Patrick Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacer Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mets Speeding Up Gooden Talks
description: While Fred McGriff of San Diego gained the fifth-richest baseball contract ever yesterday, the Mets made a smidgen of progress in their negotiations for a contract extension with Dwight Gooden. They said they would send their next offer to Gooden via overnight mail instead of the regular mail.

title: Insituform Gulf South reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Sparton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 167,880.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 219,027 and $ 446,721 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: First Capital Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenues represented total revenues.

title: Sun Electric Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,209,000 for the quarter from a reversal of benefit of net operating loss carryforward recognized in previous 1990 quarters; the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,568,000 from September 1990 sale of Service Station Management Equipment segments.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 149,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter, and the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 104,000, both from September 1990 sale of Service Station segment.d-Net loss

title: Tax-Exempt Issue Priced by Orlando
description: A $235.8 million offering of tax-exempt water and electric subordinated revenue bonds issued by the Orlando, Fla., Utilities Commission wase tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum of 6.75 percent for a bond due in 2020.

title: Xscribe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a gain on the sale of the company's discovery products of $ 1,154,000, a $ 569,000 gain from the termination of the company's pension plan and net debt restructuring gains of $ 216,000; the 9 months included charges of $ 2,689,000 for restructuring during the second quarter.c-Net loss

title: Review/Music; Offering High Technique From the U.S.S.R. State Symphony
description: Rarely does an encore define the spirit of a concert, but when Vadim Repin played a set of Paganini variations midway through the U.S.S.R. State Symphony's evening at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, he summed up what had happened to date and what what was about to come.

title: Review/Television; In Interview, Rushdie Tells of Life on the Run
description: Although tonight's interview with Salman Rushdie, at 8 on the Bravo cable channel, is not quite up to date, it does get into the state of mind of the author of "The Satanic Verses," who has been in protective custody since February 1989, when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, put out a contract on him for blasphemy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chesapeake Corp., Richmond, a manufacturer of paper products, named Thomas Blackburn group vice president for pulp and wood products. * Gap Inc., San Francisco, a chain of casual clothing stores, named David M. Demattei and Warren R. Hashagen senior vice presidents. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, named Terry A. Straeter corporate vice president and general manager of its electronics division. He succeeds Melville R. Barlow, who is retiring. * Hearst Corp., New York, named Richard P. Malloch general manager of its books and business publishing group. * Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of General Motors, named W. Allen Reed vice president and treasurer. He succeeds William A. MacGillivray, who is retiring. * SPP Hambro & Co., New York, the United States corporate finance affiliate of Hambros Bank Ltd., London, named Allan B. Ruchman president and head of mergers and acquisitions. * Tyco Toys Inc., Mount Laurel, N.J., named John P. Bohach vice president for advertising and communications. * Wang Laboratories, Lowell, Mass., named Richard L. Cote vice president and corporate controller. * Warner Brothers, Burbank, Calif., a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., named John Heinritz vice president of international marketing and licensing for its worldwide merchandising division.

title: For an Artist and His Dogs, The Feelings Are Mutual
description: On a recent day, the telephone rang in the home of William Wegman. The photographer, known for his hilarious portraits of his Weimaraners, picked up.

title: Baghdad Rescuers Search For Life With Little Hope
description: Rescuers and weeping families dug charred bodies from the concrete building blasted by allied warplanes today in a pre-dawn strike.

title: Dixon Ticonderoga reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Weapon Was Adapted for Use by Stealth Fighter
description: Pentagon officials said today that the bombs that struck a Baghdad building, reportedly killing many civilians, were a variation of the Air Force's basic laser-guided 2,000-pound bomb adapted for the F-117A Stealth fighter-bomber.

title: Strong Earnings Are Posted by Three G.M. Subsidiaries
description: The three non-automotive subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation posted strong fourth-quarter earnings today, helping to alleviate the large decline in automotive profits that G.M. is expected to announce Thursday.

title: If Efficient, Small Offices Are Grand
description: A HOME office does not have to be spacious to be efficient. Some of the most ingenious solutions are tucked into cabinets or sleeping alcoves.

title: Barbara Dodge Borland; Writer, 87
description: Barbara Dodge Borland, a writer and editor, died on Monday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Salisbury, Conn.

title: Andres Wines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: DRUG CUTS DEATHS TIED TO INFECTION
description: A new genetically engineered drug significantly cuts the death rate from septic shock, a quick and overwhelming infection of the bloodstream that kills tens of thousands of people each year. Septic shock is an especially great threat for hospital patients and wounded soldiers.

title: CBS Lost $156 Million in Fourth Quarter
description: CBS Inc. reported a net loss of $156 million yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1990 and announced that it would reduce its quarterly dividend to 25 cents from $1.10.

title: Money Fund Yields Down for Fifth Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were down for the fifth time in as many weeks, with the decline a bit more pronounced than a week ago.

title: Barnwell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Occidental Revamping Will Cost 1,000 Jobs
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will lay off more than 1,000 workers as part of its consolidation after the death of its longtime chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, company officials said today.

title: Booz, Allen's Chief Says He'll Step Down
description: R. Michael McCullough, chairman and chief executive of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, one of the nation's largest management consulting firms, announced yesterday his intention to step down as chief executive in July.

title: Morse Code Requirement For Ham Radio Is Lifted
description: In an effort to resurrect waning interest in ham radio, the Federal Communications Commission will no longer require a knowledge of the Morse code for beginning operators.

title: Syria Said to Renew Pledge on Israel's Status
description: Syria has renewed its commitment to recognize Israel's right to exist as part of a new Middle East order after the Persian Gulf war, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany said tonight during a visit here.

title: Review/Pop; Nostalgia, Plain And Simple
description: Rosemary Clooney epitomizes what might be called a meat-and-pototoes singer. Incapable of artifice, she wouldn't dream of trumping up an elaborate new concept for a familiar song or inventing a character to sing it. She is so emotionally true to herself and to the moment that unlike almost any other popular singer, she doesn't even bother to project a younger, more romantic version of herself.

title: New York Found Failing On Education In the Arts
description: New York City, which prides itself as the world's cultural capital, is not providing most of its public school children with art and music classes, throwing into doubt whether the city can produce the audiences and performers of the future, a Board of Education task force said yesterday.

title: Videocart Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it is a development stage company that was spun-off to shareholders of Information Resources Inc. on Oct. 31, 1990.

title: Minister Asks End to Protest at Queens Store
description: A leader of a protest at a Korean-owned supermarket in Queens, where a black youth says an employee assaulted him, has called for an end to the demonstrations to allow time for a resolution of the matter.

title: Regal Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains totaling $ 262,000 for the latest quarter from the sale of a division and $ 443,000 for the year-ago quarter from a tax-loss carryforward.

title: Daily Riyadh-Dammam Express: It's No Toonerville Trolley
description: War having closed the Dhahran airport to all but military aircraft and having clogged the roads with tank transporters, the train has become the preferred means of civilian travel between eastern Saudi Arabia and Riyadh.

title: St. John's Gets By Boston College
description: There are nights when just about every shot a team throws at the basket nicks the rim or the backboard and drops harmlessly to the floor. Nothing falls except the team's confidence.

title: DBA Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said the loss in the year-ago second quarter was primarily due to the divestiture in the company's military products division.

title: McCaw Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe net income for the full year 1990 included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 190.9 million; and a non-recurring gain of about $ 1.2 billion in the first quarter from the sale of some of the company's southeastern cellular operations to Contel Cellular Inc. and the consolidation for accounting purposes of Lin Broadcasting as of March 5, 1990.Revenue represented net revenue.

title: FOR YUGOSLAVIA, ANOTHER IMPASSE
description: Leaders of Yugoslavia's six quarrelsome republics failed in talks today to find a way to overcome major obstacles blocking agreement on the country's future political configuration.

title: Miscellany
description: * Newsweek magazine will publish an extra issue in May devoted entirely to the topic of children and their development. The issue, entitled "Watching Kids Grow," will be on newsstands for three months, beginning May 28. In addition, 10,000 complimentary copies will be distributed to the offices of pediatricians.

title: Did Egypt Originate Geometry Theorem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Concession by Teachers Shows System Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Killed by Friend or Foe, It's All the Same
description: Of the 11 United States Marines who died last month in ground combat west of Khafji, Saudi Arabia, 7 were killed accidentally by "friendly fire" from an American plane, the military authorities have said. Today, in response to questions, military spokesmen said they would not tell the next of kin which marines had died accidentally.

title: GM Electronic Data Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Dirty War' General vs. the Enforcer
description: When Argentines talk of this steamy city, which survives on sugar cane, tobacco, lemons and the federal Government's purse, they say, "In Tucuman, the temperature is hot and the politics is hotter."

title: Versar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dinkins Holds Court at a Town Meeting in Queens
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, in his first foray under a new strategy for getting his message out to the public, charmed and cajoled a warm audience last night as he took easy control of a town meeting at Forest Hills High School in Queens.

title: Will the Mets Sign 'Enough Pitching?'
description: For decades, the Yankees were known as the "best franchise in sports" until, bluster by bluster, George Steinbrenner destroyed it. With the title vacated, several franchises in various sports can argue that with their success over the years each now deserves to be hailed as the best. The San Francisco 49ers. The Boston Celtics, the Los Angeles Lakers. The Edmonton Oilers. And in baseball, the Oakland Athletics, the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Colonial Data Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carnage in Baghdad Erases Image of an Antiseptic War
description: The smoking ruins of the Baghdad building where allied bombing apparently killed hundreds of civilians this morning may have profoundly changed the American picture of what had been viewed as an antiseptic war of precise, surgical attacks and minimal loss of life.

title: Wellco Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Review/Cabaret; Celebrating the Songs Heard on Broadway
description: Toward the end of his wonderful new show, "Jeff Harnar Sings the 1959 Broadway Songbook," at the Oak Room at the Algonquin, the rising young cabaret star mentions that the year he is commemorating happens to be the same year he was born.

title: Garan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Amplicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Digital Sound reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 663,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,600,000, or 10 cents a share, in the year.The company said reflected in the fourth quarter losses are charges of about $ 3.3 million associated with costs attributable to the tentative settlement of the class action lawsuit against the company and about $ 1 million associated with costs attributed to its recent reduction in work force.Sales represented net sales.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about patterns of brain activity rendered a comment by Dr. Richard Davidson of the University of Wisconsin incorrectly. He said that people with more activity in the left frontal area of the brain -- not thosewith less activity -- should be more resilient to stress.

title: Accounts
description: * Henszey & Albert, a New York agency, announced three new accounts: Parlux, a fragrance company, with a budget of $3 million; Marika, a women's apparel company, with a budget of $1 million, and Atomic Entertainment, an independent production company, with a budget of $1 million. * Insurance Information Institute, an association of property and casualty insurers, to Brouillard Communications, New York, a division of J. Walter Thompson Co. Billings were not disclosed.

title: International Aluminum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GM Hughes Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings attributable to GM class H common stock.GM Hughes Electronics is a unit of General Motors Corp.

title: International Research & Development reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CNA Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Assam Separatists Terrorizing Tea Planters
description: For months, the tea planters of the sprawling, prosperous estates along the narrow highway that winds from Assam to Myanmar and China have been players in a drama that has involved terror, extortion, insurgency, a military crackdown and a secret midnight airlift by intelligence agents.

title: Saturn Cars Being Recalled for Seat Defect
description: The infant Saturn division of the General Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling about 25 percent of the more than 4,000 cars sold to customers to repair reclining mechanisms in the two front seats.

title: 18 Intimate Settings For Entertaining
description: Sometimes even a Washington power lunch is not intimate enough.

title: Review/Dance; Illusion, Mystery And Space
description: The dance theater at St. Mark's Church is a space with magical possibilities. Sondra Loring made much of it on Saturday night in a program shared with Kristin Eliasberg, presented by the Danspace Project. Flashing soft white light and small pools of light made by lamps hung close to the floor emphasized the vaulting height of the space. Booming music poured into its expansive openness, issuing from a band ranged at the back. And figures in black cloaks and a seemingly live body falling from the balcony high above set the dramatic mood of Ms. Loring's "Blackout."

title: Yesterday's Favorite Cleansers Make Modern Homes Gleam
description: AFTER decades of "new and improved" products to clean the American home, it seems that low-tech or even no-tech methods are the latest wave. Increasingly, consumers are turning or returning to simple cleaning products like vinegar and baking soda.

title: Hard News
description: Alan Simpson is a lively kind of guy, the sort who talks about "vim and vigor" and calls people "boobs," who said of opponents of David Souter's nomination to the Supreme Court "you couldn't change them if you herded them over the cliff in a buffalo romp."

title: Few Comforts of Home for Knicks
description: Visiting teams used to loathe playing the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. Now opponents enter the arena with no trepidation.

title: Agents Take Aim at Drugs in Projects
description: The door of a ninth-floor apartment in a Brooklyn housing project swung open at daybreak yesterday, and Sgt. Jeffrey Cea lunged inside with his pistol drawn. With a grab of a shirt front, he swung a startled man into a hallway filled with police officers and Federal agents.

title: Aetna's Profit Declines by 6%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company today reported a drop of nearly 6 percent in fourth-quarter earnings and said write-downs and reserves to cover losses from its huge real estate portfolio totaled $550 million for the year.

title: U.S.-Canada Air Travel
description: Restrictions on air travel between the United States and Canada costs $9.5 billion a year in lost economic activity, according to a study released Tuesday. Liberalizing air travel rules could create up to 210,000 jobs, according to United States Airports for Better International Service, a coalition of 23 American cities, states and airport authorities. The group said limited seat capacity, restricted air routes and poorly situated air transport hubs caused slow growth in air travel between the countries.

title: No Stupid Tricks For Smart-Set Dogs
description: As the producer of a comedy television program that over the years has featured dogs bowling, dogs balancing on rods, dogs scaling fences, dogs cracking whips, dogs attacking vacuum cleaners, dogs attacking imaginary gophers and dogs performing scores of other "stupid pet tricks," Robert Morton had his work cut out for him last night on "Late Night with David Letterman" on NBC.

title: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Earnings per share for the latest quarter and year were diluted primarily due to the issuance of 2 million shares of common stock in August 1990, with the proceeds of $ 35 million used to reduce long-term debt.

title: Singin' In the Jacuzzi
description: AS bathrooms keep expanding, so does the range and sophistication of bathroom equipment. The latest invention is the J-Dream.

title: Freedom Is Sought for Bakker
description: One day after a Federal appeals court threw out the sentence against the evangelist Jim Bakker because of remarks by the judge, an new judge, Graham Mullen, was selected today to resentence Mr. Bakker on his conviction for bilking followers out of some $158 million. Mr. Bakker's lawyers also filed a motion asking he be freed until he is given the new sentence.

title: LOS ANGELES AREA HAS 3D WATER CUT
description: The board of the Metropolitan Water District has approved more water rationing for 15 million Southern Californians, bringing the total cuts in water allotments to 20 percent for homeowners and industrial customers and 50 percent for farmers.

title: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Down 23.6%
description: Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks dropped 23.6 percent earlier in the month as most buyers remained out of the market because of concerns over war and the weak economy.

title: In Search of a Perfect Valentine
description: The first valentine he ever sent her was the best, they both agreed. It was no store-bought greeting but a carefully composed poem that caught the fervor of his longing, her dark beauty and entrancing traits, the intensity and laughter of their times together. It was all in slightly sophomoric rhythms, to be sure. But unwittingly he had found the secret of the perfect valentine. Intensely personal, relentlessly complimentary and speckled with allusions only he and she could understand.

title: How CNN Screens Its Baghdad Reports
description: To the Editor:

title: Catfish Coming To McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation, which has tested menu items ranging from pizza to Salisbury steak, is adding catfish to its experimental repertoire.

title: Philip Morris Sells 3-Year, 7 5/8% Notes
description: The Philip Morris Companies sold debt in the credit markets through competitive bidding yesterday. The three-year notes were won by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Taglianetti Sidelined
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins defenseman Peter Taglianetti was operated on for a collapsed lung and will be sidelined indefinitely. Taglianetti was injured in the first period of the Penguins' 7-5 loss Monday night in Edmonton when the Oilers' Kelly Buchberger drove him into the right goal post of Pittsburgh's net.(AP)

title: Damage Control -- and Real Damage
description: Allied military briefers rushed to try to control the public opinion damage yesterday after the air strike on a giant bunker in Baghdad. The hundreds of civilian casualties were the wrenching result of war. But such consequences, while unintended, are not inevitable, either.

title: Capitals Ban Kordic
description: The Washington Capitals took a risk when they traded for John Kordic last month, and for a while the gamble paid off handsomely.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hershey Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Hershey recorded in the fourth quarter of 1990 a manufacturing restructuring charge of $ 25 million associated with the modernization and relocation of certain manufacturing operations. This charge reduced net income by $ 15 million.The 1990 results included a net pre-tax gain from business restructuring activities totaling $ 35.5 million. This gain, which increased net income by $ 20.3 million, or 22 cents a share, resulted from two events: On May 25, 1990, the corporation sold its equity interest in AB Marabou for about $ 78 million. The sale resulted in a gain of $ 60.5 million and had the effect of increasing net income by $ 35.3 million, or 39 cents a share.Sales represented net sales.

title: Immigration Loses Aides in Shake-Up
description: The Justice Department has ordered the removal of three top career managers at the Immigration and Naturalization Service as the first step in a shakeup to bring better leadership to the long troubled agency, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Music Where You Want It to Be
description: OVER the past few weeks, I have heard Vladimir Horowitz play Chopin at the Village Gate, I have heard Madonna sing at concert halls in Stuttgart and Munich, and I have listened to Duke Ellington play at a modern European church.

title: Economic Investment Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings are adjusted for the restroactive effect of the $ 2.88 a share capital gains dividend declared Tuesday.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 400 Tomahawks Ordered
description: The Navy has ordered 400 Tomahawk cruise missiles, a star of the allied military offensive against Iraq, for $442.5 million. The Navy ordered 240 of the computer-guided missiles for $253.9 million from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and 160 for $188.6 million from the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: Travel Resurges Across U.S. As Americans Adjust to War
description: Almost a month has passed since the country went to war, and many Americans are tying yellow ribbons to their car antennas and heading off for a long weekend of skiing or sightseeing.

title: TSI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Topics of The Times; Get to the Meat of It
description: The food-label reforms approved last year by Congress and now being implemented by the Administration are a major advance for consumers. But the new labeling rules apply only to foods regulated by the Food and Drug Administration, not to meat and poultry products regulated by the Agriculture Department -- a giant loophole Congress now needs to close.

title: Cold War II Has Begun
description: The Cold War, we have been assured, is over. Because that conflict between superpowers originated in the Stalinist subjugation of Eastern Europe, even unreconstructed hawks agree that the liberation of all but three of those states from Moscow's rule marked our victory in that war.

title: F.C.C. Acts On Cellular Competition
description: Setting a significant regulatory precedent, the Federal Communications Commission decided today to allow a new form of mobile telephone service in six cities, including New York.

title: BRT Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said net income was after provisions for possible losses in the amounts of $ 2 million for 1990 and $ 500,000 in 1989.The company also said that the provision for losses was the primary reason for the negative results in the current quarter.

title: College Player Quits, Citing Threats Over Flag
description: A Seton Hall basketball player who became the center of controversy for refusing to wear an American flag on his uniform in support of troops in the Persian Gulf withdrew from the university today and prepared to return to his home in Italy with his wife. He said he and his wife, who is pregnant, had been threatened.

title: U.S. Calls Target a Command Center
description: Defending the attack on a reinforced concrete building in Baghdad, American officials said today that satellite and electronic reconnaissance established the structure was a command and control center for the Iraqi military.

title: Little Change in Treasury Prices
description: Lethargy continued to rule in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light trading. But some market participants said certain investors were getting edgy.

title: Pistons Stunned By Pacers
description: Michael Williams never missed a shot in scoring 21 points to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 105-101 victory over Detroit tonight, ending a five-game losing streak against the Pistons.

title: Parlux Fragrances Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Oil Finish Puts New Life in Oak Furniture
description: For sheer toughness, oak has few rivals. It has remarkable strength in proportion to its weight, and, when properly seasoned, it is well behaved. Early American settlers favored the wood, though other types were available, because they were familiar with it from the old country and trusted it.

title: NCR Seeks F.C.C. Action
description: The NCR Corporation filed a petition yesterday asking the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's takeover bid for NCR, saying the takeover would harm the public interest.

title: CBI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 6.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from the March 1990 sale of CBI's 20 percent equity stake in Australian Submarine Corp.

title: Atmos Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Murder Trial Is Denied For Former Indian Leader
description: A Federal district judge on Tuesday denied a new trial for Leonard Peltier, a former leader of the American Indian Movement who has been imprisoned 15 years for killing two Federal agents at the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota.

title: Jackpot Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Return of Fresca
description: The Coca-Cola Company began the national introduction of the reformulated Fresca, a low-calorie citrus-flavored drink. Fresca, first introduced in the 1960's but later withdrawn from the national market because of low sales, was reformulated in 1985 and has been available only in some areas. The expanded distribution will take place over the next six months, Coke officials said, and will be accompanied by radio and print advertising.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGE S. McGOVERN, the former Senator from South Dakota who was the 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate, is closing the Stratford Inn, at least temporarily.

Gamma Biologicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 75,000 in the quarter and $ 250,000 in the 9 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 97,000 and $ 510,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Brainy Glass and Bricks
description: Designers and architects are on the threshold of a bold new world of materials in which metals have memory and muscle, glass changes color, and old magazines and newspapers are turned into tables and chairs.

title: Insituform Mid-America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Penobscot Shoe Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago periods ended Nov. 24.

title: Aldus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to include results of Silicon Beach Software Inc., acquired in February 1990 and accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: Books of The Times; A Jew's Gentle Look at Germany
description: Germany The Empire Within By Amity Schlaes Illustrated. 264 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $19.95.

title: Prairie Oil Royalties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Durham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 950,000, or 11 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.c-Included income of $ 1,212,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and a loss of $ 3,912,000 in the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Prudential-Bache Chief Quits After Big Losses
description: George L. Ball, who led Prudential-Bache Securities in an expensive but failed effort to break into the top levels of Wall Street investment banks, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the struggling brokerage firm.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CURTIS MAYFIELD, the rhythm-and-blues singer and composer, made his first public appearance yesterday since he suffered injuries that left him paralyzed. In Miami, Mr. Mayfield donated a $100,000 check to set upthe Curtis Mayfield Research Fund at the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis.

title: Making Dreaded Test User-Friendly
description: A sophisticated, widely used and virtually painless diagnostic device is so terrifying that more than a thousand patients a day demand that their tests be ended before they are complete, doctors say.

title: Review/Mime; Timid Angel Visits Sad Woman
description: Many mimes are trying to change their image. They seek to demonstrate that their art involves more than the antics of gently comic and sweetly sad clowns in white-face makeup. These days, some mimes even talk. Despite their efforts, skeptics still charge that mime shows are too often nothing but collections of self-consciously clever wigglings and grimacings.

title: 'CBS Evening News' Names New Producers
description: CBS announced yesterday that Erik Sorenson would replace Tom Bettag as executive producer of "The CBS Evening News" and Susan Zirinsky would become the program's supervising producer. The changes were expected.

title: Espey Mfg & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Occupational-Urgent Care reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Japan's Trade Surplus Is Up
description: Japan's trade surplus rose in January above levels a year earlier for the first time in five months, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Review/Jazz; Freedom to Experiment
description: The trumpeter Eddie Henderson's first set on Monday night at Visiones, where he and his band will be performing every Monday night for an indefinite period, had an expansive feel to it. Rooted in the hard-swinging experimentalism of the 1960's and early 70's, Mr. Henderson's music allowed the band's improvisers to explore, to head down emotional and musical pathways that might be closed in a more orthodox context. And the compositions -- some of which might have sounded at home on a Herbie Hancock Blue Note album -- implied open spaces and freedom, despite their challenging harmonies.

title: INSIDE
description: A Stock Market Record

description: b-Included a tax benefit of about $ 1.5 million from a change in accounting procedure.

title: Healthcare International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 20 million writedown of the carrying value on real estate and equipment.c-Included $ 3.4 million in expenses related to the disposition of a hospital in Hawaii.The lower revenue figures in the latest periods were due to the sale or disposition of four general acute-care hospitals since December 1989.

title: A New Fight Over Lockheed
description: Harold C. Simmons, the investor who owns nearly 20 percent of the Lockheed Corporation, has decided to wage another proxy fight to unseat the military contractor's board.

title: Central Europe Is Scared
description: Despite Mikhail Gorbachev's assurance that Moscow will not oppose the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, anxiety is growing in Central Europe about Soviet intentions. Only this week, Andrei Kozyrev, the liberal Foreign Minister of the Russian Republic, warned, "If the forces of darkness prevail in the Soviet Union, Central Europe is next on their agenda."

title: New President Named For McKesson Drug
description: The McKesson Corporation, the nation's largest pharmaceutical distributor, has named a new president, Thomas Simone, for its McKesson Drug Company. The drug company does $7 billion worth of business annually, accounting for 85 percent of the corporation's total sales.

title: Chinese Trials End; Fate of Hundreds Unclear
description: In a wave of trials ending Tuesday, Chinese courts sentenced 18 of the nation's best-known dissidents to prison for terms ranging up to 13 years. But while those trials have ended, almost nothing is known about the hundreds of others who are in prison for taking part in the Tiananmen democracy movement.

title: Adobe Resources Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said share earnings are after preferred dividends of 16 cents a share in both quarters and 64 cents in both years.

title: Abraham H. Fineman; Allergist, 94
description: Dr. Abraham H. Fineman, an allergy specialist, died on Monday at Bon Secours Hospital/Villa Maria Nursing Center in North Miami, Fla. He was 94 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Paterno Makes Plea
description: Coach Joe Paterno said on Tuesday that he hoped Penn State would have a full Big Ten schedule for the 1993 season by spring.

title: Gyorgy Krasso; Hungarian Dissident, 58
description: Gyorgy Krasso, a former dissident jailed by the Communists for his role in the 1956 uprising, died today. The state press agency said Mr. Krasso was 58 years old.

title: Layoff of New Jersey Workers Will Hurt State
description: To the Editor:

title: Can One Airport Unite Two Nations?
description: For years the flat scrub lands here have been best known for nightly wrangles between illegal Mexican immigrants and the United States Border Patrol. But these days, Otay Mesa has also come to symbolize a far different vision of Mexican-American relations: a proposed binational airport that would join the two countries in a new experiment in cross-border cooperation.

title: Books of The Times; Asia as a Good Place To Pursue Maturity
description: The Ouroboros By Howard Coale 280 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $19.95.

title: Ford Motor's Associates Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said net earnings for 1990 only represent domestic operations, while 1989 net earnings included foreign subsidiaries, which are now owned by other subsidiaries of Ford. Associates continues to manage these operations in the United Kingdom, Japan, Canada and Puerto Rico on behalf of Ford.

title: Skyline Gold reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included a provision of $ 40,834,000 and $ 1,277,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively, for a decline in the value of mining properties and plant and equipment.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: What the Songwriter Did in the Morning
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen Hume and John Shattuck Wed
description: Ellen Hume and John Shattuck, executives at Harvard University, were married yesterday at the Harvard-Epworth United Methodist Church in Cambridge, Mass., by the Rev. Edward L. Mark. The bride, who is keeping her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Hunsberger of Washington. The bridegroom is a son of H. Francis Shattuck Jr. of Darien, Conn., and the late Ruth Murphy Shattuck.

title: Armstrong Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: The company changed its name from ATI Pharmaceuticals Inc. in January 1991.

title: Liberians Agree to Form a Government
description: The three warring Liberian factions announced agreement today to form an interim government next month and to allow the West African peacekeeping force remain in control until then.

title: Peoples Westchester Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Ruling On Screens Favors Japan
description: The Commerce Department said today that Japan was selling the display screens used in popular laptop and notebook computers below fair market value, but in a preliminary ruling it found that the differences, or "dumping" margins, were relatively modest.

title: Subway Crime Drops Sharply At Year's End
description: The number of reported felonies on the subways dropped sharply in the last three months of 1990 -- the first quarterly decline in three years -- and continued to go down in January, the transit police said yesterday.

title: Slain Youth's Mother Backs Mandela Group
description: In an effort to enhance the credibility of Winnie Mandela, who is standing trial on kidnapping and assault charges, the African National Congress today presented the mother of the 14-year-old boy who was killed after being abducted by Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards.

title: Chieftain International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results represents results from April 20 to Dec. 31, 1989.

title: A.B.A. Nominates President-Elect
description: After 88 ballots, American Bar Association members have nominated a senior partner in a Baltimore law firm to be the organization's president-elect. He is expected to be formally elected at the group's annual convention in August and would become its president for one year beginning in August 1992.

title: Scant Success for California Efforts To Put Women in Construction Jobs
description: After more than a decade of organized effort to recruit women for the construction trades, few women in California have succeeded in breaking into such jobs through the state's broad network of certified apprenticeship programs.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Reports Gain of 21.1%
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., Chicago, reported yesterday that its net income for the fourth quarter rose 21.1 percent, to $9.7 million, or 94 cents a share, from 8.0 million, or 78 cents, in the comparable period of 1989. Revenues were up 3.8 percent, to $94.9 million from $91.4 million.

title: Unico American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sears Unit Prices 8.1% Certificates
description: A $500 million issue of asset-backed securities by the Discover Receivables Financing Group, an indirect subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, was priced yesterday through Dean Witter Reynolds.

title: Harold Klein, 80, Dies; A Retired Psychiatrist
description: Harold Klein, a retired psychiatrist, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Teleflex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Allies Study New Steps to Avoid Civilians in Bombing
description: Shaken by the deaths of Iraqi civilians in the bombing of what the United States said it had identified as a purely military installation in Baghdad, senior American officers here said today that they had ordered intensive studies of methods to avoid the repetition of such an incident.

title: Republic Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 71,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 178,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Net loss

title: Black History Month
description: Here is a sampling of events in the New York metropolitan area this weekend in celebration of Black History Month: TODAY "HIGHLIGHTS OF 20 YEARS AT DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM," an exhibition of photographs by such photographers as Martha Swope and Jack Vartoogian, at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, reachable by the North Bridge from 1 World Trade Center. Hours, 7 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily. Through Feb. 28. Free admission. Information: (212) 945-0505 or 640-5232. "MY PEOPLE: A PORTRAIT OF AFRO-AMERICAN CULTURE," an exhibition of works by John H. White, a photographer for The Chicago Sun-Times, at Nikon House, 620 Fifth Avenue, at 49th Street. Hours, Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Through March 2. Free. Information: (212) 586-3907. "A CELEBRATION OF HARRIET TUBMAN," a presentation of events in the life of the abolitionist, presented by the Michael Moriarty Acting Studio, at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street, Manhattan, 8 P.M. Also tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. Donation, $5. Information: (212) 279-4200. TOMORROW POETRY WORKSHOP, for those 6 to 12 years old, Central Queens Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, 11 A.M. Free. Information: (718) 990-0767. A CELEBRATION IN WORDS AND SONG, by the students of the Harlem School of the Arts at Countee Cullen Library, 104 West 136th Street, at 2:30 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 491-2070. "GOD'S TROMBONE," a presentation of music and dramatic dialogue by James Weldon Johnson, at the College of Staten Island, Sunnyside Campus, Williamson Theater, 715 Ocean Terrace, 8 P.M.; performers include choruses from the Fellowship Baptist Church, the St. Phillips Baptist Church, the First Central Baptist Church, the Shiloh A.M.E. Zion Church, among others. Free. Information: (718) 390-7948.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Arabs in Many Nations Protest Bombing
description: Flags were at half-staff and tempers in full cry in many Arab nations today, as people took to the streets to grieve for Iraq's civilian dead and to damn the United States for what they called a deliberate massacre of women and children.

title: Fast Forwarding Into TV's Past
description: FRETTING about the future, network television has evidently decided to rush headlong into the past. Prime-time seems to be entering the Era of Primal Pop.

description: * Telerate Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Dow Jones & Co. that provides financial information and support services, to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge Inc., New York. Billings have not been determined. * Bed Bath & Beyond, Springfield, N.J., a home furniture retailer, to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster with a budget of $2 million.

description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Reflecting a Cooling by Kremlin, Press Grows Critical of Iraq War
description: After an initial round of appreciative plaudits for the American-led air war against Iraq, the Soviet press has followed its Government in turning increasingly critical of the anti-Saddam Hussein alliance.

Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and city closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No street cleaning, pickup, or recycling. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on Saturday schedule. LIRR on holiday schedule. Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state, municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit bus and rail service on Saturday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state, municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed Transportation: Metro-North New Haven line on weekend schedule.

title: Nordica of Italy Acquires Kastle
description: Nordica Sportsystem S.p.A. has acquired Austrian Kastle, a unit of the ski-equipment manufacturer Fischer A.G. A spokesman for Nordica, which is controlled by the leisure-wear manufacturer Benetton S.p.A., said no terms would be disclosed.

title: A Bond Offering By Saskatchewan
description: Among borrowers tapping the debt market yesterday, the Province of Saskatchewan priced $200 million in debentures due in 2021 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Bernard Sauer, Actor, 67
description: Bernard Sauer, an actor in Yiddish theater, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Industry Seeks U.S. Rules Covering Environment Ads
description: A group of 11 trade associations took the unusual step yesterday of asking for Federal guidelines on the use of terms like "recycled" or "recyclable" in advertising and on product labels.

title: Gov. Weicker Delivers
description: Lowell Weicker promised to be tough if Connecticut elected him governor -- so tough that he'd be dumped after one term, he quipped. Five weeks in office, he has now delivered in spades, by proposing a personal income tax. Whether his plan succeeds or fails, it took guts and it's years overdue.

title: Weicker's Tactic Is to Sell Income Tax to the People
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, who was elected Governor without the support of either major political party, began a campaign today to leapfrog the legislature and convince the people of his state to accept what they have opposed in the past: an income tax.

title: 4688: Year of the Horse. 4689? You Choose.
description: On the Chinese calendar, 4689 -- the year that began at midnight -- is the year of the ram. Or the year of the sheep. Or the year of the lamb. Or maybe the year of the goat.

description: Stocks gave way yesterday in heavy trading as financial institutions with big profits continued to pull money out of the market.

description: Marcel Tolkowsky, a Belgian-born gemologist and mathematician who developed the symmetry for cutting diamonds for maximum brilliancy, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: PINUP OF CHOICE: A police officer turned jeans model has become the most sought-after pinup among American troops in Saudi Arabia. Provo Journal, page A16.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 534 money market mutual funds increased by $926.8 million, to $460.7 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds increased by $1.27 billion, to $130.02 billion. The 269 general-purpose funds were down by $283.1 million, to $157.44 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $63.6 million, to $173.23 billion, the institute said.

title: Letters; A Wary Arab World Needs U.S. Reassurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge Section To Close Again To Fix Supports
description: For the fourth time in less than two months, a major section of the badly deteriorated Manhattan Bridge will be closed for emergency repairs, this time disrupting weekend subway service on the B and D lines.

title: Review/Film; Learning Experiences Of a Teacher in China
description: In order to film "Iron and Silk," Mark Salzman's account of his experiences as a teacher in China, Mr. Salzman has stepped back into his own memories to create a kind ofliving diary. In this film version, produced and directed by Shirley Sun, Mr. Salzman plays himself and re-enacts his experiences, a feat that would be difficult for a skilled actor and that for an amateur proves just about impossible. Mr. Salzman's eager, smiling presence gives the film a lot more gee-whiz ingenuousness than it needs.

title:
A Special Co-op Conversion;
Hotel in Manhattan Saves Tax Benefits
description: A problem faced by many residential cooperatives with commercial space is how to comply with a Federal tax regulation known as the 80/ 20 rule while getting the maximum return on that space.

Inspector for Javits Center
description: The president of the Jacob K. Javits Center yesterday appointed an inspector general to guard against abuses. The president, Fabian G. Palomino, said the move was part of a larger plan to protect exhibitors from "illegal activities that tarnish this center's reputation." His choice as inspector general was Henry P. Flinter, the former first assistant inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a former chief investigator for the New York State Organized Crime Task Force. District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan is investigating allegations of extortion and other crimes by center employees.

title: Federal Study Questions Ability Of AZT to Delay AIDS Symptoms
description: A new Federal study has raised troubling questions about who will be helped by the AIDS drug AZT and how much.

description: For the fourth quarter and all of 1990, the company recorded equity in the net loss of its unconsolidated subsidiaries of $ 10,448,000 and $ 23,515,000, respectively, as a separate component of its net loss.

title: Nicholls Suspended For Three Games
description: Bernie Nicholls, the Rangers center, was suspended for three games by the National Hockey League yesterday for striking J. J. Daigneault of the Canadiens with his stick in Saturday night's 6-4 loss in Montreal.

title: Six Die in Pennsylvania Fire
description: A fire swept through a group of row houses here early this morning, killing five children and the 37-year-old father of three of them. Five other families had to be evacuated to a Salvation Army center in this town about 25 miles northwest of Pittsburgh. The cause of the blaze was still undetermined late today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Home Front; Church Leaders Reaffirm Opposition to War
description: In their first collective statement on the Persian Gulf war since hostilities broke out there almost a month ago, leaders of more than 20 major Protestant and Orthodox Christian denominations, joined by 15 Roman Catholic bishops, have reaffirmed their opposition to the war and called for a cease-fire.

title: Talks on Cutting Europe Troops Resume in Vienna
description: Arms negotiators from 22 countries opened a second round of talks here today on reducing conventional forces in Europe. But NATO and Warsaw Pact representatives said they expected little progress until a dispute over the Soviet interpretation of the arms treaty signed in November is resolved.

title: Daly Expected to Coach '92 Olympic Men's Team
description: Chuck Daly, who has coached the Detroit Pistons to the National Basketball Association title the last two seasons, is expected to be named today as the coach of the 1992 United States men's Olympic basketball team. Both USA Basketball and the Pistons have called news conferences for this morning.

title: Celebrating Chinese New Year
description: Here is a sampling of events scheduled this weekend in the metropolitan New York area in celebration of the Chinese New Year, the Year of the Goat, which starts today: TODAY "FOLK TRADITION NEW YORK, NEW YORK," an exhibition of photographs and items relating to Chinese folk art, at the Asian American Arts Center, 26 Bowery. Exhibition hours, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday to Friday. Admission, $8 ($4 for the elderly). Information: (212) 233-2154. TOMORROW "OPEN HOUSE," a daylong celebration with food, crafts demonstrations, lectures and video presentations, at the China Institute in America, 125 East 65th Street, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission, $10 ($3 for those under 12). Information: (212) 744-8181. SUNDAY MUSIC, DANCE AND GAMES, to celebrate the New Year, at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83d Street, 10:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Free with museum admission, $4. Information: (212) 721-1223. FESTIVAL, with performances and crafts demonstrations, at the Asian American Arts Center, 26 Bowery, 4 to 6 P.M. Admission, $8 ($4 for the elderly). Information: (212) 233-2154.

title: Real Estate Group Buys G.M. Building
description: One of the country's largest private real estate investment groups quietly acquired the landmark General Motors Building in Manhattan last month, people at G.M. said yesterday. The headquarters building was sold for $500 million plus other unspecified considerations, they said.

title: Review/Film; John Goodman Plays the Palace
description: Sure, he can play "Good Golly Miss Molly!" on the harpsichord with his feet, but can Ralph (John Goodman) really rule? That is the question asked by "King Ralph," a fictitious (needless to say) account of the first Las Vegas lounge singer -- whose act includes "a tribute to the great Don Ho, the Godfather of Hawaiian soul" -- to become King of England.

title: Racial Mix In Connecticut Rose in 80's
description: The racial and ethnic diversity of Connecticut increased substantially in the 1980's as black and Hispanic populations continued to expand in central cities and Asians showed significant increases in surrounding municipalities, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.

description: The manager of the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad led journalists on a tour of the building's basement today in an effort to persuade them that American military officials were mistaken in saying the hotel houses a military communications center, according to reports from Baghdad.

title: 9 Dutch Skiers Die in Alps
description: Nine Dutch skiers were killed in the French Alps when they were buried by an avalanche apparently set off by earth tremors, local officials said today. Rescue workers had been searching since Wednesday afternoon for the skiers, who were swept away by a 250-yard-wide avalanche in an area where there had been many smaller snowslides.

description: Not far into the current exhibition of paintings by Anthony Van Dyck at the National Gallery in Washington hangs a version from Minneapolis of "The Betrayal of Christ." It presents a scene of flickering torches and figures thrusting themselves forward, the image described in fast, almost furious brush strokes that might suggest it came suddenly to the artist's mind.

description: If esthetic delectation and a dizzying array of art objects rank high on your list of favorite things, the Art Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory is the place to be this weekend.

description: Don Drysdale, the former Dodger pitcher who is in the Hall of Fame, pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor drunken driving charge and was fined $2,350, prosecutors said yesterday.

The party drew an elegant crowd of about 2,000, who sipped champagne and peered at 18th-century bronze nudes and frogs frolicking on television.

title: Ohio State Squeaks Past Wisconsin
description: Mark Baker's bank shot in the lane with one second to play gave second-ranked Ohio State a 73-71 victory over Wisconsin tonight.

title: Andal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Results Plus
description: TENNIS Becker and Edberg to Gain Boris Becker and Stefan Edberg each fought off strong challenges yesterday before advancing to the quarterfinals of the Donnay Indoor championships in Brussels. Becker, the world's top-ranked player, needed two tie breakers to defeat Eric Jelen, 7-6, 7-6, while No. 2 Edberg was taken to three sets by Pat Cash of Australia before winning, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4. Also advancing were Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and the Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union. Hlasek, seeded eighth, defeated Mats Wilander, 6-1, 7-5, and sixth-seeded Chesnokov beat Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 7-6. (AP) Garrison Advances in Chicago: A slimmer Zina Garrison ran Rozalyn Fairbank-Nideffer around the court yesterday and defeated her Australian opponent in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. A 6-2, 6-2 victory sent Garrison, seeded fifth, into the quarterfinals against Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria. The 5-foot-4-inch, 128-pound Garrison blamed a sudden rise in weight on her fall last year from No. 4 to No. 10 in the world ranking. Garrison, from Houston, said she recently took off for a month from competitive tennis and slimmed down. (AP) SKIING Soviet Women Win Cross-Country Elena Valbe became the first triple gold-medal winner at the Nordic championships yesterday by leading the Soviet Union to the women's cross-country relay title in Val di Fiemme, Italy. The Soviet team, anchored by Valbe, cruised to a 45.9-second victory over Italy in the women's 20-kilometer relay. The Soviet foursome, with Lyubov Egorova, Raisa Smetanina and Tamara Tikhonova skiing the other legs, had a winning time of 55 minutes 36.6 seconds. Norway took third and the United States placed 12th and last, 4.30 minutes behind the Soviets.(AP) SLED-DOG RACING Swingley a Winner in Montana Doug Swingley, a 37-year-old rancher from Simms, Mont., won the Race to the Sky yesterday in Dog Creek, Mont. Swingley was one of 11 mushers who began the 500-mile race Saturday in Helena, Mont. He covered the distance in 76 hours. His closest rival, John Patten, 47, of Grand Marais, Minn., trailed him by seven hours. Expected to finish third was Laurie Beckstrom, 38, of Kalispell, Mont., the only woman in the competition. Swingley started with a team of 14 Alaskan huskies, but finished with 7. Warm weather and a melting snow pack turned the trail into slush and ice, conditions that race officials said were hard on the dogs and their drivers. Four teams retired from the competition. (AP)

title: S.&P. Drops Some Ratings For 2 Japanese Banks' Debt
description: Citing adverse changes in the Japanese operating environment, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the ratings on about $15 billion of debt issued by the Industrial Bank of Japan and the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.

title: Increasingly, Prison Term Is the Price for Polluters
description: Law enforcement officials are using criminal statutes more and more instead of civil or administrative proceedings to prosecute polluters. The shift in policy has sent shivers down the spines of company executives and prompted a sharp debate about the appropriate way to punish those who damage the environment.

title: Now, No Hispanic Candidates For Federal Bench in New York
description: The lone Hispanic candidate for the Federal District Court in Manhattan has withdrawn his name from consideration after three years of inaction by the White House on his nomination.

title: Review/Art; Concentrated Passion of the Circle and the Square
description: "Dorothea Rockburne: Circle and Square" has the feeling of a manifesto. The show is concentrated -- four paintings, each 66 by 66 inches, each with swirls of rich, lush color framing, pushing through or pressing against strips of pure white canvas. It is less seductive and less specific than Ms. Rockburne's two previous shows at the Andre Emmerich Gallery. Like much of the other art that has commanded attention this season, it has a fearlessness and an absoluteness that should persuade visitors to take it seriously whether they like it or not.

title: For Children
description: New York City is home to armfuls of puppets, from the primitive to the expensively made. The city is also home to a legion of Gepettos who passionately construct witches, lost little boys, wizards and barbarous he-men. Here is a survey of some of the puppet companies and theaters that offer shows regularly. All suggest that children 3 years old and up can attend. Strollers are stashed easily, and at the end of every show, the audience meets the puppets or can be taken backstage. No refreshments are served, nor are there intermissions, though a trip to the restroom between scenes is all right. Every show also requires reservations as many as three days ahead. 'Jack and the Beanstalk' The Puppetworks 338 Sixth Avenue (at Fourth Street) Park Slope section Brooklyn (718) 965-3391 Through Feb. 24
