title: Big Losses For G.M. And Ford
description: Saying that war and recession had shattered consumer confidence, the nation's two biggest auto makers today reported huge fourth-quarter losses. General Motors, with a $1.62 billion deficit, and Ford, with $519 million, said sales had dried up faster than they could cut costs.

title: Quebec-Telephone reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Synetic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
William W. Bryan, 85, Ex-Newspaper Editor
description: William Wright Bryan, former editor of The Atlanta Journal and The Cleveland Plain Dealer, who earlier broadcast an eyewitness account of D-Day as a World War II correspondent, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Clemson Area Retirement Community. He was 85 years old.

title: Charge Is Dismissed
description: A sexual assault charge against a former San Antonio Spurs guard, David Wingate, in Bexar County was dismissed because of insufficient evidence on Wednesday and a civil suit against him in San Antonio was settled out of court.

title: General Motors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said 1990 full year results included a special after-tax restructuring charge of $ 2.1 billion in the third quarter ''to bring its cost structure more in line with the projected level of its North American automotive operations.''The company also said the resulting $ 1.6 billion loss recorded in the latest fourth quarter reflected in part the difficulty in reducing costs as quickly as the rapid volume fall-off, and it almost offset the $ 1.7 billion earned by General Motors in the first nine months of 1990, excluding the special restructuring change.

title: Review/Film; Thwarted Expectations
description: As black workers cut sugar cane in the 1940's, a narrator notes that these happy laborers are following the "hereditary urge to go back to the plantation." That archival clip, included in Stephanie Black's "H-2 Worker," suggests how little the plantation mentality has changed in nearly 50 years, though today the sugar-cane growers rely on Jamaicans imported to Florida for six months every year.

title: JWP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 1,492,000 from the purchase of debentures and an after-tax charge of $ 1,550,000 for writedowns on various energy and environmental projects.All periods restated to give effect to the acquisition of Neeco Inc., accounted for on a pooling of interests basis, and to reflect two 3-for-2 common stock splits, effected June 12, 1989 and July 16, 1990.

title: A Special Police Patrol Hacks at Roots of Crime
description: For Officer Charles Davis, fighting crime means noticing a darkened intersection on his beat and talking to the crime prevention officer about putting in a street light. It means breaking up a scuffle among 9-year-olds outside Public School 48, shooing prostitutes off Liberty Avenue and meeting with recovering drug addicts in a storefront clinic.

title: Sampras Uses His Serve To Reach Quarterfinals
description: One made it halfway through college, the other didn't go at all, but on the tennis court, MaliVai Washington is the one playing catch-up.

title: N.A.B. Names New President
description: Leonard Forman has been named president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, the sales and marketing organization of the newspaper industry.

title: Liu Chieh, Taiwan's Top Delegate At U.N. in 1960's, Is Dead at 85
description: Liu Chieh, a career diplomat who served as Taiwan's delegate to the United Nations from 1962 to 1971, died on Tuesday at Fairfax Hospital in Virginia. He was 85 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Bow Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 12.7 million writedown of miscellaneous mining and real estate assets.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cut the Sales Tax? Sure! Tax Income? 'No Way!'
description: Lydia Maffei looked a little queasy today when she learned that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. had proposed a new tax, a 6 percent state income tax, the night before.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Two Nights of Blues

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Process of News Reporting on Display
description: The conflicting Pentagon and Iraqi versions of the bombing of what may or may not have been a bomb shelter in Baghdad placed the messy process of news reporting on unusual display Wednesday as reporters struggled to separate propaganda from fact.

title: Jackie Wackie Solidifies Derby-Contender Status
description: Jackie Wackie finished first for the ninth consecutive time in winning the $50,000 Cryptoclearance Stakes today at Gulfstream Park. The victory moved him into the prime position to challenge Fly So Free, the early Kentucky Derby favorite, in the Florida Derby next month.

title: Oil Industry's Profits
description: Major oil companies recorded a 77 percent increase in profits in the fourth quarter of 1990 as high crude oil prices nearly tripled their income from oil and gas production, the Government said today. The report by the Energy Department said there was no evidence of price gouging by the companies. The companies' "greatest gains in profitability were directly tied" to the sharp increases in crude oil prices that occurred in the months after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the report said.

title: It's Still Vandalism
description: To evoke the atmosphere of New York City, film makers once routinely depicted subway cars smeared with graffiti. No more. These days, subway graffiti date a New York movie the way running boards and Tommy guns date a gangster film.

title: Brazil Cutting Tariffs
description: The Government lowered hundreds of import tariffs today as part of an economic reform begun last June. Under the new rates, effective Friday, the tariff on imported cars will fall from 85 percent to 60 percent, then to 35 percent in 1994. Tariffs on electronic goods will fall from 55 percent to 30 percent in 1994. Tariffs on capital goods, machinery, farm equipment, locomotives and petrochemical products will also be cut and continue to drop until 1994, when they will range from zero to 40 percent.

title: One for the Road
description: It sounds like an April Fool's prank, but 39-year-old Guy Lafleur says he has been talked into making one more trip around the National Hockey League before retiring again on April 1.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Technology; Baghdad Is Heart of Iraq's Complex Military Communications Structure
description: The command and control system of the Iraqi military relies on a large national network of communications centers and is based on Soviet design, experts say.

title: TALKS ON CLIMATE END WITH ACCORD
description: Fulfilling a promise it made almost two weeks ago, the United States said today that it would negotiate limits on emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases thought by scientists to cause global warming.

title: Australian on Top
description: Geoff Case, a 32-year-old Australian who won his way into the race, scaled 80 flights of stairs yesterday in the 14th annual Empire State Run-Up in the fastest time of the 107 men entered, 10 minutes 13 seconds.

title: Recap Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomePreferred-share dividends were $ 2.5 million versus $ 2.2 million in the fourth quarter and $ 10.2 million versus $ 10.4 million in the full year.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Knicks Never at a Loss for Ways to Lose a Game
description: In her years on the television show "Saturday Night Live," the late Gilda Radner created a scatterbrained character, Roseanne Roseannadanna, who was given to say, "It's always something."

title: Piedmont Federal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dr. Ellis Leonard, 86, A Veterinary Professor
description: Dr. Ellis P. Leonard, professor emeritus of veterinary surgery at Cornell University's Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital, died on Feb. 7 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Our Towns; Is It the Water? The Moonlight? Or Is It Love?
description: On another day perhaps, though certainly not in this sedate space, the headlines might scream: Cops Nabbed in Jersey Love Nest. Officers Blame Water, U.F.O.'s. Chief Plans Probe.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Poll; Americans Back Continued Air Strikes
description: While resigned that ground combat against Iraq will probably be necessary, the American public overwhelmingly prefers that bombing from the air continue for the next few weeks. That preference did not appear to change much as a result of the storm this week over the Iraqi civilians killed in a Baghdad building hit by allied bombs, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: New F.B.I. Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Lawrence Cement reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeFigures are in Canadian funds.

title: Critic's Choice
description: The Otrabanda Company was once involved in a theater production called "No Plays No Poetry but Philosophical Reflections Practical Instructions Provocative Prescriptions and Pointers From a Noted Critic and Playwright." The ensemble, founded in 1971 by seven actors on Curacao, spent 10 years of its life traveling by raft from St. Louis to New Orleans along the Mississippi River presenting free tent performances.

title: DVI Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Blind Spots in the Gulf;
Air Power: Lessons And Limits
description: The nonstop air strikes against Iraqi installations and troops have provided further proof that massive bombing cannot bring a country to its knees. Many generals once believed that it was the large-scale bombing of Germany that ultimately brought about the Nazis' surrender. They were wrong.

title: Foot Cone & Belding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Waltham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 2d Patient of Dentist In Florida Files Suit Over AIDS Infection
description: A man identified as one of three patients infected with the AIDS virus by a dentist filed a $1 million lawsuit today against the dentist's estate and insurance companies.

title: Consolidated Fibers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a reversal of an earlier-recognized tax credit of $ 55,000.c-Net income

title: Key Rates
Market Place; A New Romance With Commodore
description: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL has become an unlikely addition to some analysts' lists of promising technology companies.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Remembering Alec Wilder

title: Lee Hazen, 85, Top Bridge Player And Administrator and a Lawyer
description: Lee Hazen, a lawyer and one of the leading players and personalities in the world of bridge, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ketchum International Inc., Pittsburgh, has formed a joint venture with Kuo Hua Advertising of Taiwan. The new agency, Kuo Hua Ketchum International, will provide services to advertisers in Taiwan and mainland China.

title: People
description: * Ammirati & Puris, New York, an affiliate of Robert Marston & Associates Inc., named Kirk Souder vice president-art supervisor and Tony Gomes vice president-copy supervisor. * Della Femina McNamee, Pittsburgh, named Joe Poprosky and Donald Kress vice presidents. * Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, Philadelphia, a part of Earle Palmer Brown, named John C. Bythrow, Dale A. Kramer and Diane Lutz vice presidents. * Ned Costello has been named vice president-management supervisor at Kelley & Wallwork Advertising, Boston. * Joan Bergman has been named senior vice president-director of new business development at Deutsch Inc., New York. * Mark Herlyn has been named to the new position of associate publisher of the magazines Cruising World and Sailing World, publications of The New York Times Company Magazine Group. * Bill Madonna has been named Los Angeles advertising sales manager at USA Today. * Amy R. Churgin has been named advertising director of Elle Magazine.

title: Review/Film; What A Woman Can See
description: Standing by the side of the road, in black tights and a very short dress, is an accident waiting to happen: Pauline (Annabelle Larsen), a mysterious young woman who is beautiful, difficult and not terribly truthful about her own future plans. Pauline is also blind, which is something she neglects to mention to Robbie (Roger Kabler), Marjorie (Mary McLain)and Lance (Allen McCullough), three old friends making a car trip together for nostalgia's sake.

title: Reading Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 637,000, or 13 cents a share, and $ 18,798,000, or $ 3.78 a share, for the latest and prior years, respectively.c-Net lossLatest fourth quarter results included a $ 5,174,000 gain from the sale of certain company properties for use in the Pennsylvania Convention Center project. On Dec. 31, 1990, the company had $ 3.3 million in proceeds remaining from the Convention Center transaction, which was payable to the company upon completion of certain site preparations and the transfer of one remaining property. The company anticipates receipt of the remaining proceeds will be completed before the conclusion of the 1991 first quarter.

title: Fibreboard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,200,000 in both the quarter and year, and the quarter also included a gain on the sale of timberland to Sierra Pacific Industries of $ 5.2 million after tax, or $ 1.32 a share.c-Net lossd-Included a loss of $ 988,000 in the quarter and income of $ 1,479,000, or 38 cents a share, in the year, both from discontinued operations, and the quarter also included creation of asbestos-related cost reserve of $ 15 million after taxes or $ 3.87 a share and a gain on the sale of timberland of $ 13.5 million after tax or $ 3.47 a share.

title: Slump in Reading, Pa.: From Threat to Reality
description: In the last two months, recession has quietly infiltrated this blue-collar city on the edge of the Pennsylvania Dutch country, transforming an impending threat into a grim reality for residents like Herbert Cook.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Campbell Soup Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Metromedia Hires Salomon Brothers
description: The billionaire investor John Kluge said his Metromedia Inc. had hired Salomon Brothers Inc. to advise on the possible sale of its 68 percent stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. It was reported last week that the Sony Corporation of Japan was considering buying the debt-laden film and television concern. Other reports said Orion was trying to sell rights to some films to raise cash. Spokesmen for Sony and Orion declined to comment on the reports.

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures in New York City this weekend.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld a lower court's decision that WILLIAM HURT did not have a common-law marriage to SANDRA JENNINGS. Ms. Jennings, a former dancer with the New York City Ballet, had tried to prove that the marriage existed so she could get some of the actor's assets. She lived with Mr. Hurt from 1981 to 1984 and bore his son, ALEXANDER DEVON HURT.

title: Rothmans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 7.1 million provision for plant closing in Montreal.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Avery Dennison reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said that 1990 results were affected by a $ 85.2 million one-time charge to earnings for restructuring costs and $ 13.8 million expenses related to the merger of Avery International Corp. and Dennsion Manufacturing Co. The restructuring charge was recorded in the fourth quarter of 1990.Fiscal 1990 results have been restated to a calendar year basis, as a result of the company changing its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Nov. 30.

title: Peru's Premier Quits Amid Report of Feud
description: Prime Minister Juan Carlos Hurtado Miller resigned today after weeks of speculation in the press over a reported dispute with his Industry Minister.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossShare earnings for latest quarter are after preferred dividends.

title: Synergen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Executive Loss Likely
description: The First Executive Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss "of a material amount" for the fourth quarter and the full year.

title: Goodyear Executive To Head Celeron Unit
description: At a late date in his career, George R. Hargreaves has been handed a challenge by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. He has been named as the next president and chief executive of Goodyear's Celeron Corporation subsidiary, generally acknowledged to be the company's white elephant.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Carolina Power and Light Co., Raleigh, N.C., is offering $125 million in 8 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2021 at 98.707 to yield 9 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. Noncallable for five-years, the bonds are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. * Deere & Co., Moline, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for separate shelf offerings of medium-term notes of up to $470.5 million and up to $508 million. Both filings listed Merrill Lynch & Co. and Goldman, Sachs & Co. as underwriters. COMMON STOCK * John Nuveen & Co., Chicago, has filed for the initial public offering of 10 million common shares of the Nuveen Select Quality Municipal Fund Inc. through Alex. Brown & Sons. * Kaiser Aluminum Corp., Houston, a unit of Maxxam Inc., has filed an amendment to its registration statement to increase the size of its initial public offering of common stock through Merrill Lynch & Co., to 7.25 million common shares, from 6 million.

title: Mexican Opposition Urges Observers for Vote
description: Despite strong Government resistance, opposition leaders here have stepped up calls for the invitation of international observers to guard against fraud in coming Mexican elections.

title: Technalysis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wainoco Oil reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of U.S. property of $ 14 million and $ 21.2 million for the quarter and year, respectively.c-Included a writedown of U.S. property of $ 2 million.d-Net income

title: Peru's Neighbors Halt Food Imports
description: Seeking to contain a cholera outbreak in Peru, health authorities across Latin America halted food imports today and tightened controls on people arriving from that country.

title: Harold Goldsmith, 48; Founded a Store Chain
description: Harold Goldsmith, co-founder of Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, operator of a nationwide chain of apparel stores, died in an airplane crash Wednesday in Aspen, Colo. He was 48 years old and lived in Aspen.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Balkan, Sofia, Bulgaria, the national airline, is talking to several Western concerns, including Boeing Co., Seattle, about buying long-range aircraft. * British Steel P.L.C., London, will cut 810 jobs, or about 11.6 percent of its work force, at a plant in Britain by March 1992. * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has begun ordering merchandise for its Broadway, Emporium and Weinstocks stores. The retailer received $150 million in financing from Chemical Bank. * Diamond-Star Motors, a venture of Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp., said European exports of the Mitsubishi Eclipse would begin next month. * Electronic Data Systems Corp., a unit of General Motors Corp., received a $100 million systems management contract for 10 years from Signetics Co., Sunnyvale, Calif., which designs integrated computer circuits. * Equimark Corp., Pittsburgh, will not resume regular stock dividends without U.S. approval and will submit a recovery plan to the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland by June 13. * Hasbro Inc., Pawtucket, R.I., the toy maker, has provided financing to Olmec Corp., New York, a minority-owned toy company. No amount was disclosed. * Martin Marietta Corp., Bethesda, Md., has received a $125.9 million Air Force contract to continue producing Lantirn aircraft night-targeting systems. * RWE-DEA, a German oil and petrochemicals company, is extending to March 18 its $55-a-share offer for the common stock of Vista Chemical Co., Houston. * Sumitomo Metal Industries, Tokyo, and Masco Industries, Taylor, Mich., will form International Crankshaft Inc. to make and sell forged crankshafts. Masco will own 19.9 percent of the venture, in Georgetown, Ky. Sumitomo will own the remainder.

title: Hormel (Geo. A.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Ford Motor Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included charge of $ 424.3 million from sale of Rouge Steel Co.

title: Imo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included unspecified non-recurring income of $ 1.2 million, or 6 cents a share.

title: Cases of Measles Are Increasing
description: German measles, also known as rubella, is making a comeback, largely among young adults who were never vaccinated, Federal health researchers said today.

title: Making Point, First Lady Flies Commercial
description: In a gesture aimed at calming public fears about terrorism related to the Persian Gulf war, Barbara Bush forsook her 12-seat Government jet today and joined travelers on a flight from Washington to Indianapolis, her first commercial flight since she became First Lady two years ago.

title: Racist Cartoon
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's just a symbol. When it was the year of the horse, you didn't ask if it was a female horse. The same idea for the sheep." -- Jaidong Wang, a Chinese diplomat discussing what the Chinese New Year should be called. [ B1:4. ]

title: Bayer USA Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Bayer USA Inc. is the U.S. management holding company of Bayer AG.The company said that its healthcare company, Miles Inc., continued to show solid growth in both sales and income. The decline in net income was due primarily to the downturn in the chemicals unit, Mobay Corp., and Imaging Technologies unit, AGFA Corp.

title: Evening of the Baroque
description: The soprano Harolyn Blackwell and the trumpeter Neil Balm are to be the soloists with the New York Chamber Symphony in a program of Baroque music at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock. The program, which is to be conducted by George Manahan, includes Bach's Cantata No. 51, arias from Handel's "Semele" and "Alcina," a Trumpet Concerto in D by Telemann, and orchestral works by Delalande and Rameau. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Bloomingdale's Union Asked to Forgo Raise
description: Citing financial hardship, Bloomingdale's has asked the union representing 3,500 full-time employees to rescind an $18-a-week wage increase due to take effect March 1.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a funeral for Maj. Eugene McCarthy of the Marines, who was killed in the Persian Gulf war, misstated the place of burial. It was Calverton National Cemetery on Long Island.

title: Cigna Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 12,000,000 in both the quarter and year.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 104,000,000, or $ 1.32 a share.The company said full year results were constrained by after-tax charges of $ 98 million related to restructuring of domestic property and casualty operations, as well as declining market conditions.The company also said after-tax realized investment losses in the latest periods were $ 15 million, and $ 25 million, for the year and fourth quarter, respectively, compared with gains of $ 104 million, or $ 1.33 a share, and $ 51 million, or 65 cents a share, in the similar 1989 periods, respectively.

title: SCOR U.S. Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included merger expenses of $ 554,000, and $ 2,225,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.c-Included gain of $ 328,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter, and a loss of $ 337,000 for the year, both from subsidiary held for sale.

title: Seaboard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aspin Is Listed as Stable at Denver Hospital
description: Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin was listed in serious but stable condition today at University Hospital, where he remained in intensive care for a heart ailment.

title: Review/Film; A Liberating Friendship
description: "Perfectly Normal," Yves Simoneau's Canadian comedy, is about a friendship that is supposed to be unlikely, though it's a staple of a certain kind of movie.

title: Nacco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 12.4 million for restructuring and other non-restructuring charges.c-Included $ 14.6 million for restructuring and other non-restructuring charges such as recalling Hamilton Beach-Proctor-Silex Inc. coffee makers.d-Net incomeThe 1989 year's share earnings included non-recurring income of 61 cents a share.The company said revenue in the latest year included Hyster Co. operations for a full year following its acquisition in May 1989, and the acquisition of Hamilton Beach Inc. in October 1990.

title: Fremont General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 198,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 915,000, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 204,000.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6,747,000 in the quarter and $ 8,207,000 in the year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $ 107,000.The company said the 1990 fourth quarter earnings were adversely affected by $ 2,838,000, or 34 cents a share, as a result of a provision taken by the company to provide for potential losses resulting from its terminated commercial mortgage banking operations.

title: WATER CUT AGAIN FOR CALIFORNIANS
description: The Federal Government announced today that it was cutting by 75 percent the amount of water it supplies to California farmers and by as much as half the amount it allows the state's cities.

title: Amax Coal Buys Cannelton Concern
description: Amax Coal Industries, the nation's third-largest coal producer, today bought the Cannelton Holding Company and its large, low-sulfur reserves in West Virginia.

title: U.S. Imposes Travel Curbs
description: The State Department has begun to ban travel by Americans to Iraq and Kuwait as a "precautionary measure," saying United States passports will no longer be valid for either country.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "A CHILD'S WORLD," an exhibition of 100 paintings and drawings by children aged 2 to 12 from 30 countries, produced by the Children's Museum of the Arts, in Manhattan. At the Cork Gallery in Lincoln Center, in the concourse of Avery Fisher Hall, through Monday. Open daily from 10 A.M. to the hall's closing. Admission, free. Information: (212) 877-1800.

title: Universal Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics of The Times; Seeking Status
description: At a time when consumption is less conspicuous than it used to be, today's sure-fire clue to status is not what's being worn but what isn't. A New Yorker realized that one cold and rainy day this week when he started to look for a luncheon guest's topcoat. There wasn't one -- because said luncheon guest had a limo waiting outside.

title: Review/Theater; A Difficult Birth For 'Mule Bone'
description: IF ever there was a promising idea for a play, it is the enigmatic story of what went on when two giants of the Harlem Renaissance briefly collided in 1930 to collaborate on "a comedy of Negro life" they titled "Mule Bone."

title: Cerbco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Drabek Breaks the Bank and Arbitration Mark
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates' worst nightmare began yesterday.

title: Ms. Taylor Weds W. D. Hartley
description: Janet Louise Taylor, the unit manager of Cable News Network Business News, and William Davis Hartley, an anchor and the news editor at CNN Business News, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York by the Rev. Charles S. Temple Jr.

title: Pegasus Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said that the losses were after non-recurring, non-cash property writedowns and investment losses of $ 35.1 million in the fourth quarter and $ 18 million in the year.

title: 2 Fernandez Report Cards
description: One year after he took over as head of the New York City school system, Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez received two report cards yesterday -- one he issued himself and a less glowing one from an independent educational advocacy group.

title: Richard W. Freund, Banker, 79
description: Richard W. Freund, a retired vice president of Citibank, died Feb. 3 at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; IRAQIS ASSAIL U.S. AS RESCUE GOES ON
description: Scores of bodies were recovered from a bombed building in Baghdad yesterday as the Government of Saddam Hussein condemned what it called a premeditated attack on an air raid shelter that it said killed hundreds of civilians.

title: U.S. Breaks Off Talks With Europeans on Airbus
description: Escalating the long-simmering conflict over the Airbus aircraft, the Bush Administration today broke off negotiations with the European Community on aerospace subsidies and announced it was seeking an international judgment on the dispute.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With her 50th book coming out this month, LOIS WYSE is busily writing her 51st. Ms. Wyse, a founder and the president of Wyse Advertising, wrote the best seller "Funny, You Don't Look Like a Grandmother." Now she is writing Son of Grandmother, a nonfiction work about grandmothers in modern families.

title: Defense Lawyer Is Jailed Over Client Confidentiality
description: For almost two decades, Linda Backiel has used her law degree to defend people who disagreed vehemently and sometimes violently with the policies of the Federal Government.

title: Guggenheim May Sue For Chagall, Court Says
description: New York State's highest court today gave broad new protection to victims of art theft, ruling that the Guggenheim Museum could sue to recover a stolen Chagall painting from the private collector on whose living-room wall the work has hung for more than 20 years.

title: Robert Di Giorgio Ex-Chief Executive And Chairman, 79
description: Robert Di Giorgio, former head of the Di Giorgio Corporation, a billion-dollar family-owned concern with interests in food, drug, building materials and real estate businesses, died on Wednesday in San Francisco. He was 79 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Inspiration Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax provision of $ 12 million for streamlining corporate office and other operations. The figure also included a pre-tax base metal asset writeoff of $ 3.8 million. The net losses also included losses from discontinued operations of $ 81,593,000 for the quarter and $ 83,617,000 for the year.c-Included $ 5.2 million in gains on the sale of leases for both periods, and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 1,363,000 for the quarter and $ 9,475,000 for the year.d-Net incomeThe loss from continuing operations and the final net loss for 1990 also included $ 16.5 million writeoff of investment in Westgold.

title: First Liberty Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 242,000, or 12 cents a share, which represents a gain on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Itel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations and gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $ 135.8 million, or $ 3.10 a share, for the quarter and $ 165.2 million, or $ 3.50 a share, for the year.c-After income from discontinued operations and gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $ 7.7 million, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 30.9 million, or 61 cents a share, for the year.

title: SBT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Topics of The Times; Franking Frenzies Contained
description: One of the better commercials by a challenger during last fall's Congressional races showed senior citizens toting open umbrellas to protect themselves from a fierce downpour of taxpayer-financed Congressional mail. The message was right on target: an incumbent's urge to communicate rises sharply in election years. But thanks to a new reform of Congressional franking rules, the worst of the storm may at last be over.

title: Central Vermont Public Service reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Superior Surgical Mfg. Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aaron Rents reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-During the three-month period ended Dec. 31, the company recorded $ 2,236,000 of after-tax charges to net income resulting from increased depreciation expense on assets of certain rental contracts, provisions for future costs associated with closed locations, reserves for the write-down of rental return furniture, costs of sales tax assessments, charges for increased worker's compensation insurance, and severance pay liabilities.c-Net income

title: Public Service of New Hampshire reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Down the Middle?
description: Pete Wilson, California's new Republican Governor, has one picture behind his desk: of Ronald Reagan. In his inaugural speech last month he hailed Mr. Reagan. But among former governors he also praised Democrat Pat Brown and Earl Warren, the great liberal Republican.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Losses at G.M. and Ford

title: Lisbon Journal; From the Pure of Tongue, Catcalls in Portuguese
description: When it comes to being a mother country, Portugal has not had an easy time dealing with Brazil, dwarfed as it is by a former colony with 90 times more territory, 15 times more inhabitants, 8 times more economic clout and a good deal more self-assurance.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Intermet Corp., Atlanta, a manufacturer of iron products, named John D. Ernst vice president, finance, and chief financial officer. E.A. Bodnar was named president of the company's domestic foundry group. * Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing Co., Lake Forest, Ill., a joint venture of Macmillan Inc. and McGraw-Hill Inc., named Catherine McAward president of its international division. * National Heritage Inc., Dallas, a manager of nursing homes, named James J. Murphy executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Pinelands Inc., Secaucus, N.J., the new company that owns WWOR-TV, named Barbara L. Landes vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer. * RJR Nabisco Inc., New York, named Bruce J. Wood president of its Planters Lifesavers Co. He replaces Dolph W. von Arx, who is retiring. The company also established a new RJR Nabisco Foods Group, headed by H. John Greeniaus, to which Planters Lifesavers and Nabisco Brands Inc. will report. * Time Life Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., named Paul Stewart vice chairman. * Walt Disney Imagineering, Glendale, Calif., a subsidiary of Walt Disney Co., named Dick Sargon vice president, project management, a new position.

title: Critic's Notebook; Briefers Lose a Round As TV Goes for Blood
description: Until this week, the war on television was almost bloodless. Then suddenly, like an animal that has been denied red meat for a month, the medium was chewing away. On all networks, the pictures of bodies being taken from the ruins of a Baghdad building that had been used as a shelter instantly upstaged the military briefers, who until Wednesday had dominated the tube.

title: A Credit Review By First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation reviewed the credit backgrounds of its New England credit card holders in August to find customers who have been delinquent on other loans. Once identified, the bank either reduced the card holder's line of credit or revoked the card altogether. A spokeswoman for the bank said it was the only time the bank had selected credit histories in a particular region as a target.

title: Associated Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Immunex Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
P.L.O. Clash in Lebanon Kills 17
description: Guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, split into two rival camps in southern Lebanon today and fought fierce battles that left 17 people dead and 40 wounded, the police said.

title: Why Are We Saving a West Side Lemon?
description: As it looks now, state highway engineers, not Donald Trump or the city, will have the last word on how the largest undeveloped piece of West Side waterfront is built. And the state and city together will lose forever the wonderful opportunity to have the first major new Manhattan park in decades and new development that extends the residential character of the Upper West Side.

title: 3 Girls and Mother Die in a House Fire
description: Three girls and their mother died in an early-morning fire that engulfed their one-story frame house on Friday, the police said.

title: Islander Sidelined
description: Derek King, the most productive member of the Islanders in recent games, will be out for about 10 days with a mild separation of the right shoulder. King, who has 15 points in his last 12 games, suffered the injury in the secomd period of the Islanders' 5-2 loss to the Penguins at Pittsburgh Thursday night.

title: Recession Narrows Trade Gap
description: The nation's trade deficit fell in December to a six-month low of $6.25 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Lockheed Rebuff On Board Seats
description: The board of the Lockheed Corporation voted unanimously to rebuff the latest bid for board seats by Harold Simmons, a billionaire Texan who owns 19.8 percent of the company through his NL Industries, a specialty chemicals concern in Houston. The rejection apparently insures a proxy war for control of the big military contractor at its annual meeting on April 2.

title: Patents; Test of Wordly Wisdom
description: For those who want a new variation on Trivial Pursuit or Pictionary, Adrienne J. Weiss of Pittsburgh has invented a game called Expressions. Players advance along the board by guessing the idiomatic expression represented by the pictures on a card. Two rodents in sweat suits, for example, means "rat race," while a soup dish full of letters signifies "eat your words." Ms. Weiss received patent 4,991,854.

title: Granite State reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; 'Absolute Truths' Collide in Arabs' War of Words
description: The foreign newspapers on sale here have a flimsy lightness to them these days because government censors have torn out news of the Persian Gulf war. A recent copy of The International Herald Tribune, thus, went from page 2 to page 7, with nothing in between.

title: Hitox Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a first quarter one-time writedown of $ 500,000 from the discontinuance of certain operations.

title: U.S. Securities Mixed in Volatile Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with bills and notes slightly lower and the longer maturities showing small gains. But dealers said the price movements masked a day of sharp swings, mostly caused by short-lived hopes of peace in the Persian Gulf.

title: Bucks Trade Pierce For Sonics' Ellis
description: The Milwaukee Bucks yesterday traded the guard Ricky Pierce to the Seattle SuperSonics for the 6-foot-7-inch guard Dale Ellis. The deal depends on each player's passing his new team's physical examination, the Bucks said, adding that they expect Ellis to be available for their game tomorrow in Orlando.

title: Foreigners Get Japan Jet Role
description: Seven companies, including four based outside Japan, agreed today to join in a Japanese project to develop engines for hypersonic jet planes that are envisioned as being capable of flying between New York and Tokyo in only three hours.

title: Investors Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Livery-Cab Driver Found Fatally Shot
description: A livery-cab driver was shot and killed in Queens yesterday, two hours after another cabby was shot and wounded in a nearby neighborhood, the police said.

title: Browns' Newsome Retires for Scouting
description: It took two attempts, but after 13 seasons, 662 catches, 7,980 yards and 47 touchdowns, Ozzie Newsome has finally managed to retire from the Cleveland Browns, or almost anyway. In announcing his retirement yesterday, Newsome, the fourth-leading receiver in National Football League history and No. 1 among tight ends, said he had accepted a special assignment as a scout for the Browns.

title: Wielding New Studies, Landlords Ask Albany to Undo Rent Laws
description: With rents slipping and vacancies on the rise, a loose coalition of landlords and university housing experts is preparing a challenge to New York's 43-year-old system of rent regulations, which is facing renewal this spring in Albany.

title: Forschner Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mark Controls Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Burger King Investors Master L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Judge Is Cleared In Bribe Inquiry, Prosecutor Says
description: A grand jury has concluded that a Queens judge was not trying to bribe a diner owner when he paid him $2,000 after the judge's son was arrested in a brawl that damaged the diner, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Medical Unit Refinancing
description: The Charter Medical Corporation proposed a refinancing today of its $1.7 billion debt and warned that if the plan were not approved, the health-care provider might have to seek bankruptcy court protection.

title: Becker and Edberg Advance  Top-seeded Boris Becker of Germany and his main rival, Stefan Edberg of Sweden, both scored straight-set victories yesterday and moved into the semifinals of the Donnay Indoor Championship in Brussels. Becker, who at No. 1 holds a narrow margin over Edberg in the Association of Tennis Professionals ranking, beat seventh-seeded Michael Chang of the United States, 7-5, 6-1. Edberg defeated Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-1, 6-2. Edberg will meet a Frenchman, Guy Forget, who is ranked 11th in the world, in the semifinals today. Forget beat Marc Rosset of Switzerland, 6-2, 7-5. Becker will play Andrei Cherkasov, a Soviet wild-card entry, who beat his compatriot Andrei Chesnokov, 7-5, 6-1, in a baseline battle. Becker's lead over Edberg in the world standing is 133 points. (AP) Sukova Defeats Capriati: Sixth-seeded Helena Sukova used a powerful serve-and-volley game to beat fourth-seeded Jennifer Capriati, 6-4, 6-4, in a quarterfinal match of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Zina Garrison, ranked fifth in the world, upended second-seeded Katerina Maleeva, 6-2, 1-6, 6-1, and Helen Kelesi of Canada beat seventh-seeded Amy Frazier, 7-5, 6-3. (AP) N.H.L. Flames Rout Capitals  Gary Roberts had a goal and two assists and Calgary scored six consecutive goals in the second period last night at home to beat Washington, 8-2. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL  Princeton Wins Ninth in Row  Kit Mueller scored 17 points in the first half and Sean Jackson added 11 in the second last night in Providence as the Tigers defeated Brown, 79-63, in an Ivy League game for their ninth consecutive victory. Princeton (17-2 over all, 8-0 in the Ivy) led by 34-33 at halftime despite shooting 68 percent from the field. The Tigers and Bruins (7-14, 2-7) exchanged leads early in the second half before Princeton took command with a 10-2 run. (AP) GOLF  Douglass Leads Aetna Challenge  Dale Douglass, unbothered by a wind gusts of more than 45 miles an hour, shot a 67 yesterday and forged a four-stroke lead in the opening round of the Aetna Challenge senior tournament in Naples, Fla. (AP) Two Share Lead: Ben Crenshaw and Phil Mickelson couldn't keep pace as a couple of former champions moved into a tie for the lead yesterday at the halfway point of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Open in San Diego. Dan Forsman and Steve Pate, each of whom scored his last victory in this tournament, completed 36 holes at 132, 12 strokes under par. (AP) AUTO R
description: N.B.A. Parish Leads Celtics Over Lakers Robert Parish scored 21 of his 29 points in the first quarter as Boston scored a 98-95 victory last night at Inglewood, Calif. It was the Celtics' first victory at the Forum since 1986. The Celtics led all the way after breaking a 6-6 tie four minutes into the game and snapped the Lakers' home winning streak at 14. The 37-year-old Parish scored a season-high 29 as the Celtics won their sixth consecutive game. (AP) Trail Blazers 117, Jazz 105: Terry Porter scored 22 points, including five 3-pointers, and Cliff Robinson's 6 consecutive points capped a decisive Portland spurt. Kevin Duckworth had 18 points and Clyde Drexler, playing his 600th game for Portland, scored 17. The Trail Blazers won for the 41st time in 50 games and 11th in a row at home. Karl Malone, who scored 22 points in the first half, finished with 30 for the Jazz, and Thurl Bailey keyed a fourth-quarter rally by scoring 11 of his 19 points. Portland led by 97-84 after three quarters, but Bailey scored the first 9 points of the fourth quarter for the Jazz, and his 3-point play with 9 minutes 15 seconds left cut Portland's lead to 99-93. Malone's 5-footer closed the gap to 4 with 8:53 remaining. Portland responded with a 13-3 run. (AP) Bucks 106, Hornets 103: Milwaukee overcame a 5-point deficit with 1:20 left in regulation and Alvin Robertson scored 24 points to lead Milwaukee at Charlotte, N.C. Fred Roberts's 15-foot shot with three seconds left in regulation tied the score at 99-99 and forced the overtime. (AP) Mavericks 121, Bullets 96: Rolando Blackman scored 18 of his 28 points in the first half to lead Dallas at home. The Mavericks, averaging 91.3 points in their previous six games, had seven players in double figures. (AP) TENNIS

title: Union Carbide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Earnings in the fourth quarter of 1990 reflected a non-recurring after-tax charge of $ 86 million from the anticipated sale of a 50-percent interest in Union Carbide's UCAR Carbon subsidiary. This charge was partially offset by after-tax gains aggregating $ 41 million, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the corporation's interests in KEMET Electronics Corp. and Lincare Inc.Earnings in 1989 included a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $ 56 million mainly representing facility shutdown costs and severance and relocation benefits associated with restructuring the Linde U.S.A. business of the corporation's industrial gas subsidiary.Results for the first 3 quarters of 1990 and for the year 1989 have been restated under the equity method of accounting to reflect the sale of a 50-percent interest in UCAR Carbon and the intention to restructure the U.S. retail packaged gas business, both of which are expected to be completed during 1991.

title: Hubert M. Blalock Jr., Sociologist, 64
description: Hubert M. Blalock Jr., a sociologist at the University of Washington who was internationally known for his work on statistical research methods, died of cancer on Feb. 8 at a nursing center in Bellevue, Wash. He was 64 years old.

description: b-Included pretax provision of $ 75 million to cover probable future losses on bonds held in the company's investment portfolios.c-Included pretax gain of $ 403.5 million from sale of the company's general casualty subsidiary and pretax losses on investments of $ 177.7 million.d-Net income

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Baghdad's Position; Iraq Deals for First Time With U.N.'s Pullout Call
description: The proposal presented today by Iraq marks the first time that Baghdad has mentioned a "readiness to deal" with Security Council Resolution 660 of Aug. 3, which condemned the invasion of Kuwait and demanded the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Regrettably, the Iraqi statement now appears to be a cruel hoax, dashing the hopes of the people in Iraq, and indeed around the world." -- President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: Bridge
description: Saving against a grand slam, and deciding what to do when the opponents take that bold step, is a complex subject. What is the vulnerability? What is the caliber of the opponents? And what sort of scoring is in use? Those are some of the questions to be asked.

title: Robotic Vision reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
North Coast Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Feinstein Running for Senator
description: Dianne Feinstein, who narrowly lost the race for governor to Pete Wilson three months ago, on Thursday formally started her campaign for the 1992 Democratic nomination for the Senate seat being vacated by Alan Cranston. The 57-year-old former Mayor of San Francisco filed papers with the Federal Election Commission to establish a campaign committee, allowing her to start raising money for the June 1992 primary. Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former governor, has also announced his candidacy for the nomination.

title: Dixie Yarns Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from the repurchase of $ 3 million face value of the company's convertible subordinated debentures of $ 699,000 for both the quarter and year.Income from continuing operations of $ 1,458,000, or 8 cents a share, and $ 6,830,000, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively, included a loss of $ 1,143,000 after taxes for the quarter and 12 cents a share, for the year, resulting from plant shutdown charges.

title: Dollar Rises on Iraq's Offer And U.S. Economic Reports
description: The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday after Iraq's conditional offer to withdraw from Kuwait and a Government report that raised concerns about inflation.

title: Switch for Jets Coach
description: The Jets yesterday moved Foge Fazio to linebackers coach after a year as special-teams coordinator. Al Roberts, who had been the coach of the Eagles' special teams for three years, takes over Fazio's old post.

title: Dallas' Ex-Chief Is Acquitted
description: Former Police Chief Mack Vines was acquitted today of lying to a panel that was reviewing his department's investigation of a fatal shooting by an officer. He had been dismissed as chief after being charged with perjury last fall.

title: Olympics; Daly Eager for Challenge as New Olympic Coach
description: Charles Joseph Daly, 1992 United States Olympic basketball coach.

title: Cryomedical Sciences Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Craftmade International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
John A. McCone, Head of C.I.A. In Cuban Missile Crisis, Dies at 89
description: John A. McCone, a West Coast businessman who became chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and later the Director of Central Intelligence, died Thursday at his home in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 89 years old.

title: Reviews/Music; June Anderson in 'La Sonnambula'
description: Eve Queler brought her Opera Orchestra of New York back to Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, this time with a concert version of Bellini's "Sonnambula." It was all that we have come to expect, fear and, in the end, look forward to.

title: Court Removes Town Justice Tied to Assault
description: A town justice who was said to have assaulted a woman in his pickup truck has been removed from the bench by the state's highest court.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Morehouse College is to give achievement awards to seven black men, including three Morehouse alumni, at a dinner tonight in Atlanta.

title: Napco Security Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday referred incorrectly to the New York advertising agency of Ammirati & Puris. It is an independent agency.

title: Reacting to Crash, F.A.A. Limits Takeoffs From Middle of Runway
description: In an attempt to prevent runway collisions like the recent one in Los Angeles that killed 34 people, the Federal Aviation Administration has issued a rule limiting takeoffs from the middle of long runways.

title: Review/Film; In a Dungeon for Speeders, Somewhere in New Jersey
description: Dan Aykroyd wrote the screenplay for, co-stars in and makes his debut as a movie director with "Nothing but Trouble," a charmless feature-length joke about the world's most elaborate speed trap.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Saudi Base Is Springboard for B-52's
description: Half of the American B-52 bombing raids over Kuwait and southern Iraq are being flown from an airfield in western Saudi Arabia, a senior United States military official said today.

title: Iraq's Ploy: End Game or Dead End?
description: The announcement yesterday of Iraq's willingness to withdraw from Kuwait coupled with conditions yet to be sorted out is a classic case of good news, bad news.

title: Penn Takes Precautions on Measles
description: An outbreak of measles on the Penn wrestling team led the university and rival schools to take precautions for five weekend events in three sports.

title: Dell Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Nissan Announces Export Cutbacks
description: Nissan has announced sharp cutbacks in exports in the face of slumping demand for cars in the United States. Nissan's president, Yutaka Kume, said on Thursday that United States-bound exports would be scaled back in March by about 5,000 units although production levels at American plants would remain unchanged. "Auto demand in the U.S. is in a very severe situation," he said.

title: Review/Music; A Kronos Retrospective Of the Schnittke Quartets
description: The Kronos Quartet is sometimes carped at for its supposed limitations, although its generally soft-edged approach seems as much an interpretive predilection as a technical failing. But no one can complain about the services it provides the cities in which it regularly appears, introducing eager audiences to a wonderfully wide range of contemporary music, stretching sensibilities and providing unexpected pleasures in the process.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday about Amax Inc. misstated the closing price of the company's stock on Thursday. It was $25.25 a share, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: LaFontaine Seeks Trade
description: Pat LaFontaine, who has been the cornerstone and the most valauble player for the Islanders in recent years, has run out of patience in his contract negotiations and has asked to be traded.

title: Geraghty & Miller reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plea From Pentagon: No Parcels to Troops
description: The Defense Department today renewed its request that Americans not send parcels to troops serving in the Persian Gulf.

title: Turkey Must Recognize Rights of Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Rebukes Israeli Envoy
description: In an unusually blunt statement, the White House criticized the Israeli Ambassador today for making public complaints about United States economic aid that it characterized as "outrageous and outside the bounds of acceptable behavior by the ambassador of any friendly country."

title: Felix Gilbert, Influential Author, Historian and Teacher, Dies at 85
description: Felix Gilbert, a noted historian, educator and author who wrote on Renaissance Italy, 18th-century North America and Europe of the last century, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: McEnroe Puts an End To Cutting Corners
description: More irascible than he ought to be and less invincible than he wants to be, John McEnroe has begun a new attack on the mind-body dichotomy that for the last few years has left him scratching his head at midcourt like a stymied philosopher.

title: CUNY's High School Plan Looks Backward
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba and Yemen Introduce 3 Peace Resolutions at U.N.
description: The United Nations Security Council continued its debate on the Persian Gulf war behind closed doors today, with diplomats reporting that countries were sticking to long-held positions.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; U.S. Forces View Move By Iraq With Skepticism
description: For many American troops in Saudi Arabia, it was a day of sweeping emotions. Some were jubilant at the thought that Iraq might be willing to end the war by withdrawing from Kuwait; others were despondent that loved ones back home might pin their hopes on an Iraqi statement that seemed weighted with conditions.

title: If Iraq Really Wants Peace
description: Is Iraq's sudden offer to withdraw from Kuwait a desperate grab for peace, or is it, in President Bush's words, a "cruel hoax," a ploy to throw the impending ground war off schedule? In the end, it doesn't make any difference. If Saddam Hussein is finally serious about wanting to end the Persian Gulf war, he knows how to say so clearly -- starting tomorrow when the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, goes to Moscow.

title: No Time to Release Hijack Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Stop Whalers with a Flawless Outing
description: The only mistake of real consequence the Rangers made last night at Madison Square Garden occurred before the game, when the team decided to play Kelly Kisio, who was bothered by a groin injury.

title: Poco Petroleums reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Women Advised To Wear Coats In Penn Station
description: The Long Island Rail Road suggested yesterday that female passengers wear their overcoats while in Pennsylvania Station to ward off attacks by the mysterious assailant or assailants who have been jabbing women in the buttocks or back over the last two months.

title: New York Gets A+ From Credit Agency
description: A Wall Street credit rating agency yesterday gave an A+ rating to New York State's plan to borrow $900 million to begin closing a multi-billion dollar "accumulated deficit" built up over the years.

title: NEW DATA SUGGEST NATION'S RECESSION COULD BE SLOWING
description: In a report hinting that the economy's decline may be bottoming out, the Government said today that industrial output fell much less in January than in the two months before.

title: A Focus on 'The Light Of Truth'
description: The tumult at Syracuse University concerning the basketball team is not a scandal at all in the purest sense. If the allegations prove true, can old hat be scandalous? Can routine be scandalous? Can the giving of gifts that include lucre, greenbacks and loose change from boosters, alumni and other concerned citizens to tall, hefty or sharp-shooting personages be scandalous? Can the taking be scandalous? In this case, the answers are: No, no, no and no.

title: Dr. Kenneth Bird, 73; Used TV for Diagnosis
description: Dr. Kenneth D. Bird, an internist and pulmonary specialist who developed a method of examining patients by two-way, interactive television, died Wednesday at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Why Ban Alcohol Ads on the Cable Car?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Baldwin Follinsbee, Volunteer, 100
description: Ruth Baldwin Folinsbee, a community leader and former government official in New Hope, Pa., died Wednesday at her home in New Hope. She was 100 years old and died in her sleep, said her daughter, Elizabeth Wiggins of New Hope.

title: WAR IN THE GULF:' Pentagon; U.S. Insists Withdrawal Comes Before Cease-Fire
description: American military officials today suggested that Iraq's army in Kuwait could escape further attack by declaring an unconditional withdrawal and then beginning to retreat, but they hesitated to make a firm offer along those lines.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a student's expulsion from Brown University misidentified the campus daily newspaper in some copies. It is The Brown Daily Herald.

title: In Capitol, Debate on Parents in Gulf
description: Facing growing Congressional pressure not to leave children without a parent when their fathers or mothers are ordered to serve in the war against Iraq, the Defense Department said today that 16,300 single parents and 1,200 military couples with children were now on duty in the Persian Gulf.

title: Typewriter in Bombings Is Tied to 16 Death Threats
description: At least 16 Federal judges received assassination threats in letters prepared with the same typewriter used to label package bombs that killed a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer last winter, Government prosecutors said today.

description: In Tourneau's cluttered Madison Avenue repair shop, the two men wore pristinely white jackets and serious, serious expressions.

title: Sony Is Near Macintosh Pact
description: The Sony Corporation will manufacture significant portions of a new Macintosh laptop computer being developed by Apple Computer Inc., Sony executives said. The officials said the two companies had not reached a final agreement on the exact extent of Sony's involvement in the computer.

title: Grammys: Not a One-Night Stand
description: This is Grammy Week in New York, and although the 33d annual Grammy Awards ceremony doesn't take place until Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall, festivities ranging from a charity benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria to free concerts in the subway stations have been under way since last Tuesday.

title: Measles and Faith Combine In 5 Deaths in Philadelphia
description: Five children have died in a measles outbreak here in the last 10 days, all of them from families that belong to two fundamentalist churches that preach a reliance on prayer, not medical care, to cure disease.

title: Cut Costs or Be Sued, Bridgeport Is Told
description: The state board appointed to oversee Bridgeport's finances has voted to sue the city if it does not carry out cost-cutting measures ordered by the board.

title: Swissair Worktime Cut
description: Swissair, faced with a drop in bookings because of the Persian Gulf war, said this week that its employees would be put on reduced working hours next month in a cost-cutting move. The action, which is the first such move in the Swiss flag carrier's 60-year history, will affect about 20,000 employees starting in mid-March.

title: Viejo Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Police: Clear Vision, Fuzzy Plans
description: The woman keeps the business card posted by the phone. She got it from a police officer, who came by one day to explain that he had been assigned to her neighborhood. She has called him in emergencies, like the time her son was mugged for his jacket. But she calls more often for other reasons: to express fear about menacing people camping out in the empty lot down the street, to ask what to do about old Mrs. Jones, who wanders out late at night without her coat.

title: Olympia & York
description: The Canadian developer Olympia & York sold a 10 percent stake in the British liquor and food company Allied-Lyons P.L.C., three investment firms said. The firms bought 80.9 million shares from Olympia & York-related companies for an undisclosed price and sold them to British institutional investors for $:402 million, or $792 million. The brokerages were Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Ltd., Cazenove & Company and Lehman Brothers. Olympia & York obtained the stock by converting its holding of Allied-Lyons convertible preference shares.

title: Buying a Personal Computer: The Choices Can Be Daunting
description: Most people who bought a personal computer in ancient days -- say, the mid-1980's -- went to a store and picked out a complete system from a very limited selection.

title: Comptronix Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
General Motors of Canada Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: General Motors of Canada is a unit of the General Motors Corp.Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Symbol Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BankAmerica Unit
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it would restructure its Pacific Northwest savings subsidiary into separate state banking operations, a move the company said would give customers better service. The subsidiary, Bank of America, Federal Savings Bank, began operations in September when BankAmerica bought the Benjamin Franklin Savings and Loan. Based in Portland, Ore., it has 88 branches in four Western states: Idaho, Utah, Oregon and Washington.

title: K-Swiss Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Music; Brandenburg Ensemble's Bach and Vivaldi
description: Alexander Schneider's Brandenburg Ensemble concerts are like time capsules from the 1950's, when a rich, fat string sound was considered ideal for Baroque music, and when that era's keyboard concertos were more typically played on the piano than on the harpsichord. Today, opposing views on string weight, timbre, phrasing and instrumentation prevail, but Mr. Schneider continues to teach the former fashion to his young musicians. On Sunday afternoon, he led them, along with the pianists Peter Serkin and Andras Schiff, in works by Vivaldi and Bach.

title: Herbert L. Deane, 69, Ex-Columbia Official
description: Herbert L. Deane, a professor emeritus of political philosophy and a former vice provost at Columbia University, died on Thursday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Francis Heyden, 83, Priest and Authority On Eclipses of Sun
description: The Rev. Francis Joseph Heyden, a Jesuit priest and astronomer who was an authority on solar eclipses, died Feb. 8 at Cardinal Santos Memorial Hospital in Manila. He was 83 years old and lived in Manila.

title: Catholic School Where Buddha Is Welcome
description: At one end of the classroom is an imposing crucifix in dark wood. At the other is the goggle-eyed head of a Chinese dragon in red, green, orange and yellow. In between are 32 fourth graders who each day draw on both traditional symbols -- the cross and the dragon -- to help shape their identity and that of one of the most unusual institutions in New York's sprawling Roman Catholic parochial school system.

title: Fletcher Leisure reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included an unusual pre-tax charge of $ 557,000 related to a discontinued business.c-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 175,438, or 4 cents a share.The company said it has obtained regulatory approval to change its year-end to Dec. 31.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Alexander Kosloff, Lawyer, 88
description: Alexander Kosloff, a lawyer in Manhattan who specialized in regulations and insurance for the taxicab industry, died on Thursday at his home in Hollywood Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old and formerly lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Snow and Ice Tie Up New Jersey Highways
description: A snowstorm caused numerous traffic accidents and tie-ups last night in the Newark and Union areas, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: Central Park Zoo Isn't for Everybody
description: To the Editor:

title: A's Hire Jackson
description: Reggie Jackson is going to be a busy man this season. A week after the 44-year-old former slugger was hired as a cable television commentator for Oakland A's broadcasts, the team announced on Thursday that he would also serve as a part-time coach. Although Jackson, who spent 10 of his 21 major league seasons with the A's, was known primarily as a power hitter (563 career home runs), he will not be used simply as a batting instructor, but will have general coaching duties, the club said. (AP)

title: Joseph A. Guarino, Lawyer, 44
description: Joseph A. Guarino, a lawyer who had been a member of the Town Board in North Hempstead, L.I., since 1981, died on Wednesday at his home in Port Washington. He was 44 years old.

title: Wellman Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said sales in the latest periods resulted primarily from increased sales in the man-made fibres division, reflecting, for the most part, the contribution of Fiber Industries Inc., which was acquired on Nov. 1, 1989, and which more than doubled Wellman's sales on an annualized basis.

description: b-Net loss

title: G.M. Sets Meeting
description: The General Motors Corporation will hold its annual meeting this year in Nashville, instead of Detroit, for the first time in 27 years. G.M. said on Thursday that the meeting would take place May 24 at the Opryland convention center, about 50 miles northeast of G.M.'s Saturn Corporation assembly plant in Spring Hill, Tenn. It will be the first annual meeting run by Robert Stempel, who became chairman on Aug. 1 after the retirement of Roger B. Smith. The last time G.M. held an annual meeting outside Detroit was in 1964 in Wilmington, Del.

title: Vacationers Sticking Closer to Home
description: Travel agents and tour companies are forecasting sharp increases in vacation and leisure travel within the United States and to Canada this spring and summer as Americans cut back on bookings to Europe and other destinations they would normally reach by air. In many cases, they will substitute trips by car, bus, train and ship for airplane travel.

title: U.S. Charges Memphis Discriminates in Elections
description: The Justice Department filed suit against the City of Memphis today, charging that its system for electing the City Council and the school board discriminated against blacks.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; CBS Says Crew That Disappeared Is Believed to Be Held in Baghdad
description: The four members of a CBS News crew who disappeared in the Saudi Arabian desert near the Kuwaiti border over three weeks ago are believed to be held in Baghdad, a spokesman for CBS said yesterday.

title: Avcorp Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: For First Time, All 9 Unions And News Meet
description: Senior executives of The Daily News and its corporate parent met yesterday for the first time in one room with all the leaders of the newspaper's nine striking unions, beginning a round of talks that will most likely determine the paper's fate.

description: Most of America's European allies and Canada reacted with doubt and skepticism today to Iraq's conditional offer on Kuwait.

title: Telematics International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the loss for full year 1990 was due primarily to a $ 3,758,000 charge associated with the write-off of several software development projects whose future revenue potential was reassessed, a $ 1,233,000 charge related to the Globenet Inc. settlement, $ 426,000 of severance costs associated with the fourth quarter reduction of the company's work force, and various other charges totaling about $ 1,000,000.The 1989 loss included a $ 3,518,000 unusual charge related to the write-off of the company's investment in Globenet and a $ 1,504,000 loss from equity investments. The 1989 results were partially offset by a $ 1,462,000 income tax benefit related to the realization of net operating loss carrybacks.

title: Court to Review a Bar on Statements From Victims' Families
description: The Supreme Court announced today that it would consider whether to overrule two decisions that barred prosecutors in death penalty cases from introducing evidence about the character of the murder victim or the effect of the murder on the victim's family.

title: Monarch Machine Tool Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax charge of $ 3.8 million for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.c-Net income

title: Morgan Wins Judgment
description: It was a humiliating experience for Joe Morgan when the former Cincinnati Reds second baseman was singled out as a possible drug courier and roughed up at Los Angeles International Airport in March 1988, but a Federal jury has taken a giant step toward salving his bruised feelings.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Amman: Offer Welcomed; Bush Criticized
description: Jordan, Iraq's only sympathetic neighbor, today welcomed Iraq's conditional offer on Kuwait as a "courageous" breakthrough that would make peace possible, and it criticized President Bush for being too hasty in his rejection.

title: Inmac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Gooden's Agent Not Optimistic About Talks
description: Dwight Gooden's agent said today that the Mets had informed him that the organization was not prepared to use Roger Clemens's recent blockbuster contract as a guideline for its contract-extension negotiations with Gooden. The agent said the team's stance had left him less than optimistic that a deal could be worked out before the opening of spring training next week.

title: Not Aided by Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Mutation That Causes Alzheimer's Is Found
description: In a leap forward in the search for a cause of Alzheimer's disease, researchers have discovered that a pinpoint mutation in a single gene can cause this progressive neurological illness.

title: Nature's Sunshine Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rejected by Yankees, Randolph Might Retire
description: Still without a job and now without an offer to return to the Yankees, Willie Randolph said yesterday that he would consider retiring if he did not receive a proposal from another team soon.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; MOSCOW WELCOMES BAGHDAD'S OFFER
description: The Soviet Government, pursuing its own diplomatic peace initiative in Iraq, greeted Baghdad's conditional offer today to withdraw from Kuwait initially with "satisfaction and hope."

title: Sante Uberto Barbieri, United Methodist Bishop, 90
description: Sante Uberto Barbieri, a bishop of the United Methodist Church who was an early president of the World Council of Churches, died on Wednesday in Buenos Aires, where he lived. He was 90 years old.

Pageamerica Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Golan Heights misidentified the anniversary marked by Druse villagers there on Thursday. It was the ninth anniversary of the extension of Israeli law to the Golan Heights.

title: Guidepost; Fireworks and Soy Sauce
description: With the celebrations of the Chinese New Year that began yesterday, thoughts turn to Chinese food. And in Chinese cooking, soy sauce is the indispensable seasoning. Several kinds are sold in supermarkets and specialty food shops, and the best of the Chinese types come from China and Hong Kong. Most domestic supermarket brands of Chinese soy sauce are not brewed but are concocted from soy protein, caramel color and corn syrup. Good Japanese-type sauces, both regular and reduced-sodium, are made domestically, and can be substituted for the Chinese types. Tamari, a Japanese soy sauce, is supposed to be made by traditional methods, but most brands of tamari sold in health-food stores are not the authentic aged kind. Type Description Chinese light or superior soy Relatively thin, very salty Chinese dark or black soy Thicker, darker and a bit sweeter and less salty than light soy. Chinese mushroom soy Dark, slightly sweet, with mushroom flavor added. Japanese soy Similar to Chinese light soy but a trifle less salty. Reduced-sodium soy or "light" soy Japanese soy sauce made with less salt; not to be confused with Chinese light soy. Tamari Traditional Japanese soy sauce made without wheat.

title: Unigesco reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,600,000 which represented Unigesco's share of losses from discontinued operations at its Provigo Inc. subsidiary.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 16,000,000 and $ 20,800,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said the increase in nine-month sales is mainly due to the inclusion in the latest period of 9 months of revenue from the Sodisco Group, while the year-earlier 9 months included just 8 months of revenues from Sodisco.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Yao Opare Dinizulu, Troupe Founder, 60
description: Nana Yao Opare Dinizulu, founder of the troupe called Dinizulu and His African Dancers, Drummers and Singers, died on Sunday in Camden, N.J., after collapsing at Camden High School before a concert. He was 60 years old and lived in Queens.
