description: b-Net income

title: No Victory, No Pierce and No Harmony
description: The Knicks continue to make bad moves on the court and no moves off it.

title: MNC Bonus Returns Set
description: Senior officers of the financially troubled MNC Financial Inc. were forced to return about $1.5 million in bonuses they received without the required approval of Federal banking regulators, The Washington Post reported today.

title: American Management Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of $ 883,000 from sale of business.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about an outbreak of cholera in Peru misidentified the microbe that causes the disease. It is a bacterium, not a virus.

title: Gas Savers That Belie Their Name
description: When the price of gasoline increases, as it did in the weeks before the Persian Gulf war, motorists often look for ways to reduce their fuel consumption. Not surprisingly, companies that sell bogus gas-saving devices try to take advantage of that situation.

title: Justice Dept. Places a Prosecutor on Leave
description: An assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan has been placed on leave by the Justice Department, and his boss, Otto G. Obermaier, said it was apparently in connection with accusations the assistant made against him.

title: 3,000 at Chrysler Face White-Collar Job Loss
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today in a company newspaper that it might have to eliminate 3,000, or about 11 percent, of the auto maker's 27,000 white-collar workers.

title: Peoples Jewellers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Optical Imaging Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; Wilsonian Vision Of Ibsen
description: Ibsen's final play, "When We Dead Awaken," is one of his most adventurous and intensely personal works. As the author intended, it is a "dramatic epilogue" to his naturalism and a return to the poetic symbolism of earlier plays like "Peer Gynt" and "Brand." In it, an artist, a surrogate for Ibsen, suffers "remorse for a forfeited life."

title: Leisure Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Producer Prices Fell 0.1% in January
description: Prices at the wholesale level edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department reported today, as a big drop in energy costs helped provide a bright spot for an economy troubled by war and recession.

title: Taipei Journal; A Mainland Generation Now Being Ushered Out
description: When Wu Yen-huan fled to Taiwan in 1949, he thought it would be for only a brief stay. Soon, he thought, the Communist Government would collapse and he and other Nationalist Chinese leaders would be able to recover the mainland -- and his children.

title: Pro Basketball; Coleman Scores 42 As Nets Roll
description: Anybody wandering in at halftime of the Nets' game against Denver at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight might have looked at the scoreboard and thought they had missed the first game of a doubleheader, but they would've been wrong.

title: I.O.C. Visiting South Africa
description: The International Olympic Committee today sent its first envoy to South Africa since the early 1970's.

title: Tell Iraq Exactly What Surrender Means
description: Baghdad's offer yesterday to withdraw from Kuwait on its own terms, and the scramble in Washington and Riyadh to figure out an appropriate response, highlight a gaping hole in the coalition's strategy: The U.N. Security Council resolutions that authorized the war were not designed to end it, and they are insufficient for that purpose.

title: The War In Arab Eyes
description: Iraq is taking a terrific pounding from the air and has yet to do serious military damage to any adversary other than Kuwait. On the important propaganda front, however, Saddam Hussein is proving a tough opponent who's scoring points just where it's most important for him to make them.

title: Photo Control Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Your Money; I.R.S. Eases Rule On Outplacement
description: For people caught in the wave of layoffs sweeping the nation's businesses, there is one bit of encouraging tax news. The Internal Revenue Service, which ruled in December 1988 that the value of outplacement services should be treated as taxable income to recipients, withdrew that ruling late last year and said it would study whether employer-provided outplacement services could be treated as an excludable fringe benefit.

title: Inside
description: South African Accord

title: Governor Urges New Water Cuts By Californians
description: In his first, rather cautious response to the drought gripping California, the state's new Governor today called on all communities to cut their water use by half, created a "water bank" to transfer water to the neediest areas and asked the Legislature to establish a $100 million drought fund.

title: Review/Dance; Some Choreographers Take to the Ice Rink
description: Many skaters passionately maintain that skating can be a serious art as well as a charming entertainment. The validity of their contention was demonstrated on Wednesday night in "Dancing on Thin Ice," a program at the Rink of Rockefeller Center that featured the Ice Theater of New York.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Americans; Many Express Skepticism, But Others See Opportunity
description: Many Americans reacted skeptically yesterday to Iraq's conditional offer to discuss a withdrawal from Kuwait, but there were some calls for Washington to follow up on any chance that would lead to peace.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANK A. BENNACK JR. is the new chairman of the Museum of Broadcasting in Manhattan, succeeding the late William S. Paley, the museum's founder and chairman. Mr. Bennack, 57 years old, is the president and chief executive of the Hearst Corporation and has been a museum trustee since 1987. Under his leadership, Hearst has acquired television stations and is a partner in three cable networks.

title: Moore Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Caps Big Week With a Gain of 57.42
description: Capping a week of heavy buying and several new highs, the stock market advanced sharply yesterday in the wake of Iraq's surprise offer to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQIS SPEAK OF A WITHDRAWAL BUT IMPOSE LIST OF CONDITIONS; BUSH DENOUNCES 'CRUEL HOAX'
description: Iraq said for the first time today that it was prepared to discuss compliance with a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait if numerous conditions of its own were met. But President Bush rejected the offer as a "cruel hoax" and urged Iraq's military leaders and civilian population to "take matters into their own hands" and force Saddam Hussein from power.

title: Careercom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Problem That's Growing
description: Measles has become a serious problem nationwide in the last few years. In 1983, the disease was almost eradicated, with fewer than 1,500 cases reported. But last year, after years of Federal budget cuts affecting immunization programs, there were about 30,000 cases and nearly 100 deaths from the highly contagious but preventable disease.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KIRK DOUGLAS is expected to be released this weekend from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he is recovering from injuries suffered in a plane crash. He and NOEL BLANC , the voice of Bugs Bunny and other cartoon characters, were injured Wednesday when the helicopter they were in was struck by a stunt plane as the helicopter was taking off from Santa Paula, Calif., northwest of Los Angeles. The two men in the plane were killed. They were Lee Manelski, a T.W.A. pilot, and an 18-year-old student pilot whose name was not immediately released.

title: Kuhlman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 570,000 for the quarter and income of $ 3,625,000, or 64 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.c-After losses from disconinued operations of $ 1,096,000 for the quarter and $ 2,103,000 for the year.

title: In South Africa, Key Accord on Fighters
description: The African National Congress has agreed to stop infiltrating or training guerrillas inside South Africa and will not threaten violence in return for the Government's recognition of the nationalist group's right to engage in protest that does not involve intimidation or violence, according to an agreement made public tonight.

title: Sugar Creek Oil reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included write-down of $ 1,178,000 on the book value of four gas plants.c-Net income and share earnings are nil.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Black Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gerald J. Lustig, 70, Retired Surgeon, Dies
description: Dr. Gerald J. Lustig, the former director of cardiothoracic surgery at Staten Island University Hospital, died there Monday. He was 70 years old and lived in Todt Hill, S.I.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Anti-Iraq Nations Firmly Reject Offer, Calling It 'Insincere' and an 'Obstacle'
description: Iraq's conditional offer on Kuwait was firmly rejected today by Saudi Arabia and other Arab gulf countries, as well as by Egypt and Syria, which are at war with Iraq.

title: Citibank Joins Teller Network
description: Citibank, which for years refused to allow other banks' customers to use its automated teller machines in the New York area, announced yesterday that it would join the Cirrus network. On Cirrus, 7,200 banks and financial institutions in the United States and overseas share access to their machines.

title: Review/Rock; Fooling With Formulas And Emphasizing Noise
description: Given that it consists of a handful of repetitive and boneheaded chords, some simple rhythms and incompetent singing, it's amazing how often rock can come up with new sounds. A show by Teen-Age Fan Club and Super Chunk at CBGB's on Saturday night didn't offer one new harmony or new rhythm, but the bands sounded new and different; they did it by fiddling with rock's formulas, within its narrow bounds.

title: War Summary
description: A WAY OUT OR A CRUEL HOAX? Iraq issued a statement that, for the first time, envisioned a withdrawal from Kuwait. But it came so freighted with ifs and buts that the United States and its principal allies rejected it out of hand. While the statement was cautiously greeted in some quarters as a possible opening for diplomats, President Bush termed it a "cruel hoax" and called for the ouster of President Saddam Hussein. WAR AS USUAL, AND YET . . .

title: 'Twin Peaks' Canceled As a Saturday Regular
description: "Twin Peaks," the ABC show created by David Lynch and Mark Frost that was one of the most talked-about series of 1990, and "Under Cover," a new series created by William Broyles Jr. about a married couple who are spies, will go on hiatus after tonight's episodes, said Robert A. Iger, president of ABC Entertainment.

title: George L. Childs Sr., Banker, 93
description: George L. Childs Sr., an executive with Citibank for 42 years, died on Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 93 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Health Management Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Losses at Pepsico Venture in India
description: Business rivalries and delays in commissioning plants have cost the Indian subsidiary of Pepsico Inc. millions of dollars, according to Ramesh Vangal, managing director of Pepsi Foods, the joint venture between Pepsico and its Indian partners: the Punjab Agro Industries Corporation and Tata Group. The losses have affected Pepsi's commitment to the Indian Government to export at least half of its sales, he said.

title: Dynamite Blast in Thailand Leaves 122 Onlookers Dead
description: More than 122 people died and 99 were injured when a trailer-truck carrying dynamite to a stone quarry overturned and exploded an hour after a crowd gathered to look at the accident, the police said today.

title: Index Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax restructuring charge in excess of $ 350,000 for the quarter and year.c-Net income

title: Coping/With Electronic Clutter at Home
description: The fun and convenience of home electronics can be offset by the consequent clutter: a welter of remote controls, a thicket of cables and teetering stacks of hi-fi equipment. Luckily, and hardly by coincidence, there are plenty of accessory gadgets to keep the other gadgets organized.

title: Bowman's Revised Show Goes On
description: The image he worked so hard to perfect was Bowman the Showman: flashy, funny, a little outrageous, but always entertaining. Once in a while, he got carried away, but that was also part of Christopher Bowman's charm.

title: Victoria Creations reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1989 results included a restructuring provision of $ 2.55 million.

title: Patents; Genetic Material By Nobel Laureate
description: Dr. Thomas R. Cech, a co-recipient of the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1989 for his work with genetics, has won patent approval for what he calls "ribozymes," an unusual form of genetic material that could someday be used to deactivate deadly viruses.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Strategy; U.S. Officials Link Iraqi Offer To Mounting Losses in the Field
description: Iraq's proposal to discuss withdrawal coincides with a marked deterioration in Baghdad's military position this week and continuing American preparations for a ground war, according to American military officials in Saudi Arabia and at the Pentagon.

title: Unplugging From the Office
description: A recently retired man ran into a friend on Madison Avenue the other day, and the friend was surprised to find him tense and irritable. "Are you keeping busy?" the friend asked. "Busy?" the man said. "I'm frantic."

title: Books of The Times; How to Bait the Censor And Defeat the Purpose
description: New World Avenue and Vicinity By Tadeusz Konwicki Translated by Walter Arndt. Drawings by the author. 212 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $24.95.

title: Reliance Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax provision of $ 75 million to cover probably future losses on bonds held in the company's investment portfolios.c-Included pretax gain of $ 403.5 million from sale of the company's general casualty subsidiary and pretax losses on investments of $ 177.7 million.d-Net income and included $ 66.1 million gain from sale of investment.

title: Editorial Notebook; Creating Illiteracy in New York
description: Illiteracy already threatens to turn much of New York City's population into refugees, wandering jobless through the information age. Mayor David Dinkins's administration now plans to cut about $7.5 million from the New York Public Library and a few million each from the Queens and Brooklyn systems. That's small change in the world of high finance, but for the libraries it could mean death.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holdiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No street cleaning, pickup or recycling. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on Saturday schedule. L.I.R.R. on holiday scheudle. Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit bus and rail service on Saturday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state, municipal closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North New Haven line on weekend schedule.

title: Trenton Challenging Census Counts in Court
description: The state took action today to challenge New Jersey's census count and possibly delay the redrawing of the state's 40 legislative districts.

title: Corrections
description: The Sounds Around Town column in Weekend yesterday misstated the location for a concert tomorrow by the pianist and singer Ronny Whyte. He will appear at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, not at St. Peter's Church.

title: Jamaica Kincaid to Read
description: Jamaica Kincaid, whose most recent novel, "Lucy," chronicles a young girl's childhood in the Caribbean and her life in America, will read from her works on Feb. 26 at 1:30 P.M. at Sarah Lawrence College, Reisinger Concert Hall, Glen Washington Road, Bronxville, N.Y. Ms. Kincaid is also the author of "Annie John" and "At the Bottom of the River," a collection of stories. The reading is part of a free series offered every two weeks at the college. Information: (914) 395-2412.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: McGwire, Cone in Accord and Avoid Arbitration
description: Mark McGwire helped the Oakland Athletics attain a new baseball plateau yesterday when he accepted a $2.85 million salary for the 1991 season. The salary, agreed to just as their arbitration hearing was supposed to begin, sent the Athletics' payroll soaring past the $35 million mark.

title: Belmac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it went public in February 1988 and has been almost exclusively involved with research and development since that time, resulting in minimal sales.

title: Bronx Doctor Has Best Seller, Hit Movie and No Job
description: In a span of several hours the other day, Dr. Oliver Sacks prepared for a European lecture tour, learned that his 18-year-old book had cracked the best-seller lists, mulled over his remarks for a medical conference, saw a half-dozen patients, and ran a modest gantlet of fans sputtering good wishes.

title: Protesters March in Bhopal
description: Survivors of the deadly 1984 gas leak in Bhopal marched through the city on Thursday to protest the $470 million settlement between the Union Carbide Corporation and the Indian Government.

title: Berry Petroleum Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridging a Gap for Blind PC Users
description: Last month, 24 people at I.B.M. received an updated prototype of a computer program that could help them and thousands of others keep up with one of the most fundamental and popular changes in how computers display information and how people interact with them.

title: Thermal Profiles reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Barrister Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Restated to include a loss of $ 318,000 on the subleasing of excess office space.

title: U S West Fined $10 Million For Violating Phone Accord
description: In the largest antitrust fine ever levied by the Justice Department, one of the companies created by the breakup of A.T.&T. has agreed to pay $10 million for several violations, one of which was termed unfair competition against A.T.&T.

title: Patents; New Twist On the Game Of Chess
description: Chess fanciers have frequently experimented with some exotic variations on the traditional board, from three-dimensional designs to triangular and circular ones. Curtis Hoerbelt has patented a new form of chess that uses a flat board with 28 rows arranged in the shape of a vortex. Half of the rows have five black squares, the other half, five white squares, and each row spirals out from a central circle. It looks like a two-dimensional tornado or whirlpool viewed from the top.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., has offered to buy shares from stockholders who as of Feb. 6 owned fewer than 100 common shares. The offer will expire on March 21. * Entergy Corp., New Orleans, an electric service company, said its board had authorized spending an additional $50 million to buy back the company's common shares through March 22. This supplements a $150 million stock buyback that was authorized in October. * Inspiration Resources Corp., New York, said it would get out of the coal business and suspend payment of its quarterly dividend of 3 cents a share. The company said it would focus on its agribusiness and base metal operations. * C. A. Short International Inc., Dublin, Ohio, said it was discussing the acquisition of a private company in exchange for stock. C. A. Short described the target as a company that provides consumer products to the retail trade but declined to disclose its name.

title: R.P. Scherer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 618,000, or 30 cents a share.

title: Ford Motor Credit Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Ford Motor Credit is a wholly subsidiary of Ford Motor Co.

title: Executive Telecard reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 49,774 of other income for the quarter and $ 1,192,886 for the 9 months.c-Included $ 112,081 of other income for the quarter and $ 185,481 for the 9 months.The company said the 2,000,000 share difference between the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1989 and the 9 months ended Dec. 31, 1989 resulted from the exercise of warrants at the end of September 1989.

title: WAR IN THE GULF Next Phase: Testing a Fragile Alliance; For U.S. and Soviets, Far Different Needs
description: Iraq's proposal on Kuwait today appears to open a new phase in the Persian Gulf crisis, in which the cohesion of the anti-Baghdad coalition is likely to be severely tested, particularly the core United States- Soviet alliance.

title: Subway Ridership Drops 4.3%; Fare Rise Could Come in Spring
description: Subway and bus ridership dropped so sharply in the last 13 months that transit officials say they may be forced to seek a fare increase as early as this spring.

title: News Summary
description: War in the Gulf 4-9

title: Athlone Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,025,000 in the latest year and $ 82,000 in the year-earlier period, and an extraordinary charge related to the early retirement of the company's 155/8 percent subordinated notes of $ 278,000 in the latest year and $ 770,000 in the year-earlier period.The company said 1989 results reflect $ 10.6 million in net operating loss carryforwards, which reduced the company's provision for income taxes by about $ 3.6 million; during 1990 there were no carryforwards available.

title: Zeus Components Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 268,000, or 10 cents a share, and $ 244,000, or 9 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. The extraordinary item is related to a gain from the extinguishment of debt, net of income tax.

title: Lawter International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Bush, Scorning Offer, Suggests Iraqis Topple Hussein
description: Dismissing Iraq's offer on Kuwait as "dead on arrival," President Bush said today that if the Iraqi military and people wanted to stop the bloodshed, they should "take matters into their own hands" and overthrow their leader.

title: Filtertek Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included writedown of assets including goodwill relating to German operations of $ 3,244,000, or 51 cents a share, for both the quarter and year.c-Net incomed-Included non-recurring gains of $ 952,000, or 14 cents a share, relating to sales of assets and securities.
