Wisconsin Public Service reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Allies Fight On Despite Iraqi Proposal
description: Despite Iraq's conditional offer to discuss withdrawal from Kuwait, allied warplanes carried out punishing nonstop attacks on targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait today. But the Iraqi offer stirred complex political cross-currents in the region that might complicate the prosecution of the war.

title: Nichols Institute reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Scotsman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss and included a nonrecurring charge of 6 cents a share related to the repatriation of $ 16 million from the company's foreign operations.Results for 1989 are on a pro forma basis due to Scotsman's spin off from Household International in April 1989.

title: Beliefs
description: What do we know about George Bush's religious convictions, and what part might they play in his direction of the war in the Persian Gulf? Those are questions people have been asking out of more than idle curiosity since Jan. 16.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Japan: Tokyo Insists Again on Iraqi Pullout
description: The Japanese Government told the Iraqi Ambassador today that it stood by its demand for an unconditional pullout from Kuwait, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: CE Software Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: "The chief thing, in our view, consists of the fact that the Iraqi leadership is speaking of withdrawal from Kuwait. Unfortunately, this principled provision is linked to many conditions, which could render it meaningless. We hope that this announcement can become the starting point for peace, and will not be fruitless." -- Vitaly Churkin, spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry. [ 1:6. ]

title: Pictures Need A Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Begin the Meal With Authentic Borscht
description: FYODOROFF boldly proclaims in neon that it is both a Russian and an American restaurant. But diners would be foolish to choose a sirloin steak or steamed lobster when the likes of pelmeni, vareniki, shashlik Karsky and chicken Tabaka are as rare as rubles on Long Island.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Casey Gets a Shutout: Jon Casey turned aside 18 shots and Bobby Smith and Brian Bellows scored on power plays yesterday as the visiting Minnesota North Stars shut out the Detroit Red Wings, 3-0. Casey, felled twice by shots and once by an elbow from Bob Probert, recovered each time to record his third shutout of the season and the seventh of his six-year career. Casey was not tested often, but stopped a breakaway attempt by Jimmy Carson midway through the second period to protect a 1-0 lead. The Red Wings, 4-11-1 in their last 16 games, fell four games below .500, matching their low point for the season.(AP) Tennis Navratilova Gains Final: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova defeated Helena Sukova, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Navratilova, seeking her 11th Chicago title, will play the winner of the Zina Garrison-Helen Kelesi match, which was played later last night. (AP) Two Rally to Gain Final: Top-seeded Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere of Bulgaria and Petra Langrova of Czechoslovakia both came back from opening-set losses to win semifinal matches yesterday in the Grundig tournament at Linz, Austria. Maleeva-Fragniere defeated Regina Rajchrtova of Czechoslovakia, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, and Langrova beat fifth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of Germany, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4. (AP) Golf Pavin Draws Close: Corey Pavin, who won the Bob Hope Classic last week, shot a 65 yesterday to pull within one stroke of the leader, Steve Pate, in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Open at San Diego. Pate, who shot a third-round 67, will be seeking his first victory since taking this title three years ago. Dan Forsman, the defending champion, who was tied with Pate after two rounds, is tied with Ben Crenshaw and Jim Hallet at 13 under par. (AP) Senior Ties Norman: Peter Senior birdied the 18th hole yesterday to share the the third-round lead with Greg Norman in the Australian Masters championship at Melbourne. Senior shot a four-under-par 69 on the 6,955-yard, par-73 course to equal Norman's 11-under-par 208 total. The Australians Jeff Woodland, Rodger Davis and Peter O'Malley were three shots off the pace at 211. David DeLong was the leading American at 214 after a 73. (AP) Skiing Soviet Woman Wins: Lyubov Egorova won the 30-kilometer women's freestyle cross-country race at the world Nordic championships yesterday in Val di Femme, Italy, and kept a Soviet teammate, Elena Valbe, from winning a fourth gold medal. Valbe, the defending champion, finished second by 35.6 seconds. Egorova was timed in 1 hour 20 minutes 26.8 seconds. The Soviet Union moved into second place in the medal standing, with four gold, two silver and two bronze medals. Norway leads with a 5-2-2 record. Sweden is third at 1-4-1. Manuela di Centa of Italy was second, 48.5 seconds behind for her second bronze medal in the championships. Ingrid Butts of Park City, Utah was the top American finisher, placing 34th, 7:37.6 behind. (AP) Track and Field Johnson Wins Close Race: Ben Johnson won a narrow victory yesterday, leaning across the finish line to beat Bruny Surin and Atlee Mahorn in the 60 meters at the Canadian indoor championships at Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. Johnson was timed in 6.65 seconds. (AP) Horse Racing Stately Wager Triumphs: Robert B. Cohen's Stately Wager surged in front on the final turn and went on to win the $114,400 Whirlaway Breeders' Cup by 1 3/4 lengths yesterday at Aqueduct. Jorge Chavez rode the 3-year-old, carrying 117 pounds, to his first victory in two starts this year. King Mutesa, ridden by Mike Smith, was runner-up in the nine-horse field, three and one-half lengths ahead of Dandy Danzig, ridden by Julie Krone. Stately Wager covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:47 2/5, and paid $8, $3.40 and $2.60 for $2 across the board. (AP) Bowling Benoit Wins Second Title: Bob Benoit of Topeka, Kan., beat four opponents yesterday to win the Bud Light Classic at Sunrise, Fla., for his second Professional Bowlers Association title. In the final game, Benoit defeated Wayne Webb of Beaumont, Tex., 204-183. In the semifinal match, Benoit beat John Mazza of Mount Clemens, Mich., 224-198. Earlier, Benoit defeated the 1990 P.B.A. Player of the Year, Amleto Monacelli, 203-202, and Pete Weber of Florissant, Mo., 216-180. (AP)

title: Playing Disney in the Parisian Fields
description: With great fanfare, three $150 million amusement parks opened in France in the past three years, but all have fallen flat and two have been forced into bankruptcy.

title: Boy Finds Prehistoric Tooth
description: An 8-year-old boy recently found the tooth of a prehistoric mosasaur, a carnivorous lizard up to 42 feet long, in north Mississippi. Kent Stratton Jr. of Memphis gave it to a Memphis museum.

title: Yugoslav Army Orders Arrest of Croatia Aide
description: The federal army has ordered its troops to arrest the defense minister of the republic of Croatia on charges of planning a rebellion that was to involve the killing of army officers, a military statement said.

title: Miss Glucksman Is Married on L.I.
description: Donna Lynn Glucksman and Peter Howard Schlessel were married last evening at Temple Hillel in Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Elihu Kasten and Cantor Solomon Mendelson officiated.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: By titling Robert B. Reich's article "Secession of the Successful" (Jan. 20), rather than the more apt "Secession of the Rich," you give currency to the idea that we should equate fiscal success with success in life. The message of the article would seem to be that success, both personal and national, depend on moral, not monetary, wealth. GREGORY N. RACZ Hanover, N.H.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LITTLE PEG By Kevin McIlvoy.Atheneum, $18.95.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
In the Berkshires, Antiques and Crafts Fill an Old Factory
description: MOST visitors are attracted to the 20,000-square-foot Buggy Whip Factory complex in Southfield, Mass., by the 60 antiques dealers. Others are drawn by the local crafts, discounted clothing, children's furnishings and hand-finished sweaters.

title: THE YANKEE CYCLE
description: William Safire's On Language column "Brits, Tommies, Poms, Limeys & Kippers" (Jan. 27) didn't complete the "Yankee" cycle. If I may.

title: More Debtors Seeking Protection in Bankruptcy
description: THE word bankruptcy comes from banca rotta, or broken bench, a term used in 14th century Italy where merchants conducted their business seated on benches. When a merchant failed to meet his financial obligations, the other merchants broke his bench over his head.

title: Simple Sauces Complement Seafood
description: SEAFOOD doesn't need complicated sauces. But a simple addition to a roasted, grilled or sauteed piece of fish can give the dish polish. Fresh herbs, a sprinkling of really good olive oil, or even something a little more esoteric, like a paste of green chilies with cilantro, can add an intriguing new dimension.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; 2 U.S. Jets Are Shot Down Over Kuwait
description: Two American fighter-bombers were shot down today over northwestern Kuwait as allied forces continued their round-the-clock bombardment of targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, the United States military command said. Iraq said 130 more civilians were killed by an allied bombing mission.

title: Music, and What It May Have Meant
description: Computer models of dead civilizations are notoriously unreliable, but it is now generally accepted that music disappeared sometime in the 21st century, ET (Earth Time). Though the reasons remain uncertain, considerable evidence seems to point to global warming, ultrasonic dental equipment and the prevalence of bee pollen in the atmosphere. A few researchers still hold out for alternative causes like the progressive shrinkage of the taste buds or the emission of intellectual smog from France. What no one disputes is that music, once the most pervasive social force in the world, exists today only in printed form in aural history museums.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: A Midwesterner who moved to New York some years ago was flabbergasted when she first heard of arranged "play dates" for children and learned that the arrangements were often made a week or more in advance.

title: Camera
description: This is the tale of two cameras, one a fancy, all-in-one hybrid and one an entry-level, all-electronic single-lens reflex. Both take 35-millimeter film, but otherwise they have amazingly little in common.

title: Stephanie Shulman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jason M. Shulman of New York have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Stephanie Thea Shulman and Mark David Birman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Birman of Forest Hills, Queens. Both are 26 years old, both have law degrees from Yeshiva University and both are lawyers in New York, she in private practice and he as an associate at Feinberg, Berns & Castro. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania; he from Boston University.

title: Daring Summer Crime Titillates a Jaded Rio
description: Summer unfolded here in December with the news that thieves had stolen a car belonging to Leda Collor, the mother of the Brazilian President, Fernando Collor de Mello.

title: The Executive Computer; Networld: The Talk Is of Strategic Partnerships
description: When 20,000 managers of corporate computer systems gathered at the Networld 91 trade show here last week, they found vivid proof that the personal computer industry remains in a mating frenzy, with companies seeking strategic partners in virtually every market corner.

title: Corchiani Saves Wolfpack
description: Chris Corchiani came into North Carolina State's game against Connecticut today as one of the nation's primere and highly touted guards, with a 17.2-point scoring average and the Division I leader in assists with an average of 9.5 a game.

title: Correction
description: Pictures of two engaged couples on page 70 today are reversed. Matthew Toll and Ann Tweedy are at the left. Randall Havas and Melissa Weissberg are at the right.

title: 'Baghdad Without a Map': Where Yes and No Mean Maybe
description: Tony Horwitz's career wasn't going anywhere when his wife landed a job in 1987 as a correspondent in the Middle East. So he followed her to Cairo and spent the next two years traipsing through the desert and dust of 15 countries, trying to pick up freelance writing assignments and grabbing any opportunity for adventure that came his way. He gawked at inept belly dancers in a Cairo dive (one "had the stage presence of an amateur wrestler"), consumed camel meat in the Abu Dhabi desert ("it tasted like overcooked sandal"), chewed khat, Yemen's ubiquitous stimulant, with a local bureaucrat ("I didn't notice at first that the carpet was massaging my toes") and shook hands, or limbs, with a reception line of lepers at a colony in Khartoum ("I felt a sudden urge to flee"). Out of these and other wacky, often hair-raising, experiences, he has fashioned "Baghdad Without a Map," a very funny and frequently insightful look at the world's most combustible region.

title: For Tanner, Light Was Love
description: The most conspicuous and unifying aspect of the paintings by Henry Ossawa Tanner now at the Philadelphia Museum of Art is their light. It is different from the clear, expansive, inaccessible light of the Hudson River School painter Frederic Edwin Church, different from the muscular, unsparing light of the realist Thomas Eakins, one of Tanner's teachers and friends.

title: Czech Book Industry Paralyzed by Freedom
description: Czechoslovakia's book industry has come into hard times since a famous author became President and lifted the burdens of censorship from the publishing industry.

title: Lindsay Meredith Miller, TV Producer, Weds Peter Wistar Ambler, Architect
description: Lindsay Meredith Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bruce Miller of Richmond, was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Peter Wistar Ambler, a son of Eleanor Nash Starkey of New York and the late Wistar Ambler. The Rev. Allan Happe performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: 2 Grants for Disadvantaged Students
description: TWO Westchester school districts are the first beneficiaries of a $10 million fund from the estate of DeWitt Wallace, the founder of the Reader's Digest in Chappaqua who died 10 years ago.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Washington's birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holdiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No street cleaning, pickup or recycling. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on Saturday schedule. L.I.R.R. on holiday scheudle. Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit bus and rail service on Saturday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state, municipal closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North New Haven line on weekend schedule.

title: Robert Morris Suing N.C.A.A.
description: Robert Morris College has sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association, saying the penalties its men's basketball program received last year for rules violations were too severe.

title: Grammys Still Try to Play It On the Safe Side
description: Sinead O'Connor's recent announcement that she would not participate in the Grammy Awards this Wednesday is the latest brouhaha to erupt around an annual event that, after 33 years, is still struggling to gain the kind of respect the Oscars have enjoyed for decades.

title: Leslie L. Probert To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Probert of New Vernon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Loring Probert, to Eugene Stephen Sirbaugh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Shaffer Sirbaugh of Cockeysville, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: Amy M. Saks to Wed Jeremy Kahan in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Saks of Oreland, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Meryl Saks, to Jeremy Arthur Kahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahan of Brookline, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Shoppers Find Loans With Lettuce
description: MILDRED LAWRENCE had just pushed her shopping cart past the bananas when Jim Beaulieu approached her. "Did you know that we have a bank here?" he asked. "It's open seven days a week."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Britain; Amid Criticism, Britain Holds to Decision to Imprison Scores of Iraqis
description: Amid growing criticism, Britain is holding firm to its decision to imprison scores of Iraqi students and immigrants because of fears of terrorism over the Persian Gulf war. Government officials defended the policy as being in the interest of national security.

title: Exceptionally Sane Most of the Time
description: A PASSIONATE APPRENTICEThe Early Journals, 1897-1909.By Virginia Woolf.Edited by Mitchell A. Leaska.Illustrated. 444 pp. San Diego:Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Good Life in Romania Is Off the Beaten Path
description: The quiet of a winter's day in this snow-dappled enclave in the Transylvanian mountains is shattered by the incongruous sounds of heavy construction. Huge villas are rapidly rising to meet the skyline, a noisy testament to the entrepreneurial prowess of the shepherds who have prospered here for centuries.

title: Under a Tropical Tricolor
description: THEIR language is French, their currency the franc, their flag the tricolor. They have baguettes, gendarmes and speedy Renaults galore. And those ever-so-practical garbage cans on wheels look as natural there as they do in France. Why not? Martinique and Guadeloupe are, by law, no less part of France than Lyons or Bordeaux. But add a dose of the Caribbean and warmth, sensuality, lushness and improvisation begin to subvert all that French correctness. Clothes tumble off, stiffness cracks, impatience learns to wait. In Paris, this Franco-tropicalia could not survive. From the Antilles, it beckons enticingly to a Europe and North America trapped in winter and worried by war.

title: An Assault on Mush
description: THE PHILOSOPHER ON DOVER BEACH Essays. By Roger Scruton. 344 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portsmouth, N.H.;
55 House Lots Off the Links
description: DESPITE the recession and the dormant real estate market, the owners of the Wentworth by-the-Sea resort are planning to develop 55 house lots around the resort's 18-hole shorefront golf course.

title: Spread of Cholera Brings Frenzy and Improvisation to Model Lima Hospital
description: Hospitals and medical clinics around this capital and along Peru's coast have become the front lines in the battle against the first cholera epidemic in more than 100 years. The epidemic is sorely testing the country's meager medical resources.

title: Review/Music; Kenny Barron Quintet
description: Of all the skills a jazz pianist needs, comping -- supplying chords behind a soloist while steering the rhythm section -- is probably the most overlooked. Kenny Barron's comping never upstaged his quintet's soloists in the first set Tuesday night as they opened a six-night stand at the Village Vanguard, but his playing was a study in the uses of chord voicings, rhythmic variety and quick response to solos. He made chords transparent in one chorus, opaque in the next; he put a canopy of harmony above one solo, smoothly undergirded another and gently prodded a third. His comping transformed hard-bop pieces in conventional theme-solos-theme form into suites of emotions, from suavity to torment to triumph.

title: We Need More Than a Big Stick in Mideast; Big Teach-In Turnouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Cruel and Usual Punishment
description: SPARE THE CHILD The Religious Roots of Punishment and the Psychological Impact of Physical Abuse. By Philip Greven. 263 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The doors in my 25-year-old house, which I think were originally varnished, now need refinishing. The bathroom doors have a dry whitish look near the bottom, and others show scratch and scuff marks. What should I use and how should I proceed?

title: Catherine Futter To Wed in April
description: Kenneth Gunther Futter of Rowayton, Conn., and Margaret Spencer Futter of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Lenoir Futter to William Allen Scoggin Jr., a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Scoggin of Augusta, Ga. An April wedding is planned.

title: Inside Iraq; Amid the Ruins, Fear, Anger and Cynicism
description: THE difficulties war has created for ordinary Iraqis and the effect on their morale were described in a dispatch from Amman, Jordan, last week by Bernd Debusmann of Reuters, who had left Iraq on Feb. 8. Following are excerpts:

title: Keeping Busy During a School Vacation
description: WITH many students in the county on mid-winter vacation this week, various activities have been scheduled to entertain and occupy children of all ages. Many programs have been devised to satisfy young curiosities or to challenge the youngsters' skills. Others are aiming for amusement. Some of the events also encourage attendance by parents or accompanying adults.

title:
FORUM;
Does the Rally Signal Recession's End?
description: The question in the minds of many investors, as they watch what may be the beginning of a new bull market, is whether the current runup in stock prices signals an early end to the recession.

title: Something To Hear Every Night Of the Week
description: CULTURAL events have a way of clumping up around the weekends, but you'll find attractive concert options every day this week and great musical variety in the bargain.

title: Jill Ann Bridgman to Wed Edmond N. Moriarty 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Bridgman of Murray Hill, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Jill Ann Bridgman and Edmond Nicholas Moriarty 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moriarty Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Little Time Left for Knicks
description: When the Knicks' locker room door opened after their game with the Cavaliers Friday night, almost every player was sitting despondently in front of his stall.

title: Czechoslovaks to Set Up Office in Lithuania
description: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia has said his country will establish representation in the secessionist Soviet republic of Lithuania.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Basking Ridge 352,000 45 Tuxford Terrace 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in-kitchen, full basement; taxes $4,917. Brick 65,000 9 Post Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, screened porch, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,406. Howell 157,500 9 Patterson Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; patio, family room, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $3,665. Maplewood 230,000 37 Burnet Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, sun porch, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,744. Plainfield 140,000 945 Knollwood Court 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; c/a, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,505. Wayne 250,000 180 Kiwanis Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old contemporary mother/daughter; porch, full basement, large private lot; taxes $3,543. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. 280,000 297 Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $5,708. Brookfield, Conn. 210,000 10 Spruce Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; family room, screened porch, large deck, 1 acre, taxes not available. Kings Park, L.I. 190,000 23 Cedar Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $6,600.

title: The Region; Shattering a Taboo: Weicker Seeks An Income Tax
description: ON Wednesday Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., facing a budget gap of $2.4 billion, did what has been politically unthinkable for generations of Connecticut politicians by proposing a state income tax. Following are excerpts from his budget address to the General Assembly in Hartford: The deficit projection, as I walked into this chamber, is at $2.4 billion. It grew $40 million just within the past days as corporations claimed refunds for overpayment of taxes.

title: Opera's Fabulous Vanishing Act
description: Since World War II, we have done something remarkable with opera. We have whisked it from view. This has not been easy, for opera's sheer bulk and ungainly shape make it a poor object for concealment. But we've mastered the trick through an old detective-fiction dodge: leaving the body out in plain sight. We've disguised it, naturally, to render it unrecognizable to next of kin. If apprehended by folks in search of it, we can always shrug, point and protest that it has been there all along.

title: Currency; The Dollar Finally Gets a Lift
description: The dollar started off the week by setting a new low against the mark of 1.4475 in New York trading on Monday, despite more dollar buying by central banks to support the United States currency. But by Friday, it had rallied three pfennigs to 1.4785. It first got a lift from comments made by a Treasury official, who said the Administration did not want the dollar to move any lower. As the week wore on, the massive dollar buying by the central banks finally seemed to be having some impact. And on Friday, the dollar shot up on news of the Iraqi offer to withdraw from Kuwait. Although President Bush rejected the offer because of the conditions attached to it, some traders saw it as the beginning of the end of the war.

title: A June Wedding For Miss Dodge
description: Mrs. William Longstreth Dodge of Boston has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Robin dePeyster Dodge and Daniel Hale Sears, a son of Mrs. Ralph Scott Taggart of Blue Hill, Me., and F. Fulton Sears of Manchester, Mass.

title: Gazing Into an Opaque Crystal Ball
description: The bands crank up their guitars until they start to feed back, cue their drummers to full-scale assault and sing, in a tone determined not to be histrionic, about just how displaced and alone they feel.

title: Skepticism Rises on Dinkins's Budget Plan: He Means It, but Can He Do It?
description: Even as New York City prepares to lay off hundreds of its workers this week, a testament to painful budget problems, many fiscal analysts are starting to wonder whether the Dinkins administration will be able to carry out its plans to trim its payroll and shrink city government.

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: Olivier Bernier gives the impression in "Rococo Reaches a Frothy Peak" (Travel, Jan. 13) that the Residenz in Wurzburg has stood unblemished since the 18th century. In March 1945 the intransigence of the Nazi gauleiter of Wurzburg resulted in a 23-minute Allied bombing raid, which left the city (including the Residenz) in ruins.

title: Cut Before Fares Rise, Transit Authority Is Urged
description: New York City's Transportation Commissioner, who is a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the board should consider cutting more costs before imposing a fare increase to close an unexpectedly large budget deficit for the subway and bus system.

title: Ennui in Ray-Bans
description: NEW JAPANESE VOICES The Best Contemporary Fiction From Japan. Edited by Helen Mitsios. Introduction by Jay McInerney. 175 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Pro Hockey; Devils Get a Lift as Captain Finally Scores
description: Frustration from going without a point in six games and without a goal in 11 was beginning to build for Kirk Muller, whose Devils had been struggling along with their captain.

title: Pampered Pets in the Wilds of Utah
description: THE pugs didn't look very happy. My husband, Duke, and I were on vacation, driving around southern Utah -- Dixie, they call it -- with Bess and Stella, my 12-year-old pugs. We were meandering toward Zion National Park, and Duke had decided to take "the scenic route," a winding unpaved road through a wild series of gorges past Grosvenor Arch and Cottonwood Canyon. In the back of the jeep, the little dogs were ricocheting off the luggage and the wheel wells like pachinko balls.

title: Mourners Recall Wagner as Man Of Subtle Grace
description: Friends, loved ones, old political allies and ordinary New Yorkers remembered Robert F. Wagner yesterday as one of the city's most popular and pivotal mayors, a quiet man of conscience and probity who led New York through some of the most sweeping changes in its history.

title: Who Uses Water and Who Saves It
description: Two recent article on Long Island's public drinking water contain several inaccuracies that paint a distorted picture of our public water-supply system. One article reports that while Nassau County currently pumps about 175 million to 180 million gallons each day, only 140 million gallons per day recharge into the aquifers beneath the Island. Actually county figures show that recharge occurs at the rate of at least 250 million gallons per day, a daily net gain of a minimum of 70 million gallons. Moreover, the unique nature of our aquifer system insures that we will have a stable, plentiful supply even in times of drought.

title: A Quick Delivery of Success
description: It can be fairly said that Rick Majerus has never met a pizza he didn't like. That can be a problem, however, as Majerus found out last year when he discovered he had blocked heart arteries.

title: A Painter Wins a New Lease on Fame
description: Theresa Bernstein knows that eventually she will always be asked the question that must have become so tedious: What's your secret? How did you manage to become 100 years old? (Or 101 or 102 -- she never will really say.)

title: Democrats Clash Over Propriety Of Dual Positions
description: WHEN Benjamin L. Zwirn won election in 1989 as the first Democratic supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead in 73 years, the Nassau County Democratic chairman, John W. Matthews, was ecstatic. He hailed the victory as the beginning of the end of Republican domination in Nassau.

title: Wedding in June For Miss Cochran
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peyton S. Cochran Jr. of Glyndon, Md., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Katherine Ledyard Cochran, and William Stephen Elder, a son of Thomas G. Elder of West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: We Need More Than a Big Stick in Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Saddam Hussein's Survival Strategy
description: The confusion sown by Saddam Hussein's tricky peace bid confirms, if any proof were needed, that the Iraqi President is no madman bent on personal or national suicide. Besides trying to divide the coalition arrayed against Iraq, his arrogant and ambiguous offer to withdraw from Kuwait makes selfish sense.

title: Into the Rose Garden
description: PREPARING A BED FOR ROSES IS A LITTLE LIKE getting the house ready for the arrival of a difficult old lady, some biddy with aristocratic pretensions and persnickety tastes. The stay is bound to be an ordeal, and you want to give as little cause for complaint as possible. All of a sudden the soil that has served well for years seems lacking, its drainage dubious and its pH level off. So you begin digging, hauling bales of peat moss and blowing all at once the precious cache of compost it has taken years to accumulate. Up to now, I've avoided growing roses (real roses, that is -- I've always had a tough climber or two). But last winter the ripe catalogue shots of roses took hold in my imagination, and I decided to take the plunge.

title: Coins
description: Three coins honoring Mount Rushmore have been authorized and released by the United States Mint. Last week, Nicholas F. Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, announced a program to sell the Mount Rushmore commemorative coins to help preserve the memorial and the amenities it offers to two million visitors each year. Surcharges on each of the coins are expected to raise as much as $18 million for the monument.

title: Headliners; Kicked Out
description: In recent years a number of universities have enacted "hate speech" regulations, declaring it a violation of school policy to make harassing racial and ethnic slurs. While some civil libertarians have complained that the rules violate the First Amendment, university officials say they are needed to combat a rise in campus racism. Last week, Douglas Hann, a varsity football player at Brown University, became what is thought to be the first person in the country expelled for violating one of the rules. While celebrating his 21st birthday last October, Mr. Hann stood in a dormitory courtyard shouting what witnesses later said were insults against blacks, homosexuals and Jews. The university said he had also violated rules against excessive drinking. Mr. Hann doesn't deny that the incident occurred but he said the school's allegations are inexact. The expulsion, he insisted, "was just a political statement by the university."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Some Iraqi Units Seem To Quit Kuwaiti Front
description: Front-line Iraqi troops appear to have withdrawn from several positions that have come under heavy allied air attack during the last 10 days, say allied officers stationed along a stretch of the Kuwaiti border.

title: E.P.A. to Ignore Small Risks in Banning Pesticides
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has decided to ignore risks it considers trivial in judging whether to ban pesticides whose residues in food may cause cancer.

title: Ruffles and Other Flourishes for Active Little Legs
description: Now that colorful leggings and tights have become staples of women's wardrobes, several legwear companies are introducing lines for little girls, ever eager to look grown up. This spring, members of the lively set will camouflage their limbs in tulip colors and posy prints.

title: Block's First Blacks: Ashes to an Open House
description: It has been a year since someone set fire to Wilfred and Agnes Phillip's new house in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn -- a week before the Grenadian-born couple were to move in and become the first black family on the block.

title: Nassau Bus Riders Facing a Fare Rise
description: THE overseer of the Nassau County bus fleet likes to refer to his charges as "40-foot whales." The manager, L. A. Kimball, is trying to keep 305 whales above water, and it is not easy.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHERE IS THE WAY Song and Struggle in South Africa. By Helen Q. Kivnick. Penguin, Paper, $9.95.

title: Ms. Craighead Plans May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Craighead of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Ruth Craighead, to William Wappler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wappler of Seattle. A May wedding is planned.

title: Anne Sargent to Marry
description: June wedding plans for Anne Virginia Sargent and Stephen Francis Arcano, a son of Elizabeth B. Arcano of Southington, Conn., and the late Dr. Joseph T. Arcano, have been announced by her parents, Jean H. Sargent of Needham, Mass., and Richard Sargent of Arlington, Mass. Miss Sargent and her fiance are 28 years old and associates in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. She graduated from Northeastern University, he from Georgetown University, where each received law degrees.

title: Correction
description: A caption with the Antiques column last Sunday misstated the amount paid at the Winter Antiques Show in New York for a pair of 17th-century Japanese screens. It was about $800,000.

title:
JERSEY CITY JOURNAL;
An Arts Community Steps Into a Spotlight
description: "I JUST knew that if I built it, people would come."

title: Miss Samperton Weds William Coffin
description: Schuyler Drew Samperton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Samperton of Chevy Chase, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to William Todd Coffin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralston H. Coffin of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mark Mullin performed the Episcopal ceremony in the National Cathedral, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Amato, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Three Galleries In London
description: The National Gallery in London celebrates the reopening of its three Impressionist galleries with a "Van Gogh to Picasso" exhibition. The galleries -- 44, 45 and 46 -- have been closed for two years while undergoing complete restoration made possible with the help of Walter H. Annenberg, the former United States Ambassador. The environment, light, humidity and temperature in the renovated rooms will now be controlled by computers. Access for the disabled has been improved by the installation of an elevator.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STRONG DRINK, STRONG LANGUAGEBy John Espey.John Daniel, $17.95.

title: The Heydey Of Ocean Liners
description: William H. Miller's recalling the heyday of the ocean liner ("New Jersey Q & A," Jan. 20) brought back memories of my years of "river watching" from a private nook near Stevens Castle.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; After Fatal Fire, A Drive to Require Sprinkler Systems
description: In the wake of a fire that killed three University of California undergraduates in September, the city's Fire Department is pressing for an ordinance that would require all group residential buildings, including fraternity and sorority houses, to install sprinkler systems.

title: A SECRET PAYMENT STIRS UP FLORIDA
description: An episode involving sex and a secret payment of $47,000 in state funds intended to stifle a political scandal has proved both titillating and embarrassing for a State Capitol already beset by ethical problems.

title: Public Housing and a College to Become Partners
description: A historically black university here and the city's housing authority have proposed an unusual partnership in which graduate students in social work and education will move into one of the authority's public housing projects to provide both services and a hopeful example for low-income residents.

title: Ellen L. Fischer to Wed S. O. Taylor
description: The engagement of Ellen Louise Fischer to Spencer Olin Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Morgan Taylor Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Lake Forest, Ill., has been announced by her father, Warren K. Fischer of Jackson Heights, Queens. A September wedding is planned.

title: Of Slot Machines And Gaming Tables
description: The article "Casinos Press for More Slot Machines" (Jan. 6) neglected to mention the major reason the casinos want more slot machines. The reason is that the slot machines provide the worst payout and therefore generate the largest revenue to the casinos.

title: World Markets; America's Recovery Takes the Lead
description: Markets around the world rallied last week, but the roar was loudest in the United States. The Standard & Poor's 500 index hit a record high and the Dow Jones industrial average finally recouped all that it lost after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August.

title: Early Bulbs Ease the Wait for Spring
description: THE recent spell of warm weather encouraged many woody plants into a false spring, and buds swelled. But some of the plants remained on schedule just because they were supposed to.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Mamaroneck, N.Y. 520,000 572 The Parkway 6-bedroom, 4-bath, 36-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, skylights; taxes $9,013. Rye, N.Y. 500,000 2 Soundview Avenue 6-bedroom, 5-bath, 68-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen, pantry, den, 3-car garage; taxes $8,207. Scarsdale, N.Y. 280,000 297 Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $5,708. Brookfield, Conn. 210,000 10 Spruce Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; family room, screened porch, large deck, 1 acre, taxes not available. Danbury, Conn. 210,000 11 King Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old raised ranch; workshop on lower level, 2-tier rear deck, 1.8 acres; taxes $3,216. Ridgefield, Conn. 265,000 39 Clayton Place 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old colonial; lakefront, oversized finished basement, 1.8 acres; taxes $3,894. OTHER AREAS Manhasset Hills, L.I. 338,800 14 Larch Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old split-level; family room, den, basement, 2-car garage, stone/fieldstone exterior; taxes $6,000. Massapequa, L.I. 164,000 5 Jackson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Brick, N.J. 65,000 9 Post Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, screened porch, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,406.

title: SOHO STARES AT HARD TIMES
description: James Servin's article "SoHo Stares at Hard Times" (Jan. 20) incorrectly measures today's art scene using the fads, cliches and hype of the 1980's. Things have changed: the glitz is gone, and the art-world meteors grow more faint by the minute. What remains are the many SoHo galleries that continue to be committed to their artists and their collectors, and, most importantly, to the concept of fine art, not investment opportunities.

title: An Administration Still Hooked on Oil
description: The energy policy now taking shape within the Bush Administration is distressingly blind to the oil addiction that underlies the dispatch of 500,000 American troops to the Persian Gulf.

title: Ready for Your Close-up, Mr. T. Rex?
description: "You?"

title: Impassioned Images Ring Out Across Time Coming to Grips With an Unsettling World
description: Nearly 300 years after his death it is still not entirely clear who he was. Priest, resistance fighter, madman -- Bada Shanren has been described in many ways, and he described himself in many ways, too, going by nearly a dozen names.

title: Concorde Cuts
description: Concorde service is being cut because of the war in the Persian Gulf and the economic recession. British Airways has reduced the number of flights by the supersonic airliner between New York and London and Washington and London. In addition, Air France has postponed a plan for additional flights on the Concorde on its New York-Paris route. The British Concorde's daily runs between New York and London were reduced Feb. 7 to one from two and the three weekly Washington flights were suspended. Air France had intended to add a second Concorde flight between New York and Paris four days a week from March to June and from September to December. The airline now hopes to add these flights in September. Air France does not fly the Concorde to Washington.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; The Thinking Behind Bush's Call for Iraqi's Ouster
description: President Bush decided to make his most explicit call for the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq after watching televised scenes of jubilation in the streets of Baghdad on Friday and concluding that the Iraqis were ripe for such an appeal, officials said today.

title: Review/Music; 20th-Century Program By Composers Orchestra
description: The rich program by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last Sunday afternoon negotiated once again the Tower of Babel that is 20th-century music.

title: Wallet of Ideas: New Yorkers Suggest Ways to Save the Budget
description: New Yorkers are not known for their reticence. Ask them for their views on how local government could do a better job of reducing its budget deficit and they respond vehemently, cynically, and sometimes, with solutions.

title: Made-for-TV Chekhov, From Mamet and Mosher
description: "Chekhov's 'Uncle Vanya' is a play not far removed in construction from the old-time melodrama thrillers of the American stage." So wrote the critic for The World the morning after the play's first New York production in 1924 by the Moscow Art Theater, with Stanislavsky himself playing Astrov. David Mamet, whose version of the play can be seen Friday night at 9 on public television's Great Performances, goes even further.

title: The Misses Benenson, Twins, Are Wed in a Dual Ceremony
description: Kathryn Ingram Benenson and Sarah Megan Benenson, twin daughters of Thomas H. Benenson of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Richard E. Dirickson Jr. of San Francisco, were married last night in a double ceremony in Pebble Beach, Calif.: Kathryn Benenson to Jonathan Anthony Marcus and Sarah Benenson to Brett I. Goldberg.

title: Melissa Weissberg to Marry in April
description: Judge Franklin R. Weissberg and Elsa Weissberg, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Ivy Weissberg, to Randall Edward Havas, a son of George P. Havas of Lafayette, Calif., and the late Nancy Aileen Havas. An April wedding is planned.

title: Sunday Menu; Tasty Chicken and Polenta, by Any Name
description: Chicken With Vegetables is hardly a recipe title that will inspire cooks to run to the kitchen. But the name is deceptive, and in many ways the dish is like chicken cacciatore, which is a far more interesting name, after all.

title: Three Eastern European Leaders Confer, Gingerly
description: The leaders of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland met this week at the ruins of a historic castle to pledge mutual cooperation, and then to insist that they meant no offense.

title: Baseball Notebook; If Hershiser's Arm Feels Good, So Will Dodgers
description: Orel Hershiser and Scott Bankhead each started only four games last year. Pascual Perez didn't make it that far; he made only three starts. Todd Worrell was envious of all of them; he didn't throw a pitch. Danny Cox tossed a few pitches in the minor leagues, but he didn't throw any in the majors for the second successive season.

title: Denial of Insurance Benefits to Heirs Is Upheld
description: ALBERT MANZO JR. died of multiple gunshot wounds; his body was found in a car trunk in a shopping mall in Hillside on Aug. 22, 1983. Nearly eight years later, the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld a life insurance company's refusal to pay the $500,000 claim, saying that to do so would be an encouragement to lie.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Looking for the Good Life in the Country
description: THE lure of the great outdoors sent Suzanne and Edward Wansor job-hunting in the Albany area a year and a half ago. They were fed up with the traffic jams and residential congestion that surrounded them in Nesconset, said Mrs. Wansor, who is a nurse.

title: Company That Beamed Sex Films Is Fined
description: A Federal judge has fined a New York-based company $150,000 for broadcasting pornographic movies by satellite to some 30,000 subscribers throughout the continental United States.

title: Frostbite Fleets Meet Winter on the Sound
description: FOR most people, sailing is a summer pastime. But some die-hards extend the season, venturing out in the nastiest winter weather. Enthusiasts call this frostbite sailing, and the sport is popular on Long Island Sound.

title: Numbers Game: Putting More Police on the Streets
description: Like the elusive concept of community policing, the number of police officers that New Yorkers can expect to see on the streets through the city's just-approved anti-crime plan has been hard to pin down.

title: High Plains Drifters
description: RIMA IN THE WEEDS By Deirdre McNamer. 313 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A Parisian Trip to the 1700's" by Mervyn Rothstein (Travel, Jan. 20), it was my privilege to spend a leisurely autumn afternoon at the Nissim de Camondo Museum last year. It is rewarding to walk through the Parc Monceau before entering the museum. The sense of history and a slowing of pace create the right frame of mind for enjoying the collection.

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: For those garden lovers who will probably be disappointed in the not-quite comparable landscaped park adjacent to the otherwise splendid Wurzburg Residenz, I recommend a detour to Schloss Veitshochheim, four and a half miles northwest of the city.

title: Knick Bashing Out of Hand
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: War Summary
description: MORE CIVILIANS KILLED, IRAQ SAYS Iraq asserted that allied planes killed 150 civilians in a marketplace in the city of Fallujah, west of Baghdad. A senior allied commander said a laser-guided bomb had strayed from its target and hit the crowded market. Two American fighter-bombers, attacking entrenched positions of Iraq's Republican Guard, were shot down by surface-to-air missiles. BUSH'S COMMENTS ON HUSSEIN President Bush's call for the Iraqi military to overthrow Saddam Hussein reflects the extent to which Mr. Hussein's downfall is a key consideration in the Administration's Persian Gulf strategy. Mr. Bush was prompted to issue the call after watching televised scenes of jubilation in Baghdad at the possibility of peace, concluding that the Iraqi people were ripe for such an appeal. War Losses Allied Forces Troops: Yesterday, one airman died in a non-combat mission and two were reported missing in Kuwait. No new totals were released yesterday by the U.S. Central Command, but the latest previous toll of American was 62, including 14 killed, 12 wounded, 28 missing and eight confirmed prisoners of war. Aircraft: Two American A-10 aircraft were shot down yesterday, the U.S. Central command in Riyadh reported. At the same time, the command declared that an EF-111 lost several days ago was a noncombat-related loss, even though it was returning from a combat mission. In addition, the command said an F-16C crashed during an instrument approach in Saudi Arabia. Such "non-combat" losses are not included in the daily tally of combat losses, which yesterday's briefer placed at 29 coalition aircraft, 20 of them American. Iraqi Forces Troops: The American briefer put the number of P.O.W.'s at around 1,300. Aircraft: The briefer also reported that an Iraqi helicopter was shot down, bringing to 42 the number of enemy aircraft brought down in air-to-air combat -- 36 fixed-wing craft and six helicopters. Feb 17, 1991

title: Style Makers; David Bergman, Architect and Sculptor
description: David Bergman is a 34-year-old architect who knows about plumbing. Lately he has been using a blowtorch to join copper water pipes -- tees, fittings, connectors and elbows. He's not making house calls. He's making vases, candlesticks, chandeliers and sconces for his "Fire and Water" home design collection.

title: MANDELA'S GROUP PLAGUED BY TRIAL
description: The trial of Winnie Mandela on charges of kidnapping and assault is turning from an embarrassment into a public-relations debacle for the African National Congress, even though the odds that Mrs. Mandela will not be convicted have never looked better.

title: Marinovich And Eligibility
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Who Uses Water And Who Saves It
description: The articles, "State Water-Pumping Caps Under Fire" and "When Water Is Drawn, Anything Can Flow In" [ Jan. 6 ] attempt to elucidate the issues surrounding the four-year-old state-mandated water-pumping caps the 41 water suppliers of Nassau County must abide by.

title:
All About/Comic Books;
Reaching Beyond The Ghouls and Gore For Major Payoffs
description: For years, Spider-Man, Superman and other comic book stars were entertainment industry weaklings. Movie, television and video-game characters drew more attention. But now the superheroes are back in all their glory. Comic book sales are up and publishers are churning out new titles to feed a growing market.

title: 'La Bete' (Rhymes With Set) Arrives
description: Eccentricity is forever getting mixed up with originality. The woman who paints her fingernails black and her lips puce is thought to be original, as is the man who shares his one-room apartment with an iguana, three chickadees and a Dandie Dinmont terrier. Whenever people are expected to deliver words of appreciation -- and those words just aren't forthcoming, "How original!" is the catch phrase that's usually rushed into the breach. It is said of artworks fashioned out of old galoshes and orange rinds, papyrus beach wear and new Brazilian dances.

title: Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor: Sherry Marker's piece on the Horned Dorset Primavera in Rincon, P.R. (Travel, Jan. 6), omitted our personal candidate for the greatest, most unspoiled beach in the Americas, the municipal beach at Anasco, a bare stone's throw from the Horned Dorset Primavera. The rough surf of Rincon is beautifully balanced by the utter calm of Anasco, which, despite its milelong beach, has never sported more than 10 or 15 people at any time that we've been there. The net fishermen ply their trade while bathers gaze at the sea and at los pechos in the distance -- two beautifully rounded hills resembling Popocatepetl. HAROLD TICKTIN, ELLEN TICKTIN Cleveland Sherry Marker replies: The municipal beach at Anasco is under 10 minutes away by car and is usually tranquil during the week.

title: Town's Good Reputation Has Become Its Problem
description: Every day Lynn I. Miller looks through his office window at the Loyal Order of Moose and watches buses from big cities pull up across the street and disgorge drug addicts, alcoholics, people with AIDS and welfare families who need everything.

title: A July Wedding For Ms. McGlynn
description: Margaret Mayo McGlynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. McGlynn of Jersey City, and Peter Robert Emshwiller, the son of Carol Emshwiller of New York and the late Edmund A. Emshwiller, are planning a July wedding.

title: Celtics Win One At Forum
description: Robert Parish says it's special when the Boston Celtics win at the Forum.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: "UNCLE PETE," the small voice asked, "can I maybe look at your shotgun, now?"

title: A Big 'Yes!' For Marv Albert
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 3 on Marriage, Death and Life
description: MARRIAGE is such a state of relentless and noisy dissension that its combatants don't even have to call for help. Take Tod and Susan Simon. Hearing their distress signals, the repairman -- the matrimonial repairman, that is -- appears.

title: Blackford Oakes Goes to Nam
description: TUCKER'S LAST STAND By William F. Buckley Jr. 259 pp. New York: Random House.

title: Tech Notes; A Faster Way to Make Computers
description: A new class of transistor is being developed as a effort of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the International Business Machines Corporation. The new device turns on or off on the power of just a single electron. Conventional transistors require currents many times more massive before they will turn on or off to create the binary messages of computing. The new device is constructed like a four-layer sandwich of gallium arsenide, aluminum arsenide and gallium arsenide, topped off with a metallic layer that serves as a conductor. The gallium layers contain impurities, or "dope," that provide a source of electrons. At present, the transistor works only at temperatures approaching absolute zero, but the researchers say that problem can be solved. Although still years from commercialization, the new device could be used to fabricate computers far faster than any in use today.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: VIVIAN E. GREENBERG;
The Stress in Caring for Aged Parents
description: THE title of Vivian E. Greenberg's book, "Your Best Is Good Enough: Aging Parents and Your Emotions," sums up her philosophy, developed in 14 years as a clinical social worker specializing in the counseling of the elderly and the adult children who care for them.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Bearing Up

title: Foreshadowing A Short Recession
description: The stock market's reputation as an economic seer looks like it is about to get another boost. The American recession, which seemed so fierce only a couple of months ago, now seems to have eased as the new year began.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WORLD ON FIRE Saving an Endangered Earth. By George J. Mitchell. Scribner's, $22.50.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Geri Allen: The Nurturer Blue Note CDP 7 95139 2; all three formats.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 17, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 10 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 2 3 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures. 3 3 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $6.95.) The history of the sea islands. 4 3 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Warner, $5.95.) Adam Dalgliesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 5 4 THE CONQUEST, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $5.50.) Romance bonds two long-feuding feudal families in 15th-century England. 6 4 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) A physician struggles to clear his name. 7 18 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 8 3 MERCY, by David L. Lindsey. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Houston detective on the trail of a killer. 9 2 SECRET SONG, by Catherine Coulter. (Onyx, $4.95.) A handsome rogue sets out to rescue an imprisoned young woman in 13th-century Britain. 10 8 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving ceremonial masks. 11 26 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A Louisiana belle finds romance, power and wealth in the post-Civil War West. 13 10 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 14 2 GHOST-WALKER, by Barbara Hambly. (Pocket, $4.95.) The crew members of "Star Trek" 's Enterprise have to contend with an elusive entity when they bring relief to a troubled planet. 15 * 6 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Signet, $5.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. 16 * 28 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. Prognostications for the next decade. 6 65 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 7 1 AWAKENINGS, by Oliver Sacks. A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 10 2 REPUBLIC OF FEAR, by Samir al-Khalil. (Pantheon, $12.95.) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 12 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Data and maps relevant to the war in the Persian Gulf. 4 9 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 5 120 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 3 about a Mozart bicentennial at the Hofstra University Cultural Center misidentified the translator of the play "Sincerely Yours, Mozart." He is Alex Szogyi, professor of French and comparative literature at Hunter College.

title: Hill-Hearns Delayed
description: The quest for a more lucrative pay-per-view cable television audience has led to the postponement of the Virgil Hill-Thomas Hearns light heavyweight title bout. The fight, which had been scheduled for Friday, May 17, at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., has been moved to Monday, June 3, hotel officials said Friday.

title: Harrison Turns to Court for Cleanup of Dump
description: COMPLAINING that the Westchester District Attorney has failed to have a foul-smelling illegal landfill in Harrison cleaned up, the town is suing the haulers it says are responsible for dumping 45,000 tons of industrial waste in a residential neighborhood.

title: Sense of Emptiness Troubles Bombay's Jews
description: An old man sits alone in a corner of the synagogue, prayer book in hand, waiting for a congregation that may never come.

title: Correction
description: Pictures of two engaged couples on page 70 today are reversed. Matthew Toll and Ann Tweedy are at the left. Randall Havas and Melissa Weissberg are at the right.

title: A Roman View
description: The Hotel Hassler's rooftop restaurant on the Piazza Trinita dei Monti in Rome, known for its views of many of the city's ancient landmarks, has reopened after being closed for several months during renovation of the hotel. The restaurant is on the sixth floor, one of the highest spots in the center of the city. Sights that customers spot include the Spanish Steps, the Victor Emmanuel Monument, the twin domes of the Trinita dei Monti Church, several palaces and, on the horizon, the dome of St. Peter's. The Hassler roof, which seats up to 70 people, is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner (7 to 11 P.M.). Dinner with wine will cost $50 to $75 a person. Telephone 6782651.

title: Saddam's Signal; Underneath The Theatrics, A First Hint Of Concession
description: STRIP away the conditions, the flowery language and the hoopla surrounding the latest Iraqi peace overture and what you are left with is a core fact: Saddam Hussein flinched.

title: Cathleen Colella To Marry in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Colella of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Cathleen Colella, and Gordon Graham Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Graham of New York.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 17, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 2 2 6 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 3 4 4 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of marines from Midway to Guadalcanal. 4 1 FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) When she establishes a newspaper in Dakota Territory, a young woman finds familial problems and romance. 5 3 18 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age. 6 6 4 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia. 7 7 9 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. 8 1 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury finds himself a suspect in the strange death of a widow from England's Lake District. 9 5 6 THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert. 10 14 2 MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) The romantic and professional lives of a homicide detective become entangled as he investigates a murder in the Hamptons. 11 11 3 MIDDLE PASSAGE, by Charles Johnson. (Atheneum, $17.95.) A newly liberated slave learns about himself and the world during a voyage to Africa in the early 19th century. 12 8 12 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of a California woman who becomes a photographer. 13 9 5 VITAL SIGNS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $21.95.) A physician's quest for fertility brings her horrifying adventures in America, Australia and China. 14 12 15 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 15 10 12 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician uses genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 13 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 2 * 1 3 THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present. 3 3 14 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the itinerant television newscaster. 4 4 28 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 5 12 4 PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor. 6 5 19 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 7 7 21 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 8 6 5 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 9 * 9 5 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish and Muslim children. 10 8 14 BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays both baseball and football. 11 11 14 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 12 1 AND THE SEA WILL TELL, by Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. (Norton, $22.95.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a Pacific atoll. 13 * 10 17 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. 14 1 THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY NO, by Shintaro Ishihara. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A Japanese politician contends his homeland will surpass the United States and become "first among equals." 15 15 6 GOD, COUNTRY, NOTRE DAME, by Theodore M. Hesburgh with Jerry Reedy. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The autobiography of the theologian and former president of the University of Notre Dame. A Florida entrepreneur's advice about managing your money. 2 1 27 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 3 3 99 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Financial advice. 4 4 17 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. 5 6 11 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. title: Article 386991 -- No Title
description: More than $500,000 in cash was stolen from automatic teller machines in a Chemical Bank branch on 60th Street off Lexington Avenue, the police said yesterday.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GHETTO IN VILNIUS

title: Miss Whitehead Wed in Minnesota
description: Kimberly Sandford Whitehead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Marc Whitehead of Wayzata, Minn., was married there yesterday to John Sedberry Puckett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Puckett 3d of Signal Mountain, Tenn. The Rev. Willard V. Albertson performed the United Church of Christ ceremony at the Wayzata Community Church.

title: Sports News Briefs; Pro Soccer League Planned in Japan
description: Ten teams were picked last week for Japan's first professional soccer league, scheduled to begin operation in the fall of 1992 or the spring of 1993.

title: The Short Century -- It's Over
description: The 20th century is now over, and there are two extraordinary matters about this.

title: Dohnanyi Withdraws From Orchestra Tour
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi has withdrawn from the Cleveland Orchestra's East Coast tour because of a spinal disk problem, a spokesman for the conductor has announced. Leonard Slatkin will conduct the orchestra on Saturday at Carnegie Hall, in a revised program: the New York premiere of an oboe concerto by Ellen Taaffe Zwilich (John Mack, soloist), the Vaughan Williams Fifth Symphony, and the "Russian Easter" Overture by Rimsky-Korsakov.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: EMILY PEEL;
Why 4-Year-Olds Are Good Linguists
description: WITH the belt tightening on government spending, expanding foreign-language instruction to elementary schools might seem extravagant. But Emily Peel, president of the Connecticut Council of Language Teachers, says earlier is better.

title: Wall Street; A Money Manager's Soap Opera
description: One of the hottest new trends on Wall Street has been a staple of romantic fiction since Shakespeare was a pup. You know the plot: The girl has been betrothed for years to the mild but reliable boy-next-door, but she is drawn to the dashing but unpredictable drifter. In the Wall Street version, the heroine is played by your corporate pension fund.

title: A Nice Change From the Usual
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Australia News Groups Facing Tough Times
description: Australian news organizations, normally among the world's most vigorous, are facing severe financial difficulties in this country's deep recession. A leading newspaper group and two of the three private television networks have been forced into receivership and are expected to be sold to pay off billions of dollars in debt.

title: Schnitzel
description: To the Editor: Ann Pringle Harris's article on Wiener schnitzel (Travel, Nov. 11) was charming, but there is a warning you owe your readership.

title: Wallace W. Elton, 83, Former Ad Executive
description: Wallace Wesley Elton, a former advertising executive and a retired senior vice president of the International Executive Services Corporation, died on Thursday of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Artist Makes Masks to Reveal, Not Conceal
description: IN life everyone wears a mask. It communicates who he is or is pretending to be. Diane Churchill, an artist and teacher, helps strip away that persona and capture the true essence of power and mystery of the human face in her life mask workshop.

title: Persian Gulf War Pains Indoor Player
description: Waad Hirmez plays midfield for the San Diego Sockers of the Major Soccer League. The eight-year veteran is a favorite of the few, but loyal, fans who follow the indoor league. Like many of his teammates and opponents, Hirmez was born in another country. But, it is that country, Iraq, that carries a dramatic significance today.

title: Suspect Tied to Medellin Cartel Leadership Becomes 3d to Surrender
description: One of the country's most-wanted drug-trafficking suspects, Juan David Ochoa, surrendered today.

title: Stoned in the Streets of Moscow
description: SOVIET SOCIAL PROBLEMS Edited by Anthony Jones, Walter D. Connor and David E. Powell. Illustrated. 318 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press. Cloth, $52. Paper, $19.95.

title: Pro Basketball; Detroit's New Leading Model
description: Joe Dumars is best known for his lack of apparent emotion, especially compared with his more demonstrative Detroit Piston teammates. Recently, however, it has become easier to read his feelings.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MORNING GLORY WAR By Judy Glassman. 119 pp. New York: Dutton Children's Books. $13.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Last-Minute Bargains
description: IT used to be that people who usually took a winter vacation in the Caribbean made their reservations before Thanksgiving. But this year, when the Caribbean Hoteliers Association met in Bermuda two days before the Persian Gulf war began, they saw a clear impact of the recession in the United States. The hoteliers were quick to say that tourists were still coming, but that they were not putting cash on the line until just a couple of weeks before departure.

title: A Rare Garden in Barbados
description: AFTER the first delicious blast of tropical air, what strikes a visitor most upon arrival at Grantley Adams International Airport in Barbados are the long moist beds of tropical plants that run the length of the covered concourse. Credit for this fragrant welcome mat is due to one of the most distinguished gardeners of the Caribbean, the late Iris Bannochie. By providing plant material and design suggestions to both public and private gardens in Barbados, she greatly enhanced the island's horticultural heritage.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: Reich's important and disturbing article contained the most shocking sentence that I have read in a long time: "The number of private security guards in the United States now exceeds the number of public police officers." That tells us more about America today than we want to know. Why ever did Reich deem that statement parenthetical? NARDI REEDER CAMPION Hanover, N.H.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portsmouth, N.H.;
55 House Lots Off the Links
description: DESPITE the recession and the dormant real estate market, the owners of the Wentworth by-the-Sea resort are planning to develop 55 house lots around the resort's 18-hole shorefront golf course.

title: SOHO STARES AT HARD TIMES
description: Among the half-truths and misinformation in Servin's article are some regarding the Julian Schnabel painting, "Anh in a Spanish Landscape," at Sotheby's sale last November.

title: A 90's WESTERN; Richly Portrayed Period Piece
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Revolution As Seen By Caryl Churchill
description: "Light Shining in Buckinghamshire" is a challenging play on the subject of revolution -- the English civil war of the 17th century. Written in 1976, this was Caryl Churchill's first collaboration with the Joint Stock Theater Group, with playwright, actors and director immersing themselves in a historical canvas and creating a dramatic collage of a turbulent time.

title: The Last of the Red Hot Playwrights
description: They were once a prolific breed -- the Broadway playwrights -- and almost as dependable as the swallows at Capistrano. Every season or so, you could find their names on a marquee, and each name -- from Arthur Miller to Tennessee Williams, Paddy Chayevsky to Lillian Hellman -- commanded its loyal following.

title: Peter Sellars Digs Up 'The Cabinet'
description: What has he done now? The enfant terrible, the precocious one, the spiky-haired iconoclast: What has he done?

title: Two Old Churches of the Tarrytowns Come Together
description: AS the cathedral bell pealed one recent Sunday, members of the Second Reformed Church in Tarrytown milled about the pews of their church, chatting excitedly. Most wore name tags.

title: Audio Engineers Vs. Musicians
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 18-21

title: When the Script Is a Grim Fairy Tale
description: After he gives her incense that conjures the ghost of an old boyfriend, even before he hands over the herb tea that beckons forth a wisecracking muse, the mysterious Dr. Yang offers something more valuable to the mixed-up heroine of Woody Allen's "Alice." He explains the fantasy that has invaded this ordinary woman's life. "In times of very great stress," the wise man says, "ghosts appear."

title: Men's Style; Mob a la Mode
description: Clothes confer charisma, separating the slob from the snob, and in the case of gangland's elite, the punk from the polished don. Aware of this, film makers have focused on fashion in several recent mobster sagas, using suits to convey anything from slipperiness to flamboyance. On Andy Garcia in "The Godfather Part III," a double-breasted suit suggests an almost marmoreal gravity, gained as he forsakes his streetwise leather jackets for a forbidding corporate style.

title: D'Amato Discouraged by Talks on Baltics
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York returned from a five-day trip to the Soviet Union today saying he was very discouraged by his meeting with Soviet representatives on the issue of human rights in the Baltic republics.

title: Mad Dog Is A Preppie!
description: For six months, a young man trudged off to speech therapy classes every Tuesday and Thursday morning. Since he was employed as a sports-radio host, his station thought it would be a good idea if listeners could understand him.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: I believe America's class problems are real; however, Reich's article describes the symptoms , not the problems. The separation of classes is a result of the inability of current systems to cope with the complexities of the 1990's. Take education. Why are public schools so poorly managed and structured?

title: This Olympic Coach Better Not Lose
description: In the Olympics' devotion to athletes, team coaches in any sport never receive what they are assigned to produce: a gold medal. And in Barcelona next year more than ever before, the United States Olympic basketball coach must produce a gold medal.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Moscow Tempers Its Satisfaction at Baghdad Offer
description: The Soviet Union today tempered its initial satisfaction over Iraq's offer to discuss withdrawing from Kuwait with a statement that the conditions set by Baghdad could render the proposal meaningless. A spokesman said, nevertheless, that the Kremlin still hoped that the Iraqi proposal could become an opening to a political settlement.

title: A Fall Wedding For Kristin Smith
description: Fall wedding plans for Dorothy Kristin Smith and Colin Macrae Sykes, the son of Mrs. William H. Perry of Kent, Conn., and of Richard Sykes of Oyster Bay, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Smith of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; Iraqi Dissidents in Syria Reflecting Damascus's Complex Policy on War
description: Akram el-Hakim dreams of overthrowing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the name of Islam. Fakhri Kareem nurtures the same hope, though for him, it is Karl Marx, not divinity, that provides the inspiration.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Hoping to Defy the Odds in Bridgewater
description: AT a time when office vacancy rates are up and construction starts are down, earthmovers are busy preparing to build the second phase of a large mixed-use project on 122 acres in Somerset County's Bridgewater Township.

title: Amanda Edelbaum to Marry in June
description: Amanda R. Edelbaum, a daughter of Candy Edelbaum and Jon F. Edelbaum, both of New York, is to be married in June to Neal Moszkowski, a son of Dr. Enrique Moszkowski of Buenos Aires and Paris and the late Dr. Erica F. Moszkowski.

title: The Largesse Of Samuel Kress
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann E. Tweedy, Student, Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Tweedy 3d of Moorestown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Elizabeth Tweedy to Matthew Mitchell Toll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Toll of Kenilworth, Ill. An August wedding is planned.
