title: Turkish Immigrants Strike Gold at Gas Stations
description: YILDRIM ENES stepped off a plane from Turkey in 1980 with his wife, a son and "very little money." Today he owns a home in Dix Hills with a pool in the back and a Mercedes-Benz in front.

title: Commercial Property: 712 Fifth Avenue; High Hopes, and Vacancy, for a 4-Building Complex
description: "BATTERED" is a word used by architects to mean sloping walls. The 712 Fifth Avenue project, at 56th Street, has been battered in more ways than one.

title: A Thoroughly Domestic Betrayal
description: THE ROAD TO LICHFIELD By Penelope Lively. 216 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $17.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COLLECTING FLIES

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; 3 Big Companies Quit Career Fair Over War Protest
description: After being notified of possible anti-war protests on campus, two major manufacturers of defense equipment - the Raytheon Corporation and Pratt & Whitney - decided not to attend the annual career fair at the University of Massachusetts last week. And representatives from Exxon, who arrived Tuesday night, left the fair before noon the next day after having learned that demonstrations were taking place.

title: Earl Smith, 87, Ambassador to Cuba in the 1950's
description: Earl E. T. Smith, a financier and sportsman who was Ambassador to Cuba when Fidel Castro came to power, died Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs; Proposals Made On a Tiger Home
description: The Wayne County Executive, Ed McNamara, in a move to keep the Tigers in Detroit, has proposed substantial financial support to renovate or replace 88-year-old Tiger Stadium.

title: Technology; Using Computer Engineering To Mimic the Movement of the Bow
description: In a darkened studio at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory, Michael Hawley composes music with a Sun Microsystems computer work station that controls 64 music synthesizers and a modified Bosendorfer concert grand piano. The system permits Mr. Hawley, a 29-year-old software designer, to create and play complex scores on the piano, accompanied by a synthetic orchestra.

title: Exiled Romanian King Has Hopes of Return
description: King Michael says "the signs are encouraging" for him to return as the ruler of Romania, the country he was expelled from after forced abdication by the Communist leadership more than 43 years ago.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The doors in my 25-year-old house, which I think were originally varnished, now need refinishing. The bathroom doors have a dry whitish look near the bottom, and others show scratch and scuff marks. What should I use and how should I proceed?

title:
TELEVISION;
The Man Could Make A Short Story Long
description: Just a few weeks ago, I sat on a dais at a dinner honoring George Burns on the occasion of his 95th birthday. Next to me sat Milton Berle; next to Berle, George Burns; next to Burns, Danny Thomas. Picture Mount Rushmore -- with cigars.

title: Biographers and Their Subjects
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealand Budget Lodging
description: Travelers seeking budget accommodations in New Zealand will find several in a free flier, Good Bed Guide, available from the New Zealand Tourism Office, but they must join the United States Youth Hostel Asssociation to use them. The guide lists 51 hostels on North and South Islands where overnight fees for one person are $5 to $12 (in United States funds). All hostels except one offer kitchens, showers, bathrooms, dining rooms, laundry facilities and bedrooms. Some have family rooms for couples. The exception is Okarito, one of the $5-a-person hostels, which has no electricity and is described as a shelter hostel. At Okarito, on the west coast of South Island, cooking is done over an open fire and candles provide light. Activities include coastal and forest walks and fishing. Among other hostels are two in Auckland, with fees of approximately $10 and $12 a person; one in Wellington, $10, and two in Christchurch, $8 and $10. The guide can be had by writing to the New Zealand Tourism Office, 501 Santa Monica Boulevard, Santa Monica, Calif. 90401.

title: An Italian Bistro With a View in Stamford
description: DOLCE, which calls itself an Italian bistro, has chosen a sweet spot for its new restaurant at Stamford Landing, one with panoramic views overlooking the marina and west branch of Stamford harbor. Though two previous restaurants have occupied the spacious second-floor site, Dolce shows signs -- judging by its creative menu, culinary skills and expert service -- of breaking the jinx of this hard-to-find location.

title: A Flash Fire Kills Nine in a House in Connecticut
description: A fire swept through a three-story tenement early this morning, killing at least nine people, fire officials said.

title: Aquatic Park Fought in Calverton
description: ADVENTURELAND plans to open in May a $5 million water-theme park on a 28-acre site in Calverton.

title: The Nation; War and Recession Speed Up the Airlines' Flights to Oblivion
description: FOR America's airlines, the friendly skies are a distant memory. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, the jump in jet fuel prices, economic recession and fears of terrorism have added to the industry's angst. United States carriers lost $2 billion in the last quarter of 1990, and analysts expect them to lose another $1.5 billion or so in the first three months of this year. More than 25,000 airline workers have lost their jobs. Eastern Airlines finally folded last month, and others are clearly on the endangered list.

title: Behind the Black Lace Curtain
description: TWO GIRLS, FAT AND THIN By Mary Gaitskill. 304 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: Your Own Account; Taking the Legwork Out of Travel
description: If you are indeed a frequent flier -- logging 80,000 miles a year or more -- you may find that figuring out the best method of accumulating your bonus miles and cashing them in for leisure travel takes nearly as much time as flying.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The doors in my 25-year-old house, which I think were originally varnished, now need refinishing. The bathroom doors have a dry whitish look near the bottom, and others show scratch and scuff marks. What should I use and how should I proceed?

title: Martha Keaveny To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Keaveny 2d of Northbrook, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Shannon Keaveny, to Richard New Bradt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bradt Jr. of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Chess
description: Each chess generation has to make its own way by finding new strategies. To leave yesterday's plans and stratagems just where you found them would turn the game into a routine exercise that would take much of the fun out of it.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
description: UNEQUAL EQUITIES Power and Risk in Japan's Stock Market. By Robert Zielinski and Nigel Holloway. 246 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $21.95.

title: Gale Hayman Has a Wedding
description: Gale Hayman, a cosmetics entrepreneur in Beverly Hills, Calif., was married at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday to Dr. William Alan Haseltine, a medical researcher from Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony.

title: America, Heal Thyself
description: THE NEXT CENTURY By David Halberstam. 126 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: The View From Inside
description: NO ESCAPE The Future of American Corrections. By John J. DiIulio Jr. 301 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Pileated Woodpecker At Work
description: I read with interest the Jan. 20 article "In the Natural State" on the pileated woodpecker, following as it did my own recent encounter with this bird.

title: Paired by a Show and by Marriage
description: IN times gone by, married artists were loath to exhibit together. The reasons were never spelled out, but it is likely that professional jealousy was one.

title: Streetscapes: The Miller Highway; Razed or Rebuilt, It's a Lost Cause
description: THE story is a common one: community groups arguing with the city about demolition versus repair of an old city-owned structure. But in the case of the last remaining section of the Miller Highway -- the viaduct along the Hudson River between 59th and 72d Streets -- it is the city that wants to repair it and the community groups that want it demolished.

title: Elizabeth C. Nott, Teacher, Marries
description: Elizabeth Colahan Nott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Nott 4th of Coconut Grove, Fla., was married yesterday to Roger Barclay Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Griffin Hall of Philadelphia. The Rev. Henry N. F. Minich performed the ceremony at the Chapel of the Venerable Bede at the Episcopal Church Center in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: 'Robin Hood' Turns Over a New Leaf in Sherwood Forest
description: Robin Hood has acquired a new buddy: a princely Moor with whom he escapes from captivity during the Crusades. That is one of several twists to an old tale in "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves." The latest saga from Sherwood Forest has recently finished four months of filming in England and is an epic movie said to have cost $60 million (the producers are a little shy about revealing the exact figure). The film is directed by a Spielberg protege, Kevin Reynolds, written by two English expatriates, Pen Densham and John Watson, and stars Kevin Costner in his first role since "Dances With Wolves."

title: Managing; A Matter of Supplier-Customer Trust
description: Sherwin-Williams Inc., the big paint company, recently let executives from Sears, Roebuck Inc. help select the people who would service the Sears account. "We and Sears already had joint sales and product-turnover goals, so it made sense to jointly select the people who can make those goals happen," said T. Scott King, a vice president of sales for Sherwin-Williams.

title: The Pleasures of Playing Architect
description: I played with architectural toys as a child, but then, who didn't? Wooden blocks, tiny buildings, and construction games are so common that it is easy to forget that they, too, have a history. I was reminded of that history by the current exhibition of architectural toys at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal (through March 31).

title: On the Trail of the Late-Night Crows
description: A FEW yards from a bakery Amy Freiman stood, clutching a stuffed crow. "After tonight you will never look at a crow the same way," Ms. Freiman said.

title: The Way One Daddy Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Executive Life; Safety for 1990 Is a Low - or No - Profile
description: Last spring, when Citicorp shareholders got the company's 1989 annual report, they found dozens of photographs of the bank's top executives, including three of John S. Reed, chairman. In this year's report, to be mailed to investors next month, there will be pictures of Citicorp customers around the world, but there may be few -- possibly even none -- of Mr. Reed or top management.

title: Pendulums
description: To the Editor: My father sent me a copy of E. Oscar Kosberg's Nov. 25 letter concerning the Sept. 23 article "Tracking Down Foucault's Pendulum."

title: How Do Children Feel About the War?
description: "DO you remember where you were when the war broke out?" Dr. Mary Rose Paster asked the fourth and fifth graders sitting on the carpet in the Portledge School library in Locust Valley.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;
Baseball Park As a Catalyst
description: THE prospect of a 46,000-seat, downtown baseball stadium just west of the Inner Harbor is raising hopes for the rejuvenation of the surrounding commercial district.

title: Perspectives: Foreclosure in a Co-op; Traveling the Road That Bankers Shun
description: IT has fallen to three modest-looking walk-ups on 61st Street east of Lexington Avenue to become the first Manhattan co-op in modern times in which a lender has obtained a foreclosure judgment.

title: Bernard King Shows Doubters
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mutual Funds; Bargains in Single-Country Clones
description: In a classic psychological study, a salesman showed shoppers two pairs of shoes, identical except for the price. When the customers asked, the salesman stressed that only the price was different. Yet most shoppers bought the more expensive pair.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;
Houses to Rise From Rubble
description: TWO-HUNDRED-FIFTY low-income families will be able to buy new or rehabilitated rowhouseshere for as little as $35,000, about one-fourth their development cost, over the next four years.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; GROUND STRATEGY: FOCUS ON REAR LINE
description: To battle Iraqi forces in a ground war, American Army divisions are expected to drive into Iraqi territory in a swift offensive action designed to bypass Iraq's main defensive fortifications and to cut off the Iraqi Army in Kuwait, military experts say.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Robert Westbrook's novel "The Left-Handed Policeman," published in 1986, was not greeted with any great enthusiasm by this reviewer. Since then Mr. Westbrook has developed a style and gained in assurance; he knows how to mix satire with the action elements of a police procedural. All of this is present in LADY LEFT (Crown, $17.95), and an attractive book it is.

title: Margaret E. Rhea Has a Wedding
description: Margaret Elizabeth Rhea, the daughter of Mrs. Claude Hiram Rhea Jr. and the late Dr. Rhea of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to David McSweeney, a son of Mrs. William James McSweeney of Barrington, Ill., and the late Mr. McSweeney. The Rev. Dr. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the Sea.

title: Philadelphia Officials Find More Cases of Measles
description: City health officials said today they might have uncovered up to 500 more active and recent cases of measles among children who attend two churches that preach reliance on faith, rather than medical care, to cure disease.

title: A Mellowed Polemicist Retains His Edge
description: From 1971 to 1977, the French composer and conductor Pierre Boulez was an almost constant presence on the New York music scene. As music director of the New York Philharmonic, he horrified conservative audiences and critics by offering large doses of new and unfamiliar music alongside the standard repertory. And as chief polemicist for the Serial avant-garde, he wielded a sharp tongue and a sharper pen, championing those who shared his vision of the future of music, denouncing those who clung to the relics of history.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Airbourne Troopers; From Officers to Grunts, Anticipation of Combat
description: "One day, yeah. The next day, no," said Staff Sgt. Wayne O'Neil of the 101st Airborne Division, pondering whether he wanted to end the current relentless bombing of Iraq and begin a ground war.

title:
FORUM;
Computers, and a Sealed Room in Israel
description: Tonight I am sitting in a sealed room in Haifa, Israel, thinking about the Department of Commerce in Washington. I hope the plastic sheets that cover the windows and the masking tape that seals the door of my room will hold back the as-yet-to-materialize clouds of nerve gas and toxins that Iraq's President Saddam Hussein has promised to send us.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Feb. 2 MANHATTAN Chelsea 157,000 10 West 15th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room; maintenance $649, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Herbert H. Kleigerman Associates) East Midtown 485,000 110 East 57th Street (Dorchester) 1-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2,350-sq.-ft. penthouse co-op in a postwar building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, greenhouse/dining room, library, marble baths, wraparound terrace; maintenance $4,085, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Key Ventures) SoHo 265,000 90 Prince Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. condo in a renovated loft building; elevator, darkroom, high-ceilings, decorative columns; common charge $196, taxes $2,076 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Upper East Side 505,000 140 East 72d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining ell, 3 exposures; maintenance $875, 44% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper West Side 325,000 253 West 73d Street (Level Club) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,108-sq.-ft. condo in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, windowed kitchen; common charge $560, taxes $2,616 (Broker: Century 21/Lewis n' Clark) BRONX Riverdale 120,000 4705 Henry Hudson Parkway (Windsor South) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,070-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining el, terrace; maintenance $832, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) Wakefield 164,000 1043 East 233d Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached, brick house; dining room, hospitality suite in finished basement, 3-car garage, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,490 (Broker: Charles G. Brophy & Associates) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights 295,000 167 Clinton Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op in a town house; dining room, renovated kitchen, 2 fireplaces; maintenance $795, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Harborview Realty) Canarsie 243,000 1133 East 103d Street 2-family, attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths, dining room in primary unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, eat-in kitchen in other; finished basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,620 (Broker: Helmar Realty) Flatlands 175,000 1670 Schnectady Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semiattached, brick house; dinette, finished basement, 1-car garage, 22- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,120 (Broker: Reliance Real Estate) QUEENS Forest Hills 230,000 68-18 Groton Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, attached, brick house; finished basement, 1-car garage, 18- 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Madeleine Realty) Fresh Meadows 244,000 67-07 181st Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, Tudor-style house; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,700 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills 162,000 19 Goodall Street 2-family, detached, frame house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, eat-in kitchen in each; 25- by 135-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Schlott Realtors) St. George 275,000 9 Phelps Place 5-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, frame Victorian; dining room, 3 fireplaces, pine-plank floors, 1-car garage, 40- by 148-ft. lot; taxes $1,500 (Broker: Pearl Foreman Real Estate)

title: 'Complete Player' Sparks Fairfield Basketball Team
description: LISA MIKELIC'S basketball skills are rooted in her childhood, she said. "When I was younger, I used to play with my brother and his friends," recalled Ms. Mikelic, a senior forward on the Fairfield University women's basketball team. "I was the only girl. If I wanted to play, I had to pass the ball."

title: Salvadoran Peace Talks Stall as Voting Nears
description: With significant progress reported in recent weeks in peace talks between the Salvadoran Government and guerrilla representatives, many here had begun to hope that a negotiated settlement might soon be found to end the bloody 11-year civil war that has killed more than 70,000 people.

title: Lindsay Valentine Wed in Richmond
description: Lindsay Carter Valentine, a daughter of Mrs. Edwin T. Boyd Jr. of Richmond and the late C. Braxton Valentine Jr., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Richmond to John Randolph Chambliss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Chambliss Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. W. Holt Souder officiated.

title: Tracy Lynne Judd to Wed David George Lucas Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gordon Judd Jr. of Marlboro, N.J., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Tracy Lynne Judd and David George Lucas Jr., the son of Judge and Mrs. Lucas of Somerville, N.J.

title: U.S. Warnings On 4 Countries In Wake of War
description: Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Tanzania are among countries cited by the State Department in travel advisories warning of the increased threat of possible terrorist actions against Americans as a result of the Persian Gulf war. Here are details of those advisories:

title: FOCUS: Chicago; New Challenge for the 'Magnificent Mile'
description: WITH the opening last September of a third vertical mall on this city's fashionable North Michigan Avenue, some questioned whether the "Magnificent Mile" could absorb its 320,000 square feet of additional space.

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: Having visited Wurzburg's Residenz twice in the last two years I was delighted to read Olivier Bernier's article. While Mr. Bernier points out that the Residenz is a triumph, I think it somewhat of a slight not to mention the rose garden abloom all summer with hundreds of bushes. In addition, the formal gardens extend deeply behind the main building to a magnificent double-tiered staircase, which leads to terraces providing sumptuous views of the Residenz complex. At each level the staircases are adorned with fanciful cherubs and other rococo figures. Yet another feature is the formal hedges trained over frames to provide shade in summer. LEE SNIDER New York, N.Y.

title: Kerith Stern to Marry Philip Rudnicki
description: The engagement of Kerith Stern to Philip Jay Rudnicki, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Rudnicki of Bloomfield, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Stern of Plantation, Fla. A July wedding is planned.

title: 3 Held in Drug Raid Charged in Killing of a Hofstra Coach
description: Three men were charged yesterday in the murder of a Hofstra University football coach last September, the Nassau County police said.

title: Postings: Chimney Corners; Inn Is Out, Shops Are In
description: For more than a half century, the rambling inn with the cut-out figure of a horse-drawn sleigh on the roof was a dining landmark just off the Long Road exit of the Merritt Parkway in Stamford, Conn. But the Chimney Corner Inn, assembled from the parts of several buildings, some dating back 150 years, fell on hard and changing times. Last year, the sturdy old rooms that had seen two generations of families dine was sold to the Fieber Group, shopping center developers of Wilton, who have since pulled down all but one section of the restaurant.

title: It Is 1991, and the Nazis Have Returned to Vilna
description: An anonymous old man lies in a Jerusalem hospital bed, an oxygen mask pressed against his face. It is 1991 and bombs are falling. Their explosions release a flood of memories from 50 years before, when he crawled out of a mass grave to escape extermination by the Nazis. The doctor who saved his life in the hospital of the Vilna ghetto in Lithuania appears at his bedside. There are gunshots. A funeral procession winds its way into the hospital room. Past and present converge until they are indistinguishable.

title: Buyer and Seller Agree, But Lenders May Say No
description: UNEASY over declining home prices and surging foreclosures, many mortgage lenders are casting a more conservative eye on the deals buyers make with sellers and are cutting the amounts of the loans they will make.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the second paragraph of a review by Carol Muske on Jan. 27 about Minnie Bruce Pratt's "Crime Against Nature" omitted or altered several significant words and phrases. A corrected version of the paragraph follows:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston; Designing For Asians
description: AN Asian builder who bought 118 lots from the Resolution Trust Corporahas started building houses on them that will be marketed primarily to Asian home buyers and investors.

title: Former Bangladeshi President's Trial Delayed
description: The trial of the ousted President, H. M. Ershad, on charges of illegal possession of firearms was postponed today when he claimed to be ill and failed to appear before a special tribunal.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: A Clean, Well-Lighted Place Paul Hofmann reminds us that it is frequently in the most unremarkable habits, such as the Italian appetite for espresso, that we can find clues to a country's character. This is from "That Fine Italian Hand" (Owl/Holt, paper).

title: Sampras Pounds McEnroe In 2 Sets
description: John McEnroe turned 32 years old today only to find himself experiencing the indignity of a public manhandling by a mere teen-ager, 19-year-old Pete Sampras, in the semifinals of the United States Pro Indoor championships.

title: New Yorkers Suggest Budget-Rescue Ideas
description: New Yorkers, some of them prominent and some of them not, were asked what they think the city should do in the face of its mounting budget deficit. Should there be service cuts? Layoffs? Tax increases? And do you have any new ideas?

title: Lia Gotsis and Kent Paschal Are Wed
description: Lia Susan Gotsis and Kent Avery Paschal were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. Bishop Isaiah of Aspendos, the Chancellor of the Greek Orthodox Archdicocese of North and South America, officiated.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Brussels
description: Brussels started transforming itself into the capital of Europe in the 60's and hasn't stopped since. With geographical expansion ruled out -- the largely French-speaking capital is an island surrounded by Flemish-speaking Flanders -- this has meant that successive waves of developers have converted one residential area after another into a high-rise cityscape. Construction now under way will add office space equivalent to the twin World Trade Center towers in New York.

title: Social Security Tax Policy: A Democratic Issue for '92?
description: Democratic Congressional leaders are considering a new political offensive based on a proposal to cut the Social Security taxes of most workers by a small amount while increasing the payroll taxes of high-salaried workers.

title: Nassau Prodded Into Fertilizer Plan
description: NASSAU County has apparently given up fighting the Federal and state Governments and will go ahead with plans to produce fertilizer pellets at the Cedar Creek sewage-treatment plant in Wantagh.

title: Postings: Neo-Georgian at 65th; Madison Avenue Facelift
description: Their historic district status notwithstanding, most of the buildings on Manhattan's Upper Madison Avenue in the 60's and 70's are known not for their architecture but for the fashionable boutiques within.

title: Sick and Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Living Beyond Foster Care
description: DENISE SCHULTZ had an avid group of 20 contestants before her as she led a game modeled on "Family Feud." The "contestants" jumped up and down to press a buzzer so they could answer the questions.

title: Updike and Caro Win Book Critics Awards
description: John Updike and Robert A. Caro are among five winners of the 16th annual National Book Critics Circle Awards, announced yesterday after a board meeting in Claremont, Calif.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Hauppauge 182,000 21 Sheila Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old high ranch; den, fireplace, c/a, 2 decks, 2-car garage; taxes $4,800. Kings Park 190,000 23 Cedar Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $6,600. Manhasset Hills 338,800 14 Larch Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old split-level; family room, den, basement, 2-car garage, stone/fieldstone exterior; taxes $6,000. Mineola 227,000 127 Walker Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; family room, deck, new carpeting and windows, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Massapequa 164,000 5 Jackson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Williston Park 180,000 204 Campbell Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, finished basement, Florida room; taxes $2,600. OTHER AREAS Mamaroneck, N.Y. 520,000 572 The Parkway 6-bedroom, 4-bath, 36-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, skylights; taxes $9,013. Danbury, Conn. 210,000 11 King Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old raised ranch; workshop on lower level, 2-tier rear deck, 1.8 acres; taxes $3,216. Wayne, N.J. 250,000 180 Kiwanis Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old contemporary mother/daughter; porch, full basement, large private lot; taxes $3,543.

title: In Crowded Japan, a Bonus For Babies Angers Women
description: With its crowded roads, overstuffed commuter trains and cramped housing, Japan would hardly seem to be in need of more people. So when the Government recently started telling the Japanese to bear more children, many people, especially women, became incensed.

title: Horse Racing; Tracks Working To Lure Crowds
description: You can get more than a $2 bet if you go to the race track these days. You can get a concert, a picnic, a short "horse course," a long lecture, an umbrella, a T-shirt, a chance to pet a pony, a chance to meet a jockey, breakfast at Belmont, breakfast at Santa Anita, free admission sometimes at Gulfstream Park, a family fair, a playground for the kids and a briefing on how to place the bet you might not have placed if you had stayed home.

title: Barbara Lowenthal to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven Lowenthal of Harrison, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Barbara Rebecca Lowenthal and Paul Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Rosenthal of Muttontown, L.I. Miss Lowenthal, 23 years old, graduated from William Smith College and is a student at New York Law School. Mr. Rosenthal, 25, graduated from Cornell University and is a senior analyst with Andersen Consulting, the New York accounting firm.

title: About Men; True Confession
description: I WAS IN THE FIFTH grade when I split from the Roman Catholic Church. Of course, this schism was not of the magnitude of Martin Luther nailing the 95 Theses to the church door at Wittenberg. It was far more subtle.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Hunkering-Down Time in White Plains
description: THE residential market in White Plains, as in most of the country, has been hurt by the recession. The building pace is slow and developers use almost any means to sell units.

title: Judge Allows Bail for a Banker Charged in a Virginia Fraud Case
description: Ruling against the Government, a Federal magistrate here has decided that a former mortgage banker charged with a $500 million fraud and described by prosecutors as "the Charles Keating of Virginia" can be freed on bail because, in the magistrate's view, he is unlikely to flee.

title: Review/Music; National Gallery's New Gifts
description: A second group of gifts to the National Gallery of Art, in celebration of its 50th anniversary, has been announced by J. Carter Brown, the Gallery's director.

title: Silence of the Tiger
description: A severe throat infection has silenced but hardly subdued the Louisiana State basketball coach, Dale Brown, who has continued to coach his team despite doctors orders to keep his mouth shut. Fortunately, there is nothing wrong with his feet. "Even though Coach Brown can't speak, you know what he wants," said Vernel Singleton, an L.S.U. forward, who explained: "When I'm running down the court and see him stomping over there, I know exactly what he means." . . . Jerry Berndt, the Temple coach, has been selected by the New York Metropolitan Football Writers to receive the association's Joseph M. Sheehan Division I-A trophy. Mark Duffner of Holy Cross will receive the Robert (Scotty) Whitelaw Division I-AA trophy and Joe Gardi of Hofstra is the winner of the Irving Marsh/Stan Lomax Division II-III trophy.

title: Demon Deacons Shock Blue Devils
description: Anthony Tucker scored a career-high 31 points to lead five Demon Deacon players in double figures, and Wake Forest used 60 percent shooting in the second half to upset fifth-ranked Duke, 86-77, this afternoon.

title: THE TASTE TYRANTS
description: CAN YOU NAME ALL THE FIRST GROWTHS of Bordeaux? You can? Wonderful. Do you know the names of at least 20 prominent wineries in the Napa Valley. Yes? Excellent.

title: Architects Turning Attention to Prisons
description: WITH the market for new homes and office buildings all but stagnant, architects are turning their attention to what one of them called the "unfortunate challenge" of responding to the demand for more prisons.

title: Numbers Game
description: To hear him tell it, Don Maestri, who has been coaching the Troy State basketball team in Alabama since 1982, was as conservative as coaches come until he happened to catch a Loyola Marymount game on television a couple of years ago and was struck by the high-scoring run-and-fling offense used by the coach, Paul Westhead.

title: Pro Hockey; LaFontaine Agent Angers Torrey
description: Pat LaFontaine, the star center of the Islanders and one of the National Hockey League's elite players, has broken off negotiations with the team and has asked to be traded. The move brought an angry response from Bill Torrey, the Islander president.

title: Headliners; Talk, But Just That, About Global Warming
description: ALMOST two years ago, when President Bush invited delegates for the first international conference to negotiate a treaty to curb global warming, it was a gesture to convince allies and foes that the United States considered the threat to be real.

title: New Jersey Sewage Official Quits After Being Charged in Dumping
description: The director of a municipal sewage authority in Hudson County has resigned in the wake of Federal charges that he dumped 21 million pounds of pollutants into the Hudson River while he had been in charge of a neighboring town's sewage plant.

title: Chrystal LeRoy Has a Wedding
description: Chrystal Ann LeRoy and Edward James Lynch 2d were married yesterday at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I., by the Rev. Peter C. Dooley.

title: Witt's Past Not Forgotten
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Oakland, Calif.;
Federal Tower For Downtown
description: GROUND has been broken for the 1.3 million-square-foot Oakland Federal Building, the largest project in this city's history.

title: Eleni Maria Christopoulos Is Married
description: Eleni Maria Christopoulos, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Christopoulos of Piedmont, Calif., was married in Oakland, Calif., yesterday to Randall George Gianopulos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gianopulos of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Thomas Paris performed the ceremony in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Ascension.

title: Campus Life: George Washington; Undergraduates Take New Tack: Teaching Peers
description: Two George Washington University undergraduates are taking an innovative approach to learning: they are teaching.

title: For China, It's the Year of the Spoiled Child
description: Amid the grabbing and nudging, Zhang Song, a 6-year-old boy who could barely see over the counter, tugged at his mother's arm and pointed to a giant puzzle set of 500 pieces.

title: Behind the Black Lace Curtain
description: FEMALE PERVERSIONSThe Temptations of Emma Bovary.By Louise J. Kaplan.580 pp. New York:Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $24.95.

title: Alison Ryan Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ryan of Amherst, Mass., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Alison Ryan and Robert Minaglia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Minaglia of Arlington Heights, Ill. Ms. Ryan, 26 years old, graduated from the University of Delaware. She is an account supervisor at the Ruder Finn public relations concern in New York City. Mr. Minaglia, 26, graduated from Rutgers University. He is a sales engineer in New York with Hewlett Packard.

title: Hollywood
description: To the Editor: In "Where the Stars Dine Out" (Travel, Jan. 6), Meredith Brody states, "You may find yourself standing in the forecourt of Mann's Chinese Theater wondering if that's all there is."

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DOWN BY THE RIVERBy Monte Schulz.Viking, $19.95.

title: With Knicks, Thrill Is Gone
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Young Entrepreneur Sees Profit in the Cards
description: KLAAS ARMSTER was explaining one of his business problems. "Three years ago," he said, "Pete Rose was the hottest card around -- I mean, definitely in the top five."

title: Video Gambling: Help for State Budget or Just Another Game?
description: IN the wake of public hearings last month on the involvement of organized crime in rigging video poker machines for illegal gambling activities, a bill has been introduced to legalize these machines and funnel a portion of the profits into the state treasury.

title: Wedding in June For Lisina Noel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Noel Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisina Adrienne Noel to Yanko Della Schiava, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Della Schiava of Milan, Italy. A June wedding is planned.

title: Fashion; WATCH THE WAISTLINE!
description: FORGET THE FUSS OVER HEMLINES. INSTEAD, KEEP your eye on waistlines. And on hip lines, for that matter. At the spring couture showings in Paris three weeks ago, one of the clearest messages was that something was going on in the middle. Shoulders seemed the same as usual -- slightly padded but not extreme. And hemlines, while meandering slowly downward, were not dropping with a thunderous bang. But every top designer's collection had waistlines that were snugly nipped or cinched. Clothes that pulled in at the waist and then shaped out over the hip area gave the silhouette a new look. Bear in mind that the Paris couture showings are invariably accurate barometers of fashion change. And when several creators register the same point, the rest of the world is sure to follow.

title: Sports News Briefs; Fair Grounds Asks Extra Racing Day
description: Citing declining business, the 1991-92 season at the Fair Grounds will return to a five-day, Wednesday-through-Sunday racing schedule, the track's president said today.

title: Overwhelmed, but Not by Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Would-Be Skiers Turn to Golf
description: THE unseasonably mild winter has been a disappointing one for ski operators in Connecticut, whose snow-making equipment cannot work effectively when temperatures are above freezing.

title:
ART;
On Dealing With the Issue of Identity
description: AS if to counter the fear that civilization is less and less attuned to the individual's voice, many artists use the personal expose as a device that fuses esthetic self-expression with a desire to communicate on the human level.

title: A New Challenge for Chicago's 'Magnificent Mile'
description: With the opening last September of a third vertical mall on this city's fashionable North Michigan Avenue, some questioned whether the "Magnificent Mile" could absorb its 320,000 square feet of additional space.

title: About That Empty Office Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Yellow Ribbon Dates From Cavalry Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Commonwealth Panel Still Backs Sanctions
description: Commonwealth sanctions against South Africa should not be lifted until Pretoria takes concrete action to abolish apartheid, a committee decided today.

title: Paint, Memory
description: Francesco Clemente made his name in the 1980's as one of a small group of artists who rose to prominence under the banner of Neo-Expressionism, a movement characterized by distortions of form and charged with primal emotion. Androgynous self-portraits and psycho-erotic paintings were characteristic of his early work, but his later pieces have grown progressively more contemplative, writes Raymond Foye in FRANCESCO CLEMENTE: Three Worlds (Rizzoli, $45). The beautifully designed book has been divided into three sections, to correspond to the three cities in which Mr. Clemente works -- Rome, Madras and New York. The Italian designer Ettore Sottsass discusses Mr. Clemente's ability to illustrate such "uncertain states" as memory, nostalgia, complexes and desires. Ann Percy, curator of drawings at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, supplies some biographical information about Mr. Clemente's early years in Naples, where he was born in 1952, and then discusses Arte Povera, the conceptual movement in Rome against which the artist rebelled, choosing instead to return to traditional materials as well as to the human figure. Mr. Foye, an editor and publisher of books about artists, follows with an extensive essay about Clemente in Madras, arguing that the true subject of Clemente's work is "consciousness itself." He also discusses Mr. Clemente's early years in New York, his collaborations with the Beat poets Gregory Corso, Allen Ginsberg and John Wieners, and the artist's working process.

title: Inflation In Yugoslavia
description: Despite a big currency devaluation two months ago, prices in Yugoslavia remain considerably higher than they have been in past years.

title: Review/Music; A Monteverdi Overview in 2 Concerts
description: Chauvinistically speaking, it is upsetting that English early-music groups must still come to New York to show us provincials how things are done, and that they only get here years after they've done the same thing in London, and that when they finally do arrive, they come with reduced touring forces. Those grumbles aside, the two Monteverdi concerts by the Taverner Consort and Players on Sunday afternoon and Tuesday evening proved both didactically enlightening and, more importantly, a nearly unalloyed delight.

title: Miss Tuttle Weds D. C. Shepperly
description: Katherine Ann Tuttle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Tuttle of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. David Curry Shepperly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Shepperly of Cherry Hills Village, Col. The ceremony was performed at Christ Congregational Church in Summit, N.J., by the Rev. Russell Hicks, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. Dr. John D. Talbert, a Baptist minister.

title: Talking: Collections; Getting Delinquents To Pay Up
description: TOUGHER collection strategies are being devised to help mitigate the loss of revenues from the growing number of condominium and cooperative residents falling behind in their monthly common charges or maintenance fees.

title: Looking Ahead
description: SUNDAY: A.F.L.-C.I.O. annual meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla., through Friday. MONDAY: Financial markets, banks and most government offices closed for Presidents' Day. TUESDAY: Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, appears before the House Budget Committee. * Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. WEDNESDAY: Housing starts and permits, consumer prices and real earnings for January. * Treasury auctions two-year notes. * NCR board meeting in Dayton, Ohio. THURSDAY: Jobless claims for week ended Feb. 9. FRIDAY: The Treasury releases its deficit statement for January.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Refugees; Jordanians, Returning Home, Talk of Bombs and Hardship
description: War refugees who trickled into eastern Jordan today reported that the allies' accelerated bombing campaign in Iraq and Kuwait had stripped many cities and towns to the bare bones, with electrical power and running water often completely cut and available food becoming increasingly expensive.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: STERLING;
Tire-Burning Plant Will Let Off Steam To Foster Flowers
description: A PLANT that burns old tires to produce electricity and a series of large greenhouses that can grow anything from hydroponic lettuce to marigold seedlings are unlikely neighbors. But after five years of planning and challenges, the Exeter Energy Project Company in the tiny, rural town of Sterling is ready to show that the two will work together.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: I agree that we should be "a society whose members have abiding obligation to one another." But it is a two-way street. If a large portion of my income is to go to the public schools, I expect kids to study, not to wreck the premises, not to molest each other, etc. If a large portion of my income is to go to the subways, I expect them to be clean and safe. And so on with each public service. RONA SCHNEIDER Brooklyn

title: Natalie Angier, Reporter, to Wed
description: Natalie Marie Angier, a science reporter at The New York Times, and Richard Steven Weiss, a writer at Science News magazine in Washington, have announced their engagement. A September wedding is planned.

title: Hachette Is Paying For Its Hubris
description: If high fashion has a soul, it is French. Givenchy, Christian Lacroix, Yves Saint Laurent, Chanel -- the biggest names in couture hail from Paris. And when the French talk fashion, people listen, or so goes the thinking at Hachette S.A., the giant French publisher whose European magazines include Match, Elle and Tele 7 Jours. When it brought Elle magazine to the United States in 1985 -- the first part of what was to be a major push outside Europe -- Hachette dismissed market research.

title: Postings: Presence of the Past; A Friendlier Crystal Palace
description: Even at lunchtime, when it fills with people, the Crystal Palace atrium at 805 Third Avenue feels cold, barren and forbidding. Its features and fixtures are sharp, angular and spare; its palette is virtually monochromatic, with stainless-steel columns and gray granite walls and floors.

title: Diana Lynn Merrell to Wed Dr. Robert Alan Altman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Merrell of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Diana Lynn Merrell, and Dr. Robert Alan Altman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Altman of Longmeadow, Mass.

title: Speech Center Helps Patients and Families
description: EIGHT-YEAR-OLD John S. has had speech and language therapy for five years, but his mother sometimes still breaks into tears when she talks about his developmental problems.

title: Review/Music; Rostropovich Conducts The Tchaikovsky 2d
description: One of the most compelling things about Mstislav Rostropovich's conducting is that one never knows exactly what to expect from him. Although a listener may arrive at one of his concerts with preconceptions about his repertory affinities, and although the performance may prove them accurate in a general way, the details that make Mr. Rostropovich's readings either great or wayward are not easily predicted.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why America Still Hates the Words 'Energy Policy'
description: SINCE the election of Ronald Reagan, the nation has approached energy policy in the same ambivalent way it has approached sex education: some people think it is indispensable; others think it is none of the government's business. A silent majority appears to grudgingly agree that something is needed. But in Washington the attitude often seems to be, Do we really have to talk about it in public?

title: Children At Hospital Get Chance For Fun
description: KHALIEM ROUNDTREE, 7 years old, lay in traction in his hospital bed like a tiny trapeze artist frozen in space. He laughed after defeating an adversary in a fast-paced board game and then watched as Donielle Smith, 3, stethoscope in hand, darted around the room, checking for heartbeats in every object and person she encountered.

title: Susanna Hodges to Wed Eric D. Salk
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Hodges of Essex, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanna Hodges, to Eric D. Salk, the son of Dr. Lee Salk and Kerstin Andersson, both of New York City. A November wedding is planned.

title: Judge Rules on Who Can Sue in Valdez Spill
description: Damages from the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989 may be collected by Alaskan Natives, commercial fishermen, businesses and property owners in the Prince William Sound region, a state judge has ruled.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: Robert Reich is an economics professor who seemingly does not understand how to compose a balance sheet. His article is simply an itemization of the debits of the successful without a word about the credits. In fact, the successful do their best for the poor and everyone else by being successful.

title: No Proof for Diet Switch-Cancer Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Mindy Berk to Wed in Fall
description: Mrs. Judith G. Berk of Spring Valley, N.Y., has announced fall wedding plans for her daughter Mindy Lynn Berk and Robert Evan Finfer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Finfer of Rockville, Md. The couple, both 25 years old, graduated from American University. Ms. Berk is also the daughter of the late Sidney D. Berk.

title: Yachting; Syndicates Working in Sync
description: A tendency among America's Cup defenders to ignore their competition has spawned a united attempt by United States yachtsmen to find out what challenge teams are doing. Having realized the price of their insularity in previous campaigns, American sailors are looking beyond their own self-interest.

title: The Region; Should Suburbia Help Foot the Bill For Connecticut's Urban Poor?
description: THE thousands of commuters who drive in from the suburbs to the offices of the big banks and insurance companies here don't linger in the desperately poor neighborhoods they must cross to get to work. The thousands of poor people who live here -- more than 22 percent of the city's population is now on welfare -- depend on the property taxes paid by those companies, where few of them are able to find jobs.

title: Nuclear Dump Needs a Home; Communities Can't Say No
description: A VOLATILE "not in my backyard" battle is brewing in Connecticut. Next month, the Connecticut Hazardous Waste Management Service, established by the General Assembly in 1983, will announce three possible locations for a 150- to 250-acre disposal site for low-level radioactive waste. These three candidates will then be evaluated in more detail, and the location finally selected is scheduled to be announced by December.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Saudis; For Saudis, a Ground War Will Be a Test of Will
description: If it comes to slugging it out on the ground, as seems ever more likely, will the Saudi Army fight?

title:
Style Makers;
Christian Tortu, Florist
description: When 30-year-old Christian Tortu arrived in Paris five years ago, he blew the dust off staid traditional Parisian florists. His mix of color and material is cutting-edge modern with a hint of past ambiance, perhaps 40's Surrealistic.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: KATHERINE A. HALMI;
Intervening When Thin Becomes Too Thin
description: KATHERINE A. HALMI has spent her professional career trying to convince people -- particularly young girls and women -- that there is no truth to the adage that one can never be too thin.

title: Randi Engle to Marry
description: Randi Alexandra Engle, a job coach for the disabled and others at Ada S. McKinley Community Services in Chicago, and Thomas Murray Kuhn, a Ph.D. candidate in mathematics at the University of Chicago, plan to marry in July. She is the daughter of Mrs. Sheldon F. Eldridge of Colts Neck, N.J., and William Engle of Gillette, N.J. Mr. Kuhn is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Craig Kuhn of Pittsburgh. Miss Engle, 23 years old, graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College, from which her fiance, 24, graduated summa cum laude and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title:
DINING OUT;
2 Eating Places With the Same Kitchen
description: THE Cook Plaza Cafe has been through several changes in character, decor and ownership since its inception 10 years ago. The most recent is a change of location from snug quarters in a tiny alleyway to a much larger space that used to house the Meeting Place in the Morris County town of Madison.

title: A Simple, Sober Town
description: LYNCHBURG, a horse-and-buggy village tucked into the hollows of southern Tennessee, is all charm -- and irony. This town, which essentially owes its existence to Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whisky, made in the distillery just beyond the town square, is dry. The company that owns Jack Daniel's owns not only the distillery but also the major restaurant and general store. But nothing stronger than lemonade, coffee or tea is sold or served in Lynchburg, or surrounding Moore County, which voted to continue to ban alcohol after the repeal of Prohibition in 1933.

title: Break Up the Chinese Gulag
description: China's sentencing last week of two dissidents to 13 years in prison is the ultimate demonstration of the failure of so-called quiet diplomacy. Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming were champions of freedom, and their names deserve to be known to the world. Their arrest and convictions are an outrage, and the Chinese Government needs to hear it, in the strongest terms.

title: Food; The World Is My Custard
description: Of all the psychologically resonant foods -- oysters (success), raw carrots (virtue), grapes (peel me a grape) -- the one your mother would most approve of is custard. Or perhaps not your mother, but the Platonic-absolute mother, the mother of our imaginings, for custard is everything life would have been for us if only the perfect mother had arranged it: soft, unresisting, with no nasty surprises. No one should ever put things in custard -- raisins or nuts or bits of glace whatever. In a custard, nothing should ever bump up against your spoon or cause you to ask, "What's that?" A custard should harbor no mysteries. It should be one long, yellow sameness.

title: Colorado Journal; Meant for the Stomach, Really Taken to Heart
description: Back when the West was wilder, it was deadly dangerous to insult another man's horse. An unkind remark could start a gunfight.

title:
MUSIC;
Oboist Coming Home With Tailor-Made Work
description: JOHN MACK, principal oboist of the Cleveland Orchestra for 25 years, will be coming home on Wednesday night when the orchestra performs at the State Theater in New Brunswick.

title: Beth Posner to Wed Jonathan M. Hess
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert T. Posner of East Windsor, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Beth Sheba Posner to Jonathan M. Hess, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Hess of Brooklyn. A January wedding is planned.

title: Bank Losses Worst in 50 Years, But No Danger to System Is Seen
description: As Congress begins debate on one of the most extensive series of changes ever proposed for the nation's banking system, there are clear signs of serious illness at many banks -- large as well as small. But experts say the system itself does not appear in danger of collapse.

title: By Chopper to the Snow
description: Snowboarders now have a chance to make their own fresh tracks -- by joining the world of heli-skiing. Canadian Mountain Holidays, which organizes helicopter tours for skiers, has put together a package that will take snowboarders to the ungroomed trails of the Monashees in western Canada. The tour runs from March 23 to 30, and costs about $3,150 (American) a person (calculating the Canadian dollar at about 87 American cents), with accommodations, meals, helicopter trips and guides included. It starts in Calgary, Alberta; from there the group is taken by bus to the village of Mica Creek, where the tour company has its own lodge. Anyone joining the tour must be a good intermediate snowboarder with release bindings. Information: Canadian Mountain Holidays, Box 1660, 217 Bear Street, Banff, Alberta, Canada T0L 0C0; (403) 762-4531.

title: City Awards and Benefit Galas
description: More than a dozen New Yorkers who made outstanding contributions to their communities were honored Thursday at a dinner dance given by the Citizens Committee for New York City at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Miss Stirn to Wed Paul R. Ainslie
description: Mrs. Charles van Syckel Stirn of Dongan Hills, S.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Suzanne Cunliffe Stirn to Paul Robinson Ainslie, the son of Robert Frank Ainslie and Mary Ellen Howard, both of San Diego. An April wedding is planned.

title: Where Yes and No Mean Maybe
description: BAGHDAD WITHOUT A MAP And Other Misadventures in Arabia. By Tony Horwitz. 276 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: State Plan On AIDS Draws Mixed Reviews
description: NEW JERSEY'S first comprehensive plan for battling the AIDS epidemic is garnering mixed reviews from health care professionals, public health officials and advocates for people with AIDS, with some praising it as a national model and others warning that it may create new layers of bureaucracy at the expense of badly needed services.

title: Why Punish Reservists' Families?
description: Operation Desert Sword has exposed an embarrassingly outdated support system for families of reservists and National Guard members suddenly called to active duty. There is hardship enough in sending them off to war, perhaps never to return. To add financial distress is inexcusable.

title: Fears of War And Recession Put Pressure On the Psyche
description: STEVE ROBERTS said he often feels like a counselor on wheels. "I hear everything," said the driver for Diamond Cab Company in Bloomfield, "from the mundane to the incredible."

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Clifton
description: SERVED by five Garden State Parkway exits and four major highways -- Routes 3, 19, 21 and 46 -- Clifton is exceptionally well-connected. Yet it is practically self-contained.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: Perhaps Reich's "fortunate fifth" might take a cue from W. E. B. Du Bois's "talented tenth." Du Bois was the first black American to earn a doctorate at Harvard and an internationally acclaimed philosopher and historian. He stated in blunt terms back in 1903 that the topmost "talented tenth" of blacks had an obligation to assist the other 90 percent. He said: "Progress in human affairs is more often a pull than a push, a surging forward of the exceptional man, and the lifting of his duller brethren slowly and painfully to his vantage-ground." One cannot "pull" without looking behind. A central problem is that the paradigm of success in America does not necessarily include public service. And true public service comes from time spent as well as a check written to some 501 (c) (3) organization. ARTHUR ASHE New York, N.Y.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Mamaroneck Spot Is Holding the Line
description: NOT much has changed at this tiny shack of a restaurant since our visits three years ago, and in many ways that news is good. This kitchen makes an effort to lend some interest to its fresh-tasting productions, employing a bit of cilantro here, some wild mushrooms there. In fact, we've paid a lot more for comparable niceties in fancier digs. The Good Life has held the line on prices, charging no more than it did when it opened, making dining here something of a bargain.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Civilian Soldiers; Limbo of Mojave Tests Mettle for Hell of War
description: The ground war starts here on Sunday for the National Guardsmen of Alpha Company in a 12-day mock battle intended to show that thispatchwork group of civilian soldiers has transformed itself into an efficient fighting unit ready to join the front lines in Saudi Arabia.

title: The Chief Steps Forward
description: On a muggy January morning in Durban, South Africa, Nelson R. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, was speaking soothing words to a longtime adversary. He had come to this port city on the Indian Ocean to meet Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, president of the Inkatha Freedom Party and head of the Zulu homeland of KwaZulu; together they would try to end the vicious rivalry between their supporters that had claimed 5,000 lives since 1986.

title: Headliners; Too Much Time?
description: Judgment day for Jim Bakker was too exacting, according to a Federal appeals court, which last Tuesday threw out the evangelist's 45-year prison term. While the three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond upheld Mr. Bakker's 1989 conviction on 24 fraud and conspiracy charges, it ruled that the sentencing judge had improperly stressed religion. Federal District Judge Robert Potter, nicknamed "Maximum Bob" for his stiff sentences, had said, "Those of us who do have a religion are sick of being saps for money-grubbing preachers and priests." As a result of the appellate ruling, Mr. Bakker will be resentenced at a later date. He was found guilty of bilking followers out of some $158 million, in part by selling more vacations at his Heritage USA Christian resort and theme park than he could provide, and using some of the money to support an extravagant life style that included an air-conditioned doghouse and a fleet of Rolls-Royces.

title: About Cars; Auto Upsmanship for the Wee Hours
description: This starts, I guess, as a tale of misspent youth. In the mid-50's, a bunch of us would shoot pool at the Ritz Billiard Parlor until it closed for the night, and then we would move on to the Crystal Lunch on Hamilton Street in Allentown, Pa., where we had invented an early version of Trivial Pursuit.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Mixed Feelings on the Death of Iraqi Civilians
description: In the aftermath of the American missile attack on an Iraqi bunker in Baghdad on Wednesday night, many Israelis are shaking their heads at the hand-wringing coming from some in the West over the deaths of civilians.

title: Data Update
On Language; The New, New World Order
description: "THE OLD ORDER changeth," said the dying King Arthur in Alfred Lord Tennyson's 1842 poem "Morte d'Arthur," "yielding place to new."

title: The World; The Right War Machine Provides a Decisive Edge
description: THROUGH the 1950's and 1960's, the United States spent most of its weapons dollars on machines to beat the Soviet Union with. Then, in Vietnam, it had to make do with those weapons against an enemy that didn't fight the way the Soviets fight in a place that bore no resemblance at all to the north European plains. Hunting mosquitoes with howitzers. It didn't work.

title: Students' Book Relives UConn Glory
description: PEOPLE who had never watched a basketball game tuned in the University of Connecticut's team last year, when the Huskies became champions of the Big East Conference and went on to the national collegiate finals.

title: Outdoors; Stalking the Annual Banquet
description: Those who hunt and fish become unusually gregarious during the off season -- February and March are the heart of the doldrums for such endeavors in the Northeast -- and gather together for a variety of reasons. These include devoting time and money to improving the lot of their quarry whether it be fish or fowl.

title: 60's Revival Is Official: Courreges Is Back
description: Courreges is back, and Bloomingdale's has got him.

title: Sloan to North Texas
description: It's not that Steve Sloan has anything against Nashville. It's just that every time he spends any time there he seems to get an itch to head for Texas.

title: Gods and Other Lovers
description: THE FIRST LOVE STORIESFrom Isis and Osiris to Tristan and Iseult.By Diane Wolkstein.270 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $21.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ROOSEVELT HIGH SCHOOL;
High Ambitions at a Student TV Station
description: THE gang at WDMC-TV, Channel 19, is ready for the big time.

title: Kronos Takes One to Tango
description: It has become a point of honor (and marketing tactics) to cram as much music as possible onto a classical compact disk. Nonesuch, however, is trying a concept long familiar in pop music but a stranger to the classical world -- the single.

title: Daily News Strikers Hopeful Over a New Round of Talks
description: On the second day of new do-or-die talks between striking Daily News unions and senior executives of the newspaper, strike-weary workers expressed hope yesterday that a negotiated settlement in the four-month-old strike would finally be reached.

title: The World; Afghanistan, the Place Where the Cold War Didn't Go Out of Style
description: TWELVE years after Soviet Army paratroopers landed in Afghanistan and the Carter Administration began covertly supplying Afghan guerrillas to resist them, Afghanistan defies a pattern that has seen the superpowers abandoning proxy wars throughout the developing world.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Arabs; Arab Allies Reaffirm Unity Despite Iraqi Proposal
description: Arab members of the coalition at war with Iraq reaffirmed their united stand today and called on Baghdad to withdraw from "all Kuwaiti territories without conditions or strings."

title: Campus Life: Bucknell; Professors Gain New Insights On Athletics
description: There probably is not a college or a university in the nation where faculty members have not voiced complaints about some aspect of the intercollegiate athletic program. In the belief that some of these complaints are a result of poor communication, Bucknell University has instituted a volunteer program in which faculty members and administrators play sideline coaches.

title: Aging Boxers Should Retire
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Nation; Fallback for the Jobless Has Little to Fall Back On
description: BY providing income to jobless people for a temporary period, the unemployment insurance program is designed to be the first line of defense when jobs are cut in a business downturn.

title: DELAY IN TACKLING FISH-MARKET CRIME
description: A blueprint for ridding the Fulton Fish Market of racketeers is still on the drawing boards, six months after New York City officials announced it.

title: The Longest Battle
description: DURING the Iran-Iraq War, the great defensive battles that Saddam Hussein fought -- and won -- resembled more closely scenes from World War I than modern times. In declaring that he will drown the Coalition in "rivers of blood," it is this style of warfare, too, that he appears to have had in mind for breaking the Allied attack. Meanwhile, as the war in the Persian Gulf rolls on, the 75th anniversary of the battle that has long been regarded as the grim archetype of the Western Front, 1914-18, falls this week.

title: Becker Back To No. 2
description: When Stefan Edberg lost to Guy Forget, ranked 11th, in the semifinals of a tennis tournament here yesterday, it truly added insult to injury for Boris Becker.

title: Catherine Hegarty Weds Eric Bingham
description: Catherine Anne Hegarty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick D. Hegarty of Malden, Mass., was married there yesterday at Sacred Hearts Roman Catholic Church to Eric Walter Bingham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Bingham of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Robert J. Higgins performed the ceremony.

title: Q and A
description: Renting a Condominium Question: I own a condominium apartment and pay common charges to an association of owners that is run by a management company. The company told us that a new rule requires its approval and a $250 fee for a rental and that a fine of $500 can be imposed if the fee is not paid.

title: Minority Auto Dealers Face More Than Just the Recession
description: The automobile industry is in its deepest slump in years, leaving many established dealers struggling just to keep their doors open. For Tim Turner, who is black, the odds for success are especially steep. Minority-owned car dealerships have been failing at double the rate for all dealers. Of those minority dealers still in business, proportionately fewer are turning profits compared with their white counterparts.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: After reading Reich's article, I was left wanting to say, "Oh, take me with you!" But, on reflection, I began to feel differently. If we were smart, those of us who are less economically fortunate would let the "fortunate fifth" go ahead and secede, for it is they who will suffer by becoming isolated from the rest of us. The fact that we as a people have become divided is very sad indeed. CECELIA LYNCH Morristown, N.J.

title: In Harder Times, Larger Gifts to the Neediest
description: As The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund nears the end of its annual drive, Wednesday's mail brought an envelope stuffed with hundreds of checks from Wall Street financial analysts.

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr; Study of City Problems Has Become Hot Major
description: The Thomas Auditorium is filled on Tuesday and Thursday mornings when the introductory-level course meets for Bryn Mawr College's Growth and Structure of Cities major. Any of the 95 students who arrive late for the class, called "The Form of the City," miss their chance for one of the 90 seats available and must sit in the aisles or on the floor in front.

title: In the Summer of '42
description: In Neil Simon's new play, "Lost in Yonkers," the veteran stage actress Irene Worth portrays Grandma Kurnitz, an iron-fisted German-Jewish refugee who has stunted the adulthood of her four children. The time is the long, hot summer of 1942, the place an apartment over Kurnitz's Kandy Store in a New York suburb.

title: Ibsen In English
description: To the Editor:

title: Accent Is on the Abstract in a New Britain Landscape Show
description: ALTHOUGH landscape has never enjoyed the respect accorded the figure, its worst setback was probably the advent of Modernism. Modernist masters from Matisse on have painted landscapes, of course, but none have specialized in the genre, and even when Claude Monet was returned to critical circulation, during the Abstract Expressionist era, it was largely as a putative ancestor for the new movement.

title: When the Buffalo Roamed
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back To Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Panel Reported Ready To Seek a Rebuke of Cranston
description: The Senate Ethics Committee has reached an informal consensus that Senator Alan Cranston's actions on behalf of a savings and loan executive, Charles H. Keating Jr., merit a public rebuke by the full Senate, officials close to the committee say.

title: Last Thing Democrats Need Is to Change Nominating Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Bank/February 17, 1991
On the Street; Al Fresco Shopping, in Style
description: Each Sunday the free spirits of creative dressing converge on the outdoor antiques market on the Avenue of the Americas between 25th and 27th Streets. By 11 A.M. the after-hours dance clubs in the neighborhood have closed and that crowd shops on the way home.

title: Teaching Sensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: City Ballet's Fresh Talent Scores in Familiar Works
description: As the original Spanish saying had it, "the proof of the pudding is in the eating." The proof of the New York City Ballet's excellence is in the watching.

title: Low Humidity and Winds Fan 149 Wildfires Around Florida
description: Low humidity and high winds fanned 149 wildfires around the state today, with one having contributed to the burning of five historic buildings in this central Florida town late Friday.

title: Bomb Kills Anti-Apartheid Lawyer in Soweto
description: A lawyer who investigated allegations of Government death squads was killed when a bomb exploded in headphones of a tape recorder he received in the mail, the police and his law firm said today.

title: Elizabeth Kolbert Is Wed in Albany
description: Elizabeth Kolbert, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Kolbert of Larchmont, N.Y., was married on Feb. 9 to John Kleiner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George Kleiner of Larchmont. Judge E. David Duncan of Albany City Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Albany Delegation Pressed on School Aid
description: THE yearly breakfast meeting of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association and local state legislators drew a larger crowd than usual last weekend, as more than 125 board members and school superintendents came to protest the reduction in education aid that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed in his new state budget. They also requested a change in the way state aid is formulated, saying it is unfair to school districts near New York City.

title: GULF WAR SETS OFF CRISIS FOR GERMANS
description: War in the Persian Gulf has thrown Germany into a crisis of confidence and direction.

title: Museum in Hartford Examines the Medicine of Earlier Days
description: IN an earlier time, doctors rode on horseback to visit their patients, and they carried saddlebags containing a few instruments and remedies. At the Historical Museum of Medicine and Dentistry in Hartford, which started with four showcases of collections in 1974 and now occupies the entire three-story red-brick Hartford Medical Society Building, the clock appears to be turning back.

title: The Future of the Novel: A View From the Eight-Seated Spaceship
description: For conveying ideas, novels are among the least functional and most decorative of the blunt instruments. (Could this be a universal truth, some starry, operative mathematical principle? Most stars are decorative too, of course, their function merely to peg the universe in place like studs in upholstery.) And if, a few times in a way, novels like Richard Henry Dana's "Two Years Before the Mast" or Harriet Beecher Stowe's "Uncle Tom's Cabin" or John Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" come along to legislate, or raise a consciousness or two, or rouse a rabble, to make, I mean, what history or the papers call a difference, why that's decorative, too, I think, a lip service the system pays art -- like, oh, the claims made a few years back for the "We Are the World" folks when it was really the Catholic Relief Services already on site during the Ethiopian famine that did the heavy lifting.

title: Social Events
description: A Victorian Romance

title: Dance Celebration at Manhattanville
description: THE musical attention more often focuses on its big neighbor down the road, the State University, but Manhattanville College in Purchase frequently has its own bright cultural lights. Next weekend, for example, there will be a tripartite salute to a legendary American dance personality and the first of two all-Mozart faculty concerts.

title: Its Gains Dissipated, Vietnam Tries to Salvage Its Economy
description: Last year, the lunar new year, Tet, featured the most lavish parties in Vietnam in a decade, with new private wealth lavished on friends and firecrackers. The nation had a lot to celebrate: the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia, economic and agricultural reforms and a halt to years of wild inflation.

title: Hiring Those With Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: College Basketball; Painful Questions Haunt Syracuse
description: With its high-profile basketball team shaken by allegations and in some cases proof of misconduct, Syracuse University is conducting an intensive investigation that, along with an N.C.A.A. investigation, may ultimately lead to the downfall of a program that in the last decade has helped catapult the university to national prominence in sports.

title: Roni Rothenberg to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark D. Rothenberg of New City, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Roni Rothenberg, and Kenneth Roy Goldberg, a son of Ivan Goldberg of Ramsey, N.J., and Terrie Cosden of Closter, N.J. Ms. Rothenberg, 26, graduated from Emory University and received a master's degree in industrial social work from Columbia University. She is the assistant manager of personnel at the Whitehall Laboratories division of the American Home Products Corporation in New York. Mr. Goldberg, 26, received a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a financial analyst in New York at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Biographers and Their Subjects
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Books Move to Retail Shelves
description: CORPORATE histories, those glossy tomes once written solely to flatter the chairman of the board, are no longer destined to end up unread on warehouse shelves. Instead, some are selling well in retail bookstores, generating profits for a growing number of companies.

title: Teaching Sensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousting a Dictator
description: Saddam Hussein, with his conditional offer to leave Kuwait, finally concedes that he cannot win a military victory but still angles for a political one. George Bush, with his call for Iraqis to dump their dictator, finally reveals he will not be content with military success and that he intends to deny his adversary a postwar political triumph as well.

title: Bond Funds, Expenses and Returns
description: How can you pick a winning bond fund? A study by Lewis J. Altfest, a New York City investment adviser, suggested the answer: Buy the fund with the lowest expenses. Mr. Altfest, who looked at how 150 bond funds performed between 1974 and 1988, found that, unlike the case with stock funds, the expertise of bond fund managers and companies made little difference. Rather, the most decisive factor was the expense ratio -- the ratio of a fund's expenses to its average net assets. In the study, the expense ratios for the corporate bond funds ranged from a low of five-tenths of 1 percent to 1.6 percent. The lesson: The higher a fund's expense ratio, the lower its return.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Last chance to order perennials, groundcovers, woody plants and seeds from the catalogues to get a good selection. If the weather is mild, spray evergreens with anti-dessicants. Continue to prune trees and shrubs. Now's the time to haul out the power tools and get them serviced before they're needed. Wall Covering

title: Q and A
description: Kosher Passover Packages

title: Charges of Racism Now a Tennis Problem
description: On the surface, last year marked a renaissance for American tennis.

title: Earnhardt Is Man to Beat in Daytona 500
description: To understand why it will be such a daunting task to beat Dale Earnhardt today in the Daytona 500, stock car racing's biggest event, start with the way he lost it last year.

title: Campus Life: Virginia; Proposal to Ban Military Recruiters Is Overruled
description: A month after the University of Virginia instituted a rule prohibiting discrimination against students on the basis of their sexual orientation, its president has overruled, at least temporarily, a proposal to ban on-campus recruiting by employers like the armed forces that refuse to hire homosexuals.

title:
Your Own Account;
Cashing In on Frequent Flier Miles
description: The competition in the airline industry is creating terrific opportunities for people who want to travel now. Even if you don't want to lay out any cash, you can take advantage of the chaos in the industry by using frequent filer miles you may have accumulated. There are now fewer restrictions on how you use them than at any time in recent years, experts say.

title: Dr. Odette Aguirre Plans To Marry Dr. D. T. Zero
description: Dr. Odette Maria Aguirre, the daughter of Dr. M. Antonio Aguirre and Dr. A. Odette Arango de Aguirre of Guatemala, is to be married in April to Dr. Domenick Thomas Zero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Domenick Thomas Zero of Brooklyn.

title: Anna S. Bingemann Marries Richard A. Wall 3d
description: Anna Susan Bingemann, a daughter of Geoffrey Bingemann and Mrs. John Vincent of Perth, Australia, was married in London yesterday to Richard Aloysius Wall 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A.
