Wall Jr. of Nassau Point, N.Y., and Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Vincent Hawe performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Farm Street Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Death Watch
description: A woman with a pleasant voice answers the phone with the greeting "Oncology." I am calling Dr. James Speyer for professional reasons, but still those four syllables make a cold place in the center of my chest.

title: 'Educated in Romance'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Buswell Weds Joseph Decaminada
description: Eileen Susan Buswell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Buswell of Vergennes, Vt., was married yesterday to Joseph Decaminada, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Decaminada of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Edward A. Floretta performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title:
ART;
Primitive Portraits From Men Who Painted for Their Suppers
description: TASTES in art change quickly. Not long ago, one would have surveyed the more than 50 paintings in "Between the Rivers: Itinerant Painters From the Connecticut to the Hudson" and consigned them to the quaint and primitive category.

title: Ms. Jeffers, Manager, Weds W. R. Raub, Trader
description: Maureen Jeffers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Jeffers of West Babylon, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to William R. Raub, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Raub of Delmar, N.Y. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Preserving Bath Tiles
description: CERAMIC-TILED bathroom walls are attractive and durable, but vulnerable to moisture. Frequent cleaning will preserve their appearance; careful maintenance will insure long life.

title: Planning a Student Exchange in Uncertain Times
description: PARENTS whose teen-agers have been considering joining an exchange program with a school overseas or are signing up for an overseas home stay for this summer may be tempted at this uncertain period to tell the children to forget it. But it is probably smart to press ahead with research, since a second or even a third choice may come into play if a preferred program is washed out. Families thinking about an educational exchange in the 1991-92 academic year should certainly continue writing for catalogues and talking to officials.

title: Sunday Dinner; Bistro Fare, the Cuisiniers Club, Jazz and Italian Classics
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. La Boite en Bois

title: Accord for Burks
description: The Boston Red Sox and their center fielder, Ellis Burks, decided to split their $750,000 difference, but not exactly right down the middle.

title: Campus Life: Colorado; Learning to Turn Volunteerism Into a Career
description: Fifteen students at the University of Colorado are involved in a program to prepare student volunteers for paid careers directing their own service organizations.

title: Dr. Janis Fox Weds Richard Ian Corn
description: Dr. Janis Heidi Fox and Richard Ian Corn were married last evening in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Tom Weiner and Cantor Henry Weintraub performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge
description: Nobody outside the People's Republic of China, and perhaps nobody inside it either, has a clear notion of the number of bridge players there. All that is certain is that since the Cultural Revolution the number has grown geometrically, and in a few years there are likely to be more Chinese players than there are American. A game that is both intellectual and social, and requires little equipment, is ideally suited to the world's most populous country.

title: David Tod 2d Is to Marry Rollin T. Gilbreath in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gilbreath 3d of New Canaan, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Rollin Tyson Gilbreath and David Tod 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tod of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Crack in Japan's Nuclear Sangfroid
description: AS Japan has rapidly grown more dependent on nuclear power over the last two decades, it has also grown more confident, perhaps even a bit smug, about its prowess at running nuclear reactors. Eager to beat back a growing anti-nuclear movement, the Japanese Government constantly reminds people that this country's reactors suffer far fewer glitches and emergency shutdowns than plants in the United States or Europe. Workers are trained more intensively. Facilities are inspected more rigorously. Much like making computer chips and defect-free cars, the argument goes, nuclear safety is a matter of discipline and controlling the process.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The doors in my 25-year-old house, which I think were originally varnished, now need refinishing. The bathroom doors have a dry whitish look near the bottom, and others show scratch and scuff marks. What should I use and how should I proceed?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FROM THAT PLACE AND TIME: A Memoir 1938-1947, by Lucy S. Dawidowicz. (Bantam, $12.95.) In 1939, one week before Germany invaded Poland, the author fled Vilna (now Vilnius, Lithuania), returning after the war to document the destruction of the city's Jewish culture. In 1989 our reviewer, Tomas Venclova, called this memoir "a monument to the community destroyed, not by forces of nature, but by the evil human hand."

title: Last Plea by Condemned Inmate Who Has Rare Blend of Defenders
description: With a week to go before Joseph M. Giarratano is to die in Virginia's electric chair, an unlikely coalition of conservatives and death-penalty opponents is intensifying the pressure on Gov. L. Douglas Wilder to spare him.

title: The Boys of Summer Play Ball Forever, for Collectors
description: Baseball memorabilia became a major-league collectible in the 1980's when the prices paid for bats, balls, uniforms, locker keys, rings, pendants, press pins and the ubiquitous palm-sized cards soared. Now, fans of artifacts relating to the boys of summer -- especially Honus Wagner, Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle and Jackie Robinson -- expect even higher prices at the sale next month of one of the most important baseball collections ever formed.

title: Ruling on Asbestos: A Wider Tax Role?
description: A RULING in State Supreme Court that sharply cut taxes on a prominent Manhattan office building because it contains asbestos has opened the way for a $24 million tax refund for its owners.

title: Sports News Briefs; Hockey Group Coming Together
description: Formation of the Continental Hockey Association, a new professional hockey league that plans to begin play in October, has begun.

title: Burton Taylor Is Dead; Joffrey Dancer Was 47
description: Burton Taylor, a former leading dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, died on Wednesday at his home in White Plains. He was 47 years old.

title: 'I NEVER WAS AN INGENUE'
description: Whimsical as it may seem, I would not like my tiny moment in history to go unacknowledged. Kathy Bates is evidently a very fine actress, but David Sacks's article " 'I Never Was an Ingenue' " (Jan. 27) seems to imply that she is the first large woman to be accepted as a serious actress on screen. The producers of "The Honeymoon Killers," released in 1970, might disagree. They were considered very daring to have hired a woman of size -- me -- as their leading lady. I not only played a murderess but also a woman who had love scenes.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/February 10-15
description: THE ECONOMY

title: On the Trail of Andy Warhol: Soup, Sex and Rock-and-Roll
description: There's a picture of Andy Warhol that takes up a lot of my office wall. Like Andy Warhol, it's a huge image, created from a small photograph taken in a photo machine years ago. In "Superstar," my new film about Warhol, the little snapshot becomes transformed, becomes larger and more graphic, takes on color and definition, then magically emerges as a work of art.

title: P.L.O. Is Said to Kill 20 in Lebanon After Mutiny
description: In the aftermath of large-scale clashes between rival factions within the Palestine Liberation Organization, 20 guerrillas who had participated in a mutiny against their commander were executed in southern Lebanon early today, security officials said. The deaths raised to 37 the number of people reported killed in the violence.

title: Garuda Offers Indonesia Pass
description: To encourage visitors to Indonesia to explore islands other than just Bali and Java, Garuda Indonesia Airways has introduced a Visit Indonesia Air Pass. Throughout the year, tourists can visit 4 to 12 destinations that are served by Garuda and its sister airline, Merpati Nusantara. They include Bandah Aceh, Sumatra, one of Indonesia's most Islamic cities; Manado in North Sulawese, favored by divers; Balikpapan in East Kalimantan, an oil city from which visitors may head upriver into the jungles.

title: Seville
description: To the Editor: Anyone planning to visit the 1992 World's Fair in Seville should not plan to drive in the city proper. It is simply one of those cities where you "cannot get there from here." We spent two hours trying to find a hotel. It seemed that every street was one way opposite from the direction we desired. We could not believe how many streets turned out to be dead end without a warning. Some streets are so narrow that the tires scrape the curb on both sides. Even a policeman advised us that the hotel could not be reached by car from where we stood. We finally checked into a hotel in Alcala de Guaderia and commuted to the city by express bus. JOEL L. GOLDSCHMIDT Freehold, N.J.

title: Yes, Let's Privatize Education
description: To the Editor:

title: On Return, Arabs Find Jobs in Israel Are Taken
description: As Soviet Jews poured into Israel over the last year, the new immigrants took over nearly half of the best factory jobs and a vast portion of the other semi-skilled positions traditionally held by Palestinians.

title: INSIDE
description: Peru's Battle With Cholera

title: Cecily M. Glavin To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Glavin of Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cecily Maureen Glavin to Henry Welling Lane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Lane of Princeton, N.J. A May wedding in planned.

title: THE GUIDE
description: BACK TO THE PAST

title: Headliners; War in the Projects
description: Laura D. Blackburne's job description as chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority probably didn't include drug raids. But last Wednesday she accompanied some 100 police officers and Federal agents to Brooklyn in a joint operation against two crack gangs that had been distributing to dealers throughout the borough. The raids capped seven months of undercover work by the Drug Enforcement Agency and the housing police. The joint operation, law-enforcement officials said, was a new tactic against well-armed and deeply entrenched drug distribution systems in the projects that have outmaneuvered the police. Ms. Blackburne, who was named to her post last September, announced that she was establishing a special telephone line to encourage the half-million residents who live in these communities to report drug-dealing activity anonymously. She also announced her intention to rid the buildings of guns. "I want those guns out of circulation," Ms. Blackburne said.

title: Gardiners Island Feud Returns to Court
description: THE death on Dec. 17 of Alexandra Gardiner Creel, co-owner of Gardiners Island, has revived the longstanding feud between her brother Robert David Lion Gardiner and her heirs.

title: Miss Cohen to Wed in July
description: Marcia Cohen of the Bronx and David Cohen of Holbrook, L.I., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Deborah Sue Cohen and Richard Barry Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Wolfson of Bellmore, L.I. A July wedding is planned. Miss Cohen, 28 years old, is a manager for Bellmarc Realty in New York. She graduated from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Her fiance, 33, a lawyer in New York, graduated from the University of Florida and has a law degree from Touro College in Huntington, L.I.

title: History Is Refurbished At Old Meeting House
description: WITH its weather vane regilded, its bell freed, a coat of white paint and new black shutters, Newtown's centerpiece has regained its dignity. An 18-month community effort has restored the 19th-century building, now known as the Newtown Meeting House.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MISSING By Michelle Herman.Ohio State University, $17.95.

title: 'House of Flowers' Heads for Westbury
description: FOR devotees of musical theater, the resurrection of an obscure show is likely to be more inviting that a revival of a celebrated one. Touched by mystery and even legend, "House of Flowers," twice short lived, with five months on Broadway in 1955 and seven weeks Off Broadway in 1968, is the very model of a musical many talk of, but few have seen.

title: Saudi Army: How Fit to Fight?
description: If it comes to slugging it out on the ground, as seems ever more likely, will the Saudi Army fight?

title: The Region; A New Source of Money for the City, but at What Price?
description: BALANCING the budget, on time and under sound accounting principles, has been an article of faith in New York City since 1975, when it nearly went bankrupt from borrowing billions to pay for operating expenses.

title: Martha L. Kittredge Weds Brian Costello
description: Martha Louise Kittredge, a daughter of Mrs. David Brayton Kittredge of Charlotte, Vt., was married yesterday to Brian Costello, a son of Joseph V. Costello of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Mrs. Costello. The Rev. Thomas Gillum performed the Anglican ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in the Knightsbridge section of London.

title: Sunday Outing; A Place Where George Overnighted
description: George Washington slept here -- in his headquarters overlooking the Hudson River almost every night for 16 1/2 months in 1782 and 1783 while awaiting the official end of the Revolutionary War.

title: Nurturing Ballet With Gardener's Touch
description: DERMOT BURKE, artistic director of the Princeton Ballet, nurtures the company's growth with the touch of a master gardener. His choices over the last eight years reflect his expressed beliefs in the value of a flowering of dancers and repertory that respects the gradual process of building a quality company.

title: Harding Takes Singles Title
description: In a stunning upset, Tonya Harding of Portland, Ore., skated a near perfect program today to win the women's singles title at the national figure skating championships.

title: Campus Life: Vassar; Blacks Form Graduation Panel Of Their Own
description: The Vassar Student Association voted last week to recognize the breakaway Black Commencement Committee as a student organization, thereby giving it the right to seek school financing and to hold events on campus, as does the traditional Senior Class Commencement Committee.

title: Campus Life: Rochester; Music Professor Lures Students Aged 52 and Up
description: John Laforte is just a beginner on the saxophone. "I've always wanted to play the sax, but when I was about 10 years old, my father told me I didn't have the music in me," he said. Now, more than a half century later, he is finally fulfilling his dream.

title: Conversions
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: History and Housing; Touring Brooklyn by Bus
description: Although Brooklyn's rich diversity of historic and architecturally distinct housing is far too much to be explored in a day, those interested in serious sampling may want to consider a bus tour being offered next Sunday by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 3 about showroom buildings misidentified the owner of the Toy Center and misstated the role of Harry B. Helmsley in the ownership. The owner is Fifth Avenue Building Associates. Mr. Helmsley is a minority partner of the buildings' operator, 200 Fifth Avenue Associates, not a partner in Fifth Avenue Building Associates.

title: A Hospital's Corridors Become a Gallery for Local Artists
description: EACH day when Rosemary DeAngelis came to visit her father after his surgery at the White Plains Hospital Center here, she passed a certain painting in the hall.

title: Manila Talks on U.S. Bases Recess Without Accord
description: The United States and the Philippines ended what was expected to be the final round of negotiations on the future of the American military bases here today without an agreement. But both expressed optimism that one could be achieved soon in additional talks in Washington.

title: Headliners; Setback in Detroit
description: A symbol of pride for Detroit's black citizens took a hard blow last week when a Federal grand jury indicted the city's black Police Chief, William L. Hart, on embezzlement charges. Mayor Coleman A. Young removed him from office and named a successor, though the Mayor said he continued to presume Mr. Hart's innocence. A Federal prosecutor said Mr. Hart, 67 years old and a career member of the department, and Kenneth Weiner, a former civilian deputy chief and ex-business partner of the Mayor, were indicted on charges that they embezzled $2.6 million from a secret police fund that was used to finance covert operations. Mr. Hart denied the allegations, saying, "I intend to defend myself vigorously." Mayor Young had charges of his own to make, asserting that the indictment was part of an effort by Federal prosecutors to harass black officials. "This, in my opinion, is a political trial," he said. "The Chief was indicted because he got caught in a trap that was set for me."

title: Style Makers; James McQuay, Furrier
description: James McQuay is a furrier who has stayed on top even in hard times. His attention to detail is his secret -- that and repeat customers like Doug Williams, the former Washington Redskins quarterback; John Lucien, the singer, and Paul Barry, anchor of WJLA-TV in Washington.

title: Pro Football; Offensive Lineman Is Going Global
description: The first American drafted by an overseas team in the new World League of American Football had a special visit planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ QUINTET Marcus Roberts, who was the pianist with the Wynton Marsalis Quintet, will bring his own quintet to the stage of Morristown High School at 3 P.M. today. The event is sponsored by the Friday Evening Club.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: The Great Frederick
description: FREDERICK DOUGLASSBy William S. McFeely.Illustrated. 465 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: We Need More Than a Big Stick in Mideast; Stubborn Old Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Heroines Need Guts, Not Glamour
description: In "Sleeping With the Enemy," the glossiest of several new films in which women are pursued by deadly, scarily methodical men, a wife escapes her abusive husband and begins life anew in a small Iowa town. One night, she steals apples from a tree near the cozy little cottage she has rented. She claims to have done this because she felt a late-night impulse to bake a pie. The upshot, in any case, is a dinner date with the man next door.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: Reich is not really discussing success. He is discussing total self-absorption, which was raised to the level of a virtue in the 1980's. Now we are seeing its corrosive sequelae. MARIA CORMAN Barrington, N.J.

title: A Correspondent's Tale; Pentagon's Strategy for the Press: Good News or No News
description: REPORTERS covering the coalition forces in the Persian Gulf region are operating under restrictions imposed by the United States military that, among other things, bar them from traveling without a military escort, limit their forays into the field to small escorted groups called pools, and require all reports to be cleared by military censors. Reporters have complained that the rules limit their ability to gather information independently and, by not allowing them to get close enough to the action or the people involved, obstruct informed and objective reporting.

title:
Gardening;
Doing Groundwork for Healthy Plants
description: I have often wished that, as a young, beginning gardener, I had paid more attention to the well-known injunction to plant a dollar plant in a five-dollar hole. Since these days most plants worth having cost much more than a dollar, perhaps the price of the hole should be upgraded to ten or twenty dollars. Fortunately, it does not cost that much to prepare a hole worthy of the finest plant. What it does require is an understanding of the elementary principles that make the hole merit the expensive plant.

title: 18 Hurt in Gas Explosion at Missouri Hotel
description: An explosion and fire from leaking propane caused heavy damage to a wing of one of the Ozark region's most popular hotels Thursday night.

title: Cambridge, Mass.
description: To the Editor: On Oct. 14 you had an article about Cambridge, Mass., which said that the Irving House was a renovated inn suitable for families.

title: Old Troubles And New Vex Top Ugandan
description: When the President of Uganda, Yoweri K. Museveni, was chosen as chairman of the Organization of African Unity last July, people thought it could mark the entrance of a new-model African leader onto the world stage.

title: Leach-Pugh Wins
description: The defending doubles champions, Rick Leach and Jim Pugh, retained their title by defeating Michael Stich and Udo Rigewski, 6-4, 6-4.

title: Dial REIT Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Infant Boy Dies and Starvation Is Suspected
description: A month-old boy who died on Saturday en route to Harlem Hospital after falling unconscious in his parents' apartment had apparently starved to death, the police said.

title: Yankees Regroup, Trying to Forget '90
description: More than four months have gone by since the Yankees ended their dreadful summer of 1990, but the memory endures, almost like a recurring nightmare.

title: Crossroads in Mental Health: Red Ink and Unused Wards
description: Ward 50 at the state-run Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York seems a throwback to the age of asylums. Like geriatric wards at mental hospitals across the state, the day room is well scrubbed and cheerfully decorated, but most of the 18 elderly patients are lost in schizophrenic hazes, captives of their wheelchairs.

title: Commerce Clearing House Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Computer Telephone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Excludes non-recurring net gain of $ 727,853, or 31 cents a share.

title: Contel and GTE in Pact
description: The Contel Corporation and the GTE Corporation said Friday that they had agreed to reduce from $50 million to $20 million the "break-up fee" associated with their merger. The two companies announced last year that they would merge, creating the nation's second-largest cellular telephone company. But a class-action suit was filed in July against Contel over the fee it was to pay GTE. Contel said it had agreed to the out-of-court settlement to avoid the expense of further litigation and to expedite the closing of the merger, now scheduled before the end of the first quarter.

title: Figure Skating; Eldredge Overtakes Bowman for Title
description: A year of skating in the shadows of skepticism ended for Todd Eldredge today as he won the men's singles title at the national figure skating championships for the second consecutive year.

title: Madison Gas & Electric Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Cmos Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Reviews/Music; Japanese Violinist's Recital
description: The name, New York City Opera Orchestra, stood at the head of Carnegie Hall's program page on Friday night, but it became evident after a while that the primary purpose of this event was to promote a young Japanese violinist named Hideko Udagawa in some kind of style. Independently produced under the auspices of Panasonic, this generally ragtag affair ended with results its sponsors might not have intended.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "War is about killing. It's about mothers bleeding, fathers bleeding. If we lose sight of that, we may stop trying to find a better way." -- Rabbi Helene Ferris of Manhattan. [ 28:4. ]

title: Berkshire Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Howell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Datasouth Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Now the Endgame
description: The proposal was clouded by conditions, but it was a signal nonetheless. For the first time, Saddam Hussein used the word withdrawal and mentioned the United Nations resolution demanding that Iraq leave Kuwait.

title: Long Way From a Cappella
description: Wednesday night's double bill at Carnegie Hall, the first of two sold-out shows featuring the pianists Ellis Marsalis and Marcus Roberts and the headliners Take Six, went off with some hitches.

title: Truck Slump Adds to Woes Of Big Three
description: The woes of the domestic automobile industry are being aggravated by a decline in the sales of some of its most profitable products: full-size pickup trucks and vans.

title: Gooden, Viola Dominate Mets' Agenda
description: Al Harazin, the Mets' executive vice president, said today that he would meet here Monday with the team's general manager, Frank Cashen, to clarify the organization's position on contract talks with Dwight Gooden and Frank Viola.

title: War Summary
description: GROWING TENSION OVER GROUND WAR Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, arrived in Moscow for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev aimed at avoiding a costly land war. Only hours before, American troops fought sharp skirmishes with Iraqi forces on Saudi Arabia's northern borders. Roland Dumas, the French Foreign Minister, said "we are on the eve or the pre-eve of the ground offensive for the liberation of Kuwait." The heaviest allied military traffic in weeks was reported along the Saudi side of the Saudi-Kuwaiti border, with final pre-battle testing going on. Troop-laden American amphibious assault vessels massed off the Kuwaiti coast. With tension high, suspicion persisted that an effort was under way to spread confusion to veil the allies' true intentions from President Saddam Hussein. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Two United States soldiers were killed and six wounded yesterday when their armored vehicles were hit during one of the border engagements, the American command reported. It said the vehicles were probably struck by Hellfire missiles fired from United States Apache attack helicopters. That brought to 14 the total number of American ground troops killed in action during the Persian Gulf war, by United States count. Ten of the dead have been listed as certain or possible victims of "friendly fire," with four killed by the Iraqis. Aircraft: One aircraft was reported lost yesterday, a UH-1 Huey that was said to have come down in a non-combat accident. Its crew members were listed as missing. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Twenty Iraqi soldiers gave themselves up during two of the engagements yesterday, the American command said. More than 1,200 Iraqis have been taken prisoner, the allies say. Armor and weaponry: By American count, three tanks, two armored card, some mortars and a rocket launcher were destroyed during yesterday's clashes.

title: Catherine Corcoran Weds

Rabbi Joshua Glatzer officiated. Mrs. Grey, 29 years old, is a nurse at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. She received her training at St. Lawrence's Hospital in Dublin and at Princess Alexandra Hospital in Essex, England. The bridegroom, 30, is a lawyer and a New York City police officer assigned to the Legal Bureau in New York. He is a graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton and the New York Law School, where he was a John Ben Snow Scholar.

But there was nothing routine about it. By 8:30 A.M., there were long lines of anxious depositors at the tellers' windows and cash machines, withdrawing their money. The phones rang steadily with calls from worried customers. Bank officers tried to calm account holders, assuring them that their savings were federally insured up to $100,000.

title: Review/Rock; Introspective Songs From a Melancholy Sting
description: Sting has never lacked ambition, and on his current tour he tries to do three things simultaneously. One is to present the songs from his new album, "The Soul Cages" (A&M), a largely somber, extended song cycle about a father's death, the sea and the loss of faith. The second is to forge a small rock band (just four players) that has the ensemble spirit and improvisational moxie of a jazz group, as did the Police, Sting's first hit-making band. A distant third priority is to please his fans. On Friday night at the Beacon Theater, opening a sold-out engagement through Wednesday, the first ambition was fulfilled, but on the two others he fell short; many people walked out before the concert ended.

title: MEDICAID IS DENIED DISCOUNTED DRUGS DESPITE A NEW LAW
description: Congress recently passed a law requiring drug companies to give Medicaid the same deep discounts they give other big customers. But instead of reducing Medicaid drug prices, many companies are now raising the prices that those other big customers must pay.

title: Troubled Banks and the Role of the Press
description: On Jan. 4, The Boston Globe had a front-page article under the headline, "Damaging Loss Expected for Bank of New England." The newspaper reported that during the day the troubled bank would announce a large loss for the fourth quarter of 1990, which would effectively wipe out the equity of shareholders and make the bank insolvent. The Globe report was correct. The bank announced it would post a $450 million loss. The newspaper report led to a brief run on the bank. The run ended after the Government took over the bank on Sunday, two days later.

title: Chronicle

Last week, FREDERICO MAYOR, the director-general of Unesco, named Mr. Cardin and WITTA POHL, a German actress, as honorary ambassadors to the Chernobyl Program.

title: A Canadian Violinist Plays Bach, Beethoven and Grieg
description: Scott St. John, a 21-year-old Canadian violinist, has won competitions in the United States, Canada and China. One of his victories, in the 1988 Canada Council Competition, won him the use of a 1717 Stradivarius. He was also a winner of the 1989 Young Concert Artists International Auditions, and on Tuesday evening that organization presented a recital by Mr. St. John and his Strad at the 92d Street Y. His able collaborator was Robert Koenig, a Canadian pianist.

It had plunged with the killing of innocents in Baghdad, risen with Saddam Hussein's offer to withdraw from Kuwait, plunged again as President Bush rejected it as a cruel hoax and lurched once more with talk of a ground war perhaps only days away.

Injury, premature retirement and a mammoth book project have kept the name submerged for more than a year, but now the owner of what many pros call the best swing in the game is scratching to come back.

title: Hurricane Kevin Rages in Met Camp
description: Outside, the wild winds and freakish cold of the last 48 destructive hours had abruptly ended, replaced by a soft breeze and a reignited sun. Kevin Elster opened the clubhouse door and walked into the bright morning, the sun performing a subtle sort of laser surgery on his reconstructed right shoulder.

description: "We are on the eve or the pre-eve of the ground offensive for the liberation of Kuwait." -- Roland Dumas, Foreign Minister of France.

title: Striking a Blow for Public Justice
description: Much too routinely, judges in civil courts grant the request of both sides to seal the records and judgments when they settle lawsuits. That slams the courthouse door on information that often belongs in the public domain. Texas, Florida dna now New York have changed their rules, recognizing that even when both sides in a private context want the record sealed, their case may have broad consequences that call for broader access to justice system records.

title: Bridge
description: For dedication to the game and will to win, it would be hard to find anyone to match Heitie Noland of Lake Charles, La., who died a month ago. The most notable of her many tournament successes was a victory in the 1972 World Mixed Teams played in Miami Beach, and a second place in the 1978 World Mixed Pairs in New Orleans. One of her favorite partners was Mark Lair of Canyon, Tex., who has described her as "a fine card player and a fearless competitor in the bidding."

title: Cheerful Gathering in London
description: Several young women said they had seen a bit of American football on television, though they didn't have the foggiest what all the smashing and bashing was about. Fewer still knew what a cheerleader was or was supposed to do.

title: Suspect Seized In Strangling Of a Girl, 15
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man, on parole since November, has been arrested and charged with strangling a 15-year-old girl whose nude, charred body was found under the Williamsburg Bridge two months ago, the police said yesterday.

title: Alliance Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Navratilova Takes Final: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova won her 11th Virginia Slims of Chicago championship in 14 years, beating Zina Garrison, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday. Navratilova dominated the 58-minute match with a variety of shots that had Garrison running all over the court, sometimes going in the wrong direction. In the first set, Navratilova broke Garrison in the opening game. Then Garrison forced the second game to deuce twice before Navratilova held service. Playing close to the net when not serving and using drop and passing shots to her full advantage, Navratilova also scored service breaks in the fifth and seventh games. In the final set, Garrison forced the first and third games to deuce before Navratilova held serve both times for a 2-1 lead. Garrison lost service in the fourth game, but she broke back in the next game, cutting the deficit to 3-2. Navratilova, however, broke Garrison's serve in the sixth game for a 4-2 lead. Navratilova was forced to deuce in the seventh game before holding serve. Then a service break on a drop shot in the eighth game gave her the match. Coming off double-knee surgery last fall and revamping her game since then, Navratilova improved her record to 30-1 against Garrison. (AP) Forget Triumphs: Guy Forget of France beat Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 7-5, 3-6, 7-6, to win the Donnay Indoor tournament in Brussels. Forget played sharp, attacking tennis from the start en route to winning his second title of the year. Cherkasov was bothered early by Forget's booming serves, but fought back with steady baseline play to give Forget a strong run. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 126, Nuggets 108: Larry Bird scored 17 of his 24 points in the first period, sparking visiting Boston to its seventh consecutive victory. The Celtics took command with only two minutes gone in the game and breezed to a 36-23 lead after one quarter. Although using their reserves for most of the second half, the Celtics shot 52.7 percent in handing Denver its fifth straight loss. (AP) Golf Trevino Wins on Last Hole: Lee Trevino sank a 12-foot putt on the 18th hole for his sixth birdie of the day and beat Dale Douglass by one stroke in the Senior PGA Tour's Aetna Challenge at Naples, Fla. Trevino shot a bogey-free 66 to finish at 205 and overtake Douglass, who had a 68. (AP) First Victory for Blake: Jay Don Blake scored a two-shot victory yesterday in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Open at La Jolla, Calif., his first triumph in the five years he has been on the PGA Tour. The 32-year-old Blake shot a five-under-par 67 in the final round at Torrey Pines for a 268 total, 20 under par. Bill Sander was second. (AP) Horse Racing I'm a Thriller Prevails: I'm a Thriller stalked the leaders for most of the race, then came through on the inside to win the $113,200 Busher Breeders' Cup for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, ridden by Art Madrid, covered a mile and an eighth in 1:52 2/5 and finished 3 1/2 lengths ahead of Ten Out of Ten. Crafty Lady was three-quarters of a length farther back. It was the second stakes victory in two starts this year for I'm a Thriller, who paid $4.80, $3.40 and $2.20 for $2 across the board. (AP) Skiing Another Gold for Twardokens: Eva Twardokens won her second consecutive gold medal, overcoming near-blizzard conditions in Crested Butte, Colo., to win the women's slalom yesterday at the United States Alpine championships. The men's giant slalom, scheduled to be the concluding event, was canceled pending possible rescheduling because of unsafe snow conditions. Twardokens paced the first run of the women's slalom, finishing 34-hundredths of a second ahead of Heidi Voelker, as heavy snowfall and slippery conditions knocked eight of the top 15 seeded skiers from the race. Twardokens, 25, of Santa Cruz, Calif., finished in 51.18 seconds. Voelker, of Pittsfield, Mass., was clocked in 51.52 and Wendy Fisher of Incline Village, Nev., ranked a distant third in 52.79. (AP)

title: War Cuts Publicity For Many New Books
description: On a tour last month to promote his new novel, "A Home at the End of the World" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), Michael Cunningham was forced to cancel a scheduled appearance at a Seattle bookstore when the Persian Gulf war started. The next day at a scheduled reading at a bookstore in Los Angeles, the war was still so much on people's minds that only his immediate family showed up.

title: Sports of The Times; A Plan for Attaining More Fights in Hockey
description: An article in this section last week reported that individual fighting in hockey had taken on "added significance and visibility." Each team in the National Hockey League seeks what its officials call "specialists," though others refer to them as "goons." They are brawny gents who appear more comfortable hitting someone with a stick than skating with one.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; Red Cross Is Frustrated on Prisoners in Iraq
description: The Red Cross complained today that Iraq had without justification prevented its representatives from meeting allied prisoners of war and from determining how desperate conditions had become in battered Iraqi cities.

title: College Basketball; U.N.L.V. Displays Tough Defense
description: With a scoring average of more than 103 points a game, the Runnin' Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas obviously are one of the most potent offensive forces in college basketball. But on Saturday night, top-ranked and undefeated U.N.L.V. (22-0) relied on an almost air-tight defense to gain the edge against New Mexico State, then rolled to an 86-74 victory, its 33d consecutive triumph over two seasons.

title: Review/Dance; A Coming of Age Fable As a Music-Theater Piece
description: Poor Bebe Miller. When her company was chosen as a replacement for a previously scheduled troupe in the American Movement Festival at City Center, it seemed like a good chance to bring her compelling work to the attention of a new mainstream audience. That is one of the aims of the series, though City Center refreshingly underplays that aspect. But it is hard to imagine a worse frame for Ms. Miller's choreography than "The Hidden Boy: Incidents From a Stressed Memory," a full-evening music-theater piece devised by Jay Bolotin and presented on Wednesday night at City Center.

title: Congress: Uniform Proportion
description: Proponents of renewing the military draft assert that politicians would be slower to commit America to war if their own sons and daughters were in uniform. With an all-volunteer system, they contend, offspring of privilege can go to school and work while those from ordinary families fill the military ranks. The argument was raised late last year, when only two members of Congress had sons in the gulf.

title: Review/Television; Trying to Save Inner-City Youths
description: "Black Men: Uncertain Futures" is a brisk survey of efforts around the United States to save some inner-city youths from drugs, crime, prison and early death. Prominent figures, including Louis Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services; Representative John Conyers, Michigan Democrat, and the Cable News Network anchor Bernard Shaw, comment on the grim situation -- which particularly threatens black men in their teens and 20's -- and offer some familiar background. But most of the program is given to businessmen, educators and others who are trying to do something about it in their own areas and to a few of those who are being helped. The hourlong program can be seen tomorrow night at 10 on Channel 13.

Minutes later, they haggled in sign language near Dresden's cavernous terminal with a group of Vietnamese over prices for shabby sweaters that spilled from their bags.

title: Unlikely Name In the Middle For the Spurs
description: Did anyone think that Dwayne Schintzius would bump David Robinson, the best young center in the world, to power forward? Well, honestly, he hasn't, but the change has been in effect for the past four games. Terry Cummings has missed 10 games with a fractured hand and Schintzius has moved into Robinson's neighborhood as the starting center.

title: A 61 for Him Would Be a Record
description: Randy Maris swings sticks and plays a professional sport on grass for a living, just like his famous father. While Roger Maris made his name knocking baseballs out of Yankee Stadium, Randy taps a smaller ball around golf courses on the United States Pro Tour. With more than $1.5 million in prize money and 21 events starting March 11, the tour is a low minor league of sorts for golfers.
