description: Jeanne Marie O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. O'Brien of East Williston, L.I., was married there yesterday to J. Christopher Windisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Windisch of Stony Brook, L.I. The Rev. Thomas P. Tuite performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, a graduate of the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, L.I., is a senior account executive at Dreyfus Service Corporation in Uniondale, L.I. The bridegroom is a manager at Dreyfus Precious Metals Inc., in Uniondale. He is a Villanova University graduate.

title: Pro Basketball; Sparking Effort No Solcae for Jackson
description: There were a few neat drop passes to trailing teammates, a one-handed no-look dish that should make some highlight tapes and even a rare dunk for the unhappy soul on the Knicks who struggles to call himself the backup point guard.

title: Yale Sophomore Slain on Campus Is Thought to Be Robbery Victim
description: A Yale University sophomore was killed early today during an apparent robbery attempt on a quiet street near the center of campus, the police said.

title: Eugene Fodor, Creator of Guides For Worldwide Travel, Dies at 85
description: Eugene Fodor, whose travel guides have been carried by tourists to the far corners of the world for more than half a century, died last night at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in Litchfield, Conn.

title: The 'Rabbit' Who Just Ran 3:58.94 Mile
description: It is not giving away any military secrets to speculate that First Lieut. Mike Michno of the United States Air Force could be up to his ears in swirling sand in a few weeks or months.

title: Fight Now, Pay Now Jeff Faux is president of the Economic Policy Institute.
description: The conventional wisdom is that the cost of the war is crowding domestic problems from Washington's agenda. Not so. The problem is the willingness of George Bush and Congress to fight a war without raising the revenue to pay for it. The responsible way to finance the war is a war tax coupled, whatever the political discomfort, with a drastic cut in the still bloated military budget.

title: Review/Dance; Old and New Traditions From Korea
description: The culture and traditions of another land and other times were the wellspring for the compelling modern dance presented by the Myung-Ok Han Dance Company on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The program began with an early-19th-century Korean court-dance solo, "Choon Aeng Jeon," a dance of stately measure with small eddyings of activity like the opening up and out of the arms and the dipping of the torso. It was performed in traditional dress to traditional music by Ms. Han, whose furrowed brow suggested the solo might be something of a labor of love for her.

title: A Taiwan Pop Singer Sways the Mainland
description: Her silky, sometimes haunting voice belts out love songs and tugs China by the heartstrings, so that when the Government in Beijing urges Chinese to follow Marxism, they find relief in her hit song "Follow Your Feelings."

title: Wendy's Earnings Up 35%
description: Wendy's International Inc. reported today that its earnings rose 35 percent in the fourth quarter and 29 percent for all of 1990 as sales at its restaurants increased from year-earlier levels.

title: Birth Weight Tied to Defects
description: A four-pound infant is four times as likely to have birth defects as an eight-pound baby, a new study has found.

title: New Maryland Law Protects Right to Abortion
description: The State House of Delegates approved a bill today that would protect a woman's right to abortion if the United States Supreme Court should ever restrict abortions, and Gov. William D. Schaefer then signed the measure into law.

title: Doing Business With New York City
description: The New York Times analyzed the 23,564 contracts let by New York City in the two fiscal years ending on June 30 and recorded by the City Comptroller's office. Officials caution that because of recording errors, there may be inaccuracies in dollar values or descriptions of some contracts. The Times study exluded contracts let to government agencies, which totaled $5.95 billion. That left 22,418 contracts with a total value of $10,36 billion. The analysis was done by John C. Freed.

title: Market Place; Money Fund Investors' New Tack
description: Investors' headlong rush toward the safest type of money market funds seems to have slowed, perhaps reflecting lower interest rates and reduced fears about the fragility of America's financial system.

title: Ribare Journal; For Well-Housed Dead, TV and Other Comforts
description: Relaxing at a picnic table recently on the Day for the Dead outside the small house he built on the family plot in this Serbian village's graveyard, Branislav Dimitrijevic sipped plum brandy with family friends in memory of his only son, Peda, whose coffin lies sealed in the basement.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A helicopter carrying QUEEN MARGRETHE II of Denmark and her husband, PRINCE HENRIK , was forced to land yesterday in Virginia after developing mechanical problems in its tail section. No one was injured.

title: Durenberger Finances Are Examined Anew
description: The Justice Department has told Senator Dave Durenberger that it is investigating his financial dealings, a spokesman for the Minnesota Republican said.

title: Scudder Fills Top Posts
description: Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc., an investment management firm based in New York, has appointed a new chairman, Daniel Pierce, and a new president, Edmond D. Villani. They succeed George S. Johnston, who held those posts and who died of cancer last week. Scudder runs mutual funds and has $45 billion in assets under supervision.

title: Mining Dead Cars for Money
description: Making use of new enforcement authority, New York City is slowly beating the blight of abandoned cars -- adding to the city's depleted treasury in the process. But help from Albany could permit a lot more progress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Review/Dance; Two Balanchine Pieces To Uplift the Spirit
description: Those seeking to rid their minds of negativity, as the current new-age expression goes, might consider the effect that "Symphony in C" and "Concerto Barocco" have upon the dancegoer.

title: Cranston Urges Panel to Act on 'Malicious Leaks'
description: In an angry letter to the Senate Ethics Committee today, Senator Alan Cranston urged members to take action against "malicious leaks" on how the panel may vote on his case.

title: Cocaine Seen Harming Economy of Colombia
description: The cocaine industry in Colombia is known for the huge profits it generates -- an estimated $4 billion a year. But economists and business executives here say the cocaine trade is actually retarding Colombian economic growth.

title: The Contract Game: How New York Loses - A special report.; Without Competing Bids, New York Pays the Price
description: When New York City needed burglar alarms for its soup kitchens and its centers for the elderly, only one company bid on most of the contracts. The lack of competition almost certainly forced the city to pay more than the going rate.

title: Review/Music; Salzburg Mozarteum Group
description: The Salzburg Mozarteum Orchestra paid a visit to Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon and contributed an all-Mozart program to Lincoln Center's celebration of the bicentennial of the composer's death. The orchestra was established in Salzburg, Mozart's birthplace, in 1841, and has been associated with the city's conservatory since 1880. It is also a resident orchestra at the Salzburg Festival.

title: Jackson Is Prepared To Bargain for Time
description: The trading deadline is three days away and several Knicks are nervously counting the hours.

title: Warming of Globe Could Build on Itself, Some Scientists Say
description: A GLOBAL warming caused by industrial and automotive emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide could well build on itself and produce even more warming, some scientists argue. The warming, they say, would stimulate the release of more carbon dioxide from natural storage places like forests, grasslands and wetlands.

title: North Korea Cancels Talks With South
description: North Korea called off the next round of high-level talks with South Korea today, blaming what it called military provocation by South Korea and the United States.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses were also closed.

title: Air Travelers On Business Trickle Back
description: Business travelers are on the move again, raising airlines' hopes that things will get better soon.

title: Shelter to Protect Homeless Youths From AIDS
description: It will be called Safe Space, a haven for homeless and runaway youths living precariously in the Times Square area and at risk of contracting and spreading the AIDS virus.

title: Patterns
description: Hardly Middle of the Road

title: Romero Rolls With the Spills
description: In 20,000 or so horse races in 16 years, Randy Romero has won more than 3,500 times, finished in the money 9,000 times and taken mighty tumbles about 20 times. To the other jockeys, he is a medical marvel. To his wife, Cricket, he is "the bionic man of racing."

title: Vermont and Rhode Island Debate Length of Their Governors' Terms
description: Thomas Salmon, a former Vermont Governor, complains that when governors are elected for only two years at a time they barely take office before they have to start campaigning again.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Children; Early Lessons in Wounds of the Spirit
description: In elementary school classrooms here outside Camp Pendleton, the nation's largest Marine base, Saudi sand has become a staple of show-and-tell, and some children cry for no particular reason. They visit the nurse more than usual, draw bloody pictures of Saddam Hussein and miss school because their fathers are in the Persian Gulf and their mothers don't want to be alone.

title: Review/Television; Baltics Can Open American Eyes
description: "Guns, Tanks and Gorbachev" begins with Eduard A. Shevardnadze's warning when he submitted his resignation as Soviet Foreign Minister in December: "Dictatorship is coming." It ends with an admonition to the West by Hedrick Smith, the program's correspondent, "not to tie all our hopes to a single leader." In between, this week's offering from "Frontline," at 9 o'clock tonight on Channels 13 and 49, is a strong indictment of Moscow's continuing crackdown on nationalist movements in the Baltic republics and elsewhere.

title: Discussions on Musicals
description: Tony Randall and Donna McKechnie are to open a five-night series called Dialogues in Musical Theater, on Feb. 28 at 8:15 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. Other programs in the series are the orchestrator Jonathan Tunick and the arranger and conductor Wally Harper on March 7; the costumes designers Santo Loquasto and Patricia Zipprodt on March 14; Claude-Michel Schoenberg and Alain Boublil, the composer and lyricist, respectively, of "Miss Saigon," on March 21, and the producer Cy Feuer and director Graciela Daniele on March 28. Martin Gottfried is the series narrator. Subscriptions are $75; single tickets, $16. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Trisha Brown's Dance Talk
description: Trisha Brown, artistic director of the Trisha Brown Dance Company, is to speak about her work on Feb. 28 at 7:30 P.M. at the City Center Theater, 130 West 55th Street. Ms. Brown, a founding member of the Judson Dance Theater, formed her own company in 1970. Her appearance is part of a lecture series on the art of dance; Twyla Tharp is to appear on April 2. Tickets to Ms. Brown's lecture are $10. Information: 581-7907.

title: At Yale, Fear and Anger Join Grief Over Slaying
description: Hillhouse Avenue is an elegant stretch of mansions and vast lawns and ivy-covered buildings. Just two blocks from the center of the Yale campus, it has long been regarded as a safe street, a place where students somehow felt protected from the violence of the city.

title: Fighting Back When Dream Becomes Nightmare
description: Nick Esasky of Marietta, Ga., thought that his signing by the Atlanta Braves late in 1989 was at long last a dream come true, a chance to return home and play in front of family and friends.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I try not to linger on it or I'll get depressed. I can't cry or anything because I have a little brother and sister. I don't want to make it harder for my mom." -- Tamara Bulls, a California high-school student whose father is serving in the Persian Gulf. [ A8:3. ]

title: Pease Is Picked First
description: Brent Pease, who spent two years with the Houston Oilers and part of a season playing in Canada, was the first quarterback selected in the World League of American Football draft. The Birmingham Fire chose him yesterday in Orlando, Fla., where the league is conducting a position-by-position selection in preparation for training camps that begin Monday. Play is scheduled to begin March 23.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Also out of the hospital yesterday was KIRK DOUGLAS , injured when the helicopter he was in collided Wednesday with a small plane over a private airport in Santa Paula, Calif. The 74-year-old actor "is fine and has mended very well," said Ron Wise, a spokesman for the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.

title: 4-Goal Burst by Islanders Leads to Victory
description: The Islanders, in the throes of a messy, public divorce from their sole superstar, Pat LaFontaine, found the perfect diversion from their personnel problems yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bridge
description: Lead-directing doubles of a three no-trump contract are sometimes a source of confusion. It is relatively easy when just one suit has been bid by the defending side -- the doubler wants that suit led. But what if each defender has bid a suit?

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a depositors' run on the Bank of United States in 1930 misidentified the branch shown. It was in Brooklyn, not the Bronx.

title: Fixing Antique Furniture In an Old Railroad Station
description: An abandoned railroad station here in Columbia County, about 115 miles north of New York City, has become the center of a nationwide operation for the repair and restoration of antique furniture.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; The Big Game
description: To the Editor:

title: H. W. Eldredge, 81, Dartmouth Sociologist
description: H. Wentworth Eldredge, a Dartmouth College sociology professor who in World War II helped divert German attention from plans for the Normandy invasion, died Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 81 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: The Soviet-Iraq Axis
description: There's no use getting mad at Mikhail Gorbachev and his partner, Saddam Hussein. Both are doing what comes naturally to two nervous dictators trying to get out of terminal trouble.

title: Hong Kong Court Rules on a Refugee
description: In the first court case to challenge the fairness of Hong Kong's screening of Vietnamese boat people, a judge ordered a new hearing today for a Vietnamese man who was denied refugee status because a decisive error was written into his record by an immigration officer.

title: Berry Hired by Lions
description: Raymond Berry, a Hall of Famer and a former head coach of New England, was named the Detroit Lions' quarterbacks coach yesterday, the team announced in Pontiac, Mich.

title: Research, Often Unpredictable, Leads Doctor to Unexpected Fruit
description: RESEARCHERS spend long hours at the laboratory bench, trying to make balky instruments work and intricate experiments go according to plan. But the scientific enterprise is not always so arduous. Take the happy inquiry into highballs by Dr. David G. Bailey. His research, he reported in a recent issue of The Lancet, led to the surprising conclusion that grapefruit juice helps the body absorb certain drugs into the blood. Orange juice, strangely enough, does not.

title: Storing Wine in Crystal Decanters May Pose Lead Hazard
description: WINE and spirits can leach lead from crystal in amounts that increase with time, raising questions about possible health hazards from long-term storage in decanters.

title: Ruth M. Hill, 73, Dies; College Vice President
description: Ruth Mary Hill, a teacher and a vice president of Friends World College in Westbury, L.I., died on Feb. 6 in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 73 years old and lived in Fort Myers and Fort Myers Beach.

title: Careers; Peace Corps Is Attracting The Ageless
description: THERE is adventure for older people, and Ruth Humleker has found it.

title: The Husband Vanishes
description: Children of unwed mothers may no longer suffer endless stigma: People no longer use terms like "born on the wrong side of the blanket." And the term "bastard" has long since been bleached of its power as an epithet. What illegitimate children now suffer is poverty. Today they constitute more than one of every four children born in the United States.

title: Our Towns; When the Blind Lead the Blind And Save Lives
description: The instructor looked out on his eager students, but not quite at them. They sat there looking back, but in all different directions. "I'll be giving you the examination in a few moments," the teacher said. "But don't worry. This is a perfect example of the blind leading the blind." Everyone laughed.

title: For the Hispanic Voter, a Milestone Election
description: Two Democrats with similar political views will compete Tuesday in an election that will produce Los Angeles County's first Hispanic supervisor in 115 years.

title: Israeli Court Extends Gaza Journalist's Detention Without Charges
description: An Israeli military prosecutor said today that a Gaza journalist who has been held in jail for three weeks without formal charge had violated the law by reporting on the activities of an Islamic fundamentalist group operating in the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: In a Tide of Japanese Books on Jews, an Anti-Semitic Current
description: The Persian Gulf war has led to a boom in book sales on all aspects of the Middle East. And once again among the best sellers are books about a subject that has long held a fascination for Japanese readers: the influence and power of Jews.

title: Soviet Plant Struggles To Join the Modern Era
description: Aleksandr Samsonov, a towering man of gruff voice and crunching handshake, has little need for Harvard Business School techniques in running Moscow Watch Factory No. 1.

title: Books of The Times; The Pro-Nazi Past of a Leading Literary Critic
description: Signs of the Times Deconstruction and the Fall of Paul de Man By David Lehman 318 pages. Poseidon Press. $21.95.

title: A Difficult Season for Banks Trying to Lobby Capitol Hill
description: Alfred M. Pollard, a lobbyist, was so afraid that the banking company he represented would be a victim of collective mistaken identity that he published a pamphlet for every member of the House and Senate Banking Committees, describing the nature and role of the nation's banks. They are no savings and loans, he said, using charts, graphs and text to elucidate his topic, "Thrifts and Banks: Different Industries -- Different Goals."

title: Under-the-Counter Drug Testing
description: There was considerable surprise over a Government report last week that the AIDS drug AZT may not work for HIV-positive blacks and Hispanics and that it may not prolong life in infected people not yet showing symptoms.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iran; Teheran Says Its Peace Plan Drew Positive Iraqi Response
description: Iran said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had responded "positively" to Teheran's proposals for leaving Kuwait and that there was "the bright prospect" of peace, as Iraq pressed diplomacy with the Soviet Union and bellicosity toward the United States in the face of a threatened allied ground offensive.

title: Prices to Jump 60% In New Soviet Effort To Revive Economy
description: Soviet consumers were told today to prepare for sweeping price increases of no less than 60 percent under the Kremlin's latest plan to revive the critically troubled economy.

title: Daily News Makes New Offer to Pressmen
description: The Daily News presented a new offer to its striking pressmen's union yesterday that a mediator hoped would lead to an end of the 17-week-old strike.

title: Fire in Columbus Kills Five
description: Fire swept through a 2 1/2-story boarding house early today, killing five people, the authorities said. A sixth person, suffering from smoke inhalation, was in critical condition at St. Anthony Medical Center. Two men escaped the blaze, which was reported shortly after 4 A.M. Fire officials said the fire started in the first-floor living room and appeared to have been caused by careless smoking.

title: 3 Killed as Wave Breaks Boat
description: A large wave struck the wooden hull of a 30-foot commercial fishing boat and crushed its bottom on Sunday, killing three crew members, the Coast Guard said. Three other crew members were rescued when the boat, the Galliano, was hit by the wave in a cove off Anacapa Island, 50 miles northwest of Los Angeles, said Brenda Toledo, a Coast Guard spokeswoman in Long Beach.

title: CHRONICLE
description: REPRESENTATIVE LES ASPIN , chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was released Sunday from University Hospital in Denver.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; Latino Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid for NCR Is Extended
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today extended its offer for NCR Corporation stock. NCR said the $90-a-share cash tender offer was still inadequate.

title: The Handwriting on the Wall
description: THE pen, if you believe the soothsayers, is mightier than the keyboard. Virtually all of the big personal computer makers are racing to develop a new generation of lightweight portable computers that can be operated by writing on a screen or tablet with a pen-like stylus. Pen-based computing, the analysts say, will revolutionize the industry and attract millions of new computer users.

title: Plants May Teach How to Make Fuel From Sunbeams
description: SCIENTISTS believe they are on the verge of constructing test-tube versions of photosynthesis, the basic life process in which plants tap the sun's energy. Their aim is to open the way to new sources of usable energy based on the cheapest and most abundant of raw materials: sunlight, water and carbon dioxide.

title: Mesa Air Sets Midwest Deal
description: Mesa Airlines Inc. says it has signed a letter of intent to buy Air Midwest, based in Wichita, Kan., in a cash and stock package worth $27 million.

title: Holtzman Sees Budget Gap Rise
description: The New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, warned yesterday that the city faced a larger budget gap over the next 16 months than what the Dinkins administration has announced so far.

title: 2 RAIL TERMINALS IN CENTRAL LONDON HIT BY I.R.A. BOMBS
description: For the second time in 11 days, the Irish Republican Army struck in central London today, setting off two bombs in railroad stations, killing one man and wounding 40.

title: Decline in Oil Rigs
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 18

title: Leader Hits Iceberg
description: John Martin of South Africa, leader in the BOC solo race round the world, slammed into an iceberg Sunday in the South Pacific Ocean. Race officials in Newport, R.I., said that Martin sent a message by radio indicating that he was heading for southern Chile, a distance of nearly 2,000 miles northeast, for repairs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The private papers of MYRNA LOY , who starred in the "Thin Man" film series of the 1930's and 40's, have been donated to Boston University for its 20th Century Archives.

title: U.S. Plays Down Hopes
description: The Bush Administration indicated today that there was nothing in a new Soviet peace proposal that would, at this stage, cause a delay in a planned ground attack, and it played down expectations of a diplomatic breakthrough that would end the war quickly.

title: President Is Promoted By Alliant Computer
description: The Alliant Computer Systems Corporation said last week that its president and chief operating officer, Craig J. Mundie, had been promoted to chief executive. Alliant, based in Littleton, Mass., was a pioneer in parallel processing, which speeds computing by dividing tasks among multiple computer processors.

title: Congress Rushes to Pass Benefits for Gulf Veterans
description: Military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf may soon get help from Congress in dealing with economic hardships at home.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; U.S. Says Prisoners Seem War-Weary
description: From the initial interrogation of more than 1,400 Iraqi prisoners of war, a portrait is emerging of battle-weary front-line forces who in many cases are hungry, demoralized and bitter at President Saddam Hussein for waging a war few soldiers support, intelligence officers here and in Washington say.

title: Aaron Duberstein, 83, Boy Scout Fiscal Chief
description: Aaron D. Duberstein, the finance director and chief fund-raiser for the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America for 26 years and a Scouting advocate most of his life, died on Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Rules for Biotechnology A White House panel says products created through gene splicing should be regulated just like those made with traditional methods. Page D1. Dividing Up Drexel The investment firm's bankruptcy case moved a big step closer to resolution as the main parties agreed in principle to a settlement. Page D1. Rehearsal for Skull Surgery Eerily lifelike computer images let surgeons plan and practice complicated surgery to rebuild misshapen skulls. Science Times, page C1. New Season's Promise Afflicted by vertigo, Nick Esasky played only nine baseball games in 1990, but a physical therapy program has given him new hope. Page D13.

title: Fuhr Makes His Return in Spectacular Style
description: Grant Fuhr, the goaltender in four of Edmonton's five Stanley Cup triumphs, made his season debut in grand style tonight with a 4-0 shutout over the Devils.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; Black Women's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota to Cut U.S. Exports
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation will cut exports to the United States by 10,000 vehicles during February and March because of the soft American market, the company's president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Army Commander Is Sidelined for Surgery
description: Before what may well be the biggest battle of his career, Lieut. Gen. John J. Yeosock, commander of all Army operations in the war against Iraq, was evacuated from Saudi Arabia today for surgery in Germany.

title: Review/Fashion; Galanos Inc. at 40: Still a Class Act
description: James Galanos came out of the West last week with 10 trunks carrying 200 styles to show in New York, a trip he has been making twice a year since 1951. He hadn't realized it was his 40th anniversary until a friend pointed it out. He checked his records and found he had incorporated his business, Galanos Originals, in Los Angeles in 1951.

title: Clinton and Jamaica Win City Titles
description: DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx was an easy winner of the boys' team title, while Jamaica of Queens scored 14 points in the final event, the triple jump, to win the girls' crown yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships.

title: A.T.&T. Officer Is Set to Retire
description: Morris Tanenbaum, vice chairman and chief financial officer of A.T.& T. will retire in May, the company announced yesterday.

title: Barnes Names a Chief From Outside Family
description: The Barnes Group, a 134-year-old industrial company in Bristol, Conn., has named William R. Fenoglio chief executive. He is the first executive from outside the Barnes family to lead the company.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; Dependent Allowances
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City's Reliance on Public Hiring Is Facing a Change
description: New York City's economy, in the midst of a slide that shows no sign of abating, now faces the decline of one of its last sources of strength: government hiring and government spending.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Co., New York, named James T. Larkin vice chairman of American Express International Inc. * Buena Vista Pictures Marketing, Burbank, Calif., a subsidiary of Walt Disney Co., named Terry Press vice president-publicity. * Georgia Gulf Corp., Atlanta, a manufacturer of chemical products, named Jerry R. Satrum president and chief executive. * Moog Inc., East Aurora, N.Y., a manufacturer of aircraft controls, named Richard C. Sherrill vice president * Nash-Finch Co., Minneapolis, a food wholesale company, named Alfred N. Flaten Jr. executive vice president-sales and operations. * Price Waterhouse Europe, Frankfurt, named Volkert Klaucke a partner and managing director of its corporate finance division. * Wertheim Schroder & Co., New York, named Scott C. Marden managing director of its New York office.

title: With Chicago Calm, Daley Glides Toward Primary
description: For much of the 1980's, politics in Chicago was a cross between a street fight and civil war.

title: Fortified Foods Could Fight Off Cancer
description: IF an unusual "designer foods" project under way at the National Cancer Institute here achieves its goals, the label on orange juice might someday read: "Fortified with plant-derived limonoids, monoterpenes, carotenoids and phenolic glycosides to help prevent cancer."

title: 'Extinct' Fish Found
description: A RARE fish species that was believed to be extinct for 20 years has been rediscovered in a pond near the dried lake bed in Mexico where it once flourished.

title: No Progress Is Made On New Gooden Pact
description: The phones remained on their hooks today, and so the prognosis for an imminent agreement has remained dire.

title: Today's Gulf Weather
description: Sunny, warm conditions will cover most of the region. A storm moving slowly east from northwestern Iran will keep clouds in the northern Iraq mountains. A few high clouds will occasionally dim the sun across central Saudi Arabia. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 64, low 42; Riyadh, high 77, low 47; Dhahran, high 74, low 54.

title: Proposals On Genetic Technology
description: A White House task force on biotechnology policy has recommended that the Government develop regulations that simplify the approval of genetically engineered crops, pesticides and animals.

title: Personal Professors, Pupils and Pitfalls
description: THERE are two new professors on the faculty, and they're eager to start teaching. Professor Mac and Professor Windows are instruction programs that use, respectively, the Macintosh operating system and Microsoft Windows 3.0 to train beginners in these two similar approaches to running a personal computer.

title: 6 Die in Swiss Avalanches
description: Avalanches in various regions of alpine Switzerland killed six skiers over the weekend, the police reported today, and two more bodies were found from a snowslide on Mount Blanc in Italy, bringing the confirmed death toll in that accident to nine. The deaths in Switzerland raised the toll in avalanches this season to 16, compared with 28 in all of last winter.

title: Esther Fisher, Pianist, 90
description: Esther Fisher, a classical pianist, died here last Tuesday. She was 90 years old.

title: Travis Williams, 45, Pro Football Star
description: Travis Williams, who wrestled with homelessness, poverty and alcohol after setting records as a kick returner with the National Football League Green Bay Packers, died of heart failure Sunday after a long illness. He was 45 years old.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pepsi-Cola Expanding Its 'Uh-Huh' Promotion
description: Pepsico Inc. announced plans yesterday to expand its "Uh-Huh" Diet Pepsi promotion with a nationwide talent contest that begins during this week's Grammy Awards broadcast.

title: Chess
description: Grandmasters are generally direct and honest with one another in discussing their games and tournament achievements. When they blunder, they loudly spotlight the offending move; when they do something very well, they are not above soliciting praise for it, whether it be a fine combination, an intrepid defense or a subtle endgame.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Arkla Inc., a gas company in Shreveport, La., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 milion in debt securities. * Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc., Montgomery, Ala., filed for $60 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. * Meridian Automobile Grantor Trust 1991-A, a unit of Meridian Bancorp Inc., Reading, Pa., is offering $303 million in securities backed by auto and light-truck receivables through First Boston Corp. The 7.95 percent securities due in 1995 have an average lifespan of 1.5 years and are priced at 99 21/32 to yield 8.108 percent. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's and is supported by a letter of credit provided by Credit Suisse. * Universal Corp., a holding company based in Richmond, is offering $100 million in 9.25 percent noncallable notes due 2001 at 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. COMMON STOCK * AMSCO International Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of sterilization and infection-control equipment, surgical tables and surgical illumination systems, filed for an initial public offering of 5.85 million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. * Dell Computer Corp., Austin, Tex., filed for 3.5 million common shares, 2.8 million to be sold in the United States, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. RATINGS * Barclays Bank P.L.C.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to AA+, from AAA, by S.& P., which also lowered the subordinated debt rating to AA, from AA+.

title: A Monday Off, But to Honor Just Whom?
description: Poor George Washington. He led the threadbare Continental Army to victory over England; crossed the Delaware while (maybe) standing up in a crowded boat; became the first President but never got to live in the White House.

title: Mets Are Set to Unveil Different Style of Play
description: The crack of the bat rang out again and again from the cages along the third-base line. In the distance, the dull pop of gloves sounded in the disappearing sunshine. And from the trainer's room, there were groans of exhaustion and discomfort.

title: Teen-Agers Sat on Community Boards; More Young Prodigies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mining Dead Cars for Money; To Restore New York City; First Reclaim the Streets
description: Adding further bite, the Department of Motor Vehicles is now ready to suspend the driver's license of anyone who fails to pay an abandoned-car judgment. About 30 licenses have been suspended, with another 300 suspensions expected shortly.

title: Paul Russell, 43, Leading Dancer For the Dance Theater of Harlem
description: Paul Russell, a principal dancer of Dance Theater of Harlem and the San Francisco Ballet, died on Friday at the Davies Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 43 years old.

title: The New World Order Checklist
description: Early last fall, when the bloom was still on the rosy scenario, each American serving in the gulf was issued a wallet card emblazoned with the legend "Why We Are Here." It was, as they say, a defining moment. All across Saudi Arabia, relieved kids could be heard slapping their Kevlar helmets and exclaiming, "

title: Reviews/Theater; Trying to Ease Anguish With a Cry From the Heart
description: If the measure of a new musical was its gawky sincerity, "An Unfinished Song," which has music, lyrics and book by James J. Mellon, would earn high marks. The show, at the Provincetown Playhouse, is an examination of grief that has the feel of a personal cry from the heart. But like so many works that try to exorcise personal pain, it hasn't the foggiest idea when to stop.

title: Business and Health; Accountability In Health Care
description: EMPLOYERS, insurers, medical societies and hospitals are pressing to create tests and guidelines that they hope will bring more order and economic accountability to a health-care system that has traditionally been based on the judgments of doctors who may often disagree.

title: Global Warming Is Politics, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Conserve Oil -- and Wilderness
description: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge forms only a small part of Alaska. Smaller still is the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow wilderness that flanks the Beaufort Sea. The frozen plain is home to maybe 200 Eskimos, 180,000 caribou and dozens of rare Arctic species. It may also contain the biggest undiscovered oilfield in the United States.

title: War Summary
description: ALLIED AIR STRIKES CONTINUE The allies continued "battlefield preparation" for a possible ground war, with air strikes totaling more than 2,400 sorties, yesterday as Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, returned to Baghdad from Moscow with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposals for ending hostilities. The allied air operations included 870 sorties into Kuwait's territory, 100 attacks on Iraqi Republican Guard positions, further efforts to sever lines of communication and 130 missions against moving and fixed Scud missile launchers. No Scuds were launched by Iraq; the total fired at Israel and Saudi Arabia since the war began stood at 67. On land, along the Saudi border with Iraq and Kuwait, small skirmishes between allied and Iraqi troops took place. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: No casualties were reported, leaving at 14 the number of American ground troops killed in action, by United States count, since hostilities began. Ten of the the casualties resulted from "friendly fire," four from Iraqi fire. Aircraft: An F-16, Falcon crashed in combat 40 miles inside Iraqi-held territory, but the pilot was recovered in good condition by search-and-rescue forces. The F-16 was the 21st American plane lost in combat in the Persian Gulf; nine allied planes have gone down. Naval Vessels: The Princeton, a guided-missile cruiser, struck a mine in the gulf and was reduced to 50 percent of its propulsive power. Three sailors suffered minor injuries. In a separate incident, the Tripoli, a helicopter platform ship, struck a mine; the vessel continued in operation. Four crew members sustained injuries, none serious. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Fifty-four Iraqi soldiers were reported to have given themselves up to United States forces on Sunday, 34 more than originally had been reported. The total number of Iraqi prisoners now held by allied forces is reported to be more than 1,400. Aircraft: No Iraqi aircraft engaged allied fliers, and none were detected fleeing to Iran. The total number of Iraqi planes shot down in air-to-air combat since the war began totals 42, including 6 helicopters.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Moscow; Gorbachev Gives Iraqi a Peace Proposal
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented Iraq today with another formula for a withdrawal from Kuwait. Details were not announced, but the proposals were believed to combine an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with pledges of Soviet help in preserving Iraq's sovereignty and in calling a Middle East peace conference.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled
description: To the Editor:

title: Parolee Confessed to Killing Of Girl, 15, Prosecutor Says
description: The Brooklyn parolee charged with killing a 15-year-old girl under the Williamsburg Bridge in December has admitted to strangling her, sexually assaulting her and burning her body, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Hard Sell in Congress For Banking Industry
description: Banks are not savings and loans: that is the message banking lobbyists are taking to Capitol Hill. But in seeking legislative help for their industry, they face a hurdle in trying to escape the taint of the savings and loan scandal.

title: Injury to Force Becker Out of Action for Month
description: Boris Becker, who has an injured hamstring, will take a month off from competition, delaying his attempt to regain the No. 1 world ranking.

title: Some Progress Is Reported In Test of Gene Therapy
description: The first patient to be treated with gene therapy, a child suffering from an immune deficiency, is responding, a researcher said today.

title: U.S. Challenge To Billboards
description: In the latest challenge to outdoor advertisers, the Bush Administration is asking Congress to ban new billboards on national highways and main roads in rural areas.

title: How to Film a Gory Story With Restraint
description: Every director, in the opinion of Jonathan Demme, dreams of making a film more terrifying than anything he has ever seen. So Mr. Demme, whose inspired new thriller, "The Silence of the Lambs," is currently playing havoc with pulse rates across the nation, has done what he can to make the world a scarier place.

title: Reshaping the Delicate Art of Skull Surgery With a Computer
description: LAST Wednesday, Dr. Craig D. Hall contemplated 7-month-old Lillian Doyle's misshapen skull as it rotated slowly on the screen. He studied the protruding bone on the right side of the forehead, which gave the face a lopsided tilt. He pondered a large, flat patch at the back of her head, a birth defect normally hidden by a shock of strawberry blonde hair.

title: Lebanon to Press for Israeli Pullout in South
description: Two weeks after deploying regular troops in the embattled south of the country, the Lebanese Government said today that it planned to press Israel to withdraw from the area it maintains as a "security zone" in the area, but a senior official in Israel served notice that his Government would not comply.

title: Jackson Agrees to $2.3 Million Pact
description: Bo obviously knows salary arbitration better than Barry Bonds and Bobby Bonilla.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Pentagon; The Border Skirmishes: Strategy of Many Uses
description: Recent skirmishes along the Saudi border and inside Iraq are part of a coordinated effort by the United States and its allies to gain battlefield intelligence and confuse the Iraqi military about the main points of an allied attack, Pentagon officials say.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; Disproportionate Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; Sleepwalking Through a Too Brief Childhood
description: With its gigantic watch faces and other oversized objects, Huck Snyder's evocative scenery for "Maybe It's Cold Outside" looks like a companion landscape to that in Maurice Sendak's storybook "In the Night Kitchen." The stage setting for this show (written, directed and choreographed by John Kelly, in collaboration with his company) soon becomes a field for the play of Mr. Kelly's imagination, as the audience is transported into a world of shadowy mood and memory. At the heart of the talismanic performance piece (at the Kitchen) are Mr. Kelly's reflections about growing up, about the pleasures and problems -- and the brevity -- of childhood.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Jelen Defeats Steeb at Stuttgart Eric Jelen defeated his his German Davis Cup teammate, Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the $1 million Stuttgart Eurocard Classic. Jelen beat Steeb, who was playing in his hometown, in just over an hour. Jelen will next meet Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, who defeated Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-2. Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden defeated Marc Rosset of Switzerland in the tournament's opening match, 6-4, 6-1. Jonas Svensson of Sweden had the toughest victory of the day, rallying to beat Richard Fromberg of Australia, 6-7, 6-1, 6-0. (AP)

title: Q&A
description: Birdland

title: By Design; Year-Round Hearts
description: Long after Valentine's Day has faded into memory, heart-shaped bits of adornment will still look wonderful.

title: Jury Studies Guard Force At Arena In New Jersey
description: Robert Wasilewski's confrontation with security guards at the Meadowlands Sports Complex started with a dispute over his seat at a hockey game. The guards told him -- incorrectly, he says -- that he was in the wrong one and asked him to leave. There was a fight, he says, and Mr. Wasilewski, a gymnastics instructor from Totowa, N.J., suffered broken ribs and facial bruises. Three Meadowlands guards await trial on assault charges.

title: Restraint by Rangers' Nicholls Lasts Only Briefly
description: At least for one period, Bernie Nicholls kept his promise. The Rangers' high-scoring, highly opinionated center, said before yesterday's 5-4 loss to the Islanders at Madison Square Garden that if he could help it, he would not provoke a fight with Randy Wood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A6-8

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: EASING THE BURDEN Military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf may soon get help from Congress in dealing with economic hardships they may face at home. Page A12.

title: Laws Encourage Car Alarms, But Din May Not Be Worth It
description: It seemed a minor technicality, an amendment to section 167-d(12) of the New York State Insurance Law, and it took effect a decade ago very quietly. But since then every New Yorker has heard its consequences, often around 2 in the morning.

title: Yankees Looking Forward to Getting a New Start
description: The first workout is still four days away, but slowly, as if coaxed south by the sunshine and warmth and the promise of a new start, players have begun to drift into the Yankees' spring camp.

title: It's Back to the Blackboard for Literary Criticism
description: In the world of academic literary criticism, where arguments about "concrete universals" and "moving signifers" can fill volumes and end friendships, high-minded schools of thought are constantly colliding with one another like bumper cars in a scholarly amusement park.

title: Major Step To a Drexel Settlement
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert's bankruptcy case moved a giant step closer to a settlement yesterday as the main parties agreed in principle on how to divide up what is left of the firm. And the agreement, if it holds, could even make it possible for Drexel to reorganize and emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled; Ready for Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Agers Sat on Community Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacterial Towers
description: Scientists searching the depths of Lake Van in eastern Turkey have discovered giant underwater towers that they believe are the largest known examples of bacteria-produced sedimentary chimneys.

title: Judges Are Learning to Adjust to New Twists and Turns
description: As the national figure skating championships ended Sunday night with exhibition performances by the winners, it seemed apparent that the sport had begun to move in new directions.

title: Barclays Plans To Cut Jobs
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that it intended to sharply reduce its work force, perhaps by 15 percent to 20 percent over approximately five years.

title: Texas Calls Halt to Waste-Disposal Sites
description: Reacting to public concern over proposals to burn and bury thousands of tons of chemical wastes, Texas is about to become the first state to suspend development of new commercial hazardous-waste sites and stop expansions of existing ones.

title: U.S. to Sell Only Bills and Notes This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week, which was shortened by yesterday's observance of Washington's Birthday, is confined to the bill and note markets.

title: Iraq Aide Vows Action on CBS Crew
description: The fate of four missing CBS News journalists was raised at today's meeting between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, who promised to take action on the matter, a Soviet official said.

title: Arnold Gurin Is Dead; Welfare Expert Was 73
description: Arnold Gurin, a former professor and dean at Brandeis University, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 73 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Canadian Pork Exports
description: A Commerce Department agency has ruled that subsidized exports of some Canadian pork products are not threatening any United States industry. The agency, the International Trade Commission, approved the ruling unanimously last week, reversing two previous rulings in the case.

title: Boy Dies as a Chimney Falls
description: A 14-year-old boy died on Sunday when a 20-foot chimney collapsed on him after a fire. The state police said the boy, John Hundley, was killed when the brick chimney fell while the youth was looking through the ruins of the Lake Rest Hotel. Investigators said he was exploring the hotel's ruins with a friend, Brian Gleason, 16. Mr. Gleason jumped out of the way and was unhurt.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Postal Rise May Cancel A Direct-Marketing Edge
description: THE recent increase in postal rates appears likely to cut down on the "junk mail" that consumers receive.

title: A Man Burns Himself to Death in a Peace Gesture
description: A man carrying a cardboard peace sign set himself on fire on the Amherst town common today and died, the police said.

title: There at The New Yorker, With Thurber
description: After almost 60 years of cherished eccentricity within its walls at 25 West 43d Street, The New Yorker magazine is moving across the street on Friday. In fact, it is taking along one of the walls.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; 2 U.S. Ships Badly Damaged By Iraqi Mines in Persian Gulf
description: Two American ships, operating off Kuwait in preparation for an allied ground offensive, struck Iraqi mines today. At the same time, allied land forces stepped up artillery barrages and cut lanes for armored vehicles through the twin sand-and-rock berms that mark the Saudi border with Kuwait.

title: Delay in Further Rate Cuts Is Seen
description: A number of credit market analysts think the Federal Reserve Board will probably delay further cuts in short-term interest rates because of indications that a possible end to the Middle East war may be in sight.

title: Canada Southern Pete reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Surprise Gain At Hewlett: Stock Jumps
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company today reported unexpectedly strong earnings, attributing the gain to sales of new products and cost-cutting efforts. Analysts said the quarter's strong results could mark the end of a malaise gripping the computer company that last year prompted the return of its co-founder and chairman, David Packard, to active management.

title: Judge Who Gave Milken 10 Years Wants Him Eligible for Parole in 3
description: The judge who sentenced Michael R. Milken to 10 years in prison in November recommended yesterday that the former financier be eligible for parole after serving three years.

title: Black & Decker Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said it changed its fiscal year from a fiscal year ended on the last Sunday in September to a fiscal year ended on Dec. 31. The change is effective for the 1990 fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1990. The results for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, 1990 are compared to the transition period from Sept. 25, 1989 to Dec. 31, 1989.The company also said revenues for the latest quarter and year included $ 190 million and $ 607 million, respectively, for PRC and Dynapert, which the company fully consolidated into its financial statements in the second quarter 1990.During 1989 Black & Decker acquired Emhart Corp. at $ 40 a share in cash, with the aggreagate purchase price for such shares and related costs totaling about $ 2,650,000,000.Revenues represented total revenues.

title: Ads During War News
description: Four out of five television viewers believe there is "nothing wrong" with broadcasting advertisements during war coverage, according to a survey by Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago. The survey, in 200 telephone interviews in 10 cities at the beginning of the month, showed that 82 percent of adults questioned were not opposed to advertising with war coverage. However, 62 percent agreed that "light-hearted, upbeat commercials are not appropriate during news of the war."

title: Rijo Is Given a 3-Year Contract for $9 Million by Reds
description: Injury-prone Jose Rijo, who has never pitched 200 innings in a season, agreed yesterday to one of the more remarkable contracts in a winter of remarkable contracts. The Cincinnati Reds gave their World Series hero a three-year contract for $9 million and agreed to pay him an additional $500,000 a year if he stays healthy and pitches all season.

title: War Summary
description: KEEPING THE MILITARY PRESSURE ON As hopes for a negotiated settlement rose and fell, artillery and warplanes of the American-led coalition blasted targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Allied planes flew 2,800 missions, ranging over Baghdad and Basra and striking Iraqi front lines and emplacements of the Republican Guards. As President Bush said a Soviet peace proposal had fallen short, the Pentagon reported that ground forces were "ready now" for an offensive. A single Iraqi Scud missile, the 67th fired to date, hit Israel but caused no casualties. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: No casualites were reported, leaving at 16 the number of American ground troops the United States said have been killed in action. Aircraft: An A-10 Thunderbolt attack plane was lost over Kuwait, raising allied losses to 31, and the pilot was reported missing. It was the 22d American plane lost in combat in the Persian Gulf. Naval Vessels: The American guided missile cruise Princeton, which was hit on Monday by an Iraqi mine, was withdrawn from action because of heavy damage. The helicopter carrier Tripoli, which had a 16-by-20-foot hole blasted in her hull by another mine on Monday, patched the damatge and remained on duty. IRAQI FORCES Troops: There we no new reports of Iraqi prisoners. More than 1,200 Iraqi soldiers are reported in captivity. Aricraft: Central Command reported five Iraqi planes destroyed on the ground. The air-to-air loss tallyfor Iraq remains at 42. No additional aircraft tried to flee to Iran. Other Weapons: The allies said they destroyed 5 Scud surface-to-surface missiles, 6 tanks, 5 artillery pieces, 3 armored personnel carriers, 1 multiple rocket launcher, 15 trucks and 2 ammunition bunkers.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Iraq Ready to Pull Out, Iran Says
description: A senior Iranian official said today that Baghdad was ready for an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait.

title: U.S. High Court Will Decide If 'Son of Sam' Law Is Legal
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether New York's "Son of Sam" law, intended to limit the ability of criminals to profit from selling their stories to book publishers or movie makers, violates the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of expression.

title: Rights Report Doesn't Condemn Algeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Daily Vitamins May Reduce Risk of Cataracts
description: Older people who consume plenty of vitamins by eating lots of fruits and vegetables or by taking daily supplements appear to have a lower risk of developing cataracts, the leading cause of blindness, researchers say.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Creditors Accept Southland Plan
description: The creditors of the Southland Corporation, owner of the 7-Eleven convenience stores, have approved a revised bankruptcy reorganization plan, the company said. The company declined to release the vote tally until it is reviewed in bankruptcy court.

title: U.S. Is Investigating a Prosecutor For His Inquiry About D'Amato
description: The Justice Department is investigating a Federal prosecutor in Manhattan to determine whether he acted improperly in pursuing accusations against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and United States Attorney Otto G. Obermaier that later proved false, officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: QUEEN MARGRETHE II of Denmark is in Washington on a state visit, making the cultural as well as political rounds. Besides visiting the National Gallery of Art, the Library of Congress and the National Archives, she and her husband PRINCE HENRIK , accompanied by MARILYN QUAYLE , the Vice President's wife, went to to the National Museum of Women in the Arts yesterday and officially opened a new exhibition, "Ten Danish Women in the Arts."

title: Youth Critically Wounded at School
description: A 15-year-old boy waiting for his brother outside a Brooklyn school was shot in the head and critically wounded yesterday, the police said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; For Bush, Half a Loaf?
description: The Soviet peace initiative seems to present President Bush with a painful choice: pushing for an all-out military victory over Iraq or nurturing a diplomatic settlement that might get the Iraqis out of Kuwait but also allow President Saddam Hussein to save enough political face to preserve his Government.

title: Gulf Weather Today
description: Clouds that crossed Iraq yesterday will linger over the Kurdistan Mountains and Iran. High clouds from Africa will move over Jordon and northwest Saudi Arabia. Southerly winds will promote low clouds in the northern Persian Gulf. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 61, low 38; Riyadh, high 79, low 46; Dhahran, high 75, low 57.

title: Leaders of A.F.L.-C.I.O. Back Health Plan
description: Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. struck a compromise on health-care reform today, endorsing national health insurance as a long-term goal but agreeing to push for more modest changes for now.

title: Angeles Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $ 1,399,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $ 35,000 in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Ceramic Process Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Falling Short of Victory
description: Moscow is trying to do to the U.S. in the Persian Gulf in 1991 what Washington did to Britain and France in the Suez crisis of 1956. Then, these U.S. allies did not have the power to rebuff American demands for a cease-fire in the war against Nasser's Egypt. Today, the U.S. can resist Soviet pressures, and apparently has -- and should.

title: Little Impact From Lottery
description: The Los Angeles Clippers have had eight high first-round choices in the last four years, which should have moved them up in the National Basketball Association. Yet they will probably miss the playoffs again this year for the 15th successive season, the seventh since the lottery was instituted in 1985.

title: CCair Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Amherst Journal; Candles in the Snow Honor Suffering
description: The vigil began here barely an hour after a man carrying a cardboard peace sign strode to the center of the town common on Monday afternoon, doused himself with paint thinner and perished in a plume of fire seconds after striking a match.

title: Women Challenge Church Council Assembly
description: Some of the most striking moments of the World Council of Churches' seventh assembly here have been about women, underlining their increasing influence and inspiring a sort of backlash.

title: Books of The Times; A Black Military Hero Tells His Story
description: Benjamin O. Davis Jr., American An Autobiography 442 pages. Illustrated. Smithsonian Institution Press .

title: Man Says Police Beat Him at Act-Up Rally
description: A former seminarian said yesterday that he had been beaten unconscious by New York City police officers at an Act-Up demonstration in midtown Manhattan and taunted by officers in a jail cell later.

title: Philadelphia Battles a Measles Crisis
description: City health officials here are urging parents to have preschool children vaccinated against measles despite the apparent end of an outbreak of the disease among children from a fundamentalist church that relies on prayer to cure disease.

title: Tax-Exempt Insured Bond
description: Insured tax-exempt bonds, which are attractive to investors because of the protection given to interest and principal payments, also save borrowers considerable amounts of money over the life of an issue as a result of lower interest rates.

title: For Lasting Peace: Tougher Terms
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has now reached what strategists like to call a defining moment. Allied military success has driven Baghdad to send out its first, heavily hedged, feelers for peace. Peace is the allied objective, too. But not to the extent of lunging for a desperate foe's first offer. Even less does it require signing on to a mediator's proposal even before Saddam Hussein has given his response.

title: Fiat Truck Unit To Lay Off 3,000
description: The truck division of Fiat S.p.A., Iveco, announced plans to lay off nearly 3,000 workers for three years, while seeking ways to reduce its work force permanently. A spokesman for Fiat, Italy's largest private employer, said 2,983 workers would receive state unemployment benefits under the plan. Union leaders said they would ask the labor minister to negotiate an accord.

title: 1,000 to 1,500 Job Cuts For Pratt & Whitney
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate between 1,000 and 1,500 jobs from its Pratt & Whitney division in the first half of this year.

title: Communications Satellite reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $ 97.8 million to restructure the company's video entertainment segment.c-Net income

title: How Many More Blocked-Exit Airline Deaths?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE ON SAVING RIVER LOCK SYSTEM
description: A battle to save one of the last hand-operated river navigation systems in the nation is pitting local interests against a Federal agency unwilling to pay a $20 million repair bill.

title: 14-Year-Old Boy Is Charged With Killing 3 in His Family
description: A 14-year-old boy has been charged with fatally stabbing his parents and sister on Sunday and then raping a relative, a teen-age girl.

title: Gooden To Confer With Agent
description: Dwight Gooden's agent said today that he was scheduled to meet with the star right-hander within 24 hours to discuss strategy concerning contract-extension negotiations with the Mets.

title: Nickelodeon Ends Contest
description: Nickelodeon, the cable television network for children, announced the cancellation yesterday of a 15-day telephone sweepstakes after only one week.

title: Charles Greenthal, 73, Real-Estate Executive
description: Charles H. Greenthal, an early leader in the real-estate management field, died on Sunday at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ALC Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,365,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: Japanese Drop a U.S. Investment
description: Fanuc Ltd. of Japan, one of the world's leading producers of machine tools and robots, announced today that it had decided not to buy a stake in a Connecticut machine tool builder that helps make nuclear weapons for the Government.

title: 5 Hurt in Laundry Explosion
description: An explosion at a laundry tonight leveled a Springfield Avenue building and sent at least five people to area hospitals with minor injuries, officials said. Preliminary reports cited a possible gas leak as the cause of the explosion at the Vaux Hall Speed Wash laundry, Police Sgt. Rick Landolfi said. The explosion at 8:03 P.M. leveled the laundry and damaged buildings on either side of it and across the street, he said.

title: Capitol Transamerica reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter and year are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1990.

title: Stop the Clock on the Ground War . . .
description: Make haste slowly the most basic Roman military principle -- fits the moment exactly. Even if the Gorbachev peace plan fails, and it would be reckless for the U.S. to reject it out of hand, we should still patiently continue the air offensive. If we do that, the war should end quite soon, and conclusively. If, by contrast, the ground forces are now unleashed in an urge to finish off this war quickly with one great blow, the outcome is likely to be prolonged and inconclusive -- even if there is a smashing battlefield victory at first.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Pro Basketball; 2 Are Fined for Fight
description: Frank Brickowski of the Milwaukee Bucks was fined $7,500 and suspended for one game and Greg Kite of the Orlando Magic was fined $5,000 yesterday as a result of their fight in a game Sunday at Orlando. Brickowski will also lose a game's pay for sitting out last night's game against the Miami Heat.(AP)

title: Esther Fisher, Pianist, 90
description: Esther Fisher, a classical pianist, died here on Feb. 12. She was 90 years old.

title: Wimpy Winter
description: Well, there goes the season. Winter made a last desperate attempt to live up to its name over the weekend and by yesterday, once again, gave up. There will be some nasty days ahead and surely more rain, like the mild showers that endured through yesterday, but not much else wintry: there's just too much sun.

title: Iron Hand Reshapes Philadelphia's School System
description: It is early morning and Constance Elaine Clayton steps briskly from the gilded doors of an empty elevator, her raincoat billowing in her wake. Her staff greets her with a bright "Good morning, Dr. Clayton," before the Superintendent of Philadelphia's public schools, the sixth largest system in the United States, settles into her office, her presence scenting the air with perfume and power.

title: California Biotechnology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Age (Relax!) Comes to Turbulent Poland
description: Edward Mielnik took a long draw on his Marlboro, sipped a cup of sweetened black coffee -- his third in an hour -- and told the crowd gathered at the International Center for People and Earth Renewal that their biggest problem was stress. "You all need to relax, to breathe better," he said.

title: Book on Church Is Attacked Baselessly
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavalier Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
About New York; Haitians Talk Of New Pride And Going Home
description: The usual crowd was coming and going at Augustine's Barber Shop at 172 Park Place in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn on Saturday morning. The shop looks like any barbershop with its striped poles and bathing beauty calendar, but a pile of French-language newspapers and snapshots on a mirror identify it as the Haitian meeting spot it is.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRESIDENT BUSH will award MARGARET THATCHER the Medal of Freedom on March 7, when the former Prime Minister of Britain is to be in Washington on a private visit. The medal, established by President Harry S. Truman in 1945, is the highest civil honor bestowed by the United States Government.

title: M.C. Hammer Drops In on Harlem Youngsters
description: A group of music-industry executives, in New York for tonight's Grammy Awards show, held an informal question-and-answer session yesterday at the Wadleigh Alternative Arts Middle School in Harlem, and the 70 seventh-graders were a tough audience -- for a while.

title: CUNY Standards Plan Will Hurt the Needy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Risks and the Benefits Of Letting Sick Banks Die
description: When banks fail, the carnage horrifies most onlookers. Not so some colder-blooded bankers and economists. They say bank failures, even huge ones, do not necessarily hurt, and may even help, the economy.

title: Trying to Economize, New York Creates Its Own Alcatraz
description: On a broad, flat tract of land here along the drably named Institution Road, New York State is transforming a modern maximum-security prison into its own version of Alcatraz.

title: Developing New and More Powerful Drugs
description: Working at a crossroads between chemistry and immunology, scientists are creating a host of custom-made antibodies that could speed chemical reactions in a way that no known naturally occurring catalysts or enzymes now do. The refinement of these substances, called catalytic antibodies, could open the door to new, more potent drugs, and chemical processes.

title: Sergeant's Slap At Patrol Plan Creates a Storm
description: A police training sergeant was ordered transferred from his Queens precinct yesterday for publicly disparaging the program at the heart of the department's shift to neighborhood policing. But hours later, the Police Commissioner overruled local commanders and rescinded the transfer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A12-14

title: Auto-Trol Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Taipei Journal; Kidnapper of Chiang Kai-shek Ends Long Silence
description: At almost 90 years of age, the Young Marshal seems to have everything a man could want -- public esteem, a splendid house, a family extending for four generations. But he still has one other, more poignant desire: to discard his reputation as one of the greatest heroes in modern Chinese history

title: INSIDE
description: Death Sentence Commuted The Governor of Virginia spared the life of a Norfolk man whose long fight to overturn a 1979 death sentence has drawn national attention. Page A16. Tough Day for Police Critic A New York police sergeant was transferred for criticizing the city's new policing program. Then the transfer was rescinded. Page B1. Advantage, New York City Mayor Dinkins says a $150 million expansion plan will keep the United States Open tennis tournament in Flushing Meadows. Page D25.

title: Universal Computer Code Due
description: A group of leading computer companies today announced an ambitious effort to develop a lingua franca for the electronics age, a universal digital code that could be used by computers to represent letters and characters in all the world's languages.

title: Accounts
description: * Marshalls Inc., the discount clothing retailer based in Wakefield, Mass., to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, with a budget of $25 million. * Albertson's Inc., Boise, Idaho, a food and drug chain, to Kresser/ Craig, Los Angeles. Billings are estimated at $15 to $20 million. * Encyclopaedia Britannica USA, a division of Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., to Shain/Colavito/Pensabene Direct, New York, for television and print advertising. Billings are approximately $5 million. * Winthrop Pharmaceuticals, New York, to Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell, New York, for Primacor IV, a new cardiovascular treatment. Billings are estimated at more than $1 million. * Foster Wheeler Corp., Clinton, N.J., a construction and real estate company, to Gianettino & Meredith Advertising Inc., Short Hills, N.J. Billings are estimated at $1 million. * Southern Brands Inc. to Long, Haymes & Carr Inc., Winston Salem, N.C., for two lines of Southern food products: Zatarain's and House Autry Mills. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Alberta Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CAUTION IS URGED ON VETERANS' AID
description: Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, warned Congress today that it must cut domestic programs to offset the costs of any new benefits it might establish for veterans of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Brown-Forman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment due to the adoption of FASB Statement No. 96 ''accounting for income taxes'' of $ 11,526,000, or 41 cents a share.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 56,427,000, or $ 2.01 a share, included writeoff of $ 59.9 million for the carrying value of California Cooler intangible assets. This noncash charge includes the reversal of previously established reserve for contingencies associated with the California Cooler acquisition.

title: French Company Makes Bid Of $1.8 Billion for Square D
description: The Square D Company, a big electrical-equipment manufacturer that has been the object of much takeover speculation in recent months, said today that a French company had proposed acquiring it for roughly $1.8 billion.

title: In Beijing, a Most Imperial Family Dinner
description: THERE is no sign indicating the location of one of the most unusual and exclusive eating places in Beijing, Family Li's Restaurant. Many customers spend hours trying to find it and get lost.

title: Marketing in the Classroom: Assets vs. Liabilities
description: When Whittle Communications introduced a daily television news program, with advertising, in schoolrooms last year, the action touched off a noisy debate among educators, corporations and consumer advocates about marketing to impressionable children.

title: Buffets Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 2
description: b-Included a $ 209,000 charge to taxes to boost effective tax rate for the year overall to appropriate level.

title: Real Estate; New Office Tower Project Is Houston's First in 5 Years
description: THE Friendswood Development Company, the Houston-based real estate development subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, has broken ground for the first major commercial office building here in more than five years.

title: Writers Mobilizing Against Restrictions On Using Quotations
description: Concern is growing among historians, biographers and other writers of nonfiction that their work may be seriously compromised by new legal constraints on their use of both written sources and material gleaned from interviews.

title: Chrysler Recalls '87 Dakotas
description: The Chrysler Corporation is recalling about 56,000 Dodge Dakota trucks from the 1987 model year that exceed Federal pollution standards, a spokesman said today. The trucks have 22-gallon fuel tanks and either 2.2-liter or 3.9-liter engines. The spokesman said a ring that holds vapor in the tank is too loose and must be tightened, a job that dealers will perform without charge.

title: Cases Under 'Sam' Law: Notorious but Few
description: Their names conjure up memories of some of the most notorious crimes in recent New York history -- Jean Harris, Mark David Chapman, Jack Henry Abbott, to name a few.

title: Business Technology; Old Cans Get a New Life, In Sleek Automobiles
description: Discarded tin cans are being reycycled into automobile parts at the Budd Company's foundry in Waupaca County, Wis., about 55 miles west of Green Bay.

title: Laura Mondadori, Arts Patron, 67
description: Laura Mondadori, a member of a prominent Italian publishing family, died on Wednesday at her home in Milan, Italy. She was 67 years old.

title: Dr. Wilbur G. Downs Dies at 77; Tropical Medicine Expert at Yale
description: Wilbur George Downs, a clinical professor of epidemiology and public health at the Yale University School of Medicine and an expert on tropical medicine, died on Sunday at his home in Branford, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: Reviews/Music; A Guitarist Who Explores New Repertory
description: The Uruguayan guitarist Eduardo Fernandez plays with precision, textural clarity, flexibility in color and dynamics, and a warmth of spirit that brings music of any era to life. He is also curious about new repertory, and he devoted most of his program at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening to recent scores.

title: Bridge
description: An important trend in bidding theory in the past quarter of a century concerns low-level doubles. We have moved farther and farther from the traditional rule: A double is for take-out if, and only if, it is a double of a below-game suit bid when the doubler's partner has not taken any positive action.

title: Announcement Delayed
description: The International Skating Union has delayed announcing the results of a second drug test involving Marina Klimova of the Soviet Union until Friday.

title: Market Place; A Rearrangement Of Damon Stock
description: THE Damon Corporation, an operator of clinical laboratories and one of the last leveraged buyouts financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has done better than it was expected to when it was taken over in 1989. Sales are up, and while heavy debts have forced it to report losses, those losses are a bit less than expected.

title: George A. Follini, Contractor, 80,
description: George A. Follini, a contractor whose companies did road construction in New York City, died on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Misusing the Flag, Again
description: It is saddening when even a few Americans use the flag as a license for persecution. Yet persecution is the word that most captures the trials of Marco Lokar, an Italian citizen who was forced to withdraw from college and hounded out of the United States for refusing to wear an American flag on his basketball uniform.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It has been 45 years since we fought with the Americans in World War II. For the first time since then, we have been able to assert our independence, to ignore the dictates of Moscow. We are happy to be back." -- Lieut. Col. Lubomir Smeyhlik, with the Czechoslovak Army in Saudi Arabia. [ A14:1. ]

title: 4 More Women Report Jabs
description: Officials of the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that four more women had reported being jabbed with something sharp as they walked through Pennsylvania Station. The four attacks, which took place between November and Feb. 11, brought the total number of such incidents reported since November to 13. The incidents are being investigated by the Long Island Rail Road, Amtrak, the Transit Authority and the New York City Police Department.

title: Two Newcomers Make Waves in Ayckbourn Play
description: It couldn't have happened any better for Gillian Anderson if Schwab's Drug Store were still in business.
