A 1990 graduate of the Goodman School of Drama in Chicago, the young actress moved to New York six months ago, found an apartment in Greenwich Village and, when she wasn't auditioning, worked as a waitress at Dojo, a Japanese health food restaurant on St. Mark's Place. She made barely enough money to cover her rent, and the only theater she saw was a performance of "Lettice and Lovage" with Maggie Smith, where she says she practically got a nosebleed in the back of the balcony.

title: Communist Ex-Labor Chief on Trial in Berlin
description: In the courtroom where the former head of East Germany's Communist labor unions is on trial, a drowsy murmur of legalism covers the lawyers, the defendant and the spectators, lulling away any notion of the trial as a confrontation between reunified Germany and eastern Germany's Communist past.

title: Call to an Adult Line Leads to Rape of Girl
description: A man was arrested today on suspicion of raping an 11-year-old girl who had given her address on an adult "party line."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Czechoslovaks; Prague to Desert Sands: Soldiers With a Vision
description: In the grand panoply of the Persian Gulf war, it is easy to overlook the small desert encampment of 200 Czechoslovak soldiers in northern Saudi Arabia.

title: An Expansion of the National Tennis Center Is Announced
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, with the ball in his court, yesterday announced plans for a $150 million expansion of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, the site of the United States Open since 1978.

title: Travis Williams, 45, Green Bay Packers Star
description: Travis Williams, who wrestled with homelessness, poverty and alcohol after setting records as a kick returner with the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 45 years old.

title: A Look at the Viking Who Would Be a Met
description: D. J. Dozier's height was taken, his weight recorded. His blood pressure came next along with an electrocardiogram and then an inspection of his legs and arms.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; American Planes and Big Guns Hit Iraq, Keeping Up the Pressure
description: Artillery batteries and planes of the American-led coalition blasted targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait today, military officials said. Fighter-bombers flew their full quota of missions, ranging over Baghdad and Basra, hitting Iraqi front lines and striking emplacements of the Republican Guard.

title: Nortek Halts Its Dividend
description: Nortek Inc. said today that it would suspend dividend payments after its fourth-quarter loss soared because of a 12.5 percent drop in sales.

title: Maryland's Governor to Free Women Who Killed Abusers
description: Gov. William D. Schaefer of Maryland today commuted the prison sentences of eight women convicted of killing or assaulting abusive men, saying he was convinced that the women had acted in self-defense.

title: Reviews/Music; This Night The Works Are Watery
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's annual concert at Carnegie Hall was held hostage in a labor dispute last week. But on Sunday the orchestra's players and management came to terms, and on Monday evening the orchestra took its place on the Carnegie stage instead of on a picket line in the rain.

title: Campaign for British Knights to Escalate Sneaker Wars
description: THE latest volley in the sneaker wars will be fired tonight during the Grammy Awards show in commercials for British Knights athletic shoes that use an updated version of a classic insult.

title: Comsat Reports Loss
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation today reported a loss for the fourth quarter and for all of 1990, because of a reorganization of its Video Entertainment division. For the fourth quarter, Comsat reported a loss of $66.3 million, compared with a profit of $7.6 million, or 39 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1989. Without the reorganization, net income would have been $6.3 million, or 33 cents a share.

title: U.S. Security Prices Fall Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped a bit further yesterday in light trading, as credit market participants lightened up positions on the eve of two days of Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan on the economy and monetary policy.

title: What's the Real Goal?
description: Having offered to withdraw from Kuwait on its own terms and seeming to cooperate in another withdrawal proposal by Mikhail Gorbachev, Iraq appears to be seeking a way out of the desert war. But that good news could pose a dilemma for President Bush.

title: Deals; Basketball
description: N.B.A. -- Suspended Frank Brickowski, Milwaukee Bucks forward, for one game and fined him $7,500 and fined Greg Kite, Orlando Magic center, $5,000 for fighting in a game Feb. 17.

title: Europeans May Release Aid Frozen Over Baltics
description: Hoping to nudge Moscow toward a negotiated settlement to the crisis in the Baltic republics, European Community foreign ministers signaled today that they might soon approve a $560 million aid package that was frozen after the recent Soviet crackdown in Lithuania and Latvia.

title: Planes, Refrains And Tennis
description: The Hon. David N. Dinkins, the second most famous plane-swatter in Gotham history, was explaining yesterday afternoon along with a handful of others why New York City ought to have a new tennis center in its midst, and why the old one had become one bum joint.

title: Arizona Legislator Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: A state legislator who had told an undercover informer that "my favorite line is, 'What's in it for me?' " pleaded guilty today to five felony counts involving political bribery.

title: The Latest in Marketing? Start With Store Brands
description: LANCE into other people's shopping carts in a checkout line -- for some, a favorite supermarket activity -- and chances are you will see at least one product carrying the store's own label. The reason? Most of the time, it's to save money, and there are statistics to confirm this.

title: Allen Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge related to patent litigation of $ 18,554,000.c-Net income and the year included income from discontinued operations of $ 8,855,000, or $ 1.08 a share.

title: Economic Scene; Perestroika With Tears
description: COULD Mikhail Gorbachev become another Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean tyrant who rebuilt the Chilean economy with blood and iron?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Kremlin, Citing Suffering, Opposes a Land Offensive
description: Soviet officials argued today against beginning a ground offensive against Iraq, saying that its only effect would be enormous suffering and the destruction of the country.

title: Daily News and Unions Still Remain Far Apart
description: While The Daily News and leaders of its striking unions are expected to resume bargaining, perhaps as soon as today, four days of marathon talks were recessed early yesterday with both sides saying they remained very far apart on critical issues.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Salomon Taking A 700-Job Unit Out of New York
description: Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it would move the 700 jobs in its domestic operations division to Tampa, Fla., the first major investment banking concern to relocate a large division out of New York City, the traditional capital of investment banking.

title: Mayor Should Appoint Board of Ed Majority
description: To the Editor:

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Priest in Search of a Job
description: In the year since he resigned from Covenant House, the Rev. Bruce Ritter has continued to live on his own, ignoring an order by his Franciscan superiors to return to a friary.

title: Boeheim Wards Off Critics From All Corners
description: As his players boarded a team bus last Friday, Jim Boeheim, the head basketball coach at Syracuse University, sat in his office at Manley Field House doing some routine last-minute checking: Was the bus loaded? Who wasn't on it? Why? Where were they?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Pro Football; Broncos Hire Stautner
description: Ernie Stautner, the defensive coordinator of the Dallas Cowboys from 1966 to 1988, was selected yesterday as the defensive line coach of Denver, where he will be reunited with Dan Reeves, the Broncos' head coach who is also a former Cowboys assistant.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; A Ground-War Prelude: Captured Enemy Colors
description: In important ways, the ground war against Iraq has already begun.

title: Southern Winter Dish: Black-Eyed Peas in a Ragout
description: VEGETABLES are one of the best buys for creating those soul-warming nutritious dishes that we all crave in the winter. Not only are they high in protein, vitamins and fiber, but with prices constantly rising at the supermarket, vegetables are also one of the least expensive, highest-yielding foods.

title: Insurgents in India's Northeast Call for Peace Talks
description: A powerful insurgent group in the northeastern state of Assam says it is ready for negotiations and a peaceful settlement of its demands. But it continues to inspire fear here despite a three-month crackdown by Indian Army and paramilitary troops.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a measles outbreak in Philadelphia referred incorrectly in some copies to cases among children who attend two churches that preach reliance on faith to cure disease. Philadelphia health officials said about 500 cases of measles had been reported citywide, including about 220 involving children at the churches.

title: Food Notes
description: Two Major Tastings

title: Gas Is Nearing Pre-invasion Price
description: The price of gasoline at the pump is within a penny of where it was before the Persian Gulf crisis began in August, not counting tax increases, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Automobile Association.

title: College Basketball; Dehere's Second-Half Scoring Leads Seton Hall Past Niagara
description: Seton Hall, aiming for an N.C.A.A. tournament bid, was almost caught napping at home tonight before Terry Dehere answered a wake-up call in the second half. Dehere scored 19 of his team-high 22 points to lead Seton Hall to a 76-61 victory over Niagara at Walsh Gym. The nonconference victory gave the Pirates a 17-7 record.

title: Nets, With 17th Victory, Match Their '89-90 Total
description: Every basketball victory cannot be a splendid show of passing, shooting and playing. Some have to be messy and sloppy like tonight's version of ragged play at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Plan Is Approved in Los Angeles To Require Cutback in Water Use
description: The City Council approved a plan today that would require residents of the nation's second-largest city to ration their water use or face large fines.

title: Cohu Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MGM-Pathe Delays Film
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company halted next month's planned release of "Delirious" because it is too cash-strapped to raise $7 million to promote the John Candy comedy, a newspaper reported today.

title: Knicks Return to Reality as the Hawks Prevail
description: If anyone is dreaming that the Knicks are becoming consistent, wake up.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Jan. 17 about the Dancellington company at Symphony Space included an erroneous identification supplied in the printed program for one dancer. A letter dated Feb. 11 from Meyuki Kato says the dancer, in the Sugarplum Fairy section of "Crackerjazz; Peter and the Duke," was she, not Lisa Scialabba.

title: Dow Down 2.47; High-Tech Stocks Strong
description: Led by I.B.M., high-tech stocks had a good day yesterday, but stocks weakened across the board as investors watched for stronger signs of either peace or all-out ground war in the Persian Gulf.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Rev. JESSE JACKSON has become the second living American to be honored with a likeness of himself in a Postal Service pictorial cancellation. He is one of a group of famous black Americans pictured.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: I HAVE been cooking much more pork and less beef and veal in the last year. One reason is there are so many innovative pork dishes. Another is the relative healthfulness of lean pork as opposed to red meat, the American pork industry having made great strides in producing leaner cuts of meat without losing moisture or flavor.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday about New York state psychiatric hospitals reversed the labels on bars showing numbers of patients and staff members. The gray bars represented patients; the white bars represented staff members. On Jan. 3, 1991, there were 14,023 patients and 15,495 staff members.

title: Coors Posts Loss in Period
description: The Adolph Coors Company today reported a fourth-quarter loss largely because of the expected costs of a landfill cleanup, but the brewing company's profits for 1990 as a whole tripled on the strength of surging sales.

title: Bird Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax credit of $ 6,478,000 related to discontinued operations in the quarter and year.

title: For 'Citizen Kane,' a Fresh Start at 50
description: "Citizen Kane," considered by many critics to be the greatest American film, is to be reissued for commercial theatrical release on May 1, exactly 50 years after it was first shown in movie theaters. The film, the story of a newspaper tycoon's rise to wealth and power, was directed, written and produced by Orson Welles, then 25 years old, who also starred as the publisher, Charles Foster Kane.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; BUSH CRITICIZES SOVIET PLAN AS INADEQUATE TO END WAR; IRAQI MAY REVISIT MOSCOW
description: Without disclosing the contents of Moscow's formula for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, President Bush said today that the plan "falls well short of what would be required" to stop the war with Iraq. But Mr. Bush did not reject the offer outright and sent President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a detailed response.

title: Group Efforts Back Neediest Cases Fund
description: After Thomas F. Liotti gave $200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, he sent letters to the 200 other offices in the building where he works, urging them to contribute to the fund.

title: Johnson's Docket Busy
description: Ben Johnson missed a date with a judge yesterday, but kept one with the police. The sprinter, who has been charged with assaulting Cheryl Thibedeau, a runner, was to appear in the provincial division of Ontario Court to set a trial date. He did not show up, but his lawyer, Martin Kerbel, persuaded Judge Paul Reinhardt to move the hearing date to March 6.

title: How Many More Blocked-Exit Airline Deaths?; Not Surprised
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Computer Associates International Inc., Garden City, L.I., the software concern, said it had offered to buy all shares of its common stock from shareholders of record of 99 or fewer shares at the closing price on the day each certificate is received. * CRSS Inc., Houston, an architecture and engineering company, said it had received a contract from the Philip Morris Cos. to provide engineering design services and equipment procurement for the previously announced $400 million expansion of the Philip Morris cigarette plant in Cabarrus, N.C. * JTN Acquisition Corp., a concern led by Perry Sutherland and Barry Rosenstein, said it had ended its offer to buy up to 6,177,825 shares of common stock of Justin Industries., Fort Worth, a manufacturer of bricks and other clay products, for $18 a share in cash and had sold more than a million shares. * LDDS Communications Inc., Jackson, Miss., a long-distance telephone service and magazine publishing concern, said it had agreed to acquire two long-distance telephone service resellers with combined revenues of about $110 million. * Malev, Budapest, an airline, said it had entered into a preliminary agreement to buy two 767-200 ER jets from the Boeing Co., Seattle. Terms were not disclosed . * National-Standard Co., Niles, Mich., said it would divest portions of its speciality wire business. The company also said it had reached a tentative agreement for the sale of its tire-mold business in Hunfeld, Germany. * Northwestern Steel and Wire Inc., Sterling, Ill., has won certification as a supplier to construction projects financed by the Japanese Government. * Nycor Inc., Peapack, N.J., an investment company, announced it had nominated Sal Giordano Jr., William J. Brennan and Howard S. Modlin to the board of Zenith Electronics Corp., Glenview Ill., of which Nycor is the largest stockholder. * Tandycrafts Inc., Fort Worth, a leather goods and wood frame company, said it would offer to buy back shares from shareholders with 99 or fewer shares at $20 a share.

title: Walter Joyce, Consultant, 58
description: Walter Joyce, a magazine publishing consultant, died on Saturday at the Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Leader's Slaying Incites Ex-Contras
description: The killing of Enrique Bermudez, the former contra rebel commander, could set off a new round of political violence in Nicaragua after a year of relative peace, United States and Nicaraguan officials say.

title: Cracked Door Hinges Jeopardize First Shuttle Mission of the Year
description: The space agency's first shuttle flight of the year, a military mission in March, could be delayed up to a month because of cracked door hinges that appear limited to the Discovery spacecraft, officials said today.

title: Coming Back: A Run in the Dark
description: The fight was one month away, and he was getting ready.

title: A Woman, 80, Is Found Slain
description: An 80-year-old woman was found slain in her apartment in Manhattan yesterday, the police said. The victim, Pauline Sandler, might have been suffocated with a pillow that was found nearby, a police spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner, said. The police entered the apartment at 235 West 102d Street at 12:35 P.M. after a niece called 911, saying she had been unable to reach her aunt by telephone.

title: William La Verdiere, A Priest, Is Dead at 88
description: The Rev. William La Verdiere, pastor of St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan for many years, died on Sunday at the Bethany Center of the Blessed Sacrament Fathers and Brothers Monastery in Cleveland. He was 88 years old and lived in New York until he moved to the center 16 months ago because of failing health.

title: COURT TO REVIEW CASE FROM GEORGIA ON DESEGREGATION
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to try once again to define the point at which formerly segregated school systems may be released from Federal court supervision.

title: H.R. Medina Jr., 78, Lawyer and Expert in Libel and Privacy
description: Harold R. Medina Jr., a New York trial lawyer who was an authority on libel, privacy and copyright cases, died on Sunday at his home in Village of Golf, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: Bridgestone Cuts
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. said it plans to lay off 500 salaried workers, half of them at the company's Akron headquarters, because of slumping tire sales. The company also said it plans to leave 300 vacant jobs unfilled. The layoffs will reduce Bridgestone-Firestone's salaried staff in Akron to 1,500, down 25 percent in the past 18 months. The cuts are scheduled to take effect by June 30. There are 11,000 Bridgestone-Firestone white-collar employees nationwide and some 20,000 hourly workers.

title: Colleen Sullivan, 40, Ex-Editor of Magazine
description: Colleen M. Sullivan, a former executive editor of Manhattan, inc. who also held editing positions at several newspapers, including The New York Times, was found dead Thursday in a motel room in West Hollywood, Calif. She was 40 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a manufacturer of health care products, named George T. Maloney chairman and chief executive. * Bloomingdale's, New York, a division of Federated Department Stores, promoted Susan D. Kronick to senior executive vice president and director of stores. * Cincinnati Milacron Inc., a manufacturer of industrial products, named Raymond E. Ross executive vice president of operations. * Edward S. Gordon Co., New York, a full-service real estate firm, named Sharon Bands and Randy Kohana managing directors. * Hearst Entertainment Productions Inc., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Hearst Corp., named Glenda Grant president of its movie and miniseries division, a new position. * Orion Pictures Corp., New York, named Beverly Weinstein senior vice president-media services. * Time Warner Inc., New York, named Tod Hullin senior vice president-communications and public affairs and Jeanette Lerman vice president-corporate communications. * Trimble Navigation Ltd., Sunnyvale, Calif., a manufacturer of satellite-based navigation systems, named William N. Stirlen chief financial officer. * Wasserstein Perella & Co. International Ltd., London, the British merchant banking arm of Wasserstein Perella Group Inc., named Lord Robert Haslam non-executive chairman.

title: Wine Talk
description: VERONIQUE RASKIN is not one to beat about the bush. "There is no such thing as sulfur-free wine," she said. "Never has been, never will be."

title: Profits Down At Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. said today that its profits fell sharply in the fourth quarter and for all of last year because of one-time gains that inflated the 1989 figures.

title: Radio Personality Is Slain
description: A Haitian radio personality was shot to death Monday night as he left a nightclub. The 47-year-old victim, Jean Claude Olivier, broadcast a weekday program on radio station WQLY-AM that mixed music, humor, news and audience calls, often about Haitian politics. The police said today that they had neither a suspect nor a motive for the slaying.

title: Decision on 'Son of Sam' Law
description: The Supreme Court agreed to consider New York's "Son of Sam" law, which limits criminals' rights to profit from their stories. Page B1.

title: INCUMBENT SAVES SEAT IN NEBRASKA
description: With the incumbent casting the deciding ballot, the Nebraska Legislature today rejected a proposal to seat his challenger in a disputed election.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Johnson Leads Suns Past Celtics Kevin Johnson scored 15 of his 25 points in the fourth period last night as the Phoenix Suns won their 12th consecutive home game and ended Boston's eight-game winning streak by beating the Celtics, 109-105. Dan Majerle added 23 points, Xavier McDaniel 22 and Jeff Hornacek 19 for the Suns, who are 20-4 at home this season and 8-1 against Eastern Conference teams. Boston, which had won five in a row on the road, was playing its fourth straight game without Kevin McHale, who has a sprained left ankle. Reggie Lewis paced the Celtics with 23 points. Robert Parish had 21 plus a season-high 20 rebounds. The Suns trailed, 78-69, with 3 minutes 29 seconds remaining before closing out the third quarter with a 7-0 spurt to get to 82-80. Johnson then opened the fourth quarter with a 3-point play to put Phoenix ahead to stay. (AP) 76ers 107, SuperSonics 104: Ron Anderson's game-tying 3-pointer with 28 seconds left in regulation and his layup at the start of overtime led Philadelphia, playing at home, past Seattle. Seattle took a 97-94 lead with 34 seconds left in regulation on Gary Payton's free throw. Anderson then launched a 24-footer to tie the score, 97-97, and the game went into overtime after both teams missed desperation shots. (AP) Pacers 115, Hornets 102: Chuck Person scored 30 points as Indiana won for the first time in four games at Charlotte Coliseum. Reggie Miller added 29 points for Indiana. Indiana won its third straight game; Charlotte lost for the 15th time in 18 games. (AP)

title: Holocaust Skeptic Who Gives Advice on Death Faces Trial
description: A judge in this Boston suburb refused today to dismiss the case against a Holocaust revisionist and execution-machine builder who prosecutors say has been practicing engineering without a license.

title: Virginia Governor Blocks an Execution
description: Under intense pressure from both conservatives and liberals, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia decided today to spare the life of Joseph M. Giarratano Jr., a Norfolk fisherman whose long struggle to overturn a 1979 death sentence for murder has gained him a national reputation as an accomplished "jailhouse lawyer."

title: Review/Rock; A Band With a Beat Made For Dancing
description: Twenty-five years ago, a band with the instincts of INXS would have been playing for sock hop dancers and garage-rock entrepreneurs, pounding out riff after riff and calling for ecstasy in three-minute stretches. As rock moved back to the dance floor in the 1980's, the Australian band INXS (pronounced "in excess") emerged triumphant. With an array of solid, mostly borrowed riffs backing a singer, Michael Hutchence, who draws screams from teen-age girls, INXS has been selling millions of albums since the mid-1980's. At Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, young girls were dancing as they squealed.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Legacy of Mary Richards
description: Mary Richards made it all O.K. -- O.K. to be a single woman, O.K. to be over 30, O.K. to be independent. She even made it acceptable to stay home alone and watch her if you had a mind to, rather than go out on a date, the once-obligatory Saturday night date that women used to say they had even when they didn't.

title: Blessings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
New York City Cites New Speed in Arraignments
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown and District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday that the process of taking suspects before judges for arraignment in New York City had been speeded significantly.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Thursday about "Germany: The Empire Within" rendered the author's name incorrectly. She is Amity Shlaes.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Home Front; Arab-Americans Fear a Land War's Backlash
description: As the United States inches closer to a ground war in the Persian Gulf, Hani Fakhouri worries more and more what the toll will be on Arab-Americans.

title: Slight Profit at Turner
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. today reported a small profit for the fourth quarter of last year, as well as its first annual profit since 1985. For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, TBS had earnings of $7.3 million, compared with a $110.9 million loss in the comparable 1989 period. Revenues totaled $356.5 million, up 21.7 percent from $292.8 million. For the year, Turner reported a profit of $4.6 million, compared with a loss of $70.7 million in 1989. Revenues rose 31 percent, to $1.39 billion from $1.06 billion.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 280,000 from reversal of tax loss carryforward in the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 3,590,000, or 37 cents a share, in the year, and the periods also included loss provisions for investment in Midway Airlines Inc. of $ 12,500,000 for the quarter and $ 15,000,000 for the year.c-Net incomed-Included a loss of $ 228,000 in the quarter and income of $ 1,093,000, or 11 cents a share, in the year, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 1,300,000, or 14 cents a share, and $ 3,900,000, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Smokers' Rights Bill Tests Florio's Power Vs. Tobacco Lobby's
description: The tobacco lobby is trying to tap the anger at Gov. Jim Florio's tax policies to press into law a bill that would protect smokers from discrimination by employers.

title: Maxwell Deal Challenged
description: The French construction company Bouygues S.A. has filed suit in a Paris court to block the British publisher Robert Maxwell from selling most of his 12 percent stake in the French television channel TF1 to the investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Fight Crime, and Enjoy It
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, who last year asked New Yorkers to leave their homes on Tuesday nights to help take back the streets from criminals, is now offering somewhere to go.

title: Eating Well
description: SERVING-SIZE deflation is the flip side of grade inflation. Just as the latter can turn a C student into a more academically acceptable B student, the former can turn fatty, caloric, over-salted food products and recipes into models of nutritional virtue.

title: World Bank Sets Sale of Bond Issue
description: The World Bank plans to price for sale today its fourth global bond issue totaling $1.5 billion through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company and J.P. Morgan Securities Ltd.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about the new Maryland abortion law misstated a provision regarding health care workers who refuse to refer women for abortions. The new action removes immunity for failure to refer such a patient; it does not bar lawsuits in such cases.

title: Frances Shanahan, 88, Nun and Teacher, Dies
description: Sister Frances Shanahan, a member of the Ursuline Order and a retired teacher, died on Friday at New Rochelle Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived at the Convent of St. Teresa in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: American National Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Raytheon Is Looking Beyond the Pentagon
description: The Raytheon Company, the maker of the highly successful Patriot missile-defense system and other sophisticated military hardware, has proved itself to be one of the most technically proficient and profitable Pentagon contractors. But it has yet to prove that in can make sustained profits on its more mundane products, like Caloric stoves.

title: Top Bellcore Post Filled By Inventor-Executive
description: Bellcore, a research and development consortium for the nation's seven regional telephone companies, yesterday chose George H. Heilmeier, a Texas Instruments executive and inventor, to be its new president and chief executive.

title: Harrods to Cut 600 From Work Force
description: Harrods department store, whose popularity with tourists has made it a London landmark, said it would slash 14 percent of its work force, partly because of a drop in tourism caused by the war in the Persian Gulf. Harrods said the 600 job cuts had also been caused by Britain's deepening recession.

title: Book Notes
description: 'Scarlett,' the Sequel

title: Key Rates
NO CANCER THREAT FOUND IN FLUORIDE
description: Federal health officials said today that fluoride should continue to be used to help prevent tooth decay, and that a yearlong review of scientific studies had found no evidence that fluoride caused cancer in humans.

title: Refueling of Jets In India to Stop
description: United States military transport aircraft traveling to and from the Persian Gulf will stop refueling in India beginning on Wednesday, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Merrill Striving Hard To Be His Own Man
description: When the season came to an uneventful end last October, Stump Merrill did the thing he has done every autumn since he made baseball his livelihood.

title: I.R.A. Bombs And Motives
description: The bombs that rocked two central London railroad stations on Monday, killing one man and wounding 40, appear to signal a change of tactics by the Irish Republican Army. For the first time in more than seven years, the group has inflicted casualties among ordinary civilians in England.

title: Steisel Seeks Ruling From Conflicts Panel On Florida Vacation
description: First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said yesterday that he had asked the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board to review whether he violated any city ethics rules by vacationing last month at the Florida condominium of his friend, Sid Davidoff, a prominent lawyer who routinely lobbies city officials.

title: Making History: A Feast That Fed The Father of The Country
description: CHERRY pie used to be associated with Washington's birthday, at least in the minds of children being taught not to tell a lie.

title: Barry (R.G.) (A) reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 29
description: b-Included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $ 4,124,000 after taxes.c-Net income

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: CHRONICLE
description: An Internal Revenue Service auction of three homes owned by JOE CONFORTE , the former owner of the Mustang Ranch, and his wife, SALLY CONFORTE , was postponed yesterday pending the outcome of a legal challenge against the I.R.S.

title: Circus Circus Chief to Retire Within Year
description: A co-founder of Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., which parlayed a small casino into a major Las Vegas gaming operation, said yesterday that he planned to retire as chief executive within a year. He also announced a new management lineup for the company.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sidelines column of SportsMonday this week about the son of the former Yankee Roger Maris misidentified the golf tour on which the son, Randy Maris, plays. It is the United States Pro Tour.

title: Yields Off On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
description: Except at a few scattered banks, yields on most certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; For New American Pilgrim, Israel Offers Missile Sites
description: American visitors on political pilgrimages to Israel seldom visit the Western Wall in Jerusalem's Old City in these tense times. Instead, pilgrims are flocking to this nation's newest shrine: the Patriot missile batteries circling the Tel Aviv area.

title: Lyons Bows Out With a Few Tears
description: Marty Lyons, who symbolized the Jets era that almost was, retired gracefully and emotionally today.

title: Nothing Humane About Fur Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Limited's Net Climbs 12.5%
description: Limited Inc. said today its fourth-quarter profits rose by 12.5 percent from a year earlier as sales increased 10.2 percent.

title: A Shabby French Sulk
description: In much of Europe, the war in the gulf is increasingly called "the American war," despite the coalition of 28 states against Iraq. The careful consultation that brought international consensus is frittering away amid charges that it was all a manipulation by Washington.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'From a Distance'

title: WAR IN THE GULF: China; BEIJING SKEPTICAL OF U.S. GULF ROLE
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has described the Persian Gulf war not as a just war but as an example of "big hegemonists beating up small hegemonists," says a Chinese official with direct access to high-level information.

title: Ohio Edison Offer
description: The Ohio Edison Company is offering $150 million in first mortgage bonds due 1998 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Originally the size of the offering was to have been for $125 million, but good investor demand afforded the opportunity to sell more. Underwriters said the bonds were given an 8.75 percent coupon and priced at 100, to yield about 107 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Brunswick Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Sea Mines; Allied Ships Hunt Gulf for Iraqi Mines
description: Allied navies in the northern Persian Gulf are edging north, closer to Iraqi-controlled beaches, as they hunt and destroy mines, one of the treacherous tasks of preparing for a possible amphibious assault.

title: Browns Add Assistants
description: The Cleveland Browns' new head coach, Bill Belichick, has named Gary Tranquill quarterbacks coach and Ernie Adams offensive assistant.

title: Battling Bias, Campuses Face Free Speech Fight
description: Douglas Hann may have thought he was just blowing off steam when he shouted abusive words at fellow students at Brown University last fall, but to others his words constituted harassment.

title: Barrett Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yeltsin, Criticizing Failures, Insists That Gorbachev Quit
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, used a nationwide television appearance tonight to call for the immediate resignation of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for amassing "absolute personal power" and "deceiving the people" with a failed plan for national renewal.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hard Times at Covenant a Year After Ritter's Ouster
description: In recent years, thousands of hungry, exhausted teen-agers who went to Covenant House for help were ushered into a reception area that looked more like the waiting room of a Park Avenue law firm than a shelter.

title: CMS Enhancements Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F.D.A. Issues Warnings On Using Lead Crystal
description: A recent study reported that wine and spirits can leach lead from crystal, and while no one is suggesting that $150 lead crystal goblets or $2,000 decanters be discarded, the Food and Drug Administration is recommending that people rethink the way they use lead crystal containers for food and beverages.

title: Bush Asserts Need for Foreign Oil
description: Saying he was committed to "the power of the marketplace," President Bush presented an energy policy today that he asserted would save energy, increase domestic production of fuels and improve the environment without new taxes or harsh Government edicts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CALVIN KLEIN underwent surgery involving the esophagus Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was peppy and talkative yesterday and plans to be back at work by the end of next week, said Paul Wilmot, the designer's spokesman. He said Mr. Klein would leave the hospital over the weekend.

title: Where's Page 2 in TV News?
description: Every day, I sit in my living room addicted to the television screen, watching the dazzling technology of this war -- one covered live and in color by satellite.

title: Walter J. Slatoff, 68, Ex-Professor at Cornell
description: Walter J. Slatoff, professor emeritus of English literature at Cornell University and former chairman of its English department, died on Saturday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: In Politics, the Power of Little Money
description: Public funding for the 1992 Presidential campaign could be stifled by an ill-considered Treasury Department proposal. Favorites, like President Bush, would gain. Long shots -- and the public -- would lose. The public funding program needs repair, particularly to close the "sewer money" loophole. But the Treasury is off in the wrong direction.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; High Court Rules Aliens Can Sue Over Procedures in Amnesty Law
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Government could be sued over the way it administered the 1986 immigration law.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "One way or another, the army of occupation of Iraq will leave Kuwait soon. And so Kuwait will be liberated -- soon." -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A13:2. ]

title: Review/Theater; Slamming-Door Farce Without Any Doors
description: A true man of the theater always makes a virtue of necessity, and that's what Alan Ayckbourn did when he wrote "Taking Steps" in 1979. In this work, the dramatist and director wanted to concoct a low farce of the door-slamming school -- the play is an homage to Ben Travers, the between-the-wars master of British farce -- but as always, Mr. Ayckbourn needed to tailor his grand plan to fit his home company in Scarborough, England, the Stephen Joseph Theater in the Round. How do you send actors popping in and out of rapidly slamming doors when they are always in full view of the spectators ringing an arena stage?

title: Sonics Trade Polynice To Acquire Benjamin
description: Bob Whitsitt got his man last night.

title: Albanian, Pressured, Promises a New Government
description: Responding to a wave of increasingly bold anti-Communist demonstrations, the President of Albania said today that he would name a new government.

title: A.T.&T. Reportedly Studied Raising NCR Takeover Bid
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company recently discussed raising its bid for the NCR Corporation as part of an ongoing review of its takeover strategy, but rejected the option for the time being, according to persons close to the telephone company who provided the information on the condition that they not be identified further.

title: Victim's Husband Erupts in Rage at Love-Triangle Murder Trial
description: Paul Solomon, whose former lover is standing trial for the murder of Mr. Solomon's wife, Betty Jeanne, erupted into a rage today as the lawyer for the defense ended five days of relentless cross-examination by suggesting that the witness was involved in the killing.

title: Mayors Win Concession on U.S. Aid
description: In a move that appeared to further weaken President Bush's proposal to shift $15 billion in Federal assistance from Federal to state control, a spokesman for the nation's governors told the Senate today that the states have no interest in assuming control over community development funds or other programs whose loss would threaten the cities.

title: On Saving The Forest And Paper
description: ONE way to save a forest is to use recycled paper. A ton saves 17 pulp trees, says Earth Care Paper Inc. of Wisconsin.

title: Everett Lattimore, 63, Ex-New Jersey Mayor
description: Everett C. Lattimore, a former Mayor and Superintendent of Schools in Plainfield, N.J., died on Tuesday at the Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center in Plainfield. He was 63 years old and lived in Plainfield.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 8 about Irish Republican Army attacks in London misstated the death toll from the bombing at Harrods department store in December 1983. Six people died.

title: SOVIET EX-MINISTER GIVES NEW WARNING
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who quit the Gorbachev Government in December with a sharp warning that a dictatorship was looming, re-emerged in public today vowing to defend the "new political thinking" as head of a new independent foreign-policy research institute.

title: Metro Datelines; Electrical Fire Shuts Children's Museum
description: An overheated electrical wire ignited a fire Tuesday night in the Children's Museum of Manhattan, causing damage that has forced the museum to close for repairs. There were no injuries, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: How Much Hate to Tolerate
description: Free speech and human relations seemed to collide last month at Brown University when it expelled a student for racial and religious harassment. In fact, however, to judge by all that is publicly known, the school walked a fine line with sensitivity toward its complex mission.

title: 'Apollo'-Type Program Is Envisioned for Chips
description: Government and semiconductor industry officials are planning a bold new initiative to develop an extremely advanced computer chip and help the struggling American semiconductor industry leapfrog the Japanese.

title: But What's the Fence Going to Be For?
description: IF good fences make good neighbors, good-looking fences make good neighbors happy, says David Bouwkamp, president of the Historical Fence and Ironworks in Cincinnati.

title: Arts Agency Voids Pledge On Obscenity
description: The National Endowment for the Arts agreed yesterday to drop its requirement that the New School for Social Research sign an anti-obscenity pledge to receive the $45,000 grant allotted for fiscal 1990.

title: Panel Decides To Act to End Jail Crowding
description: Trying to end the overcrowding of New York City's jails, the Board of Correction voted yesterday to stop routinely allowing jails to squeeze more inmates than allowed into dormitory areas by Aug. 1.

title: Stuffed Beasts and a Mummy's Hand
description: WHEN his daughter Sierra was born last year, Adrian Gilboe presented the new baby with a gift: an enormous stuffed head of an eland, the African antelope with thick brown hair and twisted horns.

title: Federal Farm Credit Banks In $2.5 Billion Bond Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $2.5 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds, which are divided into four parts and are being sold through various securities dealers.

title: Interpublic Profits Up; Grey Posts 3.1% Decline
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported this week that its net income in the fourth quarter rose 18.5 percent, while Grey Advertising Inc. had a 3.1 percent decline in its profits.

title: 2 Held in Bronx in Slaying of 2; Drug Link Seen
description: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with killing a 20-year-old pregnant woman and her companion as they sat in a parked car in the Bronx on Dec. 30, the police said.

title: Hopes in Jeopardy
description: From the standpoint of records, no track and field athlete competing on the North American Grand Prix circuit can compete with Debi Lawrence of Kenosha, Wis. Among her four victories in walks of varying distances, she set a world record at 1,500 meters and an American record in the mile.

title: Coming Back: Tyson Seems Mellowed
description: For as long as he has occupied the boxing spotlight, Mike Tyson has been a figure of intrigue, eluding easy analysis.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Legislator Offers Option on Taxes And School Subsidy in New Jersey
description: The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Joseph V. Doria Jr., today unveiled a plan to revise Gov. Jim Florio's education and property tax program to shift money from school aid to property tax relief for homeowners.

title: Dow Tumbles by 33.17 Points, to 2,899.01
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday as investors turned skittish and took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average sank 33.17, or 1.1 percent, to 2,899.01, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell almost the same, suggesting that the downturn swept broadly across the market.

title: More States Study Clemency for Women Who Killed Abusers
description: Following the lead set by the Governor of Ohio late last year, Gov. William D. Schaefer of Maryland on Tuesday commuted the prison sentences of eight women convicted of killing or assaulting men who had battered them.

title: In Dinkins Inner Circle, Persistent Disarray
description: More than a year after he took office, Mayor David N. Dinkins's City Hall staff is plagued by internal disarray so persistent and open that other government officials, community groups and even some mayoral aides complain that important policy goals have suffered.

title: Brown Expulsion Not About Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approves $400 Million in Guarantees for Israeli Housing
description: After months of often bitter negotiations, the Bush Administration approved a $400 million loan guarantee to Israel today to enable it to build housing for Soviet Jewish immigrants.

title: Willard S. Elsbree, Educator, 93
description: Willard S. Elsbree, an educator, died on Tuesday at Kendall at Longwood, a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 93 years old.

title: 'Fused at the Hip,' And to the President
description: In an Administration where secrecy and loyalty are prime virtues, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, and Robert M. Gates, his deputy, are the most virtuous.

title: Nebraskan Wins Senate Seat After Challenge Is Dropped
description: The Legislature voted today to seat a state senator whose right to take office was challenged because election officials initialed ballots they should have signed.

title: Puerto Rico Will Choose, Despite White House
description: To the Editor:

title: Strangers on the Phone Share Only-Yesterdays
description: EVERY so often I find on my answering machine in mid-Manhattan a brief cry for help. "What should be used to stop water stains coming through the ceiling?" the voice asks, or "Is it O.K. to use Primer-sealer 1-2-3 for peeling paint in the bathroom?"

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; U.S. AND BRITAIN FAULT SOVIET PLAN
description: The United States and Britain have told Moscow that they find its proposal for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf unacceptable because it lacks a tight timetable for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and does not compel Baghdad to accept all Security Council resolutions on the crisis, Western diplomats said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Airborne Troops; U.S. TROOPS SENSE THE WAIT IS OVER
description: There is a sense along the miles and miles of bleak northern Saudi Arabian desert where the 101st Airborne Division is preparing for battle that the long wait is nearly over.

title: Review/Music; Jorge Mester Conducts Four World Premieres
description: The creative impulse behind "The Music Machine," a work by James Sellars that had its first performance on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall, seemed mildly promising. Piquant, even. As explained by the composer in a program note for this concert by the National Orchestral Association, at the heart of his piece "is the fantastic assumption of a machine that produces music to order, in any style, for any occasion."

title: Gwendolen Carter, Writer and Scholar Of Africa, Dies at 84
description: Gwendolen M. Carter, a teacher and writer who was an authority on Africa and one of the founders of African studies in the United States, died yesterday at her home in Orange City, Fla. She was 84 years old.

title: Litton Earnings Down
description: Litton Industries said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 9.4 percent, mainly reflecting lower profits in its electronics and assembly-line-building divisions. But per-share earnings rose for the quarter and the half because of a stock buyback, Litton said. The company said it earned $40.3 million on revenues of $1.25 billion for the quarter that ended on Jan. 31, compared with $44.5 million on revenues of $1.26 billion in the comparable period a year earlier. Per-share earnings rose to $1.85 from $1.78 for the quarter.

title: Procedures on Bridge Repairs Satisfy U.S. Road Engineers
description: New York City's procedures for inspecting and repairing four troubled East River bridges meet Federal requirements, the Federal Highway Administration says.

title: Senate Vote Revives Sanctions for a Role In Chemical Arms
description: The Senate passed legislation tonight requiring the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.

title: Washington Gun Law Often Rejected
description: To the Editor:

title: A Curious Divergence
description: The world has begun to see the conflict of interests between the Bush Administration, which wants to defeat Saddam Hussein, and the Gorbachev-Akhromeyev regime, which wants to keep its best arms customer in power.

title: Key Rates
Puerto Rico Will Choose, Despite White House; Civil Rights Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: The Economy
description: The numerous proposals for bank reform all seem to agree on a form of deregulation in which the Government's role as a savior of failing banks through deposit insurance would shrink. [ Page A1. ]

title: Accord for Justice
description: Dave Justice, the 1990 National League Rookie of the Year, agreed yesterday with the Atlanta Braves on a one-year contract worth approximately $300,000.

title: Decorating Simply Without Sacrificing Standards
description: THESE are the times that try New Yorkers' stressed-out souls.

title: Farm-Trade Talks Are Set To Resume
description: A crucial round of world trade talks that broke up in disarray last December came alive again today after the European Community countries accepted an American-backed approach for dealing with the issue of agricultural subsidies.

title: Gardener's Treasure: Token of a Colleague
description: "MUMMY did carry this around with her as she toured the garden," said Nigel Nicolson, the 72-year-old son of the British garden writer Vita Sackville-West.

title: Reforms in Banking Call For a Shrinking U.S. Role
description: The proposals for bank reform are piling up -- from the Bush Administration this month, from Congress in several bills, and from bankers, economists and Government regulators in their numerous public statements. They disagree on many points. But a common ground appears to be emerging, and it is this:

title: Cuomo Turning Budget Gap Into Tool to Sell Policy Shifts
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, doing his best to squeeze oratorical lemonade from fiscal lemons, has been speaking often these days about the "opportunities" afforded by the state's $6 billion budget gap. The state, he reasons with relish, must "reform, refocus and renew" its policies and priorities.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. A Shotless Period Hurts Oilers Minnesota held visiting Edmonton without a shot in the second period and Mike Modano had a pair of goals in a 5-1 victory. It was the North Stars' sixth straight victory at home. The shotless period is a record for both teams. The Oilers were held to one shot in a period by Boston in a 1983 game and the North Stars twice held teams to one shot in a period. (AP)

title: Review/Theater; Custer vs. the Indians, as the Indians See It
description: The grace of "Winter Man" at the Dance Theater Workshop on Saturday night came as a surprise, and it was interesting in retrospect to figure out why one approached Andy Teirstein's musical-theater piece about the winning and losing of the West apprehensively and then came away with different feelings.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Fouled Sea; The Gulf Oil Spill Cleanup Flounders in Bureaucracy
description: The cleanup of the Persian Gulf oil spill, the largest in history, has been severely hampered by poor coordination among Saudi agencies, an ill-equipped ministry leading the operation and a lack of money for equipment, Saudi and Western officials say.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about a New York Philharmonic fund-raising event misstated the telephone number for ordering the catalogue. It is (800) 247-3030.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At a screening by the Committee to Protect Journalists Monday night, FRANCOISE SIMON, wife of the missing CBS News correspondent BOB SIMON , made a rare appearance since her husband vanished last month near the border between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. "I'm relieved to learn he's alive," she said, "and I worry for his return."

title: Metro Datelines; Boy, 5, Is Killed Playing With Gun
description: A 5-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed last night in his apartment when a loaded gun went off while he and a 7-year-old friend were playing with it, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: In a Swiss Team event it is not uncommon for a team that is doing badly at the end of the first session to call it quits and head for an early night. It is rare to recover from a bad start, but with victory-point scoring it can be done.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aritmos A.B., Malmos, Sweden, a sporting goods company, has acquired the remaining 23 percent of voting stock in the sporting goods company Puma A.G. for about 70 marks a share. Besides all the voting stock, Aritmos also owns 72 percent of Puma's capital stock. * Chiquita Brands International Inc., Cincinnati, a food company, said it was willing to pay up to $500 million to acquire about half of the fruit production capacity of PPI Del Monte, a unit of Polly Peck International P.L.C., which is in bankruptcy proceedings in Britain. But Polly Peck said PPI Del Monte was not for sale. * Elcor Corp., Dallas, an industrial products manufacturer, said its Chromium Corp. unit would close its leased plant in Chicago this year. * Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., Montgomery, Ala., which operates child-care centers, has cut about 10 percent of its corporate staff and a smaller percentage of its field staff. * Koor Industries, Tel Aviv, a communications, electronics and industrial products company, said it had filed an application with the District Court of Tel Aviv-Jaffa in Israel for approval to restructure its notes in the United States and Israel. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, said it would sell its Family Life Insurance Co. unit to Financial Industries, Austin, Tex., an insurance company. Terms were not disclosed. * Motorola Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., and Northern Telecom Ltd., Mississauga, Ontario, a unit of BCE Inc., will develop enhancements for their cellular telephone products based on new open system standards. * Nucor Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a steel products company, said it would build a hot-rolled sheet steel mill in Hickman, Ark. The cost would be almost $300 million. * Rocky Mountain Helicopters Inc., Provo, Utah, has acquired Avtech Systems Inc., also of Provo, a parts manufacturing company. No terms were disclosed. * United Industrial Corp., New York, said its AAI Corp. unit has received a multiyear contract worth more than $200 million from the National Weather Service and Federal Aviation Administration to provide an automated weather system at U.S. airports. * Universal Health Services Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., was the subject of an S.E.C. filing: Members of the Bass family of Fort Worth, including Lee M. Bass and Perry R. Bass, had cut their stake to 8.6 percent, or 919,332 common shares.

title: Executives Named At Times Group
description: The New York Times Company Magazine Group announced two senior publishing appointments yesterday.

title: Waiting for Perez Again
description: Certain things bring back memories of baseball and spring training: sunshine, cloudless skies and no Pascual Perez. Again.

title: Greenspan Sees Risks to Recovery
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that he expected a recovery from the recession to begin "reasonably soon." But he said the war with Iraq and questions about the health of the banking system and the availability of credit gave his forecast "an unusually high degree of uncertainty."

title: Patience Pays Off For Redmen
description: After watching his team lose three of its last four games and nearly drop out of a tight conference race, Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's head coach, came close to shaking up his lineup.

title: Michigan Court Voids Ban on State-Paid Abortions
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals today struck down a ban on state-paid abortions for poor women.

title: Debt Ratings At Sears Cut
description: Fitch Investors Service, which rates businesses' credit, said yesterday that it had downgraded the senior debt ratings of Sears, Roebuck & Company to BBB from A on about $2.7 billion of debt. A Fitch spokesman said the new rating represented the lowest rating while remaining in investment grade.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD REAGAN, who just celebrated his 80th birthday, is seeking permission from local officials in Simi Valley, Calif., to be buried on the grounds of the $40-million library that is being built as a shrine to his Presidency. The library is scheduled to open in November.

title: 19 Killed as Plane Crashes on Way to Antarctica
description: A chartered Chilean airliner carrying 72 people, mostly American tourists on the way to Antarctica, crashed in a channel near the southern tip of Chile today. The authorities said 19 passengers died.

title: Nutrasweet Cuts Up to 12% of Staff
description: The Nutrasweet Company announced layoffs of up to 204 employees in a move that reinforces its plans to stop developing new products for its fat subsitute, Simplesse. A spokesman, Richard L. Nelson, said the layoff of up to 12 percent of Nutrasweet's work force of 1,700 would affect employees at its headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., outside Chicago; the research and development operation in Mount Prospect, Ill., as well as the aspartame plants in University Park, Ill.; Augusta, Ga., and Harbor Beach, Mich.

title: Pollini Cancels
description: The pianist Maurizio Pollini has canceled his appearance at Carnegie Hall tonight with the Ensemble Intercontemporain because he has the flu, the hall announced. Pierre Boulez will conduct the group as scheduled. Information: 247-7800.

title: KREMLIN HITS BACK AT YELTSIN DEMAND
description: The Kremlin began a full-scale attack against Boris N. Yeltsin today, devoting television programs, front-page articles and press-agency dispatches to denunciations of the Russian leader's call for the resignation of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Clinic Visit
description: There are two examining rooms, a nurse practitioner and the three pediatricians who alternate days. There is a social worker and a health educator. The psychiatrist comes on Fridays.

title: Darwin Turner, 59, A Professor of English
description: Darwin Turner, an authority on African-American literature who taught at the University of Iowa for two decades, died Feb. 11 at Mercy Hospital In Iowa City. He was 59 years old and lived in Iowa City.

title: INSIDE
description: A Surge Back to City Life

title: New York Attics Don't Need Stairs
description: E. B. WHITE once wrote in The New Yorker of a woman he knew who moved into a small apartment with no kitchen shelves. The shelves in the living room had several inches of space between the books, and so the woman arranged her supply of canned goods there.

title: Federal Regulators Tell New England Governors of Plans to Help Banks
description: Federal banking regulators told a meeting of New England governors, bankers and business executives today that new accounting rules to benefit banks would be announced within a week.

title: Woman In the News: Gloria Molina; Hispanic Trailblazer
description: Gloria Molina, the politically combative daughter of a Mexican immigrant laborer, kept her 3-year-old daughter by her side today as she told supporters of the battles she intends to fight now that she has won election as the first Hispanic county supervisor here in more than a century.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Diamond Shamrock Inc. is offering $75 million in 9 3/8 percent noncallable notes due 2001 at 99.837, to yield 9.40 percent, through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P. * NBD Bancorp Inc., Detroit, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million in convertible subordinated debentures due 2006 through Salomon Brothers. * Southwest Airlines Co. is offering $100 million in 9 1/4 percent senior unsecured notes due 1998 at 99.49, to yield 9.35 percent, through Lehman Brothers Inc. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. Common Stock * AST Research Inc., Irvine, Calif., has filed for two million common shares through First Boston. * Arkansas Freightways Corp., Harrison, Ark., has filed for 1.45 million common shares through Stephens Inc. * Liposome Co., Princeton, N.J., has filed for three million common shares through Hambrecht & Quist Inc. * Oil-Dri Corporation of America, Chicago, is offering 1.22 million common shares at $21 a shares through William Blair & Co. * PictureTel Corp., Peabody, Mass., has filed for two million common shares through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Hewlett Pact With Hitachi
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and Hitachi Ltd. said today that they had agreed to place Hitachi's artificial intelligence technology on Hewlett's computer work stations.

title: Elm: Tough Wood Is Tough to Refinish
description: Through the years, the scarcity and expense of good furniture wood has led carpenters and cabinetmakers to search for less popular woods and even to recycle. Thus it is sometimes hard to identify the wood a piece is made from, which can lead to problems in trying to restore it.

title: Petry Loses in Arbitration Case As Teams Dominate Hearings
description: When baseball's arbitration season ends each year, management officials usually lament that clubs too often negotiated contracts with the players and too seldom let their differences go to hearings. That complaint could be heard again this year because the clubs have done well in arbitration hearings and not too well in contract negotiations.

title: Dinkins's Visit to Israel Does Him Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Jets Attack Palestinians in Lebanon
description: Israeli military aircraft attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base in southeast Lebanon today only hours after an Israeli outpost came under rocket fire, the police said.

title: New York State Unit's Offering
description: The New York Local Government Assistance Corporation, which was established in 1990 to help finance local government operations, yesterday priced $905.5 million in bonds.

title: Books of The Times; Assessing the Black Population Shift
description: The Promised Land The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America By Nicholas Lemann 410 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: A Tree Can Get Too Big For Itself
description: PEOPLE move furniture. And houses. Why not trees?

title: How Fed Chief Got War News
description: On the night war broke out with Iraq, Jan. 16, most Americans were glued to their televison sets. Not Alan Greenspan. He got his news from his computer terminal. He remembered that night in his testimony today before the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Schoolgirl Runner Dies
description: Stephanie Companioni, the 16-year-old from Aquinas High School in the Bronx who collapsed after competing in a 1,000-meter race on Sunday at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track meet, died on Monday, a spokesman for Columbia Presbyterian Hospital said yesterday.

title: The Feud That Won Super Bowls
description: The most profitable feud in sports history is over. The football Giants could be in terrible trouble for next season now that they have two owners on speaking terms.

title: Business and the Law; S.& L. Lawsuits: Case of Overkill?
description: A growing number of former executives of failed savings and loan associations are finding themselves the target of lawsuits from several Federal agencies at once, often covering the same accusations.

title: If Costume Jewelry Needs Fixing
description: GERARD ZIERLER, a jeweler, works with lots of materials that sparkle and shine. But all that glitters isn't 14-karat gold. "I'm dealing essentially with junk," he said.

title: New Cable TV Service Names Its Chairman
description: John J. Sie has been named chairman and chief executive of Encore, a new national pay cable television service.

title: Deals
description: Hockey

title: Murder Ruled Out in a Death
description: The Medical Examiner's Office ruled yesterday that an 80-year-old woman who was found dead in her Manhattan apartment on Tuesday died of a heart attack and was not murdered as the police initially believed. An autopsy determined that the woman, Pauline Sandler, of 235 West 102d Street, fell in her studio apartment, fracturing her pelvis. She then suffered a heart attack, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner. The police had said that Ms. Sandler was apparently suffocated.

title: Peter Nigro Dies at 56; A Highway Contractor
description: Peter P. Nigro, a founder of Nigro Brothers, the contractor on several of the largest highway projects in Westchester County in the last three decades, died on Saturday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 56 years old and lived in Eastchester, N.Y.

title: Metro Datelines; Infectious Waste Strewn on Sidewalk
description: A garbage bag full of infectious medical waste was found torn open and its contents strewn over a sidewalk in a Newark neighborhood yesterday.

title: Review/Television; Vivian and Larry, Genteel Whether in Love or Out
description: "Make love to me, Larry!" says Vivien Leigh while walking with her husband on an Australian beach.

title: Transit Officer, Cut by Knife, Shoots Suspect
description: A plainclothes transit police officer who was slashed by a man trying to rob him at a telephone stand in Times Square shot and critically wounded his assailant yesterday, the police said.

title: The 'Sleep of Reason,' in London
description: Whenever the Irish Republican Army does something notably ghastly -- like Monday's bombing of two London railroad stations, which killed a civil servant and wounded 40 people -- a shocked world seeks a rational explanation. But none may exist. The most familiar theory is that such indefensible acts are designed to seek publicity for the perpetrators and their cause.

title: Bank of America Cuts Prime Rate to 8 3/4%
description: The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank after Citibank, said yesterday that it was cutting its prime lending rate to 8 3/4 percent from 9 percent.

title: Louis O. Kelso, Who Advocated Worker-Capitalism, Is Dead at 77
description: Louis Orth Kelso, a lawyer and economist who sought to revolutionize capitalism through employee stock ownership plans, which he invented, died on Sunday at the Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 77 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: For Record Companies, A Battle of the Parties
description: In the past two days, gripped by Grammy fever, the major record companies have been fighting what one press agent called "the battle of the bashes," trying to outdo each other in lavish, imaginative party-giving.

title: Market Place; Another Offer For Child World
description: For the second time in less than a year, Child World Inc., the troubled toy retailer that was battered by a disastrous Christmas season, has agreed to be acquired in a transaction that appears to provide a better deal for public shareholders than for the CNC Holding Corporation, the company that controls Child World.

title: Knicks Caught in Rut; MacLeod Still Trying
description: One day before the trading deadline, Al Bianchi faced the strong possibility that the Knicks may not make a deal.

title: Church Council Calls for Truce in Gulf War
description: The World Council of Churches, ending its seventh assembly, called today for an immediate and unconditional cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, followed by an unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and then regional negotiations aimed at a comprehensive peace.

title: Klimova Is Cleared Of Steroid Allegation
description: Marina Klimova, the Soviet ice dancer, was cleared yesterday of suspicion that she had used steroids in winning last month's European title with her husband and partner, Sergei Ponomarenko.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN an overhead light bulb won't light, the reason is usually obvious: it is loose or has burned out. But if tightening or replacing it doesn't solve the problem, several fairly easy tests can be made to determine whether some other malfunction is responsible.

title: Psychological Help for Children in Urban Combat
description: When a deranged woman with a gun killed several students in a second-grade classroom in Winnetka, Ill., in 1988, school officials quickly arranged psychological counseling for the children who witnessed the assault.

title: Ski Races for Experts and for Fun
description: Ski areas usually have several activities to add variety to just going up and down hills. They may include demonstration days for testing equipment, a video analysis of ski technique, old-wine-tasting and pig roasts, and volleyball and golf games on snow.

title: Money Funds Mixed, Ending 5-Week Drop
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, after five straight weeks in which yields declined.

title: Concerns Raised on Mexican Trade
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, today ran into a fusillade of hostile questions at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing on a projected free trade agreement with Mexico, signaling a tough battle ahead in selling a pact to Congress.

title: Method Aids Bladder Control
description: A simple bladder training program can help control urinary incontinence, a new study has found, and should be considered before drugs or surgery.

title: New Periwinkles Add Glory to Virtue
description: ONE of my favorite annuals has always been the Madagascar periwinkle. It used to go around under the name Vinca rosea (and still does in many catalogues) until the taxonomists, who are always meddling in these things, decided that it was Catharanthus roseus instead. Under whatever name, it has every solid virtue that one could ask for, plus an unsuspected one that gives it importance far beyond the confines of the garden.

title: Man Arrested in Metro-North Kickback Scheme
description: A Florida businessman was arrested yesterday on Federal charges of paying more than $150,000 in kickbacks in a scheme to sell $1.3 million worth of electronic equipment to the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: By Another Name, It's Barbara
description: BARBARA BUSH is on a list with Grace Kelly, Marie Curie and Don Juan: Roses are named for them. The Barbara Bush rose is a hybrid tea with coral pink and white flowers on five-foot-high plants. Its parents are Antigua, an apricot blend, and Pristine, white with pink edges.

title: Cosby Ready to Go On Despite the Inroads By Fox's 'Simpsons'
description: "We're still there," said Bill Cosby, with what sounded more like pride than relief, despite declining ratings and the near omnipresence of Bart Simpson. "After all that bombardment, we are still there."

title: Robert Tisch Agrees to Buy 50% of the Champion Giants
description: Preston Robert Tisch, the billionaire president of Loews Corporation, agreed yesterday to purchase 50 percent of the Super Bowl champion New York Giants for a price believed to be at least $60 million.

title: Helen W. Buckner, 73, A Philanthropist, Dies
description: Helen Watson Buckner, a philanthropist, died yesterday at her home in Gulfstream, Fla. She was 73 years old and also had residences in Manhattan and on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: The Measles Menace
description: In Philadelphia, hundreds of small children are suffering from measles, a disease that means discomfort for all its victims and death for 1 out of 300. Until recently, however, the disease was little more than a memory.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart in Business Day yesterday about the 1990 financial results for the Raytheon Company mislabeled one set of figures in some editions. The chart showed sales and operating income, not sales and net income.

title: Forest Hills Journal; Buddha's Watchful Eye Guards Bagels to Die For
description: Some of the best bagels on Queens Boulevard are baked by a Buddhist from Bangkok.

title: Labor Secretary Makes Careful Overture
description: In her first public appearance with the leaders of organized labor, the new Labor Secretary, Lynn Martin, made it clear today that she was unlikely to kick up dust any time soon.

title: Calendar: A Benefit For Diffa
description: Benefit Boutiques Metropolitan Home Showhouse Gala, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; (212) 727-3100.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: THE PARTISAN VIEW: Republicans and Democrats are engaged in quiet efforts to manage the war issue as they head into the 1992 campaign. Washington Talk, page A16.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ketchum International Inc., Pittsburgh, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc., has signed an agreement with Rama Advertising, Jakarta. Rama, one of Indonesia's largest independent agencies, will represent Ketchum in that country.

title: Carlos Alfonzo, 40, Painter From Cuba
description: Carlos Alfonzo, a painter who emigrated from Cuba to the United States during the Mariel boatlift in 1980 and earned recognition here as a major artist, died on Tuesday at South Miami Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Jolting Yugoslavia, a Region Widens Its Autonomy
description: The national unity of Yugoslavia was shaken today when Slovenia, the most affluent and independence-minded republic, approved basic legislation allowing it to take over functions like banking and defense from the central Government in Belgrade.

title: Washington Talk; Discreet Maneuvers Over War Issue
description: Much of American politics has seemed frozen since the war began in the Persian Gulf, and few expect that to change very soon. Even so, beneath the seeming truce on partisan maneuvering, professionals in both parties are engaged in quiet, careful efforts to manage the war issue as they head into the 1992 campaign.

title: Workers at G.E. Subsidiary Accused by Japan of Bribery
description: In a rare criminal action against an American company operating in Japan, prosecutors in Tokyo have arrested two Japanese employees of a General Electric Company subsidiary here and a prominent university professor, charging them with bribery in connection with the sale of sophisticated medical equipment.

title: Founder of HOH Water Steps Down After a Sale
description: The HOH Water Technology Corporation, a tiny outfit in Newbury Park, Calif., announced yesterday the first sale of its Electropure water-purification system after several years of preparation. And its founder, Harry M. O'Hare, took the occasion to announce that he was stepping down from active participation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Media Business page on Monday about the BBC World Service, an operation of the British Broadcasting Corporation, referred incorrectly to the BBC's financing. Although the World Service is financed by the British Government, the BBC itself is not; it is a public corporation supported with user fees set by the Government.

title: Ruth Hill McGregor, Music Teacher, 82
description: Ruth Hill McGregor, a cello and ensemble teacher at the School for Strings on West 54th Street, died on Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: NO parent expects to like all of a teen-ager's dates. Yet there are times when those relationships strike a particularly dissonant chord. To parents' eyes, the mismatch may seem obvious: He is too old for her. She acts disrespectful. He belittles her. She is not mature enough to handle the relationship, or even to be dating at all.

title: A Net Loss Is Posted by Time Warner
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had record earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in the fourth quarter, but that it had a net loss of $34 million because of interest expenses and accounting treatments for Time Inc.'s acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. at the beginning of 1990.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in January, and twice as much if gyrating food and energy costs were excluded. But economists said inflation at the retail level was not as bad as it seemed.

title: Home of Face Lifts Gets One of Its Own
