description: For better or worse, it's a designer world. Now it is possible to get a newly sculpted, wrinkle-free postmodern body in a postmodern setting: the Ochsner Clinic's Center for Cosmetic Surgery in New Orleans.

title: Debate on Hussein's Fate
description: As President Bush continued to insist in the face of considerable doubt that he was not making President Saddam Hussein's overthrow a war aim, there appeared to be growing sentiment among members of Congress today that the Iraqi President should not remain in power with his fortune and his military partly intact.

title: Rockwell Notes To Yield 8.489%
description: A $200 million note issue by the Rockwell International Corporation was priced yesterday through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 2 Called Up by Rangers
description: The Rangers, with a recent rash of injuries and a suspension on their forward lines, called up Brian McReynolds and Paul Broten yesterday from their minor league team in Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Fall
description: Credit market participants sifted through a wealth of new information yesterday and apparently concluded that, on balance, the news was negative, because prices of Treasury securities fell and yields on long-term bonds inched back above 8 percent.

title: Yanks Try Out Barker and Howe
description: Their best seasons are probably far behind them, but Steve Howe and Len Barker wanted one more chance. Today, the Yankees gave it to them.

title: Severe Problems Seen at Savings Bailout Agency
description: The Government's senior auditor reported today that the agency in charge of the savings and loan bailout was plagued by severe problems with keeping track of its bloated portfolio of real estate and securities, hiring private contractors to manage the assets, and ultimately in selling them.

title: Two Drug Suspects Held in High Seas Arrest
description: Two suspected money launderers from Colombia were lured to a private yacht off northern South America last week, where they were arrested and brought to the United States to stand trial, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Coaches Should Be Treated Like Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Awaiting Reply From Iraq, Soviets Debate Peace Plan
description: Another day came and went today with no signals from Baghdad on whether it would agree to the Soviet initiative on Kuwait, as the debate in Moscow continued on the merits and motives of the Soviet plan, Iraq's options and Washington's response.

title: Metro Matters; Better to Call The Melting Pot A Motley Quilt
description: Census figures to be released today are all but certain to confirm an epochal demographic shift: For the first time in nearly four centuries, non-Hispanic whites no longer constitute a majority in New York City.

title: Personal Health
description: A heart attack is hard to miss when it is accompanied by crushing chest pain that radiates down an arm, a cold sweat, difficulty breathing, nausea and loss of bladder or bowel control. Similarly, it is not hard to diagnose angina pectoris, the chest pain that comes when the heart muscle is deprived of oxygen during exertion or emotional excitement.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; More Companies Assigning Projects to Outside Agencies
description: Many consumer-products companies are trying to increase sales by quietly assigning special advertising projects to agencies that are known for their innovative work.

title: American Airlines' Problems With Jet
description: American Airlines may refuse delivery of a second MD-11 jumbo jet from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation because it is having problems with the first one. American has ordered 19 airplanes, with options to buy 31 more. But at employee meetings this week, American's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, said the carrier was "very, very, very unhappy" with the MD-11 it received on Feb. 1.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a Reporter's Notebook article yesterday about the situation in Israel during the Persian Gulf war mistranslated a Hebrew expression, "nahash tzefa." It means "poisonous snake," not "poisonous snack."

title: Reebok Buyback Of Pentland Stake
description: Reebok International Ltd. will repurchase almost 24.5 million of its shares from the Pentland Group P.L.C. The purchase would reduce the British company's stake to about 13 percent from 31.6 percent. The move will also cut the number of Reebok stock outstanding to about 90 million from slightly more than 114 million.

title: Senate Rejects Call to Exempt Parents From Service in Gulf
description: The Senate tonight voted down an effort to call on the Pentagon to let single parents and one member of a couple with children exempt themselves from service in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Invitation for Palmer
description: The Baltimore Orioles confirmed yesterday that they have invited the Hall of Fame pitcher, Jim Palmer, to pitch during spring training camp.

title: Editors Criticize Picture Limits
description: News photographers and photo services have been hampered in attempts to supply pictures of American military action in the Persian Gulf by the close control exerted by the United States military command, photo editors say.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington at Work; Scowcroft and Gates: A Team Rivals Baker
description: At the State Department, envious officials snipe at them as the Siamese twins of the White House, "fused at the hip." One runs at midnight and falls asleep in Cabinet meetings. The other jogs at dawn and stays up late reading intelligence on the Soviet Union.

title: Execution Blocked, Man Says He'll Seek A New Murder Trial
description: A day after Virginia's Governor commuted his death sentence to life in prison, Joseph M. Giarratano Jr. said he would seek a new trial on charges that he murdered a Norfolk woman and her teen-age daughter.

title: U.S. Says Most of Growth in 80's Was in Major Metropolitan Areas
description: The nation's flirtation with a return to rural areas in the 1970's ended abruptly in the 1980's, as 90 percent of the decade's population growth occurred in metropolitan areas of more than one million people, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.

title: People
description: * Dannielle K. Colliver has been named president of the Detroit office of Ayer Inc. * Ben L. Karr, William M. Russo and Richard H. Metzner have been named senior vice presidents at Brierley & Partners, Dallas. * Susan Pare has been named management representative at the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson. * Scott Brown has been promoted to vice president-management supervisor of the outdoor and recreation group at Carmichael Lynch Inc., Minneapolis. * Karen Grant and Vincent Nigro have been named senior vice president-associate creative directors at Partners & Shevack Inc., New York. * Ronald L. Cole has been named international publisher, a new position, at the Reader's Digest Association. * Audrey Arnold has been named director of advertising for Penthouse magazine.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For the French, War Is Indeed Hell
description: France has had a bumpy war.

title: Melamed Sells Stake in His Firm
description: Leo Melamed, who recently stepped down as chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, said today that he had sold a majority interest in his futures brokerage firm, the Dellsher Investment Company, to the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank of Tokyo.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vatican; The Pope's Divisions Attract Strange Recruits Over Gulf
description: The obvious futility of the many appeals from Pope John Paul II for an end to the Persian Gulf war is raising questions about papal influence that for some here evoke Stalin's derisive remark of decades ago: How many divisions does the Pope have?

title: William F. Niemi, Retail Executive, 86
description: William F. Niemi, a former chairman of the Eddie Bauer outdoor apparel stores, died Feb. 9 at a care center in Bellevue, Wash. He was 86 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S.-IRAQI CLASHES GROW FIERCE IN POSSIBLE PRELUDE TO ATTACK; SOVIETS AWAIT BAGHDAD'S REPLY
description: In a series of sharp encounters with Iraqi ground forces that may have presaged an early land assault, American troops destroyed large numbers of enemy tanks and howitzers today and took more than 450 prisoners of war, the American command reported.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Pentagon Defends Coverage Rules, While Admitting to Some Delays
description: The Pentagon's chief spokesman told a Senate committee today that Government restrictions on press coverage of the Persian Gulf war were justified, but said that in some instances the military had unnecessarily impeded efforts to gather and report information.

title: McCaw Proposal For Debentures
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. announced a move to save millions of dollars in interest charges by converting debentures into voting stock. The nation's largest cellular telephone company said each $1,000 in principal of the company's 12.95 percent senior subordinated debentures due on Aug. 15 could be exchanged for 35 shares of class A common stock. The company said it would also pay $12.23 in cash for each $1,000 worth of conversion.

title: War Summary
description: CLASHES NORTH OF SAUDI BORDER American troops engaged Iraqi troops in skirmishes yesterday as speculation persisted that a ground assault was imminent. Not since the battle of Khafji three weeks ago have U.S. ground forces been reported so directly and hotly engaged with Iraqi forces. As Moscow awaited a response from Baghdad on a Soviet peace initiative. Secretary of State James A. Beker 3d pledged that Kuwait would be liberated soon. Allied pilots, meanwhile, were reported to have flown 2,900 missions, raising the total number since the conflict began to more than 86,000. The American command said 1,000 of the sorties yesterday were directed at targets in Kuwait and at the Republican Guards. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES

title: Prospects Dim on Bill for Puerto Rico Referendum
description: The prospects for Congressional approval of a referendum on Puerto Rico's political status dimmed today as most members of a crucial Senate committee expressed serious misgivings about the legislation.

title: Grammys Turn Into Quincy Jones Show
description: The 33d annual Grammy Awards belonged to Quincy Jones. His album "Back on the Block," an ambitious attempt to bring together black musical styles from jazz to soul to funk to rap, was named Album of the Year, and it brought awards to nearly everyone who worked on it, a multi-generational roster of musicians from Ray Charles to the rapper Ice-T.

title: Pfizer's Pact On Plax Ads
description: Pfizer Inc. must pay a total of $70,000 to 10 states as part of an agreement to halt misleading advertising for its Plax mouth rinse, the attorneys general of those states announced jointly yesterday.

title: Mets' New Offer Doesn't Overwhelm Gooden
description: With Dwight Gooden's deadline for a contract extension 48 hours away, the Mets said today that they had mailed a revised offer to the right-hander that would make him the third-highest-paid player in baseball.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONALD TRUMP plans to subdivide his 17-acre Palm Beach estate, Mar-a-Lago. On Monday, EUGENE LAWRENCE , an architect there, filed a request with a planning commission to build eight luxury homes on Mr. Trump's Florida property.

title: Administration Plans Modest Spending to Cut Lead Poisoning
description: Bush Administration officials will propose spending a relatively small amount of money to eliminate lead poisoning in the nation compared with their estimates of what it would take to clean up the problem, Federal officials said today.

title: Transit Deficit Has Tripled in 7 Weeks
description: New York City transit officials said yesterday that the Transit Authority's budget deficit had tripled since the beginning of the year to an estimated $215 million.

title: Athens Journal; At the Foot of the Acropolis, a Big Dream Unfolds
description: In this city of breathtaking ruins and some of the nastier urban tangles of these times, an ambitious planner has taken office, impatient to mobilize barriers and bulldozers and start changing the face of the capital.

title: Doing Business Screen to Screen
description: By most measures, the business of holding video conferences was a boom waiting to happen. Thanks to an unpredictable confluence of events, ranging from the Persian Gulf crisis, to corporate curtailment of foreign and domestic travel, to a sizable drop in the cost of meeting screen-to-screen, video conference rooms are filling up.

title: Square D Jumps 39% on French Proposal
description: Shares of the Square D Company, the huge electrical equipment manufacturer that received a $1.79 billion takeover bid on Tuesday from Groupe Schneider of France, leaped nearly 39 percent today. But Square D's management indicated they would oppose Schneider's $78-a-share offer when the full board meets within 10 days.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Soldiers; Still Time for Tenderness: G.I. Makes Last Call Home
description: After buying $156 worth of candy bars, King Edward cigars and Pepsi for his platoon, Sgt. Ted L. Smith walked through the shallow puddles that filled the streets of a northern Saudi border town toward a clothing store.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A12-14

title: Architect to Head Department at Parsons
description: Susana Torre, an architect and educator, has been named chairwoman of the environmental design department at the Parsons School of Design, the office of Charles Olton, dean of the school, has announced.

title: Accounts
description: * Ixtapa/Zihutanejo Tourism, a Mexican resort, to the Los Angeles office of J. Walter Thompson.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abraham & Straus, New York, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc., named Robert Reichenbach senior vice president/general merchandise manager of its home division. The company also named Dennis Zezas senior vice president of engineering and operations. * Airco, Murray Hill, N.J., a member of the BOC Group that manufactures industrial gases, promoted Madeline Moore to vice president of sales for its carbon dioxide division. * Coopers & Lybrand, the New York-based accounting firm, named Harris J. Amhowitz a deputy chairman. He will remain the firm's general counsel. * ICM Property Investors Inc., New York, named Constance B. Moore president and chief operating officer. She succeeds Arthur W. Viner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive. * McDonnell Douglas Missile Systems Co., St. Louis, a division of McDonnell Douglas Corp., named Dr. Rodney M. Linford and Dr. James B. Peterson vice presidents. * Max Factor & Co., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of the Revlon Group Inc., promoted Elaine Esposito to vice president of the merchandisers' division. * Rockwell International Corp., El Segundo, Calif., named Charles B. Harrison vice president of advanced technology in its defense electronics organization. * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, named Brian E. Kendrick senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Wertheim Schroder & Co., New York, named Scott C. Marden a managing director in its New York office.

title: Holy Cross Snaps Fordham's 14-Game Winning Streak
description: After their 14-game winning streak had come to an end in the heat of the Hart Center at Holy Cross, Fordham's Rams decided this was a good thing. They will not have long before they learn if they were right.

title: Parcells Promotes 3 Aides and Hires 2 Others
description: Three weeks after the Giants won Super Bowl XXV, they realigned their coaching staff today by promoting three assistants and adding two. In so doing, they kept Ray Handley and Al Groh, who had been reported leaving, by making them coordinators.

title: American Express Product
description: The American Express Company, taking direct aim at Visa and Mastercard, said yesterday that it would market a new corporate "gold" card with some unusual features.

title: A Belated One-Man Show for Ismail
description: National Football League scouts today will get their long-awaited look at Rocket Ismail, Notre Dame's flanker-slotback-kick returner, who is favored to be the No. 1 choice in the draft. Scouts have found tracking down Ismail as difficult as defenses did throughout his sparkling three-year Irish career.

title: Decor for Resting Your Weary Feet
description: OTTOMANS are just the thing for cold, weary feet. Victoria and Richard MacKenzie Childs of MacKenzie Childs Limited of Aurora, N.Y., have created a pink and lavender tuffet with four bulbous ceramic feet painted in pastel polka-dot and striped designs. It is upholstered with handwoven, hand-dyed silk ikat fabric from India.

title: Events: Garden Classes, Landscaping to Lawns
description: Gardens by Design New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bronx; (212) 220-8777.

title: Regents Leave Decision on Condoms to Districts
description: The New York State Board of Regents today sidestepped the explosive question of distributing condoms in public schools, saying a decision on that matter was best left to local school districts.

title: Saving The News Is Complicated by the Preparations for Its Demise
description: With the deadline for possibly closing The Daily News one month away, the already difficult negotiations have become much trickier. As both sides maneuver for advantage in case the talks fail, it is becoming more difficult for efforts to save the paper to succeed.

title: Israel Asserts New U.S. Aid For Housing Is Insufficient
description: Only hours after the United States finally approved a long-disputed $400 million in loan guarantees for housing Soviet immigrants, Israeli officials warned today that the sum was grossly insufficient.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Integrate the Federal Bench
description: There is a scandal on the Federal bench in New York City. Judges who are members of minorities have all but disappeared. There is only one black judge in full-time active service in the Southern District, and two are on senior status -- that is, they need not carry a full caseload. There are no black judges in the Eastern District.

title: A Disappointing Deal for Browning
description: Browning-Ferris Industries had little to celebrate as it quietly reached a preliminary agreement last week to sell its state-of-the-art hazardous waste disposal site 70 miles east of Denver to the Concord Resources Group, a recently formed joint venture of the Consolidated Rail Corporation and the OHM Corporation.

title: Review/Film; Confronting Illness
description: "Princes in Exile," a small Canadian film directed by Giles Walker, offers a wrenching little twist on the theme of teen-agers coming of age. Its soulful 17-year-old protagonist, Ryan Rafferty (Zachary Ansley), and many of the friends he makes at a specialized summer camp, are youthful cancer patients whose chances of recovery are slim.

title: Cuts to Health Centers Are Ill Conceived
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; A Reading List for Students of War and the Gulf
description: As the war in the Persian Gulf continues, new books about the conflict proliferate while earlier books on the Middle East find a new readership. "THE PRIZE" (Simon & Schuster, $24.95), Daniel Yergin's detailed study of the politics of oil, has been on The New York Times best-seller list for a month now; and four books about the Middle East also head the current paperback best-seller list. Half a dozen "quickie" books on the gulf crisis have been rushed into publication, and more -- on everything from weapons systems to chronologies of recent events -- are on the way.

title: Roger E. Swaybill; Novelist and Writer of 'Porky's' Was 47
description: Roger E. Swaybill, a screenwriter and novelist, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Strong Earthquake Off Alaska's Coast Creates Huge Wave
description: A powerful earthquake struck on Wednesday in the Bering Sea west of Alaska, generating a small tsunami but causing no damage, an official said.

title: President of Gillette Becomes Its Chairman
description: The Gillette Company named Alfred M. Zeien, its president and chief operating oficer, to be chairman and chief executive yesterday, succeeding Colman M. Mockler Jr., who died last month.

title: Chrysler to Cut Ads in Playboy
description: The Chrysler Corporation will no longer run advertisements for its Jeep and Eagle vehicles in Playboy magazine because of numerous complaints it received from dealers, consumers and most notably a pastor who appeared last year in a television spot for Chrysler cars with air bags.

title: Black History Month
description: Here is a sampling of events in the New York metropolitan area this weekend in celebration of Black History Month: Today

title: W. R. B. Porter, 43, Fund-Raising Official
description: W. R. Bruce Porter, founder of The Bruce Porter Company, which specialized in private fund raising for nonprofit groups, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westport, Conn.

title: Review/Film; Oh Yes, Uncle Is Outrageous, But He's Poetic
description: "The Sleazy Uncle" is Franco Brusati's shaggy-dog story of a gleeful, amoral reprobate who brings turmoil to the life of his complacent nephew. Luca (Vittorio Gassman), the trouble-making uncle, is first seen trying to bother schoolgirls in a movie theater, and subsequently having to be hospitalized as a result of all this excitement. Indigent as well as irrepressible, he calls upon his long-lost nephew, Riccardo (Giancarlo Giannini), who has never heard of him, to settle the bill.

title: Knicks Take Defeat At Garden to Heart
description: The Knicks may be reaching the breaking point.

title: Clarence E. Bracebridge, Chaplaincy Executive, 55
description: Clarence E. Bracebridge, director of Seventh-day Adventist Chaplaincy Ministries, died Saturday at Shady Grove Adventist Hospital in Rockville, Md. He was 55 years old and lived in Highland, Md.

title: Wastefulness at Gracie Mansion Cited
description: Issuing a report on how New York City's welfare agency came to build an $11,000 headboard for Mayor David N. Dinkins, the city's Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that it was just one of scores of wasteful or mismanaged projects at Gracie Mansion in the last decade.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising; Foote, Cone & Belding Sets Changes in Its Top Ranks
description: In a move that signals its determination to improve the quality of its advertising, Foote, Cone & Belding said yesterday that John B. Balousek, the president of FCB/West and head of its acclaimed San Francisco office, would become president and chief operating officer in May.

title: Hull, Oates Rock Islanders
description: Brett Hull and Adam Oates continued torrid scoring stretches tonight, combining for 9 points as the St. Louis Blues defeated the Islanders, 7-2.

title: Palmer Accepts Tryout
description: Seven months after being inducted into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., Jim Palmer took another step toward returning to the major leagues when he accepted a tryout invitation from the Baltimore Orioles last night.

title: N. Dakota Abortion Ban Gains
description: North Dakota's House approved legislation today to ban abortion except in cases of rape, incest and when th mother's life is endangered. If endorsed by the Senate, the bill would be one of the nation's most restrictive abortion laws, the North Dakota Right To Life Association said. Representatives voted 64 to 39 to adopt the bill. It was unclear when the Senate would begin considering the bill. The legislation requires that rape and incest cases be reported to the police before the exception to the abortion ban would apply.

title: Phils Invite Hernandez
description: Still looking for a left-handed relief pitcher to get left-handed batters out in the late innings, the Philadelphia Phillies have invited 36-year-old Willie Hernandez to spring training as an unsigned nonroster player.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Orders Businesses To Accommodate Disabled Detailing how it plans to enforce a landmark law, the Administration proposed rules requiring businesses to make structural changes to offices and stores to accommodate the disabled unless it can be shown that the expense is too great. Page A14. New York City Layoffs Four hundred workers lose their jobs this weekend, to help close a budget gap that the State Comptroller warned is growing. Pages B1 and B2.

title: Market Place; The Stock Surge At Fannie Mae
description: DESPITE the relentless grim news from banks and savings institutions, the stock of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, has been performing well lately.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A6-10

title: Donald F. Young, 39, A Stockbroker, Is Dead
description: Donald F. Young, a stockbroker who helped develop a leading risk-analysis system for stock option trading, died on Tuesday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 39 years old.

title: Review/Film; A Twice-Told Tale of Reportorial Romance
description: On the theory that there are at least two sides to any love affair, "He Said, She Said" has come up with a good idea for poster art, if not for an entire film. The romance between two competing Baltimore journalists, Dan (Kevin Bacon) and Lorie (Elizabeth Perkins), is explained from each of their differing perspectives, his that of someone seeking to avoid serious commitment and hers largely marriage-minded. There are also references to things like a "New Republic piece on the Sandinista educational system," to prove that the film has its serious side.

title: Leningrad Journal; A Russian Renaissance: T-Shirt for Art's Sake
description: Two centuries after Catherine the Great's yen for a private art collection became the seedbed for the Hermitage museum, a confident new team of curators is heeding the long-neglected muse of materialism.

title: Scalia Tightens Policy on Death Penalty Appeals
description: Justice Antonin Scalia, who recently assumed administrative responsibility for appeals to the Supreme Court from Texas, said today that he expected death row inmates who cannot find lawyers to comply nonetheless with the Court's deadlines for filing appeals.

title: John Woodhouse, 92, Scientist and Inventor
description: John C. Woodhouse, an inventor who was a research scientist for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for 34 years, died on Sunday at Crozer-Chester Medical Center in Upland, Pa. He was 92 years old and lived in Crossland, Pa.

title: The Sound of Spring: Rustle of Crisp Bills
description: The meaty part of baseball's signing season is over, and the results are staggering. With only lower-paid players remaining to be signed, major league teams have 226 players who will earn $1 million or more this year.

title: Review/Film; Warhol: The Man Behind the Can
description: Why does Andy Warhol's work reveal so little about the artist? "Well there's not very much to say about me," drones Warhol, in an old interview that Chuck Workman has included in "Superstar," his witty and enterprising documentary about Warhol and his world. The film itself, which spans the same wild extremes that Warhol's life did, offers strong evidence to the contrary. It bears out the thought that Warhol, described by one of Mr. Workman's many interviewees as "this crazy peasant who somehow is the eye of the storm," was indeed a person about whom others -- and he himself, in "The Andy Warhol Diaries" -- could speak volumes.

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures and readings in New York City this weekend.

title: Richmond Bonds' Top Yield 6.85%
description: The City of Richmond yesterday tentatively priced $266.2 million in tax-exempt public-improvement general-obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 6.85 percent for issues due in 2018 and 2021.

title: Arrest in Indiana Killings Raises Racial Tensions
description: Early in the investigation into a series of chilling murders that shrouded northwestern Indiana in fear for months, police officials released a description of a suspect: a white man with long brown hair.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Baghdad; Frayed Spirits of Residents As Raids Shake Confidence
description: Every night Adnan Aswad herds his family into one of the bedrooms of their suburban home to sit out the allied bombing raids.

title: Edwin Wolf 2d, 79, Rare-Books Specialist
description: Edwin Wolf 2d, a specialist in rare books and bibliography who headed the Library Company of Philadelphia for 32 years before he retired in 1984, died on Wednesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 79 years old.

title: At The Bar; A retired Justice finds that even a campus seminar can set off a brouhaha on inequality.
description: For many, William J. Brennan Jr. embodies values like equality and due process of law. But to some students at the University of Miami Law School, where he is teaching a class this semester, everything the retired Justice stands for has been violated.

title: Coming Back: Attacking With Fury and Caution
description: Mike Tyson walked in nervous circles as his assistant trainer, Aaron Snowell, tried to pull 18-ounce gloves snugly around the fighter's hands.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Blazers Keep Nuggets Sliding Kevin Duckworth had 25 points and 14 rebounds as the Portland Trail Blazers defeated Denver, 122-111, last night, handing the Nuggets' their seventh consecutive loss. It was the fourth victory of the season for the Trail Blazers over the Nuggets, giving Portland its first series sweep ever over Denver, which was playing at home. Clyde Drexler had 19 points and 8 assists for the Trail Blazers, who ended a three-game road losing streak and improved their record to 43-10. The Pacific Division leaders made only 43 percent of their 107 shots, but their defense kept Denver at bay. (AP) Lakers 106, Mavericks 92: In Dallas, Magic Johnson had 21 points, 12 assists and 10 rebounds for Los Angeles. It was Johnson's ninth triple-double this season and 132d of his career. He had 18 points, 10 rebounds and 17 assists against Houston on Tuesday night. Los Angeles held Dallas to a club-record low for a half in building a 52-29 halftime lead. Dallas's previous low for a half was 31 points against Houston in 1981. (AP) Rockets 92, Bucks 90: Milwaukee's three-game winning streak ended as Otis Thorpe had 28 points and 19 rebounds, and Vernon Maxwell scored the game-winning basket with 40 seconds to play in Houston. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins' Barrage Finishes Leafs Mario Lemieux scored one goal and assisted on two others as the Pittsburgh Penguins scored six times in just over seven minutes of the second period last night and beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 11-4, in Pittsburgh. The Penguins overcame a 3-0 deficit after 30 minutes for their ninth consecutive home victory, tying the team record set from Feb. 26 to April 5, 1975. The Penguins also scored four goals in 2 minutes 41 seconds of the third period. Lemieux had three assists over all for his second consecutive 4-point game. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Iowa Shocks Indiana in Overtime Iowa rallied from a 16-point deficit in the second half and beat Indiana, 80-79, in overtime last night in Bloomington, Ind., on a tip-in by James Moses at the buzzer. Indiana (22-4 over all, 10-3 in the Big Ten), which missed six straight free throws that could have won the game in regulation time, took a 77-74 lead on two free throws by Matt Nover and three straight by Calbert Cheaney with two minutes left in the overtime. After a timeout called by Iowa (18-7, 7-7) with 8 seconds to go in overtime, Acie Earl missed one shot and Chris Street missed another on the rebound before Moses' winning tip. (AP) Nevada-Las Vegas 80, Pacific 59: The Runnin' Rebels, playing at home, recorded their 35th straight victory over two seasons, getting 26 points and 11 rebounds from Larry Johnson. Johnson hit 14 of 15 free throws as U.N.L.V. used its inside game to pull away from the Tigers in the second half and remain unbeaten (24-0 over all, 15-0 in the Big West). U.N.L.V., moving within three victories of an undefeated regular season, appeared lethargic and mistake-prone at times, but was never seriously threatened. The point total was the second lowest of the season for U.N.L.V., which came into the contest averaging 104.2 points a game. Pacific dropped to 12-1 and 8-7. (AP) Arizona 100, California 63: In Tucson, Khalid Reeves hit five of Arizona's nine 3-pointers, and the Wildcats' balanced scoring smothered California as Arizona tightened its Pacific-10 Conference lead. Reeves, a reserve freshman guard, and Brian Williams each had 19 points while Matt Muehlebach and Ed Stokes scored 13 apiece as Arizona (21-5, 10-3) made the Golden Bears (11-13, 7-8) their 60th consecutive victim at McKale Center, the nation's longest current home winning streak. (AP) Utah 67, Colorado St. 56: Josh Grant made five of six free throws in the closing minutes and Utah held off Colorado State for the Western Athletic Conference victory in Fort Collins, Colo. The Utes (25-2, 14-1) led by 56-53 when Colorado State's Tracy Jordan missed two free throws with about four minutes left. Utah scored the next 6 points, including the only 4 points of the game by Phil Dixon. Grant, who led Utah with 19 points, made five free throws to put the game away for the W.A.C. champions. Colorado State fell to 13-12 and 4-9.(AP) Temple 80, Massachusetts 70: Playing without Mark Macon for the first time in 120 games, Temple got 20 points from Donald Hodge and beat Massachusetts in Amherst for the Atlantic 10 victory. The triumph was the Owls' 20th without a loss against the Minutemen. Macon, a guard, sprained his right ankle earlier in the week and is expected to be out at least one more game. The Minutemen (16-9, 9-7) cut a 13-point Temple lead to 39-37 at halftime, then led by 41-39 after 1:11 of the second half on a Tony Barbee jumper. Temple (19-7, 12-4) broke the game open with an 11-2 run six minutes into the second half.(AP) Duquesne 88, Rutgers 80: In Pittsburgh, James Hargrove scored 21 points and four teammates also scored in double figures as Duquesne ended Rutgers's streak of nine Atlantic 10 victories. Tony Petrarca added 17 points, including four 3-pointers for Duquesne (12-13, 9-7). Rutgers fell to 17-8 and 12-4. (AP) TENNIS Edberg Defeats Camporese Stefan Edberg beat Omar Camporese, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the Eurocard Classic in Stuttgart, Germany. Other winners included Guy Forget, Karel Novacek and Andrei Cherkasov. (AP)

title: Cranston Calls Senate Proceedings Politically Motivated 'Disgrace'
description: Alan Cranston today denounced the Senate Ethics Committee's deliberations on him and four other Senators as a "disgrace," saying they had been driven by political motives.

title: Critic's Choice
description: Since emerging two and a half years ago out of the Greenwich Village club Eighty Eight's, Jeff Harnar has grown from an ingenuous, overly emotive interpreter of theater standards into a rangy, controlled performer who reveals a gift for comic as well as lyrical singing.

title: Chronicle
description: AUDREY HEPBURN is to make double-barreled appearances in New York in the same role: guest of honor. On March 6, GREGORY PECK, ISABELLA ROSSELLINI and about 400 friends of Unicef will appear at a dinner honoring her as a Unicef Goodwill Ambassador.

title: Made in the U.S.A., but by Sharp
description: Japan's largest maker of flat-panel display screens, the Sharp Corporation, said today that it would begin producing some of them in the United States. The announcement appears to be a largely political gesture intended to defuse a new and increasingly contentious high-technology trade dispute.

title: Pop/Jazz; Catching Some Jazzmen On the Way to Stardom
description: New York's jazz bookers rely on proven names to fill clubs. Meanwhile, critics and diehard fans search the band rosters and fine print for new names. In an oral tradition like jazz, apprentices get the best part of their education in public, working alongside masters until some mysterious alchemy of skill, luck, publicity and timing makes them proven names themselves; then, insiders can cackle, "I heard them when. . . ."

title: Article 006491 -- No Title
description: The BankAmerica Corporation yesterday priced its third issue of subordinated debt of 1991 through Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: New York Growth is Linked to Immigration
description: New York City took in 854,000 immigrants between 1980 and 1989, who fanned out into all five boroughs to feed great changes in racial and ethnic concentrations, according to data released yesterday by Federal immigration officials and the Census Bureau.

title: NCR Stock Plan Seeks to Thwart A.T.&T.
description: In its first tactical step to fend off a hostile takeover attempt by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the NCR Corporation moved yesterday to muster the loyalty of its employees. It announced it had created a $500 million employee stock ownership plan that could effectively control 8 percent of the company's stock.

title: First, How Do Children Feel About the War?; Rose-Tinted Goggles
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reaction; U.N. PANEL TO MEET ON MOSCOW'S PLAN
description: The Persian Gulf peace plan agreed to by the Soviet Union and Iraq produced mixed reactions tonight from the members of the United Nations Security Council, which must decide whether to approve it and bring hostilities to a halt.

title: KEEP IN MIND
description: "RAPUNZEL," a Grimm fairy tale with a modern script, produced by Theaterworks/USA at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. At 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sundays through March 10. Tickets, $16 and $13. Information: (212) 677-5959.

title: Pilic May Coach Becker
description: Niki Pilic, captain of the German Davis Cup team, said yesterday that he had been asked by Boris Becker to become his coach, and indicated that he was willing to take the job.

title: Our Towns; City Children And Seedlings, Helping a Forest
description: In her 11 years, Nathalie Pagan has not had much to do with trees in North Newark. She has seen some in a tiny park. Well, actually, those trees had been knocked down. But over at her school, St. Michael's on Crittenden Street, a few pines are sticking out of the playground pavement, and Nathalie finds them "quite beautiful."

title: Fordham Is Trying to Create New Memories
description: Perhaps there is something about the stately architecture at Fordham University that inspires an eagerness for nostalgia. Maybe a mindset is transferred in dining-room conversations between longtime and future alumni. Or maybe there is just something about life in the Bronx that clearly passes the notion from one student generation to the next: Things can never be as good today as they were yesterday.

title: Review/Film; A Marriage On and Off The Rocks
description: By no leap of the imagination do Woody Allen and Bette Midler seem to have been made for each other. He is a passionate skeptic, an observer. She is someone who participates with her entire being. They are pastrami on rye and a double-dip strawberry ice cream soda.

title: Venus's Craters May Be Named for Women
description: About 100 craters on Venus may soon be known by the last names of famous women like the authors Pearl Buck, Rachel Carson and Gertrude Stein.

title: Did You Say 'Least,' Or 'Beast?'
description: Although the regular season is eight days from being over, a number of Big East watchers are already wondering how the "Conference of the 80's," as it has been called, will do when the national tournament begins on March 14.

title: Vice Chairmen Named For Two Nynex Groups
description: As part of its move to manage its telephone companies apart from its unregulated operations, the Nynex Corporation named two vice chairmen yesterday to oversee its two groups of operating companies.

title: Linda Marmelstein, TV Producer, 55
description: Linda Marmelstein, an independent television producer, died Monday at the Cabrini Hospice. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music; Cecilia Bartoli, a Mezzo, in Recital Debut
description: When the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli made her New York debut last summer at the Mostly Mozart Festival, she struck gold in the florid music of Rossini. That also proved to be true of her second recital, which drew a large and warmly appreciative audience to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening. Why not? Her singing was not always as unstrained and richly colored as a bel canto purist might ask, but when the program played to her greatest strengths in the all-Rossini second half, the recital was a knockout.

title: Sears 'Optimistic' About Catalogue
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which recently denied that it had planned to sell or close its catalogue, is "very optimistic" about the operation, but conceded it could be eliminated. The catalogue, the nation's biggest, has been unprofitable since 1985.

title: Phelps Looks Back on Old Days and an Abrupt Ending
description: Not long after a young basketball coach named Dick Phelps had been introduced to the nation as Digger, he was sitting in Notre Dame Stadium during his first autumn in South Bend, Ind., watching a football reunion of the classes of 1947, 1948 and 1949.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; New Bill Mandates Sanctions On Makers of Chemical Arms
description: The Senate passed legislation on Wednesday night that requires the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.

title: Margot Fonteyn Dead at 71; Ballerina Redefined Her Art
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn, whose blend of refinement and passion redefined 20th-century ballet style and made her an international idol as the prima ballerina of the Royal Ballet in Britain, died yesterday in Paitilla Hospital in Panama City. She was 71 years old and lived on a farm near La Quinta Pata, Panama.

title: Joan Millman for City Council
description: Tuesday's nonpartisan election to fill the City Council seat in Brooklyn's 29th District is important. The winner will have a clear advantage in the fall election when the Council expands to 51 members and comes into its own under the new City Charter.

title: Key Rates
Saatchi Trims Debt Burden With Revised Capital Plan
description: Bowing to pressure from its preferred shareholders, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's second-largest advertising concern, introduced a revised recapitalization plan today that would give such shareholders a much larger ownership stake but would significantly ease its debt problems.

title: Bonn to Raise Taxes to Pay for Unification, Official Says
description: The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, acknowledged today that tax increases were being planned to help pay the rising costs of unification. But he rejected contentions by critics that the Government's policies had helped push eastern Germany toward economic collapse.

title: Medal for All in the Military
description: The Pentagon is awarding the National Defense Service Medal to all members of the United States armed forces in connection with the Persian Gulf war, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today.

title: For Children
description: Art Workshops National Academy School of Fine Arts 5 East 89th Street Manhattan (212) 996-1908 Recommended ages: 5 to 8; 9 to 12 Saturdays, through March 9

title: Lockheed Proxies
description: Harold Simmons has accepted the Lockheed Corporation's proposal to forgo newspaper advertising in their separate attempts to win shareholders' votes at the military contractor's annual meeting on April 2. Mr. Simmons, the billionaire Texan who owns 20 percent of Lockheed through his NL Industries, is again trying to get his own directors elected to the Lockheed board.

title: Dismissed Bridges Official Subpoenaed by City Council
description: The Transportation Committee of the City Council has subpoenaed the city's former Deputy Commissioner for Bridges to testify at a hearing on the conditions of the city's bridges, officials said yesterday.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The U.N.; U.S. and Britain See U.N. Mandate to Maintain Curbs Against Iraq
description: The United States and Britain say they have the power to maintain United Nations sanctions against Iraq for as long as they choose, and to continue the war authorized under the United Nations mandate, despite the terms of the Soviet proposal announced today in Moscow, diplomats and international lawyers say.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Leader; Text of Hussein's Radio Speech Dealing With War and Peace
description: Following is the text of a speech by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq broadcast today on Baghdad Radio, as translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, an agency of the United States Government:

title: Castrol Tries to Quash Talk of Dropping Scali
description: Castrol Inc. attempted yesterday to quash speculation that it might terminate its relationship with Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc.

title: Weicker's Tax Proposal: Winners and Losers
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s income-tax plan promises to divide Connecticut residents into sharply differing camps based on their place of work, life style and source of income. In a small state with large numbers of out-of-state commuters and great disparities of rich and poor, tax winners and tax losers could easily live next door to each other in the same town, on the same block.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Land Co. P.L.C. will buy 15 supermarkets from J. Sainsbury P.L.C., a British food retailing group, for $:135 million in a leaseback arrangement. * Geest P.L.C., a British fresh produce group, said it would be interested in buying Del Monte, the fruit subsidiary of Polly Peck International P.L.C., if the administrators of Polly Peck put it up for sale. * Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., Tokyo, will set up a wholly owned mobile communications subsidiary in mid-1992. * Premier Bancorp Inc., Baton Rouge, La., said Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, would buy $65 million of Premier's newly issued capital notes. Banc One also has an option to buy Premier in the fourth or fifth year after the date of the $65 million investment. * Prudential Insurance Co., Newark, will acquire the insurance company functions of the health maintenance organization operated by the Johns Hopkins Health Plan, a medical provider in Baltimore. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Prove You Need Fare Rise, Cuomo Demands of M.T.A.
description: The fight over potential fare increases on New York City's subways, buses and commuter railroads got into full swing yesterday when the Governor and ranking state legislators told the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to prove that higher fares were critical to offset rising budget deficits.

title: System Is Cited in Subway Crash
description: The failure of inspectors to spot defective motor supports led to a subway derailment in downtown Philadelphia last year that killed 4 people and injured 158, the National Transportation Safety Board says.

title: William H. Short, 66, New Jersey Architect
description: William H. Short, an architect who supervised the construction of the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan and the restoration of Drumthwacket, the governor's mansion in New Jersey, died on Wednesday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Inconsistent Devils Are Offering No Consistent Answers to Solve Problem
description: John Cunniff is running out of psychology books on coaching. He has tried just about every approach imaginable to get his Devils angry enough to stop underachieving.

title: First, How Do Children Feel About the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Review/Film; Bride's Head Revisited
description: "This is no longer about re-animating the dead," says Dr. Herbert West, a prissy, warped but brilliant scientist, at the beginning of "Bride of Re-Animator." "This is about creating new life!"

title: Moynihan Tries to Save Puerto Rico Referendum
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan assailed Senate colleagues today for what he called a "shameful display of negativism" concerning a bill that would authorize a referendum in Puerto Rico on the island's future.

title: Japanese Paper Closes
description: Lady Kong, which appeared three months ago as Japan's first newspaper for women, stopped publication last week because of financial problems. "We could not get as much financial support as we had expected when we started the paper, in part because of the gulf war," said Kyo Moriyama of the Ranka Sha Company, the publisher. The tabloid-size paper was a joint venture of the Japanese publisher and a British brokerage.

title: Repeal of Gay Rights Law Is Pushed in Pittsburgh
description: Nearly 10,000 residents have signed a petition asking for a referendum to repeal the city's year-old homosexual rights ordinance.

title: U.S.-Florida Deal Raises Everglades Cleanup Hope
description: The Federal Government has agreed to halt all proceedings in its three-year-old lawsuit against Florida over pollution in the Everglades, raising hopes for an eventual settlement.

title: People
description: * Steven Penchina has been named executive vice president-executive creative director in the New York office of Ketchum Advertising. * Kevin O'Neill, Lynn Giordano and Roger Mosconi have been named group executive vice presidents, which are new positions, at Lintas New York. * Deanne McLean, director of creative recruitment at DDB Needham in Chicago, has been elected a vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide. * Alden Ludlow has been named executive vice president-manager of creative services at Warwick Baker & Fiore Inc., New York. * Linda Morgenstern has joined Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, as an event marketing director. * Bonnie Varela, traffic director at TBWA Advertising, New York, adds vice president to her title. * Deborah Radcliffe has been promoted to vice president-account supervisor at Kobs & Draft Inc., New York. * Thomas Teepell has been named senior vice president-marketing for the Institute of Outdoor Advertising, New York. * F. Bradley Lynch has been named senior consultant and director of public relations for the Advertising Council, New York. * Eileen Roper Ast has been named vice president and director of public relations at Bozell Inc., New York. * Patrick C. G. Coulter has been named director of media relations and advertising at Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass.

title: Little, Brown Chief in Early Retirement
description: Kevin L. Dolan, the president and chief executive of Little, Brown & Company, will take early retirement, effective immediately. He will not be replaced, and his duties will be assumed by William Sarnoff, the chairman of Time Warner Trade Publishing, of which Little, Brown is a part.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Behind 'Nick and Nora' Delays

title: Chronicle
description: BARRY GOLDWATER, CHUCK CONNORS and JAMES DRURY have one thing in common: the American West. On March 16, Mr. Goldwater, the former Senator from Arizona, and the two actors will be inducted into the National Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City. Mr. Goldwater is a historian of the West, and Mr. Connors and Mr. Drury starred in two long-running television westerns.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Home Front; On Campuses, Coordinated Antiwar Protests
description: With the nation uncertain whether the next few days will bring sudden peace or a devastating ground war in the Persian Gulf, student groups on college campuses around the country yesterday held antiwar demonstrations, but fell short of the coordinated effort they had hoped to achieve.

title: F.B.I. Arrests 2 Drug Suspects on High Seas
description: Two suspected money launderers from Colombia were lured to a private yacht off northern South America last week, where they were arrested and brought to the United States to stand trial, law-enforcement officials said Wednesday.

title: WARHOL: WHERE AND WHEN
description: "Andy Warhol's Video and Television," a monthlong series of programs made by or featuring the artist, will run through March 22 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. Admission to each screening is included in museum admission: $5 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 570-0537. Here is a schedule. Today-Thursday

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Upbeat Bill Frisell

title: Review/Art; Bringing the 1940's Back Alive
description: THE decade began with the invasion of Hitler's army into Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium. It ended with the establishment of apartheid in South Africa and of the Communist regime in China. Who could blame theatergoers during the 1940's if they confused Jean-Paul Sartre's new play "No Exit" with realist drama?

title: 20-Year Term for Lujan's Son
description: The 28-year-old son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. was sentenced today to 20 years in prison for breaking into a woman's apartment last November and raping her.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Karen Akers Debut

title: Arson Fire Damages House Of an Iraqi-American Family
description: The house of a naturalized American citizen from Iraq was set on fire Wednesday, and the authorities found the words "you are dead" painted on an outside wall.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Statement; Moscow's Statement on the Iraqis' Response
description: Following is a transcript of a statement in Moscow last night by Vitaly N. Ignatenko, a spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, after a meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq. A simultaneous translation by CNN was transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Chronicle
description: FRANK SINATRA has postponed his European tour, which was to have begun May 25 in Oslo. "Promoters in Europe suggested that this be postponed until the fall," said SUSAN REYNOLDS, Mr. Sinatra's spokeswoman. "A major reason is the war."

title: Love-Triangle-Case Witness Admits Selling Defendant a Gun
description: A private investigator testifed today in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus that he sold her a .25-caliber Beretta pistol and a silencer a week before the fatal shooting of Betty Jeanne Solomon.

title: A Correction
description: A sentence in a Feb. 18 letter from six executive board members of PEN American Center about Sari Nusseibeh, a Palestinian under Israeli detention, appeared incorrectly. The sentence should have read: "We are concerned that the Israeli Government is exploiting these difficult days of war against Iraq to crack down on precisely those figures whose moderation and opposition to violence will be essential to the conclusion of a just and secure peace between Israelis and Palestinians in the aftermath of this war."

title: WAR SUMMARY
description: BRACING FOR A VAST LAND BATTLE Artillery and ground clashes along the Saudi border grew larger and more heated. In the heaviest allied artillery bombardment to date, a British armored division hammered Iraqi border positions and American artillery and helicopters also pounded enemy fortifications. Iraq fired three Scud missiles into Saudi Arabia, but the rare daylight attack caused no damage. American planes bombed Baghdad even as Baghdad radio played a tap of President Saddam Hussein's speech vowing to continue fighting. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Two American pilots were killed in the crash of an Army OH-58 Scout helicopter returning from a reconnaissance mission along the border, bringing to 19 the number of American combat fatalities, Central Command said. In addition, seven American soldiers were reported killed when an Army medical evacuation helicopter, a UH-60 Balckhawk, crashed in Saudi Arabia, apparently while trying to land in bad weather. If their deaths are classified as non-combat fatalities, the number would rise to 40. Aricraft: The crash of the OH-58 Scout helicopter brought the total number of American aircraft reported lost in combat to 23. The other allies have reported nine aircraft lost. Two aircraft were reported sustained an engine failure while conducting refueling operations and a U.S. Marine CH-46 helicopter that made a controlled emergency landing but could not be repaired. Thus, the number of aircraft lost in non-combat accidents since the air war began rose to 18, the Pentagon said. IRAQI FORCES Troops: A final prisoner of war count resulting from bunker attacks Wednesday was revised to 421, 20 of them officers, including the battalion commander and his staff. Fourteen more Iraqis surrendered at the site yesterday and seven surrendered in a small ground skirmish. Armor and weaponry: A ranking United States commander said that 2,100 of Iraq's 4,200 main battle tanks have been destroyed, up from 1,400 reported a week ago. Five anti-aircraft guns, five radar dishes and seven vehicles were reported destroyed in four American helicopter raids on Iraqi border posts.

title: Continental's La Guardia Service Rises
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would add 32 flights to nine cities from La Guardia Airport, largely filling the vacuum left by the collapse of Eastern Airlines.

title: In Queens, Yes and No On Tennis
description: John Tirva, a 74-year-old retired mechanic, was in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park yesterday, swinging a golf club and enjoying "watching the geese and the gulls." His mood fell when he was asked about a plan announced earlier this week to use some park land to expand the National Tennis Center, home of the United States Open.

title: Banker Held in Laundering of Drug Funds
description: Ernest Liu, a former account officer for Citibank, was so good at opening new accounts for the bank that in 1986 he was named his unit's "Salesman of the Year."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; SOVIETS SAY IRAQ ACCEPTS KUWAIT PULLOUT LINKED TO TRUCE AND AN END TO SANCTIONS; BUSH REJECTS CONDITIONS: WAR IS TO GO ON
description: Moscow announced early today after talks with Iraq's Foreign Minister that President Saddam Hussein had given a "positive" response to a new Soviet peace proposal and had agreed to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Battle Horrors: U.S. Troops Prepare
description: As preparations for a ground war continue, American military commanders are trying to prepare the inexperienced for grim battlefield realities.

title: Debenture Offering By Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation yesterday began offering $250 million in debentures due in 2021 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bonn Pledges New Aid To Visiting Nicaraguan
description: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua ended a four-nation tour today by announcing that Germany had promised her Government $65 million in new aid.

title: At the Movies
description: McDonnell After 'Wolves'

title: Oregon Shakes Up Pioneering Health Plan for the Poor
description: After coming under intense criticism for a list of medical priorities that placed headaches and thumb-sucking ahead of diseases like cystic fibrosis and viral pneumonia, Oregon health officials have overhauled the rankings and produced a list that is far more reflective of popular sentiment -- a kind of health care by democracy.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Allies' Troops Brace for War On the Ground
description: Allied forces braced today for what Defense Secretary Dick Cheney termed "one of the largest land assaults of modern times" as artillery and ground clashes along the Saudi border with Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait grew larger and more heated.

title: Why One High School In Queens Excels
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Exiles; Saudis Gather Ousted Iraqi Groups
description: Saudi Arabia, with the apparent acquiescence of the United States, has been quietly assembling former Iraqi political and military officials to form a potential government-in-exile that can fill a power vacuum in Baghdad if Saddam Hussein is ousted, diplomatic sources and Iraqi exiles said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Warhol On TV: Mirror, Mirror...
description: WHAT wouldn't Andy Warhol do for fame and money? There must have been limits, but they didn't preclude a guest appearance on "The Love Boat," the corny television series that resembled a floating retirement home for one-time stars. In a 1985 episode, the opening credits roll by alphabetically, with each guest's face encircled by a wave: from Milton Berle and Tom Bosley on to Warhol, complete with platinum wig and a dazed expression. Playing himself on the show, Warhol wanders the deck with a camera around his neck and an entourage behind him. "When did Andy Warhol become the ship's photographer?" jokes Isaac, the bartender, as the laugh track kicks in.

title: U.S. Rules Would Force Businesses To Make Alterations for the Disabled
description: The Bush Administration today proposed rules that would require businesses to make structural alterations to offices and stores to accommodate the disabled unless they can show that the expense would be too great or if they furnish an alternative way of providing service.

title: Review/Theater; Simon on Love Denied
description: OF all the odd couples created by Neil Simon in his 30-year career in the theater, none has been less funny or more passionately acted than the battling mother and daughter indelibly embodied by Irene Worth and Mercedes Ruehl in "Lost in Yonkers," the writer's new memory piece at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The two parties came to the conclusion that it is possible to find a way out of the military conflict in the gulf." -- Vitaly N. Ignatenko, spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A6:4. ]

title: New York City's Finances Worsening, Regan Says
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that New York City's fiscal situation had sharply worsened, even in the last month or so, and that the Dinkins administration had not presented a "credible plan" to deal with it.

title: Retaliation Against Informer
description: A used-car dealer who was implicated by the CBS News television program "60 Minutes" in an odometer-rollback scam has been charged with firing shots at the home of the program's informer. The 70-year-old dealer, William Frank Whitlow, was indicted on a charge of felony retaliation Wednesday. Shots were fired Nov. 1 at a mobile home belonging to Charles Vance, a former used-car dealer who told the program in December of a multimillion-dollar scam run by several Houston dealers to roll back odometers. Mr. Vance was not home when the shooting occurred.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: White House; PRESSING DEMANDS
description: After meeting with his advisers until midnight, President Bush decided today that the United States could not accept the latest Soviet proposal for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, his spokesman said.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 534 money market mutual funds increased by $3.7 billion, to $464.4 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds fell by $806.3 million, to $129.21 billion. The assets of the 269 general-purpose funds were up by $1.5 billion, to $158.94 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $3.01 billion, to $176.25 billion, the institute said.

title: Another Yugoslav State Breaks Ties
description: More of the fraying legal ties binding Yugoslavia's six quarrelsome republics snapped today when the Parliament of Croatia adopted measures giving the republic's Government veto power over federal laws that it deems dangerous to its sovereignty and national interests.

title: Rangers Turn Late Effort Into Tie
description: The result had its own sort of rough justice. The Rangers didn't really deserve to win, despite their third-period comeback, because John Ogrodnick shot wide of an open net in overtime.

title: An F.D.A. Approval for Amgen
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the use of the first of a new class of genetically engineered drugs that are expected to be of major benefit to people with cancer and could eventually open an era in the treatment of a wide variety of infections.

title: Honda to Lift Civic's Mileage
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would replace its Civic CRX HF subcompact model this fall with a version that would achieve 65 miles a gallon in highway driving and 50 miles a gallon in the city.

title: Accounts
description: * Jardine Wines and Spirits and Societe Jas Hennessy & Co. to Leo Burnett Kyodo-Tokyo, for advertising in Japan for its Hennessy and Jardine brand alcoholic beverages. Billings were estimated at $14 milltion to $15 million. * Omega S.A., the international watch maker to Scholz & Friends Hamburg, a subsidiary of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, for marketing communications in Germany. Billings were not disclosed. * R. H. Macy & Co. to Lintas New York for work with Macy's in-house advertising staff on a major expansion of its television advertising. Billings were not disclosed. * Seagram Classics Wine Co. to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley Inc., San Francisco, for its Mumm Cuvee Napa and Sterling Vineyards wines. Billings were not disclosed. * Burgdorff Realtors to MacDougall Co., New York, for a print campaign. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Latins Admire the Stability of the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Distributors Targeted
description: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration said in Washington yesterday that the government plans to increase its vigilance against those involved with the illegal distribution of anabolic steroids, including doctors who prescribe them to athletes. "I want to send a loud and clear signal to doctors and pharmicists that it will not be business as usual with steroids," said Robert C. Bonner, adding that the Government would aggressively enforce a law that goes into effect next Wednesday giving the D.E.A. the responsibility of regulating the steroids industry.

title: Memorial for Scientist
description: A memorial service for Bassett Maguire, former senior scientist at the New York Botanical Garden, who led many expeditions into Venezuela and Brazil, will be held today at 4:30 P.M. at the auditorium of the botanical garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard in the Bronx. Dr. Maguire died on Feb. 6 at the age of 86.

title: Spending Was Down in Races for Congress
description: Campaign spending for all 1990 House and Senate races totaled $445 million, a drop of 3 percent from the 1988 total, the Federal Election Commission reported today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Va Bene

title: Grimness and, Yes, Joy, in Photos of the Homeless
description: Most people have never been inside a homeless shelter, but they think they know what one looks like. They have seen the typical media images of squalor and human misery, of worn-out mothers and sad children marooned in rooms with little more than television sets for diversion.

title: Divorce, Yugoslav-Style
description: Yugoslavia did not exist when the 20th century began. The way things are going, it may not last till the 21st. The chronically strained Balkan federation now appears on the brink of, well, balkanizing.

title: Remodeling Plan At Bloomingdale's
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. was given approval by a bankruptcy court to spend $22.6 million to remodel its Bloomingdale's store in Manhattan. The plan, approved by United States Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug, involves the renovation of about 20 percent of the 500,000-square-foot store at 1000 Third Avenue at 59th Street beginning this summer. The remodeling is to be finished before the 1992 Christmas selling season.

title: John Fetzer, 89, Dies; Baseball Team Owner
description: John Fetzer, a former owner of the Detroit Tigers baseball team and a broadcast pioneer, died today in Honolulu. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed, but Mr. Fetzer had a history of heart problems.

title: Harrelson To Stress The Basics For Mets
description: Bud Harrelson, on the verge of his first spring training as the manager of the Mets, said his emphasis would be on fundamentals, a working philosophy he promptly underlined by conducting an essentially safe first news conference today during which all the proper bases were touched with diplomacy and optimism.

title: The Life of Saddam Hussein
description: In its new move to regain political power in the Middle East, the Gorbachev Government has one vital goal: the survival of Saddam Hussein.

title: It Is a Victory
description: The late-night agreement between Moscow and Baghdad poses hard questions for President Bush. But it entitles him to claim a great victory of principle. And that is the way he should frame his reply: as a statement of victory.

title: For Greenspan, Problems Not Confronted Before
description: Like judges, economic policy makers rely on precedents. If the economy performed a certain way in a particular set of circumstances, then, the policy makers assume, it will perform a similar way when those circumstances recur.

title: New Orleans Journal; In One City, 2 Campuses Worlds Apart on War
description: Two black Avia hightop sneakers rest at the bottom of an abandoned locker in the Xavier University gym, and the size 15 feet that used to fill them are now swathed in military leather. Chris Harvey, a 6-foot 7-inch junior, had just become the basketball team's starting center last November when the mobilization put his athletic career on hold. Like many black students, this former reservist is in the Army now.

title: Cracked Door Hinges Found On Second of 3 Space Shuttles
description: Cracked door hinges like those threatening to delay the space shuttle Discovery's military mission next month have been found on another shuttle, the space agency said today.

title: Don't Back Down: Humiliate Hussein
description: The Soviet peace proposal and Iraq's apparent qualified acceptance of it starkly raise the question of the advantages and disadvantages of a compromise -- one that might save Saddam Hussein's face politically and militarily.

title: Dow Slips 7.18 for Third Consecutive Loss
description: Stock prices turned mixed yesterday, with Soviet-Iraqi negotiations on all-out war or peace in the Middle East too close to call by the market's closing hour.

title: Rapist Wielding Knife Is Hunted After 9 Attacks
description: The police are hunting for a knife-wielding man who they say has robbed and raped eight women and a 10-year-old girl in the Bronx since December 4, sometimes in daylight.

title: The Keating One?
description: Senator Alan Cranston indignantly disowns his star status on the Keating Five, the Senators who did so many favors for Charles Keating, a big contributor accused of savings and loan frauds. Mr. Cranston complains of hostile leaks while the Senate Ethics Committee is debating whether to discipline any or all of the five. According to news reports, the committee almost surely will call for a rebuke to Mr. Cranston on the Senate floor but is split over the other four.

title: Drug Is Found to Prevent Deadly Pneumonia
description: An inexpensive pill taken three times a week can be extremely effective in preventing a deadly pneumonia in people with AIDS, a new study has found.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chesapeake Bay Bridge and Tunnel District is offering $13.7 million in zero-coupn tax-exempt revenue bonds through Paine Webber Inc. The bonds pay no interest but if held to maturity will yield from 6.15 percent in 2001 to 6.5 percent in 2006. They are priced from $375.27 to $535.12 per $1,000 face value. They are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corp. The issue is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Co. * Comcast Corp., Philadelphia, is offering $150 million in 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2001 at a price to yield 8.5 percent through Morgan Stanley & Co. and 2.3 million shares of special common stock at a price of $13.625 a share. The debentures are convertible into common shares at $16.55 a share. * Long Island Lighting Co., Hicksville, L.I., plans to redeem all of its $225 million in outstanding 13 1/4 percent general and refunding bonds due on June 15, 1995. * Norfolk Southern Railway Co., a unit of Norfolk Southern Corp., is offering $54 million in equipment-trust certificates priced to yield between 6.68 percent and 8.38 percent. Maturities run from 1992 to 2006. The noncallable certificates, whose underlying security is diesel electric locomotives, are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P. * Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million in floating-rate notes due in 1995 at various prices through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes float 60 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than the three-month Treasury bill and are noncallable. * Times Mirror Co., Los Angeles, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million in debt securities.

title: Economic Scene; The Impact Of the Gulf War
description: HISTORICALLY, wars have given a powerful thrust to the economy by increasing spending on arms and manpower, reducing unemployment, raising consumers' incomes and putting pressure on industrial capacity. World War II wiped out what remained of the Depression; the Korean War ended the 1949 recession, and Vietnam kept the longest expansion on record rolling.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Chemical Weapons; High U.S. Toll Is Feared If Iraq Uses Poison Gas
description: United States military officials have not been able to locate key Iraqi chemical weapons units on the battlefield and therefore are preparing for heavy casualties if Iraq seeks to repel an allied ground attack with chemical artillery shells and short-range missiles.

title: 3 Carolina Politicians Are Indicted for Bribery
description: Three more legislators have been charged with bribery in an F.B.I. investigation of Statehouse corruption, adding to indictments that have been brought against 14 lawmakers and 5 other people.

title: Beber Silverstein Loses Subway Sandwiches Job
description: Subway Sandwiches, the chain of 5,100 sandwich shops that is based in Milford, Conn., and Beber Silverstein & Partners, an advertising agency based in Miami, have agreed to terminate their association after less than a year.

title: Boys & Girls Clubs Do Make a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Treaty Dispute With Soviets Causes Delay in Troop Talks
description: Negotiators at arms talks here agreed today to postpone further formal meetings toward a new round of talks until March 21 as a consequence of a dispute over a Soviet interpretation of the conventional arms treaty signed last November.

title: New Protests in Albania; Crisis Mounts
description: With thousands of Albanians demonstrating in the streets of the capital for an end to Communist rule and with the country's economy in a shambles, President Ramiz Alia began today to try to form a crisis government.

title: Gooden Wants a Deal Today or He'll Break Off Talks
description: Dwight Gooden, having rejected as inadequate the latest contract extension offer by the Mets, said today that the organization had until Friday to come up with a satisfactory package or he would end negotiations and play out the season as his last as a member of the team.

title: Armco to Lay Off 500 Plant Workers
description: The Armco Steel Company said it would lay off 500 employees at its Ashland plant for 8 to 12 weeks. The company said the layoffs, to begin next month, would be made as it idled some operating units. Company officials blamed the recession and depressed demand for Armco's products for the move. Company officials said about 2,700 employees would remain on the job.

title: Frohnmayer Says Grants Are Being Spread Thinner
description: John E. Frohnmayer, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, told a House subcommittee today how the agency was trying to make do these days with less money. New legislation has cut the amount of money the endowment dispenses while reallocating more money for state arts agencies.

title: First, How Do Children Feel About the War?; Moral Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The Prince a Corporate Raider? No, Just Joking
description: Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the 35-year-old Saudi who is investing $590 million in Citicorp, once declared in an effusive moment that he would "love to be a corporate raider."

title: Yankees Invite Steve Howe to Camp
description: Steve Howe wrapped his arms around his wife, hugged her tightly and smiled.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Gwendolen Carter, a scholar on Africa, misidentified a book she wrote about apartheid. It was "The Politics of Inequality."

title: 'Thirtysomething' To Go Off for 6 Weeks
description: ABC has announced that it will take the series "Thirtysomething" off the air for six weeks starting next month to try out a new series called "Eddie Dodd."

title: Tisch Doesn't Plan to Be A Figurehead for Giants
description: Preston Robert Tisch did not shell out a princely sum to buy half the Giants merely to get tickets to their games. He already has six.

title: Saudi Prince to Become Citicorp's Top Stockholder
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that a member of the Saudi royal family, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, had agreed to invest $590 million, in a deal that will help Citicorp strengthen its finances.

title: Philip Morris Files Lawsuit
description: Philip Morris U.S.A., the tobacco company, filed a trademark infringement lawsuit yesterday against a San Jose, Calif., maker of video arcade games.

title: Third Patient Will Sue In Florida AIDS Case
description: Claiming she is the third patient a dentist infected during treatment, a 65-year-old retired schoolteacher infected with the AIDS virus says she will sue the estate of the dentist, who died from AIDS.

title: Jackson May Miss Royals' Season Opener
description: The hip injury Bo Jackson suffered during the football season may sideline him for the baseball season opener, the Kansas City Royals said yesterday.

title: Women's Milestone: Majority on Minnesota Court
description: Everyone knows that women are entering the legal profession in record numbers. But no powerful legal institution -- no law school faculty, no large corporate law firm, no appellate court -- has ever been dominated by women. Until now.

title: Few Stars Will Be Out Tonight at the Garden
