description: Another indoor Grand Prix track and field season concludes today in Madison Square Garden with the USA/Mobil indoor championships, a meet that gives the event winners the right to call themselves national champions even though many of the leading American stars will not participate.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. OUTER SPACE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS -- 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM -- GOVERNING COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MGM-Pathe Bond Sale
description: About $5 million in bonds of the MGM-Pathe Communications Company have been purchased by the Lincy Foundation, a charitable foundation controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian, a spokesman for Mr. Kerkorian said on Wednesday. Mr. Kerkorian was the controlling shareholder of MGM/UA Communications before it was sold to Pathe Communications. Mr. Kerkorian has not purchased any bonds himself and has no such plans, the spokesman said.

title: Energy Strategy Draws Congressional Criticism
description: In its first presentation to Congress, the Bush Administration's national energy strategy was criticized today as one-sided even by those who vigorously support its plan for drilling for oil in environmentally fragile areas.

title: Sara Lee to Buy Stake in Compack
description: The Sara Lee Corporation announced it was entering the Eastern European market through its acquisition of a 51 percent stake in Hungary's largest coffee roaster, the Compack Trading and Packing Company. Sara Lee did not disclose the purchase price.

title: A Call for Peace
description: Like all telephone conversations between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, tonight's 33-minute talk about the Soviet-Iraqi proposal for peace in the Persian Gulf was a superpower conference call with simultaneous translation.

title: Southland Ruling
description: A United States bankruptcy judge today approved the reorganization plan of the Southland Corporation, clearing the way for the parent company of 7-Eleven convenience stores to emerge from Chapter 11. Judge Harold Abramson's ruling will also allow Southland to accept a $430 million buyout offer by its Japanese affiliates, Ito-Yokado Group Ltd. and the Seven-Eleven Japan Company. The purchase of a 70 percent stake in the new Southland by the Japanese affiliates will take place in early March, the company said.

title: Waking From a Dream: New York City Lays Off 400
description: Linda Moses was sick and tired of being sick and tired, so the single mother dangling on welfare decided to get some schooling and some job training. In November of 1987 she realized her modest dream of independence through a job as an office aide for New York City. That dream is now ending with a pink slip.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Analysis; U.S. Keeps Options Open
description: In its response this evening to the latest Soviet plan for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the White House took a tentative step toward becoming engaged in negotiations to end the war.

title: Rockland County Housing; 'Clearance' Sale Is Planned at 3 Projects
description: Three Rockland County builders are holding a "clearance" sale on existing housing here to make way for new units that they think will be more salable in today's soft market.

title: Amid Talk of Peace, The Fighting Goes On
description: While peace was being discussed in Moscow, each side pressed attacks on the other.

title: Gorman Stays in Boston
description: Lou Gorman, under whom the Boston Red Sox have won three division titles in the last five years, was rewarded yesterday with a two-year contract extension through 1994 as the club's senior president and general manager.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Ease
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly yesterday, as dealers adjusted positions in order to place bids at the auction of $9 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about video conferences misstated the number of rooms on the Sprint Meeting Channel reserved by one big company after the start of the Persian Gulf war. It was some, not all, of Sprint's 900 rooms.

title: Eugene A. Forsey, 86, Canada Charter Expert
description: Eugene A. Forsey, one of Canada's foremost constitutional experts and a former senator, died Wednesday while vacationing in Victoria, British Columbia. He was 86 years old and lived in Ottawa.

title: Review/Art; 'Fauve Landscape': Shocking Colors and Tranquil Themes
description: The rich, sprawling and occasionally confusing survey of Fauve landscape painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is best described as a something-for-everyone exhibition. Those who agree with Matisse that art should be as soothing as a comfortable armchair will have plenty to savor. This exhibition, organized by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, is a visual feast that spreads before the eyes one of the most beloved and accessible art movements of early modernism.

title: TV Weekend; Chekhov's 'Uncle Vanya' as Adapted by Mamet
description: When Anton Chekhov offered his early play "The Wood Demon" to the Aleksandrinsky Theater in St. Petersburg in 1889, it was turned down "for want of effects, situations and interesting characters." The theater's board was reacting to Chekhov's effort to write a play in which the action was almost entirely internal. When, 10 years later, it was produced by the Moscow Art Theater in a revised form, under the title "Uncle Vanya," it was better received and has been in the Chekhov canon ever since.

title: America's Captive Nation
description: How perverse it would be if American politicians who upbraid Mikhail Gorbachev for ignoring Lithuania's independence plebiscite were to refuse Puerto Rico the same right of expression. But that's exactly what seems to be happening in the U.S. Senate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about North Korea's suspension of talks with South Korea included an outdated reference to the South Korean Prime Minister. He is Ro Jai Bong, not Kang Young Hoon. Mr. Kang retired in December.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bernard Chaus Inc., New York, a manufacturer of women's sportswear, named Nicole Eskenazi executive vice president in charge of its Josephine blouse division and its Ms. Chaus dress and petite divisions. * GTE Electrical Products Group, Stamford, Conn., named John J. Vetere vice president for engineering, and manufacturing. He replaces Richard de La Chapelle, who retired. * Melville Corp., Rye, N.Y., an operator of several retail chains, named Daniel B. Katz senior vice president and David P. Dash and Judy Vredenburgh vice presidents. * Thomas Industries, Louisville, Ky., a manufacturer of lighting products, named Timothy C. Brown executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Wyndham Foods Inc., Augusta, Ga., a subsidiary of President Enterprises Corp., named George K. Liu vice chairman.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.S. Statement; Transcript of White House Statement and News Conference on Soviet Plan
description: Following is a transcript of a briefing last night by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Restaurants
description: In a forest of trattorias, a northern Italian longtimer as solid as its oak walls.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Feb. 14 about the diagnostic devices called magnetic resonance imagers misidentified a company that supplied a music system to the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine to help patients tolerate tests. It was Magnacoustics Inc. of Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: U.S. Hears Debate on Mandatory AIDS Tests for Health Workers
description: A number of leading medical, public health and AIDS activist groups argued at a meeting here today against mandatory testing of health workers for the AIDS virus and mandatory disclosure of the results to their patients.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: CAMPUSES DIVIDED In New Orleans, students at Xavier University are angry about the war, in striking contrast to their neighbors at Tulane University. Page A12.

title: Your Money; New Calculations For Keogh Plans
description: Although income tax rules for 1990 returns are little changed from last year, self-employed people face some tricky new calculations that must be done correctly to determine how much may be contributed to a Keogh tax-deferred retirement plan.

title: Schneider Steps Up Its Bid for Square D
description: Groupe Schneider of France stepped up the pressure today on its American takeover target, the Square D Company, saying it would nominate candidates to the board of the electrical-device maker.

title: Howell Loses Case
description: First, Jack Howell lost his third-base job; now he has lost his salary arbitration case. Anthony Sinicropi, the arbitrator, ruled yesterday that the California Angels should pay Howell $652,500, the same salary he earned last year, when he batted .228. Howell, who had sought $835,000, suffered his initial setback of the winter four weeks ago when the Angels signed Gary Gaetti as a free agent.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Accuride Corp., a unit of Phelps Dodge Industries, Phoenix, has named Robert F. Hoffman president. He succeeds Gerald T. O'Neill, who is retiring. * Bridgeford Group, New York, a financial services firm for Japanese companies doing business in the United States and for United States concerns doing business in Japan, has named Alexander P. Lynch senior managing director. * First Bank, Troy, N.C., has named Jim Gunter president. He will replace John Wallace, who retires on Monday after 26 years as president. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, said Ronald L. Kerber, vice president-technology and strategic business development, had resigned to direct technology operations for Whirlpool Corp. * Northern Telecom Ltd., Toronto, has named Guy D. Gill vice president, investor relations. * Sematech, Austin, Tex., a consortium of technology companies, has named William L. George chief operating officer and executive vice president.

title: Man Sets Himself Afire in Springfield, Mass.
description: A man doused himself with gasoline and set himself afire on a street here Thursday night, three days after an antiwar protester burned himself to death in nearby Amherst.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview BUSH DEMANDS IRAQ START PULLOUT TODAY DESPITE ITS ASSENT TO 3-WEEK SOVIET PLAN; OILFIELDS AND TRENCHES AFLAME IN KUWAIT GROUND WAR VOWED
description: As the Soviet Union pressed ahead with its attempt to broker peace in the Persian Gulf, President Bush today gave President Saddam Hussein of Iraq what he said was the alliance's final demand: Start withdrawing from Kuwait by noon on Saturday or face a huge ground attack.

title: Joel R. Wells Jr., 62, Bank Executive, Dies
description: Joel R. Wells Jr., chairman of SunTrust Banks Inc., died of cancer Thursday at Emory University Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Chief Executive Post Shifted at Nestle Foods
description: Nestle operations in the United States, built up through big acquisitions over the last several decades to become a business with $7 billion in annual sales, have been in the throes of reorganization since the first of the year.

title: Gorbachev Is Losing Battles at Home
description: It is a measure of the fate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev that tonight, as he was attempting difficult Persian Gulf peace negotiations, a throng of tens of thousands of protest-minded Soviet citizens marched past the Kremlin walls intent on spelling out his failures as a leader at home.

title: Albanian Names Cabinet Amid Unrest
description: In an effort to deflect a tide of protests, President Ramiz Alia of Albania today appointed a caretaker Government of second-tier Communists. Four people were killed today in a clash involving security forces and civilians in the country's capital, Tirana.

title: Iowa Athletic Director Retires After 21 years
description: Bump Elliott, the dean of Big Ten athletic directors, who guided Iowa's athletic department longer and more successfully than anyone before him, is retiring. Elliott, who is 66 years old, announced yesterday that he would step down on Aug. 1 after nearly 21 years as athletic director.

title: About New York; Life Lessons, As Taught By the Dead
description: The worth of God's children transcends their contribution to society. That essential point made, some people seem more useful dead than alive.

title: Rangers Are Overcome By Capitals' Comebacks
description: The Washington Capitals entered their game with the Rangers tonight on a three-game losing streak. Their fifth-place status in the Patrick Division left them 4 points short of a playoff berth.

title: Health System In New York Faces Big Cuts
description: Hospitals and nursing homes in New York State face the loss of $1.15 billion in Medicaid and Medicare funds -- 5.5 percent of their total revenues -- under state and Federal budget cuts planned for the coming year, health-care experts said yesterday.

title: M. William Voss, White House Physician, 67
description: Dr. M. William Voss, a Navy officer who served as a White House physician, died Wednesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 67 years old.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up a Bit on the Big Board
description: In a short sale, an investor, betting that a stock price will decline, sells borrowed stock in anticipation of buying it back later at a lower price. The number of shares in which a short position is still held by investors is totaled by each exchange and by the National Association of Securities Dealers at the end of a reporting period and represents the "short interest" for that period. Significance of the Figure Debated

title: Secondhand Reports Were used to Count Millions in Census
description: Population counters added 7.3 million people to the 1990 census based on secondhand information from neighbors, postal carriers and building superintendents, Congressional investigators told Congress on Thursday.

title: George W. Arnett, 87, Former Bank Executive
description: George W. Arnett, a banker and former president of what is now the Trenton Savings Bank, died on Feb. 15 at a nursing home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 87 years old and lived in Mill Valley.

title: Miami Beach's New Drug Weapon Will Fire Off Letters to the Employer
description: The new Chief of Police in this venerable resort community plans to try an unusual tactic to combat drug crimes. When his officers arrest someone on a drug charge, he will notify the suspect's employer.

title: Review/Music; A Committee Of Geniuses, Composing
description: Composing by committee has become a modern joke on faceless creativity. Schumann and his colleagues -- they called themselves the Davidsbundler -- made it into an act of friendship. The music in question is the "F.A.E." Sonata for Violin and Piano, with its four movements by three composers. Albert Dietrich wrote the first, Brahms the third, Schumann himself the two others.

title: How Students Can Benefit From Credit Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Taming Itchy Underarms
description: When underarms suddenly become irritated, red and itchy, antiperspirant products are often to blame. In winter particularly, such reactions are common, doctors say, because the skin is already dry, a condition aggravated by the chemicals in antiperspirants.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 12 about effects of the Persian Gulf war on Nigeria referred incorrectly to Bayero University in Kano. With 10,000 to 15,000 students, it is not Nigeria's largest university.

title: Zenith Fights Nycor Takeover
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation is urging its stockholders to reject an attempt by a shareholder, Nycor Inc., to take control of Zenith's board. In a letter dated last Wednesday and signed on behalf of the directors by Zenith's chairman and president, Jerry K. Pearlman, shareholders are asked not to sign any proxy statement sent to them by Nycor, an investment company based in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Ruling on German's Police File
description: A Government investigation of the former East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, has concluded that he may have once been a secret-police informant, but that he never sold information or incriminated anyone.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Superpowers; U.S. Softens View of Soviet Motive in Peace Effort
description: Although President Bush and his top aides were initially suspicious, they have concluded that the Soviet mediation effort with Iraq is not some mischievous cold-war scheme intended to frustrate American policy in the gulf, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Management Faulted In Child-Care Report
description: The municipal agency charged with administering Head Start and day-care programs for 106,000 New York City children last year is failing to plan and manage the programs it oversees, a study released yesterday said.

title: Topics of the Times; Mr. Davidoff's Friends
description: "We had a good time. That's the bottom line." That was how Sid Davidoff, a New York lawyer and lobbyist, brushed off criticism of the vacation that First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and his wife enjoyed last month with Mr. Davidoff, an old friend, at his Florida condominium. But the trip raises ethical concerns that aren't so easily dismissed.

title: Noncombat Bill: Up to $40 Billion
description: Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said today that the Administration could not calculate the actual combat costs of the war with Iraq, but he provided the most detailed figures to date on other costs of the war.

title: Patents; Call-Waiting System For Computer Modems
description: Telephone customers have long been able to obtain call-waiting, which allows them to place one conversation on hold while taking a second call over the same line.

title: Dennis Scott, 51, Led Yale Program For Stage Directors
description: Dennis Scott, chairman of the directing program at the Yale School of Drama, died on Thursday at the Yale University Infirmary. He was 51 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: A Likely Winner in Air Dispute
description: It is too early to predict the outcome of the fight between the United States and Britain over landing rights at Heathrow Airport near London. But at least one airline seems likely to emerge a winner: Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd.

title: U.S. Surplus In January
description: The Federal Government recorded a small budget surplus of $1.76 billion in January, despite sharply lower tax receipts from corporations, the Treasury Department said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Troops; Harlem's Guard Troops Complain of Treatment
description: Members of the Harlem Hell Fighters, one of the country's oldest and most renowned black National Guard units, say it has been broken up, stripped of much of its equipment and moved into front-line positions without proper preparation or training.

title: Sticking to Deadline, Gooden Breaks Off Talks
description: Determined to become the highest-paid player in baseball and making good on his threat regarding a deadline for negotiations, Dwight Gooden today broke off talks with the Mets on a contract extension. Gooden, who insisted he would file for free agency at the end of the coming season, made clear that the failure to work out a deal left open the very real possibility that this would be his last year with the Mets.

title: Komatsu Dresser To Cut 200 Jobs
description: The Komatsu Dresser Company said it would lay off half of its work force by the end of the year because of a slowdown in the construction and heavy equipment industries. The layoffs will furlough about 200 salaried and hourly workers, Michael Guilfoy, company human resources manager, said. One of two plants Komatsu Dresser operates here also will be closed, he said. The layoffs are expected to begin in March.

title: Inner-City Asthmatics Lack Drug Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Contract Talks Resume in Strike at Daily News
description: After a three-day break, The Daily News and its striking unions resumed talks yesterday without signs of significant progress.

title: Many Homeless at P.S. 194; Happily, It's Hard to Notice
description: Dr. Gwendolyn C. Baker, the president of the New York City Board of Education, visited a school in Harlem yesterday where dozens of transient children are students to spotlight the successes and shortcomings of how the system deals with the homeless.

title: Putting Faith Over the Law As Pupils Die
description: At the Wednesday evening service of the Faith Tabernacle Congregation church, the voice of Elder Gary Kelley rolled through a litany of thanks and supplication: "A sister prays for a nice, easy and safe delivery, a brother offers a note of thanks for the health of a child, a sister prays for a return of appetite after illness, a brother prays for strength because the authorities have taken his child to the hospital."

title: California Legislature Challenges Ballot Measure Limiting Terms
description: The California Legislature has asked the State Supreme Court to throw out a constitutional amendment that limits the number of years politicians may hold statewide office.

title: Abraham S. Bolsky, Realty Executive, 68
description: Abraham S. Bolsky, a real estate executive who built some of the tallest buildings in Los Angeles, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: Pro Basketball; George Steals the Show As Nets Fall to Celtics
description: Derrick Coleman played 44 minutes and scored a game-high 29 points in the Nets' 111-99 loss to Boston tonight, and the Celtics were led by Robert Parish and Brian Shaw, who scored 26 points apiece. But it was Tate George, who came in with 10 minutes 40 seconds left and scored 2 points for the Nets, who got most of the cheers from the sellout crowd of 15,239 fans.

title: London Journal; A 2d Tunnel Project: Less Glamour, More Water
description: What will be longer than the English Channel tunnel, deeper than the London Underground railroad and will insure that there are not a lot of thirsty, smelly Londoners in the 21st century?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; Bush and Gorbachev Converse Person to Person, Sort Of
description: While it may seem the stuff of high drama, the White House insists that the 72-minute telephone talk between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today was a "standard living-room operation," like any long-distance chat between old friends.

title: Zhang Wenjin Is Dead; Chinese Envoy Was 76
description: Zhang Wenjin, a former Deputy Foreign Minister and Ambassador to the United States and Canada, died on Monday, China Central Television reported today. He was 76 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Oilfields; Extent of Kuwaiti Oil Damage Unclear
description: With reports that most of Kuwait's oil wells have been set ablaze by Iraqi forces, Kuwaiti and other specialists said today that the full extent and severity of damage could only be determined when the installations were closely examined.

title: Guidepost; Pillow Talk
description: Over the years pillows become lumpy and lose their resilience. And they collect dust, dirt and perspiration that can discolor them. For these reasons, the Feather and Down Association, a trade industry group, and the Better Sleep Council, which represents bedding manufacturers, recommend that pillows be replaced every 3 to 10 years, depending on the filling and its condition. If you sleep on your side, a firm pillow will give your head extra support. If you sleep on your back, a medium-firm pillow will cradle your head. And if you sleep on your stomach, a soft pillow will ease the strain on your neck. To judge firmness, press down on the center of the pillow. Squeeze and scrunch it; the pillow should be springy and free of lumps. Here are some tips on three kinds of fillings. Polyester fiber: The most popular. They vary widely in price and feel, from very soft to very firm. They are nonallergenic, and some are treated to inhibit bacteria and mildew growth. Down and feather: They have a luxurious "give" and durability. Down is the most expensive and softest, though some grades of down are softer than others. Goose down, the softest, is more expensive than duck down. Over the years down tends to flatten out. Dry cleaning will refluff a pillow; new down can also be added. Those with allergies should beware of down and feathers. Those who prefer a firm pillow should try a mixture of down and feather. Foam: Foam pillows tend to be firm and buoyant. They cannot be fluffed, but they hold their shape for years, until the foam starts to crumble. Polyurethane foam is the least expensive; latex, the most. Sources: The Feather and Down Association and the Better Sleep Council

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Neighboring Allies Outraged By Iraqi Violence in Kuwait
description: Saudi and Egyptian officials deplored Iraq's "scorched-earth" policy in Kuwait yesterday, while Kuwait accused Iraq of killing dozens of Kuwaitis and arresting thousands more indiscriminately.

title: Widening Drug Availability: Two Views
description: Women who suffer from recurring vaginal yeast infections recently got some good news: Gyne-Lotrimin, a drug frequently prescribed by physicians for that problem, became available as an over-the-counter drug. It will soon be joined by Monistat, a similar prescription drug, which was approved this month by the Federal Food and Drug Administration for nonprescription sales.

title: Treasury Securities Hold Steady
description: The Treasury securities market meandered in a narrow price range yesterday after a brief upward movement early in the session. Dealers said bond prices rose about a quarter-point after the opening on hopes of an end to the Persian Gulf war. But there was no follow-through buying and prices retreated to opening levels.

title: Gillette Plans To Split Stock
description: The Gillette Company said on Thursday that its board had voted to propose a 2-for-1 stock split and a 15 percent dividend increase.

title: INSIDE
description: A County's Changing Face

title: Doctors Say Surgery on Arteries Is Highly Successful in Preventing Strokes
description: A type of surgery to prevent strokes by reaming out narrowed arteries leading to the brain has shown impressive success in a trial involving more than a thousand patients, doctors announced yesterday.

title: Johns Hopkins Will Sell Tobacco Holdings
description: Johns Hopkins University, home to one of the nation's most prestigious medical schools, decided today to sell its holdings in tobacco companies, saying the investments undermined its efforts to fight cancer.

title: Georgetown Journal; An Island of Prosperity Since Toyota Moved In
description: Over a decade ago, pigeons and starlings were making a mess of the little downtown here. "So we had a pigeon shoot," said William N. Offutt 4th, an eye doctor and tobacco farmer.

title: Let the Small-Time Drug Peddlers Go
description: In New York State, we have almost five times as many inmates as we did 20 years ago, and the state now spends well over a billion dollars a year on them with no significant decrease in crime. As a result of criminal justice policies like New York's, the United States now incarcerates more people per capita than any other nation, and more black men per capita than South Africa.

title: His Kingdom For a Horse, Not a $2 Bet
description: In this age of high-tech sports, video scoreboards, pay-per-view TV and satellite betting, Tom Meeker has a message for the horsey set: Put the horse back in horse racing.

title: Senator's Trial Is Postponed Indefinitely
description: The prosecution of State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein on charges of hiring "no show" Legislative employees was indefinitely delayed yesterday, a further blow to a case already weakened by a previous court ruling.

title: Mordechai Ish-Shalom, Jerusalem Ex-Mayor, 90
description: Mordechai Ish-Shalom, a former Mayor of West Jerusalem, died on Thursday, Israeli officials announced today. He was 90 years old.

title: Recycling Doesn't Come Without Its Costs; Buyback Center
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: War in the Gulf 4-8

title: Coping/With Buying a Mattress
description: The old rule of mattress buying used to be: For a healthy back, firmer is better. But with advances in mattress construction over the last 50 years, the notion of firmness has become a bit mushy, much like the soft mattresses doctors warned against.

title: Child World Receives Offer Competing With Earlier Bid
description: A second investor group announced a bid for Child World Inc. yesterday, in competition with an earlier agreement with WC Acquisition, a group led by two former Toys "R" Us executives. But Child World's largest shareholder reacted coolly to the second bid and said he continued to favor the earlier deal.

title: At AIDS Meeting, Calls for Rules on Patient Safety
description: In closing a two-day meeting on the risk of doctors and dentists transmitting the AIDS virus to patients, the head of the Centers for Disease Control said today that he had heard wide agreement that such mandatory testing of health care workers was neither necessary nor useful.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Polaroid Appeal
description: As expected, the Polaroid Corporation filed a notice of appeal in United States District Court, contesting a damages judgment in the company's landmark patent infringement case against the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Fire Disrupts Subway Service
description: A track fire on the No. 1 line south of West 79th Street in Manhattan disrupted southbound subway service on the West Side for about an hour last night, the Transit Authority said. The first of two disruptions on the No. 1, 2 and 3 lines lasted 40 minutes, beginning just after 9 P.M., when firefighters tried to put out burning debris on tracks near 79th Street, said a Transit spokeswoman, Caren Gardner. Service was restored at 9:44 P.M. but was disrupted again at 9:57 for about 15 minutes when firefighters returned to extinguish pockets of burning debris.

title: Role of Taxes Debated in Adding to Income Gap
description: Federal tax policy contributed to the widening gap between the wealth of rich and poor Americans in the 1980's, a group of experts told the Senate Budget Committee today, but they disagreed on how great a role other economic factors played in the inequity.

title: Joseph Ciampi, Builder In Queens, Dies at 88
description: Joseph Ciampi, a builder and chief executive of the Ciampi Organization, a development company in Flushing, Queens, died on Thursday at St. Johns Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Malba, Queens.

title: Statement by Iraqi Revolutionary Council
description: Following is a transcript of a statement made in Baghdad yesterday by a spokesman for the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of CNN:

title: A Big Step for Hershiser
description: Orel Hershiser took what he labeled a major step today when he threw breaking pitches for the first time since reconstructive surgery was performed on his right shoulder nearly a year ago.

title: Sporting Goods Sales
description: Factory sales of sporting goods are expected to grow by 6 percent in 1991, to $32.7 billion, from $30.8 billion a year earlier, a trade group said on Thursday. The Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association said the industry was better positioned than others to withstand the recession. Sports apparel sales at the wholesale level are expected to grow by 8 percent.

title: Ancient Macedonians Spoke Greek Dialect
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Cites Tapes in Effort to Bar Gotti's Lawyers
description: A Federal prosecutor argued yesterday that two prominent defense lawyers, Bruce Cutler and Gerald L. Shargel, were "house counsel" for the Gambino crime family and should be disqualified from John Gotti's coming racketeering trial.

title: 'City of Joy' Starts Filming, But Calcutta Still Simmers
description: After more than a year of threats, bans, negotiations and rewriting, filming finally began this month on the movie of Dominique Lapierre's mammoth book on slum life in Calcutta, "The City of Joy." But the start of work has not ended a fierce political controversy over the film or cooled the tempers of those who resent foreigners who display the city's poverty to the world.

title: Police Tie 3 Suspects to 9 Sexual Assaults and Ask for Caution
description: The police issued warnings yesterday about three men who they say have raped, robbed or sexually assaulted nine girls or women in Brooklyn and Queens in the last several months.

title: Recycling Doesn't Come Without Its Costs; Labeling Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Time's U.S. Publisher Quits
description: Louis A. Weil 3d resigned yesterday as United States publisher of Time magazine and said he would leave the Time Inc. Magazine Company. An announcement by Time Inc. Magazines gave no reason for Mr. Weil's resignation.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: White House Memo; Bush Moves to Control War's Endgame
description: By ordering Saddam Hussein to begin getting out of Kuwait at high noon on Saturday, President Bush moved decisively to take control of the war's endgame.

title: Atrocities and Repentance in Chile
description: Chile's President, Patricio Aylwin, faces a tough challenge. His Commission on Truth and Reconciliation has now reported on human rights violations during the 17-year dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Its report is still secret, but is said to include powerful testimony on the atrocities that scarred those years.

title: H.O.V.'s for the L.I.E.
description: The importance of saving public money and what's left of Long Island's scenery limits the number of new highway lanes that can be plastered on the turf alongside the overcrowded Long Island Expressway. That's why the New York State Transportation Department wisely proposes to add two lanes and limit them to autos carrying more than one person. Similar schemes for H.O.V.'s -- high-occupancy vehicles -- have worked well in at least 13 states.

title: F.A.A. Sees Quick Recovery for Airlines
description: The Federal Aviation Administration predicted today that the airline industry would quickly recover from its costly recession as fuel prices stabilize once the war ends in the Middle East.

title: Keep Diplomacy Alive
description: I hope Saddam Hussein accepts the offer of President Bush and the coalition, and starts to withdraw immediately and unconditionally from Kuwait, the war should end. This is not the time to expand our objectives -- to insist on the total destruction of Iraq's military, march on to Bagdhad or try to get to get rid of Saddam Hussein.

title: Three Police Officers Are Charged In Bronx Attack on Epileptic Boy
description: Three police officers were charged yesterday with assaulting a 12-year-old Bronx boy 14 months ago while, his mother says, he was recovering from an epileptic seizure.

title: Vice President At A.&P. Quits
description: Aaron Malinsky has resigned as executive vice president of the A.&P. subsidiaries of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to pursue personal interests, the company said.

title: Topics of the Times; Unleaded Inelegance
description: Two doctors at Columbia University have dealt yet another blow to what little is left of elegant living. Pouring wine out of lead crystal decanters and into test tubes, they discovered that the spirits were absorbing lead from the bottles. The lead content of a decanted bottle of port poured over four months jumped from 89 micrograms per liter to 5,331. Anything to worry about? Historians believe that the Roman taste for sweet wines, unwittingly laced with toxic lead, helped bring down the Empire.

title: Raymond A. Young Jr., Pilot, 80
description: Raymond A. Young Jr., a pilot for Pan American World Airways who set up the line's route network in Latin America in the 1930's, died on Tuesday at Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Somerville.

title: Even the Affluent Aren't Buying
description: Retailers who cater to the wealthy and the merely affluent are finding out that things are bad all over. Stores freshly stocked with $1,200 spring suits and $2,000 dresses, in settings of rich mahogany paneling and artful decor, have only a trickle of customers.

title: Review/Dance; Three Works With Cruelty As a Theme
description: "Cruelty and Reconciliation" was the title of the first of the three dances that Donald Byrd/The Group presented last Saturday night at Davis Hall at City College. It could have been the title of all of them, for Mr. Byrd concerned himself with forces that keep people apart and bring them together.

title: P.&G. Is Selling Its Santa Fe Brand
description: The Procter & Gamble Company agreed to sell its Santa Fe brand of men's fragrances and toiletries to Ducair Tsumura. P.&G. declined to disclose the sale price or other terms.

title: Pro Basketball; Jackson Suspended After Row With Bianchi and MacLeod
description: After a heated argument today with Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager, and John MacLeod, the coach, Mark Jackson was suspended for four days without pay. Jackson, the Knicks' backup point guard, will also be fined, probably between $500 and $1,000.

title: Patents; An Orbiting Sweeper To Clean Up Debris
description: An engineer at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has patented an orbital debris sweeper to clear particles of fast-moving space clutter from the paths of satellites and other spacecraft.

title: Patents; Melodious Phones
description: AT&T Bell Laboratories won a patent this week for software that allows telephones to ring with different melodies, depending on the source of a call. Invented by Joel Angiolillo and Linda Roberts, reseachers at Bell Labs, the software is already used in some of A.T.&T.'s switching systems for small companies.

title: Fixed Mortgages Rise
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.29 percent this week, up slightly from 9.25 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the first increase since mid-January. The 9.25 percent rate last week was the lowest since rates averaged 9.07 percent in the week that ended on March 27, 1987. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.57 percent, down from 7.59 percent last week and the lowest since a 7.56 percent rate for the week that ended on May 18, 1988.

title: Hudson County a Harbinger of a New Hispanic Influence
description: "In the beginning, it used to be signs saying, 'We speak Spanish,' " Jose Michel Lopez said as he strolled down a stretch of Bergenline Avenue, looking at row after row of windows of Hispanic-owned shops.

title: Retail Official Named
description: Tracy Mullin has been named president of the National Retail Federation's government and public affairs division in Washington. She succeeds Joseph P. O'Neill, who recently resigned to start a consulting firm. Ms. Mullin, formerly executive vice president of the division, will report to John J. Schultz, the president of the federation's business services division. Mr. Schultz has been given added responsibilities, including supervision of the Washington division.

title: Wolff Plans to Leave New Jersey Symphony
description: Hugh Wolff, the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, plans to leave when his contract expires next year.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Americans; Americans Confront Anguish and Fear as Bush's Deadline Looms
description: Weighted by a month of intense war coverage, dragged in recent days in the ebb and flow of peace ventures, Americans seemed somehow weary yesterday, even as they realized that the war has reached a moment of truth.

title: Bridge
description: It is not uncommon for a spot card to spell the difference between success and defeat, but to know this before a card has been played is very rare indeed. It happened on the diagramed deal in the 1990 Eastern Regional Women's Pairs, and the auction was lively. East and West were Flo Goldman of Franklin Square, L.I., and Elaine De Shrage of Malverne, L.I., who were en route to victory in the event.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALFRED H. BLOOM, the vice president of academic affairs and dean of faculty at Pitzer College, Claremont, Calif., has been nominated to become the 13th president of Swarthmore College in Swarthmore, Pa. His confirmation is expected at the Board of Managers meeting next Saturday.

title: John Sherman Cooper Dies at 89; Longtime Senator From Kentucky
description: John Sherman Cooper, a liberal Republican from Kentucky who represented his state in the Senate for more than two decades, died in a Washington retirement home on Thursday. He was 89 years old.

title: High Noon
description: All along, even as the headlines and TV screens have projected the grim and grisly side of war, the Persian Gulf conflict has always had another dimension, off camera but not off stage. Yesterday, diplomacy took center stage.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The coalition will give Saddam Hussein until noon Saturday to do what he must do -- begin his immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait." -- President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress; BUSH'S ULTIMATUM GETS WIDE SUPPORT
description: President Bush won a round of cheers today when members of Congress reacted to his ultimatum demanding Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait by noon on Saturday.

title: Recycling Doesn't Come Without Its Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Hendricks H. Whitman, Executive, 70
description: Hendricks Hallett Whitman, president of Clark Tyler Associates, financial advisors, died on Feb. 14 at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Weapons; Napalm's Formula Is Simple, But Its Properties Are Lethal
description: Napalm, which allied aircraft have reportedly begun dropping on Iraqi fortifications and tank obstacles in Kuwait, is one of the simplest but most effective weapons against enemy troops sheltered in caves, bunkers and other enclosed places.

title: Man Is Shot and Wounded in Holdup at Marshall's Office
description: In a midday robbery, two armed men stormed into the office of a city marshal in downtown Brooklyn yesterday took $15,000 in cash and fled after one robber shot and seriously wounded a 24-year-old man, the police said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Moscow Sends Revised Plan to Baghdad
description: The Soviet Union and Iraq's Foreign Minister sent proposals for several new Iraqi concessions by radio to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today in a race against the deadline declared by President Bush.

title: Hernandez Injured
description: Keith Hernandez's hopes of making a comeback from another season filled with injuries were dealt a setback yesterday in Tucson when Hernandez reported to the Cleveland Indians' camp with a back injury.

title: New Nabisco Treasurer Aided Chrysler Rebound
description: Fred W. Zuckerman, a high-profile corporate finance specialist who became known in banking circles during the bailout and recovery of the Chrysler Corporation, has been named senior vice president and treasurer of RJR Nabisco Inc. in New York. The appointment becomes effective Monday.

title: Books of The Times; Humanizing Douglass With Warts and Virtues
description: Frederick Douglass By William S. McFeely Illustrated. 465 pages. W. W. Norton. $24.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Marines at Front Listen for Peace but Hear Bombs
description: On the front lines today, the latest diplomatic efforts at peace by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union were greeted with disbelief. On the Kuwait border near a no-man's land that marines call "Indian country," tracer rounds from occasional firefights streaked through the dark as soldiers from a Marine reconnaissance team strained to hear the radio reports over the noise of allied bombings over Kuwait.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; U.S. PEACE TERMS DENOUNCED BY IRAQ
description: Iraq's Government today denounced President Bush's demand that Iraqi forces begin withdrawing from Kuwait in 24 hours as "shameful" and appeared to pin its hopes for peace on a Soviet initiative.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In a $25 million lawsuit filed Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court, BLAKE EDWARDS, the director, producer and screenwriter of six "Pink Panther" movies, charged MGM-Pathe Inc. with breach of contract. The suit claims that MGM-Pathe had agreed to let Geoffrey Productions , Mr. Edwards's company, develop and produce a sequel and that if MGM-Pathe decided not to finance it, Mr. Edwards could seek financing from a third party.

title: Review/Ballet; Gray Evocations of Canadian Winter
description: William Forsythe's chrome-polished new work for the National Ballet of Canada is gray on gray. Anyone who knows how lively Toronto can be behind its ever-proper facade might not believe that the American choreographer has distilled his impressions about the city's Canadian winters and the National Ballet's concern with textbook style within his latest ballet.

title: When Somewhere to Live Isn't Enough
description: A decade ago, when advocates for the homeless first began to press their demands on New York City, they portrayed their constituents as ordinary people who, down on their luck in the nation's tightest housing market, just needed a place to stay.

title: Review/Music; Pierre Boulez and Ensemble In the Post-Webern Esthetic
description: Pierre Boulez returned to New York on Thursday evening to conduct another of his illustrated lectures about the music of the future. Not that Mr. Boulez actually spoke during his appearance at Carnegie Hall. He was content to lead his Ensemble InterContemporain in a typically didactic program that ranged from early Schoenberg to late Boulez, with stops along the way to examine Webern, Berio and Ligeti.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Iraqi Army's Status Raises Concerns
description: As negotiations continued today over an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, Israeli officials grew more alarmed.

title: Dow Rally Wiped Out Late in Day
description: With Wall Street cautious on the eve of a crucial weekend in the Persian Gulf war, investors pulled back yesterday in heavy trading after a strong rally earlier.

title: Charles W. McCullom, Executive, 57
description: Charles W. McCullom, a vice president of Nabisco Brands, died on Thursday at his vacation home in Chatham, Mass. He was 57 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: Where America Is Growing: The Suburban Cities
description: A decade ago this suburb on the outskirts of Dallas was like other bedroom communities that sent their commuters down the freeways every morning. But in the 1980's Plano grew big and rich through a new form of urban development that is transforming the nation's economic geography.

title: Roger Clapp, 71, Dies; Physicist and Inventor
description: Roger Edge Clapp, a theoretical physicist and inventor, died Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 71 years old.

title: SCE May Halt Merger Offer
description: SCEcorp, parent of the Southern California Edison Company, said a proposed decision by the California Public Utilities Commission might make it impossible to proceed with its $2.90 billion merger offer for the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks Streak Past Lakers Dominique Wilkins scored 34 points to spark Atlanta over Los Angeles, 111-102, last night. It was Atlanta's franchise-record 18th consecutive victory at home. It was the fourth loss in the last 25 games for the Lakers, who had won three games in a row and 9 of their previous 10 on the road. It was the sixth time in nine games that Wilkins had scored 30 or more points. (AP) Bulls 129, Kings 82: Michael Jordan scored 34 points while playing three quarters as Chicago scored its eighth consecutive victory. The Bulls, 22-3 at home, have won 17 straight at Chicago Stadium, while Sacramento lost for the 25th time in 26 road games. (AP) Hornets 122, Pistons 114: Mike Gminski scored 5 of his 25 points in the last minute, leading Charlotte to its first victory over Detroit. The Hornets, who shot 59 percent from the field, scored the most points against the Pistons this season. (AP) Magic 103, Timberwolves 101: Jerry Reynolds scored 7 of his 14 points during a 14-7 spree to start the fourth quarter and Scott Skiles had 25 points and 14 assists as Orlando won its third game on the road this season. (AP) 76ers 103, Heat 96: Hersey Hawkins scored 26 points and led a third-quarter comeback as Philadelphia rallied from an 18-point deficit. The 76ers have never lost to Miami, winning 10 times. (AP) Pacers 106, Cavaliers 98: Micheal Williams scored 13 of his 19 points in the fourth quarter and Indiana did not allow a field goal in the first six minutes of the period as Indiana won for only the second time in the last 16 games in Richfield Coliseum. Indiana, which has won five in a row, outscored Cavaliers by 18-3 at the start of the fourth quarter. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Princeton Clinches Ivy Tie Sean Jackson made two 3-point baskets in the final 2 minutes 12 seconds of the first half to lead Princeton, which clinched at least a tie for the Ivy League title by defeating Columbia, 56-33. Princeton (19-2 over all, 10-0 in the Ivy) has won 11 straight games and 24 in a row at Jadwin Gymnasium. Jackson has scored 74 3-point baskets, breaking Matt Lapin's school record. Columbia is 7-16 over all and 5-6 in the Ivy. (AP) GOLF Wyatt Ahead by 2 Strokes Jennifer Wyatt's performance in the first round of the Hawaiian Ladies Open in Honolulu awed even one of the L.P.G.A. tour's leading players. The defending champion, Beth Daniel, the 1990 player of the year, marveled after Wyatt shot a career-best six-under-par 66 amid brisk winds and on hard greens on Thursday. Wyatt held a two-stroke lead over Patty Sheehan, with Daniel and Ok-Hee Ku of South Korea three strokes back. (AP) Lietzke Leads Los Angeles Open: Bruce Lietzke shot an eight-under-par 63 to take the second-round lead in the Los Angeles Open at the Riviera Country Club. Four players -- Ted Schulz, Andrew Magee, Davis Love 3d and Jeff Sluman -- were two shots behind Lietzke at the midpoint of the tournament. (AP) Player and Charles Disqualified: Gary Player and Bob Charles, International team partners in Chrysler Cup competition, were disqualified after hitting the wrong balls -- their own -- on the first fairway at Sarasota, Fla. Player and Charles said they were confused by a seldom-used alternate-shot stroke-play format." The disqualifications helped give the United States team a 12.5-7.5 lead over the Internationals. In other matches, George Archer and Miller Barber of the United States tied Bruce Crampton and Brian Waites at 68; the Internationals' Simon Hobday and Harold Henning edged Chi Chi Rodriguez and Charles Coody, 66-67; and Lee Trevino and Jim Dent beat Bruce Devlin and Roberto DeVicenzo, 68-72. Each match at the Tournament Players Club at Prestancia was worth 5 points. The alternate shot format, a new addition to the Chrysler Cup this year, calls for each player to tee off, then hit his partner's ball on the second shot. From there, each two-man team selects its best ball and plays it for the remainder of the hole, alternating shots. (AP) TENNIS Edberg Advances in 61 Minutes Stefan Edberg, looking every bit the top player in the world, breezed into the semifinals of the $1 million Eurocard Classic in Stuttgart, Germany, yesterday by beating his fellow Swede Magnus Gustafsson, 6-2, 6-3. Edberg needed only 61 minutes to raise his career record against Gustafsson to 4-0. His semifinal opponent will be Jan Siemerink, a 20-year-old Dutchman who upset Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union, 7-6, 7-5. Another Swede reached the semifinals when seventh-seeded Jonas Svensson beat Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-2. He will meet Guy Forget of France, the hottest player on the tour, in the semifinals. Forget, seeking his third title of the year, beat Goran Ivanisevic, 7-5, 7-6. The Frenchman, winner in Brussels last week and seeded sixth, needed 1 hour 38 minutes to beat the third-seeded Yugoslav and never lost his service. Using deadly passing shots, he broke Ivanisevic at love to take the first set. Ivanisevic saved a match point in the 10th game of the second set and had two serves at 6-6 in the tie breaker. But he made two errors at the net and Forget clinched the match. (AP) Lendl and Chang Gain: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and fifth-seeded Michael Chang rolled to straight-set victories last night, advancing to the semifinal round of the $750,000 Volvo Indoor tournament in Memphis. Lendl powered his way past Darren Cahill, 7-6, 6-3. Chang topped Jeff Tarango 6-3, 7-5. Today, Lendl will meet the 11th-seeded Derrick Rostagno, who rallied to defeat Cristiano Caratti, 6-7, 6-2, 6-0. Chang will meet seventh-seeded Michael Stich, the defending champion, who defeated Mark Koevermans, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) N.H.L. Gretzky Leads Kings Wayne Gretzky scored a goal and set up four others to lead Los Angeles to a 6-4 victory over the Jets at Winnipeg. The Kings lead the Calgary Flames by 4 points ahead in the battle for first place in the Smythe Division. (AP) Red Wings 5, Oilers 5: Steve Yzerman scored his second goal of the game with 4 minutes 28 seconds left in the third period to lift Detroit. Grant Fuhr, playing his first home game since being reinstated after a suspension for drug use, allowed five goals on 26 shots. (AP)

title: Confident Howe Aiming To Be Cozy With Yanks
description: The newest Yankee pitcher dressed at the far end of the clubhouse, but his first day at work still must have felt like a strange, new experience.

title: Lynn Martin Is Sworn In
description: Former Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois was sworn in today as Secretary of Labor, replacing her predecessor, Elizabeth Dole, as the only woman running a Cabinet-level department. Ms. Martin's husband, Judge Harry Leinenweber of Federal District Court, administered the oath of office. The ceremony, at the Labor Department, was attended by President Bush, who nominated Ms. Martin to the post after she lost a a bid last year to take Senator Paul Simon's seat away from him.

title: Garagiola Wins Fame
description: Joe Garagiola, a catcher for nine years in the major leagues with a .257 career batting average, will enter the Hall of Fame this summer as the recipient of the Ford C. Frick Award for broadcasting.

title: Critic's Notebook; An Excess of Excess, But What A Party
description: Let's see: a Playskool Tiny Tim, three pens, four buttons, "The Big Apple Guide," one can of caffeine-free Diet Pepsi, a bottle of lemon-flavored Perrier, a small bottle of Glenfiddich Scotch whisky, a cassette sampler, a New York restaurant guide, not one but two copies of Entertainment Weekly magazine, a sample of Elizabeth Taylor's Passion for Men cologne, a Warner Brothers cap, a Life magazine 1991 calendar, a Trump Plaza key chain, a C.D./book package of "The Lives of Quincy Jones." Anything else? Oh, yes, the most important: earplugs.

title: Patents; A Treatment To Reverse Osteoporosis
description: A gynecologist in Massachusetts obtained a patent this week on a treatment program using hormones that he said appeared to reverse the bone-weakening condition known as osteoporosis, which primarily affects elderly women.

title: Religion Notes
description: Bickering Bishops

title: If a Shop Closes With Your Item Inside
description: When Hank Hachmann left a computer printer at a store to be repaired late last year, he thought he would have it back in a couple of weeks. But the store, Wolff Office Equipment at 23 West 18th Street in Manhattan, filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Dec. 28 and closed its doors.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan; King's Remarks Hint at New Shift
description: King Hussein of Jordan seemed to shift positions today by acknowledging that Iraq's effort to link the crisis to the Palestinian issue had failed.

title: Businesses Contend Rules on Disabled Are Vague
description: Business groups contended today that proposed Federal regulations on how commercial establishments must treat disabled customers were so vague that the courts would end up setting the standards.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The worlds of fashion, art, beauty, show business and design collided Thursday night as GEOFFREY BEENE, the designer; ALEX KATZ, the artist; KENNETH, the hairdresser; JOAN RIVERS, the funny; NAOMI CAMPBELL, the supermodel; VICENTE WOLF, the interior designer, and about 500 other people with perfect haircuts squeezed into a SoHo loft for a look at Allure, the new beauty magazine.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air France, the state-owned airline, will receive two billion francs, or about $400 million, of new capital from the French Government in 1991 as part of the effort to help the company through the current downturn. * Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., New York, the technology and management consultant, will acquire Spicer & Oppenheim Consultants, London, a financial services consultant, for undisclosed terms. * British Steel P.L.C., London, said it would cut a further 1,100 jobs at its Scottish Ravenscraig steel works and operate only one blast furnace at the plant. * Campeau Corp., Toronto, the real estate and retail company, will sell its Hippodrome Blue Bonnets properties in Quebec to the Societe d'Habitation et de Developpement de Montreal, a municipal agency, for $46 million (Canadian). * Champion International Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of building materials and paper products, reduced the quarterly dividend payment on its common stock to 5 cents a share from 27.5 cents. * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., said its president, Philip Benton, would undergo coronary bypass surgery in the next few days. Mr. Benton's duties will be temporarily assumed by Allan Gilmour, president of Ford's automotive group. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., said its equally-owned CFM International joint venture with Snecma of France had received an order worth more than $500 million to provide CFM56-3 high bypass turbofan engines for Asiana Airlines of South Korea. * Volvo Cars of North America said it would raise the prices of its 1991 models by 1.8 percent on a sales-weighted basis.

title: Dixon Wins Another 400-Meter Title; Morceli Takes Mile
description: It has become rather commonplace for Diane Dixon to win another national title in the women's 400-meter race. It is starting to get a little repetitious, too, for Noureddine Morceli of Algeria to win another mile race.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once one of the world's leading tenors, JOSE CARRERAS has made his first major opera house appearance since he quit the stage in 1987, suffering from leukemia. After singing the leading role in "Samson et Dalila" at London's Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, on Thursday, he received a standing ovation. The audience had paid up to $190 to hear him.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; The Seven-Day Strategy Bush Timetable Seeks to Humble Hussein While Diminishing Army's Fighting Ability
description: In setting a seven-day limit for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, the Bush Administration is seeking to deliver a decisive political blow to Baghdad while diminishing the Iraqi Army's war-fighting abilities, diplomats and American officials say.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Bush Gets Europe's Support While Jordan Is Optimistic
description: Leading European countries today gave full backing to Washington's ultimatum to President Saddam Hussein on an immediate withdrawal of his troops from Kuwait.

title: Camps Victimize Vietnamese Boat People
description: To the Editor:

title: School Regains Teams
description: Ten days after announcing that he would be dropping four sports for cost-cutting reasons next season, Paul Verkuil, the president of William and Mary, said yesterday that the college would reinstate them. The sports were women's basketball, men's wrestling and men's and women's swimming. He said the reaction from students, alumni and fans opposing the cuts, along with new funding for the sports, led to the decision. A spokesman, William N. Walker, said contributions and future financial commitments had saved the sports.(AP)

title: Sports Car By Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would begin producing a high-powered two-seat sports car in November at a manufacturing center in Detroit.

title: Korean War Memorial Shifts Again
description: The Commission of Fine Arts has approved a revised concept for the Korean War Veterans Memorial but asked the architectural firm of Cooper-Lecky to provide more specifics of its proposed sculpture and mural.

title: A Foolish Decade
description: As U.S. forces roll toward military victory over Iraq, President Bush's high approval rating seems unlikely to be shaken by his cool response to the Soviet peace plan. When combat ultimately winds down, however, and patriotic fervor begins to fade, the U.S. public may begin to recall two circumstances, among others, that helped bring on the Persian Gulf war:

title: War Summary
description: BUSH GIVES IRAQ A DEADLINE

title: Cynthia Ransom Wed To Nels A. Lindquist
description: Cynthia Eileen Ransom, a daughter of Marlys C. Ransom of Jacksonville, N.C., and Morris E. Ransom of Bayonne, N.J., was married yesterday in Roswell, Ga., to Nels Andrew Lindquist, the son of Mrs. Maurice W. Lindquist of Des Moines and the late Mr. Lindquist. The Rev. Elaine Puckett officiated at the Northbrook United Methodist Church.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Devils Control Penguins As Lemieux Watches
description: Tonight, unlike in their five previous meetings with the Penguins, four of them losses, the Devils refused to play Pittsburgh's wide-open style of game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Tom Haas, Theater Director, 53
description: Tom Haas, artistic director of the Indiana Repertory Theater, died Thursday at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis. He was 53 years old and lived in Indianapolis.

title: Man Acquitted of Killing and Boiling Roommate
description: A Manhattan jury found an East Village man not guilty by reason of insanity yesterday for killing and dismembering his roommate after she tried to throw him out of her apartment.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat BUSH DEMANDS IRAQ START PULLOUT TODAY DESPITE ITS ASSENT TO 3-WEEK SOVIET PLAN; OILFIELDS AND TRENCHES AFLAME IN KUWAIT AIR WAR IS PRESSED
description: Allied fighter-bombers pounded enemy troop emplacements in every corner of Kuwait today, flying a record number of missions over the emirate despite clouds of inky smoke from oil-well fires, apparently set by Iraq, that covered a quarter of the nation.

title: The Feminist Disdain for Nursing
description: At a recent party, a lawyer friend with whom I've shared feminist causes introduced me to her house guests as "almost a doctor." "No," I protested, "I am a nurse" -- to which she replied, "Oh, no, Ellen, you're more than a nurse."

title: Key Rates
For Israel, Light -- Or More Tunnel?
description: Israelis, sealed in frustrating passivity, hope that conditions after the war will help bring about an Israeli-Palestinian settlement. Yet there are persuasive grounds for gloom.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.S. Statements; Transcripts of Statements by Bush and Fitzwater on Unconditional Pullout
description: Following are transcripts of the statement made this morning by President Bush on the Persian Gulf, and a statement later by his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, as provided by News Transcripts Inc.: BUSH'S STATEMENT

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Moscow's Statement; Transcript of Comments on Soviet Peace Proposal
description: Following is a transcript of a statement yesterday by Vitaly N. Ignatenko, a spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after talks between Foreign Ministers Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union and Tariq Aziz of Iraq. The translation is in part by Reuters and in part by a Soviet Foreign Ministry official.

title: Du Pont Pays $1.85 Million In a Waste Disposal Dispute
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has agreed to pay $1.85 million in penalties to settle a complaint by the Government on the disposal of hazardous waste, the third-largest such fine ever obtained.

title: Congressional Report Urges U.S. To Set a Policy on Medical Waste
description: Congress enacted legislation in 1988 to keep medical refuse from turning up on public beaches or in garbage bins, but a Government study says there still is no comprehensive plan to properly dispose of the waste.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; Inner-City Youths And Students Working Together
description: Students at Syra cuse University are teaming up with inner-city youths to help out around the community.

title: Data Bank/February 24, 1991
Review/Theater; Recalling a Dead Friend
description: A gigantic sculpture of an animal dominates the stage in Jean-Claude van Itallie's "Ancient Boys" (at La Mama Annex). Towering like an icon, this is a Trojan horse-like assemblage designed by Jun Maeda from twigs and branches. Would that Mr. van Itallie's play had lived up to Mr. Maeda's design. "Ancient Boys" is itself like a Trojan horse, promising one thing (a probing study of the effects of AIDS) and delivering another (a sentimentalized dramatization of a death in a family).

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 24, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 11 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 2 19 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 3 4 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures. 4 4 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Warner, $5.95.) Killings on the Norfolk coast. 5 * 4 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $6.95.) The history of the sea islands. 6 5 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) A physician struggles to clear his name. 7 5 THE CONQUEST, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $5.50.) Romance in 15th-century England. 8 4 MERCY, by David L. Lindsey. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Houston detective on the trail of a killer. 9 1 SCANDAL, by Amanda Quick. (Bantam, $4.95.) A woman finds romance with an enigmatic nobleman in 19th-century England. 10 3 SECRET SONG, by Catherine Coulter. (Onyx, $4.95.) A handsome rogue sets out to rescue an imprisoned young woman in 13th-century Britain. 11 9 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving ceremonial masks. 12 1 SLEEPING WITH THE ENEMY, by Nancy Price. (Berkley, $4.95.) To escape a cruel marriage, a woman fakes her death and starts a new life, only to have her past catch up with her. 13 * 7 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Signet, $5.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. 14 11 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 15 * 2 PAINT THE WIND, by Cathy Cash Spellman. (Dell, $5.95.) A Louisiana belle finds romance, power and wealth in the post-Civil War West. 16 * 1 THE ANASTASIA SYNDROME: And Other Stories, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) Five stories in which romance and the macabre lurk beneath the veneer of ordinary life. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 28 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 2 4 SADDAM HUSSEIN AND THE CRISIS IN THE GULF, by Judith Miller and Laurie Mylroie. (Times Books/Random House, $5.95.) A report on the Iraqi President and his invasion of Kuwait. 3 6 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) The ordeal of an American woman held captive in Iran by a hostile husband. 4 4 THE RAPE OF KUWAIT, by Jean P. Sasson. (Knightsbridge, $4.95.) The invasion of Kuwait as observed by people who witnessed it and escaped. 5 66 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 6 * 3 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Avon, $5.95.) Prognostications for the next decade. 7 24 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 8 383 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 9 2 AWAKENINGS, by Oliver Sacks. (Harper Perennial, $9.95.) The case histories of patients who contracted sleeping sickness and recovered decades later through use of a new drug. 10 1 ARMAGEDDON, OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST CRISIS, by John F. Walvoord. (Zondervan, $8.95.) A theologian says current events are fulfilling the Bible's promise of the Second Coming of Christ. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 13 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 2 2 DESERT SHIELD FACT BOOK, by the staff of GDW. (Game Designers' Workshop, $10.) Data and maps relevant to the war in the Persian Gulf. 3 30 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 4 121 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 10 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Electrical Outlets
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip a companion found himself with an inoperative video recorder in the middle of Africa, and it was only by good luck that we were able to find a repair shop that could fix it.

title: All About/Convention Halls; The Latest Municipal Malady: Convention Center Fever
description: They're the places where the Society of Foresters come to don straw boaters and fit in some free-spirited carousing. Where the members of the Kansas State Square Dance Association turn out to network while they find out the latest twists in dance calls. Those structures that resemble vast, beached, extremely homely whales: convention centers.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Americans; America on Edge: A Day for Emotional Turmoil
description: Some cried for endangered loved ones and the failure of diplomacy. Others spoke of a chance for crushing victory. There were demonstrations for and against the war. But as the deadline for Iraqi capitulation passed, and before word came of the beginning of the ground war, most Americans went about their weekend routines yesterday, carrying fears and lingering doubts home with the groceries.

title: Census on Reservation: 2 Indians, 759 Whites
description: The United States Census reports that whites, not Indians, make up almost the entire population of the Onondaga Indian Reservation.

title: Movable (Whew!) Closets, With a Dutch Accent
description: The heftiest status symbol for Dutch settlers in Colonial America, a massive cupboard called a kas or kast, reigned supreme in fashionable New York and New Jersey parlors throughout the 18th century. The larger the cupboard -- some were eight feet tall -- the more formidable the fortune of the family that owned it, or so it was thought. Filled with linens, porcelains, silver and the householder's gun, the kas (pronounced kaz) was kept locked, with the woman of the house in charge of the key.

title: Pro Hockey; Richter Continues to Impress
description: If the Calder Trophy competition were an Olympic sport, Mike Richter of the Rangers would be a strong candidate for the bronze medal, a possibility for the silver and a long shot for the gold.

title: World Markets; In Hong Kong, the Surge Goes On
description: The money managers who have bet on Hong Kong this year -- and there are many -- have been right. And some analysts argue that the market will continue to go their way as long as the war in the Persian Gulf ends soon, the United States economy snaps out of its recession fairly quickly and China continues to press for economic growth and springs no surprises.

title: For Wallboard Blues
description: MINOR damage to wallboards -- dents, protruding nail heads, holes up to about four inches in diameter -- is fairly easy to repair.

title: The Early Days Of a Symphony
description: The informative article "All Agree Orchestra Needs a Larger Endowment" (Jan. 27) about the current critical state of the New Jersey Symphony contained a historical fact I thought I might expand on.

title: Article 948292 -- No Title
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rich Bisques to Warm Winter's Chill
description: A BOWL of warming soup is a winter favorite. Some of the heartiest, most sustaining varieties are thick, bisque-like, richly flavored creations.

title: Stamps
description: A joint issue by the United States and Switzerland on Friday marked the 700th anniversary of the founding of Switzerland.

title: On Not Getting Away From It All
description: NO what matter their motives for leaving home, be it a crucial conference in Grand Forks or an incredible cruise to Grand Cayman, voyagers with a clear agenda usually return satisfied. Sure, the typical inconveniences confronting travelers -- delayed flights, lost luggage, bad weather -- often rear their unwelcome heads, but such annoyances are almost expected and, thus, easily overcome. Let's face it, no matter how much travelers complain, the majority of them, whether seeking a sun-drenched pina colada or a notarized contract, come back from their distant destinations having accomplished what they set out to do.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Worcester, Mass.;
Ethnic Enclave Gets Housing
description: SHREWSBURY STREET, the commercial center of this city's Italian-American community, is about to get its first public housing, the 75-unit Mount Carmel Apartments for the elderly.

title:
Focus: Philadelphia;
From Industrial Sites to Artists' Studios
description: LATER this year, artists are expected to move into an unusual cooperative here: a 72-year-old warehouse in the Germantown section divided into 16 no-frills residential studios with high ceilings. Costs for the artists, most with annual incomes below $22,000, are being subsidized by a foundation.

title: Eastchester Pupils Campaign for a Stamp
description: TO Corrine Magnani, the project has become more important than anything else. Melissa Kosack didn't think the goal would be so hard to achieve, and Josh Gaynor doesn't mind giving up his lunch hour to work on it.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures of two engaged couples last Sunday were reversed. Matthew Toll and Ann Tweedy were at the left. Randall Havas and Melissa Weissberg were at the right.

title: As in Vietnam, Troops Will Bring Truth Home; No First Nuclear Use
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the Chief Medical Examiner for the state of Virginia and a woman who loves her morbid job, performs it with verve and brilliance in BODY OF EVIDENCE (Scribners, $18.95). Patricia D. Cornwell's nerve-jangling sequel to "Postmortem" finds the pathologist stunned by the savagery of a young novelist's death ("stab wounds spread open like large red buttonholes") and outraged by the cavalier response of the Richmond police to the victim's futile pleas for protection. "If it had been me," one apologist offers, "I would have been suspicious the lady was lonely, wanted the attention."

title: Design; OBJECTS OF INFLECTION
