title: The Executive Computer; Radio Waves That Really Bind, From Motorola
description: Making good on a 1990 promise, Motorola Inc. has developed a wireless networking device that allows computers to send and receive data within a building at high speeds over radio waves. The Altair Ethernet network, demonstrated at the Networld 91 trade show held here earlier this month, is faster and less susceptible to data interruption than previous wireless systems.

title: Miss Pantaleoni to Wed Neil Tardio Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Pantaleoni have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Tea Pantaleoni, to Neil Joseph Tardio Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tardio of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Chess
description: Is there such a thing as enough chess for Anatoly Karpov?

title: Kara Weiss and Steven Maser Wed
description: Kara Beth Weiss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Weiss of Livingston, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Steven Alan Maser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Barry Maser of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Barry Friedman officiated at Temple B'nai Abraham.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
The Way Chile Was
description: When Chileans voted against Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the 1988 plebiscite on which he bet his presidency, the gray land that he had spent 15 years creating suddenly went Technicolor. Exiles flocked home, politics came alive and passions that had been consigned to old songs and private conversation spilled again into the streets. And from old boxes and behind shelves, Chilean photographers pulled out negatives that through years of poverty and censorship had mostly gone unprinted. With the American photojournalist Susan Meiselas, 16 of them have now assembled many of those images in an extraordinary visual memoir, CHILE: From Within (Norton, $39.95). The book is most striking for what it leaves out. General Pinochet -- who once boasted that not a leaf moved in Chile without his knowledge -- appears only twice. Instead of the street violence that he made a news agency staple, the photographers offer images such as that of a dwarf in a business suit, crossing a promenade that riot police have just swept of demonstrators, or a park after curfew, its inviting benches filled only by an eerie mist. Though the photographs are uneven in their power, almost none of them reveal themselves on first glance. But even before the photographs give way to a selection of writings by the Chilean novelist Ariel Dorfman, the book manages to explain much about how a people coddled for so long by democracy were able to endure General Pinochet's dictatorship and then so patiently take back their freedom.

title: Jane N. Barrett, Lawyer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Jane Nicholls Barrett to Christopher E. Ridley, a son of Mrs. Edmund C. Ridley of New York and the late Mr. Ridley, has been made known by her father, Harry L. Barrett Jr. of Wayland, Mass. A May wedding is planned. The prospective bride also is a daughter of the late Barbara Tucker Barrett.

title: IN JERSEY, A FIGHT OVER REDISTRICTING
description: A dispute over whether the 1990 Census accurately counted minority residents of New Jersey has led to a legal conflict between Democrats and Republicans over when and how to redraw the state's legislative districts.

title: Job-Related Ailments in Offices Increasing

description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Futter of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Gail Futter to William David Cohan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Cohan of Worcester, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

description: Pamela Dukes Wooters, a daughter of J. title: L.A. Lore Delivers A Jolt
description: Consider it poetic justice: the man who once complained that the main cultural advantage to California living was being able to make a right turn on a red light can now be seen toting a personalized surfboard and wearing a small, discreet ponytail. Woody Allen's very presence in Paul Mazursky's "Scenes From a Mall," which casts him as a Los Angeles entertainment lawyer with a warm-up suit, car phone, long and iffy marriage to a wife who has written a self-help book, plus two teen-age children who are eager to borrow his gold card, attests to the wide world of comic possibilities inherent in culture shock -- in all its many forms.

description: WET WORK By Christopher Buckley. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Track and Field; Young Runners Making Their Mark
description: While Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson prepare to resume their sprinting rivalry, now that Johnson's two-year suspension for drug use is over, it should be noted that their first encounter, scheduled for May in Sweden, could become a second-rate event.

title: Ruth Landes Is Dead; Anthropologist Was 82
description: Dr. Ruth Landes, an anthropologist who won critical acclaim for her studies of black Brazilians, Indians in North Dakota and Hispanic-Americans in the American Southwest, died on Feb. 11 at her home in Hamilton, Ontario. She was 82 years old.

title: Princeton Ballet Offers A College Dance Fair
description: BEFORE the proliferation of regional ballet companies in the last 10 years, career-minded ballet students had to make the often difficult choice between a college education and further dance training. Today they can enjoy both, since many colleges and universities offer degree programs in dance that provide professional training and equip a young dancer to enter a company with degree in hand.

title: Electrical Outlets
description: To the Editor: Eric N. Berg's article about electrical outlets abroad (Practical Traveler, Jan. 13) omitted one important point about outlets in Germany. While the spacing between prongs in the adapter plugs available in the United States was described correctly, the article did not take into account the fact that German sockets are recessed in the wall and are not wide enough to accommodate the plugs. We were reminded of this last autumn in Berlin when we tried to find an adapter for the adapter plug. Shopkeepers were familiar with the problem but could offer no solution. Eventually, we fashioned an extension of the prongs themselves by disassembling a German multiple plug adapter and using its prongs to extend those on our adapter plug, a serviceable if somewhat risky solution. ROBERT L. LICHTER, DIANE SCOTT Huntington Station, L.I.

title: The Care and Feeding of Sitcom Stand-Ups
description: Among fellow comedians, Jonathan Winters has a reputation as a master improviser, capable of inventing sidesplitting lines at the snap of a finger. But Mr. Winters has had difficulty finding a place in situation comedy. With the ABC series "Davis Rules," however, the intention from the start has been to build Mr. Winters's zany unpredictability into the structure of the show, on the theory that such an approach is easier -- and more rewarding -- than trying to rein in the comedian. "We provide a launching pad and he provides the trajectory," said Danny Jacobson, the show's executive producer and a veteran of "Roseanne."

title: Headliners; Last Hired...
description: The closing of the New York City budget gap is opening a personal budget gap for Linda Moses. She is only one of hundreds of city workers who are part of the first wave of layoffs prompted by New York's fiscal problems, but she is symbolizes a segment of the city workforce for whom joblessness brings a special jolt. Ms. Moses is one of many former welfare recipients who, through special programs or by their own initiative, got city clerical jobs. Ms. Moses, a mother of two who went to work as an office aide in a city housing agency about three and a half years ago, was in turmoil last week after learning she would be laid off. "I'm scared, I'm mad, I'm frustrated and all of that," she said. "I don't want to go back on welfare; it's degrading." Another former welfare recipient about to lose her job, Adrian Mannigault, had similar concerns. "I'm mad at the sysytem," she said. "I got back on my feet, I raised my kids, I thought it was going to be smooth. Then they pull the rug out from under your feet."

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: How I wish Philip M. Murphy had been with me in Moscow on New Year's Eve 1970. I had gone there to investigate the well-being of Mstislav Rostropovich, who had offered Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn refuge in his own home. Mr. Rostropovich had become a friend of mine in 1967 when he performed with the Philadelphia Orchestra and I was on the orchestra's library staff.

title: In Baghdad, Criticism Followed by Silence

The official, Izzat Ibrahim, who is Mr. Hussein's second in command, was quoted as saying that the only way to stop the war was for Washington to accept the last-ditch Soviet-Iraqi peace plan.

description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ME AND MY BABY VIEW THE ECLIPSE, by Lee Smith. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Though he loves his wife, the small-town grocer in one of these short stories decides to have an affair with a dying woman. "It seems to me that nearly every one of the stories in Lee Smith's new collection could move a reader to tears," Ethan Canin said here last year, "for in almost every one of them there is a moment of vision, or love, or unclothed wonder that transforms something plain into something transcendent."

description: "I know, I know," said Stanley, even before I could sit down. "You're wondering why I look so pale."

description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A water pipe upstairs burst recently, and before the water could be shut off there was considerable flooding. Water dripped through to the ceiling below, leaving a water ring or stain on the acoustic tiles on that ceiling. Is there any way to eliminate these stains without having to paint the whole ceiling?

title: Support for the Desert Rats?
description: Even the squirrels here are adorning their homes with yellow ribbons. Nest-building rodents filched six yellow satin sashes tied around a tree and telephone pole in front of the Borntrager house here. "We know they did it," said 15-year-old Thomas Borntrager. "If you look outside my house now, you can see it in the nest." Many residents of this Bergen County community have tied yellow ribbons around trees to show support for U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf war.

title: An Alliance Turning Into a Free-for-All
description: Beyond the Persian Gulf war and the deepening recession, there looms another make-or-break issue for America: How to deal with Japan and Germany in the new world order?

title: Business Diary/February 17-22
description: THE ECONOMY Gasoline Prices on the Downswing, but for How Long? Gasoline and crude oil prices have fallen to their lowest levels since shortly before Iraq marched into Kuwait. An American Automobile Association survey released last week said that gasoline had declined to $1.135 a gallon, about the same price as before the war but for a 5-cent-a-gallon Federal tax increase. Oil, driven down by peace proposals, closed on Friday at $17.91 a barrel, less than half its October peak. But don't start celebrating just yet. Even some of those analysts who expect crude oil to stay low expect gasoline costs to rise. Iraqi and Kuwaiti refineries have been ruined in the war; the Iraqis were apparently torching Kuwaiti facilities at the end of the week. Even the Saudis have to import fuel to supply the military, and gasoline demand will rise more rapidly once the American economy revives. "There will be ample crude for refiners, but not adequate refining capacity for consumers," said Alfred O. Munk, a consultant and the former foreign affairs manager for the Amoco Corporation. "Crude," he pointed out, "is not what you consume." The Inflation Numbers Game A recession that was supposed to extinguish inflation has still left the pilot light burning. Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, eight-tenths without food and energy. Economists, who can no more take a figure at face value than Ella Fitzgerald can leave a melody unadorned, went to work explaining away the news. Look at higher liquor taxes, increased auto costs, rising apparel prices, other one-time events, they said. But a few saw underlying pressures, especially the 6 percent annual-rate increase in service costs, which account for about half of the inflation index. In dousing inflation, said William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, "a short, shallow recession isn't going to give you much benefit." Greenspan Confused? Let nobody out-worry Alan Greenspan about the Persian Gulf war and the credit crunch. In addressing two Congressional committees last week, he rehearsed his forecast of a mild recession, but then added more fine print than your typical car-rental agreement. Some of those clauses concerned the war, but most troubling, he said, was the Fed's inability to prompt banks to resume lending to their creditworthy customers. If Mr. Greenspan usually appears as a determined general unwilling to reveal his battle plans, last week he all but confessed to confusion. He seemed uncertain about whether to maintain or lower interest rates, adding that others at the Fed are divided. Some of his colleagues counsel patience, anticipating a rebound; others have a darker outlook than his. Here Comes Unicode The United Nations' near-unanimity on Kuwait was unusual, but the computer industry's agreement to use a common digital code is truly extraordinary. The usually fractious companies, including International Business Machines, Apple, Sun and Microsoft, hope for Unicode to become a global standard representing letters and characters in every language. Companies could then more readily write software to work in a variety of languages, and international computer communications would flow more smoothly. "It's a lot more meaningful than Esperanto, because we're dealing with computers, not people" said Esther Dyson, publisher of the newsletter Release 1.0. She added that the third world would benefit the most. "It's like affirmative action for smaller nations," she said. Where a Bank Finds Cash Banks may be where they keep the money, but when Citicorp itself needs money, it looks to the Middle East. Prince al-Waleed bin Talal agreed last week to invest $590 million in Citicorp. He had accumulated 4.9 percent of the company's stock last year, so his latest purchase could give him 14.9 percent if he converts his new preferred stock to common. He said in 1988 that he "would love to be a corporate raider"; just a joke, his aides now explain. Exactly where all the money is coming from is unclear. Prince Waleed is indeed a nephew of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, but he had to put up his house as collateral to get a loan from Citicorp just a decade ago. Where Citicorp will find even more badly needed capital might soon become clear. Other possible sources include the displaced royal rulers of Kuwait. "You go wherever there is a lot of spare cash," said James E. Akins, a consultant and former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Even though the Saudi rulers are temporarily pinched, he said, "There is a lot of spare cash in the Arabian peninsula." COMPANIES

title: Postings: Sunrise Mall Renovation; A Second Dawning
description: During the 1960's and 70's Muss-Tankoos Corporation of Manhattan was a major force in the creation of suburban super malls on Long Island. The company built two of the region's largest multilevel enclosed shopping centers -- the 1.4-million-square-foot Smithaven Mall in Smithtown and the 1.3-million-square-foot Sunrise Mall in Massapequa.

title: A History Told in Patches and Patterns
description: THE fragmented patterns of American quilts can serve as lenses, revealing multifaceted views of historic and domestic events. Through the colors, textures and associative value of fabrics the quilts also convey the "feeling tone" of their periods. Both effects can be found in a cluster of exhibitions now in the county that, collectively, chart a continuum of quilt-making from the 18th through the 20th centuries.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Can You Believe This?

title: The World; South Africa and Apartheid: No Apologies
description: IN the more than four decades that apartheid has been the law in South Africa, the toll it has exacted on victims of color might begin something like this: Seventeen million arrests of blacks found in areas reserved for whites. The dispossession of 3.5 million people from their homes. Eighty thousand detentions without trial. Up to 40,000 South Africans driven into foreign exile. But it is harder to measure the destruction of families torn apart by racial reclassification, the ravages of inferior education, deprivation of job skills and the attendant suffocation of self-worth.

title: Truce on Parking Fines for New York Soldiers

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Front; Soldiers Poised on the Edge of the Unknown

title: Q and A
description: Security on Lease Question: I signed a five-year lease for office space in New Jersey with options to renew for two additional five-year terms. The landlord received a two-month security deposit when the lease was signed. Am I entitled to interest on the deposit and is there a time period after which the security has to be returned if the renewal options are exercised? . . . Michael Rosengarten, Dumont, N.J. Answer: The answer to both questions is probably no. According to Richard R. Kahn, a Hackensack lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, your right to interest would be deterimned by the terms of the lease, not any law.

title: Strasbourg
description: To the Editor: Your fine article on Strasbourg (Travel, April 22) inspired us to squeeze in a visit there between business stops in Paris and London.

title: Funeral Held for Aquinas Runner
description: A funeral Mass was held in upper Manhattan yesterday morning for Stephanie Companioni, the 15-year-old runner who died last Monday after collapsing two days earlier at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships. Attending the service at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church were relatives and friends of the Aquinas High School sophomore, as well as officials of the C.H.S.A.A. and other athletes.

title: LOOKING ON THE BRIGHT SIDE
description: It's as if designers everywhere want to give the world a lift. Instead of being on the somber side - which would be completely understandable - the latest styles are exactly the opposite. Exuding confidence and cheeriness, these new fashions are like bright flags bravely waving above the troubled landscape. Jaunty in line, perky in silhouette, the spring clothes vibrate with color. They still sport short, snappy hemlines, but have smaller shoulders. Accessories, which remain all-important, are amusing in shape, hue and material - daisies bloom everywhere.

title: 'The Way of the WASP'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech Notes; Fine-Tuning the Search for Oil
description: Time was, a gusher erupted over the field when oil was struck. Not so anymore. Low pressure in older fields, especially in the United States, has made the gusher a thing of the past. Now, oil is much more likely to seep from small scattered reservoirs through tiny root-like cracks in porous rock. Find the cracks, find the oil. To do that, Atlas Wireline Services in Houston, a joint venture of Litton Industries Inc. and Dresser Industries Inc., has designed a circumferential borehead imaging device to produce sharp electronic images of the inside of the well hole at depths up to 30,000 feet and temperatures up to 350 degrees Farenheit.

title: A Troubled New Heroine at the Met
description: When "Katya Kabanova" opens at the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow evening, in a new production directed by Jonathan Miller and conducted by the Janacek specialist Charles Mackerras, it will become only the second of Janacek's operas to be performed by the company. ("Jenufa" racked up 6 performances in 1924-25 with Maria Jeritza, 7 in 1974-75 and another 10 in 1985-86.)

title: Fairy Tale Ending for the Giants and Me
description: Fifty years of a life brushed aside in a tidy 10-word headline: "Robert Tisch Agrees to Buy 50% of the Champion Giants." What the headline fails to say is that somewhere lost in talk of the uncle and the nephew is the sister who grieves for the end of a fairy tale filled with giants. . . .

title: God and Man in Provincetown
description: RESUSCITATION OF A HANGED MAN By Denis Johnson. 257 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Putting New Zing Into Cuban Food
description: ALL of a sudden, 30 years after the first big influx of Cubans into Miami, this lively South Florida metropolis is discovering its Cuban culinary heritage. Cubans and Cuban food have always been part of the Miami scene, of course, since the city was incorporated in 1896. But the food hasn't always been of a quality to stir wide interest. Traditional Cuban food is filling, with roast pork, black beans and a medley of tuberous vegetables as its key ingredients, and its principal cooking fat the infamous lard. (Undeservedly infamous;according to the Department of Agriculture, lard is lower in cholesterol than butter.)

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Chemical Warfare; Vehicles Roam the Front To Detect Gas Attacks
description: With the allies considering it likely that Iraq will try to use chemical weapons against their troops, it is up to soldiers like Cpl. Larry Boudreau to determine which chemical agents have been unleashed and how much.

title: Where County Skaters Go to Find Ice
description: THERE have been some spells of balmy weather this winter, but they have not stopped Westchester residents from donning their skates and taking to the ice. If the real stuff is not to be found outdoors, skaters have indoor options available in the county.

title: Metro Datelines; Students Suspended For Carrying a Gun
description: Two 14-year-old students at Rippowam High School here have been suspended and face expulsion after bringing a gun and bullets into the school, officials said.

title:
MUSIC;
Chorale to Sing Works With a 'Kindred Spirit'
description: THE music director of the Pro Arte Chorale has put together a choral program intended to show some of the similarities in the American and British approaches to choral composition.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: INDIAN DANCES

title: Klaus Tennstedt, Ill, Cancels 2 Concert Series
description: Christopher Keene, director of the New York City Opera, and the Finnish conductor Paavo Berglund will replace the ailing Klaus Tennstedt in two concert series with the New York Philharmonic next month at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: A Dean of Watchmakers Credits His 'Tweezer Skills'
description: HENRY B. FRIED, like a fine timepiece, is a study in balance and counterbalance. He is surrounded in his spacious apartment here by 60 museum-quality clocks. "But I don't wind them up very often," he said. "They're too noisy."

title: Review/Opera; A Replacement Shines In the Met's 'Figaro'
description: Even with the withdrawal of Mirella Freni as Susanna, the Metropolitan Opera pulled out the casting stops for the first performance this season of "Le Nozze di Figaro" on Monday evening. Indeed, Miss Freni's replacement, Helen Donath, was the best singer in a starry cast. But as an overall performance, this one failed to cohere into a moving statement of this extraordinary Mozart masterpiece.

title:
The Executive Life;
Prove It's Harmless, Or Get Grounded
description: A word of advice to executive travelers: Don't pack anything you can't operate while under pressure. Just ask the top officer at a Wall Street investment bank who recently almost missed a flight from Europe to New York because he didn't know how to use his new electric traveling razor.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Augusta, Me.;
Mall Awaits Its Anchors
description: Late last month, the $60 million, 500,000-square-foot Mall at Augusta passed its final regulatory hurdle when it won a wetlands permit from the Army Corps of Engineers for what will be the state's third largest shopping center.

title: Goya Braces for a Challenge From the Food Giants
description: For the head of a food company, Joseph A. Unanue has some downright heretical views.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Soviet Army Marks Holiday by Protesting Democracy
description: A large but noticeably dispirited protest rally took place outside the Kremlin today as the Soviet military establishment resorted to a technique of democracy -- the right to free assembly -- the better to complain about democracy's alleged excesses.

title: Monument Maker
description: Maya Lin reluctantly faced the pale light of a Bowery dawn one morning last October and stepped around the reclining derelict on her doorstep who by day patrolled the sidewalk near her loft.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 10 of the New Jersey Weekly today about an exhibition of works by enamel artists at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Gallery on Route 206 south of Princeton omits the opening date. It is Thursday.

title: Boxing; One Jab Too Many Costs Camacho
description: A one-point penalty deduction by the referee, Carlos Padilla, at the start of the 12th and final round tonight cost Hector Camacho his World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title in a shocking upset registered by Greg Haugen indoors at Caesars Palace.

title: The Gorbachev Factor
description: As bad as things are under Mikhail Gorbachev, they would be worse still -- for Soviet citizens and for most others around the world -- under any likely successor.

title: Sunday Outing; What Better Day to Tour a City's Great Churches?
description: Americans fly thousands of miles to visit the churches and cathedrals of Europe, but how many people visit the churches of Manhattan? About 200 have been designated as New York City landmarks, with their Tiffany stained glass, 19th-century marble carvings and other treasures.

title: The Little Devils That Make H2 S
description: The article "Illegal Debris Tied to Noxious Odors at Closed Dump" [ Jan. 20 ] reported that the bad smell near Hempstead was produced by hydrogen sulfide. He mentions methane, a hydrocarbon generated by decaying organic matter in old garbage, and gypsum, which comes from construction debris. Methane is the source of hydrogen, and gypsum is the source of sulfur in hydrogen sulfide.

title: English Tea and a Florida Folk Tale
description: There's no shortage of reasons to catch "Absent Friends," the 1974 Alan Ayckbourn comedy that has been impeccably revived by the Manhattan Theater Club. But let's start with the breakdown that the British actress Brenda Blethyn undergoes midway through the second act.

title: What They're Wearing
description: Adding a dash of this and a dash of that is a great way to make a sure splash with fashion. Here, recent sightings in Manhattan.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: BABY'S BOOK OF LULLABIES & CRADLE SONGS. Selected and illustrated by Yvonne Gilbert. Dial. $12.95. (Ages 6 months to 5 years) Here are 16 traditional lullabies, each with words and music set out as though in a decorative frame opposite a pretty picture, most of which feature pretty babies. Among the mostly familiar songs are English, French, Norwegian, Austrian and Canadian (Iroquois) tunes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 16-19A

title: War Torn
description: OVER THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS, WELL before Operation Desert Shield blew up into Operation Desert Storm, I watched an NBC reporter interviewing American soldiers in Saudi Arabia. My father-in-law watched with me. He had fought in World War II, as an artillery forward observer with a division supporting Brig. Gen. Anthony (Nuts) McAuliffe's 101st Airborne at the Battle of the Bulge, then as a battery executive officer in Korea. I had been a Marine platoon commander in Vietnam.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK OF SCIENCE LITERACY: What Everyone Needs to Know From Newton to the Knuckleball. By the editors and reporters of Science Times. Edited by Richard Flaste. (Times Books/Random House, $24.95). The 120 or so articles in this collection by the staff of Science Times, the weekly science news section of The New York Times, have helped the public wrestle with current issues from passive smoking and disappearing beaches to the greenhouse effect and the perils (if any) of radiation from power lines. Gathered together by Richard Flaste, formerly the editor in charge of Science Times, they convey a view of science not as a mumbo jumbo of specialists or a collection of disciplines but as a sophisticated and perfectly accessible way of thinking whose importance to nonscientists is greater than ever, and unlikely to diminish.

title: Pro Basketball; 3d Period Becomes Nets' Chief Obstacle
description: The Nets led the Boston Celtics by 6 points at halftime on Friday night and lost.

title: Chevrolet Ranks High and Low in New Crash Tests
description: A front-seat passenger in the 1991 Chevrolet Caprice is vulnerable to serious or even fatal head injury in a crash, while the Chevrolet Beretta's air bag and seat belts make serious injury unlikely, according to Government tests of seven new vehicles.

title: Campus Life: Brown; Students Produce Video on Turmoil In Lithuania
description: Brown University students have turned a smuggled videotape of the Soviet crackdown on the nationalist movement in Lithuania into a documentary that strongly indicts the Soviet Union's actions in the Baltic republics.

title: Point Is Missed In Rose's Case
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Fashions of The Times/Magazine Pt. 2

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN OUR DEFENSE The Bill of Rights in Action.By Ellen Aldermanand Caroline Kennedy.Morrow, $22.95.

title: Ever Greene
description: THE LAST WORDAnd Other Stories.By Graham Greene.150 pp. New York:Reinhardt Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: Sunday Menu; Pizza, When You're in a Hurry
description: I've tried every possible base for a quick pizza: bialys, pitas, ready-to-bake pizza dough and flour tortillas. When speed is the object, the only one that works and tastes good as well is the flour tortilla. And if you aren't in a hurry, you certainly can use unbaked pizza rounds.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Stamford's Stake in Morgan Stanley Plan
description: OVER the next several months the Morgan Stanley Group, the country's fifth largest securities firm, will decide whether to move from Manhattan to Stamford.

title: Nancy L. Moses Weds K. F. Stern
description: Nancy Lynn Moses and Kenneth F. Stern were married last evening at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mayor Eileen Pilla of Tarrytown officiated. The bride is the daughter of Sally G. Lam of Nanuet, N.Y., and Richard Moses of Brooklyn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Stern of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: From Max Ernst, for Your Eyes Only
description: When the centenary of his birth comes round on April 2 of this year, Max Ernst will be in place as a fixed star in the firmament of our century's art. The author of famous and disconcerting images that can be found in every history of modern art, he ranks very high as a poet in paint and -- no less so -- as a poet in collage.

title: Conflicting Peace Plans Offered in Ethiopia Strife
description: The Ethiopian Government and Eritrean separatist guerrillas offered widely divergent peace proposals on Friday, the second day of a new round of negotiations to end three decades of civil strife.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dover, Vt.;
Prices Drop Near Slopes
description: ALTHOUGH strict environmental regulation has protected most of Vermont from overbuilding and resultant plummeting prices, it has not worked that way in this ski resort 15 miles north of the Massachusetts border.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Seedbed of Symbols The novelist Cesare Pavese argues that mythology is the great storehouse of symbols from which -- intentionally or not -- all writers must draw. This is from "Dialogues With Leuco," translated by William Arrowsmith and D. S. Carne-Ross (Eridanos).

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Janice I. Cohn;
Helping Children Cope With War Fears
description: WITH the news media reporting nearly every event in the Persian Gulf and the possibility of terrorism in the United States, children are bound to be affected, says Dr. Janice I. Cohn, a psychotherapist who helps children and adults deal with death, divorce and separation.

title: Sports People; Financial-Aid Bill
description: He has never scored in his long legislative drive to recognize University of Nebraska football players and other student athletes as state employees entitled to full compensation for their labors beyond the value of the athletic scholarships they receive in exchange for playing on Cornhusker teams.

title: Mutual Funds; The Allure of 'Dull' Little Stocks
description: Their cluttered offices are just a few steps from Central Park, in the heart of Manhattan, but their true address could be Main Street, U.S.A. Listen to how money managers Chuck Royce and Tom Ebright describe their favorite stocks. Mr. Ebright: "Not sexy, not exciting, real Middle America." Mr. Royce: "We don't own anything that ends with 'tech.' "

title: Susan Cuoco to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Cuoco of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Adrienne Cuoco to Timothy Owen McMullan, a son of Mrs. Robert J. McMullan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. McMullan. The wedding is planned for early next year. Ms. Cuoco, 25 years old, is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin. She is a personnel assistant at McCaffrey & McCall Advertising in New York. Mr. McMullan, 29, a Colgate University alumnus, is a financial consultant in the private-client division of Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.

title: Travel Advisory; Carhenge in the Midwest Has a Familiar Look
description: Jim Reinders was impressed on a visit to Stonehenge and felt his native Nebraska deserved a similar landmark, but with an American twist. Carhenge, Mr. Reinders's monumental re-creation of England's most famous druidic site, using gray-painted automobiles in place of rough-hewn boulders, is on U.S. 385 near Alliance, Neb., 260 miles northeast of Denver and about 5,500 miles west of the Salisbury Plain.

title: Freeing the Banks From 1930's Chains
description: Now that the Administration has unveiled its long-awaited plan to free banks from their Depression-era handcuffs, the real work begins: implementing the plan. The complicating factor in this case is timing. The recommendations come hot on the heels of the collapse of the savings and loan industry, a collapse that some wrongly insist is a foreshadowing of what's in store for banking.

title: Talking: Growing Old; Adapting A Home to New Needs
description: HOME, normally a warm and welcoming place, can begin to seem less comfortable and secure to an aging person who is growing frail or is having difficulty in hearing and seeing.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: Recently the rate for up to three passengers for a four-mile ride to the airport in Genoa was $168. We had hoped to end our trip there, but circumstances forced a change, so we ended our visit in Padua and flew home by way of Venice and Milan.

title: Camera
description: I've written several times in the last 12 months about the need for a high-powered telephoto lens for photographing wildlife, whether on safari in Africa or at a local bird sanctuary. Egrets and elephants may be vastly different in terms of size, but they're equally shy when you try to get close to them. The best solution in terms of photography: Magnify their presence with a long telephoto lens.

title: Changing Shapes of Clothes: Little for Men, Lots for Women
description: FROM 1780 to 1920, Fairfield was primarily an agricultural town with a small overlay of wealthy inhabitants. "During this time, fashions changed a great deal from traditional vernacular, not much influenced by high styles," to the clothing of an era "when Fairfielders were very much influenced" by the latest trends, including the "emancipation in women's dress," said Chris Nevins, the curator of the Fairfield Historical Society.

title: The Packaging Industry's New Fancy - Composting Garbage
description: Led by the Procter & Gamble Company, a group of major consumer products manufacturers is promoting the use of composting to reduce the mountains of trash being sent to increasingly scarce and expensive landfills.

title: Bees With Wheels
description: FOLLOWING THE BLOOM Across America With the Migratory Beekeepers. By Douglas Whynott. 214 pp. Harrisburg, Pa.: Stackpole Books. $19.95.

title: Weicker to Appear in Opera
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an opera buff who listens to his tapes as he travels the state, will make his operatic debut next month in a Hartford production of "Madame Butterfly," the Governor's favorite. Mr. Weicker will portray an American naval officer in Act I, in the role of attendant at the wedding of Lieut. Benjamin Franklin Pinkerton and Madame Butterfly. It is not a singing role. Mr. Weicker denied he was embarking on a new career, according to a statement released by Connecticut Opera, the company producing the opera. The production will run March 14-16 at the Bushnell Auditorium in Hartford, and Mr. Weicker will appear on the 15th.

title: Editorial Notebook; Which Boskin Is Right?
description: Economist Boskin versus Economist Boskin. Which one is more persuasive in the the debate about the impact of President Bush's proposal to cut the tax on long-term capital gains? The idea is to reduce from 28 percent to about 20 percent the tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds and other investments.

title: Robert List Weds Mary Ann Minor
description: Mary Ann Minor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walter Minor of Columbus, Ohio, was married in Alexandria, Va., yesterday to Robert Frank List, a former Governor of Nevada. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edna Jacobs Banes at the Old Presbyterian Meeting House.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Scottsdale, Ariz.;
Emphasizing Multifamilies
description: A $150 MILLION master-planned community, the first of about a dozen in the Scottsdale area to emphasize multifamily housing, is now rising about 10 miles northeast of downtown in this city of 130,000 residents.

title: Kay Cardwell and Michael Davis Wed
description: Kay Cardwell and Rabbi Michael A. Davis were married last evening at the Sheraton-Palm Coast Resort in Palm Coast, Fla., by the bridegroom's father, Rabbi Maurice A. Davis and the bridegroom's brother, Rabbi Jay R. Davis.

title: Airlines
description: To the Editor: I was disappointed with Pan Am's policy regarding treatment of free ticket holders when the carrier discontinued service from San Diego.

title: Mary Taylor, Banker, to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Taylor of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Taylor to Christopher Charles Behrens, the son of Herbert H. Behrens of San Jose, Calif., and Barbara A. Behrens of Kailua, Hawaii. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Style Makers;
Anna Miller, Michael Stuno, Eric Kramer and Fred Vicarel, Spoof Troupers
description: On any given Saturday night, no one, not even the director, knows what's going to happen on stage in "Specific Hospital": the ex-Mafioso-psychic-surgeon or the shrink who thinks she's a Russian spy.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: It's time to clean away the twigs and dead vegetation remaining in the garden. Give slow-growing annuals a headstart indoors. Coleus, impatiens, begonia, salvia, lobelia, petunia, vinca and verbena are among those that can be started from seed now. Beset by Burdock

title: Stadium Site For Orlando
description: The Orange County Commission has chosen a 75-acre downtown site for a baseball stadium, if Orlando gets a major league franchise.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A water pipe upstairs burst recently, and before the water could be shut off there was considerable flooding. Water dripped through to the ceiling below, leaving a water ring or stain on the acoustic tiles on that ceiling. Is there any way to eliminate these stains without having to paint the whole ceiling?

title: Hank Aaron Still Wields a Hammer
description: Hank Aaron has a long memory, longer to be sure, at age 57, than any of today's athletes, a sometimes unconcerned and "selfish" group, he says. His memory is long because some of the slights and hardships and pain he experienced as a black man in a racially divided nation are indelible, long because he feels it is important that he doesn't allow himself to forget. Long because he isn't permitted to forget.

title: When Soviet Art Tried to Remake The World
description: Dying when she did, in 1924 at the age of 35 from scarlet fever, the Russian artist Liubov Popova at least never had to face what befell her comrades in the avant-garde. Alexei Gan and Gustav Klucis ended their lives in Stalinist labor camps. Kazimir Malevich completed his days harassed by Soviet officials and in poverty. Popova's life, by contrast, followed a straight, vertical trajectory.

title: 'Wolves' Stalks Oscar and Video
description: Earlier this month "Dances With Wolves" set the pace in Oscar nominations: it received a dozen. The film also leads others nominated in quantity of planned tape releases: two. On Aug. 29 Orion is scheduled to issue the standard three-hour version of the Kevin Costner movie, and around Christmas will come a two-cassette collectors' edition. The latter will contain, for those craving still more Sioux and big sky, 52 minutes of additional footage that wouldn't fit into the original story line, plus a 30-minute documentary on the making of the film.

title: Disturbing Sounds to Unruffle the New Age
description: "Tyranny for You," The new album by Front 242, sounds like business as usual for the Belgian band. It features the customary trademarks: juddering girderlike beats, seismic pulses, bombastic sequencer flourishes and domineering, chanted vocals. These days, Front 242 isn't so fond of the samples that used to punctuate its techno-mantras (snatches of political oratory, televangelist preaching or trash-movie dialogue). But their aura is still overbearing and ominous.

title: Dollar Climbs On Peace Hopes
April Wedding for Miss Grill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Felix Zelik Grill of Coconut Creek, Fla., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Suzanne Grill and Dr. Andrew Garber, the son of Dr. Ella Garber and Dr. Michael Garber of New York. Miss Grill is a registered nurse at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. Her fiance is an attending perinatologist at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J., and an attending physician in obstetrics and gynecology at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City. His mother is an obstetrician and his father is an internist, both in New York.

title: The World; Sense of Pride Outweighs Fears of War
description: IT remains unclear what the Persian Gulf war will do to the political geography of the Middle East, but so far it has transformed the psyche of the United States.

title: Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities
description: Seldom has the publication of a historical monograph on a subject ordinarily of interest only to a few specialists -- the treatment of prisoners of war -- received so much attention or excited so much anger as James Bacque's "Other Losses." Published in 1989 in Canada, it was the subject of a cover story in the popular Canadian magazine Saturday Night, of a British Broadcasting Corporation documentary, of two German television documentaries and of a coming Canadian Broadcasting Corporation documentary. (The Canadian book, I should say immediately, carries a jacket blurb from me that was taken out of context and used without permission.) It has been discussed on American television, in Time magazine and in many other news media outlets. In its German edition, it was a runaway best seller. The British edition elicited major reviews in The Times Literary Supplement and elsewhere. Prima Publishing of California intends to publish the book in May, which could fan the flames in the United States.

title: See a Penny, Pick It Up . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank N. Bowers, Shipping Executive, 95
description: Frank N. Bowers, president of the International Freighting Corporation for 18 years before the shipping line discontinued operations in 1957, died on Thursday at his home in Juno Beach, Fla. He was 95 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J., before he retired to Tequesta, Fla., in the 1960's.

title: Campus Life: Iowa; Crossing Disciplines To Study Environment
description: To cope with the problem of global warming, the University of Iowa has formed an interdisciplinary Center for Global and Regional Environmental Research, encompassing 15 of its academic departments.

title: Pro Basketball; Tucker Stuns Bullets in Last Second
description: Perhaps it took more turmoil to finally awaken the Knicks.

title: The Nation; Some Corporations Plead for the Firm Hand of Uncle Sam
description: THE pace of regulatory activity in Washington slowed sharply after President Ronald Reagan promised to get big government off the back of industry in the 1980's. Budgets were cut and top officials emphasized a free market approach. But now, faced with a patchwork of conflicting regulations at the state level, a broad coalition of companies that produce and sell consumer products is deciding that maybe uniform Federal regulations wouldn't be such a bad thing after all. In some cases, companies are actually going to Washington and asking for a return to the good old days of broader Federal control.

title: The World; The I.R.A. Reminds Britons of the War At Their Back Door
description: SINCE the outbreak of fighting in the Persian Gulf, Britain's domestic security forces have gone on a war footing. Soldiers patrol airports, fresh signs in subway stations warn of the threat of bombs, and scores of Iraqi immigrants await deportation inside British prisons, where they have been detained as possible agents of terrorism.

title: Brenda Steinfeld Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Steinfeld of Monsey, N.Y., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Brenda Phyllis Steinfeld, and Marc Paul Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rosenberg of Melville, L.I. Miss Steinfeld, 25 years old, is an associate at the Hackensack, N.J., law firm of Kaps & Barto. Her father is a physician in Suffern, N.Y. Her fiance, 24, is the vice president of the Wilmington Abstract Company, a Forest Hills, Queens, title-research concern founded by his father, who is also the president.

title:
THEATER;
Shakespeare's Past Is Present
description: In 1595, as a member of a newly formed company of actors, the Lord Chamberlain's Men, William Shakespeare began a theatrically sophisticated tetralogy on events leading up to the civil conflict, the Wars of the Roses, that had ended about 100 years earlier. Together, "Richard II," "Henry IV, Parts 1 and 2" and "Henry V" comprise an epic that some have compared to "The Iliad." Like most epics, the plays chronicle a society in transition -- England's emergence from a feudal state into a Renaissance nation. But when the two parts of "Henry IV" open on Wednesday at the Public Theater under the direction of JoAnne Akalaitis, with a score by Philip Glass, more than history will be on stage. Shakespeare's passionate characters are moving psychologically from a world of certainty to the modern one of doubt and transience.

title: Thai Military Overthrows Government
description: Military chiefs toppled Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan's elected Government today, apparently without firing a shot. The coup leaders, who were reportedly angered by the appointment of a rival to a top Government post, accused the Government of corruption and protecting enemies of the monarchy.

title: 'Chorus Line' Opens A Theater
description: ISN'T it remarkable how "A Chorus Line" keeps on living up to its signature lyric: "One Singular Sensation." Here is a seamless fusion of the components of a musical (spoken, sung and danced) and the basic elements of theater (scenery, lighting and audience connection). When the show is performed at full strength, all that is achieved with nonstop momentum. Climax after climax induces a visceral response that defines the essence of musical theater.

title: Debate in Philadelphia on Forced Vaccinations
description: Even as it appears to be subsiding, the measles epidemic that has swept through two church congregations is confronting Philadelphia health officials with a painful ethical choice: whether to ask the courts to compel children to be vaccinated over the religious objections of their parents.

title: The Region; Putting Cops On the Beat: Easier Theory Than Practice
description: IN olden times, it was the hue and cry -- a citizen's shout obligating all within earshot to follow in pursuit of a felon. Only later did police enter the picture, professionals paid to maintain order by their mere presence and, less often, to collar miscreants.

title: Nylon Was for Parachutes, Not Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: The O'Keeffe Canon
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT A BRIDE!
description: A wedding is not a prom, a masquerade ball or a burlesque show ("The Wedding," Jan. 27). It is a celebration of two people making a serious commitment, and many times this takes place in a house of worship. The bride's choice of dress may be simple or elaborate, but it should be in good taste and should command respect for her and the wedding.

title: Bridget Foley to Wed William Queally
description: Mr. and Mrs. Brian F. Foley of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bridget Ann Foley, to William Doyle Queally, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Queally of Jupiter Hills, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: Megan Gerber and William R. Bachman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Gerber of Rye, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Megan Rose Gerber and William R. Bachman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Bachman of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: New Jersey Klan Rally Fizzles As Only 2 Members Appear
description: A rally planned by a faction of the Ku Klux Klan fizzled today when just two Klansmen showed up.

title: Meredith Miller to Wed C. A. Rutter 3d in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Halyburton Miller of Birmingham, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Austin Miller, to Carroll Arthur Rutter 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutter Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: A Prince Of a Deal For Citicorp
description: People used to denounce banks for charging usurious interest rates. Now Citicorp, desperate for capital, is paying such rates.

title: We've Won -- Why More War?
description: Although his deadline has passed without an adequate Iraqi response, and even as he authorizes a large-scale ground campaign, President Bush should understand that America has already won the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a crisis of confidence in Germany over the Persian Gulf war misidentified a company that reportedly headed a consortium that built an Iraqi plant that developed poison gas and biological weapons. It was Thyssen Rheinstahl Technik G.m.b.H.

title: Travel Advisory; Northern Lights At Peak in '91, Scientists Say
description: This will be the finest year in centuries in which to view the celestial pyrotechnics of the aurora borealis, or northern lights, according to scientists at the University of Alaska Geophysical Institute.

title: Plan for Park at Little Cost to Taxpayers Draws Criticism
description: MAYOR Louis J. Stellato thought he had a good idea for Lyndhurst: take an undeveloped 35-acre expanse of mud and meadowgrass on the outskirts of town and turn it into a recreational oasis complete with two baseball fields, a running track and a playground designed to be accessible to the disabled.

title: Arab-Americans Share Sentiments on Gulf War
description: THE voices rose and fell in fervent discussion at a recent meeting of the Arab-American Foundation here. Several members fluent in English were willing, cautiously, to share their thoughts at a time when the world's attention was riveted on their native countries.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Centereach 91,500 202 Mark Tree Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33- year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 75- by 134-foot property; taxes $2,200. Central Islip 97,500 284 Feller Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old town-house condominium; dining room, pool; monthly common charges $149, taxes $2,500. Lake Ronkonkoma 151,500 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 50-year-old, lakefront Cape Cod; basement, inground pool, 0.25 acre; taxes $3,000. Medford 128,000 152 Bedford Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 13-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,100. North Patchogue 124,000 62 Lexington Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $3,700. Mastic 118,00 25 Forrestall Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,200. OTHER AREAS East Brunswick, N.J. 155,000 17 Donald Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, fireplace, fenced yard; taxes $3,029. Stratford, Conn. 149,000 35 Fallon Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 11-year-old ranch; alarm system, oversized deck, walk to train; taxes $2,100. Somers, N.Y. 176,250 Mahopac Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old ranch; fireplace, 2-car detached garage, patio, 1 acre; taxes $2,662.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A water pipe upstairs burst recently, and before the water could be shut off there was considerable flooding. Water dripped through to the ceiling below, leaving a water ring or stain on the acoustic tiles on that ceiling. Is there any way to eliminate these stains without having to paint the whole ceiling?

title: About Cars; For Pontiac Buffs, a New Source
description: The owners of older Pontiacs can consider themselves luckier than most.

title: California's Flowering Pinnacles
description: ON a map of the western United States the Pinnacles National Monument -- a volcanic remnant of spires, crags, caves and colorful spring wildflowers -- is an insignificant speck 135 miles south of San Francisco.

title: Getting Old in 'Sparky and Fitz'
description: IN "Sparky and the Fitz," this week's play about aging, he (Sparky) is a retired ambulance driver and she (Fitz), who worked at K-Mart for 25 years, is bored.

title: Sports People; Spinks vs. Spinks
description: If confidence counts, the 18-year-old Golden Glove novice should have a bright future in the ring. When he was decisively beaten in his very first boxing lesson at the age of 16, the youngster was hardly intimidated by his overpowering instructor.

title: Prince Was A Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Street; Pea Jackets Re-Enter The Fashion Arena
description: Sometimes fashion and world events cross paths. Lately, military jackets have been showing up on Fifth Avenue. Some are authentic Army-Navy surplus; others are designer adaptations that reproportion original military styles and are cut to flatter a woman's body. One of the most popular is the navy pea jacket in both fingertip length, worn with sailor pants, and an abbreviated hip-length style, worn with a skirt. There are also variations on the Marine and Army dress jackets with new velvet epaulets or authentic-looking stripes and elaborate, costume-jewelry medals. There are even gold-embroidered jackets that suggest a Gilbert and Sullivan Very, Very Major General. One woman dressed her puppy in a sailor's middy coat with a familiar square collar and gold buttons down the front.

title: Pro Hockey; Islanders Incur Their Fans' Ire
description: An unhappy superstar, ungrateful fans and an imbalanced first period were the key ingredients in the Islanders' 5-3 loss to the Flyers tonight at Nassau Coliseum

title: Out of the Shadows, Briefly, Papa Haydn
description: It is good to see, in a Mozart year, that Haydn has not been totally eclipsed. On Saturday evening, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will present the first of six concerts over an eight-day period concentrating on his chamber and solo keyboard works, with Andras Schiff as artistic director and piano soloist, and featuring the Takacs String Quartet.

title: Campus Life: Pomona; Disabled Student Leads Crusade For Accessibility
description: Edward Uhl-Tessier is one of only two students at Pomona College who navigate the campus in a wheelchair. The obstacles have been many, leading Mr. Uhl-Tessier, a senior in sociology from Claremont, to crusade for the rights of disabled students at the 104-year-old liberal arts college.

title: The O'Keeffe Canon
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Continental Fare in a Maharajah's Palace
description: IMAGINE a Hollywood set designer's vision of a maharajah's palace -- room dividers shaped like minarets, massive candelabrums studded with faux gemstones, a mural of the casino's Indian namesake, waiters dressed up in gilt-trimmed tunics -- and that is Scheherazade. The fanciest restaurant at the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort is one part luxury and two parts kitsch.

title: A Stepson of the Republic
description: MY FRANCE Politics, Culture, Myth. By Eugen Weber. 412 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: Technology; Toward the Voice-Literate Computer
description: Kazuhiko Sumiya spoke softly but clearly into a telephone handset. "Teikiatugaari," he said, looking at the Sun Microsystems workstation perched on a nearby desk. In seconds, the Japanese phrase appeared on the screen in phonetic English, followed by several rows of Japanese kanji characters. "Taikio," Mr. Sumiya added. Again, the Japanese characters appeared on the screen. The two phrases taken together mean, "There is a low pressure system that makes the atmosphere unstable." The voice recognition system had correctly identified the spoken Japanese on the first try, but also offered several choices in case it had misunderstood some words.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are very few certainties in the world but one of them, without question, is that it is virtually impossible for even the immoderately well off to send a check to all the benefits they are invited to attend.

title: Miss Walden Wed To Walker Bagley
description: Hallie Gay Walden, the daughter of Margaret Elliott Walden of Lexington, Ky., and Benjamin Parrish Walden Sr. of Del Mar, Calif., was married yesterday to Smith Walker Bagley Jr., the son of Sandra Peabody Robinson of Farmington, Conn., and Mr. Bagley of Washington. The Rev. Michael L. Ward, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the Pisgah Church in Versailles, Ky.

title:
ART;
Simple Forms Hold Complex Messages From 17th-Century China
description: IN his book "The Making of Modern China," Jonathan Spence cites the painter Bada Shanren (1626-1705). In his account of revolutionary events that took place in the 17th-century, when the Ming Dynasty was overthrown by the Manchus who became the Qing Dynasty, he writes that Bada Shanren -- who gave himself that name, which means One Who Dwells in the Eight Great Mountains -- defied the Qing with his silence. "After writing the Chinese character for 'dumb' upon his door, he refused to speak any more, though he would still laugh or weep extravagantly when drunk or caught in creative fever," Mr. Spence says.

title: Baseball; Yanks Wait for a Catcher to Emerge
description: Not even Stump Merrill, the man who will eventually be asked to provide the appropriate answers, is certain how to unravel this one. It is like a mystery novel in the first few pages, the characters having been introduced and the primary plot explained.

title: When an Airline Takes Flight, What Then?
description: ELISE GROSSMAN, a New York student, remembers all too well the inglorious demise of Eastern Airlines last month. She found herself stranded in West Palm Beach, Fla., her Eastern ticket worthless. "I ended up spending an extra $350 to get home," she said. "I was furious."

title: Travel Advisory; Hotel Discounts
description: The Hyatt hotel group has cut 25 percent off regular room rates for guests aged 62 and over at its 108 properties in North America and the Caribbean. The discounts are in response to the growing number of senior travelers, a Hyatt official said. He noted that the rate was subject to availability and had to be requested when guests make reservations.

title: Curator Keeps Military History Alive
description: ON a wall in Building 6501 at Fort Dix is Pvt. Samuel Bert's pay book, which shows he was paid $33 in April 1918 before he went to France to fight in World War I.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Philip M. Murphy's account of New Year's Eve in Moscow (Travel, Dec. 30) is at odds with the frenzied joyousness my wife and I observed in the same place at the same time.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Life column on Feb. 3 about a sale at Guernsey's Auction House misidentified the current owner of a wine bottle once owned by Thomas Jefferson. It is Lloyd's of London; after the bottle was broken, the insurer took it over from the New York wine merchant William Sokolin.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Need Major Surgery, by Somebody Else
description: First, do no harm. This Latin admonition, primum non nocere, is believed to be from the writings of Hippocrates, although not actually part of the Hippocratic Oath that all doctors take.

title: Perspectives: Manufacturing Zones; Cracking the Straitjacket on Expansions
description: THIS year will be a good one for turtles, says Marc Beige. His family-owned business, Rubie's Costume Company, makes costumes of all sorts, not to mention masks, wigs, carnival heads and other holiday paraphernalia. The popularity of teen-age Ninja mutant turtles suggests that turtle outfits will be a big item for Halloween.

title: Notebook; The Newest Import Arriving From Japan: American Players
description: No one can hope to achieve the comeback Cecil Fielder made upon his return last year, but players continue to come back to the United States from Japan in the latest East-West trend. Floyd Bannister, Rich (Goose) Gossage and Matt Keough are seeking re-entry to the major leagues this spring after pitching in Japan. In Keough's case, he is back after a four-year career there.

title: Headliners; Breaking Away
description: Slovenia, the most prosperous of the six shakily allied republics that make up Yugoslavia, last week threatened to take the money and run. The Slovenian Parliament approved legislation allowing it to take over banking, defense and other functions now controlled by the central Government in Belgrade. Slovenia, whose 2 million people make up 8.5 percent of Yugoslavia's population but generate about 20 percent of its cash earnings from abroad, has grumbled ever more loudly about going it alone in the decade since Yugoslavia's seams began to show in the aftermath of Tito's death. Officials cited studies showing they would do well as an independent nation and said that, in any case, the country was already falling apart. Said Milan Kucan, the head of Slovenia's collective presidency, "Whenever foreign partners try to convince me that I should stay within Yugoslavia, I offer them the opportunity to trade places with us."

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: I went to Florence three years go to see the Masaccio fresco in the Brancacci Chapel, but it was closed because the frescos were being restored.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; Pentagon Plans to Stop Giving Information to Avoid Aiding Iraq
description: President Bush announced tonight that after giving President Saddam Hussein "one last chance" to get out of Kuwait, he directed the commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf to begin ground operations and drive the Iraqi Army from Kuwait.

title: Cash Cards
description: To the Editor: Because I was in Europe I did not see the Nov. 11 letter regarding problems with Cirrus cash machines abroad. A more recent letter (Travel, Dec. 23) does not mention yet another problem with the system.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reactions/Iran; U.S. Aims in Gulf Are Questioned
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that the United States seemed to be pursuing goals in the Middle East that went beyond Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Melissa Gross Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gross of Blauvelt, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Tami Gross to Kenneth Brian Newman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Newman of Great Neck Estates, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Gross, 24, is a psychologist at the Thiells Elementary School in Haverstraw, N.Y. She graduated magna cum laude from the State University of New York at Albany, where she also received a master's degree in educational psychology and statistics and a certificate of advanced study in school psychology. Her fiance, 23, a cum laude graduate of Union College, is a student at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Pentagon Statement; Cheney's Remarks After Start of Ground War
description: Following are excerpts from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's remarks tonight on the ground war in the Persian Gulf:

title: Suzanne Noga Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Noga of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the May wedding plans for their daughter, Suzanne Marie Noga, and Edwin D. Miska, the son of Karin Miska of Fairfield and the late Laimons Miska. Ms. Noga, 29 years old, is a performance measurement analyst at Neuberger & Berman, a New York investment management firm. She graduated from Wheaton College. Mr. Miska, 28, is a securities analyst with Lieber & Company, investment advisers in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Unable to Crack the Code
description: TO KNOW A WOMAN By Amos Oz. Translated by Nicholas de Lange. 262 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. Resolutions; Iraq's Shift in Position: Not Enough for the U.S.
description: Since Feb. 16, Iraq has shifted from a repudiation of all Security Council resolutions calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait to acceptance of Resolution 660, demanding its unconditional withdrawal.

title: Pianists Leave Ideological Warfare to Composers
description: There may still be feelings of hostility between composers in the Minimalist and atonal camps, but performers -- including some who had heretofore taken sides -- are buying out of the conflict.

title: Your Own Account; Rules for the Reunited Family
description: If your grown children are moving back home to get through some rough financial times, experts say you should:

title: Stop-and-Go Tour
description: To the Editor: While in Puerto Plata, the Dominican Republic, we signed up for a tour to Santo Domingo. We departed at 7:30 A.M., a half-hour late because, we were told, the guide had to wait to be given money for the trip. When we arrived in Santo Domingo, we stopped at a bank for another group to change money.

title: Ms. Maycock to Wed Stuart Goldberg
description: Virginia Anne Maycock and Stuart Mitchell Goldberg have announced June wedding plans. Ms. Maycock is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John C. Maycock of McLean, Va. Mr. Goldberg is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Goldberg of New York.

title: Headliners; Going Far?
description: With the aid of a court-ordered map, Gloria Molina appears to be on her way to national political prominence. With her victory in a runoff election last week, Ms. Molina became the first Hispanic member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors, one of the most powerful local government units in the country. Hispanic residents account for about one-third of the county's 8.8 million people, and a Federal judge ruled last summer that the board had drawn districts that intentionally diluted the power of Hispanic voters. The court ordered that the map be redrawn to include a district with a Hispanic majority. Ms. Molina, who will leave the Los Angeles City Council to join the county board, played down the national significance of her victory. Though some analysts say she may become the most prominent Hispanic political figure in the nation, Ms. Molina says that for now at least, her politics is local. "Very frankly, she said, "my first job is to meet the needs of the residents of the First District."

title: Review/Dance; Variations in Two City Ballet Performances
description: Dancing a ballet involves more than performing its steps. Those steps must be shaped to give the work its own choreographic personality. Some dancers shaped steps more effectively than others at two performances by the New York City Ballet last Sunday at the New York State Theater.

title:
Travel Advisory;
New Hampshire Ski Touring
description: Cross-country skiers in the Mount Washington Valley in New Hampshire need not worry about rest stops, refreshments or a place to sleep while they explore a new 37-mile trail system. Ten businesses, including several inns, have joined to provide support along the network between North Conway and Intervale. Along with 49 landowners permitting ski trails to cross their properties, the businesses are operating as the Mount Washington Valley Ski Touring Association.

title: Miss Gillan Wed To R. F. Sharpe Jr.
description: Rebecca Ann Gillan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Gillan of Kettering, Ohio, was married yesterday in Westport, Conn., to Robert Francis Sharpe Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sharpe of Hilton Head, S.C. The Rev. Dorothy P. Greet performed the ceremony at the Saugatuck Congregational Church.

title: Splendid Little War
description: SOMETHING TO DIE FOR By James Webb. 333 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: 'Finding a Mate': Women Respond
description: This is in response to Irving Levine's lament "Finding a Mate" [ Feb. 3 ] .

title:
Food;
The Golden Bough
description: I was 12 when someone told me that tarantulas sometimes stowed away in shipments of bananas. I increased my consumption then, assiduously looking for hairy legs in each new bunch. My father, unable to resist a bargain in anything, brought home sacks of discounted, fully ripened bananas, though he himself liked to eat ones that were still bright green. Scarcely had the golden horde arrived, of course, than it began to turn mahogany, softening and fermenting. My mother took comfort in the sweet musk that filled the air, knowing that it masked the smells of the things that I brought home.

title: Mandatory Sentencing For Drugs Questioned
description: DESPITE recommendations from a gubernatorial commission and a judicial task force strongly urging reconsideration of mandatory drug sentences as a way of alleviating prison overcrowding, legislators, facing re-election in the fall, appear unlikely to address the mandatory sentencing issue.

title: The Scholar Who Misread History
description: SIGNS OF THE TIMES Deconstruction and theFall of Paul de Man.By David Lehman.318 pp. New York:Poseidon Press. $21.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A water pipe upstairs burst recently, and before the water could be shut off there was considerable flooding. Water dripped through to the ceiling below, leaving a water ring or stain on the acoustic tiles on that ceiling. Is there any way to eliminate these stains without having to paint the whole ceiling?

title: Intrigue Is Always in Style for Lustbader
description: A SECRET plot that could result in the upheaval of a country, if not the entire world order. Fast-paced action that has a reader's eyes rushing from page to page. An American who studied in Japan summoning her wa, or spiritual resources, in a moment of crisis. Exotic settings that include the Orient, where nothing is as it seems. And the certainty that his tale of international intrigue will show up on best-seller lists.

title: Lanford Wilson's 'Burn This' in Westport
description: AS soon as a writer puts his most private feelings on paper, he must destroy the evidence at once. That would be the self-preserving thing to do. Such an intriguing reflection reportedly prompted Lanford Wilson to fashion the play "Burn This." At least it helps to explain the title.

title: Miami's Caribbean Enclaves
description: LIKE most ethnic enclaves of big cities elsewhere, Miami's Little Havana and Little Haiti are classic juxta positions of immigrant optimism and inner-city decay. Simmering with promise for a paradise found, they are America's modern melting pot, the new Ellis Island. In both the food is saturated with spices, the music hip-grinding good and the people resourceful and proud. For the tourist, a foray into these neighborhoods offers an intimate and eye-opening encounter with cultures determined to maintain the traditions of their homelands.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reactions; U.S. Backed by Allies, Doubted in Iran
description: As the deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait passed today, French, British, Italian German and Japanese leaders received last-minute telephone calls from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev urging them to give new consideration to the Soviet plan to end the Persian Gulf war.

title: For Chilly Winds That Come and Go
description: With weather that not only shifts from day to day but varies according to the side of the street, many men would welcome the layering a windbreaker provides.

title: CRACKING THE WHIP
description: It was shocking to learn that the Bush Administration had been headed inexorably toward war from the moment that Iraq invaded Kuwait ("Cracking the Whip," by Michael R. Gordon, Jan. 27). Defense Secretary Dick Cheney lobbied "week after week" for the view that "only military force . . . could insure that the Iraqi troops would leave Kuwait," even as experienced military experts and officers, including General Schwarzkopf, "argued that sanctions be given more time."

title: Rebecca Sheridan to Wed T. A. Malone
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Sheridan of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Sheridan to Thomas Alfred Malone, the son of Mrs. James D. Malone of Sussex, New Brunswick, and the late Mr. Malone. A July wedding is planned.

title: An Elegist's New England, a Buddhist's Dante
description: OLD AND NEW POEMS By Donald Hall. 244 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $12.95. THE WORLD OF THE TEN THOUSAND THINGS Poems 1980-1990. By Charles Wright. 232 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Data Update
LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARDI GRAS

title: Corrections
description: Pictures of two engaged couples last Sunday were reversed. Matthew Toll and Ann Tweedy were at the left. Randall Havas and Melissa Weissberg were at the right.

title: The Goat Smugglers Were Cordial
description: MOTORING WITH MOHAMMED Journeys to Yemen and the Red Sea. By Eric Hansen. 240 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: The trivia quiz in this column last week omitted a picture credit. The silhouette of a 1949 Buick Roadmaster was part of a larger photograph taken by Jay Hirsch and published by Macmillan in Mr. Hirsch's book "Great American Dream Machines."

title: The World; Fujimori In the Time Of Cholera
description: WHEN Alberto Fujimori took control of the Peruvian Government last July, many remarked that seldom had a new President inherited a nation in such disarray. Peru was suffering from 24 consecutive months of hyperinflation. Eighty percent of its work force was either underemployed or unemployed. Economic output had fallen 20 percent over the course of two years. One-third of the country was malnourished. The Shining Path guerrilla organization was causing havoc in the highlands. And more than 40 leaders of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, the second largest terrorist group, had just escaped from Lima's top security prison.

title: Desert Fog; The Uncertain Time Beyond High Noon
description: FOR one brief moment, as the clock struck noon yesterday, a certain clarity enveloped the Persian Gulf crisis. The choices for Saddam Hussein were crystal clear: humiliating surrender or military defeat. America and its allies were convinced their moral case was clear: good versus evil. And the final outcome, the coalition was promised, would also be clear: the total liberation of Kuwait, one way or another.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Mid-February auto sales. * European Community finance ministers meet in Brussels. TUESDAY: Durable goods orders for January. * Balance of payments for the fourth quarter. * Conference Board's consumer confidence index for February. WEDNESDAY: Fourth-quarter gross national product. * Comecon summit in Budapest, through Thursday, to formally disband the organization. * Pilots vote on new contract with American Airlines. THURSDAY: Personal income and spending for January. * Deadline for Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores to file bankruptcy reorganization plans. FRIDAY: Leading economic indicators and construction spending for January.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; ALLIED FORCES STORM IRAQ AND KUWAIT AFTER HUSSEIN IGNORES U.S. DEADLINE; BUSH SEES A SWIFT, DECISIVE VICTORY
description: A vast, multi-pronged land attack against Iraqi forces began two hours before dawn today after President Bush's deadline for the start of an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait slipped by with no sign in word or deed that President Saddam Hussein would comply.

title: Lincoln's Masterpiece
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost Among Eligibility's Fine Lines
description: Heather Gottlieb began competing in tennis when she was 11 years old, and developed into a sectionally ranked player with a game powered by her 5-foot-7-inch frame and her drive to become a successful professional. Now, a month past her 18th birthday, she is a disappointed freshman at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas who is looking beyond the sport for a career.

title: Charity Worker Beaten to Death
description: The founder of a charitable group that gives food and clothing to needy people throughout central New Jersey has been discovered beaten to death in her car trunk, the authorities said today.

title: Style Makers; Debra Griboff, Stage-Set Researcher
description: The smoke-filled speak-easies of the 1920's are never too remote for Debra Griboff. Neither are the rattling trains of the 1940's, the ones that carried troops all over Europe.

title: Woody and Mia: A New York Story
description: "It's no accomplishment to have or raise kids," Woody Allen often used to say. "Any fool can do it."

title: On Language; Degrading Attrition
description: "TOO BITTER IS THY jest," says the King of Navarre in Shakespeare's "Love's Labor's Lost." "Are we betrayed thus to thy over-view ?"

title: South Dakota Panel Rejects Abortion Bill
