description: A bill to ban most abortions was rejected Friday, 6 to 1, by the State Senate Judiciary Committee, but the sponsor said he expected the full Senate to take up the measure anyway.

title: Medical Second-Guessing -- in Advance
description: Helen Blumen, medical director of Value Health Sciences Inc., scans a patient record and shakes her head in amazement. A gynecologist in Colorado has proposed a hysterectomy for a 25-year-old woman with pelvic pain. The doctor presumes endometriosis, in which endometrial tissue grows abnormally outside the uterus, but did not confirm the diagnosis with a biopsy. And there is no mention of treatment alternatives, like medication or a procedure that would save the uterus.

title: Travel Advisory; Hawaii Curbs Some Boating
description: Under a law designed to protect the humpback whale, Hawaii is banning jet skis, para-sailing and other high-speed operations west and south of Maui until May 15.

title: Calverton: Final Resting Place for Gulf War Dead
description: SINCE interments began in September 1978, more than 85,000 veterans, their spouses and, in some cases, their children have been buried at the Calverton National Cemetery in the Town of Riverhead.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Moscow; Moscow Hopes Iraqis Can Find 'Guts' to Retreat
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's spokesman said Saturday night that Iraq had "lost the chance" to take advantage of Moscow's mediating effort, but he said the Soviet Union still hoped that President Saddam Hussein would "have the guts" to end the war by withdrawing promptly from Kuwait.

title: Landmarking
description: To the Editor:

title: Release of Bakker Before Sentencing Is Fought
description: Federal prosecutors oppose Jim Bakker's release from prison before the television evangelist receives a new sentence for defrauding followers who bought partnerships in a Christian theme park.

title: Headliners; Other People's Words: Fair Use or Fair Game?
description: UNTIL recently writers felt safe in assuming that quoting up to 200 words of another's prose was protected under the doctrine of "fair use." Then, in the late 1980's, two rulings by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan all but prohibited authors from quoting letters, diaries and other unpublished material without permission. The court said that if a biographer "copies more than minimal amounts" of letters or diaries, "he deserves to be enjoined."

title:
FOCUS;
In Philadelphia, Two Projects Create Artists' Studios
description: Later this year, artists are expected to move into an unusual cooperative here: a 72-year-old warehouse in the Germantown section divided into 16 no-frills residential studios with high ceilings. Costs for the artists, most with annual incomes below $22,000, are being subsidized by a foundation.

title: Managing; Coping With Cultural Polyglots
description: Most anthropologists study exotic cultures in faraway places. Lucy Suchman, an anthropologist working for the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center, studies workers at her local airport.

title: Campus Life: N.Y.U.; Sleep-to-the-Beat Flops in a Dorm Over a Nightclub
description: A newly opened no-alcohol night club, the Ultra Violet Dance Club, has already become a mixed blessing for New York University. Students who were looking for such a club on campus say they are delighted, while students living in Goddard Residence Hall, which houses the Ultra Violet, say they are deafened.

title: New for the Joffrey: Five Works, Four Styles
description: As the Joffrey Ballet marks its 35th anniversary, the company's tradition of presenting work by choreographers new to most ballet audiences will be more than upheld.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Servicewomen; At Combat's Doorstep, She Confronts Peril and Male Doubt
description: Her superiors refused to describe her assignment, but they will confirm that Sgt. Theresa Lynn Treloar has a dangerous job, and that she is the United States Army woman closest to the front lines in the war with Iraq.

title: Enamels That Glow Like Stained Glass
description: COLOR attracts enamelists to their craft: rich, intense colors with the luminosity of stained glass. Marilyn Druin, a member of the Enamel Guild of New Jersey, sometimes applies 40 coats of cobalt blue or emerald enamels to attain the ocean-deep hues of her silver jewelry and small vessels.

title: A Resolute Gooden Looks Beyond Mets
description: The unthinkable had been thought about for 24 hours, the once unimaginable had been envisioned. The result was a bad night of sleep for Dwight Gooden and an even worse prognosis for the Mets.

title: Poetic License With Knicks Past
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kathryn Jane Fasano Wed to Lyle Foster
description: Kathryn Jane Fasano, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fasano of Alfred Station, N.Y., and Randall Lyle Foster, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Malcolm L. Foster of New York, were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Parish in Darien, Conn. by the Rev. Douglass E. Ray, an Episcopal priest.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Helen Ward;
Making Adequate Child Care Accessible
description: CHILD CARE has become a priority for many families. As deputy director of the Connecticut Association for Human Services in Hartford, Helen Ward said she has heard numerous stories about the problems of finding and affording child care.

title: Nancy E. Pick, Writer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Frederic Pick of Northfield, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Elizabeth Pick to Lawrence Robert Douglas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Douglas of Great Neck, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: I went to Florence three years go to see the Masaccio fresco in the Brancacci Chapel, but it was closed because the frescos were being restored.

title: Cindy Tannenbaum Weds
description: Cindy Beth Tannenbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tannenbaum of North Woodmere, L.I., was married there last evening to Daniel Ross Wotman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wotman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel. Mrs. Wotman, 27, is a graduate of New York University. Mr. Wotman, 33, is a graduate of the University of Colorado and received a J.D. from Brooklyn Law School. He is in private law practice in New York.

title: Conserving Land in a Natural State Can't Simply Be Left to Nature
description: THE Great Meadows Marsh, one of the largest unprotected tidal marshes in Connecticut, straddles the Stratford-Bridgeport line, just off Long Island Sound. The marsh is a critical feeding and nesting ground for waterfowl and shore birds, including piping plover and least tern, both listed as threatened under Federal law. Black ducks, mallards and green- and blue-wing teal nest there, and peregrine falcons stop by during their autumn and spring migrations.

title: Jody Kaplan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Kaplan of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Jody Beth Kaplan, and David James Thelander, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Burton L. Thelander of Delmar, N.Y. Ms. Kaplan, 25 years old, graduated from the University of Vermont and is studying for a master's degree in human-resource management at Marymount University in Arlington, Va. Mr. Thelander, 35, graduated from the State University of New York at Oswego and the Vermont Law School. He is a lawyer in the corporation finance division at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Weicker's Budget Demands Austerity
description: IN the instant statewide debate that erupted following Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s budget address on Feb. 13, all eyes were on his proposal for an income tax and the other measures to overhaul Connecticut's tax system. But some of the Governor's suggestions for changes in spending could have an even greater impact on state residents.

title: Baseball; Righetti Relishes Escape
description: Dave Righetti, operating in the present, pulled on strange-looking uniform pants, white with weird black and orange stripes. Dealing with the past, however, he used a word that also was alien to the team of that past. The word was "embarrassment."

title:
ART;
Finding the Passionate Self
description: THE observable world, with its stimuli of form, light and color, provides the raw material for Stan Brodsky's paintings. But his aim is not to reproduce appearances.

title: A June Wedding For Margot Adam
description: Mrs. Peter John Canaday Adam of New Canaan, Conn., and Yaounde, Cameroon, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margot Adam, to Dr. Samuel Husbands Langstaff 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Langstaff Jr. of Littleton, Colo. A June wedding is planned.

title: In Chile, a Rural Hacienda, Family Style
description: ON awakening in an antique bed and gazing up at what must be 20-foot-high ceilings in Hacienda los Lingues, I told myself that the vast adobe house and its surrounding 10,000 acres proved that there had been a time when foreign correspondents were properly appreciated. The hacienda, now a guesthouse and working farm 75 miles south of Santiago, was the gift of Carlos V of Spain to a man who chronicled the advance of the conquistadors through the southern reaches of the New World in the first half of the 16th century.

title: As in Vietnam, Troops Will Bring Truth Home; Political Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.S. Statements; Declarations by White House As the Noon Deadline Passes
description: Following are the texts of statements issued today shortly after the noon deadline passed by President Bush and by the White House through its spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater: BUSH STATEMENT

title: The Rights of Slaves and Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: 'New Scars, New Stories, No Excuses'
description: SUBTRACTION By Mary Robison. 216 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Landmarking
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Events
description: Dinner at Sea

title: Ruth Pinkham, Lawyer, Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Janet Reeh Pinkham of Pittsfield, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Ruth Anne Pinkham to Douglas Edward Haring, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Haring of Waubun, Minn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Reporters Or Cheerleaders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street; The Hidden Value of Bond Insurance
description: The companies that sell municipal bond insurance have traditionally emphasized how they protect investors by covering any missed interest or principal payments if an issuer defaults. These days, with the muni market awash in bad news, the insurers are quietly pointing to a less obvious benefit: price protection.

title: Colombian Seeks Anti-Drug Pacts on U.S. Trip
description: During his visit to the United States next week, President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo is expected to sign several agreements to advance both anti-drug and economic cooperation between his Government and the United States, Colombian officials say.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on Jan. 27 with the Your Own Account column misidentified one top ranking insurance company selling annuity contracts. It is Continental Assurance, not Connecticut Assurance.

title: Baseball; Palmer Takes First Step
description: Jim Palmer, always the picture of calm whether on baseball fields or billboards, looked the polished part after making good on his promised attempt at an unprecedented comeback by a baseball Hall of Famer when he joined the Baltimore Orioles in spring training camp today.

title: Mutual Funds; Gauging Growth and Value
description: Money managers fall into two camps: those who emphasize growth and those who focus on value. Growth managers invest where earnings are expected to outpace the average. Value managers look for stocks that are cheap relative to a company's probable worth.

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN I.R.A. MAN
description: A great deal was made of the fact that the undetonated bomb did not contain any batteries. Your author describes Flood as "a technical expert and the top bomb maker in the city." Surely, an expert bomb maker would simply fail to connect a wire in an unobvious part of the circuit. A loose wire would be much easier to explain should the undetonated bomb be examined later by his own people. This "proof" that Paddy Flood betrayed the I.R.A. sounds as if it were made from whole cloth RALPH GUALTIERI Amston, Conn.

title: Fashion; WHAT ABOUT HEMLINES?
description: Shoulders can expand or contract. Waistlines can wander. That's just fashion doing its thing. But let a few important designers hike up a hemline -- or drop one -- and suddenly everyone is interested. Otherwise normal people act as if hemline peregrinations were the work of designers determined to wreak havoc on women's wardrobes, not to mention their budgets and the retail economy in general.

title: Colleen M. Carney Marries Geoffrey H. Edmonds
description: Colleen Mary Carney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Carney of Woburn, Mass., was married yesterday in North Andover, Mass., to Geoffrey Hope Edmonds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Edmonds of Andover, Mass. The ceremony at the North Parish Unitarian-Universalist Church was performed by the Rev. David M. Blanchard, the church's minister, and the Rev. Richard K. Gross, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TV Flexes Its Muscles and Takes Some Punches
description: The 1989 champ is taking a beating in 1991. Little more than a year ago, television was being acclaimed not just as the bearer of good tidings from around the globe but as a freedom fighter in its own right. Not only was television there at the fall of the Berlin wall, but scenes of protest and crackdown that it sent forth from the streets of Beijing and Bucharest, Prague and Moscow were credited with rousing the long oppressed against their oppressors. The small, light, easy-to-use video cameras that suddenly appeared everywhere were hailed as the people's weapons against authority's big guns.

title: Asians Spread Across a Land, and Help Change It
description: In Birmingham, where eating out long meant barbecue, there are now 60 Chinese restaurants. In Huntsville, Korean managers at the Korean-owned Gold Star television factory give orders to their American workers. And here in Bayou La Batre, at the tip of Mobile Bay, a third of the old Cajun fishing village's 2,600 inhabitants are now Vietnamese or Cambodian.

title: Donna Tritter to Marry
description: Donna Lynne Tritter and David Steven Biderman, lawyers in Washington, plan to marry in April. Ms. Tritter, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Tritter of Amherst, Mass. A graduate of the University of Chicago, she has a law degree from Boston College and is an associate in the firm of Howrey & Simon. Mr. Biderman, 27, is the son of Judy Biderman of Englewood, N.J., and Jack Biderman of New York. A graduate of Johns Hopkins University and the University of Pennsylvania Law School, he is an associate in the firm of Steptoe & Johnson.

title: Sports People; Sherrill's Campaign
description: It was Coach Dana X. Bible who called the first 12th man down from the Texas A&M stands and put him in uniform for a game against Center College in 1922, but it was Jackie Sherrill who transformed what had become a treasured A&M tradition into week-to-week reality by rotating student volunteers as the Aggies' kickoff squad.

title: Postings: To Have and to Hold; Balcony Tale
description: The balconies aren't much as balconies go -- wide enough to stand on, but no good for sitting. Yet the owners of the co-op at 255 West 90th Street liked their Art Nouveau style and the way they echoed the design of the parapet 12 stories above Broadway. So even though an engineer had recommended that they be chopped off to save costs, the co-op board voted instead to retain and restore the three balconies.

title: Review/Rock; Hard Country by Kentucky Headhunters
description: The well-groomed country-rock on most of the Kentucky Headhunters' album "Pickin' on Nashville," which just won a Grammy Award, barely suggests how rowdy the band is on stage. On Tuesday night at the Lone Star Roadhouse, the Headhunters slammed through their own songs and an unlikely selection of cover versions, twanging and socking and blasting power chords like a latter-day Lynyrd Skynyrd.

title: Piece, by Piece, Firemen's Memorial is Rebuilt
description: Scattered all over a ridge of Riverside Drive in Manhattan, the 80-year-old Firemen's Memorial lies in pieces. Its finer marble touches are in crates on the lawn, its rough stone foundation has been jackhammered away, and all that remains is its craggy core: a decaying brick wall.

title: A Benign View of Humanity
description: STAGED in 1935, the Museum of Modern Art's "Family of Man" was billed as "the greatest photography exhibition of all time." Yet, when introducing the show in the catalogue, the curator, Edward Steichen, made it seem primarily a plug for humanity. And, aside from Ansel Adams's famous landscape of boulders all the way to the Rocky Mountains, it was all of that, too.

title: Outdoors; Suffern Exhibition Heralds Approach of Spring
description: If you have been having difficulty conjuring up sweet visions of the forthcoming fishing season, a visit to the 1991 World Fishing & Outdoor Exposition could prove salubrious.

title: Students Attend Classes There, So How Come It's Not a Campus?
description: THE sign at the entrance says, "The University of Connecticut at Torrington." A UConn banner is taped to the information desk, and the campus bookstore is well stocked with university T-shirts, notebooks and stuffed likenesses of the Husky, UConn's mascot. The single brick building on the 200-acre rural campus has 10 classrooms, 2 seminar rooms, a library and a 260-seat auditorium. Eight full-time faculty members and 28-part-time instructors teach courses there.

title: Uganda's Women: Children, Drudgery and Pain
description: When 28-year-old Safuyati Kawuda married the man she remembers as "handsome and elegant," her husband scraped together the bride price: five goats and three chickens. The animals represented a centuries-old custom intended to compensate Mrs. Kawuda's father for losing the labor of his daughter.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A CLOSET TANNER
description: When I was younger and stronger, I spent a lot of time delivering boats from one near-equatorial spot to another. In our tightly-knit fraternity, a pallid complexion connoted all things dull and insular. It was the signifier of what we called "the civilian," meaning all those unfortunates trapped in office jobs.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Apartments On the Lake
description: A $110-MILLION apartment complex at the edge of the Chicago River and Lake Michigan is scheduled to open this spring, part of what is expected to be a 20-year, $2-billion redevelopment effort on a 60-acre site just east of Michigan Avenue.

title: Miss Burr to Wed Chauncey Goss 2d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Burr of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Joy Burr, to Chauncey Porter Goss 2d, a son of Representative and Mrs. Porter J. Goss of Washington and Sanibel Island, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Historic District Discussion; Skirting the Edges
description: Most people concerned with New York City's historic districts focus on what goes on within them, and particularly on preserving the older buildings that give them their special character. But now what goes on just beyond the borders of the districts is to get some attention.

title: Winter Haven Journal; Old Fears and New Ones In Rash of Church Fires
description: On Feb. 3, shortly after the Sunday morning service, someone set a fire in the Inman Park Baptist Church. It destroyed a balcony storage area, charred ceilings and walls and did $50,000 worth of damage.

title: Cookie-Crunching Forecasts, Revisited
description: Once again, sales of Girl Scout cookies represent a leading economic indicator. Despite the refusal of certain stick-in-the-mud economists to look beyond housing starts and manufacturers' inventories, key questions about the vitality of our economy can be answered with but a single glance at the Girl Scout Pocket Order Form that I carried in my briefcase to the office through cookie-selling season.

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN I.R.A. MAN
description: That Paddy Flood was an informer, at least in terms of the ruse described by Kevin Toolis, seems somewhat improbable ("Informer: The Life and Death of an I.R.A. Man," Feb. 3). The large population of sociopaths in both the I.R.A. and the Royal Ulster Constabulary is far too cunning to have fallen for so elementary a double ploy.

title: Travel Advisory; New Routes Set For Two Liners
description: Citing concern about travel to the Mediterranean, Royal Viking Line has replaced three itineraries scheduled for the Royal Viking Sun. The new trips: from Fort Lauderdale to Montreal, April 25 to May 11; Montreal to Fort Lauderdale, May 11 to 17, and Fort Lauderdale to Copenhagen, May 27 to June 17. The Montreal-Fort Lauderdale cruise includes a visit to Baltimore on May 18, the day of the Preakness horse race, and to Charleston, S.C., on May 23 during the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.. The Copenhagen cruise includes calls at other ports in Scandinavia and in England and Scotland.

title: How Cocaine Brought Low a Soaring Law Career
description: Just out of law school in 1970, Henry G. Barr landed what he told friends was a dream job: prosecuting criminals as the youngest assistant in the office of Dick Thornburgh, the United States Attorney in Pittsburgh.

title: Ms. Cox Engaged To John H. Dolan
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Harley Cox Jr. of Pine Bluff, Ark., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Cox to John H. Dolan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mario A. Dolan of Irvington, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Sun Valley, an American Original
description: CERTAINLY, there are places in the Northern Hemisphere with more flash, better snow, easier access and steeper slopes than Sun Valley, Idaho -- the granddaddy of American winter resorts. But where else can a skier find a blend of big bowls and scrubbed sky by day, and at night curl up in front of a marble fireplace a few feet away from a frame of Ernest Hemingway's last letter and a picture of Judy Garland catching a 16-inch trout? Not Colorado's Aspen or Vail. Not Park City, Utah, or Stowe, Vt. The nation's leading snow playgrounds all have their respective virtues. Most of what Sun Valley has came from nature, the rest came from Hollywood. Together, they make for an American original.

title: Review/Music; Another Indian Master, This Time of the Sarod
description: Not to mince words, Amjad Ali Khan, a 45-year-old sarod virtuoso who appeared for the first of four concerts on Thursday night at the Asia Society (the last is this afternoon at 3, on Park Avenue at 70th Street), is the most charismatic performer of North Indian ragas to appear hear since the glory days of Ravi Shankar in the 1960's. Of course, the 90's are not the 60's, so the Zeitgeist may not confer upon Mr. Khan the fame it granted Mr. Shankar. But he is a quite remarkable and compelling artist, nonetheless.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 23 about the composer Jule Styne included a quotation from him that referred imprecisely to the departure of the playwright Simon Gray as the librettist from the musical version of the film "The Red Shoes." Correspondence at the time, newly made available to The Times, establishes that Mr. Gray left the project voluntarily because of creative differences with Mr. Styne and the producer Martin Starger, and that drinking was not a factor in the departure. A letter on this subject from Mr. Gray appears on this page today.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: State of Grace 1990. Orion. $94.98. 2:14. Closed captioned. R. Phil Joanou's Irish mob in the New York Hell's Kitchen neighborhood includes Gary Oldman as Jackie Flannery, the toughest and most volatile of hoods, Sean Penn as the less colorful Terry Noonan and Ed Harris as the icy gang boss Frankie. A somber and chilling tone is only rarely breached. Still, "Mr. Oldman's hot-wired Jackie demonstrates that it is possible to be in a wide-open space and still bounce off the walls." (Janet Maslin) Air America 1990. LIVE. $92.95. Laser disk, $39.95. 1:53. CC. R. The year is 1969 and Mel Gibson and Robert Downey Jr. are pilots for an airline in Laos run by the Central Intelligence Agency. From muddled plot to silly script, Roger Spottiswoode's film fails at about every level. "There are people who will see Mel Gibson in absolutely anything. 'Air America' should offer a cure." (Caryn James) Quick Change 1990. Warner. $92.95. LD, $24.98. 1:29. CC. R As a stickup man he's smart and appealing, but Bill Murray can't salvage this otherwise tired tale about three yuppies' getaway from the horrors of New York living. Mr. Murray seems "bogged down by films that don't begin to match his comic imagination." (James) The Catered Affair 1956. MGM/UA. $19.98. 1:33. No rating. Paddy Chayefsky's expanded teleplay stars Bette Davis as a Bronx mother determined to give her daugher (Debbie Reynolds) a catered wedding reception. "Richard Brooks directed in a sort of free-wheeling way that carries the action jumpily," wrote the Times reviewer. Roger Corman's Frankenstein Unbound 1990. CBS/Fox. $89.98. 1:26. CC. R. Lines like "It is an abomination in the eyes of God!" live only in movies made by Roger Corman, this one about the monster in a horror-sci-fi setting mixed with scenes from Byron and Shelley's lost Swiss summer of 1816. John Hurt, Raul Julia and Bridget Fonda star. "The movie looks fine and the performers are mostly good." (Vincent Canby)

title: Rani Rosenberg to Wed Bruce Pollack
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Roy A. Rosenberg of Brooklyn have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Rani Rosenberg and Bruce Richard Pollack, a son of Mrs. Barry Bangel of Roslyn, L.I., and Marvin A. Pollack of Great Neck, L.I.

title: 2 Hospitalized Babies Die After Overdose
description: Two premature babies died last Saturday after Parkland Memorial Hospital here had given them overdoses of an antibiotic.

title: War Summary
description: THE GROUND WAR BEGINS The much-anticipated allied ground offensive began about 8 P.M., Eastern time. Thousands of tanks and tens of thousands of troops pushed into Kuwait and Iraq shortly before dawn after the deadline for Iraq to begin to pull out its forces from Kuwait or face an allied land invasion passed with no reaction from President Saddam Hussein.The American commander in the Persion Gulf had been given the authority to mount the ground offensive when he saw fit. Bombing runs continued over Kuwait and Baghdad, and napalm and ground-clearing fuel-air bombs were dropped over Kuwait to open paths for armor and infantrymen. Shortly before President Bush's withdrawal deadline, Iraq fired a Scud surface-to-surface missile that hit central Israel; no injuries were reported. U.S. charges atrocities in Kuwait City

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: COLETTEA Life.By Herbert Lottman.Little, Brown, $24.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Greater Roslyn
description: ONE Sunday afternoon 10 years ago, Dr. Thomas Loeb, a resident at New York University Hospital, went to see a friend on Long Island and discovered the village of Roslyn.

title: Headliners; Civil Warrior
description: When the Chinese Nationalist Government was at war with the Communist rebels a half-century ago, Zhang Xueliang, then known as the Young Marshal, mounted a brash gambit that put him firmly on both sides. With an invading Japanese army steadily encroaching, Mr. Zhang, a Nationalist-allied warlord, kidnapped the Nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-shek, and extracted from him a promise to make a temporary peace with the Communists to better fight the Japanese. Mr. Zhang might then have joined Mao and become a hero of the revolution that eventually prevailed, but he chose instead to accept Chiang's judgment -- a lifetime of house arrest which ended only recently -- and became a symbol of patriotism for Nationalists and Communists alike. Now almost 90 years old, Mr. Zhang, in his first interview at home, said that after 50 years of isolation he is uncomfortable as an object of reverence. "I can't take everybody's compliments," he said.

title: The High Life in St. Moritz
description: ST. MORITZ is the oldest and, in the minds of most people familiar with Switzerland, the grandest of Swiss ski resorts. A group of intrepid English travelers were the first to winter in St. Moritz in 1864, when a local hotelier promised them plenty of sun and snow. Ever since then, winter travelers, and especially affluent ones, have been going to this town 6,089 feet above sea level to relax and ski in the snow that normally comes in December and stays through April.

title: David Herlihy, 60, Leading Historian On Medieval Times
description: David Herlihy, historian and professor of medieval history and former president of the American Historical Association, died Thursday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 60 years old.

title: Lasting Impressions
description: IN THE PALACES OF MEMORY How We Build the Worlds Inside Our Heads. By George Johnson. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: The Campaign to Save A Dusty but Historic Hall
description: IT was once the essence of English gentility, an elegant manor house on a high bluff overlooking both the Hudson and Saw Mill Rivers, the center of the most prosperous estate in the Colonies. With its formal gardens and picket-fenced deer park, it represented what one historian called "all that was best in the life of the province."

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: The nominal Japanese voltage is 100 volts, rather than 110. The actual voltage may be greater or less. Much electronic equipment and motors designed for use in the United States will not operate properly below 105 volts.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Philip M. Murphy's New Year's Eve experience in Moscow couldn't be more different from mine in 1988 when I traveled with a group of American peacemakers from the Fellowship of Reconciliation.

title: Once in Aleppo
description: CHIMES FROM A WOODEN BELL A Hundred Years in the Life of a Euro-Armenian Family. By Taqui Altounyan. 189 pp. New York: I. B. Tauris & Company/ St. Martin's Press. $21.95.

title: New York Counters Allowed to Keep Loon Program
description: The loon rangers will be allowed to patrol Adirondack Mountain lakes to count the birds this spring and summer under the continued sponsorship of the Audubon Society of the State of New York.

title:
Gardening;
Shade for Delicate Plants, A Simple Winter Project
description: The most often borrowed and least often returned items in my garden shed are the lath shades my husband designed to protect seedlings and recently divided plants from the direct sunlight. As spring is coming, and the season of dividing and transplanting is almost upon us, self-interest prompts me to share his design and method of assembly. There is still time to repair to the garage or basement and build a few of these simple sun-screens of your own.

title: Spending Rises For Drug Programs As Alcoholism Funds Are Curbed
description: ALCOHOLISM services, once the primary focus of addiction treatment, are being eclipsed on Long Island by programs for cocaine addicts.

title: Ecstasy 10 Years After a Gift: a Kidney
description: To paraphrase a line from another great love story, Dr. Eli Friedman's party for his wife, Mildred, on the 10th anniversary of her organ transplant last week was by way of saying, "Here's looking at you, kidney."

title: Welcome Progress on Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Pointers for Starting Plants From Seed
description: GARDENERS who like to start their own annuals, perennials and vegetables from seed need to keep a few points in mind. Though moisture is essential to the process, many novices keep the seed-starting medium too wet, and as a result, the seeds rot.

title: Bonnie Lyons Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Reese Lyons of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Starr Lyons to Lee Sumner Richards 3d, a son of Mr. Richards Jr. of Stuart, Fla., and the late Elaine G. Richards. An April wedding is planned. Miss Lyons, 31 years old, is known as Bonnie. A graduate of the University of Virginia, she is the director of accessories at J. Crew, the mail-order clothing company in New York. Mr. Richards, 40, is a summa cum laude graduate of Amherst College, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received a J.D. degree from Columbia University. He is a founding partner in the New York law firm of Richards Spears Kibbe & Orbe and is an adjunct professor at the Fordham University Law School. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Way Back Yonder in the 1980's
description: SLEEPWALKING THROUGH HISTORY America in the Reagan Years. By Haynes Johnson. Illustrated. 524 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company.

title: Why AIDS Memorial Doesn't Belong on Farm
description: An article referred to "some officials" who have criticized the proposal for an AIDS Memorial at the Suffolk County Farm [ "L.I. Sends China Moving AIDS Message," Feb. 3 ] .

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Adding to the Elderly's Housing Choices
description: IT didn't take long for Ruth G. Smith, an 85-year-old widow, to decide to sell her condominium at a traditional adult housing complex and rent an apartment at nearby LeisurePark, a continuing-care retirement community in Lakewood.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 24, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve their marital and romantic problems. 2 1 5 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 3 2 7 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 4 3 5 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of marines from Midway to Guadalcanal. 5 4 2 FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) A young woman finds familial problems and love in Dakota Territory. 6 5 19 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) Europe in the Ice Age. 7 7 10 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. 8 10 3 MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) The romantic and professional lives of a homicide detective become entangled. 9 9 7 THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert. 10 8 2 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury finds himself a suspect in the strange death of a widow from England's Lake District. 11 6 5 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia. 12 14 16 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man. 13 11 4 MIDDLE PASSAGE, by Charles Johnson. (Atheneum, $17.95.) A newly liberated slave voyages to Africa in the early 19th century. 14 12 13 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of a California woman who becomes a photographer. 15 51 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 16 * 13 6 VITAL SIGNS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $21.95.) title: NEWS PRESSMEN CONTINUE TALKS
description: Leaders of the pressmen's union huddled privately with a labor mediator for nearly three hours yesterday, as last-ditch talks between The Daily News and its striking unions dragged on for a sixth day.

title: Move Aside, People! The Cat Show's Coming
description: The first of the 1,000 or so cats who will be competing for ribbons, trophies and perhaps even fame at Madison Square Garden (or merely be on exhibition during the seventh International Cat Show), padded into town the other afternoon to meet the press.

title: Sunday Dinner; 4 for American Cuisine, 2 With a Nautical Feel
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some Manhattan restaurants that specialize in American cuisine.

title:
PRISON OVERCROWDING POSES TOUGH ISSUES;
2 Bills Ask Inmates To Repay The State
description: THREE legislators from Passaic County have come up with what they regard as a novel approach to easing New Jersey's budget crunch. They have submitted bills that would require prisoners to reimburse the state for the costs of incarceration through liens that would be placed on their property and income.

title: Playing Prime Time Close to the Shtick
description: Imagine a sitcom named "Eco" in which the semiotician Umberto Eco plays a semiotician named Umberto Eco. At the start, in the middle and at the end of each show, he reads a bit from his latest book, inspired by that episode's typical sitcom problem: Eco gets caught in the snow wearing his new suede jacket, or Eco's best friend, George, says something dumb to a woman he really likes.

title: Review/Dance; Eliot Feld's Visualizations Of Scarlatti Piano Sonatas
description: Eliot Feld's "Ah Scarlatti," presented by Feld Ballets/NY on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, starts out looking like a 1990's music visualization. Neatly ordered ranks of dancers cut through the air with just as precisely ordered hinging arms and legs. Solos for Lynn Aaron never let her stray far from the tethered-looking central axis of her body, even when they demanded a teasing play with balance. Elizabeth Simonson was lifted high with her legs stretched taut in a midair split. It all seemed to accentuate every beat of the Scarlatti piano sonatas to which the piece is set. Why did Mr. Feld care about this music, one wondered?

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Syracuse University basketball program misidentified the university's chancellor and a professor at its S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications. The chancellor is Melvin A. Eggers; the professor is Nancy Sharp. The article also misstated the cost of building the Carrier Dome, the sports arena on campus. It was $27 million.

title: Horse Racing; Fly So Free Captures Fountain of Youth Stakes
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby took a couple of dramatic turns through Gulfstream Park today with another smashing victory for the winter-book favorite, Fly So Free, while the superstar filly Meadow Star arrived on the scene and bided her time in the barn.

title: Exchanging Technology, in Miniature
description: Three men old enough to have fought in World War II clustered around a Soviet-built model of an airplane of even earlier vintage at the opening of a two-day model airplane show here today, leaning in occasionally to inspect its engine the way surgeons might assess a heart transplant.

title: Sports People; Honor for Ryans
description: Last fall Nolan Ryan lent his name to a fund-raising dinner to revive the dormant baseball program at Abilene Christian College in Texas.

title: Bumpy Road For Nolan Ryan
description: An effort to name part of a Texas highway for Nolan Ryan has some politicians playing hardball.

title: Oliver Stone and 'The Doors': Obsession Meets the Obsessed
description: One morning last summer, San Francisco awoke and found itself back in the 1960's. The corner of Haight and Ashbury was again a swirling carnival of psychedelic street theater and protests against the Vietnam War. Flower children streamed in, bells on their wrists and blossoms in their hair, all converging for that sacred rite of the counterculture, a be-in at Golden Gate Park.

title: New York Parochial-School Aid Called Unfair
description: New York City's efforts to provide remedial education to lower-income students in parochial schools have effectively shortchanged needy public school students, a private coalition on education has charged.

title: Gunfire Leaves 6 People Dead in 3 Boroughs
description: Six people were shot and killed in separate incidents in New York City yesterday and late Friday, the police said.

title: Why Marilyn Monroe Is a Polish Baritone
description: Marek Gajewski is one of Poland's most recognized figures, and well he should be. In the last 22 years, he has been John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, Ali MacGraw, Ryan O'Neal, Donald Duck, Sophia Loren, Marcello Mastroianni and even characters from the television show "Lost in Space."

title: Opera's 'Singing Actor' Is Still Revered
description: THE twists and turns of Alexander Kipnis's life rivaled those in his opera roles. He rose from poverty in the Ukraine to become one of the world's most celebrated singers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about Earl E. T. Smith, a former United States Ambassador to Cuba, referred incorrectly to his third marriage, to the former Florence Pritchett. She died in 1965; there was no divorce.

title: Donna Pflaumer to Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Pflaumer of Weymouth, Mass., have made known August wedding plans for their daughter Donna Marie Pflaumer and Michael Brian McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. McDonald of Glen Head, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MEAN SPIRIT By Linda Hogan. Atheneum, $19.95.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Boating, With Hotels, on the Waterfront
description: THOUGH many developers of waterfront housing are putting projects on hold until the market strengthens, two builders of mixed-use projects with hotels, retail space, restaurants and marinas believe there is still a strong demand for such commercial developments and are moving ahead.

title: Susan Tregurtha to Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Tregurtha of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Susan Lee Tregurtha to Newton Conklin Marshall 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Marshall of Huron, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title: College Basketball; Pirates Coast Past Wildcats
description: Once upon a time, a Big East basketball game between Villanova and Seton Hall was no contest. It's still like that, only in reverse.

title: 11 Killed in Leningrad Blaze
description: A fire swept through a tourist hotel in Leningrad today, killing at least 11 people, including foreigners and firefighters, the official press agency Tass and officials said. Soviet television said the fire broke out at about 9 A.M. in the nine-story Leningrad Hotel. Interior Ministry officials said three foreigners were among the victims, but did not identify them further.

title: Pianists, Drummers and Acrobats
description: IF you like piano concertos, you're in luck this week, since four top-notch American pianists -- Claude Frank, Seymour Lipkin, Christopher O'Riley and Jodie Gelbogis DeSalvo -- are featured in orchestral programs next weekend.

title: The World; Taiwan Walks Gingerly On the Path To Reform
description: HAVING avoided the violent clashes of South Korea or the coup attempts of the Philippines, Taiwan has moved steadily toward democracy in the last few years. And over the next 18 months, it is poised to take the biggest step of all: replacing its constitutional structure, which is now based on the claim that the Government here has sovereignty over the entire Chinese mainland.

title: Llamas: They're Adorable and They're Profitable
description: WHEN Carolyn Blalock looks out the kitchen window of her house in Long Valley, her view is somewhat different from that of her neighbors. Mrs. Blalock gazes at a yard full of llamas.

title: About Cars; 4-Cylinder Luxury in a Sporty Peugeot
description: Things go along and it's easy not to notice. But it is not so long ago that imported cars were peculiarly alien to the American hand.

title: Kimberly Parker to Marry Seth Ingall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton Parker of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kimberly Rebecca Parker to Seth Matthew Ingall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Ingall of Highland Park, Ill. An August wedding is planned.

title: Welcome Progress on Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LICORICEBy Abby Frucht.Graywolf, $18.95.

title:
Fashion;
THE SHAPE OF PARIS
description: The day before the Christian Lacroix show, radios and miniature television sets were tucked behind mounds of fake roses, behind bolts of fabric in the white-walled couture workrooms where Lacroix and his assistants hovered over final fittings. The mood: subdued. As Jean-Jacques Picart, Lacroix's director of communications, said: "It's hard just now to get excited by a jewel, a feather. But we force ourselves."

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TAR BEACH Written and illustrated by Faith Ringgold. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $14.95. (All ages)

title: Style Makers; Roger and John Woo, Film Designers and Producers
description: "In a technical field like ours, everyone is looking for a new approach," Roger Woo said. "A style is old after about six months."

title: SLOVENIA'S SCHISM IS A CAUTIOUS ONE
description: Slovenia's slow separation from the crumbling six-republic Yugoslav federation amounts in many ways to a bookkeepers' revolution.

title: Love in Three Villas
description: HAPPY ENDING By Francesca Duranti. Translated by Annapaola Cancogni. 165 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; As the Deadline Passes, Iraqis Are Still Defiant
description: In the hours before American ground forces roared into Kuwait and Iraq, the last official word from Baghdad was a stinging attack on the American ultimatum by a member of President Saddam Hussein's inner circle. The official, speaking on Saturday, said the only way to stop the war was for Washington to accept the last-ditch Soviet proposals for peace.

title: Do Runnin' Rebels Need Degrees?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Caution: Now Entering The War Zone
description: You've seen the timeworn 1960's image: Jimi Hendrix at Woodstock in 1969, playing "The Star-Spangled Banner" with screaming siren notes and blasts of feedback that suggested the chaos and carnage of Vietnam bombing raids.

title: Expanded Congress Would Help Women
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Campion: Airs (22) Drew Minter, countertenor; Paul O'Dette, lute. Harmonia Mundi HMU 907023; CD and cassette.

title: Mandela Group May Shift on Nationalization
description: The African National Congress has publicly expressed reservations about its longstanding commitment to nationalize key industries if it comes to power.

title: More Tiffany Treasures Found on L.I.
description: SIX years ago, when they set out to write a tourist guide to Long Island, the husband-and-wife team of Raymond E. and Judith A. Spinzia of Hauppauge had no intention of becoming experts on Louis Comfort Tiffany, the artist and craftsman who turned stained glass into a decorative art.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reactions/Egypt; Officials Call For Iraqi's Ouster
description: Abandoning much of their previous caution, Egyptian officials said today that the Iraqi President had to be toppled from power for peace to prevail in the Middle East.

title: SPRINGTIME IN PARIS
description: It all happened last October -- but with the weather meltingly balmy, the fashions effervescent and fresh, it might as well have been Springtime in Paris! The whole world hade come to see what the French designers were planning for spring 1991. For one feverish week, from Wednesday to Wednesday, the city was taken over by fashion and fashion followers, when buyers, press, celebrities and groupies all converged on the three tents pitched for the shows in one courtyard of the Lourve to see the newest trends . . .

title: Motels
description: To the Editor: As a card-carrying member of the Super 8 VIP club, I read Betsy Wade's "On the Road, Sleeping for Less" (Travel, Dec. 16) with great interest. Her expedition into foreign territory was enjoyable reading, but her preface to the morning food offerings betrayed her patrician travel habits. She informed us that many of the motels "offered some palliative for those who leave before Denny's . . . opens." Among those of us who travel the short-towel hotel circuit the one great certainty is that Denny's never closes. GERALD A. WHITE Colorado Springs

title: THE VIRTUES OF VIRTUE
description: Joan Gould expresses my feelings exactly. In these days of choice, young people should also be exposed to the conventional wisdom in her article. They certainly are being bombarded with all sorts of bizarre views via the electronic media. E. T. KINGLSEY New Canaan, Conn.

title: Meg Tozier to Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Tozier of Long Valley, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Margaret Lindsay Tozier and Robert Allan McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. McDonald of Garden City, L.I. Ms. Tozier, who is 33 years old and is known as Meg, graduated from Trinity University in San Antonio. She is a marketing manager in New York for RAM Mobile Data, a nationwide telecommunications company. Mr. McDonald, 36, graduated from New York University and received a law degree from St. John's University. He is a partner in the law firm of Collins, McDonald and Gann in Carle Place, L.I.

title: Campus Life: Purdue; Computer Project Sends Messages To Persian Gulf
description: With donated computers and stores of stamina, students at Purdue University have created a telecommunications link to men and women serving in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Deborah L. Cohen to Marry Mark A. Friedman
description: Dr. and Mrs. John M. Cohen of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Levinger Cohen, to Mark Adam Friedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Friedman of East Rockaway, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Susan H. Baker to Wed Richard A. Leavitt in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. David H. Baker of Savannah, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Halliday Baker to Richard Adam Leavitt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Leavitt of Ipswich, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Downhill Racing Set Back in Japan
description: Strong head winds and poor visibility today forced officials to postpone the women's World Cup downhill race until Sunday.

title: More War -- and Less
description: Millions drew up before the international hearth of television yesterday, struggling to read between the lines for some sign of peace.

title: What the Investor Should Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders Voter Registration Plan to Begin
description: In unusually strong language, a State Supreme Court Justice has ordered the New York State Board of Elections to begin a long-delayed program aimed at registering more poor people and minorities as voters.

title: Indians in Aspic
description: The Sioux and Lieut. John Dunbar, the character enthusiastically played by Kevin Costner in "Dances With Wolves," meet auspiciously: He's naked, and that so disconcerts a group of mounted warriors that the naive young soldier lives to tell the tale, a sort of Boy Scout Order of the Arrow ritual carried to the nth power.

title: Beijing Denounces Defector
description: The Government has denounced as a traitor and expelled from Parliament a senior offical who has sought refuge in the United States. The man, Xu Jiatun, who served from 1983 until early 1990 as the top Chinese official in Hong Kong, fled China in April and is now living is seclusion in California. A member of the Communist party's Central Advisory Commsiion and friend of Deng Xiao-ping, China's senior leader, Mr. Xu was the highest official to flee China after the military crackdown in 1989.

title: Freud, Leonardo and Biographers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dana Stricker to Wed
description: Mrs. Norman Kaufman of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. Howard Stricker of Fort Lee, N.J, have announced the engagement of their daughter Dana Renee Stricker to Jonathan Mark Goidel, the son of Ilene Needle of Fort Lee and the late Alvin Goidel. Ms. Stricker, 27 years old, is the assistant to the counsel at Handy & Harmon, a precious-metals processor in New York. A magna cum laude graduate of Rutgers University, she received a J.D. degree from the Brooklyn Law School, as did her fiance. Mr. Goidel, 29, is a partner at the New York law firm of Goidel & Siegel. He graduated from Hamilton College.

title: Something Borrowed, Something New
description: Plus ca change . . . or, it seems to me I've heard that cover before.

title: One More River to Cross
description: THE PROMISED LAND The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America. By Nicholas Lemann. 416 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Metro Datelines; Attendance Drops At the Meadowlands
description: Attendance at the Meadowlands sports and entertainment complex dropped sharply in January because of the Persian Gulf War and the recession, officials said Friday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 122, Mavericks 107: Dominique Wilkins had 31 points and 14 rebounds as Atlanta stretched its franchise-record winning streak at home to 19 games. The Hawks were in control for most of the game after using a 10-0 run in the first quarter to erase a 15-14 deficit. Spud Webb scored 26 points for the Hawks, who have lost nine of their last 10 road games. (AP) Track and Field Soviet Women Set Relay Mark: The Soviet Union set a world record in the women's 1,600-meter relay and a combined German team took the overall title yesterday at the Six Nations indoor meet in Paris. Germany collected 102 points, with the Soviet Union second with 100. France took third with 84.5 points, followed by Italy 74.5, Britain 62.5 and Spain 57.5. A Soviet foursome of Aelita Iurchenko, Lyudmila Szhigalova, Marina Shomonina and Margarita Ponomaerva was timed in 3 minutes 28.80 seconds, shattering the record by nearly six seconds. The previous mark was 3:34.38 by a West German team in 1981. Katrin Krabbe of Germany, a triple gold medalist at the 1990 European outdoor championships, won the women's 60-meter dash in 7.23. Sigrun Wodars, the 1988 Olympic champion for East Germany, won the women's 800 in 2:00.91. (AP) Tennis Edberg-Svensson Final: Jonas Svensson saved a match point and rallied to beat Guy Forget yesterday and set up an all-Swedish final against Stefan Edberg in the $1 million Eurocard Classic tournament in Stuttgart, Germany. Svensson ended Forget's bid for a third tournament triumph this year and the second in a row with a 2-6, 7-6, 6-2 victory. Edberg, the No. 1 player in the world, beat Jan Siemerink of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-4. The seventh-seeded Svensson faced a match point on Forget's serve in the second-set tie breaker. But he saved it and went on to win the set and raced through the third after the sixth-seeded Frenchman began making too many errors. (AP) Lendl Breezes in Memphis: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl gave Derrick Rostagno a very brief but thorough lesson, winning in straight sets, 6-3, 6-2 to coast into the final of the $750,000 Volvo Indoor in Memphis. Lendl, ranked third in the world, took only 72 minutes to eliminate Rostagno, 11th-seeded and ranked 42d in the world.(AP) Boxing Knockdown Victory for Dele: Gilbert Dele of France won the vacant World Boxing Association junior middleweight title as he stopped Carlos Elliott in the seventh round of a scheduled 12-round fight yesterday in Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe. Dele, the European champion, is unbeaten in 27 fights with one draw. Elliott, an American fighting out of Japan, is 26-3. He had to be taken from the ring on a stretcher after not being able to move for about 10 minutes after the knockdown. (AP) Bowling Title for Stayrook: Jess Stayrook defeated Walter Ray Williams Jr., 256-207, yesterday in the title match of the Professional Bowlers Association $130,000 Flagship City Open in Erie Pa. The career title was the second for the left-hander. (AP) Golf Sluman Grabs Share of Lead: Jeff Sluman, whose 1988 PGA Championship is his only tour victory, rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to grab a share of the lead after three rounds of the Los Angeles Open. Sluman shot a three-under-par 68 to move into a tie with second-day leader Bruce Lietzke, who had a 70. Sluman and Lietzke were 10-under at 203 through 54 holes at the Riviera Country Club, barely atop a logjam near the lead. Ted Schulz and Davis Love 3d, both with a 69, were a shot back. Four others were at 205. Lietzke opened a three-stroke lead with a second-round 63, but faltered on the back nine yesterday. Sluman overcame a slow start Saturday to catch Lietzke. Sluman shot a 1-over 36 on the front nine, but had five birdies and a bogey on the backside. Lietzke seemed on the verge of pulling away when he went on a three-birdie spree beginning at No. 9 to go 12-under, but slipped back with bogeys on the 14th and 15th holes. (AP) Sheehan Wins in Hawaii: Patty Sheehan came out strong, came apart and came back yesterdayto win the $350,000 Hawaiian Ladies Open. Sheehan, who won her 26th L.P.G.A. event, shot a 2-under-par 70 to finish with a 9-under-par 207 in the 54-hole tournament at the Ko Olina Resort course. (AP)

title: Eastern German Buyers Learning the Hard Way
description: Consumers in the former East Germany are discovering the dark side of capitalism: life insurance scams, "you have just won first prize" sweepstakes offers and unpayable debts.

title: Heart-Healthy Menu For Utility Workers
description: The About Long Island column of Feb. 3 incorrectly characterized our food-service contract with Lilco.

description: Chatham 330,000 66 Fairview Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 52-year-old colonial; 1.5 acre, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $5,719. East Brunswick 155,000 17 Donald Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, fenced yard; taxes $3,029. Jackson 144,000 Box 84-R Leesville Siloam Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, w/w carpeting, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,898. Ramsey 195,000 91 Buckingham Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath 33-year-old ranch; screened porch, attic storage; taxes $4,227. OTHER AREAS Stratford, Conn. 149,000 35 Fallon Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 11-year-old ranch; alarm system, oversized deck, walk to train; taxes $2,100. Somers, N.Y. 176,250 Mahopac Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old ranch; fireplace, 2-car detached garage, patio, 1 acre; taxes $2,662. North Patchogue, L.I. 124,000 62 Lexington Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $3,700.

title: Ms. Boutin Weds Thomas O'Hara
description: Antonia Marie Boutin of New York and Thomas John O'Hara of Old Brookville, L.I., were married in Chicago yesterday. The Rev. Charles Faso performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Juggling To Honor Mozart
description: People offer us two kinds of gifts -- the ones we ask for and the ones they want to give us. Mozart isn't around to tell us what he wants for the 200th anniversary of his death, and even if he were, we would probably end up suiting ourselves. Having so much, he is a hard man to shop for. Commemorating Mozart as a one-year, full-time industry seems redundant to begin with. Who has forgotten him? What hymn can we raise to him that has not already been sung?

title:
Your Own Account;
The Awkward Full Nest Syndrome
description: A Washington professional in his mid-50's is facing this prospect: His oldest son, out of work and unable to pay his mortgage, feels he has no choice but to bring his wife and two children to live in his parent's home while he looks for a job.

title:
DINING OUT;
Hearty and Homey Cuisine in Peekskill
description: THE cozy Americana that the designers of this eatery chose has weathered well over the last few years since its opening. The painted checkerboard floors show the tread of many diners, the brass patina on the bathroom faucets is wearing thin, and the place in general has taken on a lived-in, comfortable look. And the food comforts as well. It's not quite Mom's -- no mashed potatoes -- but dishes are hearty, vegetables plentiful and nicely prepared, and very much in evidence are the kitchen's efforts to employ fresh ingredients in tempting ways.

title: A Friedlander Retrospective
description: THE big attraction at the Neuberger Museum here is a retrospective of Lee Friedlander's photography, a Seattle Art Museum production that comes with the title "Like a One-Eyed Cat." Taken from the 1950's song "Shake, Rattle and Roll," the line ends ". . .peeking in a seafood store / Well, I could look at you / tell you ain't no child no more."

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: A la Carte: Roslyn Transfer
description: UNTIL last October, Cliff Goodman, a creative chef, was known to discerning Long Island diners as the man who put Michael's, a Pub, in Roslyn on the culinary map.

title: 'Finding a Mate': Women Respond
description: Apparently, Mr. Levine, you have been wrung ragged with the new modern woman and her wims regarding marriage.

title: Mongolian-Style Barbecue for the Family
description: IN these budget-watching times, it's refreshing to find an attractive new restaurant offering family dining that is both inexpensive and enjoyable. Atilla's -- on the Fairfield-Westport line, in the building formerly occupied by a restaurant called East Coast -- fills the bill with Mongolian barbecue. While grill or fire cooking is traditional in Central Asia, Atilla's has added a new twist -- a buffet table, where diners can sample a range of appetizers before embarking on their grilled, all-you-can-eat meal.

title: Correction
description: A listing of cruise ships on Feb. 3 misstated several facts about the Angelina Lauro of Starlauro Cruises. She has a capacity of 360 passengers and of 6,000 tons, and she entered service in 1969 as the Vicente Puchol. The details published were for a larger ship of the same name that sank in 1979.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: NEAR the reception desk at the Family Place in Newark, partly hidden by a spiraling small-leaf philodendron, a small poster is taped to the wall. "I have AIDS," it says over a child's crayon drawing of a round-headed boy with arms outstretched. "Please hug me. I can't make you sick."

title: Jennifer Coleman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Coleman of New York have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Jennifer Coleman and Lawrence Gardiner Creel, a son of Mrs. John Kirtland Colgate Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I., and the late J. Randall Creel 3d. Miss Coleman, 26 years old, graduated from Pine Manor College. She is a women's clothing designer at Polo/Ralph Lauren in New York. Mr. Creel, 27, graduated from Lake Forest College. He is a vice president of Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, the New York investment brokerage house.

title: Rental Cars
description: To the Editor: For those planning to use a Eurail Drive Pass, a word of warning. Do not expect to find the Hertz office -- Hertz is the exclusive Eurail auto rental agency -- open in Germany over the weekend.

title: Many Who Made It Big Remember Neediest
description: John McEnroe -- that John McEnroe, former bad boy of the tennis courts and ex-Malibu resident -- is a native of Queens, and never forgot his hometown while he was on the world tennis circuit. Every year, through his foundation, he sent a $10,000 gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Q and A
description: St. Bernards in Switzerland

title: The World; 'The Rulers Will Have to Face the Music'
description: AS they gaze beyond the clouds of the gulf war toward the future, many Arab officials and commentators see more questions than answers and a great deal of bad news ahead.

title: Reservations Not Accepted
description: The group of veterans marched down the street, and as they came into sight the crowd at the curb seemed to move forward to greet them, to hold them like a hug. They were youngish men, and their camouflage clothes were as different from the neat uniforms of the other groups as their war had been from other wars. Beside me an old man waved a flag. "We're with you," he shouted, as though he were putting all our cheers into words, and then he added, "We should have let you finish what you started." And the smile froze on my face, and fell.

title: Lumbering in the Age of the Baby Tree
description: Harry A. Merlo, chief executive of the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, has always been willing to move in one direction when the rest of the forest products industry was moving in another. He bought forest land when others were selling and fought the labor unions when others were negotiating. He largely shuns Wall Street, paper-pushing and industry trade groups, preferring instead to cut the figure of a swashbuckler, overseeing his empire by flying from sawmill to sawmill, decked out in cowboy boots and a leather jacket.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; New Approach In Fight to Reduce Alcohol Abuse
description: Alcohol abuse on college campuses is nothing new, but Princeton University administrators say they have an innovative solution: appoint a high-level official to inspire a student movement against it.

title: As in Vietnam, Troops Will Bring Truth Home; Limits of Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: THE VIRTUES OF VIRTUE
description: Joan Gould must think little of men (Hers: "The Virtues of Virtue," Jan. 27). To claim that women must force them into marriage and fatherhood by withholding sex seems a bit strong. The fact is that the childless but sexually content woman of 35 is better off than the 25-year-old spinster of Gould's day. It's O.K. to advertise the longing for a child in 1991; it wasn't O.K. to advertise the need for sex in 1951. To blame my generation for having too much fun in bed sounds an awful lot like 40 years of sour grapes. KRYSTIE KELLER New York, N.Y.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Dover, Vt.;
Prices Drop Near Slopes
description: ALTHOUGH strict environmental regulation has protected most of Vermont from overbuilding and resultant plummeting prices, it has not worked that way in this ski resort 15 miles north of the Massachusetts border.

title: Slump Catches Up With Once-Booming California
description: The mighty California economy is stumbling, marking the delayed arrival of the national recession on the West Coast and prompting concern that the state's downturn could outlast the slump in the rest of the country.

title: 'The Way of the WASP'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: A TYCOON'S TASTE

title: Walesa Walks Fine Line on Wages
description: s Lech Walesa addressed a Solidarity convention today, two months after he was elected President of Poland as a symbol of the working class, he was struggling to navigate a precarious passage between labor unrest and economic chaos.

title: Pro Football; N.F.L. Planning to Add Pay TV to Its Package
description: The era of pay-per-view for major league sports will start within the next two years, when the National Football League will offer a package of games, for a fee, in addition to its lineup of free television.

title: Deborah Vinnick to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Vinnick of Stamford, Conn., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Deborah Michele Vinnick and Dr. Peter Jon Tesler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Tesler of Pawtucket, R.I. Dr. Vinnick, 28 years old, and her fiance, 30, are residents in pediatrics at the New England Medical Center in Boston. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and received her M.D. from Jefferson Medical College. Dr. Tesler graduated from Providence Country Day School and Swarthmore College. He received his M.D. from the University of Vermont College of Medicine.

title: John Griggs, Adviser to New York On AIDS Policies, Is Dead at 50
description: John Griggs, a consultant who advised New York City officials on AIDS policy, died of the disease on Thursday night at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Teacher Is the Key In Quality of Education
description: Re: "Panel Begins Overhaul of Education" (Jan. 27): The quality of a nation's economic, political and social systems is a direct function of the quality of its educational system. Although we are now faced with lean budget years, the schooling of our children is the way we plan for better times to come.

title: Bridge
description: Back in 1968 a wealthy Texas businessman, Ira Corn Jr., decided to do something to end a string of American defeats at the hands of the Italian Blue Team. He formed a professional team of young stars: Jim Jacoby, Bob Wolff, Bob Hamman, Mike Lawrence, Bill Eisenberg and Bob Goldman. The group, named the Aces, trained hard and formed solid partnerships. Within a year they were winning national titles, and in 1970 they won the world team title in Stockholm, Sweden, albeit in the absence of the Italian stars.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JANET T. LANGSAM;
New Director at the Council for the Arts
description: WHEN Janet T. Langsam decided in December to take on the job of executive director of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, she knew the council's finances would be a key challenge. At that time, the County Board of Legislators was on the verge of adopting -- and has since adopted -- a 1991 county budget that halved the funds for the council, an umbrella organization that awards grants to promote local arts and cultural events. The budget cut the funds to $200,000 from $400,000.

title: CHINA IS BLOCKING PHONE CONTACTS
description: Expanding a campaign to increase secrecy in an already secretive nation, the Government seems to have rewired its telephone system so military officials and many foreigners cannot place calls to one another from their offices or homes.

title: INSIDE
description: Thai Prime Minister Ousted by Generals Military leaders in Thailand toppled the elected Government of Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, apparently without firing a shot. The coup leaders, reportedly angered by the appointment of a rival to a top post, accused the Government of corruption and protecting enemies of the monarchy. Page 14. Plight of Africa's Women Exploited, abused and neglected by men, rural women bear the back-breaking brunt of farming in Africa. Their plight has worsened. Page 10. A Secret Life The story of a former Justice Department official convicted in a cocaine case is one of social envy and tragically clouded judgment. Page 24. Senate Races Start Early Nearly two years before voters go to the polls, the 1991 Senate races are well under way in New York, California and several other states. Page 28.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ST. BERNARD'S CENTER FOR LEARNING;
Social Skills for Homeless Children
description: ATTENDANCE at the St. Bernard's Center for Learning is not mandatory, but it certainly beats hanging around hotel hallways and motel parking lots.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate

title: As in Vietnam, Troops Will Bring Truth Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Alert Issued For Galapagos
description: Americans considering a tour to the Galapagos Islands, off Ecuador, should check with their travel agent regarding the safety specifications of the boat to be used, says a State Department advisory. It was prompted by the deaths of three Americans on a tour boat that caught fire and sank on Oct. 26.

title: Margaret Forbes Weds in Phoenix
description: Margaret Mary Forbes, a daughter of Mrs. James C. Forbes of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Forbes, was married yesterday in Phoenix to Michael Philip Osselaer, a son of Mrs. Thomas Osselaer of Phoenix and the late Mr. Osselaer. The Rev. Anton J. Renna, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Brophy College Preparatory School.

title: The Nation; From the Front Lines Of the War on Drugs, A Few Small Victories
description: ALTHOUGH there is growing evidence that crack and cocaine, which have cut a mean, ugly swath across the country, are finally beginning to lose some of their allure, the grim saga of drug addiction is far from over. Millions of Americans remain entangled with the two drugs and other debilitating substances, and experts say that the aftershocks of the nation's worst drug epidemic are likely to be felt for generations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'MY BIG LAND'

title: Commercial Property: Southern Textile Mills; Old Plants Don't Die -- They Just Go on the Market
description: ON the outskirts of this town of 2,100 people is the Mount Vernon Mills textile mill, whose owners would greatly like to sell it. They did once, in 1987, after deciding to get out of the kitchen-towel business. But the buyer went bankrupt in 1989 and Mount Vernon foreclosed on the 190,000-square-foot building and its 25 acres.

title: Miss Gilbert Wed To Dr. S. C. Calle
description: Lynn Auchincloss Gilbert and Dr. Stuart Carl Calle were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Seymour Flinn. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Parker Gilbert of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Martin Calle of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Hers; Cut to the Quick
description: ONE DAY, WHEN I was a little girl, my mother unpacked a white cardboard box, glossy but dented, and introduced me to the surviving dolls of her childhood. The one I remember best was a little-girl doll, whose glued-on wig had been hacked down to one-inch auburn tufts that stuck straight out where there weren't clearings of raw scalp. What I remember about my mother in the moment of that doll's presentation was her still-scandalized thrill at the bold mutilation she'd committed some 40 years before, in the hidden time of her own childhood.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; Near Border, Iraq's Silence Was No News
description: The United States deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait came and passed with barely a ripple in northern Saudi Arabia.

title: A Big Win-Win on Trade
description: Finally, a crucial breakthrough on trade. The European Community last week agreed to demands from the U.S. and third world food exporters to negotiate specific reductions in each of three areas of farm subsidies. That breaks the impasse that paralyzed the Uruguay Round of international trade talks in December and opens the way for a bold trade agreement that could add trillions to the world's economies in the 90's.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Feb. 9 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill 650,000 40 East 94th Street (Carnegie Hill Tower) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,850-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, floor-to-ceiling windows; common charge $625, taxes $3,600 (Broker: Fox Residential Group) Gramercy Park Area 360,000 235 East 22d Street (Gramercy House) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room, renovated kitchen; maintenance $1,123, includes gas and electricity, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: J. I. Sopher & Co.) Upper East Side 201,000 111 East 85th Street (Savoy) 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 975-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, new kitchen appliances; maintenance $713, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) Upper West Side 264,000 176 West 87th Street 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room; maintenance $1,183, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Nancy R. Sweetzer-Klauber Realty) Upper West Side 391,000 194 Riverside Drive (91st St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room, decorative fireplace; maintenance $944, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Halstead Property Co.) BRONX Clasons Point 62,000 601 Beach Street 2-family, detached, frame house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining area in each unit; 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. corner lot; taxes $650 (Broker: Charles G. Brophy) Riverdale 65,000 750 Kappock Street (Glen Brier) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 568-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, parking space; maintenance $465, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Trebach Realty) BROOKLYN Cobble Hill 162,000 157 Kane Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 963-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; den, fireplace, roof rights; maintenance $480, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn A. Donahue-The Prudential/ Carl F. Peek) Ditmas Park 265,000 85 Rugby Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached house; dining room, fireplace, Jacuzzi, c/a, finished basement, 2-car garage, 35- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,000 (Broker: Jacob Gold Realty) East Flatbush 158,500 144 East 89th Street 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, dinette in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, eat-in kitchen in each; 1-car garage, 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,190 (Broker: Helmar Realty) QUEENS Elmhurst 71,000 92-30 56th Avenue (Toledo Court) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; entry foyer, dining room; maintenance $499, includes gas and electricity; 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Forest Hills 270,000 68-10 108th Street (Lexington) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; part-time doorman, dining room, fireplace; maintenance $931, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Terrace Realty) STATEN ISLAND Grant City 75,000 100 Colfax Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $238, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Salmon Real Estate) Sunset Hill 195,000 30 Baker Place 4-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, Cape Cod; dining area, 1-car garage, 50- by 101-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Coldwell Banker/ DeSimone Realty)

title: Yonkers Pleads Its Case To Albany
description: WHEN the legislators who represent Yonkers in Albany were called to City Hall this month, there was just one item on the formal agenda: how to resist, or at least reduce, the deep cuts in state aid that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed for the city.

title: Metro Datelines; Limit Inmates' Suits, New York State Asks
description: New York State will ask the Federal Justice Department in coming months to certify a grievance procedure for inmates, said a spokesman for the State Department of Correctional Services, James Flateau. If that program is approved, prisoners would be forced to exhaust administrative moves to settle grievances before taking them to Federal courts.

title: College Basketball; Hoyas Run Away From the Huskies
description: Dikembe Mutombo scored 7 points in the first five minutes of the second half this afternoon, helping 25th-ranked Georgetown to a 71-57 Big East victory over Connecticut.

title: Shame on the Asset-Strippers
