description: To the Editor:

title:
DANCE;
New Comedy Ballet Has a Venetian Air
description: "AFTER doing the 'mamushka'all day long on a sound stage in the middle of Hollywood, I come back to my hotel and listen to Stravinsky," Peter Anastos said in a recent and very rushed telephone conversation. As a choreographer who spends several months each year as the artistic director and principal choreographer of the Garden State Ballet, Mr. Anastos has become increasingly adept at leaping from one company or medium to another and always landing in a perfect fifth position.

title: Postings: Board's Rights Clarified; Self-Dealing Leases
description: In a ruling that clarifies the rights of co-op boards in buildings where sponsors have retained so-called "self-dealing" garage leases, a Federal appeals court has thrown out such a lease at the co-op at 2 Tudor City Place.

title:
ART;
Angst and Injustice
description: A YEAR ago, when the Discovery Gallery in Glen Cove planned its current exhibition, "Democracy's Struggle," artists and galleries had already begun to treat contemporary social commentary as valid and important. No one could have imagined, however, how timely such a presentation would be just now.

title: A Tough Building Helps Patients Fight Disease
description: There are two ways to make hospital facilities: the standard old way, which is to make the place look like a well-lighted factory, and what is coming increasingly to be the new way, which is to make hospitals soft, warm and cuddly. If the old mode can be unbearably harsh and institutional, designed as much for the convenience of janitors as for the well-being of patients, the new one isn't perfect, either. It may be more user friendly, but it also runs the risk of being disingenuous, even false, in its attempt to make the hospital as inviting as home.

title: Metro Datelines;
description: Seeking to eliminate a potential $5 billion budget deficit over the next five years, transit officials in New York City have outlined a package of remedies that could include increasing subway and bus fares in stages to $1.80 by 1996 and cutting subway, bus and commuter rail service by as much as 20 percent over the same period.

title: The Nation; Justice System Takes A Hard Second Look At Scientific Evidence
description: AT first blush, the evidence seemed irrefutable. Wayne B. Williams, on trial in Atlanta for the murder of two young men killed in the late 1970's, was linked to the crime scenes by analysis of textile fibers, which also tied him to 10 other victims. Police eventually implicated Mr. Williams in the deaths of 24 children.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The liberation of Kuwait has now entered a final phase." --President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: Political Memo; For Big Races, 1992 Campaign Year Is Also 1991
description: In the big tent of national politics, the lights are trained on the Persian Gulf, and Presidential hopefuls are nervously cooling their heels in the aisles. But in the sideshows, the acrobats are more audacious. In New York and California, the 1992 races for the United States Senate are already well under way. And in several other states, the preliminaries for the 1992 elections are entering their final stages.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: I went to Florence three years ago to see the Masaccio frescos in the Brancacci Chapel, but it was closed because the frescos were being restored.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMATEUR NIGHT AT THE APOLLO Ralph Cooper Presents Five Decades of Great Entertainment. By Ralph Cooper with Steve Dougherty. HarperCollins, $25.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Pilots; Racing Through the Darkness in Pursuit of Scuds
description: Preparations for an allied ground offensive have brought no respite for the men who fly the Air Force's F-15E Strike Eagle jets. For them, the air war remains a deadly race of dodging spitting antiaircraft guns and streaking rockets over targets they have christened Scudville, Samstown, AAA Alley and Rat a Tat Tat.

title: Writing 'The Red Shoes'
description: To the Editor:

title: Steals Key Arizona's Victory
description: Two key steals, including Matt Othick's deflection of a pass by Duke's Christian Laettner, helped spur No. 9-ranked Arizona to a 103-96 double overtime victory over the seventh-ranked Blue Devils today. With Matt Muehlebach scoring 7 points in the second overtime, the Wildcats (22-5) extended their nation-leading home winning streak to 61 games at McKale Center. With Othick's pass deflection, Rooks hit a spinning layup with 3.8 seconds left in regulation to tie the score at 78-78, and Chris Mills's 10-foot jumper with 13 seconds left in overtime tied the score at 88-88. Mills missed a 12-footer at the buzzer and the teams played a second overtime. The lead see-sawed throughout regulation and the first overtime, with Bobby Hurley's 3-pointer tying it for Duke at 86-86 with 1 minute 14 second left. Hill's two free throws and Mills's jumper followed. But in the second overtime, Muehlebach hit a 3-pointer and Arizona never again trailed. Georgia Tech 82, Louisville 69

title: Allies Struggling to Handle Flood of Iraqis Surrendering
description: The legions of Iraqi soldiers surrendering to allied forces are straining the coalition's ability to deal with prisoners, American officials and coalition commanders in the field say.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBIN WILLIAMS will pick up an award from his alma mater, the Juilliard School, tonight in Beverly Hills at the Los Angeles alumni chapter's reunion. Named alumnus of the year, Mr. Williams is the first drama student to get the award since the school added a drama program in 1968.

title: Suspect Fire in L.I. Deli Injures 2 Critically
description: Arson was suspected in a fire early today that critically injured two men and extensively damaged a delicatessen and some other stores in a Long Island shopping center, authorities said.

title: Review/Music; German Joins Final 'Fidelio'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's last performance of "Fidelio" this season served to introduce the Met audience to a German soprano of substantial qualities. Its service to Beethoven's opera was decidedly less.

title: Hall Eyes Season In Mellower Tone
description: When he finally walked into the bold morning sun today, Mel Hall still had the swagger that has marked his eight seasons in the major leagues. But his bite might be gone.

title: Metro Matters; The Big Dimout To Save Millions: Will It Really?
description: How many light bulbs does it take to change a city?

title: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: First Firefight Hits Marine
description: Some of the first casualties of the ground war arrived at Navy Fleet Hospital Five late tonight by helicopter, bus and on foot.

title: Debra Spier Wed To Bruce Prince
description: Debra Eve Spier, the daughter of Toby Spier of Riverdale, the Bronx, and William Spier of New York, was married last evening to Baruch Y. Prince, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Z. Prince of Elizabeth, N.J. Rabbis Pinchus Teitz and Irving Greenberg officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Tyson Escapes With Ninjas
description: MIKE TYSON waited eagerly in Las Vegas, Nev., last week for a trunk of kung fu video cassettes. Tyson is a devoted follower of the genre and often watches a kung fu film or two at the end of the day. "Even if I'm asleep when the trunk comes," Tyson instructed an aide, "put it in my room." Don King, the fighter's promoter, said Tyson watched the movies for the messages they deliver about the resilience and fortitude of each kung fu clan. "You knock off one of them, 20 years later the clan comes back to get even," King said. "We get a good message out of that." Tyson disagreed. "I don't get no message," he said. "I just like watching 'em."

title: Foreign Tours Cut As U.S. Orchestras Worry About War
description: Fears of terrorism and concerns about the logistical difficulties of international travel since the start of the Persian Gulf war have forced several American orchestras to reconsider their plans to tour abroad. In recent weeks, the St. Louis Symphony has canceled a European tour that was to have taken place this month. The Minnesota Orchestra has canceled a tour of Japan that was to have started on March 19. And a student orchestra from the Juilliard School canceled a tour of France that had been scheduled for early March.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods . . . Jan. Wednesday G.N.P. . . . 4th Qtr. Thursday Farm Prices . . . Feb. Personal Income . . . Jan. Friday Construction Spending . . . Jan. Leading Indicators . . . Jan.

title: Tech's Anderson: Dress for Success
description: IMAGINE Kenny Anderson, Georgia Tech's flamboyant point guard, dressed not in his uniform but for a date with Dorothy and Toto. As part of the never-ending efforts by schools to find novel ways of attracting attention to players, Tech did a poster featuring Anderson in attire suitable for a walk on the yellow brick road: a gold and purple top, a purple beret, a gold No. 12 chain around his neck, a gold ring and a gold bracelet. Waving a silver wand over a crystal ball, Anderson is dubbed by the poster "The Wizard of Ahhhs."

title: Announcement by Bush
description: Following is a transcript of the statement made by President Bush at the White House on Saturday night to announce the start of the ground war against Iraq:

title: 40,000 Rally to Support Yeltsin Against Gorbachev
description: Reflecting growing concern that Boris N. Yeltsin, the leader of the Russian republic, is being singled out by the Kremlin for a political fall, tens of thousands of people took to the streets today to voice support for him and demand the resignation of his rival, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Review/Television; Destitution in the 1930's (No, It's Not "The Grapes")
description: It is probably not necessary for the country to be in a recession for network television to program a movie like "Long Road Home," a sort of bowdlerized spinoff of "The Grapes of Wrath," but it can't hurt. Viewers always like to be reminded that things could be worse, although today's alien migrant workers might not entirely agree.

title: The Prices of Punishment
description: Governor Mario Cuomo argues that New York State can no longer afford its law requiring judges to imprison criminals convicted for the second time. He has a point. But abandoning the requirement makes little sense without a serious commitment to creating criminal sanctions outside of prison.

title: Gas Prices Fall Nearly a Nickel
description: Lower winter demand and higher oil supplies sent the average price of gasoline down nearly 5 cents nationwide in the last two weeks, almost to its price before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, the Lundberg Survey reported today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: ISRAEL Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity; Relief and Pleas To Oust Hussein
description: Israelis greeted word of the allied ground offensive against Iraq with satisfaction, relief and a fervent hope that the allies would not stop fighting until President Saddam Hussein was ousted.

title: Bucharest Journal; Oh, for a Light Bulb! Dark Days Aren't Over Yet
description: The woman with the loaves of bread slung over her shoulder was pleading with the manager of the electronics store. "I'm desperate," she said. "Do you have any light bulbs at all? No? Maybe you'll have some next week? When do they usually arrive? In the morning? In the afternoon? When?"

title: War Damage
description: One by one, President Bush's senior aides fanned out to the television studios yesterday to hail the auspicious beginning of the ground war. They spoke of "dramatic success," of divisions moving forward like "lightning," of modest resistance and "remarkably light" allied casualties. Their assessments recalled the euphoria generated by the first night of bombing in January, when a high-tech firestorm seemed to presage swift collapse of Saddam Hussein's war machine.

title: Review/Dance; A New Cast In 'Coppelia'
description: A new cast appeared in principal roles in the New York City Ballet's production of "Coppelia" on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Treasury to Offer Bills at Auction Today
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday, outstanding three-month bills were bid at a price to yield 5.96 percent, and six-month bills were bid at 5.95 percent.

title: Officials of Kuwaiti Government Move to Saudi City Nearer Home
description: Key members of Kuwait's Government in exile have moved to Dhahran, the Saudi city closest to the battle lines, to conclude final preparations for a return to their country, Kuwaiti officials said yesterday.

title: Ralston Awards Stock Bonuses
description: The stock of the Ralston Purina Company reached an elusive incentive target on Friday that places nearly $150 million worth of shares in the hands of the company's top executives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A12-17

title: ALLIES REPORT FAST ADVANCES IN IRAQ AND KUWAIT, WITH LITTLE RESISTANCE; THOUSANDS OF IRAQIS TAKEN PRISONER
description: Allied troops drove deep into Iraqi-occupied Kuwait on Sunday, reaching the outskirts of Kuwait City before nightfall, according to senior officers. To the west, powerful armored columns and a huge fleet of helicopters stormed into Iraq, heading northeast toward Basra in an effort to isolate Iraq's elite Republican Guards.

title: The Ground War and the American Economy; Boost but No Cure For the Recession
description: If the ground war ends in an allied victory in the Persian Gulf by late March, with relatively few casualties, the American economy will almost certainly receive a boost. But many economists doubt that peace by springtime would be sufficient in itself to end the recession.

title: Review/Television; Bringing Up Big Guns In Cause of Free Speech
description: Together for the first time! Starring, in alphabetical order, Tom Brokaw of NBC , Peter Jennings of ABC , Robert MacNeil of PBS, Dan Rather of CBS and Bernard Shaw of CNN ! All in a single hour! This coup of television journalism, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, is in the cause of freedom of speech.

title: School Finds Self-Rule Is No Rule
description: There is an expression among some New York City teachers that tries to capture the stream of perplexing, paradoxical or just plain maddening rules and memos that come their way almost daily.

title: Hussein's Driving Force: Mission to Save Arab World
description: In refusing the American ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein once again confounded conventional Middle East wisdom and demonstrated a messianic streak that has characterized his conduct throughout the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Gains in Europe Flights
description: European airlines were slightly more punctual last year than the year before, but only after timetables were rewritten to allow for slower travel. The 22-member Association of European Airlines said last week that 20 percent of flights were delayed by more than 15 minutes last year, compared with a record 24 percent in 1989. Last year's improvement was made despite an 11 percent rise in the number of flights, it said. But the improvement was attributed mainly to increases in scheduled flight times.

title: Nordstrom Net Up 47.5%
description: Nordstrom Inc. said on Friday that its earnings leaped 47.5 percent in its fourth quarter, which ended on Jan. 31.

title: Lewd Bumper Stickers Upheld in Georgia
description: A state law banning bumper stickers with lewd or offensive messages wrongfully restricts a motorist's right to self-expression, the Georgia Supreme Court has ruled.

title: David Herlihy, 60, A Leading Scholar On Medieval Times
description: David Herlihy, historian and professor of medieval history and former president of the American Historical Association, died Thursday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 60 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the first time since he defected from the Soviet Union in 1979, LEONID KOZLOV will dance there this week. He is leaving today with 40 other dancers to present an American dance festival at the Kremlin.

title: Silvio Conte's Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Fears Amid Prayers for Troops in Gulf
description: The faces were solemn, the prayers fervent. The ground war had begun at last, and across the New York metropolitan area yesterday people at religious observances turned to one another for comfort and spoke of personal sorrow and national sacrifice, of fears for loved ones and hopes for a swift end to bloodshed in the Persian Gulf.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two royal wives surprised the public in Britain on Wednesday by hinting separately that they did not intend to have any more children. PRINCESS DIANA, who was visiting Glasgow's Royal Maternity Hospital, told a pregnant woman that she was probably "sticking at two."

title: Books of The Times; Judging From 2 Novels' Dust Jackets
description: Silver By Ira Levin 190 pages. Bantam Books. $19.95. Wet Work By Christopher Buckley 274 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Network's Last Patriarch Offers a Survival Strategy
description: LEONARD H. GOLDENSON, who is 85 years old, believes he knows television business: The ideas are not fresh enough, the programming is not risky enough and the executives are not young enough.

title: A Guide to New Magazines Shows Widespread Vitality
description: When Dr. Samir Husni was a sixth grader in Lebanon, someone showed him the first issue of Superman comics in Arabic. "I was hooked," he said. "I started to buy first issues. I fell in love with them."

title: Omnicom Group Plans A Public Stock Offering
description: The Omnicom Group said Friday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 1.5 million shares of its common stock.

title: What Rhymes With Dirty Towel?
description: AFTER winning three Grammy Awards this week, the rap artist M. C. Hammer appeared on the NBC television program "Late Night With David Letterman." Hammer told Letterman how he worked for the Oakland A's as a clubhouse attendant when he was 11, and sported a World Series ring as proof. When Letterman asked the rapper what the players say to him when they see him now, Hammer replied, "They say, 'Remember when you used to pick my underwear up off the floor?' "

title: Fed Warned on Loans
description: The Federal Reserve should not buy commercial loans from United States banks to ease tight credit, Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said last week. If the central bank made such a move, banks would have more money to lend. That could stimulate the economy. "I don't think that is a good idea," Mr. Forrestal said after a speech here on Friday. "That gets into the allocation of credit, and that should not be the Fed's preserve."

title: Cruising Down Main Street on Imported Powder
description: PICTURE 6,200 people on skis gliding across an open field, over a lake, up and down treacherous hills, through the forests of northern Wisconsin. Waves and waves of poles, parkas and people. Picture them skiing along Main Street, past the town's only movie theater. It is a Main Street, by the way, that the town fills with snow three days before the event to facilitate better skiing.

title: China Fights an Academy Award Nomination
description: The nomination of the Chinese film "Judou" this month for an Academy Award might have been a tremendous triumph for a nation that has long sought respect from the West. Instead, in a move that says much about the state of the arts in China today, the Government has tried to suppress the film and withdraw it from consideration.

title: S.& L. Deposits Fell in October
description: Customers at the nation's savings and loans withdrew $7 billion more than they deposited in October, as the industry continued its rapid shrinkage, the Government said last week.

title: Effect of Persian Gulf News On Tokyo Markets Is Slight
description: The beginning of the ground attack in the Persian Gulf war had a modest but positive effect on financial markets here early today. Traders said a quick victory by the United States and its allies over Iraq had been anticipated by investors last week.

title: Publishers Look Beyond the Books for Advice
description: While trying to decide whether to produce books on audio cassettes, John Wiley & Sons turned to a consultant for advice. As a result, Wiley decided after a brief experiment with audio to stick with books.

title: Review/Art; Exhibition of Works By Those the Nazis Hounded and Scorned
description: By the opening in Munich in July 1937 of the gigantic "Entartete Kunst," or "Degenerate Art," exhibition that is dramatically if not completely re-created in a memorable show here at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the fate of culture under Hitler had already been spelled out.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Readers of Inc. magazine, Newsweek, U.S. News and World Report, and Working Woman may soon find themselves doing double takes, thanks to a new advertising campaign for Mita copiers and fax machines. In the print campaign, which begins in the March issue of Inc., the magazine color cover is duplicated in black and white on the next page. A banner at the bottom of the duplicate cover conveys the theme line: "Just a reminder: When you think duplication, think Mita copiers." Two 30-second Mita television spots, scheduled for broadcast in March, use clips from the films "The Wizard of Oz" and "High Noon." The $15 million campaign was prepared by Lord, Dentsu & Partners, New York. * A can of chow mein noodles that can leap off a shelf and a bottle of soy sauce that can jump from the floor onto a counter are the stars of a new television campaign for La Choy products, which begins today. The campaign, prepared by the San Francisco office of Ketchum Advertising, marks La Choy's first major television commercials since it used the theme line: "La Choy makes Chinese food swing American." * Mannington will introduce a multimillion-dollar national campaign on March 1 to promote its floor coverings. The campaign, which was prepared by Weightman Advertising, includes 15- and 30-second television spots that will be broadcast on network and cable television, as well as print ads that will run in more than 25 consumer publications.

title: Rangers Set Back Devils, 5-2
description: Under the Rangers' system of rotating goalies, Mike Richter and John Vanbiesbrouck get a game to rest after a game of work. Yesterday afternoon, Richter got a little of both when the Rangers beat the Devils by 5-2 at Madison Square Garden to end a streak without a victory at three games.

title: Coleman Ready for Challenge
description: Vince Coleman reported four days early to spring training today, in part, he said, to acclimate himself to the humidity. The conditioning strategy can't be a bad one for the fleet outfielder, for the heat of the spotlight is sure to be intense in New York upon the start of the season.

title: Reporter's Notebook; News Mediator Tight-Lipped, but Keeps Sides Talking
description: Bill Usery Jr., the private mediator trying to bridge the gap between The Daily News and its nine striking unions, is a tall man of regal bearing, with flowing white hair and a disarmingly folksy manner. He is also a poet of the noncommittal.

title: Excerpts From Address by Saddam Hussein
description: Following are excerpts from an address today over the Baghdad radio by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, as monitored and translated by The Associated Press here:

title: Market Place; Have Investors Already Made Their Bets on Victory?
description: More than a month ago, Wall Street analysts were nearly unanimous in their fears that the beginning of the allies' war against Iraq could send stock prices plunging. They were wrong.

title: Poland Reaches an Accord To Get Monetary Fund Aid
description: Poland said today that it had reached a tentative accord on a crucial three-year pact with the International Monetary Fund, and its Prime Minister asked members of the Solidarity trade union for their help in maintaining "social peace."

title: 2 West Virginia Towns Battle for F.B.I. Center
description: Two towns that share their water, their dogcatcher and even a page in the telephone directory are battling for the F.B.I.'s Fingerprint Identification Center.

title: K Mart Plans 200 TV Spots To Emphasize 'New Quality'
description: K MART, the nation's third-largest retailer, will begin one of its biggest television campaigns early next month with a series of 200 separate commercials. The ads are intended to demonstrate that the chain, known primarily as a discount store, has some things in common with fancier department stores like Nordstrom's.

title: With News Lacking, the Maps Shine
description: In other circumstances, the line might have brought a laugh. "Up to now," Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters at the Pentagon two hours after the start of the land offensive in the Persian Gulf, "we've been as forthcoming as possible about military operations." Now, he announced, regular briefings would be suspended.

title: Carril Demands Versatility
description: Pete Carril says that there is neither mystery nor mystique to Princeton basketball.

title: A Team Spawns Pride In a Land of Despair
description: IN a land of backyard satellite dishes and ceremonial huts, of horses in pasture, a modern high school sits proudly near the base of a 1,700-foot mountain the Navajos call Rock With Wings.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Bay State Gas Co., Canton, Mass., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $100 million offering of debt securities. * Caterpillar Inc., Peoria, Ill., filed for up to $500 million in debt securities.

title: No Second Career With a Van Line
description: MIKE MORGAN, the Dodger pitcher, will miss about a week of spring training because, of all things, he was being helpful to his mother. Morgan injured his hip this month while moving a television in his mother's home in Las Vegas, Nev. Morgan has remained there for therapy on a strained right hip.

title: Islanders Lose Again
description: If there is such a thing as losing gracefully, that's what the Islanders almost did tonight.

title: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance; Depositor Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Somber Voices at Home Show Emotions at War
description: A mother in Vermont with a 19-year-old son fighting in the Persian Gulf said the ground attack "had to happen."

title: Jamaican Assails I.M.F.
description: Prime Minister Michael N. Manley of Jamaica today accused the International Monetary Fund and the Inter-American Development Bank of inflexibility in refusing to allow Jamaica more time to pay its debts. Mr. Manley, who is in Venezuela on a three-day visit, said that over the last two years Jamaica had paid back more money to the two international lending institutions than it had received in new loans.

title: Transcript of Briefing in Riyadh by the American Commander
description: Following is a transcript of the briefing today by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the United States Central Command: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Review/Music; Vaughan Williams Evokes What Never Was
description: The early-music movement could find no greater enemy than Ralph Vaughan Williams. With its use of period instruments and period procedures, the first presents old music as we suppose it was. Vaughan Williams gives us old music as we wish it had been. History, after all, is what we see and hear of it right now. This gives him quite an edge.

title: Banks Press A Developer
description: Three New England banks have petitioned to force a developer and stock speculator, David F. LaRoche, to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, two of the banks said last week.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Are Killed in a Brooklyn Blaze
description: Three teen-agers died last night after they were trapped in a smoky fire that swept the top two floors of a four-story brownstone in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: Women Brace for Report on Chile's Missing
description: Viviana Diaz Caro was 21 years old when the Chilean military stormed her family's home in October 1973 looking for her father, a Communist Party official and a labor leader.

title: 'We Own This Piece,' G.I. Proclaims
description: More than 2,000 American air assault troops plunged at least 50 miles into Iraq at first light today in what officials described as the largest helicopter-borne operation in military history.

title: Avrett, Free's New Subsidiary
description: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg has set up a wholly owned subsidiary, called the Tucker Group, that will handle $60 million in billings, including the agency's $45 million account with Trans World Airlines.

title: Burmese Oil Has Attracted Exploration
description: To the Editor:

title: Dona Nobis Pacem
description: If the official accounts are believ able and they are -- the ground war has begun easily and well for the allies. We can hope for a quick military victory.

title: Gooden Changes His Pitch
description: Dwight Gooden, who hasn't thrown a pitch in earnest yet, today delivered a changeup of enormous proportions off the field.

title: INSIDE
description: Cattle Blood in People? F.D.A. Approves Tests In experiments that could lead to safer and cheaper blood transfusions, a Boston company is to begin injecting small amounts of purified cattle hemoglobin into 25 human volunteers.

title: Imperial Mayors
description: New York City's Department of Investigation finally has put the Great Headboard Caper in perspective, and it's a gloomy perspective indeed. In a report about why the city welfare agency built an $11,000 headboard for Mayor David Dinkins, the department found that city workers have been assigned to wasteful projects at Gracie Mansion for at least the last decade.

title: Washington Talk; Women in Politics Gain, But Road Is a Long One
description: Statistics on women in elective office are a classic test to separate the glass-half-empty crowd from those who marvel that the glass is half full.

title: Man Arrested in Brooklyn Tied to Killing of 3 Officers
description: A 22-year-old man arrested in Brooklyn on Saturday faces charges of killing three police officers in the Caribbean and has been linked to six other slayings, including the killing of a jewelry store manager found in a closet in Bushwick, the police said yesterday. A detective called him the "most wanted" man in Puerto Rico.

title: Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity
description: Amid reports of early successes from the battlefront, Prime Minister John Major said tonight that "things seem to be going very well indeed" for allied troops in the long-awaited ground offensive for Kuwait.

title: Sighs Drown Out War Cries as Arab Marches Against Arab
description: Along one of the many narrow lanes of the rumpled Khan al Khalili bazaar, a buyer's market in these tourist-starved times, Gamal Abdel Aziz paused at his jewelry counter today to catch the latest radio bulletins about Egyptian forces joining the ground war against Iraq.

title: The Ground War and the American Economy; Further Drop Seen In the Price of Oil
description: The ground war against Iraq is likely to result in lower oil prices, at least in the short term, experts said yesterday. Most of these experts said a short ground war was more likely to bring lower prices than a longer conflict.

title: Epidemic in Philadelphia Raises Issue of Religion vs. State's Interest
description: Even as it appears to be subsiding, the measles epidemic that has swept through two church congregations is confronting Philadelphia health officials with a painful ethical decision: whether to ask the courts to compel children to be vaccinated over the religious objections of their parents.

title: Division III Matchups
description: Stony Brook University, which won 22 of its 25 regular-season games, yesterday was made the top-seeded team in the East Region of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III men's basketball tournament. In first-round play, the University of Rochester will play at R.P.I. on Feb. 28 for the right to play at Stony Brook on March 2, the same date that Geneseo State will play at Buffalo State.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 24, 1991: MONDAY BRE Pptys Inc Detroit Edison Co General Mills Inc San Diego Gas & Elec Co Waxman Inds TUESDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Angelica Corp Bausch & Lomb Inc Brush Wellman Inc Calmat Co Century Tel Enterprises Ipalco Enterprises Inc Kellwood Co Longs Drug Stores Corp Merck & Co New England Elec Sys Talley Inds Westvaco Corp WEDNESDAY Ametex Inc Cigna Corp Deere & Co First VA Bks Inc Geico Corp Inspiration Res Corp Owens & Minor Inc Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt Co Scana Corp Stanley Wks THURSDAY Ashland Coal Inc Avery Dennison Corp Bowater Inc Burnham Pac Pptys Inc General Host Corp Sequa Corp Union Pac Corp Washington Natl Corp FRIDAY Atlantic Energy Inc NJ

title: Syracuse Nears Title Outright
description: Syracuse took a major step toward winning its first Big East Conference regular-season title outright by trouncing Pittsburgh today, 89-68.

title: From Stately Forest Hills, Anxiety Over Sex Attacks
description: Andrea Zama moved into a new apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, her arms filled with boxes but her heart filled with anxiety.

title: Tokyo's Importing More, but Who's Benefiting?
description: After a five-year battle by the United States and European nations to open Japan's markets and correct its big trade imbalances, imports have risen swiftly and Japan's huge financial surpluses have plummeted. On the surface, the changes seem substantial.

title: CBS Claims a Comeback In Reporting on the War
description: Saturday night's coverage of the start of the ground war in the Persian Gulf was a "major comeback" for the broadcast networks in general and for CBS in particular, Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said yesterday.

title: Knicks Defeat Heat For a Small Streak
description: The Knicks took their troubled act farther south tonight, and for the second time in 24 hours channeled their emotion into a winning effort, rolling past the Miami Heat, 108-92.

title: Drop in Commodity Index Ignored
description: Transfixed by war developments and forced to cope with a flood of new corporate and Treasury securities, participants in the credit markets seem to have discounted or overlooked the continued slide of commodity prices in recent weeks.

title: Welfare Cuts Will Haunt New York State in Later Social Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sporting-Goods Makers Hawk Wares at Show
description: THE sporting-goods industry did its best last week to ignore the recession. The 85,000 sports aficionados who gathered here for the industry's largest annual trade exhibit -- the Super Show -- whet their appetites on a menu of new technology sauteed in marketing hype.

title: No War Gain For Military Contractors
description: Although the ground war in the Persian Gulf is the first test in combat of several frontline weapons systems, a relatively short ground campaign would have little effect on the financial prospects of military contractors, analysts and industry executives said today.

title: 2 Divisions Said to Near Kuwait City
description: Feinting and darting along the border to confound Iraqi defenses, United States marines breached mine-sown barriers and moved toward Kuwait City today, reportedly nearing the outskirts of the occupied capital in less than 22 hours.

title: Thomas W. Gerber, Newspaper Editor, 69
description: Thomas W. Gerber, editor of The Concord Monitor for 16 years, died Friday at his home in Concord, N.H. He was 69 years old.

title: War Summary
description: Allies Race Into Iraq and Kuwait Across a 300-mile front, the biggest American-led invasion force since World War II drove deep into Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, with units of the 2d Marine Division reportedly reaching the outskirts of Kuwait City. While resistance was reported to be crumbling in several areas, senior commanders warned that the first Iraqi defenses were manned by the least capable troops. French Foreign Legionaires and other French troops teamed with British Desert Rats and three American Divisions in an armored thrust involving more than 1,250 tanks that raced more than 30 miles into Iraq in six hours.

title: Lakers Top Pistons In Overtime, 102-96
description: A. C. Green scored 4 his 14 points in overtime and the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Detroit Pistons, 102-96, today to sweep their two-game season series with the defending National Basketball Association champions.

title: Girl Accused of Trying to Poison Principal
description: An 11-year-old girl tried to poison her principal in an attempt to prevent her parents from learning that she had been in a fight at school, the police said Saturday.

title: Draft Boards Keep Mobilization-Ready
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors: Anglers Catch More Than a Few Chills
description: IF you can't wait until spring to feel a fish tugging on your line, you could go ice angling.

title: Review/Theater; Candida, a Pre-Feminist With a Way With 2 Men
description: If the gist of George Bernard Shaw's play "Candida" were reduced to a single slogan, it might read, "All men are little boys." In Shaw's serious comedy, which the Riverside Shakespeare Company is presenting at Playhouse 91, the title character, Candida Morell, is an all-knowing sexual diplomat who mediates between the two men who vie for her like a mother pacifying bratty siblings.

title: George Gobel, 71, TV Comedian And Game Show Panelist, Is Dead
description: George Gobel, the bristle-haired entertainer whose 60-year career encompassed singing on the radio, his own television show and regular appearances as a panelist on the "Hollywood Squares" game show, died yesterday at Encino Hospital in California. He was 71 years old.

title: 9-Way Race for a Seat Soon to Vanish
description: On Tuesday, voters in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn will choose from among nine candidates who have spent a total of $500,000 in a race for an office that will cease to exist before the end of the year.

title: Review/Theater; Evoking Life and Myth in West Indies
description: Jubilant calypso music washes through "The Mermaid Wakes," a fable-like family musical that celebrates the daily life and mythology of a Caribbean village. The facades of the village and its pathways have been constructed in a storybook set at the Triplex Theater, along with a painted shoreline and a dark-blue ocean that extends almost to the feet of the front-row spectators.

title: Question Box
description: Koufax's Losses to Mets

title: News from Gulf Is Good, and Cheney's Press Curbs Are Loosened
description: The Pentagon's highly restrictive news policy announced by the Secretary of Defense last night was loosened today when allied field commanders came forward with glowing reports of early success in the war zone.

title: Salary Scapegoat Shrugs Off Critics
description: In his nine years in the major leagues, Bud Black never became a well-known figure, but his name became an often-spat expletive among baseball executives this winter.

title: Putting Class Ahead of Rank
description: HAMILTON COLLEGE has won 24 consecutive games and is ranked first in the nation among Division III basketball teams. Like the University of Nevada-Las Vegas in Division I, the Continentals would be favored in the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. There's a slight problem, though. They could not receive an invitation when the pairings were announced last night.

title: Hussein Orders 'No Mercy' for Foe But Hints Iraq May Face 'Abyss'
description: In an emotional address laced with Koranic verse and invocations of Islam, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today urged his soldiers facing the advance of allied forces into Kuwait to "fight them and show no mercy."

title: N.C.A.A. and Pros at Odds Over Players
description: Bill Curry, the University of Kentucky's football coach, recalled the spring of 1989, when he was the Alabama coach and when his star linebacker Derrick Thomas was being timed and tested by National Football League scouts before the N.F.L. draft. It was a period when the N.F.L. continued to enjoy wide privileges in its on-campus scrutiny of college players.

title: Lack of Etiquette Costs Camacho a Title
description: In the end, the crucial moment in Hector Camacho's loss of his World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight title against Greg Haugen Saturday came down to an impromptu decision by the bout's referee, Carlos Padilla.

title: The Starting 6 For U.N.L.V.
description: WHEN you are Jerry Tarkanian and your team last lost about three dozen towels ago and looks as if it could qualify for the National Basketball Association playoffs, you can take risks. Wanting an appropriate means to honor the six seniors on the Nevada-Las Vegas roster in their last home game on Saturday, Tarkanian simply started all six against California-Irvine. After the tip off, play was stopped and the Runnin' Rebels were assessed a technical foul for having too many players on the court. No matter. They cruised to their 36th straight victory. The only team with even a slim chance of spoiling U.N.L.V.'s perfect regular season is New Mexico State, which faces the Rebels tonight in Las Cruces, N.M. Actually, an upset would occur tomorrow in some parts of the country. This insomniac's special won't end until 2 A.M. on the East Coast.

title: Tool Orders Fell 32.4% in January
description: New orders for American-made machine tools plunged 32.4 percent in January from an unusually high level in December, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: A Triumph of the Spirit
description: On Saturday, minutes before the U.S. deadline for leaving Kuwait, Saddam Hussein's forces fired a Scud missile at Israel. When the sirens wailed, Zubin Mehta was conducting the Israel Philharmonic with the violinist Isaac Stern at the Jerusalem theater. The audience donned gas masks, and the orchestra left the stage. But Mr. Stern, with awesome courage, returned to the stage and played a saraband for solo violin by Bach. When the all-clear sounded, the concert resumed.

title: The General Tries Not to Seem Too Confident
description: His words were cautious, warning that "the war isn't over yet," but his manner wasn't. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf seemed barely able to contain himself with delight.

title: Bronx Youth Is Shot While Handling a Gun
description: A 15-year-old Bronx boy was shot in the head last night while while he and two friends were handling a gun in a Bronx apartment, the police said.

title: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance; End Glass-Steagall
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Economic Growth
description: Japan's economy is experiencing its 51st consecutive month of expansion in February, an Economic Planning Agency official said on Friday. This is Japan's second-longest period of growth ever, trailing only the 57 months of expansion from November 1965 to July 1970. The official, briefing reporters on the agency's monthly report to economic ministers, said domestic demand showed a continuous firm trend, with strong personal consumption and capital expenditure.

title: Upper East Side Journal; Van Riders Try to Duck Mass Transit and Police
description: Early every morning, braces of finely groomed men and women in Burberry raincoats slink past doormen and nannies and stealthily pace the well-swept streets of the Upper East Side. Purposeful yet oddly furtive, they exchange fleeting glances with a man in a shabby windbreaker who lurks in a shadowed doorway, nervily alert to the approach of a transit police car. When the coast is clear, they duck across York Avenue and file silently into unmarked vans.

title: Correction
description: A news analysis article on Friday about negotiations between The Daily News and its striking unions misidentified the mediator in the negotiations. He is Bill Usery Jr.

title: Youth Held in Killing of New Jersey Charity Founder
description: A 16-year-old youth has been arrested in the beating death of a New Jersey woman whose charity work aided the suspect and his family, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Joseph Yancey, 80, Olympic Track Coach
description: Joseph Yancey, a co-founder and the first coach of the New York Pioneers track and field club and an Olympic coach, died on Friday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 80 years old,

title: Four White Lies
description: A few days ago, the world's media were certain that Iraq's acceptance of the Soviet proposal to avoid retribution meant at least this: that George Bush still had a mandate to press the air war, but could not conceivably launch a ground attack without dividing the coalition and invoking the wrath of world opinion.

title: Blaze Strikes Office Tower in Philadelphia, Killing 3
description: Three firefighters were killed today in a fire that raged for 18 1/2 hours through eight floors of a downtown office tower.

title: Thai Officers Say They'll Try To Set Vote Within 6 Months
description: The country's military commanders, who put an end to another Thai experiment with democracy on Saturday with a bloodless coup, said today that they would attempt to hold new elections under a modified constitution within six months.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis No. 1 Edberg Wins in Stuttgart: Stefan Edberg won his first title of the year and bolstered his No. 1 world ranking yesterday with a four-set victory over a fellow Swede, Jonas Svensson, in the Eurocard Classics tournament in Stuttgart, Germany. Edberg, who won, 6-2, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, broke Svensson's serve three times as he took the first set in less than 30 minutes. He had trouble with his own serve in the second and almost dropped the third set when Svensson led, 5-4. But Edberg broke for 5-5 and the match turned in his favor. The victory was worth $137,000 for Edberg, while Svensson earned $76,400. (AP) Lendl Straight-Set Victor: No. 3-ranked Ivan Lendl used precision groundstrokes and a strong serve to knock off defending champion Michael Stich, 7-5, 6-3, in yesterday's Volvo Indoor final in Memphis. The victory was the second in two weeks for Lendl, a winner at Philadelphia last week, and the 90th tournament title of his career. Lendl is 4-0 against Stich. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals Tie Penguins: Dino Ciccarelli's goal with 32 seconds left in the third period capped a comeback in which the Washington Capitals scored twice in the final 3 minutes and 35 seconds of regulation to salvage a 5-5 tie yesterday with Pittsburgh in Landover, Md. (AP) Track and Field Johnson Loses to Cuban: Ben Johnson was fast, just not fast enough. Joel Isassi of Cuba eked out a victory against the Canadian star as both were clocked in 6.54 seconds in the 60 meters at an indoor meet yesterday in Karlsruhe, Germany. Officials at the meet in the Europahalle Sports Center gave Isassi first place after studying photos of the race. The fast time is Johnson's best since coming off a two-year suspension for use of performance-enhancing drugs that cost him his Olympic gold medal and wold record for 100 meters. (AP)

title: Wrist Repaired, Connors Longs To Win Again
description: JIMMY CONNORS is 38 years old and has not played competitive tennis since October. Some people have suggested that he might be better off remaining a spectator or playing in an over-35 league. But with a reconstructed left wrist that has Connors referring to himself as somewhat bionic, he could be grunting his familiar grunt and smashing his notorious two-fisted backhand by July.

title: Accounts
description: * Chevys, a chain of Mexican restaurants based in San Francisco, to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, San Francisco, with a budget of $3.6 million. * Idaho Potato Commission to the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam, with a budget of approximately $3 million. * Sointal, a casino operator based in Algarve, Portugal, to Ayer Portugal, a subsidiary of Ayer Worldwide. Billings are estimated at $1 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "So far, the offensive is progressing with dramatic success. The troops are doing a great job. But I would not be honest with you if I didn't remind you that this is the very early stages." -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. [ A1:6. ]

title: Bishop Leo Maher, 75; Led San Diego Diocese
description: Bishop Leo T. Maher, the former head of the Roman Catholic Diocese in San Diego, died at his home on Saturday. He was 75 years old.

title: On Baseball; Quest for Extra Innings Is Hard to Resist
description: Yogi Berra probably thought he said it all when he opined "it ain't over 'til it's over."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: GERMANY Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity; Uniform Support And Hope for End
description: Germany reacted today to the beginning of the ground war by asserting its full solidarity with the anti-Iraq coalition.

title: U.S. Approves Test of Blood Substitute From Cattle
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first American tests in humans of a purified blood product from cattle. If successful, the experiments could lead to safer and cheaper blood transfusions for accident victims, war casualties and hospital patients.

title: Risk to Arteries Seen in Smoking
description: Cigarette smoking speeds deterioration of arteries that supply the brain and quadruples the risk of one kind of stroke, studies show.

title: Redmen Keep Them Guessing
description: Normally, this is the time of year a college basketball team should have a solid sense of its abilities. Yet, it is Feb. 25 and St. John's is still wondering.

title: Officials From Minorities Angered by Cuomo's Budget
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, which recommends deep cuts in social programs, has created a rift between the Governor and his minority constituents that many black and Hispanic officials regard as the worst of his tenure.

title: Avoiding New World Disorder
description: The U.S.-led coalition's rejection of any deal with Iraq and the prospect of total victory in the fast-moving ground war have fed America's confidence in its capacity to write the rules of the new world order that President Bush cited during the mounting confrontation with Saddam Hussein.

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: Will Hussein Be Ousted? While not saying it publicly, Administration officials are making it clear that the United States now considers the downfall of President Saddam Hussein attainable as an outcome of the war. Page A15. Implications for Economy

title: Sun-Hewlett Tie Expected
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company, rivals in the computer work station business, are expected to announce on Monday an alliance to develop an advanced type of computer software.

title: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance; Making Money
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: FAMILIES
description: For months now the families left behind at this vast Army base in Central Texas have been preparing themselves for the day their soldiers would go into battle.

title: Personal Trials Grow in Rhode Island Bank Crisis
description: On New Year's Day, when Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun closed 45 of the state's banks and credit unions, Ann Quinn thought she would be able to get her money in a day or two.

title: Woman Sues Over Exclusion From Park's Civil War Events
description: While many American women are serving in the Persian Gulf, some national parks will not let Lauren Cook join "living history" portrayals of Civil War battles because of her sex.

title: Gorbachev Gamble: Brokering Peace
description: If there is still some question about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's motive in initiating his Persian Gulf mediating effort, there is no mistaking his regret at its failure.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Ground War Begins

title: Review/Music; Austrian, in His Debut, Leads the Philharmonic
description: Periodically, a new performer washes up on our shores with all the trappings of record-company hoopla in his wake. In the case of the 31-year-old Austrian conductor Franz Welser-Most, for instance, who is making his New York debut leading the New York Philharmonic for two weeks, the back of the Avery Fisher Hall program booklet carries an EMI-Angel advertisement displaying not one but four Welser-Most recordings. For that matter, the program's soloist, a 16-year-old Russian violinist named Maksim Vengerov, has a record ad of his own, but for just one disk and on the obscure Biddulph label.

title: Aides Discuss Pressing For Hussein's Removal
description: Although Administration officials are not prepared to say so publicly, they are making it increasingly clear that the United States now considers the downfall of President Saddam Hussein and the elimination of his Baath Party structure not only the most desirable ending to the war but also an attainable outcome.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: FRANCE Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity; Mitterrand Calls Iraqi's Choice Fatal
description: President Francois Mitterrand said tonight that the ouster of President Saddam Hussein was not an allied objective but that Mr. Hussein had nonetheless chosen "a kind of political and military suicide" that could change the situation in Iraq and "weaken his moral, political and military authority."

title: John Hannah, 88, Who Headed Michigan State and Rights Panel
description: John A. Hannah, the former president of Michigan State University who fought world hunger and served as the first chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, died Saturday at a son's home in Kalamazoo, Mich. He was 88 years old.

title: Ford Leads in Car Layoffs
description: More than half of the 41,000 auto workers scheduled for temporary layoff this week will come from the Ford Motor Company.

title: Bridge
description: Writers about bridge tend to concentrate on the sublime, but there is also a place for the ridiculous. If a king is led, for example, in a suit in which you lack a stopper, a solemn unblock of dummy's honor from a doubleton queen or jack may deflect a naive opponent. He may reach the erroneous conclusion that you have strength in the suit.

title: Sidney Reiner, 58; Travel Agent Helped To Open Soviet Door
description: Sidney Reiner, a travel agent who led efforts to reopen the Soviet Union to American tourists during the thaw in East-West relations in the 1970's, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Battle for Kuwait
description: When the gun went off for the ground war, the allied war plan unfolded as a complex series of thrusts and feints, but with a very simple overall goal: race to the rear of the Iraqi Army and cut it off, then take it apart piece by piece.

title: Revival of Trade Talks Stirs Political Fight in U.S.
description: The agreement in Geneva last week that cleared the way for a resumption of global trade talks sets the stage here for what is likely to be one of the fiercest scraps in years between protectionists and free traders.

title: Gooden's Restless Days and Nights
description: FOR most people, getting the amount of money the Mets have offered Dwight Gooden -- $13 million -- would be like winning the lottery.

title: Lobo Fans: Fearless, Patient
description: IF there was ever any doubt about the allegiance of New Mexico fans, their dedication was illustrated after a bomb threat interrupted their game with Texas-El Paso on Saturday. Though the 18,100 fans had to evacuate the Pit and wait almost an hour while the arena was searched, there was hardly an empty seat when the game resumed. The Lobos rewarded the faithful with a 80-74 victory.

title: Los Angeles Times to Drop Some Readers
description: The Los Angeles Times, which became the nation's largest metropolitan daily last year through its aggressive expansion efforts, plans to stop selling papers in a large part of central California and in neighboring states.

title: First Chicago Revokes Credit Cards
description: The First Chicago Corporation said it had revoked thousands of credit cards held by residents of nine Northeastern states as part of a credit review of the economically weakened region.

title: For Everyone's Sake, Give the Poor More Help; Federal Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Telmex Is Planning Improvements
description: Telefonos de Mexico, the recently privatized telephone company known as Telmex, announced a three-year plan today to expand service and automate the nation's creaky telephone system.

title: 2 Leaving HarperCollins
description: Cornelia and Michael Bessie, who have published books under their own name at HarperCollins since 1981, will end their relationship with the publishing house by the end of June. No reason was given for the split, which was announced by HarperCollins last week.

title: A Celebrity Hangout at Gulfstream
description: There may be more celebrated race horses in the barns along the backstretch at Gulfstream Park these days than anywhere else in America.

title: Accounts
description: * Panasonic Co. to the Food Group, New York, for its commercial microwave oven division. Billings were not disclosed. * PHH Relocation and Real Estate Management Services Inc., Wilton, Conn., to Dickison & Hendee Advertising Inc., Westport, Conn., with a budget of more than $1 million.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; U.S. Cites 'Tremendous Success' in Kuwait Action
description: Iraqi resistance to the allied ground offensive toughened only slightly on Monday, although units of the Republican Guards swung into action, and the American command said it was achieving "tremendous success" all across the front.

title: 'Too Late; Fall Back, Baby'
description: John McLendon's voice immediately brightened when he was asked about one of his former players at Tennessee State University -- the one whose signature was his left-handed fall-away jump shot, the one they called Skull.

title: Review/Dance; New Choreography In City Ballet Finale
description: The New York City Ballet closed its season with its seventh annual benefit for the company's Dancers' Emergency Fund on Sunday night. The cause was good (help for dancers in time of crisis or need) and the twist was new: for the first time, the benefit was presented largely as a showcase for new or aspiring choreographers within the company.

title: By Design; Trendy Trench Coats
description: Trench coats are the latest classics to be given a style rehab. Not that there is anything wrong with the coats just the way they have always been. They are practical and quite dashing with their military mien. But this spring, designers in Paris and New York have taken the trench coat and cut it to fit the current mode.

title: New Look in Suits Is Loose and Light
description: Some men's wear designers are calling it the most fundamental change in suits in 20 years. In the men's business, of course, a quarter inch here or there can be a big deal.

title: The 1990 Census: California
Remember Flop by A's? La Russa Has the Answer.
description: Tony La Russa, seeking to become the first baseball manager in nearly four decades to win four consecutive pennants, has had all winter to think about it, and now he is prepared to tell his players later this week why they lost the World Series last fall in four quick games.

title: Patterns
description: Clothes Unbound

title: On War News, Networks Smile and Blush
description: Like the start of the war itself, the opening of the ground phase of the war in the Persian Gulf brought renewed attention to network news coverage.

title: A Correction: Women in State Legislatures
description: This chart appeared yesterday with an incorrect scale. (Source: Center for American Woman and Politics)

title: Bank Fraud Inquiries
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has dozens of cases pending against financial institutions, the S.E.C.'s chairman, Richard C. Breeden, told a House subcommittee today.

title: Arthur L. Richards, Diplomat, 83
description: Arthur L. Richards, a former United States Ambassador to Ethiopia, died on Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 83 years old.

title: Florence F. Schumann, A Philanthropist, 99
description: Florence Ford Schumann, a founder of a major philanthropic foundation in New Jersey and a generous contributor to health, education and community development causes, died on Friday at her winter home in Delray Beach, Fla. Mrs. Schumann, who also lived in Montclair, N.J., and Madison, Conn., was 99 years old.

title: The Price of Not Raising Tolls
description: It may not be a pleasant or popular thing to do. But that hardly justifies the reluctance of Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey to approve higher tolls on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority.

title: Lockheed Rejects Plan of Simmons
description: Counterproposals by Harold C. Simmons to a plan to limit costs in his proxy war to unseat the board of the Lockheed Corporation were rejected by Daniel M. Tellep, chairman of the big military contractor. Mr. Simmons, who owns 20 percent of Lockheed and lost an expensive proxy contest in 1990, last week accepted Mr. Tellep's proposal that both sides forgo newspaper advertisements to solicit support for their positions.

title: Jerry Mason, 77, Editor and Publisher
description: Jerry Mason, who published the photographic book "The Family of Man" and who was known as an editor and publisher of innovative picture and text books, died on Wednesday in Vineyard Haven, Mass. He was 77 years old.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "Orders have been issued to our armed forces to withdraw in an organized manner to the positions they held prior to Aug. 1, 1990." -- Baghdad radio. [ A12:1. ] "The war goes on." -- Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. [ A1:5. ]

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Republican Guards; Iraqis' Special Troops: Key to Hussein Survival
description: The Republican Guards, who might try to remain in southern Iraq under Saddam Hussein's newest withdrawal order, hold the key to the Iraqi leader's military fate and to his political survival if he is still in power once the war ends.

title: Support the Families, Too
description: Operation Desert Storm is America's first war with all-volunteer forces and the first with a large contingent of women, many in the combat zone. These developments bear heavily on families in ways that dramatize the need for reforms.

title: Jackson and N.B.A. Union to Meet
description: Mark Jackson and Charles Grantham, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, will meet tomorrow afternoon to determine a course of action in response to the Knicks' four-day suspension of their unhappy backup point guard.

title: Rent Law Fight Pitting U.S. Against New York
description: The Federal agency charged with bailing out the nation's failed savings and loan associations said yesterday that it would evict nine tenants of rent-regulated apartments from a building on East 57th Street, a move that is likely to prompt a legal fight over New York State's laws protecting renters.

title: U.S.-British Airline Talks
description: The United States and Britain agreed today to hold a sixth round of talks over transferring takeoff and landing rights at Heathrow Airport near London to United Airlines and American Airlines.

title: Phone Numbers for Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf. Army (800) 626-1440 Air Force (800) 253-9276 Marines (800) 523-2694 Coast Guard (800) 367-8724 Navy (800) 255-3808* Navy (800)732-1206+ *Immediate family members. +Other relatives and friends.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Baroness James of Holland Park, a.k.a. P. D. JAMES , has assured her peers in the House of Lords that they will not star in any of her mystery novels. "The Lords would be a wonderful setting for a crime novel," she told The Times of London last week, "but you can set such a story anywhere."

title: ARCO Approves Oilfield Spending
description: The board of the Atlantic Richfield Company approved development of the Point McIntyre oilfield in Alaska, the largest domestic oil discovery in the last decade. ARCO is co-owner of the field with the Exxon Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, which must still approve their shares of the $727 million development cost.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Exiles; Worries Dim Hopes as Kuwaiti Exiles Lose Touch With Resistance
description: Kuwaitis in exile marked their National Day yesterday with joy over what they see as their country's impending liberation. But there was deepening anxiety over atrocities that they say are taking place there.

title: Hold the Take Out
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Grieves for a Fallen Soldier
description: In some ways, Lou Ann Monroe says, the days have been a blur since the morning of Feb. 18, when a solemn Army sergeant rang the doorbell at her house on Triton Place.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Families; Leading Role of 101st Airborne Stirs Pride and Worry at Home
description: Here at the home base of the 101st Airborne Division, pride warred with apprehension among family members and retired military personnel today after news reports that the unit had penetrated more than 50 miles into Iraq and established a base to be reckoned with.

title: Tisches Reduce Shawmut Stake
description: Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of CBS Inc., and his family disclosed that they had cut their holdings in the Shawmut National Corporation, a bank holding company based in Hartford.

title: Siemens Unit Gets Solar Energy Job
description: Siemens A.G., the German electronics concern, said one of its subsidiaries had won a contract to build the world's biggest solar energy system. The system, to be built in the Sahara, will supply the Cape Verde Islands, Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritania and Senegal.

title: 51,000 Refugees to Get Year's Reprieve in U.S.
description: About 51,000 people who fled political upheavals in Kuwait, Liberia and Lebanon will be permitted to remain in the United States for at least another year, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has announced.

title: Our Towns; Biggest Brain At This College Is Not Enrolled
description: With 2,900 students, Marist College is not a big school as colleges go. Five Marists and you'd have Ohio State's freshman class. So what is a mammoth I.B.M. 3090 200 E mainframe computer doing there?

title: Sears Backed on Visa; Banks Grow Concerned
description: A Federal court has ruled that Sears, Roebuck & Company can issue Visa cards, and the move is expected to intensify competition in the credit card business, which is already being reshaped by the entry of companies other than banks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: M. F. K. FISHER is the first culinary writer to be elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. The other new members are MICHAEL GRAVES and EDWARD LARRABEE BARNES , the architects; JOHN CORIGLIANO and EZRA LADERMAN , the composers, and JANE WILSON , the painter.

title: Robert Johnson: Once Largely Myth, Now a Hit
description: Few facts about the blues singer and guitarist Robert Johnson ever surfaced; his life was heavily masked in myth.

title: TBWA Wins Carvel Account
description: The Carvel Corporation, the ice cream retailer based in Yonkers, said yesterday that TBWA Advertising Inc. had beaten its incumbent agency, Hal Riney & Partners Inc., for its $6 million advertising account.

title: Thomas Carter, 67, Who Beat A.T.& T. In Lawsuit, Is Dead
description: Thomas F. Carter, an entrepreneur who won a landmark lawsuit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. He was 67 years old and lived in Gun Barrel City, Tex.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Iraq's Kuwait Defense: 3-Tier Plan That Collapsed
description: Two days of American and allied ground assaults have thwarted Iraq's basic military strategy for holding onto Kuwait, military experts say.

title: Chemed Will Sell DuBois to Molson
description: The Chemed Corporation announced an agreement to sell its DuBois Chemicals Inc. subsidiary to the Molson Companies of Canada for $243 million. DuBois, which makes and sells institutional and industrial maintenance and cleaning products, is to be merged with Molson's Diversey Corporation subsidiary, a Toronto-based maker of cleaning products and systems, Chemed said.

title: Trying to Fill The Shortage Of Engineers
description: American contractors are expected to have a big role in rebuilding the hundreds of bridges, roads and buildings destroyed in the Persian Gulf war, further straining an industry suffering from a chronic shortage of engineers.

title: Twain Manuscript Resolves Huck Finn Mysteries
description: "This is the moment I have been waiting for," Victor Fischer said as he turned the pages of the long-lost first half of Samuel Langhorne Clemens's manuscript of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn." He was looking for the place where the author left off writing in 1876, before his three-year hiatus from what many regard as the great American novel.

title: Webb Pierce, 65, Dies; Was Country Singer
description: Webb Pierce, a flamboyant singer who dominated country music in the 1950's and 60's, died at his home here on Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: Gary Mihalic, Landscape Architect, 40
description: Gary Mihalic, a landscape architect who was chief of design for the New York City Parks and Recreation Department, died on Feb. 13 at Cabrini Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers Stun Lakers Charles Barkley scored 18 points, including a game-winning layup with 5.2 seconds left, as Philadelphia beat Los Angeles, 92-90, last night for its fifth straight victory. The lead changed hands eight times in the final 3:44, with Barkley's driving shot snapping a 90-90 tie. It was only the Lakers' third loss in their last 13 road games. The Lakers twice inbounded the ball in the final 5 seconds, but a desperation shot by Magic Johnson was partially blocked and fell short as the game ended. Armon Gilliam scored 19 points and Ron Anderson and Hersey Hawkins 15 each for Philadelphia. Byron Scott's 18 points, James Worthy's 17 and Johnson's 16 paced the Lakers, who played their fifth game in seven days, including an overtime victory over Detroit on Sunday. (AP) Hawks 96, Kings 88: Dominique Wilkins scored 31 points and had a career-high 19 rebounds as Atlanta extended its home-court winning streak to 20 games. Wilkins rallied the sluggish Hawks at the start of the fourth quarter, scoring 8 points in the first 2:11 to give Atlanta a 77-72 lead. It was the 24th consecutive road setback for the Kings, who completed a six-game road trip. Atlanta's winning streak at home is the longest in the league this year, and this one added another notch to its franchise record. Travis Mays led the Kings with 24 points, Lionel Simmons had 20 and a former Hawk, Antoine Carr, 19. Kevin Willis added 17 points and 15 rebounds for the Hawks. (AP) Suns 128, Hornets 108: Tom Chambers scored 30 points and helped spark a decisive third-quarter rally as Phoenix earned its 13th consecutive victory at home. The Suns have a 21-4 home record and haven't lost at Phoenix since Dec. 21, when they defeated San Antonio, 130-128, in overtime. (AP) COLLEGES Corchiani Sets Record Chris Corchiani became the National Collegiate Athletic Association's career assist leader and Rodney Monroe scored 31 points as North Carolina State defeated Tennessee, 90-82. In the first half Corchiani made his 961st career assist, breaking the record of Sherman Douglas of Syracuse. Corchiani added 15 points for the Wolfpack (17-8). Carlus Groves led Tennessee (9-19) with 20 points. (AP)

title: Lessons of the War
description: Nobody knows the day the war will end, whatever frantic signal Saddam Hussein is sending out. The man has lost, but the war he started will take more lives as he thrashes about to save his neck.

title: Australian Airlines
description: Australian Airlines, the Government-owned domestic carrier, is to begin talks this week with Singapore Airlines about a possible alliance. Ted Harris, chairman of Australian Air, said two executives would travel to Singapore to discuss areas like joint ticketing and catering. Mr. Harris said Singapore Airlines and the Indonesian airline Garuda had shown an interest in taking a stake in Australian Airlines.

title: Lawyer Who Vanished Returns and Is Charged
description: A lawyer accused of fleeing with $15 million of his client's funds two months ago walked unannounced into the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday morning and said he had been "laying low" after escaping from two men who he said tried to abduct him in Queens.

title: Dinkins Backs Condom Plan for Schools
description: With the fate of the proposal hanging in the balance, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday said that he favored Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's plan for making condoms available on request to high school students, even without parental consent.

title: California Painfully Faces Grim Truths of Drought
description: After five years of drought, the hills here are bleached tawny, the stream beds are dry and ground squirrels forage where cattle can no longer graze.

title: Inflation Up in Europe
description: Average unadjusted inflation in the 12 European Community countries quickened to a pace of five-tenths of 1 percent in January from one-tenth of a percent in December, the European Community's statistic agency, Eurostat, said today. The agency said consumer prices were 5.6 percent higher in January from the period a year earlier. Inflation in January was highest in Spain, where prices rose 1.2 percent, followed by Portugal with a 1 percent rise and Belgium at eight-tenths of a percent.

title: Changsha Journal; China's Castaway Babies: Cruel Practice Lives On
description: The babies in the stuffy, toasty-warm rooms of the orphanage, where hundreds of abandoned infants are brought each year, say something about Chinese social values: most are girls, the rest are handicapped.

title: Yankees Hope Cary Will Blossom
description: The comparison may sound odd, but in a sense, Chuck Cary is like a flower on the verge of full bloom. Ten seasons of careful nurturing and grooming have finally brought him here, to perhaps the crossroads of his career as a big league pitcher.

title: The Garbage Problem: It May Be Politics, Not Nature
description: GARBAGE, garbage, everywhere: images of overflowing landfills, homeless garbage scows and polluted wells have been widely interpreted as nature's way of telling us to slow down. "The devastation wrought by economic production is closely related to the amount of materials consumed," warns John E. Young, an environmental researcher at the Worldwatch Institute.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell by 10.5% in Mid-February
description: Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States continued to fall in mid-February, although the declines were not as steep as those of the last two months.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; Prisoners Surpass 25,000 and Counting
description: Thousands of Iraqi soldiers -- in some cases entire battalions -- continued to surrender to allied forces today, raising the number of prisoners to more than 25,000, coalition commanders said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 20 about the expulsion of Douglas Hann, a student at Brown University, misidentified his fraternity. It was Delta Tau Delta, not Delta Phi.

title: Marcella Markham, Featured Actress, 68
description: Marcella Markham, a Brooklyn-born actress who had stage and television careers in New York and London, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 68 years old and had homes in both cities.

title: Gorbachev Appoints New Finance Minister
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed a conservative economist today to be the new Soviet Finance Minister.

title: No Tricks and No Fads In Scaasi's Spring Line
description: "No coats," Arnold Scaasi said before his spring and summer couture show yesterday afternoon in his Fifth Avenue salon. "My customers don't need them in warm weather; they go from the doorway to the car."

title: Mexican Debt Deal May Save Jungle
description: In one of the largest private "debt for nature" exchanges yet negotiated, Mexico has accepted an agreement that would reduce its foreign debt by $4 million in return for specific Government commitments to help preserve the country's tropical rain forests and other fast-disappearing natural resources.

title: Boeing Sees Rising Sales To Airlines
description: Even as some carriers are parking airplanes because of weak business, the Boeing Company forecast yesterday that airlines will sharply increase their purchases in the next 15 years.

title: New Effort Would Test Possible Coexistence Of Oil and Rain Forest
description: CITING lifeless streams, deforested wildlife preserves and the degraded health of Indians and settlers, American and Ecuadorian environmental groups are demanding that oil companies abandon plans to expand drilling into the pristine half of Ecuador's Amazon River basin. At the heart of the debate is the question: can oil be pumped from the Amazon without damaging the rain forest?

title: POLITICAL VIOLENCE KILLS 5 IN ALBANIA
description: Another Albanian was killed Sunday night, bringing to five the number of deaths in political strife this weekend, as orthodox Communist forces, aided in some cases by the military, sought to reassert authority in various parts of the country.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about women in state legislatures misstated their percentages because of an erroneous scale. A corrected version appears today on page A21.

title: Review/Music; Juilliard's Focus Series
description: Joel Sachs can be counted on for interesting programs and even more interesting program notes. When the playing is good, too, it's almost like a bonus. Mr. Sachs has demonstrated his gifts with his Continuum new-music series and more recently with the Juilliard School's annual Focus series of 20th-century-music performances. These free concerts are overtly didactic for the audiences but especially for the performers, who are drawn from the ranks of Juilliard undergraduates.

title: Bond Prices Move Slightly Higher
