description: The early success of the allied ground offensive into Kuwait and southern Iraq was almost completely ignored in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury issues moved marginally higher and interest rates fell slightly in light trading.

title: Paul Harvey Aron, 69, Economist And Japanese Investments Expert
description: Paul Harvey Aron, an economist who was an authority on Japanese investments, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ready or Not, Knights Open Camp
description: They have a Belgian player named Daniel, whose second name is pronounced Boone by his teammates, three tight ends on a team that doesn't use one, and only eight wide receivers when they need 16 to run a good camp.

title: Oil Companies Getting After Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: German Team Shows Eastern Dominance
description: Less than two weeks from now in Seville, Spain, athletes from a once-divided Germany will compete together in a major track-and-field competition for the first time since the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo.

title: Gretzky a Part Owner Of Toronto Argonauts
description: The Los Angeles Kings' owner, Bruce McNall, his superstar center, Wayne Gretzky, and the comedian John Candy yesterday joined to purchase the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League.

title: From the Body Itself, Hope for a New Breed Of Potent Antibiotics
description: EVERY time a microbe slips into the body through the slightest cut or sore, immune cells called neutrophils in the vanguard of the defense system can engulf the interloper in a matter of seconds. And working inside each neutrophil is a potent brew of natural antibiotics that scientists only lately have identified and begun to understand.

title: Philadelphia Fire Officials Rule Out Collapse of Tower
description: Fire and safety officials said today that the 38-story building that burned here over the weekend, taking the lives of three firefighters, was perhaps irreparably damaged but in no danger of collapsing as had been feared.

title: The Flaws in Iraqi Strategy
description: In planning its defense of Kuwait, Iraqi strategists appeared to think this war would be like their last. But the allies can do things Iran never could. Military analysis, page A15.

title: In South Bronx, a Boarding School for the Homeless
description: A committee at Bronx Regional High School was distracted from global questions several years ago. The teachers were discussing plans for setting up a Peace and Social Justice Institute to introduce students to political issues -- racism, war in Central America, nuclear proliferation -- when someone added homelessness to the list of topics.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Baghdad; 'NIGHT OF HORROR' IN BAGHDAD RAIDS
description: Enormous explosions shook Baghdad overnight and again at mid-morning Monday as bombs and cruise missiles pounded the Iraqi capital, correspondents for Western news organizations there reported.

title: U.S. Unfreezes Kuwait Assets
description: The Treasury Department announced today that seven Kuwaiti banks have been authorized, starting March 18, to draw on frozen assets to settle claims made before the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2.

title: Unions See Little Chance of News Settlement
description: Some leaders of the nine unions striking The Daily News, along with the unions' chief adviser, said yesterday that after seven days of marathon negotiations, they had little hope of a settlement in their four-month strike.

title: Levi Strauss Net Up 51.2%
description: Levi Strauss Associates Inc., the jeans manufacturer, today reported strong gains in its profits for the fourth quarter and announced a stock buyback that will help keep the company in private hands.

title: San Francisco Agency for The New Yorker
description: THE New Yorker magazine awarded its $1 million advertising account yesterday to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein of San Francisco, but the significance of the assignment goes far beyond its billings.

title: California Hispanic Population Up 70%
description: California's Hispanic population grew nearly 70 percent in the last decade, the Census Bureau said today, confirming statistically what has been apparent throughout the state's economy, social structure and politics.

title: Red, White, Blue, Yellow
description: Of the two signs Americans are using to show one another their relation to the gulf war -- the yellow ribbon and the Star-Spangled Banner -- I confess that I'm cheered more by the former than the latter. The yellow ribbons make me love and respect my fellow citizens; the flags make me fear them.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Armored Column; Vast Armada Of U.S. Tanks Rolls Into Iraq
description: From the air over the scrub-covered Iraqi desert, the scene today was one of both majesty and utter menace: more than 100,000 American fighting men and their machines stretched from the border of Saudi Arabia north into the dusty horizon, deep into the core of enemy territory.

title: Tests Show Viola Has Bones Chips In Elbow
description: Frank Viola, one of the most formidable forces on a Mets staff that on paper is as potent as any in baseball, underwent a sophisticated medical examination today after complaining of discomfort in the elbow of his pitching arm.

title: Dow Finishes 1.49 Lower After Early Gains
description: Despite overwhelming signs of an allied victory in the Middle East, stocks edged down yesterday after rising sharply in the morning. Analysts said profit taking and program selling toppled the market.

title: Hershiser: The 'Ifs' Turn Into 'Whens'
description: Legend has it that the Dodgers' manager, Tommy Lasorda, looking to instill confidence in a mild-mannered, baby-faced pitcher, dubbed the prospect Bulldog and unleashed him on the National League.

title: Review/Music; Brazilian Oboist in Debut
description: The oboe can be a cantankerous, fiery instrument or one that sings with a graceful lilt. Washington Barella, a Brazilian oboist, explored both aspects of the instrument's personality at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening. Mr. Barella was a winner of the Concert Artists Guild competition last year, and the concert, his New York debut, was part of his prize.

title: Amid the Ruin, Calls for Sprinklers in Every High-Rise
description: Thousands of high-rise office buildings across the United States lack the complete sprinkler systems that engineers and fire experts call essential to prevent fires from spreading quickly through skyscrapers.

title: Keating Wins Access Ruling
description: Lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr. and his associates won access today to several volumes of Securities and Exchange Commission transcripts the agency sought to keep secret.

title: Bridge
description: In any sport or recreation it is almost inconceivable that the chief organizer of a major tournament would compete, let alone win. But it does happen, very rarely, in bridge, and did at the Long Island Regional Championships in Hauppauge, L.I. over the weekend.

title: U.S. Lists Top Pension Plans at Risk
description: The nation's 50 largest underfinanced pension plans have a potential combined shortfall of more than $14 billion, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said today.

title: Exploring The Beauty Of Chaos At Home
description: THE study of chaos, the mathematical underpinning of such seemingly erratic shapes as coastlines and clouds and such elusive processes as the weather, once required professional training and powerful computers. The mathematics is still not elementary, but now anyone with the kind of computer found in many homes and offices can experiment with the often-haunting products of chaos theory.

title: J. Franklin Ray Jr., Diplomat, 85
description: J. Franklin Ray Jr., who served in several United Nations and State Department posts after World War II, died on Friday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 85 years old.

title: Fur Industry Shrinking With No End in Sight
description: These are bitter times for those involved in trapping, dressing, making and selling furs. In a harshly symbolic blow to the industry, the Hudson's Bay Company of Canada announced recently that it was closing the last fur salons in its Bay department stores.

title: Trainer Suspended
description: The trainer Michael J. Laudano has been suspended and denied access to the Aqueduct grounds for 45 days after Heptaminol, a cardiac stimulant, was found in one of his horses.

title: Edgar M. Reilly, Curator, 75
description: Edgar M. Reilly, the curator of zoology at the New York State Museum in Albany for 30 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Old Chatham, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Smoke Billows In Oval Office
description: White House attendants forgot to open the flue tonight when they lit a fire in the Oval Office fireplace for President Bush and his national security team.

title: Business Scene; Dollar's Decline As Export Engine
description: NOT in a decade has the dollar been so weak. That means American exports should be rising, and they are. But why aren't they rising fast enough to make the nation's trade deficit disappear, as it almost did in 1980, the last time the dollar was this weak? The answer seems to be that the dollar has lost some -- maybe even a lot -- of its old magic as an engine for exports.

title: Review/Piano; Recital of Variations by Ax
description: At his piano recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Emanuel Ax chose a program that explored one of music's great motivating devices, the process of thematic transformation. In the program's first half, he played four variation sets that covered a range of styles that could not have been broader.

title: A Pace Car Made (Quickly) in U.S.
description: After protests from union leaders, snide letters from angry race fans and a surge in patriotic fervor coinciding with the Persian Gulf war, the Chrysler Corporation shifted gears today. It is yanking a Japanese-made two-seat sports car as its pick to be the pace car of the Indianapolis 500.

title: Chess
description: Who is right, the strategists who advocate ceaseless surprise or those who, like Aron Nimzovich, urge the taking of a stand and sticking to it?

title: Big Loan Is Proposed For F.D.I.C.
description: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said today that he had recommended that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation borrow $10 billion to avert the possible insolvency of the program that protects bank deposits and that the interest on the loan be paid by raising the annual contributions of banks by 18 percent.

title: Texas Executes Inmate for Supermarket Slaying
description: A man convicted of killing a supermarket customer during a robbery in 1980 was put to death by lethal injection early today hours after the Supreme Court refused to halt the execution.

title: African Art Given to Met
description: More than 150 bronze and carved-ivory sculptures from Benin, a former kingdom in what is now southern Nigeria, have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the collection of Klaus G. and Amelia Perls of New York. The museum says it is the most important gift of African art since the establishment of its Michael C. Rockefeller Wing in the late 1970's.

title: 2 Youths Shot Outside School
description: A student and a former student were shot and wounded outside their high school in Manhattan yesterday, the police said.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Judge Rejects Suit on Bias in Harvard's Hiring
description: A lawsuit filed by a group of Harvard Law School students accusing their school of discriminating against women and members of minorities in hiring and promoting faculty members has been dismissed here by a judge who ruled that the students had no standing to sue.

title: 5% Zenith Electronics Stake Is Sold to Goldstar of Korea
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it had sold nearly a 5 percent stake in the company to the Goldstar Company, the giant South Korean consumer electronics concern.

title: THAI ARMY PLEDGES GOVERNMENT SOON
description: The Thai military, which seized power on Saturday without firing a shot, said today that it would announce a provisional government in the next five to seven days.

title: Soviet Liberals Get Smart
description: Soviet liberals are far from crushed. This was evident on Sunday, when Mikhail Gorbachev allowed Boris Yeltsin's supporters to rally in Moscow and demand Mr. Gorbachev's resignation. A few days earlier, Mr. Yeltsin had gone on national television to denounce him and make the same demand.

title: INSIDE
description: Britain Now Doubts Guilt Of 6 Called I.R.A. Bombers Government prosecutors said there was not enough evidence to support the convictions of six men in a 1974 bombing case. The so-called Birmingham Six have been a cause celebre for critics of British justice as applied in Northern Ireland. Page A3. Plan to Help Bank Fund The F.D.I.C. chairman is urging that the agency borrow $10 billion and raise the premiums banks pay to aid the insurance fund. Page D1.

title: Redmen Win by Keeping Lid On Mourning and Mutombo
description: Although the college basketball season may have a long way to go in the grand scheme of things, with conference and national tournaments still to come, St. John's may have come up with its most significant victory of the regular season last night.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Review Rights Law's Use
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Reconstruction-era civil rights statute intended as a legal weapon against the Ku Klux Klan can be the basis for Federal court orders to keep abortion opponents from blocking entrances to abortion clinics.

title: Grumman Creates 4 Operating Units
description: The Grumman Corporation, the aerospace and transportation manufacturer, is consolidating its seven operating divisions into four groups to streamline management. The four new groups are aircraft, systems, allied, and data systems and services.

title: Patent Action On Software By A.T.& T.
description: A.T.& T. has quietly sent letters to a number of computer makers and software publishers informing them that they are infringing a 1985 Bell Laboratories patent that covers basic software technology for running several programs simultaneously on a computer display.

title: Rooting Out Viruses
description: COMPUTER viruses have not been in the headlines lately, but that does not mean they have gone away. They tend to pop up around days like Halloween or Friday the 13th or Easter because many of them are timed to lie dormant until a certain date.

title: G.M. in Plans On Natural Gas
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Gas Research Institute said they would spend $39 million to develop trucks that run on cleaner-burning natural gas. The auto maker and the gas-company group said production could begin by the mid 1990's.

title: Sidewalk Newsstands Are Part of the Fabric of New York Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Marinovich Seeks Help
description: Todd Marinovich asked yesterday to be placed in a drug-counseling program, and if the request is met, misdemeanor drug charges against him may be dismissed.

title: Witness's Honesty Attacked At Teacher's Murder Trial
description: The defense for Carolyn Warmus ripped into the prosecution's chief witness today, making the private investigator who has testified that he sold the defendant a gun and silencer acknowledge that lying and breaking the law were tools of his trade.

title: New Jersey Defenders Battle Death Law
description: When New Jersey reinstated the death penalty in 1982, a group of public defenders set to work to defeat it.

title: Flying, in the Face of Fear
description: Why should anyone be surprised at the dramatic downturn of air travel that began Jan. 15 with the war in the Persian Gulf? Moreover, no one should be surprised if travelers continue to avoid airplanes even after a speedy allied victory against Iraq.

title: Bavaro to Have Unusual Surgery
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' tight end, has a dead bone in his left knee, a condition that threatens his career, and will undergo unusual surgery today in which the dead bone will be replaced by a bone from a cadaver.

title: BULGARIANS BEGIN EX-LEADER'S TRIAL
description: Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's longtime Communist leader, went on trial here today on charges of misappropriating state funds and handing out apartments, foreign cars and other rewards to relatives and friends in this country's erstwhile Communist elite.

title: Joseph M. Beitel, Horticulturist, 39
description: Joseph M. Beitel, a horticultural taxonomist at the New York Botanical Garden who was an authority on ferns, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Q&A
description: Gray Overnight

title: Publishing Executive To Head Angel Records
description: Capitol-EMI Music Inc. has reached into the world of books to find a president for its Angel Records classical music label.

title: Since Lincoln, Wartime Rights Erode; Not Like Bismarck
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa to Tackle Race Gap in Education
description: In a small but potentially significant move to redress the stark learning gap between black and white children in South Africa, the white-minority Government agreed today to form a working group with prominent black educators to seek solutions to the crisis afflicting segregated black education.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Marines; Beneath a Charcoal Sky, Marine Units Roll Toward a Rendezvous
description: The trucks, laden with anti-tank missiles and tank ammunition, crept ahead one by one, as if in slow motion.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Scud Attack; Scud Missile Hits a U.S. Barracks, Killing 27
description: In the most devastating Iraqi stroke of the Persian Gulf war, an Iraqi missile demolished a barracks housing more than 100 American troops on Monday night, killing 27 and wounding 98, the American military command in Riyadh said early today.

title: Books of The Times; An Israeli Spy Retires, and Reflects
description: To Know a Woman By Amos Oz Translated by Nicholas de Lange. 262 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich . $19.95.

title: Romance Is In Again at the Box Office
description: "Ghost" and "Pretty Woman" led the way, showing that love could be very lucrative indeed at the box office. Now a flock of romantic comedies is poised to capitalize on what Hollywood sees as the moviegoing audience's continuing yearning for kinder, gentler fare.

title: Sovran Under Review
description: The C & S/Sovran Corporation, an Atlanta-based bank holding company with $51.2 billion in assets, has put its advertising account under review. Among the agencies invited to participate are the two incumbents, the Atlanta office of Ogilvy & Mather and Earle Palmer Brown/Lawler Ballard. Scott Scredon, a spokesman for the bank, declined to disclose the other agencies involved but said the bank hoped to consolidate the account with one agency.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; New G.I.'s Shake Off Vietnam Ghost
description: When the 101st Airborne Division flew into battle at dawn on Sunday, the ghost of Vietnam hovered alongside their helicopters.

title: MacLean Gets 3 Goals For Devils
description: John MacLean's trademark after scoring a goal is pumping his right fist, but it's something the leading goal scorer for the Devils has not been able to do consistently this season.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: United Nations; A Diplomatic Flurry at U.N. Falls Short of Deal on Iraq
description: The Soviet Union and Iraq asked the United Nations Security Council to declare a truce in the Persian Gulf war tonight. Moscow said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had given the order for his forces to withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait as the Council had demanded.

title: For Everyone's Sake, Give the Poor More Help
description: To the Editor:

title: War Summary
description: BAGHDAD SPEAKS OF WITHDRAWAL Baghdad radio said Iraq's armed forces had been ordered to make an orderly withdrawal from Kuwait, and Iraqi tanks and trucks were reported heading north from Kuwait. But Washington dismissed the broadcast, saying that there had been no authoritative communication of its message, and that the war would go on. ALLIES FORGE AHEAD Bombers and attack helicopters roamed ahead of advancing allied armies in southern Iraq and Kuwait as Americans reported their first contact with the Iraqi Army's vaunted Republican Guard. Saudi and Kuwaiti units backed by United States Marines and airborne troops were reported preparing for an assault on Kuwait City, while a Marine amphibious force waited offshore. To the north, the 101st Airborne Division sat astride the Guards' supply lines as two other United States Army units, the First and Third Armored Divisions, were reported closing in on the Guards from the west. For the first time in the war, the allies reported the launching of Iraqi Silkworm anti-ship missiles at allied warships off Kuwait, but no damage was reported. Baghdad reported crushing allied ground attacks, with allied troops "rolling in their blood and shame." TERRORISM: 'THE ONLY IRAQI SUCCESS' Citing the destruction of Kuwait oil wells and reports that buildings were being blown up and citizens executed in Kuwait City, an allied Central Command spokesman said that "terrorism remains the only Iraqi success to date." The top Saudi general said he hopes to bring war crimes charges against those responsible. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: In the worst Scud attack of the war, at least 27 American soldiers were killed and 98 were wounded when an Iraqi missile demolished a barracks in Saudi Arabia. Before the Scud attack, American casualties since the allied ground offensive began were listed as 4 killed and 21 wounded. From Jan. 17 to Feb. 23, 23 Americans were reported killed, 34 wounded and 9 missing. Five allied Arab soldiers were reported killed and 20 wounded in ground action. Aircraft: Four American aircraft were lost, with three of the five pilots rescued, bringing to 27 the tally of American planes lost in combat. Other allies have lost 9. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraqi troops continued to surrender en-masse, with the total now reported to about 20,000. There have been no reports from either side on the number of Iraqi dead and wounded. Armor and Weaponry: An "extremely conservative" count by American commanders listed more than 270 Iraqi tanks destroyed in two days, including 35 of their top-of-the-line T-72's. Extensive destruction of artillery batteries was also reported by the allies.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Land Mines; How U.S. Troops Destroy Or Skirt Iraq's Minefields
description: The minefields allied ground forces confronted on the offensive into Kuwait this week were penetrated with relative ease, using standard tactics and equipment. American officers said that the minefields were not as sophisticated as had been believed at first, and that American intelligence about their locations was good.

title: Indians Sign Alomar
description: Sandy Alomar Jr., the American League Rookie of the Year in 1990, yesterday agreed to a one-year contract worth $345,000 with the Cleveland Indians.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: CUNY Trustees Vote to Tighten Academic Standards for Freshmen
description: The trustees of the City University of New York voted yesterday to tighten graduation standards by requiring incoming freshmen to have completed a tough academic curriculum in high school or to take extra classes to make up deficiencies when they enter college.

title: Flake's Lawyers Call Method Of Summoning Jurors Biased
description: As jury selection began yesterday for the trial of Representative Floyd H. Flake of Queens, defense lawyers said that the pool of prospective jurors did not include enough minority-group members.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) -- Agreed to terms with Sandy Alomar Jr., catcher, and Jeff Manto, infielder, on one-year contracts.

title: Iraqi Message: 'Duty' Fulfilled
description: Following is a transcript of a statement read on Baghdad radio tonight, as translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, an agency of the United States Government:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Supply; BIG SUPPORT TRAIN IS BEHIND ASSAULT
description: Following fast on the heels of armor thrusting into Kuwait and Iraq, a vast logistical train must head into the desert to feed, fuel and arm the immense attacking armies of the alliance.

title: John Daly, Newsman, Dies at 77; Host of TV's 'What's My Line?'
description: John Charles Daly Jr. whose affable charm was the hallmark of one of television's most enduring game shows, "What's My Line ?," died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: Surface Problem with Depth
description: Scientists who thought they were using pictures of biological molecules to study molecular structure may, in fact, have been using pictures of the surface on which the molecules were placed for study, two Utah researchers contend.

title: Inside Track for Florida
description: Both National League franchises that will begin play in 1993 could be awarded to Florida cities, the league president, Bill White, said yesterday during an expansion-committee visit to Miami.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, said Joan Edelman Spero had been named executive vice president and a member of the corporate planning and policy committee. * Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc., Cincinnati, has named Susan D. Kronick senior executive vice president and director of stores.

title: Review/Television; The Story of Saddam Hussein's Rise: A Trail of Corpses
description: "The Mind of Hussein," tonight's "Frontline" profile, might have been more helpful in the years when the West was courting and supporting the Iraqi ruler, but the fascination remains. The interviews with a few people who knew Saddam Hussein when he was plotting his way to power and others who have been observing him since he achieved it are neither flattering to their subject nor reassuring for prospects of stability in the Middle East while he remains in Baghdad. The hourlong documentary can be seen at 9 on Channels 13 and 49.

title: Hewlett, Sun In Venture On Software
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company, the two leading vendors of computer work stations, today announced a joint effort to develop advanced software that will allow their computers, as well as machines made by other companies, to work together.

title: Warsaw Pact Agrees to Dissolve Its Military Alliance by March 31
description: Fatally stricken by the collapse of Soviet power in Eastern Europe, the Warsaw Pact today signed its own obituary with an agreement to dissolve the 36-year-old military alliance by March 31.

title: Fed Official's Bank View
description: A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that he expected the economy to swing out of recession, helping the troubled banking industry, by this summer if the Persian Gulf war ends soon.

title: Macy Reduces Operating Loss
description: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday reported an operating loss of $7.3 million before an extraordinary item for its second quarter ended Feb. 2, compared with a loss of $39 million in the corresponding quarter the year before.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A bronze sculpture of ROSA PARKS will go on display at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington on Thursday, joining the gallery's collection of images of Americans of historical interest. Mrs. Parks, whose refusal to move from a whites-only section of a bus in Montgomery, Ala., in 1955 helped start the civil-rights movement, is expected to attend the private presentation ceremony Thursday. She is 77 years old and lives in Detroit.

title: Review/Television; A Portrait of the Secret Star Of Soviet Success in Space
description: If the name Sergei Korolev means nothing to you, it's not your fault. The Kremlin took pains to keep him out of the public eye during the years when he was sending Soviet rockets, satellites, animals and humans into space, beating the United States every time. He is given his due in the first hour of "Russian Right Stuff," a three-hour documentary that is remarkable for the amount of once supersecret material its producers have managed to extract from Moscow. This rewarding exploration by "Nova," narrated by Stacy Keach, begins tonight at 8 on Channels 13 and 49 and continues tomorrow and Thursday at the same hour.

title: Trading No. 1 Picks for Fast Rewards
description: Willis Reed, the Nets' vice president of basketball operations, was in Richmond, over the weekend. So was Bernie Bickerstaff of the Denver Nuggets and several other general managers and scouts.

title: Since Lincoln, Wartime Rights Erode
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A12-17

title: Review/Jazz; Charlie Byrd Leads a Trio, Still Faithful to Bossa Nova
description: Almost 30 years have passed since the quintet led by the acoustic guitarist Charlie Byrd joined the saxophonist Stan Getz on a record album called "Jazz Samba," which introduced the Brazilian bossa nova to North American audiences and lighted a craze for the music that has had lasting effects.

title: Cuomo Wants to End Voting Agency as a 'Patronage Mill'
description: Ronald Reagan used to talk about the "welfare queen" who drove around town in a Cadillac. William Proxmire, the former Senator, gave out Golden Fleece awards to ridicule Government waste.

title: 5 Aboard a U.S. Helicopter Die in a Crash in El Salvador
description: A United States Army helicopter crashed in Lake Ilopango east of San Salvador today, killing the five soldiers aboard, officials said. The pilot of the UH-1H had reported mechanical trouble minutes after taking off from the Salvadoran Air Force headquarters at Ilopango, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Barton Industries, Shawnee, Okla., a maker of valves, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. * FMR Corp., Boston, a holding company, raised its stake in First Chicago Corp., Chicago, a bank holding company, to 9.98 percent after buying 676,700 additional shares for between $24.20 and $24.68 a share.

title: Holtzman Wants More Cuts to Balance Books
description: City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday that New York City should consider a range of measures from unpaid job furloughs for most city workers to wage freezes and increased productivity to help close its multibillion-dollar budget gap over the next 16 months.

title: Arbitration Case Filed Against WPP, Ogilvy
description: Bruce Beach, who resigned last month as executive vice president and managing director of Ogilvy & Mather's Chicago office, has begun an arbitration proceeding against the agency and its parent company, the WPP Group.

title: Report on U.S. Tritium Supplies Urges Delay in Restart of Reactor
description: Congressional investigators said today that plans to restart the tritium-producing reactor at the Savannah River nuclear weapons complex later this year should be delayed because there was no pressing need for the material.

title: Interferon Set to Treat Hepatitis
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation received Food and Drug Administration approval today to use alpha interferon, one of the earliest drugs produced by biotechnology, for the treatment of hepatitis C. Alpha interferon is the first treatment approved for this sometimes fatal viral infection, which causes chronic liver inflammation and can lead to cirrhosis and liver cancer.

title: Mezzo-Soprano Cancels
description: The mezzo-soprano Brigitte Fassbaender has canceled two appearances at Carnegie Hall with the Vienna Philharmonic because of illness. Tatiana Troyanos is to replace Miss Fassbaender in tonight's performance of "Lied der Waldtaube," from Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder." On Sunday, Mignon Dunn is to sing the role of Klytemnestra in a concert performance of Strauss's "Elektra."

title: Thailand Marches in Reverse
description: Saturday's military coup in Bangkok is a calamity for Thailand and a setback for U.S. interests in Southeast Asia. Washington is right to condemn the interruption of a promising democratic experiment and to suspend most U.S. aid. The new rulers have already backed off from their promise to hold elections within six months. A return to military-dominated regimes would cloud the bright future Thailand seemed to have in store.

title: Flawed 2-in-1 Protein Causes Cystic Fibrosis
description: THE protein that goes awry in cystic fibrosis, the most common lethal genetic disease among whites, is a peculiar two-in-one molecule unlike anything biologists have encountered before, scientists have reported.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Black G.I.; Blacks Are Hailed by Bush For Their Role in Military
description: Responding to complaints that there are a disproportionate number of blacks in the Persian Gulf forces, President Bush today called the American military "the greatest equal opportunity employer around" and praised black military heroes, living and dead.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Comdisco Inc., Rosemont, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $400 million in senior debt securities. COMMON STOCK

title: W. H. Taft 3d, 75, Ex-Envoy to Ireland And Son of Senator
description: William Howard Taft 3d, a former Ambassador to Ireland, died on Saturday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 75 years old.

title: New Jersey Turnpike to End Shell Oil Pact
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority voted yesterday to join a boycott against the Shell Oil Company by not renewing the company's contract to operate the turnpike's 13 service stations.

title: The U.S. Response to Iraq
description: Following is a transcript of the statement last night by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, after President Bush met with his security advisers, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: The Nylon Effect
description: SCIENTISTS have identified a significant source of the increasing amount of nitrous oxide in the atmosphere. The gas contributes to ozone destruction and the warming of the atmosphere.

title: Wallenbergs Seeking Rest of Saab-Scania
description: Sweden's leading industrial family, the Wallenbergs, offered today to buy the portion of Saab-Scania A.B. that it does not already own for nearly $2.3 billion.

title: Key Rates
Vote Yes for Condoms
description: Tomorrow the Board of Education will vote on an issue that may mean the difference between life and death for many hundreds of New York's youngsters. It will consider Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez's proposal to distribute condoms on request at 30 high schools in an effort to halt the transmission of AIDS through unprotected sexual activity. Distribution needs to be as wide and unfettered as possible to reduce the threat of AIDS to sexually active, typically heedless teen-agers.

title: Conductor Cancels
description: Franz Welser-Most, the music director of the London Philharmonic, has canceled the remainder of his debut concert series with the New York Philharmonic because of a back injury. Samuel Wong, who filled in for Mr. Welser-Most on Saturday evening, will conduct the Philharmonic tonight and, for the second of Mr. Welser-Most's two series, on Thursday, Friday, Saturday and next Tuesday. Aaron Copland's Symphony No. 3 will replace a previously scheduled work by Franz Schmidt in the second series.

title: Robert B. Downs, 87, Librarian and Author
description: Robert Bingham Downs, an author and librarian who spent his career opposing limits on the circulation of books, died Sunday at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 87 years old.

title: Ad for Drug Is Challenged
description: Genentech Inc. filed a lawsuit today in United States District Court here accusing SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. of false advertising.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: MOURNING IN NEWARK Private Robert Tally wanted to become a doctor but he lost his life to "friendly fire" in the Persian Gulf. Metropolitan News, page B4

title: Invention That Shaped the Gulf War: the Laser-Guided Bomb
description: FOR the first time in history, precision-guided bombs and missiles have played a decisive role in war, paving the way for the invasion of Kuwait and Iraq. With their help, the United States and its allies critically weakened the fourth-largest army in the world while suffering surprisingly light casualties during the month of the air war.

title: Market Place; Are Oil Stocks A Bargain Now?
description: WAR may make the world crude-oil market more volatile and uncertain than ever, but some analysts say this is a good time to buy stock in oil companies.

title: Corrections
description: The Dividends table in Business Day on Saturday misidentified a 94- cent payment by Keycorp. It was the regular dividend for Keycorp's adjustable-rate cumulative preferred stock, series A; it was not an irregular dividend.

title: Shifting of Top Duties At International Paper
description: Shifting the responsibilities at the top, the International Paper Company has named two of its three executive vice presidents to its board and announced the retirement of the third.

title: Mother Tells of Abuse That Led to Her Son's Death
description: Speaking in a barely audible monotone, a Queens woman yesterday told of the brutal beatings that she said her male companion inflicted on her 3-year-old son in the months before the child died in 1989.

title: British Move to Free 6 Linked to I.R.A.
description: A prosecutor's office said today that it believed that there was not enough evidence to support the murder convictions of six men who have each served more than 16 years in prison for the 1974 bombings of two bars in Birmingham, England, by the Irish Republican Army.

title: Review/Recital; Breadth and Depth Of Samuel Ramey
description: Perhaps the only negative effect of Samuel Ramey's recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night was that the listener came away exhausted by its virtues. Few voices at any range work as well and are used to better purpose so consistently as Mr. Ramey's.

title: Not Ready-to-Wear, But Ready to Party
description: As she settles into her second couture season, Vera Wang says she feels more secure.

title: New Uncertainties Said to Invigorate NATO
description: Just as the demise of the Warsaw Pact appeared ready to deal a symbolic blow to NATO's role as defender of Europe, the Persian Gulf war and the erosion of Soviet reforms have joined to pump new vigor into the aging Western military alliance, Bush Administration officials say.

title: Alzheimer's Researchers Close In On Causes
description: AS a result of new findings, researchers are concluding that many, if not most, cases of Alzheimer's disease have a genetic basis. This marks a dramatic switch in the understanding of the disease from just a few years ago, when many scientists estimated that no more than 10 percent of Alzheimer's cases were inherited.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Poll; Public Shows Support for Land War
description: The initial reaction of the American public to the start of the ground war against Iraq is strongly supportive, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQ ORDERS TROOPS TO LEAVE KUWAIT BUT U.S. PURSUES BATTLEFIELD GAINS; HEAVY AMERICAN TOLL IN SCUD ATTACK
description: The Baghdad radio announced tonight that Iraq had ordered its occupation army to withdraw from Kuwait, but the Bush Administration parried the move and said the war would continue.

title: Drexel Is Said to Agree To Giving Data to U.S.
description: As part of its preliminary bankruptcy settlement, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has agreed to turn over documents to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation relating to claimants' lawsuits against current and former Drexel employees, people who have been told of the deal said yesterday.

title: Trial of 2 Lawmakers Starts in S. Carolina
description: Two state legislators went on trial on bribery charges today in a case that took a new twist last week when the prosecution's top witness was indicted on drug charges.

title: Community Newspapers Preparing for Chapter 11
description: Community Newspapers Inc. announced yesterday that it would seek to reorganize under bankruptcy protection. It also ended a four-month offer to repurchase some of its bonds after some bondholders refused to accept the proposal.

title: Wool Prices Decline
description: Wool prices slid 35 percent today at the first free-market wool auctions here in 17 years. Japanese buyers, who buy 20 percent of Australia's wool, made few bids at the sales, the first since Parliament scrapped a plan that fixed the minimum wool price at the equivalent of $5.40 a kilogram because of low demand.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about a builder who headed a developmentcompany in Flushing, Queens, rendered his name and that of his organization incorrectly. He was Joseph Ciampa; he headed the Ciampa Organization.

title: Dominant Emotion: Anger at the U.S.
description: As Iraqis danced in the streets of Baghdad in response to President Saddam Hussein's speech ordering a withdrawal from Kuwait, Palestinians and Jordanians, who had been his ardent supporters, seemed stunned, bewildered and enraged today.

title: CBS Details How It Got to Kuwait City
description: CBS was able to move the first news crew into Kuwait City through a combination of careful planning and technical expertise, a CBS News spokesman said yesterday.

title: Cairo Says Pullback Is Not Compliance
description: Although delighted by the announced Iraqi retreat from Kuwait, Egypt cautioned today that Baghdad still had more to do to comply with United Nations resolutions on the Persian Gulf, including one that nullifies the annexation of Kuwait last summer.

title: Futures Bill Advances
description: A House panel approved legislation yesterday that would impose a variety of changes on futures market trading and strengthen the regulatory powers of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. But the Agriculture Committee rejected a last-minute request from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to include in the bill the Administration's plan to shift regulation of stock index futures from the commission to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bill would restrict brokers from simultaneously trading for themselves and their customers in high-volume markets. It would also tighten record-keeping of trades and increase market surveillance.

title: Tangy Cabbage Dishes: Rustic to Elegant
description: LEWIS CARROLL may have written of cabbages and kings, but cabbages and peasants is more like it.

title: Metro Datelines; 239 Voters Join Weicker's Party
description: Three months after Lowell P. Weicker Jr. won the gubernatorial election under his new Connecticut Party banner, 239 state residents have joined the party.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A18-23

title: Cuomo Bill Seeks Insurance for the AIDS Exposed
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed legislation today that would prohibit health insurers from denying coverage to people who have tested positive for the AIDS virus.

title: Opposition Chief's Statement
description: An Iranian-based Iraqi opposition leader, saying Iraqis would not accept a Western puppet regime, urged President Saddam Hussein today to surrender power "to the nation," the Teheran radio reported. The call was made by Mohammed Baqer Hakim, a Shiite Muslim cleric, who also warned coalition forces against occupying Iraq. His group, the Supreme Assembly of Islamic Revolution in Iraq, seeks an Iranian-style Islamic government in Iraq.

title: Metro Datelines; Loss of Job Linked To Persian Gulf War
description: A former Sikor sky worker says he was discharged after he refused to go to Bahrain to instruct crews there in the maintenance of a Blackhawk helicopter built for the Middle Eastern country's crown prince.

title: Iowa's Earl Fined $50 After Pleading Guilty
description: One day after pleading not guilty to a charge of simple assault on a 17-year-old girl, the University of Iowa's leading scorer and rebounder yesterday changed his mind and entered a written plea of guilty. Acie Earl was then fined $50 in Johnson County District Court in Ames, Iowa. If he had gone to trial and been convicted, the 6-foot-10-inch sophomore from Moline, Ill., would have faced a maximum penalty of 30 days in jail and a $100 fine.

title: Now It's Sandberg Playing Money Game
description: The Chicago Cubs, whose uncharacteristic off-season expenditures have elevated them to the contending status of the Mets, have also, like the Mets, developed a contract-extension problem with one of their star players.

title: Old West Idea In a New Era
description: At the mention of Saddam Hussein, the bearded man in a cowboy hat and boots ground his cigarette in an ashtray.

title: Youth Gets Maximum in 2 Drowning Deaths
description: A judge imposed the maximum sentence today on a teen-ager who had pleaded guilty to causing the deaths of two friends by pushing them off a rock into the swift waters of the Niagara River, where they drowned.

title: War Summary
description: IRAQI ARMY IN FULL RETREAT

title: Operation Puts Bavaro's Future In Doubt
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' former All-Pro tight end, underwent a bone graft on his left knee for an hour and a half yesterday. His football future remained unsettled, and his career may be over at the age of 27.

title: Ken Scott, 72, Dies; A Fashion Designer Known for Fabrics
description: Ken Scott, a fashion designer known for his fabric designs and for developing fashion shows, died yesterday at his home in Eze, France. He was 72 years old.

title: Compromise Still Uncertain On Condoms
description: On the eve of the New York City Board of Education's vote on a condom-distribution plan, the Dinkins administration, a key actor in the drama, shifted its position several times yesterday. After supporting a possible compromise, it backed off, then seemed to say it could live with one.

title: Devils' Stewart Retires
description: Al Stewart, the feisty Devils forward, walked into Lou Lamoriello's office early yesterday morning and told the president of the Devils that he was retiring effective immediately.

title: Murder Charges Dismissed In Killing of Father and Baby
description: Murder charges against a man accused of killing a father and child in Brooklyn were dismissed yesterday after prosecutors confirmed the defendant's claim that he had been working in New Jersey at the time of the murders.

title: A Study on College Closings
description: Gov. William F. Weld has set up an 11-member commission to study closing some of Massachusetts's public colleges to cut an anticipated budget deficit.

title: Ice Climber Dies in Avalanche
description: An ice climber was killed and his partner injured Sunday when an avalanche swept them off the wall of a Mount Washington ravine and they fell 2,000 feet, the authorities said. Thomas Smith, 41 years old, of Montpelier, Vt., was pronounced dead at Androscoggin Hospital in Berlin, Jean McAlister of the Appalachian Mountain Club said.

title: Surprise Pact By G.E. Unit To Buy FNN
description: CNBC, General Electric's cable news service, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the troubled Financial News Network for $105 million in cash.

title: John (Pat) Rooney, 86, Fordham Tennis Coach
description: John Jerome (Pat) Rooney, coach of the women's tennis team at Fordham University since its inception as a varsity in 1973, was found dead yesterday, apparently from natural causes, at his home in the Bronx. He was 86 years old.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS A Losing Return for Connors Jimmy Connors, coming back after a long layoff, could not scrape the rust off his game fast enough to avoid a 6-3, 6-0 pounding last night by Jaime Yzaga in the first round of the Volvo-Chicago tournament. The 38-year-old Connors had not played a match since losing to Ronald Agenor at Toulouse, France, early last October. He underwent surgery on his left wrist in November, then spent nine weeks in a cast. Connors was not sharp enough to play competitive tennis, even against the 65th-ranked Yzaga. He was broken in the fourth and eighth games and Yzaga closed out the first set on serve in the ninth game. In the second set, Connors managed to win just 7 points, "Was I nervous to play? Yeah, a little," Connors said. "But not about playing. I was nervous to see how my wrist would hold up." Connors said the loss hardly discouraged him and called his comeback effort "a day-to-day thing." He said he hoped his game would improve enough to warrant a shot at the United States Open, which he has won five times. Connors is now ranked No. 978. In another first-round match, top-seeded John McEnroe defeated Gilad Bloom of Israel, 6-2, 6-1. (AP) SKIING Girardelli Nears Fourth Title Rudolf Nierlich may have won the slalom, but the third-place finisher, Marc Girardelli, was the big winner. Girardelli, skiing despite an aching left knee, took a big step toward a record-tying fourth World Cup overall title yesterday at Oppdal, Norway, as two of his main rivals were disqualified for missing gates in the opening run. The next two World Cup races, a giant slalom and a slalom, are set for this weekend at Lillehammer, Norway, site of the 1994 Winter Olympics. Girardelli, who finished 42 hundredths of a second behind Nierlich, has had problems with his left knee since a crash in Colorado in 1984. Dr. Richard Steadman, surgeon for the United States Ski Team, rebuilt Girardelli's left knee. Girardelli added 15 points yesterday for a total of 191. Nierlich won his first slalom of the season, edging Paul Accola of Switzerland by 18 hundredths of a second as the men's tour resumed after a six-week break. (AP) N.B.A. Bulls Rout Celtics for 10th in Row Scottie Pippen scored 13 of his 33 points in a 33-12 first quarter as Chicago scored a 129-99 home-court victory over Boston, the Bulls' 10th triumph in a row. The second quarter belonged to Michael Jordan, who finished with 39 points, 18 in the period. The Bulls won their 19th straight at Chicago Stadium. The 30-point loss was Boston's worst of the season. (AP) Cavaliers 106, Pistons 103: Larry Nance scored 7 points during a span of 2:11 late in the fourth quarter and Cleveland withstood three 3-pointers by Dennis Rodman to beat Detroit, 106-103. The loss was Detroit's sixth in nine games. The Pistons were without the starting guards Joe Dumars (strained hamstring) and Isiah Thomas (injured right wrist) and the backup forward John Salley (strained back). (AP) Bucks 119, Heat 106: Dan Schayes, averaging 9.6 points a game, scored 29 to pace visiting Milwaukee. He had a season-high 31 Saturday in a victory over Cleveland. (AP)

title: Hollywood Hangout Gets a Short Reprieve
description: Hollywood's venerable Formosa Cafe has been granted a new short-term lease on life.

title: Review/Film; The Far Right, in Its Own Words and Deeds
description: "When you have to do the time," Bob Miles tells his audience, "don't regret the crime."

title: Bridge
description: Many bridge players would want, but very few are granted, a long, healthy and happy life ending suddenly at the card table. One of the few was Joel Tarlo, 84 years old, a British international expert, who died of a heart attack two weeks ago while playing in Malaga, Spain.

title: Theme Parks Offer Discounts
description: In an effort to increase attendance, MCA Inc.'s Universal Studios Hollywood said today that it would offer residents of California a $5 discount on its $22.50 admission price from March 15 to May 5.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $150 million issue of two-year notes being sold by Merrill Lynch & Company was priced yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., is offering two million convertible preferred shares at $50 a share through First Boston. The dividend yield will be 9 percent annually and the shares are convertible into common stock at $26.50 a share. The shares are noncallable for five years and are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

title: Calls for Adherence To U.N. Rulings
description: European members of the coalition against Iraq backed the United States today and said that the war against Iraq would not end until President Saddam Hussein had explicitly agreed to all United Nations Security Council resolutions regarding his invasion of Kuwait.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aegon U.S.A. Inc., Baltimore, a subsidiary of Aegon N.V., a Dutch insurance group, said one of its subsidiaries had acquired Western Reserve Life Insurance Co., Idex Distributors Inc. and Idex Investor Services Inc., from Pioneer Western Corp., a unit of Enstar Group Inc., Montgomery, Ala. Terms were not disclosed. * Contel Corp., Atlanta, a telecommunications company, said its 90 percent-owned subsidiary, Contel Cellular Inc., would purchase a rural Kentucky cellular property from an unnamed seller for undisclosed terms.

title: Atlantic City Mayor Proposes Tax Rise in '92 Budget Plan
description: Mayor Jim Whelan proposed today a $126.3 million budget for next year that would require laying off 130 municipal workers and raising taxes by more than 10 cents per $100 of property value.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We're outflanking them, outmaneuvering them and destroying them in place." -- Brig. Gen. Richard I. Neal, the American military spokesman in Saudi Arabia. [ A18:3. ]

title: Armco and Cyclops End Merger Deal
description: Two steel companies, Armco Inc. and Cyclops Industries, ended an agreement to merge, apparently after financing difficulties. The agreement had provided that Cyclops's shareholders would receive $22 in cash for each common share of Cyclops stock, for a total of about $156 million. The Alleghany Corporation, a leading Cyclops shareholder, was to acquire $100 million of a new Armco convertible preferred stock. Armco had planned to use the investment as two-thirds of the $156 million purchase price of Cyclops, and Ed Romanoff, a spokesman for Cyclops, said the deal fizzled because Armco was unable to conclude its deal with Alleghany.

title: Court Says 'Post No Bills' But Don't Pester Public
description: Citing constitutional guarantees of free speech, a state appeals court yesterday struck down a New York City ordinance that penalized people whose names appeared on fliers and advertisements that were illegally posted.

title: Critic's Notebook; Human Images Help Add Drama to War Coverage
description: Even as the war in the Persian Gulf showed signs of ending yesterday, the television war gained drama. Now, finally, human beings upstaged the maps and numbers.

title: The Fed Strategy to Ease Credit
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, is attempting to combat the leading threat to an economic recovery -- a shortage of credit -- with less stringent reserve requirements for banks, the prospect of relaxed accounting rules for shaky loans and lower interest rates.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Drop
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, but the rate of decline appeared to be easing after three weeks.

title: Dvorak House Declared A Manhattan Landmark
description: Antonin Dvorak, the great Czechoslovakian composer, wrote his most famous symphony, "From the New World," in a house on East 17th Street in Manhattan. Yesterday New York returned the favor.

title: Self-Taught Farmer, Self-Taught Cook
description: SUMMERFIELD FARM sits in the rolling Virginia hill country that climbs slowly to the Blue Ridge escarpment. Since the guns of the Civil War ceased 126 years ago, the landscape has been peaceful and bucolic, made more so by an abundance of small farms like Summerfield, where Jamie and Rachel Nicholl raise dairy cattle, veal calves, sheep and lambs, along with several hunting dogs, a couple of barnyard cats and one very active baby, Emily Deveren, born in February 1990 here in her parents' home.

title: Monrovia Journal; A Monument to War: The City of Dreadful Sights
description: One of the rarest sights in Monrovia these days is the once ubiquitous palm tree. The trees began disappearing last fall when, as starvation spread in this war-shattered capital, thousands were cut down and their edible hearts eagerly and desperately consumed.

title: Bouygues Ends Maxwell Suit
description: The French construction company Bouygues S.A., the main shareholder in the French television station TF1, last week withdrew its suit against the British publisher Robert Maxwell over his sale of a stake in the television station.

title: Miners in Ukraine Plan 1-Day Strike Over Pay
description: More than 500,000 miners in the Soviet Ukraine's Donets Basin coalfield are to stage a 24-hour strike on Friday to press demands for a 150 percent pay increase, trade union leaders said today.

title: Another Bidder Woos Child World
description: A third bidder for Child World Inc., the troubled toy retailer, emerged yesterday, but it is likely to encounter the same hurdles confronting the second bidder: courting Child World's largest shareholder and the company's suppliers and banks. Both bidders are trying to unravel an earlier deal between Child World and WC Acquisition. The two companies signed a letter of intent last week.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: OUTLOOK ON OIL: For oil-importing nations like the United States, the immediate postwar outlook is highly favorable, but the long-term picture is far more troubling, said experts at a conference on Middle East oil and security. Business Day, page D.

title: Gooden Is Getting Off To Overpowering Start
description: With all quiet on the contract front, Dwight Gooden made some noise with his fastball today. Gooden, throwing with explosive elegance, turned a brief routine workout into a fireworks display.

title: 2 Coaches Ruled Out
description: Franz Beckenbauer and Kenny Dalglish have been ruled out as possible coaches for the United States national soccer team, Alan Rothenberg, the president of the United States Soccer Federation, said yesterday.

title: Jackson Returns but Plays Little in Overtime Victory
description: With 3 minutes 34 seconds left in the third quarter last night and the Knicks ahead of the Bullets, 65-64, Coach John MacLeod sent Mark Jackson into the game. The crowd of 14,360 fans, which had been chanting, "We want Mark, we want Mark," welcomed Jackson back from his four-day suspension with a thunderous ovation.

title: At Teacher's Murder Trial, Witness Admits Infatuation
description: The private investigator who is the prosecution's major witness in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus testified under cross-examination today that he had been infatuated with her.

title: Howard E. Spragg, 73, Church of Christ Aide
description: The Rev. Dr. Howard E. Spragg, former executive vice president of the board for homeland missions of the United Church of Christ, died yesterday at his home in Deering, N.H. He was 73 years old.

title: Book Notes
description: A '93 Sequel to 'Catch-22'

title: Viola Is Facing Likelihood of Elbow Surgery
description: The word was used, even if the procedure hasn't yet been decided upon. Surgery. Frank Viola shook his head at the sound of it and crossed his fingers against the prospect.

title: Edward P. Brooks, 95, M.I.T. Dean Emeritus
description: Edward Pennell Brooks, founding dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, died Friday at his farm in Millboro Spring, Va. He was 95 years old.

title: Festival Of Arts Lowers Its Sights
description: Three years after its first mammoth extravaganza drew almost as much criticism as applause, the New York International Festival of the Arts unveiled its plans yesterday for a second, more modest cultural celebration. This year's festival will run from June 8 to 23 and will feature more than 60 performing-arts events from 23 countries in 28 sites.

title: Concerns Are Raised Over the Long-Term Outlook for Oil
description: For oil-importing nations like the United States, the immediate postwar outlook is highly favorable but the long-term picture is far more troubling, according to experts at a conference here on Middle East oil and security.

title: Corruption Trial Opens for Zhivkov
description: With defiance and self-possession, the former Communist dictator of Bulgaria, Todor Zhivkov, was in Sofia's Supreme Court today to answer corruption charges in the illegal distribution of apartments, cash and other privileges to his relatives and political minions.

title: Consumer Confidence Index Rose Slightly at Midmonth
description: Consumer confidence, which has become the most widely watched indicator of when the recession might end, rose slightly in February -- the first improvement since September -- but the rise was not enough to foster optimism that the economy might begin to recover soon, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Stock Price Falls
description: The stock of the International Business Machines Corporation dropped $3.875 a share yesterday, to $129.75, after Stephen K. Smith, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., forecast a big drop in computer spending overseas and downgraded his recommendation for I.B.M. stock. A Paine Webber survey found that nearly 300 overseas companies planned to cut spending on computers sharply.

title: U.N.L.V. Extends Streaks of Two Different Sorts
description: On Monday night, the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team survived what was expected to be its stiffest late-season test by beating New Mexico State here on the Aggies' home court.

title: Low-Fat Diet Aids Drug In Reducing Cholesterol
description: A commonly prescribed drug for lowering cholesterol is more effective in bringing cholesterol down to recommended levels when combined with a low-fat diet, a study has found.

title: Not All Anger Is Toward Iraq
description: A street corner mural that once warned residents and visitors to New York's East Village to avoid drugs now implores passers-by to shun war.

title: A Pocket Cellular Telephone
description: Fujitsu America Inc. has a new cellular telephone that fits in a shirt pocket and is the smallest and lightest portable cellular phone on the market, the company says.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boston Five Bancorp Inc., Boston, named Peter J. Blampied chairman. He will continue to serve as president and chief executive. * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, named Lance E. Disley vice president and treasurer.

title: Huge Allied Force Faces Iraq's Top Troops: Is This the Showdown?
description: A fearsome array of American and British armor lined up across southern Iraq today in preparation for what may be the decisive battle of the war against Iraq, American military officials said today.

title: 2 Share $5,000 Prize For Plays by Women
description: Cheryl West of Champaign, Ill., and Rona Monro of Edinburgh are the joint winners of the 13th annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for outstanding works by women for the English-speaking theater. Ms. West won for her play "Before It Hits Home," about the impact of AIDS on a black family; Ms. Monro won for her play "Bold Girls," which examines the lives of four women in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: G.M. Withdraws From Czech Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation has withdrawn from a deal to produce gear boxes for its Opel cars with the Slovak auto company Bratislavske Automobilove Zavody, a G.M. official said. Andrej Barcak, G.M.'s managing director for Czechoslovakia, said a deal with BAZ, sanctioned by the Slovak regional government, was off. G.M. had not yet decided where the gear box contract would go, but Austria was the front-runner among several interested countries, he said.

title: Bill to Restrict Abortions Is Defeated in S. Dakota
description: By a single vote, the South Dakota Senate today rejected a bill proposing one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the nation. The House had overwhelmingly approved the bill about two weeks ago.

title: Islanders, For Sale, Ring Up a Tire
description: The only sign of stability in a season of internal dispute and disintegration for the Islanders has been their undisputed tenancy in the Patrick Division dungeon.

title: Wagner Helped to Drive Nazis Out of Yorkville
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIED UNITS SURGE THROUGH KUWAIT; TROOPS CONFRONT ELITE FORCE IN IRAQ; BUSH SPURNS HUSSEIN'S PULLOUT MOVE American and British Troops Gird for an Iraqi Last Stand
description: Iraqi troops were in headlong retreat across most of Kuwait this morning, the American command said, and allied forces entered Kuwait City, a smoking wreck, after its Iraqi occupiers fled the capital of the nation they conquered on Aug. 2.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINUS PAULING turns 90 tomorrow, and the moment is being celebrated around California. Last night, 800 birthday guests honored him in San Francisco; tomorrow, a symposium and dinner will be held in Pasadena at the California Institute of Technology, where he spent much of his distinguished career, from 1922 to 1963.

title: Five Die in Murder-Suicide
description: A man killed his wife and three daughters at the family's home in this Mojave Desert community on Monday and then committed suicide, the authorities said today. The 39-year-old man, Roy Anderson, a NASA mechanic at Edwards Air Force Base, as well as his wife and two teen-age daughters were found shot in the head. A third daughter, 20 years old, was found stabbed to death. The police said no suicide note had been found.

title: Reviews/Music; Modern Recitals By 2 Pianists
description: In what amounted to a mini-festival of contemporary music, two fine pianists gave recitals on consecutive evenings last week at Merkin Concert Hall. On Wednesday, Lois Svard made her New York recital debut in a program that seldom transcended the narrow range from pretty to cute, with works by Hans Otte, Jerry Hunt, William Duckworth, Blue Gene Tyranny and Gyorgy Ligeti. On Thursday, Joseph Kubera, a veteran recitalist, presented a far more varied series of works by La Monte Young, Laurie Spiegel, Roscoe Mitchell, Anthony Coleman, Carson Kievman, Peter Gena, David First and Julius Eastman.

title: Beyond Fury, Cool Calculation
description: At every chance, Saddam Hussein has worked to make himself the most hated man in the world. Even apart from sacking Kuwait, he has used innocent foreigners and prisoners of war as "human shields." He poisoned the Persian Gulf with torrents of oil. And now he has turned to what President Bush rightly denounces as "the pathological destruction of Kuwait."

title: PERU CHALLENGED BY 2D INSURGENCY
description: At a time when the Government has begun to make inroads against Peru's largest and most violent guerrilla organization, the Shining Path, a newer insurgent group has begun an offensive, aimed primarily at American establishments like the United States Embassy, cultural centers and fast-food franchises.

title: New Chief Vows New Vitality at F.D.A.
description: Saying he intended to revitalize an overburdened agency, the new Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration said today that he would get tough in enforcing its regulations while seeking to approve new drugs more quickly.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States declined by 10 last week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. The Houston-based oilfield tool supplier counted 967 rigs in its latest tally, compared with 897 a year ago. The rig count traditionally falls in the first quarter of the year and continues to decline through April.

title: Review/Opera; Benackova and Rysanek in New 'Katya Kabanova'
description: It took the Metropolitan Opera 70 years to get around to Leos Janacek's "Katya Kabanova," but Monday evening's premiere went a long way toward making amends. Not in recent seasons has the company lavished more care and intelligence in assembling the talent necessary to make a new production succeed at every level. That respect for an unfamiliar work began with the casting of the leading female characters: Gabriela Benackova in the title role and Leonie Rysanek as the dour matriarch, Marfa, who represents the puritanical provincialism that Katya yearns to escape.

title: Market Place; Mortgage Banker A Popular Stock
description: AS a mortgage banker with less than sterling credit, Countrywide Credit Industries gave the appearance a year ago of being a likely victim of a credit crunch. Now Wall Street thinks it will be a beneficiary, and a new issue of common stock seems likely to be snatched up this week.

title: Electric and Magnetic Fields in the Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Other vs. Nuclear
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Are at Their Best In Victory Over Pacers
description: If the Nets performed with the same precision on other nights as they did tonight against Indiana, they would not be pondering another lottery selection in the next college draft and Byrne Meadowlands Arena would not be an empty, quiet place.

title: Senators Fear Allies Will Renege on War Payments
description: Senators from both parties complained today that United States allies were slow to help pay for the gulf war and warned high-ranking Administration officials that if combat ended in the next few days, they might be even more reluctant.

title: Twisted Hulk of Warehouse Tells a Grim Story of Death
description: Miniature American flags tucked into duffel bags and placed on the street stood guard today in front of the twisted metal girders and shards of metal -- the ghostly remains of a military barracks destroyed in a single flash on Monday by an Iraqi Scud missile.

title: Merck Approves Purchase of Stock
description: Merck & Company said its board had approved the purchases of an additional $1 billion worth of the company's common stock for its treasury. Under prior approvals between 1985 through 1990, Merck spent $2.7 billion to acquire 57 million shares of its stock on the open market.

title: Net at Central Newspapers
description: Central Newspapers Inc., which owns newspapers in Indiana and Arizona, said its earnings dropped in the fourth quarter and all of 1990 because of weak advertising and costs from employee cutbacks.

title: People
description: * Dave Tutin, Geoff Naus and Bob Nisbet have been named vice presidents and creative directors of McCann-Erickson Worldwide's International Team, its agency devoted to global advertising. * Lord, Dentsu & Partners, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam and Dentsu, announced several promotions in its New York office. They are: Pat Capetta, vice president-group account director; Larry Lue, vice president-management supervisor; Gunther Maier, associate creative director; Tom Cunniff, vice president-copywriter, and Rich Goodman, vice president-copywriter.

title: Saddam Hussein's Speech on the 'Withdrawal' of His Army From Kuwait
description: Following is a transcript of President Saddam Hussein's speech today over the Baghdad radio, as translated and distributed by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a Federal agency, via the Federal News Service:

title: Massachusetts Is Again Facing A Budget Battle
description: Gov. William F. Weld threatened today to shut down the state Government, except for vital health and public safety services, if the Massachusetts Legislature did not move quickly to erase an $850 million deficit.

title: Bonn Sets Big Tax Rise For Unity and Gulf Aid
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government agreed today to an unexpectedly large package of tax increases to help pay for German unity, as well as Bonn's contribution to the allied forces in the Persian Gulf and aid to Eastern Europe's fledgling democracies.

title: Metro Datelines; Indians Defy Court On Collecting Taxes
description: Indians scorned a United States Supreme Court ruling today allowing states to tax some goods sold on reservations, saying they would not act as tax agents for outside governments.

title: G.E. Unit's Notes Have 8.62% Yield
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, is offering $250 million in 10-year notes through Lehman Brothers, as sole manager of the underwriting.

title: Daley Is Easy Victor in Mayoral Primary
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley easily won the Democratic mayoral primary tonight with the kind of gaping margin reminiscent of the days when his father, Richard J. Daley, the longtime Mayor and Democratic boss, ruled Chicago politics.

title: Protectionism Is Like a Blockading Squadron; Import Permits
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: A sentencing hearing for CHRISTIAN BRANDO, who has admitted killing his half-sister's boyfriend, began yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. Family members including his father, MARLON BRANDO, attended to ask the court for a short sentence.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Bush Statement; Transcript of President's Words on Iraqi Retreat
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's statement this morning at the White House, as provided by News Transcripts Inc.:

title: Giant Sony TV Runs Free Ads
description: Some of the nation's biggest corporations and advertising agencies found it difficult to pass up a chance to see their wares in lights above Broadway today, particularly since it did not cost them a cent.

title: Reggie Rogers Signed
description: Twenty days after his release from prison, the defensive end Reggie Rogers began to rebuild his life yesterday by signing a contract with the American Football Conference champion Buffalo Bills.

title: Brady Says Banks Need Regulatory Relief Soon
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady warned today that a large taxpayer bailout would be required if Congress and the Bush Administration failed to reach agreement on an overhaul of the banking system.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Camacho Is Adjusting To Life in the Slow Lane
description: Hector Camacho went sashaying up and down the aisles of the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., Monday night, eliciting loud boos from the crowd.

title: Puerto Rico Sugar Corp. Prices Short-Term Offering
description: A short-term borrowing by the Puerto Rico Sugar Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Sicilian Mafia Leader Freed on Technicality
description: Michele Greco, the white-haired "godfather" of the Sicilian Mafia jailed in 1987 for life for having ordered 78 murders, was released from prison today on a legal technicality.

title: A Rare Open Election for Bangladesh Today
description: In a mood of noisy jubilation, along city streets and in country towns blanketed by posters and bunting, the people of Bangladesh are to vote on Wednesday in the most open democratic election this nation has ever known.

title: Virginia Mae Brown Dies at 67; First Woman to Head the I.C.C.
description: Virginia Mae Brown, who as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission became the first woman to head an independent administrative agency of the Federal Government, died Sunday at her home in Charleston, W. Va. She was 67 years old.

title: COLOMBIAN LEADER IS HAILED BY BUSH
description: President Bush strongly endorsed the drug policies of Colombia's President today despite the Colombian leader's new offer to negotiate the surrender of cocaine traffickers in exchange for immunity from extradition and shorter prison terms.

title: Youth Held in Beating Death of His Grandfather
description: A 17-year-old Harlem youth was arrested yesterday and accused of beating his grandfather to death Monday night during an argument over the use of a telephone, the police said.

title: Future of Philadelphia High-Rise Where 3 Died in Fire Is in Doubt
description: Fire officials continued to search today for the cause of the weekend fire that badly damaged a 38-story high-rise office building here, while engineers pondered whether the scorched and charred structure was worth rehabilitating.

title: Protectionism Is Like a Blockading Squadron; Japanese Practices
description: To the Editor:

title:
Real Estate;
A New Effort To Redevelop Harlem Site
description: ON March 8, New York City will invite builders to propose redevelopment plans for a long underutilized property on the 125th Street shopping corridor in Harlem.

title: Gert Schiff Memorial
description: A memorial service for Gert Schiff, an art historian who died on Dec. 19, is to be held at 3 P.M. Sunday at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, 1 East 78th Street. Professor Schiff was Avalon Foundation Professor in the Humanities at the institute. The speakers will include Colin Eisler, professor of fine arts at the institute; Marian Burleigh Motley, head of educational programs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Edward Sullivan, chairman of the department of fine arts at New York University, and Robert Rosenblum, professor of fine arts there.

title: Kennedy Center Opens World of Arts to Young
description: "I love blue hamburgers," 300 preschoolers and first graders shouted in unison, simultaneously spelling the sentence on their fingers in sign language.

title: Wine Talk
description: IN this country, chablis (small c variety) never really recovered from its jug wine image. For some reason, burgundy (small b variety) fared better.

title: 1990 Called Wall St.'s Worst Year
description: Wall Street firms lost as much as $500 million in 1990, the worst annual earnings performance by the securities industry in history, according to a preliminary estimate by the industry's trade association.

title: Microsoft Gets Support on New System
description: Twenty-one computer makers say they plan to use a Microsoft Corporation operating system in notebook-sized computers that use a stylus rather than a keyboard, according to the company.

title: Florida Looks at Lottery To Ease Education Cuts
description: Under proposed changes to its state lottery, Florida education officials hope that the state's financially strapped schools will finally hit the jackpot.

title: The Twains Shall Meet
description: In a letter to his London publisher in 1883, Mark Twain said, "I've just finished writing a book, & modesty compels me to say it's a rattling good one, too." Rattling good it still is -- "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," the captivating tale of a rebellious boy and a runaway slave, and a seminal work of American fiction.

title: Navy Cancels a Grumman Contract
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that the Navy had canceled its contract to modernize existing F-14 fighter aircraft. The move will save the Pentagon nearly $1 billion, and will cost the jobs of hundreds of Grumman employees, many of them on Long Island.

title: Cocom Delays Rule Change
