description: Cocom, the Western trade body that oversees high-technology exports to the former Eastern bloc nations, postponed a high-level meeting this week that was expected to loosen restrictions, trade officials said today.

title: L. L. Bean Plans Shipping Charge
description: L. L. Bean Inc. is ending its 79-year tradition of shipping merchandise free. The mail-order outdoors outfitter says it cannot afford to absorb increased delivery costs. Starting this summer, the company will add a flat $3.50 charge to each order, regardless of how much a customer buys, a spokeswoman, Catherine Hartnett, said.

title: Risk Found in Depressed Nursing Home Patients
description: Severely depressed patients in nursing homes have a sharply higher risk of dying over the course of a year than other nursing home patients, a new study has found.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LIZ SMITH is leaving WNBC-TV in New York to join "Personalities," a syndicated show by Twentieth Television, a division of Fox Inc. The program, broadcast five nights a week on 129 stations, focuses on celebrities, whom Ms. Smith has been tracking for ages.

title: North Korean Military Is Put on Combat Alert
description: The Supreme Commander of North Korea's Army today ordered all military units to take up "combat mobilization" positions, the official North Korean press agency said.

title: Japan's Gulf Vote Gives Minor Party a Big Role
description: For nearly three decades, a small political party tied to a popular Buddhist sect has been the poor cousin of Japanese politics, subsisting on crumbs dropped from time to time by the governing establishment.

title: Political Memo; Bush's War Success Confers An Aura of Invincibility in '92
description: While the war in the Persian Gulf is not over, it has produced extraordinary levels of support for President Bush and presented the Democrats with a daunting task in finding a candidate who can effectively oppose him in 1992, political professionals say.

title: Economic Scene; Greening California
description: GOV. PETE WILSON'S first priority in California's water crisis is to keep the troops marching to the same drummer: "North and South, coast and valley, urban and rural, we are in this together, and we are going to have to pull together to overcome this drought."

title: A Bold Plan for Choice In Delaware's Schools'
description: If Pete du Pont had his way, elementary and secondary schools would operate more like colleges and universities: autonomous, competitive and often selective. Students would receive tuition money from the state that they could spend at any public, private or parochial school that would accept them.

title: Books of The Times; Theorizing on War's Future as a Real One Erupts
description: The Transformation of War By Martin van Creveld 254 pages. The Free Press. $22.95.

title: Despite Their Own Problems, Donors Help Neediest Cases
description: New Yorkers have a reputation for being callous and hard. They are said to look past beggars on the streets more often than not, ignoring their jingling cups and calls for spare change.

title: Making Steel Faster and Cheaper
description: In the midst of this wide stretch of quiet farmland just west of Indianapolis, a new steelmaking process championed by Nucor Inc. is now gaining worldwide attention from steel industry executives because of its potential to make steel more cheaply and quickly.

title: Approval as Allies Press the Offensive
description: Israelis watched with delight today as American and allied forces ignored Iraq's call for a cease-fire and pressed on.

title: Webb Pierce, 65, Dies; Was Country Singer
description: Webb Pierce, a flamboyant singer who dominated country music in the 1950's and 60's, died at his home here on Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: Yellow Fever
description: A busy ski slope in Vermont recently allowed discounts on lift tickets to anyone wearing a yellow ribbon in support of the troops. All over the country, the ribbons themselves are reported to be hot items in the shops. In one community I visited, each downtown telephone pole was looped with yellow. Across America, these days, yellow ribbons are everywhere -- not just round the old oak tree but on front porches, pickup trucks, store fronts, church doors.

title: TEXAN IS EXECUTED FOR A 1980 SLAYING
description: A man convicted of killing a supermarket customer during a robbery in 1980 was put to death by lethal injection early today, hours after the United States Supreme Court had refused to halt the execution.

title: Trade Deficit Is Narrower
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit narrowed 3.1 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.4 percent in 1990 as a whole, the Commerce Department said today. The annual deficit of $108.68 billion was the smallest in seven years.

title: Heir Tracer Sues New Jersey For Data on Dormant Funds
description: An "heir hunter" wants the state to help him find relatives of bank depositors who collectively abandon millions of dollars in their accounts in New Jersey.

title: First '91 Workout For Meadow Star
description: Meadow Star, the undefeated filly champion of 1990, worked out for the first time in 1991 this morning when she breezed close to a mile in the rain at Gulfstream Park.

title: Former College Student Sentenced in Drug Case
description: A 20-year-old scholarship student at the University of Pennsylvania was sentenced to 16 years to life in prison yesterday for conviction of possessing a gun and more than 2,200 vials of crack in what the court called a Harlem drug factory.

title: Hall of Fame Selection For Veeck and Lazzeri
description: Bill Veeck, the owner who gave baseball exploding scoreboards and giveaway days and even sent a midget to bat, and Tony Lazzeri, second baseman for the Yankees during the Babe Ruth era, were elected today to the Baseball Hall of Fame by the veterans committee.

title: Robert Hall Dies at 85; Designed F5F Hellcat
description: Robert L. Hall, an aviator who designed World War II warplanes like the F4F Wildcat and F5F Hellcat that helped the Allies win the war, died on Monday at Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 85 years old and lived in Newport.

title: Sun City Journal; Staying Young With Sis, Boom, Bah
description: When the Sun City Poms take center stage in an explosion of red satin, silver sequins and blond bouffants for their "pompom" routine, complete with back flips, cartwheels and splits, the reaction is profound.

title: E-II Will Miss Interest Payment
description: E-II Holdings Inc., a retailer and the owner of the McCrory Corporation and other chains, said it would miss an $80 million interest payment due on March 1. The announcement came at the first meeting between the company and a new committee of bondholders. The interest payment is on $1.2 billion of its bonds.

title: What Next in the Gulf?
description: With military victory seemingly days away, the U.S. and its partners have plenty of ideas for establishing long-term security in the Persian Gulf, but only now begin to advance a plausible plan. After Iraq's defeat in Kuwait, what next?

title: Savoring a Scent of Victory but Wondering About When the Guns Go Quiet
description: "The way I see it, if we don't go after Hussein now, he might come back bigger and stronger later on," Reuban Parmer said today as he polished off his lunch plate at the Shanty House Restaurant.

title: Strawberry Proclaims Joy in a New Life
description: Darryl Strawberry, showing a new enthusiasm that was equal parts Billy Graham and Billy Sunday, breezed into Dodgertown today and vowed to prove he was born again as a baseball player and as a human being.

title: About New York; The Cash Motive Overcomes Fear In Fighting Crime
description: On the streets of the Bronx, there are few things a desperate person won't do for $10,000 -- even be a good citizen.

title: Bozik Leaving Pitt
description: Ed Bozik, the University of Pittsburgh athletic director, whose department is the subject of investigations into booster funds and recruiting practices, will retire on July 1.

title: California's Liquid Deficit
description: Mother Nature has dealt California a horrible drought. But the unhappy economic and environmental effects -- from reduced crops to destroyed fish populations -- are largely of human origin. The state not only failed to adapt to its desert climate; it thought it could conquer it.

title: Bail Denied for Lawyer Held on Theft Charges
description: A Manhattan lawyer charged with stealing more than $15 million from his clients was denied bail yesterday after stating that he was an innocent victim of a gigantic conspiracy masterminded by a company he called the "X Corporation."

title: A First For the Formidable Orangemen
description: It's fitting for Syracuse's head coach, Jim Boeheim, that his most challenging season off the court is rapidly becoming his most satisfying season on it.

title: Iraqis' Relief Over Retreat Tempered by War Worries
description: War-weary Iraqis responded with expressions of relief today after President Saddam Hussein's announcement that he was pulling all his troops out of Kuwait immediately.

title: Food Notes
description: Zagat Suburban New York

title: Pennsylvanians Weep For Sons Killed by Scud
description: The families of two members of an Army Reserve unit based in this small city in the western foothills of the Alleghenies learned today that their sons were among the 28 soldiers killed Monday in a Scud missile attack in Saudi Arabia.

title: Joyful Noises for New York
description: New York is many things, not all admirable, likable or even bearable. A lot of places can beat it for livability; almost any place can beat it for civility; and as for affordability -- don't ask. Even so, New York City still puts on the greatest shows on earth. Nowhere in the world is there more "live" theater than in this complex, cacophonous city.

title: Unitas Thrown For a Loss
description: What with Dwight Gooden playing king-of-the-hill to challenge Roger Clemens as the highest-paid pitcher in history, for the moment, a lot of fans want to know why athletes should make so much money.

title: Bolar Is Charged in Drug Inquiry
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company has been charged with illegally distributing adulterated generic drugs and obstructing Federal and Congressional inquiries, Justice Department officials said yesterday. If convicted of all 20 charges, Bolar, which until early last year was a leader in the generic drug industry, will face maximum penalties of $10 million.

title: Brooklyn Lawyer Defeats 8 Rivals In Special Race for a Council Seat
description: Kenneth Fisher, a 38-year-old lawyer, claimed victory last night in the special election in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IRENE DEITCH of Staten Island, on one of those never-ending multi-cinema lines, cannot avoid overhearing neighboring couples.

title: The U.N Today
description: General Assembly

title: Louisiana's New Environmental Tool: Using Taxes to Discourage Pollution
description: After taking a hard look at the financial and ecological toll from industrial development, Louisiana has imposed a new rule that ties a company's environmental record to the amount of taxes on business property the company must pay.

title: Chasing Mazda's 'Phantom' Car Account
description: ONE of the most sought-after accounts on Madison Avenue these days is for a luxury car that does not yet exist.

title: Princeton Wins 26th in Row at Home
description: Kit Mueller scored 16 points and Sean Jackson made three 3-pointers to spark a 14-4 spree at the start of the second half tonight to lead No. 21 Princeton to a 63-56 victory over Penn. The victory was the 26th in a row at Jadwin Gym for Princeton (21-2), the Ivy League champion, and kept the Tigers undefeated in 12 conference games.

title: Regents Quiz
description: Early in March, the New York State Legislature will announce its choices for three spots on the Board of Regents. The 16-member body, which the Legislature appoints by geographic district, sets educational policy and standards and also oversees licensing and discipline for 32 professions, ranging from physicians to masseurs.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Teen-Ager Is Shot and Killed Outside His Home in Queens
description: A 16-year-old Queens youth was shot in the head and killed near his home yesterday as he was returning from school with friends, the police said.

title: Kuwaitis Plan Big Restoration Effort
description: Anticipating the devastation to their homeland, Kuwaiti leaders have begun preparing for a reconstruction project that could cost as much as $100 billion. In the last few days alone, the estimated costs have soared because of reports that Iraqi troops set fire to more than 600 oil wells and to hotels and other buildings.

title: Foreign Banks Filling the Loan Gap
description: Because so many of their American competitors have been reluctant to lend, foreign bankers have been expanding their portfolios of business loans in the United States.

title: Kuwait Bank's Credit Line
description: Credit Lyonnais said today that it had signed an agreement to give the Commercial Bank of Kuwait a $160 million line of credit.

title: Saudi Envoy Warns Arabs Who Backed Iraq
description: Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States issued a warning today to Arab leaders who were sympathetic to Saddam Hussein that they must publicly recant.

title: Lokar Plans to Return
description: Marco Lokar, who refused to wear the American flag on his basketball uniform, returned to Trieste, Italy, yesterday but said he planned to play again at Seton Hall some day.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A tribute to ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER for writing all those hit musicals was organized by the Los Angeles Music Center on Monday night. MADONNA, who is to star in the film version of "Evita," gave him a statue, and lots of stars sang his songs at a fancy dinner at the Regent Beverly Wilshire hotel.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: For Arabs on Ground, Fiery Help From Skies
description: Arab armies are rolling into Kuwait with American aircraft working for them in an unusual collaboration, Western military officials said today.

title: Allies Rush to Cut Off Hussein's Elite Forces
description: Having collapsed Iraq's defensive structure in Kuwait, the American and allied forces have moved to close off escape routes for Iraqi forces south of Basra.

title: Blame Poverty for Their Learning Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge Report Warns Rotting Is Pervasive
description: Investigators for the New York City Council have found dozens of city bridges that have so deteriorated that gaping holes have opened in their decks and steel beams. Some bridges, they say, are being supported by wooden pillars that must often be replaced because homeless people are stealing them and using them for firewood.

title: Soviet, at U.N., Sides With Allies On Setting Terms for Cease-Fire
description: After pressing for a cease-fire for several days, the Soviet Union sided today with the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf war, insisting that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accept all the Security Council's demands before the fighting ends.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANKLIN A. THOMAS and FRED WILPON will get nonedible apples tonight as Brotherhood Week awards from the Association for a Better New York and 100 Black Men at a reception in Manhattan.

title: Dow Stocks Off by 23.27, To 2,864.60
description: Stocks gave ground yesterday for the fifth straight session, with weakness in I.B.M. contributing heavily to the decline.

title: Two Yanks Facing Off at Third Base
description: The temperature rose steadily toward 90 degrees the other day, but Randy Velarde kept sprinting across the outfield grass, back and forth, as if he were running a race that had no finish line.

title: Trade Talks Are Resumed
description: Ten weeks after collapsing over the question of farm subsidies, a crucial round of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade resumed here today, with no new deadline set for conclusion of the four-year-old negotiations.

title: NORMALCY RETURNS AFTER THAI COUP
description: The Thai Army is mostly off the streets now, which are themselves back to their usual state of steamy, tropical gridlock.

title: ALLIED UNITS SURGE THROUGH KUWAIT; TROOPS CONFRONT ELITE FORCE IN IRAQ; BUSH SPURNS HUSSEIN'S PULLOUT MOVE SURRENDER DEMAND
description: President Saddam Hussein today made the public commitment to withdraw from Kuwait that President Bush demanded. But Mr. Bush said the promise was inadequate, pressed for virtual surrender and ordered allied forces to continue attacking to break the Iraqi's "power and control in the Middle East."

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Former Fed Governor Named Visa President
description: How is the Visa credit-card system like the Federal Reserve? H. Robert Heller, who knows both institutions, says they have a lot in common.

title: Key Rates
Durable Goods Orders Decline 0.7%
description: The value of orders to manufacturers for "big ticket" durable goods slipped seven-tenths of 1 percent in January from the month before, the Government said today. It was the second drop in three months, but the rate of decline appeared to be slowing.

title: Prosecutor Asks Justices to Restore North Verdicts
description: The Iran-contra prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, asked the Supreme Court on Monday to reinstate three criminal convictions against Oliver L. North, the retired Marine Corps officer at the center of the affair.

title: Home-Grown Hatemongers
description: Some Americans are the victims of appalling acts of hatred. [ It ] is a sad irony if, while our brave soldiers fight aggression overseas, a few hatemongers here at home are perpetrating their own cowardly aggression. Death threats, physical attacks, vandalism, religious violence and discrimination against Arab-Americans must end.

title: Bankers Trust Layoff Plan Will Cut Hundreds of Jobs
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is in the midst of a cost-cutting program that will eliminate several hundred jobs by the end of the year, according to company officials and workers who have been laid off in the last few days.

title: Soviets Move to Re-establish Ties With South Africa
description: The Soviet Union and South Africa have agreed to open "interest sections" in each other's capitals, a sign of Moscow's support for Pretoria's steps toward dismantling apartheid, the Soviet Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Review/Dance; A Tribute for a 98-Year-Old Perfectionist
description: Hanya Holm came to New York from Germany in 1931 and opened a studio. She thereby helped make American dance history.

title: Gorbachev Denounces Radicals, Meaning Yeltsin
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused Soviet radicals today of seeking to achieve power by force and said the country could slide into civil war if their campaign was not stopped.

title: Buzz Suspends Publication After Magazine's 3d Issue
description: Buzz, a kind of West Coast Vanity Fair and one of the more ambitious magazines to start up in last year's tough economic climate, has suspended publication after three issues because it was unable to reach terms on new financing.

title: Reviews/Music; Oboist Alone And Aided
description: Blair Tindall, an oboist who plays with Orpheus, the Orchestra of St. Luke's and several other New York ensembles, played a clever, stylistically varied debut program at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon. She also brought a few notable collaborators. With the tenor Robert White, she offered Vaughan Williams's "Blake Songs," in which the oboe line serves as a commentary on the impassioned vocal line. Mr. White's voice had greater weight than it once did, and he sang the Blake texts movingly.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 12 about effects of the Persian Gulf war on Nigeria referred incorrectly to a demonstration at the United States mission in Kaduna, Nigeria. It occurred in September, not this month.

title: The Pop Life
description: Reaping the Sales

title: Hang Hussein? A Big Mistake
description: At midnight on Dec. 23, 1948, the Japanese Prime Minister, Gen. Hideki Tojo, walked up the 13 steps to a wooden platform under a blaze of lights. Ten minutes later he was dead, hanging from the end of a 7-foot-7-inch rope, a drop length precisely calculated to break his neck.

title: Grand Met Executive Gets New No. 2 Post
description: Ian A. Martin, the Scotsman who led Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s 1989 acquisition of the Pillsbury Company, has been promoted to a new No. 2 job at Grand Met. He thus becomes the heir apparent to Grand Met's feisty chairman and chief executive, Allen J. G. Sheppard, who is 58 years old.

title: Eating Well
description: COMPANIES often settle suits with governmental agencies without admitting any wrongdoing. But just the same, they agree to stop doing whatever they said they were not doing wrong and they agree to pay court costs, lawyers fees and maybe a fine. To those without legal training, it is a fascinating minuet.

title: The Rout Bush Wants A Disorderly, Humiliating Iraqi Surrender Will End Hussein's Power, Officials Believe
description: The Bush Administration is making it difficult for Iraq to end the war because it believes that only unconditional surrender can insure America's aims of eliminating Iraq as a military threat and permanently discrediting President Saddam Hussein.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Stocks closed lower on the Tokyo exchange today in slow trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 188.71 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 26,094.25.

title: Greek Diners, Where Anything Is Possible
description: IT stands like some child's sweet-tooth fantasy, a merry-go-round loaded with jumbo strawberry shortcakes, giant chocolate layer cakes, lemon meringue pies so tall they defy gravity, gooey banana cream pies, pools of coconut custard and cheesecakes as thick as bowling balls.

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: THE WAR

title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments On Random Drug Checks in Buses
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today in a case testing the constitutionality of an increasingly popular police strategy in the war on drugs: the boarding of long-distance buses to question passengers at random and to seek permission to search their luggage for narcotics and weapons.

title: Musical and Play to Close
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Aspects of Love" and "La Bete: A Comedy of Manners" by David Hirson are both to close after their Saturday evening performances, each representing a substantial loss for their producers.

title: Soviet Aide in China to Help Improve Ties
description: A Soviet official arrived in Beijing today for a four-day visit, part of a broad effort by China to improve its relations with the Soviet Union and European countries.

title: Edmond P. Garvey, 86, Ex-College President
description: Edmond P. Garvey, the founder and first president of Springfield Technical Community College in Massachusetts, died Sunday at the Holyoke Soldiers Home, a hospital in Holyoke, Mass. He was 86 years old and lived in Springfield.

title: Interest Rates on Treasuries Up
description: Credit market participants, apparently sensing that victory in the Persian Gulf will lead to a pickup in the economy and push up interest rates, sold Treasury notes and bonds yesterday. The drop in prices pushed rates higher.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: YOGURT is a tremendously popular snack food in this country, but with the exception of certain ethnic groups, people rarely use it in cooking. Part of this has to do with the way yogurt was marketed in the 1970's. Because this tart-tasting substance did not appeal to the American palate, yogurt makers decided to sweeten it with fruits and flavors. It was a hit. Some brands are so loaded with fruit and gelatin that they hardly resemble the original product.

title: Health Commissioner Is in Intensive Care
description: The New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, a pre-eminent figure in the administrations of two governors, suffered what Albany officials close to him called a severe stroke while attending a meeting in Washington on Monday. He was in the intensive care unit of a Washington hospital today.

title: Town Hopes for Peace but Is Reassured It Won't Last
description: No one in Watervliet likes war. Everyone hopes that the conflict in the Persian Gulf ends soon and that peace is restored. Just not too much peace.

title: Panel Seeks Foster Care Reform
description: A private panel of child care experts today decried what it called "a growing crisis in foster care" reflecting an increase in the demand for foster homes and a decrease in the number of available, qualified foster parents.

title: CZECHS TO RETURN SEIZED PROPERTY
description: Under a new law, Czechoslovakia will return, to the original owners or their heirs, hundreds of thousands of businesses and other properties confiscated by the former Communist Government.

title: Nominee for Drug Post Is Assailed at Hearing
description: President Bush's nominee to be the nation's chief anti-drug coordinator encountered strong attacks from some Democratic Senators today as his confirmation hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee opened in a strained atmosphere.

title: EXPERTS BACK U.S. ON RULES OF WAR
description: Specialists in military law said today that the rules of war clearly permit the United States and its allies to attack retreating Iraqi troops until they lay down their arms.

title: Protectionism Is Like a Blockading Squadron
description: To the Editor:

title: John Charles Daly Jr., the Host Of 'What's My Line?,' Dies at 77
description: John Charles Daly Jr. whose affable charm was the hallmark of one of television's most enduring game shows, "What's My Line ?," died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: France Sends Reinforcements to Riot-Torn Island
description: France sent a Cabinet minister and more police officers to the Indian Ocean island of Reunion today after eight people were killed in an outbreak of violence in the French territory.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ketchum International Inc., Pittsburgh, a unit of Ketchum Communicaitons, has formed an exclusive association with Campaign Advertising, one of the largest agencies in Hong Kong, to enable Campaign to represent Ketchum in Hong Kong.

title: Glamour and Glad-Handing At High-Fashion's Awards
description: WITH a mixture of glamour and gravity, the fashion industry gave out its annual awards Monday night. The black-tie affair at the Metropolitan Museum of Art began with cocktails and a huge crush of designers, models and celebrities in a frenzy of sequins and flashbulbs.

title: Chrysler Ends Grand Wagoneer
description: With pressure rising to focus its limited financial resources on mainstream products, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would stop producing its slow-selling Jeep Grand Wagoneer this fall.

title: LTV Near Agreement On Pension Payments
description: The LTV Corporation said today that it had completed the outline of a tentative agreement with the Federal Government that calls for the company to replenish underfunded pension plans gradually for the next 30 years.

title: INSIDE
description: Moscow Warms to Pretoria

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; BUSH HALTS OFFENSIVE COMBAT; KUWAIT FREED, IRAQIS CRUSHED
description: Declaring that "Kuwait is liberated" and Iraq's army defeated, President Bush ordered allied forces on Wednesday night to suspend offensive military operations against President Saddam Hussein's isolated and battered army.

title: Don't Bar Women From Combat; Pinups and Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: 50 Laid Off in Police Wage Dispute in Jersey City
description: Mayor Gerald McCann laid off 50 police officers this week in a contract dispute that has deepened strains between City Hall and the police in New Jersey's second largest city.

title: Don't Bar Women From Combat
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwarzkopf's Minefield
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who seemed testy today when asked if the threat from Iraqi mines was exaggerated, himself crossed a minefield in the Vietnam War, to rescue a wounded private whose leg was blown off by a mine.

title: A Spotlight on New York's Bridge Mess
description: New York City's bridges are crumbling, and so is public confidence in the Dinkins Administration's handling of the city's infrastructure crisis.

title: A New Bank President For American Express
description: The American Express Bank Ltd., an overseas instititution that caters to wealthy customers, yesterday named Steven D. Goldstein to be president and chief executive.

title: Readmission of South Africa Is Moving Up on Agenda
description: With German unification accomplished and a combined team for the 1992 Olympics now a certainty, officials of the International Olympic Committee have turned their attention to South Africa and a timetable for its readmission to the Games.

title: Ballesteros Looks for His Old Groove
description: The first round of the Doral Ryder Open today begins the Florida swing on the PGA Tour, which this year promises heightened competition as several of the world's leading players prepare to make their seasonal debuts in this country.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; Texts of Iraqi Letters to U.N.
description: Following are the text of the letter from Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq that was delivered here on Wednesday night, as translated by the United Nations from the Arabic, and the text of the letter submitted by Iraq earlier in the day:

title: Concern Voiced on Undercooked Pork
description: Although cases of the parasitic disease trichinosis have steadily declined in the United States, outbreaks last year show that it has not been eradicated and that continued vigilance is needed in cooking pork and game, health officials say.

title: Topics of The Times; Crime Does Not Play
description: A New Jersey family arrived home the other day to discover the basement window broken and camera and jewelry, including some irreplaceable heirlooms, stolen. Knowing that only one of every seven burglaries results in an arrest and never thinking the valuables would turn up again, the mother nonetheless decided to challenge the odds. She called the police and filed a report.

title: Alaska Air Leader Quits
description: Bruce R. Kennedy, chairman of Alaska Air Group, will step down in May and will be replaced by the president and chief executive of Alaska Airlines, Raymond J. Vecci. The Alaska Air Group's board announced Mr. Kennedy's retirement today.

title: The Gulfie Awards
description: Hence, loathed Melancholy! After winning the "mother of all bug-outs," a nation of mesmerized gulf potatoes must brace itself to its happy new duty: a trickle of tick-tocks (who were hero-advisers on the fateful night, and who advocated blinking); a torrent of declassified military retrospectives (print journalists will tell you what really happened on the battlefield); and a deluge of what-nexters (so you think this is a time for celebration, eh?).

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; General's 'Wild Guess': 50,000 Prisoners, So Far
description: On a day when allied forces drove Iraqi occupiers from Kuwait City and swept victoriously across the desert, thousands of soldiers were smiling, cheering and flashing V-for-victory signs -- thousands of Iraqi soldiers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROGER VADIM made his debut as a stage director last week in Paris. He is directing VICTOR LANOUX and MARIE-CHRISTINE BARRAULT, the couple who starred in the popular movie "Cousin, Cousine." In "Same Time, Next Year," a comedy by BERNARD SLADE, Mr. Vadim has a hit. The Edward VII Theater has been sold out every night and the run will continue indefinitely, the management said.

title: Allies Destroy Iraqis' Main Force; Kuwait Is Retaken After 7 Months
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Thursday, Feb. 28 - Hours before President Bush announced the conditional suspension of offensive military operations in the Persian Gulf, allied armored units trapped Iraq's vaunted Republican Guard and cut it to pieces in a ferocious tank battle that began Wednesday and raged until early this morning, American officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Formosa Plastics Corporation agreed to pay a $3.4 million penalty for improperly handling hazardous waste, the stiffest such fine in the Environmental Protection Agency's 20-year history. The Florham Park N.J., company will also treat the waste water in question at its plant in Point Comfort, Tex., about 80 miles southwest of Houston.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aicorp Inc., Waltham, Mass., a software manufacturer, named Dan Schmidt president of its European division and vice president of internal operations. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, named John T. Kirkland vice president of corporate development for consumer products.

title: U.S. SEEKS CUTOFF OF SANDINISTA AID
description: The Bush Administration plans to ask the Soviet Union to cut off aid to the Nicaraguan Army because the Sandinistas, who control the military, still wield broad political power independent of the American-backed civilian Government.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Postwar Kuwait; U.S. Corporations Win Kuwait Rebuilding Jobs
description: The rebuilding of Kuwait will not only be one of the biggest and most rapid construction programs in history, but the rehabilitation of the emirate might also be a period of overhauling the nation's economy, streamlining its bureaucracy and reshaping its work force.

title: Treasury Prices in Retreat Again
description: Prices of Treasury securities retreated again yesterday and interest rates rose, as retail investors remained on the sidelines.

title: Whirlpool Notes To Yield 9.063%
description: The Whirlpool Corporation is offering $200 million in notes that are due to reach maturity on March 1, 2003, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Originally, the note sale was to have been for $150 million.

title: Delay in New Jersey Redistricting Is Denied
description: The State Supreme Court today ordered the redrawing of New Jersey's legislative districts to proceed immediately, rejecting arguments by Democrats that the available census data discriminates against minorities.

title: A Belle of Fifth Avenue Returns, Freshened Up
description: Almost half a century ago, the Parisian House of Coty perfumery left its gracious Fifth Avenue building and abandoned 276 masterwork panes of glass to the gradual ravages of New York City grime.

title: Japan Is Wary Of Kuwait Role
description: With Kuwait's ruins still smoldering, officials and politicians have warned Japan's leading industrial giants not to be seen as economic invaders trying to grab major reconstruction contracts.

title: U.N. Chief Would Disband Truce Monitors
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar recommended today that the United Nations observer group monitoring a 1988 cease-fire between Iran and Iraq be disbanded and replaced with civilian offices in Teheran and Baghdad.

title: Nathan Perilman, Retired Rabbi Of Temple Emanu-El, Dies at 85
description: Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman, who for 41 years was the spiritual leader of Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, one of the most prominent Reform temples in the world, died yesterday at the Brandywine Nursing Home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 85 years old and had lived in Chapel Hill, N.C., since retiring in 1973.

title: War Summary
description: A CONDITIONAL CEASE-FIRE President Bush announced that the United States and its allies would suspend offensive combat operations as a midnight Wednesday, Eastern time. Adding that a permanent cease-fire was up to Iraq, he warned that hostilities would resume if Iraq fired on coalition forces or launched any Scud missiles. Mr. Bush also demanded that Iraq hand over all prisoners, assist with mine-clearing operations and comply with all relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. BUSH PROCLAIMS VICTORY President Bush said, "Kuwait is liberated. Iraq's army is defeated. Our military objectives are met." His address followed a tank battle described as the largest since World War II, in which 800 American tanks and armored vehicles, battleing 250 to 300 Iraqi tanks, reportedly defeated two Republican Guard divisions some 50 miles west of Basra. United States marines captured the Kuwait International Airport after an intense, two-day tank battle. And marines, Kuwaitis and other Arab troops rode in triumph through a devastated Kuwait City that had been occupied for seven months. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The allied commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, reported that 28 Americans had been killed in the ground war to date, not counting the 28 killed by Monday's Scud attack on a barracks in Saudi Arabia. The official tally of American deaths since the air war started six weeks ago was 79. The number reported wounded in the ground offensive was 89, bringing the total of wounded in action to 213. Five Americans were reported missing in the ground campaign, raising the total to 44. Thirteen British soldiers have been reported killed, nine of them by "friendly fire" when an American A-10 anti-tank plan mistakenly attacked two British vehicles. Thirteen Arab soldiers and two French soldiers were alos reported killed. Aircraft: General Schwarzkopf said an American F-16 airplane crashed and a helicopter of the 101st Airborne trying to rescue the pilot was shot down. The fate of the airmen in both aircraft was unknown. IRAQI FORCES Troops: General Schwarzkopf said 29 Iraqi divisions, about 300,000 soldiers, had been rendered ineffective for combat, up 8 divisions from Tuesday's report. General Schwarzkopf said there were more than 50,000 prisoners of war. Armor and Other Weaponry: More than 3,700 of an estimated 4,230 Iraqi tanks in the Kuwaiti theater of operations had been destroyed as of yesterday, General Schwarzkopf said.

title: A Case of a Missing Doorframe And Other Unsolved Mysteries
description: Over the years the Grove House, a late-Georgian house in Hackney, East London, has been shorn of most of its important features, including all but one of its original fireplaces.

title: Money Pours Into Mutual Funds
description: Encouraged by the prospect of a quick end to both the recession and the Persian Gulf war, investors have been pouring money into stock mutual funds this month. Some fund managers say that sales are proceeding at a record pace.

title: Private Cures for Public Ills
description: With very little public notice, a small miracle is taking place in America's toughest urban neighborhoods. Grass-roots entrepreneurs known as C.D.C.'s -- short for community development corporations -- are rehabilitating abandoned homes, creating commercial enterprise and organizing social services. Their aim is to succeed where government programs have often failed: reclaiming city streets from crime and economic rot.

title: Europe News Channel
description: The European Broadcasting Union said today that it planned to begin an all-news satellite television channel, called Euronews, next year. Officials said they planned to broadcast 9 hours a day in 1992 and around the clock by 1993. They said the Cable News Network's coverage of the Persian Gulf war "showed the absence of a European voice." In its effort to rival CNN, Euronews will draw on 50 European broadcasters, many of them state-financed.

title: L.A. Gear Shoe Spurs Nike Suit
description: Nike Inc. filed a lawsuit today against L.A. Gear Inc., charging its rival with incorporating a Nike-patented design in its new Catapult basketball shoe.

title: Hard-Working Meulens Gets a Shot
description: All around him, there has been a kind of slow and steady eagerness for this day to finally arrive. Now that it has, Hensley Meulens seems ready.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Iraq Issues a Call for Peace Hours Before Bush's Speech
description: Hours before President Bush announced a conditional suspension of offensive fighting today, Baghdad moved closer to capitulation, offering to relinquish all claim to Kuwait, release allied prisoners and accept responsibility for war reparations in return for an immediate cease-fire and the lifting of international sanctions.

title: Speed Skiing Is Making Strong Strides on International Front
description: Speed is what skiing is all about. Gravity pulls skiers downhill on a slippery surface and they try to control their descent by turning and maneuvering their skis.

title: U.S. Management Program for East Europe
description: The Bush Administration announced today that it would sponsor American-style management training and instruction in market economics for East European countries over a three-year period.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Kuwait; For a Jubilant Crowd in Kuwait City, It's Victory Signs, Tears and Kisses
description: Although the inky smoke from burning oilfields formed a pall overhead, the people of Kuwait City lined their streets in jubilation today waving Kuwaiti flags, flashing victory signs, crying and often kissing those they took to be members of the allied force that captured the city in the last 24 hours.

title: Westinghouse Revises Results to a Loss
description: Reacting to losses in real estate, "junk bonds" and leveraged buyouts, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would write off $975 million of losses in its finance subsidiary. As a result, it slashed its previously reported fourth-quarter profit of $284 million, or 97 cents a share, to a loss of $449 million.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Commander's Briefing; Excerpts From Schwarzkopf News Conference on Gulf War
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference today by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf: OPENING STATEMENT

title: America's New Combat Culture
description: Iraq lost the war because of Saddam Hussein's military incompetence and the shock of the allies' excellence. Iraq was doomed because its backward-looking forces clashed with America's new military culture and competence. The bad news is that if the military budget is cut in accordance with present plans, that competence will suffer and our ability to resist aggression will be hurt.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The White House; Transcript of President's Address on the Gulf War
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address from the Oval Office last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: BRIEFS
description: * CCL Industries said it would acquire all the outstanding shares of Kolmar Laboratories Inc., Port Jervis, N.Y., a cosmetics and toiletries company, for $43 million. * CMS Energy Corp., Dearborn, Mich., an electricity and natural-gas company, said it had taken a charge of $745 million, or $9.16 a share, against its 1990 earnings.

title: Banc One Seeking New England Bank
description: The Banc One Corporation plans to bid for all of the Bank of New England Corporation but would also be interested in buying a bank in the Washington, D.C., area, Banc One's chairman and chief executive, John B. McCoy, said. But he said the banking company had held no talks with anyone in the Washington area.

title: Reward for Parental Involvement Is $100
description: Patricia McTyer was tired of seeing her second grader's afternoons slip away in front of the television. Jannie Dixon wanted to help her 7-year-old granddaughter learn to share.

title: Review/Dance; A Legendary Antiwar Ballet of 1932
description: The Joffrey Ballet is back in New York. This was hardly an idea that could be taken for granted nearly a year ago, when an internal crisis threatened to tear the company apart or destroy it altogether.

title: Hopes Rise for Spending Rebound as End of War Is Seen
description: WITH the end of the Middle East war in sight, once-pessimistic agency executives are almost giddy, anticipating a healthy surge in advertising spending.

title: Fellowship Awards in Art
description: A grant of $892,000 to establish a series of $15,000 fellowship awards for doctoral candidates in the field of American art was announced yesterday by the Henry Luce Foundation of New York. The grants are to be administered by the American Council of Learned Societies. Ten awards are to be made each year for five years.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Families; Scud's Lethal Hit Takes First 3 Female Soldiers
description: Two women, among the first American female soldiers killed in the Persian Gulf war, died with eight other Reservists based here in a Scud missile attack in Saudi Arabia, the Army said today.

title: Review/Opera; A Giannini Rarity for Radio Done on Concert Stage
description: The politics of musical style being what they are, the operas of Vittorio Giannini may be due a comeback. As composers scramble to retreat from the trenches of the avant-garde back to the relative comforts of major and minor chords, they might look at this elegant American reactionary of the 1930's for a few pointers.

title: Reviews/Music; The Tipica Sound of Cuba
description: It was clear from the first few notes played at S.O.B.'s on Friday night that Orquesta Miami Aragon is different from most of the Latin groups working the circuit. Where most of the younger Latin bands playing Cuban or Puerto Rican styles have assimilated new technology in the form of electric keyboards, and intensified and speeded up their rhythms, Orquesta Miami Aragon played a relaxed, gracious style that exuded a type of Saturday-night ease that's mostly been lost. Using an acoustic piano, and setting up riffs with two singers, three percussionists and a violin (the rest of the string section, another violinist and a cellist, couldn't make the show), the band swung hard through salsa pieces, older tunes, cha-chas and mambos.

title: Ford to Announce Cost-Cutting Effort
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would introduce a cost-cutting plan on Thursday, feeding speculation that the nation's No. 2 car maker will trim back its staff of 52,000 salaried employees. Ford's chairman, Harold A. Poling, will announce the cuts, a spokesman, Tom Foote, said. He declined to elaborate.

title: Review/Dance; Adding Song And Speech To Motion
description: It is hard to imagine a more varied program than the one presented on Friday night at the Dia Center for the Arts in SoHo. "The Haunted House," choreographed by David Dinolfo and accompanied by words and music rendered on tape by Diamanda Galas, Max Steiner and Walter Schumann, suggested love and the threat of loss, remembrance of love and even the complexities of lives necessarily lived in secret from the larger world. Mr. Dinolfo made quietly inventive use of the sometimes amorphous-seeming Dia stage space, with assistance from Mark London, who painted the stage with light. Mr. Dinolfo was all jagged acerbicism. Christopher Hawks was his fluent, softly resilient opposite.

title: Delayed Honor    Shattered glass caused a brief delay in the City Hall ceremony marking yesterday as Lou Carnesecca Day. The framed proclamation honoring the St. John's basketball coach was knocked off the easel by a Councilman jockeying to get into a photographer's picture. Carnesecca this month became the 30th major-college coach in N.C.A.A. history to win 500 career games.
description: The Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, gave the coach the proclamation after a quick replacement of the glass.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The only female correspondent on "60 Minutes" is leaving the show.

title: Boondoggle
description: Calvin Trillin, the writer frequently called a humorist because there is no more precise term for a man who disembowels pomp with such a good-natured sword, has announced that he has sworn off Dan Quayle. Given the fact that children bring Dan Quayle stories home from school along with knock-knock jokes, and bartenders proffer them with bowls of beer nuts, Mr. Trillin has decided that the Vice President is just too obvious to be taken humorously.

title: Carl Hartdegen 2d, Geophysicist, 72
description: Carl Hartdegen 2d, an official of the Palisades Geophysical Institute, died on Feb. 18 at the Cape Canaveral (Fla.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Cape Canaveral.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.

title: Steady as You Sit
description: To The Home Section:

title: New York Philharmonic Cancels Trip To Europe
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that it had canceled its European tour. The orchestra and its music director, Zubin Mehta, were to open the new Lucerne (Switzerland) Easter Festival March 30 to April 1, and were to play in Amsterdam on April 2 and in Brussels on April 3.

title: Key Rates
Tops Markets Chain Is Sold
description: The investment banking firm Freeman Spogli & Company said today that it had agreed to sell Tops Markets Inc., a food retailing company in Buffalo, to Koninklijke Ahold N.V., a food retailer in the Netherlands.

title: No Leading Contender Yet In Sale Of Islanders
description: A month ago, John O. Pickett Jr. said he had no intention of selling the Islanders.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: FIGHTING THE FIRES Companies hired to put out fires in Kuwait's oilfields are faced with complicated desert conditions and a lack of firefighters, as well as possible booby traps. Business Day, page D1.

title: NCR Amends Bylaws To Expand Board Size
description: The NCR Corporation has amended its corporate bylaws to allow the company to increase the size of its board to 20 members and to appoint one of the new members acting chairman. The move appears intended to foil an attempt by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to remove Charles E. Exley Jr., NCR's chairman and chief executive, from the board.

title: Fugitive Is Undone by His Own Fleet Feet, Princeton Says
description: He seemed to be like other college students, tall and thin, running in track meets and earning money by holding the first-down marker at football games. But even he acknowledged that his background was unusual. He claimed to be a self-educated ranch hand with a mother dying of leukemia in Switzerland.

title: Nathan Ehrlich, Union Official, 87
description: Nathan Ehrlich, a retired bakers' union official, died on Friday at the Eisenhower Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old and lived in Palm Desert, Calif.

title: IRAQ ELITE ROUTED, U.S. SOLDIERS SAY
description: American troops described a ferocious armored battle between the United States and troops of Iraq's Republican Guards that resulted, they said in interviews tonight, in devastating losses for the Iraqis and a torrent of thousands of battle-weary Iraqi prisoners of war.

title: Lawrence Terry, Headmaster, 91
description: Lawrence Terry, the headmaster of the Middlesex School in Concord, Mass., for a quarter-century, died Friday at the Apple Valley Continuing Care Center in Ayer, Mass. He was 91 years old and lived in Harvard, Mass.

title: People
description: * Craig Mason Barnard and Charles D. Schreck have been named vice presidents of Leo Burnett Co., Chicago. * Steven Sonnenfeld has been named associate media director and David Eldredge has been named vice president-management supervisor for public relations at Lord, Dentsu & Partners, New York.

title: Etan Manasse, Graphics Designer, 48
description: Etan Manasse, a New York industrial and graphics designer, died last Thursday. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan and New Hope, Pa.

title: 2d Prospective Buyer Invited to Daily News Talks
description: Talks between The Daily News and a prospective buyer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, reached an impasse yesterday, and The News's owner invited a second prospective buyer, the British publisher Robert Maxwell, to begin talks today about a possible sale of the paper.

title: CBS Wins Ratings Race
description: In a turnabout that reflected the changing fortunes of two networks, CBS won its first rating sweep period competition since February 1985 andNBC lost its first since then.

title: Business Summit Maps a New Era For L.I. Economy
description: A Moscow summit planned for earlier this month was canceled, but one was convened in Woodbury, L.I., that represented a potential victory for collective security and a triumph over balkanization.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the landmark designation of the Manhattan house where Antonin Dvorak wrote the symphony "From the New World" misidentified the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Prague. He is Frantisek Cardinal Tomasek.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR most children, spending time alone at home is something to be proud of. It is a confirmation that they are growing up and that their parents trust them. Being allowed to care for yourself is an emotionally significant and memorable step toward adulthood.

title: A Fantasy Life, Outlined in Detail
description: HE sketches -- quite nicely, thank you. He exercises at home. He quotes famous literary figures; Nietzsche is a favorite. And yes, he lives in New York, at least part of the year. "He's a European businessman with an American sensibility," said Laurie Palma, vice president of fragrance marketing for Chanel.

title: Replacing Belichick Is a No-Win Mission
description: Al Groh has been a football coach for 25 years. And now he is in an almost no-win situation.

title: An Absent Terreri Proves His Value
description: Chris Terreri's value to the Devils was exemplified tonight in a humiliating 7-3 loss to the lowly Maple Leafs, who are in such disarray they have used 43 players this season.

title: Cuomo Visits Ailing Health Commissioner
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo flew to Washington today to visit his ailing Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, and later confirmed that Dr. Axelrod had suffered a stroke. He also said at a news conference that Dr. Axelrod had undergone surgery, but declined to describe the operation.

title: K N Energy Selling Its Coal Operations
description: K N Energy Inc., a natural-gas supplier, said it would leave the coal business and absorb a loss when it sells two coal units to a Montana company for about $20 million. K N Energy, based in Lakewood, Colo., said it expected to sign an agreement this week with Entech Inc., a unit of the Montana Power Company, subject to conditions. The sale is to be closed by April 1.

title: Gotham to Europe: Take Us, Please Barry M. Fox is a lawyer specializing in international mergers and finance.
description: New York City could profit from a variation on a wry slogan of the 1960's: "New York Out of U.S."

title: What Bryce Really Said of Presidents; A Day for Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: NatWest Warning To Troubled Units
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said it had given its troubled securities firm one to two years to improve its performance before its future is reappraised and had given its money-losing American banking operation a bit longer. NatWest's chairman, Lord Alexander, suggested the units might be sold off if their performances did not improve in line with other operations.

title: Talking Deals; Swedish Empire Tightens Control
description: THE Wallenberg family's offer this week to pay $2.27 billion for the balance of Saab- Scania A.B. is only its latest move to retain power as Sweden prepares to open itself to foreign investment.

title: A Slow Night Out for Some
description: City Hall's effort to entice New Yorkers to a night on the town Tuesday with offers of discounts on restaurant meals and concert and theater tickets was a plum for many merchants.

title: INSIDE
description: Condom Plan Approved The New York City Board of Education narrowly approved a plan to make condoms available to the city's 250,000 high school students. Page B1. New Rival to Phone Industry Three cable television companies plan to build experimental networks that would alow people to use very small wireless telephones. Page D1.

title: Improvisations; Wine Storage Made Easy
description: WINE lovers with small collections that are too large for a tiny rack but not important enough to require a refrigerated cellar need not despair. Storage systems are available to avert the eyesore of protruding bottles or the hazards of guests' tripping over them.

title: Gorbachev On Offensive
description: His politics under fierce attack at home and abroad, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has opened a fiery counteroffensive, accusing his political foes of waging a struggle for power that could lead to civil war and warning the world outside to mind its own business.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Robert Hall, a designer of warplanes, misidentified one of his designs. It was the F-6F Hellcat, not the F-5F.

title: Ethics Unit Singles Out Cranston, Chides 4 Others in S.& L. Inquiry
description: Seeking to set standards for the way lawmakers raise money and do favors, the Senate Ethics Committee concluded today that Senator Alan Cranston engaged in "an impermissible pattern of conduct" that might warrant disciplinary action by the full Senate.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Up 0.4% on Nasdaq
description: The association also said that 42.4 million shares were in a short position as of mid-February in 1,203 less active over-the-counter securities that are traded in its automated quotation system but not in the national market system. That represented an increase of more than 39 percent above the 30.4 million shares in a short position in the January period, when 1,122 securities were involved.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a snowfall in the New York region misidentified the bridge shown in Central Park. It was the Gapstow Bridge at the Pond, not the Bow Bridge at the Lake.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Dallas County, Tex., is offering $27 million in triple-A rated tax-exempt road refunding and permanent improvement refunding bonds through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Yields range from 5 percent in 1993 to about 6.678 percent in 2006, including a zero-coupon bond due in 2002, which yields 6.60 percent if held to maturity. The zero-coupon bond is priced at $476.22 for each $1,000 of bonds. * Hertz Corp., Park Ridge, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $800 million in debt securities.

title: TV Specialist Named President of the N.F.L.
description: The National Football League has chosen Neil Austrian, an expert in cable television, marketing, investing and advertising, to fill the new post of league president.

title: Isaac Stern to Perform In 2 Boroughs in March
description: The violinist Isaac Stern will appear in recital in Brooklyn and Manhattan next month. At 2 P.M. Sunday he will be at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Broklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, in the Flatbush section. On the program are works by Mozart, Brahms, Schumann, Bartok and Karol Szymanowski. Tickets are $17 to $25. Information: (718) 434-2222.

title: Brady's Banking Priorities
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady today indicated that the Bush Administration was willing to compromise by undertaking only part of its plan to overhaul the banking system this year.

title: Suspension Reported
description: Jim Doehring, the 1990 United States champion and the world's third-ranked shot-putter last year, has been suspended by The Athletics Congress for two years after failing a doping test, a United States track and field source told Reuters yesterday.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Outnumbered and Outgunned, Allied Forces Outfox Hussein
description: Outnumbered in combat troops, tanks and artillery, the United States and its allies relied on deception, mobility and overwhelming air superiority to defeat the Iraqi military.

title: Yields of Money Funds Are Down Again
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell during the week ended yesterday. A decline over several weeks has lowered the average yield about three-quarters of a percentage point.

title: Tactics in the Annual Campaign for Oscars
description: On Sunset Boulevard, huge billboards proclaim that "Goodfellas" has been nominated for six Academy Awards and "Awakenings" for three. At home, the nearly 5,000 performers, technicians and executives who actually select the Oscar winners have once again been besieged with promotional brochures, videocassettes and screening and party invitations, all submitted "for your consideration."

title: New Gift Ideas Focus On Earth and Nation
description: TWO themes -- patriotism and ecology -- dominated this week's New York International Gift Fair, which closes today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Penn State Moves In
description: Penn State's football team will be fully admitted into the Big Ten by 1993, a schedule sought by the team's coach, Joe Paterno, and the university's president.

title: Phone Numbers for Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf.

title: Japanese Buy Savoy Label
description: Extending Japan's shopping for American cultural assets, the Nippon Columbia Company bought the Savoy jazz record label this week from the New York-based Muse Records.

title: Eugene H. Nellen, Professor, 64
description: Dr. Eugene H. Nellen, a member of the College of Staten Island faculty from 1969 until this year, died on Saturday at the Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus. He was 64 years old and had lived in Greendell, N.J., until moving recently to Parkersburg, W. Va.

title: Calendar: A Benefit and Shop Safety
description: Benefit Auction Sotheby's, 1334 York Avenue (72d Street); (212) 337-3519.

title: Excerpts of Statement By Senate Ethics Panel
description: Following are excerpts from the statement today of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics concluding its hearings involving Senators Alan Cranston, Dennis DeConcini, John Glenn, John McCain and Donald W. Riegle Jr.: Introduction

title: Dow Ahead 24.51 in Hectic Trading
description: Stocks gyrated in hectic trading yesterday but ended the day with a strong gain after an earlier rally was wiped out.

title: Reviews/Music; John Cage's Musical Noises And Ruminative Silences
description: John Cage's long career as a composer might be described in two culinary phases. Until the early 1950's, Mr. Cage was both chef and server, cooking, arranging and setting his musical dishes in front of us. We admired with our eyes and noses and then devoured them.

title: USF&G Posts $610 Million Quarterly Loss
description: The insurance giant, the USF&G Corporation, said yesterday that it would cut its stock dividend for the second time in three months and sell off secondary businesses following a $610 million loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Daley Breaks His Father's Record in Winning Primary in Chicago
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley easily won the Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday with the kind of gaping margin of victory reminiscent of the days when his father, the longtime Mayor and Democratic boss, Richard J. Daley, ruled Chicago politics.

title: Bids Urged For Channels
description: An agency of the Commerce Department today proposed selling most commercial broadcast channels to the highest bidder.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Royal Family; Kuwait's Joy Tempered By Rift Over Absolutism
description: Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait, is poised to return to his homeland after almost seven months of Iraqi occupation. But how much power the Sabah family should have and how they should rule are already in fierce dispute.

title: Slim Gaillard, 74, a Jazz Pianist And Composer of 30's Hit Songs
description: Slim Gaillard, an innovative jazz musician and composer whose best-known songs include "Flat Foot Floogie," "Tutti Frutti" and "Cement Mixer," died on Tuesday at University College Hospital in London. He was 74 years old.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today in all boroughs except Manhattan.

title: Gray Flannels or Not, John Major Is Riding the Crest of Popularity in Britain
description: Prime Minister John Major has had what the British call "a good war."

title: Report Says Mercenaries Aided Colombian Cartels
description: Groups of British and Israeli mercenaries provided paramilitary assistance to Colombian drug-trafficking organizations in 1988 and 1989, according to a Senate staff study and testimony presented today to a Senate panel.

title: Two Clubs Drop Events Over Minority-Group Rules
description: Two private golf clubs have decided to drop out as hosts of future United States Golf Association amateur events rather than conform to the association's recent anti-discrimination membership guidelines.

title: Eviction Law Assists in Fight Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Gerber Moves Account To Grey Advertising
description: The Gerber Products Company said yesterday that it had awarded its worldwide food and general-merchandise advertising account to Grey Advertising Inc., New York. The account represents $15 million to $20 million in billings.

title: Home Resales Drop by 7%
description: Sales of existing homes dropped 7 percent in January as prospective buyers became preoccupied with the Persian Gulf war despite favorable financing conditions, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Biden Says He'll Back Bush Drug Nominee
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he would vote for confirmation of former Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida, President Bush's nominee to be Director of National Drug Control Policy.

title: Cetus Upheld On Rights To Patents
description: In a big victory for the Cetus Corporation, a Federal District Court jury here today upheld the company's patents on a key gene technology. The verdict came in a suit filed against the struggling biotechnology concern by the Du Pont Company, which sought to invalidate the patents on the basis that early work at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology anticipated Cetus's invention.

title: Kelly Among the Missing
description: Pascual Perez still hasn't arrived in camp, but now the Yankees have someone else to fret over: Roberto Kelly.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Battlefield Overcoming the Iraqi Fighters, Plus Minefields and Weather; In a Desert of Buried Terror, Only One Dirt Track Is Safe
description: A convoy of light armored vehicles sat in the desert with their engines idling just outside Kuwait City.

title: McCall's Gets New Editor, Ex-Working Woman Chief
description: McCall's magazine named Kate White as its new editor in chief yesterday, replacing Anne Mollegen Smith, who has held the post since 1989. Ms. White joins McCall's from Working Woman, where she has been editor in chief since October 1989.

title: Panel Votes to Use Pension Money For Raises for New York Workers
description: The trustees of New York City's main employee pension system voted yesterday to approve a proposal that would let the city help finance raises for 150,000 municipal workers. But the move would not produce enough money to pay for the eventual cost of such raises, if they were also given to other workers covered by the system.

title: Bridge
description: One of the many delightful characters created by P. G. Wodehouse, Psmith, used to remind his friends "not to confuse the improbable with the impossible." North may have echoed this sentiment after the diagramed deal, played last weekend in Toronto.

title: Personal Health
description: Every few weeks, it seems, the sudden death of a young athlete during or just after a sporting event makes the headlines. A year ago it was Hank Gathers, the basketball star at Loyola Marymount in Los Angeles who collapsed and died in a conference championship game. Ten days ago a 15-year-old Bronx high school girl, Stephanie Companion, collapsed and later died after running in a track and field championship race. And last Sunday, a Yale sophomore from Ainsworth, Neb., Bryent Wilkins, 19, died suddenly while playing intramural basketball.

title: School Board Approves Plan For Condoms
description: In a dramatic and emotional session, the New York City Board of Education last night narrowly approved a plan to make condoms available on request to the city's 250,000 high-school students.

title: Leipzig, the City of Bach, Falls on Hard Times
description: The churches here run several hospitals, but Johannes Richter, pastor of the renowned Thomaskirche, the workplace of Johann Sebastian Bach, says he has "no idea how to finance them in the future."

title: Tourists Stay Home, Blighting the Caribbean
description: As a glance down any of the nearly empty beaches here attests, these are difficult times for the islands of the Caribbean.

title: For AIDS Patients, a Caring Place
description: "THE idea was to treat people who can't afford private care in a full-service office with a humane atmosphere," said Anthony Mallen, a designer who recently completed the decoration of a 7,000-square-foot AIDS treatment center at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Women Among War Dead
description: At least three women were reported to be among the 28 American soldiers who were killed in an Iraqi missile attack on Tuesday. Page A13.

title: Review/Theater; Akalaitis's 'Henry IV,' Parts 1 and 2, at the Public
description: Kenneth Tynan famously described the two parts of "Henry IV" as "the twin summits of Shakespeare's achievement." The first good news about JoAnne Akalaitis's New York Shakespeare Festival production of both plays is that she hasn't turned them into "Twin Peaks."

title: Negro Ensemble Theater
description: "The Little Tommy Parker Celebrated Colored Minstrel Show," a play about black performers at the turn of the century, is to open the 24th season of the Negro Ensemble Company today at the Master Theater, 310 Riverside Drive, at West 103d Street. The play was written by Carlyle Brown and directed by Douglas Turner Ward, the artistic director of the ensemble. Performances run through Mar. 31. Information: (212) 663-8170.

title: Topics of The Times; The Gastronomical She
description: Calling M.F.K. Fisher, who has just been elected to the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters, a food writer is a lot like calling Mozart a tunesmith. At the same time that she is celebrating, say, oysters (which lead, she says, "a dreadful but exciting life") or the scent of orange segments drying on a radiator, she is also celebrating life and loneliness, sense and sensibility.

title: Girl, 17, Is Accosted By a Man Suspected In Rapes in Queens
description: An armed man suspected in a series of rapes apparently attacked and robbed a 17-year-old girl in Queens on Tuesday night but was frightened away before sexually assaulting her, the police said yesterday.

title: For Once, Winfield Can Enjoy Spring
description: Dave Winfield talked and looked like a rookie. First, he arrived later than he wanted for his first day of spring training because he underestimated the distance he was staying from the California Angels' camp. Then, after he went out to the field with the rest of the team, he came running back to the clubhouse.

title: Review/Music; Vienna Philharmonic Plays Hometown Works
description: The Vienna Philharmonic is making an even grander statement than usual for its 1991 Carnegie Hall visit, part of the hall's centennial season, with five concerts that will culminate Sunday afternoon in a semi-staged performance of Richard Strauss's "Elektra."

title: South Dakota Senate Rejects Abortion Restrictions
description: By a single vote, the South Dakota Senate on Tuesday rejected what would have been one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the nation.

title: Fleeing Violence, Peruvians Fall Into Poverty
description: The Santa Rosa communal kitchen in Monte Negro, a poor Lima neighborhood occupied by people who have fled violence in the Peruvian highlands, is a hub of activity every day. Some 30 women, dressed in traditional Peruvian colors and carrying their infants on their backs, feed themselves, their families and the community's orphans.

title: Let's Protect Parks From the Exploiters
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Hits A Winner In Overtime
description: A Connecticut team that until recently was still seeking its most effective combination, and a state full of fans in search of rivaling the happiness of last winter, each took an important step forward tonight.

title: 2 Arrested in S.& L. Case
description: A former executive with the Columbia Savings and Loan Association was arrested today and charged with taking kickbacks of $1.5 million from a businessman who sold lease packages to the savings association for $166 million.

title: New Beginning Pledged for Arizona
description: Arizonans have elected a governor for the first time since the impeachment of Evan Mecham three years ago, but most attention here remains focused on allegations of bribery involving a number of state legislators.

title: The Job of Fighting Kuwait's Infernos
description: The companies hired by the Kuwaitis to extinguish the oilfield fires set by Iraqi forces are faced with complicated desert conditions, a lack of firefighters and appropriate equipment as well as the booby traps and mines that the Iraqis left behind.

title: What Bryce Really Said of Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Ridding an Antique of Unpleasant Odors
description: As a professional furniture restorer, I am sometimes asked not only to restore the outside of a chest of drawers, but also to "remove that smell" from the inside.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Allies Destroy Iraqis' Main Force; Kuwait Is Retaken After 7 Months
description: Hours before President Bush announced the conditional suspension of offensive military operations in the Persian Gulf, allied armored units trapped Iraq's vaunted Republican Guard and cut it to pieces in a ferocious tank battle that began Wednesday and raged until early this morning, American officials said.

title: Slain Leader's Widow Leads in Bangladesh Vote
description: Khaled Zia, the widow of an assassinated President, held a strong lead this morning with the results of two-thirds of the contests in a parliamentary election unofficially declared.

title: A Kuwaiti Named 'Chris'
description: As this city celebrated the end of Iraqi occupation, Nura Dhubia, a new mother, raced through the crowds today looking for the first American she could find.

title: Suddenly, Darling Matters Again
description: The exploratory surgery on Ron Darling's right elbow produced a considerable catalogue of discovery. What Darling and the doctors found out was that the extent of the damage was great, the collection of bone chips sizable. For the Mets, what was found in Darling's elbow made them reconsider what he actually possessed in his heart.

title: Books of The Times; An Advocate of Legalizing Drugs
description: The Case for Legalizing Drugs By Richard Lawrence Miller 247 pages. Praeger Publishers. $21.95.

title: The Giant Who Hired A Midget
description: After his father sold the White Sox in 1980, Michael Veeck was out of baseball for 10 years. He said he once made an inquiry about a baseball job, only to be told, "Veeck is not a good name for getting a job."

title: Jackson Considers Appealing Suspension
description: The National Basketball Players Association is planning further steps to appeal the four-day suspension of Mark Jackson, the Knicks' point guard.

title: Tel Aviv Stock Move
description: The Bank of Israel said on Tuesday that it would permit foreign companies to issue stocks and bonds on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. But the amount of money a foreign concern could take out of the country would be limited to 20 percent of any new issue. Previously the central bank had turned down applications by foreign firms to issue shares on the stock market. The change of policy "will make the Israeli stock market more international," said Gideon Schurr, speaking for the Bank of Israel."Now we need local investments, not Israeli investments abroad."

title: Polish Get German Aid
description: The German Government has guaranteed an $80 million loan to Poland's second-largest steel mill to enable it to modernize and reduce pollution, the Polish news agency P.A.P. reported today. The loan will allow construction of a continuous steel pouring line at the Tadeusz Sendzimir steelworks at Nowa Huta, outside Krakow, in southern Poland. Construction of the pouring line will permit the steelworks to close the last three open hearth furnaces, a big source of environmental pollution, and save $90 million in annual energy costs, P.A.P. reported.

title: Leningrad Journal; Never Mind Bolsheviks, The Memory Speaks!
description: "Tell me something spicy about Vladimir Nabokov," said Galina Kleshnova, a bureaucrat lazing like a butterfly in the great emigre novelist's boyhood bedroom.

title: Martha Christine Eber, Deaconess, 91
description: Sister Martha Christine Eber, a Lutheran deaconess, died on Tuesday at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ah, Subway Memories!
description: EVER wonder what happened to all those old subway tokens?

title: Chief Executive Shift Set at Bayer USA in July
description: Bayer A.G., which has a $5.9 billion business in the United States selling many things, but not Bayer aspirin, chose a new president and chief executive yesterday to head Bayer USA Inc.

title: Inquiry Sought on Drug Tests That Exclude Women
description: A Congressional group concerned with issues affecting women called today for an investigation of drug evaluation policies that exclude women as research participants.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Monday about a concert by the Cleveland Orchestra at Carnegie Hall misidentified the trombone soloist in Saturday's performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's "Russian Easter" Overture. He was Allen Kofsky, not Richard Solis.

title: Here, Occupying Troops Are Armed With Pencils
description: For Arab merchants in Brooklyn, the rout of the Iraqi Army has raised hopes for victory on their own turf: the liberation of Atlantic Avenue.

title: Brand Officer Quits Burger King
description: Gary L. Langstaff, the Burger King executive who oversaw the development of the slogan "Sometimes you've gotta break the rules," resigned yesterday, as the company and its advertising agencies weighed whether to replace the slogan.

title: G.N.P. Rate Off a Revised 2%; Signs of a Mild Slump Seen
