description: In a report that tended to support the idea that the recession would be relatively short and shallow, the Commerce Department today revised its estimate of economic activity in the final quarter of 1990, showing that the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 2 percent.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Leader; Hussein's Errors: Complex Impulses
description: Behind President Saddam Hussein's humiliating defeat in Kuwait is a simple question with a complicated answer: How could the Iraqi leader have so badly miscalculated the political will and the military power of his enemy?

title: Corrections
description: The Active Stocks table in Business Day on Monday misstated two percentage changes in the stock price of the Pall Corporation. Adjusted for a 3-for-2 split that took effect last week, the price declined four-tenths of 1 percent last week on the American Stock Exchange and it has risen 33.4 percent so far this year.

title: Company Ousts Gay Workers, Then Reconsiders
description: The sign on the door of the Cracker Barrel Country Store and Restaurant said, "Now Hiring," and added that the company was a place that "gives you everything you need to cook up a great future."

title: S.E.C. Charges L.I. Brokerage
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had filed a complaint accusing Nicodemus E. Faitos and his firm, Faitos & Company, a Long Island brokerage, with stealing at least $1.8 million from its customers.

title: Society Looks Askance At the Family of One
description: THEY don't all say it in the same way.

title: A Home on the Range? No, the Range at Home
description: PARTNERS for the past five years, Cheryl Troxel and Jeffrey Nablo of Key West, Fla., have moved from designing custom-made kitchens into designing furniture. "Things that are festive and fun" is the way Ms. Troxel described the first collection of their company, 21st Century Primitive . The eight pieces cost from $450 to $2,000.

title: S.E.C. Chief Backs a Change in Bank Data
description: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that the S.E.C. favored some recently proposed changes in the way banks account for troubled loans.

title: Putting One's Best Blossoms Forward
description: THE blue ribbon beckons. This is flower show time, and home gardeners are preening their treasured species for a moment of public glory. From New York to San Francisco, ferns and fuchsias are being bathed in special soap, fed with special fertilizer and scrutinized daily for insects or a hint of disease.

title: Jean Rogers, Actress, 74
description: Jean Rogers, who co-starred in two "Flash Gordon" adventures and other serial films, died on Sunday. She was 74 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A6-13

title: Report of Cutbacks Is Denied by P.& G.
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said it was seeking to control costs to weather the recession but denied a report that said the company was cutting development and marketing budgets because of sluggish sales. The Wall Street Journal, in a report attributed to unidentified sources, said today that P.& G.'s chief executive, Edwin L. Artzt, had been telling managers to concentrate on their most important projects and to discard the rest.

title: Today the Villain of Purim, Haman, Is Spelled Saddam
description: Purim, a joyous Jewish festival that has a touch of the Mardi Gras spirit, is being celebrated today with new fervor and humor as Jews draw parallels between Haman, the villain of the ancient holiday, and Saddam Hussein.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "At midnight tonight, Eastern Standard Time, exactly 100 hours since ground operations commenced and six weeks since the start of Operation Desert Storm, all United States and coalition forces will suspend offensive combat operations." -- President Bush. [ A12:2. ]

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Advances in Chicago Top-seeded John McEnroe relied largely on his passing shots last night to beat India's Ramesh Krishnan, 7-5, 6-3, in a second-round match at the Volvo tournament in Chicago. McEnroe next will face unseeded Alexander Mronz of Germany, a 7-6, 6-3, upset winner over eighth-seeded Gary Muller of South Africa in a quarterfinal match tomorrow. Against Krishnan, McEnroe displayed a steady ground game, forcing his opponent to knock several returns over the end line. McEnroe, serving as fast as 116 miles an hour, recorded 11 aces and seven service winners. (AP) Lendl Rolls in Rotterdam: Ivan Lendl trounced Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-1, last night to advance to the second round of the ABN Amro indoor tournament at Rotterdam, the Netherlands. In another first-round match, Jan Siemerink defeated a fellow Dutchman, Mark Koevermans, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2. Lendl, the third-ranked player in the world, is one of the last major players still in the tournament, with third-seeded Emilio Sanchez knocked out by Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, in the second round. (AP)

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Postwar Politics; Kuwait Says Borders Disputed By Hussein Are Not Negotiable
description: Kuwait's foreign minister was quoted today as saying that his country would never negotiate border and oil-rights claims with Iraq, even if President Saddam Hussein were forced from power.

title: Cable TV In Phone Challenge
description: Local telephone companies may face formidable new competition within the next few years from the cable television industry.

title: United Engines Gears Up For Fire Equipment Orders
description: With Kuwait's oilfields ablaze and fires at some wells likely to burn for years, welders, mechanics and managers at the United Engines Inc. plant in Oklahoma City are working on two shifts to quickly produce the special equipment needed to fight the fires.

title: Alzheimer's Disease: Dangers and Trials of Denial
description: Alzheimer's disease is the fourth leading cause of death in this country. An estimated four million Americans have the disease and one family in three is touched by it. Yet Alzheimer's disease almost never appears in obituaries or even on death certificates. The disease, experts say, is one of the few that still carries such a stigma that families and patients often refuse to acknowledge it or call it by name.

title: San Francisco Journal; End of Road for Unpopular Highway
description: It may have come just in the nick of time. Waiting for the hated Embarcadero Freeway, severely damaged in the October 1989 earthquake, to come down has been an exercise in frustration that threatened to make urban terrorists out of couch potatoes.

title: New York State Agency Financing
description: A $241.7 million financing by the New York State Urban Development Corporation was priced yesterday for offering to the public with a maximum yield of 7.95 percent for a 7.5 percent bond due in 2011 at a price of about 95.515.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Black G.I.'s; Powell to Study Complaints By Harlem Unit in Gulf War
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will investigate allegations by members of a Harlem National Guard unit that they were placed into a combat situation in the Persian Gulf without proper training and not treated with respect by regular army forces, Representative Charles B. Rangel says.

title: Profit Posted By Ann Taylor
description: Ann Taylor Stores, the New York-based fashion chain of 174 stores, said yesterday that it had earnings of more than $1 million in the year ended Jan. 31, in contrast to a net loss of $11.2 million the year before. Revenues rose 16.1 percent, to $411 million, and same-store sales were up 5.1 percent.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SINGLE-HANDLE cartridge faucets, the kind found in many newer kitchens and bathrooms, are relatively easy to fix, since they have only one main internal component: a cylindrical metal or nylon cartridge.

title: War in the Gulf: Bush Halts Offensive Combat; Kuwait Freed, Iraqis Crushed
description: WASHINGTON--Declaring that "Kuwait is liberated" and Iraq's army defeated, President Bush ordered allied forces on Wednesday night to suspend offensive military operations against President Saddam Hussein's isolated and battered army.

title: Savings Bailout Delay Seen Without New Funds
description: Senior regulators said today that the Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry would stall if Congress and the Administration failed to reach agreement by next week on new financing for the effort.

title: Events: Garden Design
description: Gardens: The Country Place Era Paine Webber Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (51st Street); (800) 777-7931.

title: Finishing Touches for Needlepoint
description: DURING the last five years interest in needlepoint has grown. And with the growing number of people doing needlepoint has come an increased demand for people who will put the finishing touches on completed canvases, making them into pillows, eyeglass cases, footstools, wall hangings, rugs, even backgammon boards.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: G.I. Benefits; Senate Panel Supports Proposals For More Tax Breaks for Troops
description: Members of the Senate Finance Committee voiced support today for additional tax relief and other economic benefits for military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf war but ran into some skepticism from the Bush Administration.

title: Man's Best Provider
description: To The Home Section:

title: Judge Orders Homeless Aid In New York
description: A judge yesterday ordered New York City to provide stable housing and outpatient services for thousands of homeless mental patients discharged from city hospitals, in effect forcing the city to expand an existing agreement.

title: M.T.A. Commuter Lines May Escape Fare Increase
description: Under heavy pressure from suburban lawmakers, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said today that they might keep fares on commuter rail lines unchanged this year even as they seek increases in New York City's subway fare of a dime or more.

title: Nursing Home in Their Future
description: Nearly half of all the people who turned 65 years of age in 1990 will spend some time in a nursing home, a new study estimates. And the longer they live the more likely it becomes that there is a nursing home in their future.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Torture; Freed Kuwaitis Tell of Iraqi Abuse Including Some Cases of Torture
description: On the third floor of a gutted mansion, a Kuwaiti Army major slowly pushed open a door with his foot to what was once a laundry room. It had been converted by the Iraqis, he said, into a torture chamber.

title: Senate Panel Derails Bill on Puerto Rico Referendum
description: A Senate panel today derailed, and possibly killed, a bill to authorize a referendum that would enable Puerto Rico to choose its political future.

title: Alan T. Schumacher, Investment Banker, 78
description: Alan T. Schumacher, a retired investment banker, died on Sunday at his home in Newport, R.I. He was 78 years old.

title: New Report Complicates Dispute Over Who Isolated AIDS Virus
description: The mystery of who first isolated the AIDS virus has deepened with a report that virus samples that might have answered the question do not resemble those from either of the two laboratories involved.

title: Accounts
description: * Spalding Pro Racquet Sports, a division of Spalding Sports Worldwide, to Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md.

title: Bolar Plans Guilty Plea On Generics
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said yesterday that it would plead guilty to charges of illegally distributing adulterated generic drugs and obstructing Government inquiries. The company also said it would pay $10 million in fines in connection with the 20 criminal charges brought Tuesday by the Justice Department.

title: The Bush Budget Cares About Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcella Markham, Featured Actress, 68
description: Marcella Markham, a Brooklyn-born actress who had stage and television careers in New York and London, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 68 years old and had homes in both cities.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Monday about the marriage of Debra Eve Spier to Baruch Y. Prince misidentified the bride's stepmother and misstated the bridegroom's mother's position. The stepmother is Radine Spier. The bridegroom's mother, Judith Prince, is an administrative secretary at the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Ticketmaster Deal To Get Ticketron
description: The Ticketmaster Corporation said it would acquire Ticketron, its rival computerized ticketing agency. The Los Angeles-based Ticketmaster did not disclose terms of the deal for Ticketron, which is owned by the Carlyle Group, a Washington investment group, and is based in Landover, Md. Both companies are private.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: United Nations; Allies Wary of Overture By Iraqis on Cease-Fire
description: The United States and its coalition partners resisted demands today from the Soviet Union and Iraq for a Security Council resolution calling for a permanent cease-fire to bring a formal end to the Persian Gulf war.

title: Tin Soldiers Need Not Apply
description: SO far, paper has been her exclusive medium, and tin toys, postcards, matchbook covers and antique labels and textiles her inspirations.

title: U.S. Survey Finds Problems In 49% of Lens Implant Cases
description: Half the people in the United States with lens implants have problems with them, a Government survey has found. A quarter of the people with cardiac pacemakers also have trouble, as do a third of those with artificial joints, the survey says.

title: British Rates Cut Again
description: Britain shaved interest rates today for the second time in two weeks in an effort to help the economy out of a recession. The Bank of England said it was cutting its money market lending rate by half a percentage point, to 13 percent, a signal to commercial banks to cut their base lending rates. The Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major also cut rates by half a point on Feb. 13. The National Westminster Bank P.L.C., Britain's biggest bank, led others today in cutting base lending rates to 13 percent. The Halifax Building Society, the largest mortgage institution, cut its mortgage rate to 13.75 from 14.5 percent.

title: Diminishing Returns Ride Mass Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Mud Is the Strongest Enemy as the 101st Takes Central Iraq
description: The Black Hawk helicopters set down in the Euphrates River Valley on Monday night under a dark sky and lashing rain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Controversy may be catnip to GERALDO RIVERA on his television talk show, but he will strive for a tamer tone in his newest job: managing editor of The Two River Times. Mr. Rivera bought controlling interest in the New Jersey weekly yesterday.

title: Homecoming, Without Honors
description: With victory in the Persian Gulf, the nation is already looking forward to a boisterous welcome-home party. If all goes according to expectations, there will be bands, balloons, flags galore and miles of yellow ribbon testifying that this war, as President Bush so often promised, will not end like Vietnam.

title: Rangers Rally For a Tie
description: By the end of the night, both teams were playing at a fever pitch, both goalies were frazzled by their near-equal share in an 83-shot outing, and nobody managed to win the game.

title: A Glittery Opening for New Bendel Store
description: ON one floor of Henri Bendel's new store last night hung Isani's interpretations of the crisp "Jackie Kennedy" suits of the 1960's. On another floor, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis wore a beaded gold jacket over black chiffon as she shook hands on a receiving line.

title: Brain May Have Separate Units to Digest Writing and Speech
description: The human brain has separate systems for processing written and spoken language, a new study suggests.

title: Jerry Mason, 77, Dies; Editor and Publisher
description: Jerry Mason, who published the photographic book "The Family of Man" and who was known as an editor and publisher of innovative picture and text books, died on Feb. 20 in Vineyard Haven, Mass. He was 77 years old.
